site_title: Vietnam Airlines considers creating cargo unit to boost revenue
summary: Vietnam Airlines is considering creating a dedicated cargo unit to boost revenue, capitalizing on the country's growing manufacturing industry. With companies like Samsung Electronics and LG Electronics producing billions of dollars in devices, Vietnam Airlines expects a higher number of international passengers, especially from Japan and Korea. The airline forecasts serving 23.4 million passengers this year, up from 22 million in 2017, and aims to have 110 planes by 2020 and 150 by 2030.

site_title: Gig economy business model dealt a blow in California ruling
summary: The California Supreme Court ruled that companies can no longer classify workers as independent contractors, instead forcing them to follow minimum-wage and overtime laws, and pay benefits like workers' compensation and unemployment insurance. The ruling, which scrapped the existing test for determining employee status, could have sweeping consequences for companies like Uber, potentially upending their business models and requiring them to classify drivers and other gig workers as employees.

site_title: Oxley takes 10% stake in Malaysia's Aspen for S$23.3m
summary: Oxley Holdings acquired a 10.07% stake in Aspen Group in Malaysia for S$23.28 million, representing a 14.72% premium over Aspen's stock price. Aspen will use the funds to acquire land, develop properties, and work capital. Both companies may collaborate on joint ventures to develop projects in Malaysia or co-invest in regional projects, benefiting all parties involved.

site_title: UK's new interior minister promises immigration reforms after scandals
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May appointed Sajid Javid as the new interior minister, pledging to create a "fair and humane immigration" system amid controversy over deportation targets and the Windrush scandal. Javid, a second-generation immigrant, vowed to move beyond the scandal and adopt a new tone in the role, distancing himself from his predecessor Amber Rudd's "hostile environment" policy. Javid's appointment comes as the government faces criticism over its treatment of elderly immigrants from the Caribbean, and he is expected to address the issue in his first task.

site_title: Trump says Singapore among possible sites for meeting with Kim Jong Un
summary: US President Donald Trump said the demilitarized zone between North and South Korea could be a venue for his planned summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, but Singapore is also a possible site. Trump expressed interest in the DMZ Peace House, but acknowledged concerns about its appearance. He also praised North Korea's decision to close its main nuclear test site, calling it a "hopeful sign." However, Trump emphasized that North Korea must give up its nuclear weapons for the summit to be successful.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump said on Monday the demilitarised zone between North and South Korea would be an excellent venue for his planned summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, but that Singapore was also a possible site.

site_title: Panasonic fined US$280m by US in bribery scheme
summary: Panasonic has agreed to pay US$280 million in fines to settle charges related to a bribery scheme involving its aircraft electronics unit. The company paid US$875,000 to a government official to win business for its electronics unit, with the official providing little to no services in exchange. Panasonic Avionics was fined US$137.4 million by the Justice Department and US$143 million by the Securities and Exchange Commission for Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and accounting fraud violations. The company has taken steps to strengthen its compliance programs and internal controls.

images.alt_text: Panasonic will pay US$280 million in fines to settle charges over bribes to an employee at government-owned airline to win business for its aircraft electronics unit, US authorities announced Monday.

site_title: Australia home prices fall for seventh month, led by big cities
summary: Australia's property prices fell for a seventh consecutive month in April, with national prices dropping 0.1% and prices in Sydney and Melbourne declining 0.4% each month. This marks the first decline in the eight state and territory capitals since November 2012. The decline in prices is attributed to a cooling market in the nation's two largest cities, with values down 3.4% from a year earlier in Sydney.

site_title: Prices of completed condo, private flats 1% higher in March: NUS index
summary: The prices of completed private apartments and condominiums in Singapore rose 1% in March, according to the National University of Singapore's Singapore Residential Price Index. This marks a 0.5% increase from February, with the central region seeing a 0.1% rise and the non-central region experiencing a 1.6% increase. Prices for small units also rose 0.9% in March. The price increase follows a revised index value for February, which initially reported a 0.5% rise.

site_title: AMP chairwoman, legal counsel quit over scandal
summary: AMP, Australia's largest-listed wealth manager, has announced the resignations of its chairwoman and legal counsel, Catherine Brenner and Brian Salter, amid a scandal involving misconduct and deception. The exits follow CEO Craig Meller's early departure and a judicial inquiry's revelations of AMP misleading customers and deceiving regulators. The company has slashed directors' fees by 25% and is searching for a new CEO. Analysts expect more executives to leave, with a possible shareholder class action looming.

site_title: PUB to generate solar power from Bedok and Lower Seletar reservoirs
summary: PUB has called a tender for engineering studies on deploying floating solar PV systems in Bedok and Lower Seletar reservoirs. The project aims to generate solar power to meet the energy demands of the water loop, including raw water pumping, waterworks, and wastewater treatment. The study will assess the feasibility and potential benefits of this innovative approach to renewable energy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, May 1, 2018, during Japan's Golden Week holiday period, as investors awaited key earnings and economic data in the US. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index edged down 0.05% or 10.17 points to 22,457.7, while the Topix index fell 0.26% or 4.6 points to 1,772.63.

site_title: European shares end April on a high as Sainsbury/Asda merger shakes up retail
summary: European shares ended April with a 3.8% gain, the strongest monthly gain since 2016, as investors' risk appetite improved amid easing inter-Korea tensions. The Sainsbury's/Asda merger, creating Britain's largest supermarket group, contributed to the rally, with Sainsbury's shares rising 14.5%. The Stoxx index and DAX index also rose, with all eyes on the deal's potential to challenge Amazon's dominance in the UK.

site_title: Businesses are buying more renewable power than ever before
summary: Companies are buying renewable power at a record pace, with 36 businesses, government agencies, and universities agreeing to buy 3.3 gigawatts of wind and solar power so far this year. This is on track to surpass the previous high of 4.8 gigawatts of disclosed deals last year. Smaller companies are driving the growth, with AT&T and Walmart among the leading buyers. The surge in renewable power purchases is attributed to increasing comfort among smaller companies to invest in these deals.

site_title: Asian markets closed for holidays
summary: Asian financial markets closed on May 1, 2018, for public holidays in China, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, and Thailand. The article does not provide relevant information about this date as the provided news articles are from July 2025.

site_title: World's oldest known spider dies
summary: A 43-year-old spider, named Number 16, has died after being monitored for years in a long-term population study in Australia. The spider, a trapdoor matriarch, outlived the previous record holder, a 28-year-old tarantula found in Mexico. Number 16 was killed by a wasp sting, not old age. The study provided insights into the behavior and population dynamics of trapdoor spiders, which can be found across Australia. The research project, launched in 1974, helped scientists understand how climate change and deforestation may impact the species, which typically live between 5-20 years.

site_title: Oil gains after Netanyahu says Iran lied after signing nuclear deal
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday after Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Israel had proof that Iran lied about its nuclear capabilities. This statement boosted oil prices, with Brent June contract gaining 53 US cents to settle at $75.17 a barrel. US President Donald Trump has until May 12 to decide whether to restore sanctions on Iran, driving the uncertainty that affects oil prices.

site_title: Making public transport in Singapore more family-friendly
summary: An advisory panel in Singapore has recommended over 20 ideas to make public transport more family-friendly, including stroller restraints on buses and transportation apps to locate nursing rooms. The panel, co-chaired by Richard Magnus and Sitoh Yih Pin, gathered over 3,000 commuter feedback and submitted its recommendations to Senior Minister of State for Transport Lam Pin Min. The proposals include rear-door boarding of buses, stepless buses, and improved signage to guide parents to family-friendly facilities. The government has welcomed the report, calling it a "labour of love" and promising to work with transport operators to implement the changes.

site_title: Trump postpones decision on metals tariffs for Canada, EU, Mexico
summary: US President Donald Trump has postponed imposing steel and aluminum tariffs on Canada, the EU, and Mexico until June 1, and reached agreements for permanent exemptions with Argentina, Australia, and Brazil. Temporary exemptions for these countries were set to expire on May 1. The decision extends negotiations for 30 days, with the focus on quotas to restrain imports and protect national security. Canada and the EU have expressed concerns, with Canada's Prime Minister calling a tariff on Canadian steel "a very bad idea."

site_title: Fed likely to keep rates steady; investors bet on June hike
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates steady at its Wednesday meeting, despite rising inflation and low unemployment. Investors have largely priced out the chance of a rate hike, with many expecting a hike in June. The Fed has raised rates twice this year, and policymakers forecast two more increases. The economy's strong growth, fueled by tax cuts and fiscal stimulus, has pushed inflation near the Fed's 2% target, but policymakers are cautious about the impact of trade tensions and a slowing economy.

site_title: Philippine workers march in protest at short-term contracts
summary: Thousands of Philippine workers and activists marched in Manila on May Day, protesting President Rodrigo Duterte's failure to end short-term employment contracts, a campaign promise he made before his presidency. Despite his warnings to companies, the practice persists, particularly in the fast-food industry. Duterte initially denied journalists access to the presidential palace, where protesters burned his effigy. The march was part of a broader labor movement, with workers demanding higher wages, improved working conditions, and an end to labor-only contracting.

images.alt_text: Thousands of Philippine workers and activists marched in a May Day rally in Manila on Tuesday in protest against what they said was President Rodrigo Duterte's failure to keep a campaign promise to get rid of short-term employment contracts.

site_title: SPH Reit to acquire Rail Mall for S$63.24m
summary: SPH Reit has agreed to acquire The Rail Mall for S$63.24 million, funded by debt and internal resources. The mall, with 43 shop units and 95 carpark lots, will be acquired from Pulau Properties, owned by the Lee Foundation and Lee family members. The acquisition aims to complement SPH Reit's existing assets and strengthen its food and beverage offerings. The deal is expected to be completed on June 28, with the Reit manager expressing optimism about the property's potential to attract a wider catchment through community programs.

site_title: Why being loyal to your customer needs to come before brand loyalty
summary: Consumers are gaining the upper hand in retail, driving a shift in power from retailers to consumers. To succeed, brands must focus on providing a seamless customer experience, unified commerce, and personalized services. This includes offering inventory visibility, payment insights, and card tokenization to build loyalty. The rise of mobile wallets, such as WeChat Pay and Apple Pay, also enhances consumer convenience. As consumers become more discerning, unified, consumer-centric experiences will be vital for businesses to build brand loyalty and stay competitive in an increasingly crowded market.

site_title: Noble to adopt more conservative accounting practices
summary: NOBLE GROUP, a Singapore-based conglomerate, has announced plans to adopt more conservative accounting practices, aligning its profit and loss statement with cash flow. Chairman Paul Brough expressed optimism about reaching a consensus with bondholders and shareholders on restructuring, citing the need to address trade finance limitations. The company has faced criticism over aggressive accounting practices, but Brough emphasized the need to match cash flow with profit and loss accounts. A special general meeting approved the disposal of a vessel, and the company is working towards a consensual restructuring to avoid insolvency.

site_title: STI bounces back to pre-correction levels
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) bounced back to above 3,600, a position it hasn't held since the market correction early this year, gaining 36.72 points to 3,613.93. DBS Group Holdings led the upward charge, adding 2.8% to S$30.84 after posting a bumper first-quarter net profit. Meanwhile, Venture Corporation fell 2.1% to S$20.95, while off-index tech stocks like Serial System and Valuetronics rose. Analysts attribute the market's rebound to better-than-forecast US corporate earnings and a promising six-month business outlook.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Boeing to buy aircraft parts supplier KLX in US$4.25b deal
summary: Boeing is acquiring KLX Inc, an aircraft parts supplier, for $4.25 billion in an all-cash transaction. The deal includes $1 billion of net debt and will bolster Boeing's services division, which offers maintenance, spare parts, and other services to airlines. Boeing aims to triple sales at the division to $50 billion within a decade. The acquisition is part of Boeing's strategy to expand its services business and round out its product portfolio.

images.alt_text: Boeing Co is acquiring KLX Inc for US$4.25 billion in an all-cash transaction that includes US$1 billion of net debt, as the world's largest planemaker bolsters a fast-growing new division that offers maintenance, spare parts and other services to airlines.

site_title: Faltering voice, head down, Korean Air daughter appears for police questioning
summary: Korean Air Lines' youngest daughter, Cho Hyun Min, made her first appearance for police questioning over allegations of throwing a drink at people at a business meeting last month. The 20-year-old apologized for causing concern, saying she was "genuinely sorry" for her actions. This incident reignites public impatience with South Korea's family-run conglomerates, known as chaebol, over perceived unchecked behavior by the rich and powerful. Cho Hyun Min stepped down from her senior position at the airline after her father, chairman Cho Yang Ho, publicly apologized for the behavior of his two daughters.

site_title: How old is 'Big Ben'? The trivia Meghan Markle must know to become British
summary: US actress Meghan Markle will take the nationality of her new husband, Prince Harry, after their May 19 wedding. To become a British citizen, she must pass the "Life in the UK" test, which requires answering 18 out of 24 questions on historical facts and trivia. The test, which costs £50, has a high failure rate, with 133,490 tests taken in 2016 and 47,312 failures. Critics argue the test is too difficult and does not effectively prepare new citizens for life in the UK.

site_title: CapitaLand Q1 profit down 19% on absence of one-time gain
summary: CapitaLand, a Singapore-based real estate company, reported a 19% decline in Q1 net profit to S$319.09 million due to the absence of a one-time gain. Revenue rose 53.3% to S$1.38 billion, driven by higher development profits and rental income from new properties. The company remains on track to achieve its annual S$3 billion capital recycling target and is exploring investment opportunities. It expects the Singapore residential market to improve this year, while being cautious on the China market due to government property cooling measures.

site_title: Australia's central bank sees faster growth, slow inflation as rates sit still
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia, left interest rates at 1.5% for a 21st consecutive month, predicting inflation would remain muted despite a slowing economy. The bank forecast annual GDP growth of 3% in 2018 and 2019, with business conditions and investment spending on the rise. However, underlying inflation pressures are rising, and the bank warned that capacity pressures could support labor demand and inflation risks. The decision suggests a hike in rates is unlikely until 2020, as the bank is cautious about the impact of higher rates on households burdened by mortgage debt.

site_title: DBS shares shoot past S$30 on 21% surge in Q1 earnings
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, reported a 21% surge in Q1 earnings to S$1.5 billion, exceeding analyst expectations. The bank's shares rose 2.8% to S$30.84, marking the first time they crossed the S$30 threshold. DBS attributed the growth to higher interest rates, loans, and a property sale gain in Hong Kong. The bank's net interest margin rose 9 basis points to 1.83%, and its full-year loan growth guidance remains at 8%. CEO Piyush Gupta expects a "fairly strong year" for DBS, citing robust global growth momentum.

site_title: Si2i: No firm decision on appointment of new chairman
summary: Si2i, a Singapore-listed telecom products and IT services provider, has not yet made a decision on appointing a new chairman, despite being on the Singapore Exchange watch-list due to three consecutive years of losses and a low market capitalization. The company has until March 3, 2019, to meet the delisting requirements or risk being removed from the list.

site_title: Singapore union membership bucks sliding global trend
summary: Singapore's union membership has defied the global trend of declining unionization rates, with the NTUC (National Trade Union Congress) reporting a significant increase in membership. In contrast, unionization rates in the UK have fallen from 55% in 1979 to 23.5% in 2016. The NTUC has taken a new approach to recruitment, adapting to changing industries and labour markets. This shift suggests that Singapore's unique economic and labour dynamics may be contributing to the country's bucking of the global trend.

images.alt_text: "There are some who will not be a union member, but we hope that they can be a member of the labour movement," says Ms Cham.

site_title: Taiwan says China dangled US$3b to grab ally Dominican Republic
summary: China allegedly offered the Dominican Republic a US$3.1 billion package to sever ties with Taiwan, a diplomatic blow to the self-ruled island. Taiwan claims China's offer as an attempt to lure the Caribbean nation into its fold. The offer was reportedly made after the Dominican Republic switched allegiance to China. China denied any economic pre-conditions for the offer, stating that Taiwan is a "wayward province" with no right to state-to-state ties.

site_title: Twitter inks more than 30 video deals with Disney, NBC, Viacom
summary: Twitter has signed over 30 video deals with major publishers like Disney, NBC, and Viacom, expanding its video offerings with news, entertainment, and sports content. NBCUniversal will distribute live video and clips through its media properties, while Viacom is creating new show formats, including "BET Breaks" and "Comedy Central's Creator's Room." Disney is working with Twitter to create live sports programming and other content.

site_title: Man and machine are bosom buddies at Dyson's Tuas facility
summary: Dyson's Singapore facility, which manufactures digital motors, has seen a significant increase in its workforce to 1,100 employees, despite the use of automation. Vice-president Scott Maguire emphasizes that the company's focus is on improving technology and products, rather than replacing human labor. Over 400 workers have benefited from fully-funded training schemes, and Dyson plans to hire 500 engineers by 2021. The company believes that automation has freed up human resources for more complex tasks, such as quality control and software maintenance.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Greenback pushes towards 3-month highs again
summary: The US dollar rose on Monday, holding near its strongest level since mid-January, driven by weaker-than-expected German retail sales and rising US Treasury yields. The dollar index rose 0.3% to 91.780, while the euro dropped 0.4% to $1.2088, its lowest in three months. Analysts expect US consumer spending numbers and the Federal Reserve's monetary policy meeting to further boost the dollar. The eurozone's economic sentiment has been dampened, and investors are trimming expectations for the Bank of England to raise interest rates next month.

site_title: ANZ flags slower revenue growth, cites more regulation and bank inquiry impact
summary: ANZ flags slower revenue growth due to increased regulation and competition, citing a "golden period" for Australia's banking industry coming to an end. The bank's CEO, Shayne Elliott, attributed the change to the impact of a Royal Commission into the finance industry and the government's push for stricter regulations. ANZ posted a 4% increase in cash profit for the first half, despite net interest income falling 1%. The bank will simplify its business structure, selling non-core assets, to improve profitability.

site_title: DeClout blocks Procurri from issuing new shares
summary: DeClout, a major shareholder of enterprise hardware supplier Procurri, has blocked the company from issuing new shares, citing concerns over triggering an event of default. DeClout, which owns 47% of Procurri, has taken a $10 million loan against its Procurri shares to fund its own portfolio companies. Procurri's chairman and CEO Vesmond Wong said DeClout's actions are aimed at protecting its own shareholders and avoiding a potential loan repayment trigger. Procurri plans to continue with its business as usual and assess funding options.

site_title: Marathon to become top US refiner with US$23b Andeavor buy
summary: Marathon Petroleum Corp agreed to buy rival Andeavor for over $23 billion, creating one of the largest global refiners. The deal gives Marathon access to booming US shale fields and growing US fuel export markets. The combined company will process 3.1 million barrels of crude oil into gasoline, diesel, and other fuels, making it the largest US refiner. The acquisition also provides a line into fast-growing Mexican fuel markets, with Andeavor expanding its retail network of motor fuel stations. The deal is expected to close in the second half of this year.

images.alt_text: Marathon Petroleum Corp agreed to buy rival Andeavor for more than US$23 billion in a deal creating one of the largest global refiners that will benefit from access to booming US shale fields and growing US fuel export markets.

site_title: Korea peace talks: Is China in or out?
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-In and North Korean Chairman Kim Jong Un signed the Panmunjom Declaration, agreeing to establish a permanent and solid peace regime on the Korean Peninsula. The declaration calls for active cooperation between the two Koreas and the US, or a quadrilateral meeting involving China, to achieve this goal. China's involvement is seen as crucial, but its desire to play a key role may be driven by a fear of marginalization, following US President Donald Trump's acceptance of Kim's offer of a face-to-face meeting. The declaration's outcome brings general relief to a worldwide audience, but the future of a peace treaty remains uncertain.

site_title: UK supermarket giants Sainsbury's, Asda to merge
summary: UK supermarket giants Sainsbury's and Asda, owned by Walmart, have agreed to merge, creating a retail king that would surpass current leader Tesco. The deal values Asda at £7.3 billion and will result in a combined business with £51 billion in total revenues and 2,800 stores. The merger aims to increase competition and resilience in the market, while no store closures are planned. The transaction is subject to approval from Britain's Competition and Markets Authority.

site_title: Request for trading halt followed call by S'pore Customs over possible duties infringement by unit: Transcorp
summary: Transcorp Holdings reported a trading halt request after Singapore Customs called for its Regal Motors subsidiary to assist in an investigation into possible under-declaration of import duties in 2016 and 2017. The company stated there's no indication of under-declaration and its director is assisting the investigation. No charges have been preferred, and no restrictions have been imposed on Regal Motors' importation of motor cars. Transcorp will update shareholders on the investigation.

site_title: Ten journalists among dozens killed in Afghan attacks
summary: Ten journalists, including Agence France-Presse's chief photographer in Kabul, Shah Marai, were killed in a double suicide blast in Kabul on May 1, 2018, in the deadliest single attack on the media since 2001. The attack, claimed by the Islamic State group, targeted reporters at the scene, and at least 49 people were wounded. The incident highlights the dangers faced by journalists in war-torn Afghanistan, where violence is increasing as the Taliban and Islamic State groups step up their campaigns.

site_title: US: Stocks slide on worries about Iran, tariffs
summary: US stocks fell on concerns over US policy towards Iran and impending tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from the European Union and other countries. Despite strong earnings from McDonald's and a positive start to the day, investors were deterred by Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's accusations about Iran's nuclear intentions. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq also edged towards fresh records despite uncertainty over the US Federal Reserve's interest rate increases and ongoing US-EU trade talks.

site_title: No more hard copies of annual report? Stacks at AGM
summary: A Singaporean investor expressed concern that companies may interpret listing rules to abolish printed annual reports, citing environmental sustainability as a reason. However, the investor attended the AGM and found stacks of printed ARs available. The investor believes shareholders expect printed copies upon request, not as a standard practice. The investor urges companies to provide printed copies upon request, not as a default.

site_title: Summit delivers modicum of hope for peaceful future for all Koreans
summary: South and North Korean leaders, Moon Jae-In and Kim Jong Un, respectively, have reaffirmed the principle of self-determination for the Korean nation and agreed to work towards a peace treaty ending the Korean War. They also committed to family reunions, improved communications and infrastructure, and joint participation in international sports events. However, the deal's significance may be limited, as the focus on inter-Korean relations and nuclear disarmament may not be enough to convince North Korea to give up its nuclear arms, which are a key factor in the regime's survival.

site_title: Dymon Asia Private Equity Fund II closes launch with US$450m in the bag
summary: Dymon Asia Private Equity Fund II has closed its final round with US$450 million, targeting lower middle market companies in Southeast Asia earning US$5m to US$30m a year. The fund, launched in the fourth quarter of last year, follows its predecessor, which had a 30% internal rate of return. Demand from investors was strong, with the fund oversubscribed within months, and new investors include sovereign institutions, banks, and multi-generational family outfits, expected to broaden the network and bring benefits to portfolio companies.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: UK interior minister Rudd resigns after immigration scandal
summary: UK Interior Minister Amber Rudd resigned on April 30, 2018, after admitting to misleading Parliament about immigration targets. Rudd, a key ally of Prime Minister Theresa May, had denied the existence of targets for deporting illegal immigrants, but leaked documents showed otherwise. The scandal, known as the "Windrush crisis," has highlighted issues with the treatment of Caribbean residents who were wrongly labeled as illegal immigrants. Rudd's resignation is a blow to May as she navigates the final year of Brexit negotiations.

site_title: Prologis to acquire DCT Industrial Trust for US$8.4b
summary: Prologis has agreed to acquire DCT Industrial Trust for $8.4 billion, becoming the world's largest warehouse owner. The deal, expected to be completed in Q3, will add 71 million square feet of real estate to Prologis' portfolio, expanding its presence in high-growth markets. The acquisition is expected to result in $80 million in cost savings and $40 million in additional annual revenue. Prologis CEO Hamid Moghadam stated that the deal aligns with the company's strategy, focusing on e-commerce and logistics services, which have seen increased demand due to online shopping.

images.alt_text: "Think of DCT as a smaller, US-focused version of Prologis. In the US we're very similar - the same kinds of customers, the same customers in many cases." says Mr Moghadam.

site_title: Furnishing flexibility with e-commerce
summary: FortyTwo, an online furniture retailer, has transformed its processes for greater efficiency, allowing it to showcase thousands of products without the need for physical space. Founded by Naveed Lee in 2007, the company initially focused on selling beds but later expanded to other bedroom-related products and furniture items. Today, FortyTwo features over 20,000 items in over 500 categories, with about 70% of sales coming from its own products. The company has also implemented technological improvements, such as a delivery scheduling system, to enhance customer experience. Despite facing challenges, including the shutdown of its online marketplace, FortyTwo aims to refine its internal processes and expand regionally, with plans to become the leading online retailer for home-related products in four years.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close mixed ahead of key US earnings, data
summary: Tokyo stocks closed mixed on May 1, 2018, ahead of key US earnings and economic data, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.18% to 22,508.03 and the Topix index falling 0.17% to 1,774.18.

site_title: Alstom to supply 17 new MRT trains for North-East, Circle lines
summary: Alstom has won a contract to supply 17 new MRT trains for Singapore's North-East Line and Circle Line, increasing capacity and incorporating condition monitoring systems for predictive maintenance. The new trains will be equipped with advanced technology to boost reliability and efficiency. The contract marks a significant expansion for Alstom in Singapore, with the new trains expected to be delivered in the coming years.

site_title: On the backfoot, British PM braces for election test
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May is facing a test in local elections, with the opposition Labour Party targeting her strongholds, including Wandsworth, south London. Labour hopes to capitalize on May's struggles with Brexit and immigration policy. The party is also trying to capitalize on the recent resignation of top ally Amber Rudd as interior minister. The local elections could further weaken May's position, potentially affecting the UK's general election.

site_title: Twitter sold users' data to man linked to Cambridge Analytica
summary: Twitter sold data access to Aleksandr Kogan, a Cambridge University academic linked to Cambridge Analytica, which harvested Facebook users' data without consent. In 2015, Kogan's firm, Global Science Research, obtained a one-time API access to a random sample of public tweets for a day. Twitter has removed Cambridge Analytica and affiliated entities as advertisers, citing its data licensing and revenue grew 20% in the first quarter. This incident highlights Twitter's data sharing practices and raises concerns about the misuse of user data by third-party companies.

images.alt_text: Aleksandr Kogan, who created a personality quiz on Facebook to harvest information later used by Cambridge Analytica, set up Global Science Research, which was granted access to large-scale public Twitter data, covering months of posts, for one day in 2015, Twitter said.

site_title: Please, sir, I want some more dividends
summary: OCBC Bank chairman Ooi Sang Kuang explained that the bank's dividend payout is sustainable and predictable, despite shareholders' requests for higher payouts. OCBC maintains a 40-50% dividend payout ratio, compared to DBS and UOB's 30-40% and 40-50% respectively. The bank has no excess capital and prioritizes maintaining capital buffers to comply with Basel III requirements. OCBC's final dividend for FY17 was 19 cents per share, a 1-cent increase from last year, yielding 2.7%.

site_title: Raffles Medical Q1 profit up 1.7% on new contract, hospital load growth
summary: Raffles Medical Group's net profit grew 1.7% to S$15.81 million in Q1 2018, driven by an increase in local patient load and a new border screening contract. Revenue rose 4.6% to S$120.19 million, offset by higher expenditure on expansion and staff costs. The company expects to remain profitable in 2018, with new medical centers and beds planned for Singapore and China.

site_title: China manufacturing activity slows in April
summary: China's factory activity slowed marginally in April, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 51.4, beating expectations. However, analysts warn of headwinds as credit growth eases. This suggests China's economic growth may slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Incoming NTUC leader Ng Chee Meng says he will listen to workers to chart future direction
summary: Incoming NTUC leader Ng Chee Meng has promised to listen to workers to chart the future direction of the organization. At his first May Day rally, he emphasized the need for workers to be poised to seize new opportunities in the future economy and regional markets. Ng will conduct more dialogues with workers to better address their needs and challenges, particularly in understanding the 23 Industry Transformation Maps (ITMs). He cautioned against complacency in the face of technological disruption, highlighting the importance of workers being proactive in seizing new opportunities.

site_title: India's Allcargo Logistics plans to build an Uber for shipping
summary: India's Allcargo Logistics plans to adopt an Uber-like model for shipping by aggregating marine container orders and making it easier for clients to book freight. The company, facing declining profits, aims to boost volumes and compete with overseas rivals. ECU Worldwide, a unit of Allcargo, will use technology to simplify the booking process, allowing clients to book from anywhere. The move is seen as innovative, but challenges lie in navigating regulatory checkpoints in export-import trade.

site_title: US dollar steady near 4-month highs, awaits Fed and data for fresh cues
summary: The US dollar held steady near four-month highs, awaiting the Federal Reserve's policy decision and US employment data for fresh cues. The Fed is expected to stand pat on policy, with investors watching for hints of a rate hike in June. The US dollar index rose to 91.805, its strongest since January 11, after the euro slumped to near three-month lows due to soft German retail sales data. The euro and pound also declined, while the US dollar was lower against the yen.

site_title: Gold near six-week low as US dollar firms, Korea tensions ease
summary: Gold prices fell to a six-week low on Monday, losing 0.3% to $1,318.14 per ounce, amid a stronger US dollar and easing tensions on the Korean peninsula. Geopolitical risks abating, investors are shifting to higher-risk assets like stocks, reducing demand for gold. North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un and South Korean President Moon Jae In declared a formal end to the 1950-53 Korean War, contributing to the lack of solid demand for gold as a safe haven.

site_title: Australian shares edge up as financials firm; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to 6013.20, driven by gains in financials and real estate stocks. The Australian financial index rose 1.1% as Commonwealth Bank of Australia received an extra A$1 billion capital requirement. Real estate stocks like Dexus and Alumina Ltd also gained, while Rio Tinto fell 0.4% due to a lawsuit. New Zealand's benchmark index remained flat.

site_title: PM Lee to new generation: Open a new chapter, create new possibilities for Singapore
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong urged the new generation to renew the country, open new chapters, and create possibilities. He emphasized the importance of holding on to successful values such as planning ahead, doing better, and stewardship. The economy is expected to grow 1.5-3.5% this year, but faces external challenges including US-China trade tensions. The government will continue to support businesses and workers in adapting to disruption, with initiatives such as retraining and industry transformation maps.

site_title: Mount Fuji eruption could paralyse Tokyo: report
summary: A government disaster planning study in Japan found that an eruption of Mount Fuji, Japan's highest mountain, could paralyze Tokyo with ash, rendering roads impassable and stopping water supplies. The study estimates that 10 cm of ash could cause significant damage, including mechanical problems for cars and mass power outages. The potential cost of an eruption is estimated to be over $31 billion, with the impact on aviation and transportation also considered. The government is assessing the scenario and preparing measures to deal with the possibility of an eruption.

site_title: Najib says Opposition will sour ties with China if they win
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak warned that if the opposition wins the election, it may lead to strained ties with China, potentially affecting the country's economy. He cited the review of contracts with Chinese companies, such as the East Coast Rail Line, as a risk factor. Najib emphasized the importance of maintaining good relations with China and other countries for economic success, stating that a strong Barisan government will deliver economic success.

site_title: Good prospects for economy in 2018: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced that Singapore's economy grew 3.6% in 2018, with productivity growth reaching its highest in seven years and more jobs created, including higher-paying ones. He expressed optimism for healthy economic growth in 2019 if the current momentum is maintained.

site_title: SGX to review how Vard's delisting EGM was handled
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) will review Vard Holdings' extraordinary general meeting (EGM) following complaints of errors in the circular to shareholders and allegations of improper voting poll. Minority shareholders, who attended the EGM in large numbers, claimed they were not given the opportunity to cast their votes and were confused by the company's board of directors. The review will examine the conduct of the EGM proceedings and the disclosures in the circular to ensure shareholders' approval was properly obtained.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Mother Nature is skipping right over spring into summer in US
summary: US weather is skipping spring and heading into summer, with temperatures expected to rise to record highs in cities like New York and Chicago. A storm system in the central US is pumping warm air into the East, leading to heat waves across the eastern US this week. The warmth is forecast to bolster demand for natural gas and electricity, and could be the warmest stretch of days for the region this year. This unusual weather pattern is in stark contrast to April, which was significantly colder than the 10-year normal.

site_title: Keeping the family business together
summary: A family feud is brewing in Singapore over the Genting Group, founded by Tan Sri Lim Goh Tong. The dispute involves certain beneficiaries being excluded from a trust and will, sparking tension among the heirs. The situation is reminiscent of high-profile family feuds in Asia, such as the Samsung and Ambani brothers' disputes. To prevent similar conflicts, experts suggest distributing assets, using trusts, and passing the baton before one passes on.

site_title: Mood upbeat in services, manufacturing sectors
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector shows improved business prospects, with a net weighted balance of 13% of firms expecting more favorable conditions for the next six months. The precision engineering cluster is the most optimistic, with a 39% net weighted balance. The services sector also sees improved sentiment, with a 8% net weighted balance of firms expecting more favorable business conditions. However, firms in the retail trade, accommodation, and food & beverage services industries expect business prospects to deteriorate.

site_title: Rise of the machines needs to be matched with rise in skills
summary: A report by the OECD warns that 66 million people may lose their jobs due to automation by 2030. Robots are increasingly replacing human workers in various sectors, with 14% of jobs in developed countries being highly automatable. However, experts suggest that this shift towards automation will also lead to new job opportunities, requiring workers to acquire new skills. Companies like Honey House in Singapore are embracing automation, while others, such as Prudential Singapore, are investing in training employees to work alongside robots. To adapt, workers must prioritize skills development, and employers must lead in equipping their staff with the necessary skills to remain relevant in a rapidly changing job market.

images.alt_text: Above: Honeymill founder Sophia Lim uses a robot to mix drinks.
Above: Aryani Suhardi started as a Prudential customer service executive but now trains chatbots and more.

site_title: Annual inflation measures jump, as expected
summary: US consumer prices accelerated to a 2.0% year-on-year gain in March, exceeding expectations and nearing the Federal Reserve's 2% target. The core PCE price index, the Fed's preferred inflation measure, rose 1.9% over the 12 months, its largest increase since February 2017. The inflation rise is attributed to a tightening labor market and faster economic growth, driven by a $1.5 trillion tax cut package and increased government spending, which is expected to keep the Federal Reserve's interest rate increases gradual.

site_title: North and South Korea start to dismantle border speakers, fulfilling summit pledge
summary: North and South Korea began dismantling loudspeakers along their border, fulfilling a pledge made at their historic summit last week. The move marks a small step towards reconciliation after decades of propaganda broadcasts. The South had stopped its broadcasts ahead of the summit, and the North followed suit. This comes amid speculation about a potential meeting between North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and US President Donald Trump, with possible venues including the Peace House in the demilitarized zone or Singapore.

site_title: Australia's four major banks at risk if house prices slump: Fitch
summary: Australia's four major banks, Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Westpac Banking Corp, Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, and National Australia Bank, are at risk of a ratings downgrade if the country experiences a severe housing market downturn. Fitch Ratings' stress test found that these banks could suffer significant losses, particularly Westpac and ANZ, due to their large mortgage books. However, the banks maintain that they are "comfortable" with their home loan portfolios, and Fitch's base case assumes the banks can withstand a significant housing market downturn.

site_title: Merkel threatens Trump with trade war
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel warned the US that Europe could enter a trade war if the US does not extend a key trade tariff exemption, set to expire on Tuesday. Merkel lobbied for the exemption, which would allow European steel and aluminum imports to continue without tariffs, after a difficult meeting with President Donald Trump at the White House. Trump had previously threatened to impose tariffs on European car exports, which Merkel criticized as "very bad." Merkel's comments come after a tense meeting with Trump, where she failed to secure diplomatic breakthroughs on several issues, including the Iran nuclear deal.

site_title: Iran bans use of popular Telegram messaging app
summary: Iran's judiciary has banned the popular Telegram messaging app, citing concerns that it allows armed opposition groups to fuel unrest. The move comes after a recent presidential directive banning foreign messenger apps and amid efforts to develop Iranian social media networks. Telegram, with 40 million users, has been temporarily banned in the past and is now completely blocked by internet providers and phone operators, who face prosecution for non-compliance. This decision follows a wave of protests in Iranian cities earlier this year and a growing trend to limit reliance on foreign-based platforms deemed hostile to the Islamic Republic.

site_title: Oil heads for monthly gain on Iran risks and as Opec clears glut
summary: Oil prices are poised for a second monthly gain due to concerns over a potential US withdrawal from the Iran nuclear deal, which could reimpose sanctions and curb Iranian oil exports. Opec has trimmed output, clearing 97% of the global glut, but US drilling activity continues to weigh on prices. Oil futures have surged to levels last seen in 2014, driven by geopolitical risks and supply disruptions. Prices are up 5.2% for the month, with WTI crude trading at $67.48 a barrel and Brent crude at $73.90 a barrel.

site_title: Alibaba cannot block cryptocurrency firm from using similar name: US judge
summary: A US judge rejected Alibaba Group Holdings Ltd's bid for a preliminary injunction to block the Dubai cryptocurrency firm Alibabacoin Foundation from using the Alibaba name. The judge found Alibaba did not demonstrate jurisdiction, as it failed to show a reasonable probability that Alibabacoin's websites were used to transact business with New York customers. The ruling does not prevent Alibabacoin from using the name, but rather allows it to continue.

images.alt_text: A US judge on Monday rejected Alibaba Group Holdings Ltd's bid for a preliminary injunction to block the Dubai cryptocurrency firm Alibabacoin Foundation from using the Alibaba name.

site_title: WTA Finals tickets go on sale on May 10
summary: The WTA Finals in Singapore, a $7 million season-ending tennis tournament, will take place from October 21-28. Ticket sales begin on May 10, with a portion of the proceeds going to SportCares, a local organization supporting youths from vulnerable backgrounds. The cheapest ticket starts at $27, while the priciest is $239 for a Category A ticket to the final. The tournament will also feature a charity silent auction and a Racquet Club VIP hospitality program.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: WhatsApp co-founder to quit in loss of privacy advocate at Facebook
summary: WhatsApp co-founder Jan Koum is leaving the company after a decade, citing a clash with Facebook over WhatsApp's strategy and encryption. Koum, a strong advocate for user privacy, will depart without specifying a date. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg praised Koum's commitment to encryption, but acknowledged Facebook's efforts to use WhatsApp user data. Koum's departure comes amid growing concerns over Facebook's handling of personal information, following the Cambridge Analytica scandal. Koum's co-founder Brian Acton left the company in 2017 to start a foundation.

site_title: Is it better to hire specialists or generalists?
summary: A mix of specialists and generalists is considered ideal for teams, with a balance of expertise and adaptability. Hiring specialists can boost productivity, but may limit flexibility. In contrast, generalists can cover more bases, but may lack depth in specific areas. Implementing a job rotation program, similar to the old management trainee model, can help bridge the gap between specialists and generalists, allowing employees to gain experience in multiple roles and develop a broader skill set. This approach can also foster talent growth and adaptability in a rapidly changing business environment.

site_title: Carlsberg keeps 2018 outlook despite disappointing Q1 sales
summary: Carlsberg reported a 5% decline in first-quarter sales, primarily due to a negative currency impact and lower volumes in its Russian market, which accounts for around a fifth of its sales. Despite this, the company expects mid-single-digit organic growth in operating profit for the year. Carlsberg's premium brands delivered strong growth across markets, but sales fell in Western and Eastern Europe, with Asia being the only region to see sales growth. The company attributed the decline to increased promotional pressure in Russia and the impact of initiatives to discourage drinking.

images.alt_text: Danish brewer Carlsberg said on Tuesday sales fell 5 per cent in the first quarter, weighed by a negative currency impact and lower volumes in its key Russian market.

site_title: Singapore still needs more hotel rooms; occupancy likely to stay above 84%: Colliers
summary: Singapore's hotel industry still faces a significant shortage of rooms, despite a substantial increase in room supply over the past three years. The Singapore Tourism Board projects 4% growth in international visitor arrivals to 18.1 million this year, leading to hotel occupancy rates expected to remain above 84%. Hoteliers can expect an increase in average daily rates, driven by regional currencies remaining relatively weak. Chinese tourists are expected to drive visitor arrivals, with outbound trips projected to jump by 47.7% by 2020.

site_title: Singapore must forge its own strategy to become a global AI leader
summary: Singapore must develop its own AI strategy to become a global leader, rather than following a nationalist approach or imitating others. The country should leverage its unique strengths as a financial hub and education center to create a global platform for AI development. Additionally, Singapore can differentiate itself by driving an entrepreneur-friendly environment and showcasing a healthy work-life balance to attract top AI talent. By finding its own story and strategy, Singapore can enjoy an exciting future in the AI industry.

site_title: 'Simpsons' breaks TV record but faces controversy
summary: "The Simpsons" broke the record for the most episodes in a primetime scripted series, surpassing "Gunsmoke" with its 636th episode. However, the milestone came amidst controversy surrounding the character Apu, voiced by white actor Hank Azaria, who has faced accusations of racism and stereotypes. In response, Azaria expressed willingness to step aside or transition the character, while show creator Matt Groening defended the show, calling the criticism "politically incorrect."

site_title: Market conditions differ in Vard's, Otto Marine's delistings
summary: Vard Holdings and Otto Marine are set to delist from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) due to different market conditions. Vard, which has seen improved oil prices, recent order wins, and diversification efforts, has a controlling shareholder Fincantieri Oil & Gas that has expanded its expertise and portfolio. In contrast, Otto Marine delisted in 2016 due to sector crisis and severe debt financing and cash flow problems. Vard's shareholders feel deprived of potential upside after three consecutive years of losses, while Otto Marine shareholders were more focused on avoiding liquidation.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on robust earnings, M&A activity
summary: US stock indexes opened higher on Monday, driven by strong earnings and merger activity, kicking off a busy week for inflation watchers. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 99.22 points, or 0.41%, to 24,410.41, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: US stocks opened lower on July 11, 2025, amid a fresh tariff salvo by President Trump on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to H1, while London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained an employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case, and Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Masdar and PBOC announced cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: T-Mobile acquires Sprint for US$26.5b in stock
summary: T-Mobile has agreed to acquire Sprint for $26.5 billion in stock, reducing the US wireless industry to three major competitors from four. The deal values each Sprint share at 0.10256 of a T-Mobile share, or about $6.62 a share. The combined entity will have about $74 billion in annual revenue and 70 million wireless subscribers. Regulators will scrutinize the deal, which aims to build a next-generation wireless network and pressure larger rivals, Verizon and AT&T. The merger is expected to generate $43 billion in synergies, mostly from network spending.

site_title: Innovating to engage the millennial consumer
summary: A roundtable discussion among industry experts, including Mastercard, GroupM, and OCBC Bank, explores how companies engage with millennials. Key findings include: millennials are increasingly becoming entrepreneurs, are digitally savvy, and value authenticity and uniqueness. Companies are adapting their offerings to suit this demographic, such as creating new products and engaging in co-creation. Millennials are also socially conscious, driving demand for environmental sustainability and social responsibility. The experts emphasize the importance of understanding and catering to the needs of this demographic, and highlight the need for companies to continuously cultivate relevance and address audience concerns.

site_title: FortyTwo makes room for ideas from staff
summary: FortyTwo, a Singapore-based startup, has implemented a new policy to encourage staff ideas. Fadzly Othman, a 37-year-old web developer, joined in 2012 and was surprised by the level of involvement he had in driving change. The company aims to create a dynamic environment where staff can share their ideas and contribute to the organization's growth. This move is seen as a positive step towards employee engagement and innovation.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Audit finds Aramco oil reserves slightly higher than reported - sources
summary: An audit of Saudi Aramco's oil reserves found the state oil giant to have slightly higher reserves than previously reported, according to sources. Saudi Arabia has long held the world's largest reserves of easily recoverable oil. The discovery could impact Aramco's planned initial public offering (IPO).

images.alt_text: An audit of Saudi Aramco's oil reserves - an essential part of the preparatory work for its planned initial public offering - has found the state oil giant to have higher reserves than it previously reported.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Manulife US Reit reported a restated distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.51 US cents for its first quarter ended March 31, 2018, down 0.7% from the previous year. This was due to a rights issue in 2017.

site_title: Indonesia vows to restore calm to currency market after selloff
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, has pledged to restore stability in the country's financial market after the rupiah slumped to a two-year low, sparking a selloff in stocks and bonds. Governor Agus Martowardojo announced plans to adjust interest rates and boost dollar supply through forex swap auctions if the pressure on the rupiah persists. The government will use its budget to support economic growth, despite a weakening currency, and has at least $60 billion in swap facilities under bilateral agreements. The government maintains its GDP growth forecast of 5.4% for this year.

site_title: Chaswood granted extension to hold AGM for FY2017 by June 30
summary: Chaswood Resources Holdings has been granted an extension by the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) to hold its annual general meeting for FY2017 by June 30 and present its financial statements by June 29. The company had requested an extension to finalize a restructuring scheme with its lenders. The Singapore Exchange has also approved the waiver for the AGM to be held by June 30.

site_title: Dubai port operator, Hyperloop team up on high-speed cargo delivery
summary: DP World, Dubai's port operator, and Virgin Hyperloop One have formed a global company, DP World Cargospeed, to develop high-speed cargo delivery systems using Hyperloop technology. The partnership aims to create futuristic transport systems, linking existing road, rail, and air transport infrastructure. With potential projects in India, the UAE, and Saudi Arabia, the new company will invest tens of billions of dollars. The goal is to deliver goods in under 14 hours, regardless of location, with the first full super-fast rail network expected to be in commercial use by 2025.

site_title: Management changes at CDW after chairman's retirement
summary: CDW Holding's chairman and CEO, Urano Koichi, is retiring, effective April 30, and will be replaced by Chief Operating Officer Yoshikawa Makoto. Koichi, 61, will relinquish his shares and options, while Yoshikawa, 44, will assume the CEO position. Tomonori Kato, 47, has been appointed COO and executive director, replacing Makoto. The changes take effect immediately, following a transition period.

site_title: US pending home sales rise 0.4% in March
summary: US pending home sales rose 0.4% in March to a reading of 107.6, driven by a second consecutive monthly increase. This contradicts economists' forecasts of a 1.0% rise. The housing market has regained some steam, bolstered by a strong economy and low unemployment, but a shortage of supply and rising house prices have limited first-time buyers. Pending sales were down 3.0% compared to the same period last year, with the South being the only region to see an increase.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokerages' take on Singapore stocks: CapitaLand Retail China Trust upgraded to "accumulate" with a target price of S$1.66, Sheng Siong Group downgraded to "hold" with a target price of S$1.09, and ComfortDelGro Corporation upgraded to "buy" with a target price of S$2.72, citing favorable market conditions and expected earnings growth.

site_title: AccorHotels agrees to buy Movenpick Hotels for 560m francs
summary: AccorHotels has agreed to purchase Movenpick Hotels & Resorts for 560 million Swiss francs (S$750 million), boosting its earnings and expanding its presence in emerging markets. The deal, expected to be completed in the second half of 2018, will add to the company's earnings from the first year onwards. This acquisition marks the latest in AccorHotels' ambitious takeover strategy, following previous deals in the hospitality industry.

site_title: New Silkroutes CFO, joint company secretary Lim Koon Hock retires; company appoints new finance director
summary: New Silkroutes Group announced the retirement of CFO and joint company secretary Lim Koon Hock after 13½ years, effective immediately. Lim will be succeeded by Teo Thiam Chuan William as finance director, responsible for treasury, finance, audit, and strategic planning functions. The company shares rose 1.7% to S$0.295 on the announcement.

site_title: Avengers opens with US$630m box office, smashing global record
summary: Avengers: Infinity War opened with a record-breaking US$630 million at the global box office, surpassing previous records. The achievement was made without China's contribution, which has a later release date. This milestone marks a significant success for the Marvel blockbuster, solidifying its position as a box office powerhouse.

images.alt_text: Avengers: Infinity War features more than two dozen superheroes fighting to save the universe against the powerful purple alien Thanos (above), played by Josh Brolin.
