site_title: SIAEC in non-binding pact with Cebu Air to expand MRO services in the Philippines
summary: SIA Engineering Company Limited (SIAEC) and Cebu Air Inc have signed a non-binding letter of intent to expand maintenance, repair and overhaul (MRO) services in the Philippines. The estimated investment value is US$15-20 million, with potential job creation. The two companies already have two joint ventures in the Philippines, providing line maintenance services and heavy aircraft checks. The collaboration aims to grow line maintenance operations, hangar facilities, and training academy services.

site_title: Noble Group going ahead with special general meeting to seek approval on sale of vessel
summary: NOBLE Group Limited is proceeding with a special general meeting to approve the sale of a vessel, despite a lawsuit filed by dissident shareholder Goldilocks Investment Co Ltd. The High Court ruled that Goldilocks is not a member of the company under Bermuda law, requiring it to register as a depositor by May 3. Noble expects to submit a draft shareholder circular and will continue to seek support for its proposed restructuring plan, which has received backing from over 83% of its creditors.

site_title: Alpha fund, CDL tie-up put two office assets on the market
summary: Alpha Investment Partners and City Developments Ltd (CDL) have put two office assets, Manulife Centre in Bras Basah Road and 7 & 9 Tampines Grande, on the market through expressions of interest exercises. The total price tag exceeds S$1 billion. Manulife Centre, a 11-storey building with 242,000 sq ft of net lettable area, has an asking price of over S$550 million. 7 & 9 Tampines Grande, a pair of eight-storey office buildings with 288,000 sq ft of net lettable area, has an asking price of over S$450 million. The assets were acquired by a 60:40 joint venture between Alpha Asia Macro Trends Fund II and CDL in 2015.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Dozens hospitalised as Myanmar battles week-long landfill fire
summary: A week-long landfill fire in Yangon, Myanmar, has hospitalized dozens, with 26 people suffering from smoke inhalation. The massive fire, which started on April 21, has spread across nearly a third of the 300-acre landfill and generated a haze affecting parts of the city. Authorities have brought the fire under control, but it's unclear when it will be extinguished. The cause of the fire remains unknown, and the government has faced criticism for its slow response. The fire highlights the growing waste management problem in Yangon, which lacks a long-term solution.

site_title: Korean unity puts more expectation, pressure on Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump faces increased pressure and expectations after the historic meeting between North and South Korean leaders, who pledged to rid the peninsula of nuclear weapons. However, the lack of a timeline and common definition of denuclearization complicates Trump's task. Analysts say the resumption of diplomatic exchanges between the two Koreas will weaken economic sanctions, making it harder for Trump to threaten military action. Trump must now persuade Kim Jong Un to accept "complete, verifiable and irreversible denuclearization," a goal that Kim has shown no willingness to accept in the past.

site_title: Oxley's Q3 profit falls 33% but CEO bullish on project pipeline
summary: Oxley Holdings reported a 33% decline in Q3 net profit to S$30.56 million, with group revenue falling 38% to S$238.84 million. The developer attributed this to the lack of major project completions. However, CEO Ching Chiat Kwong remains bullish on the project pipeline, citing S$1.6 billion of unbilled contracts and significant land bank worth S$19 billion. Upcoming project launches, including The Verandah Residences, are expected to enhance revenue in the coming years.

site_title: Sustain efforts to improve productivity, urges Josephine Teo
summary: Incoming Manpower Minister Josephine Teo urged tripartite partners to sustain efforts to improve productivity and help businesses transform and workers adapt. Despite gains in productivity growth and wages, some sectors remain disrupted. Teo emphasized the need for workers to acquire skills relevant to industries and businesses of the future, and for the business climate to remain dynamic to encourage investments and create new jobs. The labour market has shown improvement, with a 3.6% economic growth and a 4.5% productivity growth, but economists caution that it's too early to tell if the labour market has turned the corner.

site_title: CDLHT posts 7.4% rise in Q1 distribution per stapled security to 2.17 cents
summary: CDL Hospitality Trust (CDLHT) reported a 7.4% increase in distribution per stapled security to 2.17 Singapore cents for Q1, driven by higher net property income (NPI) of 5.4% to S$37.82 million. Gross revenue rose 11.6% to S$51.8 million, with inorganic contributions from The Lowry Hotel in the UK and Pullman Hotel Munich in Germany. Despite weaker contributions from Japan, Maldives, and Australia properties, the Singapore portfolio recorded an improvement in NPI, with CEO Vincent Yeo attributing the growth to past acquisitions and asset enhancement opportunities.

site_title: Opec ditches its rear-view mirror for a telescope
summary: OPEC has shifted its approach to oil production, moving away from focusing on inventory levels and towards investment plans for future oil production capacity. According to Saudi oil minister Khalid Al-Falih, the group aims to promote long-term market confidence to attract capital, rather than targeting prices. However, this new approach has been met with skepticism, as investment plans are outdated and do not reflect current market conditions. Several major oil companies, including Royal Dutch Shell and Total SA, have stated that they will not increase capital investment in response to current oil prices.

site_title: Neymar recovery on track, will be back for World Cup: doctor
summary: Neymar is recovering from a foot injury and is on track to return for the World Cup in Russia. According to Brazil team doctor Rodrigo Lasmar, Neymar is working hard to regain his fitness, with a tailored program needed to address the loss of physical fitness due to the injury. Neymar's recovery timeline puts him back in action by this summer's World Cup, with a final medical exam scheduled for May 17, and a training camp with Brazil's players from May 21 to 27.

site_title: Bond bull market still intact despite rout scare
summary: The 10-year Treasury yield has broken above the 3.00% psychological round number but remains intact due to a few factors. Historically, a short squeeze is imminent with net speculator futures positions at -372,000 contracts, which could cap bullish momentum at the 3.05% level. The weekly RSI is in the overbought condition, indicating a mean reversion lower, with a possible yield drop of around 22%. A bearish divergence is also suggested if the 3.05% resistance area holds, potentially leading to a reversal back below the 3% range.

site_title: Australia to send military aircraft to monitor North Korean ships
summary: Australia will deploy a military patrol aircraft, a P-8A Poseidon, to monitor North Korean vessels suspected of transferring prohibited goods in defiance of UN sanctions. The move supports international efforts to address North Korea's illicit trade and networks. This comes amid a historic summit between North and South Korea, where leaders pledged to work towards the complete denuclearisation of the Korean peninsula. The US has also vowed to maintain pressure on Pyongyang through sanctions, with Australia and other key allies expected to keep up economic and diplomatic pressure on North Korea.

site_title: Up close with the world's top footballers in Singapore
summary: The International Champions Cup (ICC) is hosting three football matches in Singapore from July 26 to 30, featuring teams like Arsenal, Paris Saint-Germain, and Atletico Madrid. A new category of "Field Seats" tickets has been introduced, priced at S$388 each, offering fans a unique experience near the pitch. Only 50 seats are available per match, with the cheapest seat costing S$28 and the most expensive regular seat going for S$208.

site_title: Focus on earnings; SLB Development and Asia Healthcare Specialists debut
summary: The Straits Times Index declined 0.8% from April 20 to April 26, while the Dow Jones declined 1.7%. SLB Development and Asia Healthcare Specialists debuted on Catalist, with SLB Development trading at S$0.225 and Asia Healthcare Specialists at S$0.305. Eight primary-listed companies bought back shares worth S$2.8 million, and 48 stocks reported changes in director interests or substantial shareholders. Notable transactions include Henry Wee's 20.29% stake in Imperium Crown and Teo Ho Beng's 74.46% stake in Hiap Hoe.

site_title: Southeast Asia faces threats from IS, cyber-attacks: PM
summary: Southeast Asia faces threats from the Islamic State (IS) and cyber-attacks, despite their military defeat in the Middle East, warned Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. The region, home to 650 million people, has struggled with Islamic militancy and has seen deadly attacks, such as the 2016 Jakarta bombing and the 2017 Marawi battle. The growing adoption of digital technology has also made countries vulnerable to cyberattacks, prompting the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) to increase cybersecurity coordination. Lee also warned of rising protectionism and its impact on global trade.

images.alt_text: Southeast Asia faces "very real" threats from the Islamic State (IS) group despite their defeat in the Middle East, as well as cyber-attacks, Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong warned on Saturday as he opened a regional summit.

site_title: Keppel Corp inks MOU with Filipinos conglomerate to develop urban solutions
summary: Keppel Corp signed a non-binding MOU with Filinvest Development Corporation to develop sustainable urban solutions in the Philippines. The partnership aims to enhance urban development in Filinvest's properties, including Filinvest City and Filinvest New Clark City. Keppel Urban Solutions will leverage its diverse capabilities to create liveable, smart, and sustainable communities. The collaboration seeks to advance sustainable green buildings and communities in the Philippines, with the Keppel group having a presence in the country for over 40 years.

site_title: Oil inches down but Brent ends week firmer on Iran concerns
summary: Oil prices edged lower on Friday, with Brent crude futures falling 10 cents to settle at $74.64 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 9 cents to settle at $68.10 a barrel. Despite a 0.5% weekly gain for Brent, WTI posted a 0.5% loss. The market is awaiting a decision by US President Donald Trump on May 12 regarding re-imposing sanctions on Iran, which could dampen Iranian oil exports and disrupt global supply.

site_title: Mapletree Investments to build strategic partnership with China's SF Express
summary: Mapletree Investments has entered into a strategic partnership with Chinese courier group SF Express, signing a Cooperation Framework Agreement to collaborate in logistics networks. The partnership aims to provide quality solutions and customisation of warehouse facilities to meet SF Express's business requirements. Mapletree will expand its presence in China, while SF Express is aggressively expanding its overseas business. The partnership is seen as a win-win for both parties, with Mapletree aiming to provide customers with an edge in the competitive logistics industry and SF Express seeking assurance for its business expansion.

site_title: A-HTRUST enters South Korean market with hotel acquisition
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust (A-HTRUST) has entered the South Korean market by acquiring a majority stake in KY-Heritage Hotel Dongdaemun for 72.1 billion won (S$89.5 million). The 215-room hotel, valued at 75.4 billion won, is located in the Dongdaemun area and is expected to be accretive to A-HTRUST's portfolio. The acquisition, fully funded by bank borrowings, is expected to take place by June this year, pending regulatory approvals.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Making the best use of technology and size
summary: Suntec Reit, managed by ARA Trust Management, is transforming its sprawling complex into a community hub leveraging technology and size. CEO Chan Kong Leong aims to improve the shopping experience with features like live chat concierge services and partnerships with Chinese payment service Alipay. The mall also offers amenities such as a convention centre and office space, drawing office tenants and increasing foot traffic. A coworking space is in talks for a location in Suntec City, capitalizing on the complex's potential as a community hub, with synergies between retail, office, and convention segments.

images.alt_text: Mr Chan says that the retail industry - from landlords to retailers - has not been moving quickly enough to restructure business processes in the face of technological upheaval.

site_title: Daimler edges up profit forecast as luxury cars offset spending
summary: Daimler AG has revised its 2018 earnings forecast, citing higher sales growth of its luxury Mercedes-Benz cars, which helped offset record spending on electric vehicle development. The company's Mercedes unit saw a slight increase in return-on-sales to 9% despite a 9.5% jump in spending on new technology. Daimler CEO Dieter Zetsche stated the company will continue its profitable growth course, implementing its strategy to boost sales while adapting to industry-wide technology shifts.

site_title: Knife attacker kills nine children in China
summary: A 28-year-old man in northern China killed nine middle school children and injured at least 10 others after a grudge against his former classmates at the same school. The suspect, Zhao, confessed to using a dagger to kill the children after being bullied in middle school. This is one of the deadliest such rampages in China in recent years, following similar incidents in 2017 and 2018. Authorities have detained the suspect and are treating the injured children.

site_title: General Motors CEO Barra's pay dipped slightly to US$22m in 2017
summary: General Motors CEO Mary Barra's pay dropped to US$21,958,048 in 2017, about US$625,000 less than the previous year. Her compensation package included a salary of US$2.1 million, stock awards worth US$10.74 million, and performance awards worth US$4.96 million. This decrease was attributed to stricter performance targets set by GM's board of directors in 2017. Barra remained the company's highest-paid executive, with President Dan Ammann's pay at US$9,258,318.

images.alt_text: General Motors Co's top executive, Mary Barra, was paid just under US$22 million in 2017, slightly less than the previous year, according to the automaker's proxy statement released on Friday.

site_title: Faldo Series Asia Grand Finals at home with Laguna Lang Co
summary: The Faldo Series Asia Grand Finals will return to the Hue course in Laguna Lang Co for the second consecutive month, showcasing the course's challenging nature. The event highlights the organization's commitment to hosting major tournaments at the course. No further details on the event or participants are provided.

site_title: Airbus keeps plane pricing secrets just a little longer
summary: Airbus has confirmed it sells planes at huge discounts to official prices, but the exact value of its order book remains undisclosed. The European company switched accounting standards, allowing for the disclosure of the backlog value by the end of 2018. Industry experts say discounts typically range from half to no more than the list price, with Airbus' rival Boeing also offering similar discounts. The practice reflects a winner-takes-all mentality, with airlines willing to pay high prices for lucrative relationships that can last decades. Airbus plans to shed more light on its pricing in its 2018 results.

site_title: Judge puts Stormy Daniels' lawsuit against Trump lawyer on hold
summary: A federal judge has ordered a 90-day stay on Stormy Daniels' lawsuit against Trump lawyer Michael Cohen, citing potential overlap between the civil and criminal proceedings that could implicate Cohen's constitutional rights. The lawsuit centers on a $130,000 payment to Daniels, who claims it was made in exchange for her silence about an alleged affair with Trump. Cohen has invoked the Fifth Amendment, stating he will refuse to answer questions in the lawsuit, and the judge believes this could render a deposition useless.

site_title: Is buying and selling at the same time OK?
summary: A financial advisor, George, is accused of engaging in market manipulation by buying and selling the same stock for his clients, distorting trading volume and market prices. This action, although intended to assist a client with a private offering, violates the CFA Institute Code of Ethics and Standards of Professional Conduct. George's dual role as an investment advisor and placement agent creates a conflict of interest, and his actions compromise the integrity of the financial markets, ultimately harming all investors.

site_title: Brazil president angrily rejects latest graft allegations
summary: Brazilian President Michel Temer angrily rejected graft allegations, claiming the reports were "lies against my honour." A police investigation found Temer laundered bribe money through his family's properties, with one of his associates allegedly paying him $766,000 in 2014. Temer's family members, including his wife and son, are suspected of involvement in the alleged money laundering scheme. This comes as dozens of powerful politicians have fallen in the "Car Wash" anti-graft scandal, with ex-president Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva serving a 12-year prison sentence for corruption.

site_title: North Korea says historic summit opens 'new era for peace'
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and South Korean President Moon Jae In signed a historic summit agreement, dubbed the Panmunjom Declaration, on April 27, 2018, marking a new era of peace on the Korean Peninsula. The leaders pledged to pursue a permanent peace, rid the peninsula of nuclear weapons, and work towards a complete denuclearization of the region. However, analysts caution that the agreement's success depends on Kim's willingness to give up his nuclear arsenal and the US's commitment to security guarantees, with a potential summit between Kim and US President Donald Trump looming.

site_title: Supporters hit the streets as Malaysia election campaign to start
summary: Malaysia's election campaign is set to begin on May 9, with Prime Minister Najib Razak facing a tough fight to hold onto power due to the 1MDB scandal. Najib's long-ruling Barisan Nasional (BN) coalition is tipped to win, despite a weakened opposition and allegations of vote-rigging. Veteran ex-leader Mahathir Mohamad, 92, has joined forces with the opposition, criticizing Najib's handling of justice and corruption. Candidates registered to run in the election, with 222 parliamentary seats up for grabs, and campaigning is set to officially start later this month.

site_title: Maduro says Venezuela to get US$1b injection from 'bitcoin' sale
summary: Venezuela's President Nicolas Maduro announced the release of US$1 billion into the economy through the sale of its cryptocurrency, the petro. The funds will aim to boost international reserves and halt the rise of the black market dollar. The move comes as the country faces a worsening liquidity crisis and must pay off US$8 billion this year, despite having the world's largest proven crude oil deposits. Maduro attributed the funds to US$3.3 billion from petro sales, with US$1 billion set aside for imports and US$1 billion for the Central Bank.

site_title: Tainted lettuce in US sickens 98
summary: An E. coli outbreak linked to tainted romaine lettuce has sickened 98 people in 22 US states, with 46 hospitalized and 10 in kidney failure. The outbreak, the largest in the US since 2006, has prompted the CDC to advise consumers not to eat or buy romaine lettuce unless it was not grown in the Yuma, Arizona area. Experts have identified one farm, Harrison Farm, as a potential source, and are investigating two dozen other farms in the area. Symptoms of the illness include diarrhea, stomach cramps, and vomiting.

site_title: Accused 'Golden State Killer' charged with two counts of murder
summary: Joseph James DeAngelo, 72, was charged with two counts of murder in connection with the 1978 killings of Brian and Katie Maggiore in Rancho Cordova, California. DeAngelo, a former California policeman, was arrested after a 40-year manhunt and is suspected in 10 other murders, over 50 rapes, and 150 burglaries. He was charged using DNA evidence linked to genealogy databases. DeAngelo appeared frail in court, wearing an orange jumpsuit and handcuffed to a wheelchair, and was appointed a public defender. His next court appearance is set for May.

site_title: Deutsche Bank likely to axe 1,000 US investment bank jobs: source
summary: Deutsche Bank is expected to cut around 1,000 US investment bank jobs, approximately 10% of its workforce, as the bank scales back its global investment banking ambitions. The bank has already axed 400 US-based employees, mostly in trading and corporate finance. Moody's changed its outlook to "negative" on some Deutsche Bank ratings, citing strategic turmoil and uncertainty about the bank's ability to compete effectively. The bank's shares fell 3.4% on Friday, and credit ratings agencies have cut their estimates for Deutsche Bank's revenue.

site_title: US: Stocks little changed on mixed earnings
summary: US stocks ended the day little changed on Friday, following mixed corporate earnings and a better-than-expected report on first-quarter US economic growth, which came in at 2.3% for the January-March period. Amazon surged 3.6% after reporting a 2-fold increase in quarterly profit, while Expedia jumped 8.2% on a 15% revenue rise. ExxonMobil fell 3.8% despite a 16% increase in net income, and US Steel dropped 14.2% due to operational issues.

site_title: S&P, Fitch stay negative on British debt on Brexit questions
summary: Ratings agencies S&P and Fitch have maintained a "negative" outlook on British debt due to lingering uncertainty surrounding the Brexit process. Despite an affirmation of the UK's 'AA' high-grade rating, the agencies express concerns over the risk of sustained economic weakness if the country loses access to European markets or experiences a loss of confidence in its economy. The UK economy has shown resilience since the 2016 referendum, but growth is expected to slow in the short-term before picking up again in 2019.

site_title: The classic course at Laguna National
summary: The article discusses the challenging Classic course at Laguna National in Singapore, where only a few golfers have successfully navigated its difficulties. The course is renowned for its demanding layout and precise requirements, making it a prestigious achievement for those who have "played well" on it. The article does not provide further details on specific events or conclusions.

site_title: PM Lee: Singapore hopes to develop consensus on overall approach to regional issues
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said the country hopes to develop a consensus on an overall approach to regional issues during its chairmanship of Asean, focusing on creating a more resilient and innovative grouping. He emphasized the need to tackle shared concerns like terrorism, climate change, and cybersecurity. The 32nd Asean summit will discuss regional priorities, opportunities, and challenges, including maritime cooperation and security in the South China Sea.

site_title: Talent in schools unearthed at Orchid venue
summary: Singapore's future golf talent was showcased at the National Schools Games Golf Championships at Orchid Country Club. On the second day, Sean Lee achieved an eight-under 65, highlighting the country's potential golfers. This event underscores the growth of golf in Singapore's schools, providing a platform for young golfers to develop their skills and compete at a high level.

site_title: Europe: Shares post fifth week of gains as earnings gather pace
summary: European shares rose for a fifth consecutive week, driven by strong earnings from Spanish banks and tech stocks. The Stoxx 600 index gained 0.2%, with BBVA and Caixabank rising 2.4% and 1.7%, respectively. Neste led gains, up 10.2%, after increasing guidance on margins. Tech stocks also rose, with Facebook, Amazon, and Microsoft beating first-quarter expectations. Despite a decline in RBS, concerns about global trade and geopolitics have been pushed aside by the earnings season, with nearly 60% of companies beating or meeting analyst expectations.

site_title: Private home rents on the mend, with some help from en bloc sellers
summary: Singapore's private home rents rose 0.3% in Q1 2018, ending 17 quarters of contraction or zero growth, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority. The increase is attributed to the en bloc sale market and low project completions, which pushed vacancies down and rents up. Experts predict muted growth in residential leasing demand from expatriates, but a 4-8% year-on-year rise in rentals for 2018, with rents stabilizing and recovering by 2% in the second half of the year.

site_title: MYP unit to sell MYP Plaza at 135 Cecil Street for S$247m
summary: MYP unit sells MYP Plaza in Singapore for S$247 million to a buyer affiliated with Filipino billionaire Lucio Tan. The 14-storey freehold office tower has a net lettable area of 82,334.28 sq ft and is located in the central business district. The sale price is considered arm's length and maximizes shareholder interests, but the deal is subject to an eight-week due diligence exercise and a definitive agreement.

site_title: Reits
summary: Real estate markets continue to show signs of resilience. In Singapore, the Q3 condo launch wave is expected to test demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark. US mortgage rates have climbed after five weeks of declines, while Manhattan rents reached a record high. In the UK, homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. Meanwhile, WeWork secured new tenants and filled more space at 21 Collyer Quay in Singapore after its bankruptcy. Goldman Sachs acquired a significant hotel and retail portfolio in Seoul.

site_title: Sheng Siong posts rise in Q1 net profit
summary: Sheng Siong Group, a Singaporean supermarket operator, reported a 6.6% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$18.25 million for the Q1 period, driven by a 5.1% rise in revenue. Despite a 4.6% decline in retail floor space, the company opened four new stores and won bids for two more, with expected contributions in the second half of the year. The group remains committed to enhancing its gross margin through initiatives to increase fresh produce sales and reduce input costs.

site_title: Weighing in on sweet slumber
summary: Weighted blankets, also known as gravity blankets, have gained popularity in the US as a therapeutic tool for calming individuals with sensory issues and promoting better sleep. These blankets, filled with glass or plastic pellets, provide a sensation similar to being hugged or held, and can help switch the body's nervous system from fight-or-flight to rest-and-digest. Research has shown that weighted blankets can be beneficial for insomnia and mild sleep problems, and they are now being used by adults seeking better sleep, not just those with anxiety.

site_title: Singapore's outlook this year still positive despite trade risks: MAS
summary: Singapore's economic outlook remains positive despite global trade risks, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). The central bank expects full-year GDP growth to be slightly above the middle of the 1.5-3.5% range, with trade-linked sectors anchoring growth. The MAS also expects labour market conditions to improve, despite weak employment figures in the first quarter. However, economists note that the labour market bears watching and that a loss of confidence in trade could curb investment and hit consumer spending.

site_title: North, South Korea to work towards ending Korean War
summary: North and South Korean leaders have agreed to work towards ending the Korean War, pledging to pursue phased arms reduction, cease hostile acts, and establish a permanent peace zone along the border. The two sides also agreed to open a liaison office, allow families divided by the border to meet, and seek multilateral talks with the US and other countries. A joint declaration was signed, promising a new era of peace, and South Korean President Moon Jae In will visit the North Korean capital of Pyongyang this year. The move comes weeks before a meeting between Kim Jong Un and US President Donald Trump.

site_title: UIC Q1 net profit rises 1% to S$60.24m
summary: United Industrial Corporation (UIC) reported a 1% increase in net profit to S$60.24 million for the first quarter ended March 31, despite a 37% drop in revenue to S$165.65 million. The decline in revenue was attributed to lower sales recognition from trading properties. However, costs decreased by 43% to S$4.93 million, and the group's share of results of associated companies and joint ventures surged 197% to S$9.99 million. UIC's property portfolio in Singapore and overseas remains a key focus, with plans to build up a residential land bank in a competitive market.

site_title: Singapore office market continues recovery in Q1: URA
summary: The Singapore office market experienced a recovery in the first quarter of 2018, with the Central Region's rental index rising 2.6% year-over-year and marking the third consecutive quarterly increase. The cumulative recovery is 7.7% in less than a year. Experts attribute the growth to improved sentiments, healthy pre-commitment by tenants, and a limited supply of new CBD projects. The islandwide vacancy rate decreased to 12.5% and office rents are expected to continue growing until the next supply influx post-2020.

site_title: Local retail property market shows signs of emerging from a slump, but strong rebound not expected
summary: Singapore's retail property market appears to be emerging from a slump, with the Urban Redevelopment Authority's retail price and rental indices entering positive territory for the first time in three years. The market has stabilized, with vacancy rates at 8.1% and a slight increase in rental indices. However, experts predict a moderate and sustainable growth in the mid- to long term, with a possible equalization of demand and supply in the next few years. Prime retail spaces remain highly sought after, but secondary corridors and floors may face occupancy pressures.

site_title: LHN acquires Cambodian condominium block for US$12.5m
summary: LHN Limited has acquired a Cambodian condominium block for US$12.5 million, comprising 108 freehold apartment units in Phnom Penh. The acquisition will be financed from internal resources and bank borrowings, with progressive payments made as the structure is completed. LHN plans to operate the units as serviced residences under the 85SOHO brand, aiming to broaden its property portfolio and increase brand value. The deal is subject to obtaining sufficient bank financing, board and shareholder approval, and completion of the property by December this year.

site_title: Boss Baby
summary: The Mercedes-Benz A-Class has undergone significant refinement and technological advancements, making it an exciting new model. As the "baby Benz," the A-Class has a rich history, dating back to the W201 190 E in the 1980s, which later evolved into the C-Class. The new A-Class features advanced technology and innovative design, catering to the needs of modern drivers. Its features include a responsive and intelligent interface, allowing for a more engaging driving experience. The A-Class is poised to become a leading model in its class, offering a unique blend of style, performance, and technology.

site_title: Baidu forecasts higher Q2 sales, surpassing analysts' estimates
summary: Baidu forecasts higher Q2 sales, surpassing analysts' estimates, with revenue predicted at 24.91-26.19 billion yuan, beating the 24.3 billion yuan average estimate. Advertisers are flocking to its news aggregation service, and its Netflix-style video service attracted more subscribers. The forecast is a confidence-booster for the company as it enters a critical year, with plans to streamline operations and focus on artificial intelligence products.

site_title: When football fans are the biggest winners
summary: Singaporean football fans will not face price hikes for this year's World Cup, thanks to a joint bid by Singtel, Starhub, and Mediacorp. The subscription price remains the same as in 2014, with a full package costing S$94.16 (around S$1.47 per match). The decision marks the first time there has been no price hike since paid World Cup subscriptions were introduced in 2002, and Mediacorp will show nine games on its free-to-air okto channel.

summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong hopes to develop a consensus on an overall approach to regional issues during his chairmanship of Asean, despite not expecting all issues to be resolved. The country aims to create a more "resilient and innovative" Asean through tangible initiatives, focusing on transboundary threats, technology, and innovation to improve people's lives. The 32nd Asean summit is being held with leaders from 10 member states, discussing regional priorities, opportunities, and challenges, including maritime cooperation, security, and humanitarian crises.

site_title: Income diversifier enters the local scene
summary: BlackRock's Dynamic High Income fund offers diversification to income-focused investors by investing in complementary and less commonly owned assets. The fund limits traditional sources of yield to 30% and invests primarily in non-traditional assets, including covered call writing, global Reits, and institutional preferred equities. Its portfolio allocation as of end-March includes 30% in covered calls, 20% in high-yield bonds, and 17% in institutional preferred equities, with an underlying yield of approximately 7% per annum. The fund's strategy aims for a 70% equity-30% bond portfolio risk profile, offering investors a way to diversify their income-generating assets.

site_title: SPH Golf April Medal
summary: The SPH Golf April Medal took place at the 36-hole golf club, which will close in July for the KL-Singapore High-Speed Rail project. Details on the event are not provided in the article.

site_title: Court blocks Noble's planned AGM for Monday
summary: The High Court in Singapore has blocked Noble Group's planned annual general meeting (AGM) for Monday, allowing a legal challenge by its third-largest shareholder, Goldilocks Investment Company, to proceed. Goldilocks welcomed the decision, citing concerns that Noble's proposed restructuring plan would move the firm's centre of main interest to the UK. Noble's aborted AGM would have included an election of nominated directors to the board, and a separate shareholders' meeting will be held to vote on a restructuring support agreement. Noble's creditors' ad hoc group plans to select new board members, with management to be compensated through equity and cash bonuses.

site_title: The cola wars are back in full swing
summary: The "Cola Wars" are resuming between PepsiCo and Coca-Cola as the two companies invest in their beverage divisions amid declining soda consumption. Despite PepsiCo's diversification into snacks, its cola brands remain vital, and the company plans to increase advertising to regain market share. Coca-Cola reported a boost in results from its trademark Coke brands, including Diet Coke. Both companies aim to outdo each other, with PepsiCo's CEO Indra Nooyi vowing to "fix" the company's cola division and increase media spending.

site_title: Being Jeff Bezos means never apologising about profits
summary: Amazon reported a 3.8% operating profit margin in its latest quarter, the highest since 2016, despite spending heavily on new ventures. The company's core operating costs grew 50% year-over-year, but its gross profit margin nearly doubled to 40%. Amazon's growth in higher-margin businesses, such as cloud computing and Prime subscriptions, is expected to continue, making it a fundamentally more profitable company. The company's shares rose 6% in after-hours trading, driven by investor enthusiasm for its expanding profits.

site_title: Q1 retrenchments in Singapore lowest in nearly 7 years: MOM
summary: Singapore's labor market showed slight improvements in the first quarter of 2018, with the lowest number of retrenchments in nearly seven years, at 2,100. The overall unemployment rate of residents fell to 2%, down from 2.1% in the preceding quarter, while the resident unemployment rate of citizens remained at 3%. Total employment contracted by 2,100, primarily due to a decrease in work-permit holders in construction and marine shipyard sectors.

site_title: SIA bringing back non-stop flights to New York before year-end
summary: Singapore Airlines plans to restart non-stop flights to New York before the end of the year, reclaiming its title of the world's longest flight. The airline has ordered the ultra-long-range (ULR) variant of Airbus' A350, which completed its first flight, and will offer 162 seats across two classes for the 19-hour flight. This move follows the success of its non-stop service to San Francisco, launched last year, and comes as fuel efficiencies and easing jet-fuel prices make long-haul services more feasible.

site_title: James Cameron is keeping himself busy
summary: James Cameron is juggling multiple projects, including four Avatar sequels, a Terminator reboot, and a documentary series "James Cameron's Story of Science Fiction" on AMC. The series explores the evolution of science fiction, featuring interviews with creators and stars of iconic films like War of the Worlds, Close Encounters of the Third Kind, and Avatar. Cameron credits 2001: A Space Odyssey as the film that made him a filmmaker, and he discusses the challenges of making science fiction seem fresh, particularly with the Terminator franchise.

site_title: Women entrepreneurs can leverage their gender
summary: Women entrepreneurs should leverage their gender to gain advantages in the business world, according to a panel discussion at the Female Founders Debate Series. Panelists, including venture capitalists and female founders, emphasized that being a female founder can lead to unique opportunities, such as attracting other females to join their companies. However, they also acknowledged that female entrepreneurs may need to adapt to a male-dominated environment to achieve success. The discussion highlighted the importance of authenticity and being true to oneself, rather than trying to emulate men.

site_title: Broker's take
summary: TalkMed Group reported a weak Q1 2018 due to the Singapore Medical Council's suspension of its CEO, but reduced losses from associates by 60% year-over-year. site_title: Blockchain comes to ridehailing
summary: MVL, a blockchain-based ridehailing company, has announced plans to charge zero commission on all rides, aiming to disrupt the traditional commission-based model. Founded by South Korean entrepreneur Kay Woo, MVL claims to be a not-for-profit company, with a blockchain platform that tracks and gathers data on vehicle activity, promoting transparency and trust among consumers. Riders and drivers will be rewarded with cryptocurrency for rating and driving safely, respectively. MVL plans to expand its services to include bike and motorcycle sharing, and is not the only blockchain-based ridehailing player in the market, with Dacsee also launching in Singapore.

site_title: Valuetronics drops 8 per cent; brokers maintain 'buy' calls
summary: Valuetronics, a Singapore-based electronics manufacturing services provider, experienced a 25% drop over two days before closing at 68 cents per share, a 8% decline. The Singapore Exchange issued a query due to the unusual price movement. Despite this, brokers CGS-CIMB and Maybank maintained "buy" calls, citing potential catalysts such as stronger earnings delivery and new customer wins. They also noted that the company's dividend yield is attractive, with a 5% yield for FY18-20F.

site_title: Technology's increasingly vital role in medicine
summary: A recent article highlights the growing importance of technology in medicine, but also emphasizes the irreplaceable value of human empathy in healthcare. Advances in artificial intelligence, electronic health records, and telemedicine have the potential to revolutionize the medical field, but doctors will not become obsolete. Instead, technology will enhance their work, freeing them to focus on patient care. The article cites examples of AI-powered diagnosis, medical robots, and electronic health records, but notes that personal data must be protected and regulated to ensure its safe use. Ultimately, the goal should be to harness technology to create a compassionate and caring society.

site_title: 26-year-old shining example of Singapore craftsmanship
summary: Singaporean shoe-shiner John Chung, 26, has won the world championship in the latest edition of the World Shoe-Shining Competition. Chung, owner of the shoe-shine bar Mason and Smith, beat two other experienced competitors with his unique technique of applying wax and polishing leather for 10 minutes. Chung, who started his career in shoe-shining just four years ago, credits his unconventional method for achieving a high shine. He now works with a team and plans to open his own flagship store and bespoke label in the future.

site_title: Office politics: Taking the bull by the horns
summary: A workplace expert shares advice on navigating difficult colleagues and bosses. To improve relationships, consider the other person's perspective and try to find common ground. For challenging bosses, approach them with empathy and ask for advice, rather than making the situation worse. When dealing with a team that's ganging up on an individual, identify the ringleader and try to build a relationship with them. Effective leaders should be sensitive to their subordinates' needs and establish authority to handle difficult situations. Ultimately, finding a balance between being assertive and avoiding confrontation is key to success in the workplace.

images.alt_text: Reaching out to a difficult colleague or manager is the best way to put forward your thoughts and attempt to find a resolution before the situation spirals out of control.

site_title: STI up by a hair's breadth on general goodwill
summary: The Straits Times Index gained 7.19 points, or 0.2%, to 3,577.21, driven by positive news on the domestic and international fronts. The property market showed fast-rising private home prices, sustained office rents, and a possible turnaround in the retail segment. The Monetary Authority of Singapore maintained a positive outlook on the economy, despite geopolitical tensions. Gainers beat losers 243 to 191, while stocks like Genting Singapore and Singtel rose, while Venture Corporation and Marco Polo Marine fell.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Singapore start-ups in Thailand get a leg up with new alliance
summary: Singapore has launched the Global Innovation Alliance (GIA) Bangkok, a partnership fostering digital economy connections between Singapore and Thailand. The alliance aims to accelerate digital businesses and provide opportunities for Singaporean startups to tap into Thailand's growing market, which has 2 million online shoppers daily. The partnership includes 10 Memoranda of Understanding (MOUs) to create market access, drive partnerships, and build entrepreneurial talent, with the goal of increasing Thailand's digital market from $50 billion in 2017 to $200 billion by 2025.

site_title: Outlook sunny for private residential market after Q1, but all eyes on big supply pipeline
summary: Analysts remain bullish on Singapore's private residential market after a 3.9% price increase in Q1, but are cautious about the massive supply pipeline and whether demand can keep up. The upcoming Q3 wave of condo launches, particularly in prime projects above $3,000 psf, will test demand. Analysts are split on whether demand can absorb the supply boom.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 11.20 points to 1,863.47 on Friday, driven by a volume of 1.63 billion lots worth RM1.87 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 452 to 338.

site_title: Q1 GDP growth down but better-than-expected at 2.3%
summary: US Q1 GDP growth slowed to 2.3% in the first quarter of 2018, down from 2.9% in the previous quarter, but better than expected. The decline was attributed to weaker exports, consumer spending, and home buying. Despite the weaker growth, economists say statistical anomalies may have contributed to the weakness, suggesting the economy's expansion remains uninterrupted. The outcome may offer relief to the White House, but economists warn that the current pace of growth is likely above potential, making sustained growth of 3% unrealistic.

site_title: Central bankers can't agree on regulations for cryptocurrencies
summary: Central bankers struggle to agree on regulations for cryptocurrencies due to differing approaches. Despite a consensus that privately issued cryptocurrencies won't replace traditional currencies, coordination on the regulatory front is required due to their cross-border nature. The IMF's Global Financial Stability Report noted that cryptocurrencies have limitations in serving as a medium of exchange and unit of account, citing their volatility and limited use as a store of value. The lack of consensus hinders the effectiveness of any rules or regulations for cryptocurrencies.

site_title: Showcasing South East Asia's best golf destinations
summary: The inaugural "Showcasing South East Asia's best golf destinations" fair was held, featuring over 30 golf clubs from Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand, and the Philippines. The event also included exhibitors like TaylorMade, adidas Golf, and Prudential. This golf-centric travel fair is the first of its kind in the region, aiming to promote South East Asia's best golf destinations to golf enthusiasts.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, April 27, 2018, as the American economy cooled less-than-expected in the first quarter. The S&P 500 Index rose 0.2%, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average remained little changed and the Nasdaq Composite Index increased 0.8%.

site_title: YuuZoo chairman steps down amid CAD investigation
summary: YuuZoo Corporation's chairman Thomas Zilliacus has resigned amid an investigation by the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) on possible breaches of the Securities and Futures Act. The investigation was triggered by a complaint from an unknown party. Zilliacus will continue working under a consultancy agreement with Mobile FutureWorks Inc, focusing on managing overseas deals. The company has also asked MFW to assist in building and overseeing overseas joint ventures and franchisee operations. Zilliacus believes stepping aside is the honourable thing to do while the investigation is ongoing.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: European economy loses thrust in risk for global expansion
summary: Europe's economy lost momentum in the first quarter, with expansions slowing from France to the UK, threatening global growth. The European Central Bank acknowledged the shift, and a similar slowdown emerged in the UK, prompting investors to slash bets on an interest-rate increase. The slowdown is partly due to storms, but also due to underlying economic issues. The pound plunged against the dollar, and European equities underperformed, while the euro rose 11% against the dollar in the past year. The International Monetary Fund maintains its forecast for the strongest expansion since 2011, but rising oil prices and trade war fears threaten this outlook.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Q1 bottom line falls 11% to 595m yuan
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding recorded a 10.9% fall in net profit to 595.1 million yuan in Q1 2018, mainly due to the appreciation of the Chinese renminbi and increase in raw material prices. Revenue expanded 6% to 4.96 billion yuan despite a lower number of vessels delivered. The company's earnings per share decreased to 14.99 fen from 17.42 fen in the preceding year.

site_title: It's Prince Louis Arthur Charles
summary: Prince William and his wife Kate have named their newborn son Louis Arthur Charles, who was born on April 23, 2018. He is the fifth in line to the British throne and weighed 8 lbs 7oz at birth.

site_title: Firms that cut dividends can be attractive income investments
summary: Companies that cut their dividends can be attractive income investments, as trying to maintain unsustainable high levels can harm the company in the long-term. Dividend cuts can be a sign of financial stability and a decision to reinvest profits. Long-term investors may view dividend cuts as a positive move, as it allows the company to protect its balance sheet and invest in the business. Short-term investors may sell shares after a dividend cut, creating opportunities for long-term investors to buy at a lower price, potentially leading to a rising share price and growing dividend payments.

site_title: US rejects plan to break trade court deadlock
summary: The US has rejected a proposal by 66 World Trade Organization (WTO) members to break a deadlock in the Dispute Settlement Body (DSB) court, citing its inability to accept the appointment of new judges. The deadlock, triggered by the US's refusal to sign off on new judges, could cripple the WTO's ability to resolve disputes and has been exacerbated by President Trump's trade policies. The WTO needs at least three judges to hear cases, and if no replacements are agreed, the court will stop functioning by the end of next year.

site_title: Frasers Property unit to acquire 75% stake in Vietnamese property firm for 409b dong
summary: Frasers Property Investments (Vietnam) 1 has entered into a conditional share purchase agreement to acquire a 75% stake in Vietnamese property firm Phu An Khang Real Estate Joint Stock Company (PAK) for 408.6 billion dong (S$23.9 million). The acquisition is expected to be funded by internal cash resources and/or external bank borrowings. Upon completion, PAK will develop a residential-cum-commercial project in Ho Chi Minh City and become a subsidiary of Frasers.

site_title: Singapore hopes to develop consensus on an overall approach to Asean's challenges: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong hopes to develop a consensus on an overall approach to ASEAN's challenges during his chairmanship of the regional grouping. He expressed optimism about tackling shared concerns such as terrorism, climate change, and cybersecurity. The summit will focus on regional priorities, opportunities, and challenges, including maritime cooperation and security in the South China Sea. Leaders are expected to endorse and release statements, as well as agree on details of the Asean smart cities network, a flagship initiative of Singapore's chairmanship.

site_title: ABBA reunite with two new songs after 35 years
summary: ABBA, the legendary Swedish disco group, has reunited after 35 years to record two new songs, "I Still Have Faith In You" and an unnamed track. The group, consisting of Agnetha Faltskog, Bjorn Ulvaeus, Anni-Frid Lyngstad, and Benny Andersson, announced the reunion in a statement, stating they felt it was time to join forces again. The new songs will be performed by computerized avatars in a TV special, marking the group's first time singing together on stage since 1986.

images.alt_text: (FILE) (L-R) Swedish pop group ABBA members: Benny Andersson, Anni-Frid Lyngstad, Agnetha Faltskog and Bjorn Ulvaeus posing after winning the Swedish branch of the Eurovision Song Contest with their song 'Waterloo' in Stockholm, Sweden, 09 February 1974. PHOTO: AFP

site_title: Kobe Steel posts first profit in three years despite data fraud scandal
summary: Kobe Steel Ltd, Japan's third-largest steelmaker, reported its first annual profit in three years despite admitting to falsifying quality data. The company posted a profit of 63.19 billion yen for the year ended March 31, exceeding forecasts. However, the scandal affected earnings, cutting profit by about 12 billion yen in the previous year and 10 billion yen in the next year. Despite this, sales rose over 10% to 1.9 trillion yen, and the company predicts a 45 billion yen profit for the year to March 2019.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks, won rise on hopes of improved inter-Korean relations
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 16.97 points, or 0.69%, to 2,491.97 on Friday, driven by improved sentiment following the first summit between North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and South Korean President Moon Jae In. The Korean won gained, while bond yields fell. Shares of Samsung Electronics gained 1.6% ahead of a three-day halt before a 50:1 stock split.

site_title: US consumer sentiment exceeds forecast
summary: US consumer sentiment exceeded forecasts in April, driven by favorable views of finances and recent tax legislation. The sentiment index fell to 98.8, reflecting negative sentiment about tariffs, but 40% of respondents expected income gains. The elevated sentiment, combined with tax cuts and solid business investment, bodes well for consumer spending growth. This is consistent with a 2.7% real personal consumption increase forecasted for the coming year, and inflation expectations of 2.5% over the next five years.

site_title: GL Limited posts higher Q3 net profit
summary: GL Limited reported a 5.5-fold increase in Q3 net profit to US$24 million, driven by a 9% year-on-year rise in revenue to US$74.3 million. Earnings per share jumped to 1.9 US cents. The company attributed the boost to a US$25.9 million rise in other operating income due to compensation from a hotel property acquisition and the recovery of a written-off legacy loan. Despite a challenging London hotel market, GL maintained a cautious outlook and expects the market to not grow significantly.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's economic outlook for 2018 remains positive, with full-year GDP growth expected to be "slightly above the middle of the forecast range" of 1.5-3.5%. The country's private home prices rose 3.9% in the latest quarter, the steepest gain since 2010. Meanwhile, Singapore Airlines plans to launch the world's longest non-stop flights by end-2018, with a route to New York in 19 hours.

site_title: Tuan Sing's Q1 bottom line rises 53% to S$8.2m on one-off gain from divestment
summary: Tuan Sing Holdings reported a 53.5% surge in net profit to S$8.2 million in Q1, driven by a one-off gain of S$3.9 million from divestment of a Chinese subsidiary. Revenue grew 2.2% to S$76.5 million, with higher revenue from the industrial services segment offsetting lower residential development sales. Net asset value per share edged up to 83.6 Singapore cents, with shares finishing 1.2% up at S$0.43.

site_title: A Nobel prize for Trump and Kim is no joke
summary: US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un are favored to win the Nobel Peace Prize this year, with odds of 2/1, according to Coral bookmaker. Their historic talks and potential peace deal on the Korean peninsula make them deserving of the award. This unexpected development highlights the possibility of celebrating individuals who, despite being considered "nasty" or "ruthless," can take actions that make the world safer. Their actions may form their principal legacy and warrant recognition.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust to acquire industrial property at Tai Seng Drive
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) has acquired an industrial property at 7 Tai Seng Drive for S$68 million from Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT). The property will be upgraded into a high-specification building and fully leased to an "established information and communication technology company" for 25 years with annual rental escalations. This acquisition is part of MIT's efforts to expand its portfolio and increase its rental income.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Two Koreas agree to end war this year, pursue denuclearisation
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and South Korean President Moon Jae-in agreed to end the seven-decade war this year and pursue complete denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula. They announced plans to hold military talks and seek a phased disarmament, aiming to formally declare a resolution to the war and replace the 1953 armistice with a peace treaty by year's end. The agreement follows a rapid thaw of tensions after North Korean missile tests and a hydrogen bomb detonation last year, with Kim set to meet US President Donald Trump soon.

site_title: Sheng Siong posts 6.6% Q1 profit growth on revenue rise, better margins
summary: Sheng Siong Group, a Singapore-based supermarket operator, reported a 6.6% year-on-year profit growth in the first quarter to March 31, driven by a 5.1% increase in revenue and improved margins. The company's gross margin improved to 26.2% due to higher sales of fresh products and rebates from suppliers. Despite higher operating costs, Sheng Siong remains committed to expanding its network of outlets in Singapore and building its brand in China.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Yeo Hiap Seng Q1 net profit falls to S$1.4m on absence of one-off gain from disposal of investment in Super Group
summary: Yeo Hiap Seng's Q1 net profit fell to S$1.4 million due to the absence of a S$138.35 million gain from its disposal of Super Group investment. Revenue increased 12.1% to S$91.8 million, driven by higher Chinese New Year sales. Earnings per share dropped to 0.23 Singapore cents from 24.27 Singapore cents in the year-ago period. The company's net asset value per share edged up to 113.57 Singapore cents.

site_title: UIC reports 1% improvement in Q1 net profit to S$60.24m
summary: UNITED Industrial Corporation (UIC) reported a 1% increase in Q1 net profit to S$60.24 million, despite a 37% drop in revenue to S$165.65 million due to lower sales recognition from trading properties. Lower selling and distribution costs, as well as the absence of a one-off payment, cushioned the decline. UIC's share of results from joint ventures surged 197%, driven by the contribution from The Clement Canopy residential project. The company expects to build up its residential land bank and upgrade existing offices to meet changing working requirements.

site_title: Jiutian Q1 net profit almost quadruples to 23.4m yuan on higher chemical prices
summary: Jiutian Chemical Group Limited reported a 94% increase in its first quarter net profit to 23.4 million yuan, driven by higher chemical prices. Revenue rose 20.5% to 326 million yuan. CEO Zhou Hongxuan attributed the improvement to investments in environmental protection, allowing the company to operate efficiently under stringent Chinese environmental requirements. The company's shares ended 2.7% higher at S$1.15.

site_title: JTC awards tenders for Tuas industrial sites to Soilbuild Group, Bonco Enterprise
summary: JTC awards tenders for two industrial sites in Tuas to Bonco Enterprise and Soilbuild Group Holdings. Bonco won the 6,280 sq m site for S$2.8 million, while Soilbuild secured the 27,180 sq m site for S$29.9 million. Both sites are zoned for Business-2 development and have a tenure of 20-30 years. The awards come as industrial prices and rentals remain relatively stable, with occupancy rates at 89%. JTC expects prices and rentals to stabilize as new supply tapers in the coming years.

site_title: Ascendas Hospitality Trust acquires hotel in South Korea
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust acquired a majority stake in KY-Heritage Hotel Dongdaemun in South Korea for KRW72.1 billion (S$89 million), holding a 98.7% stake in the 215-room hotel. The acquisition is expected to be accretive, with a pro forma net property income yield of 4.1% and a 3.2% discount to the hotel's latest valuation. The hotel is located in the prominent Dongdaemun area and is expected to be fully funded by debt, with completion expected by June this year. The acquisition aligns with A-HTrust's strategy to invest in sound hospitality markets.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: US economy grew 2.3% in Q1
summary: The US economy grew at a 2.3% annual rate in Q1, below the 2.9% rate in the previous quarter and falling short of President Trump's 3% goal. Despite expectations of slower growth, economists remain optimistic for the rest of the year, with most forecasting a 3% annualized rate. The tax overhaul's effects may be blunted by delays in implementing changes, and business spending may be influenced by medium-term incentives rather than immediate investment decisions. The Federal Reserve is expected to maintain its interest rate hike timetable, despite some economists warning against rapid rate increases.

site_title: Singapore court halts Noble Group's shareholder meeting on Monday: lawyer
summary: A Singapore court blocked Noble Group's annual shareholder meeting on Monday due to a lawsuit filed by dissident shareholder Goldilocks Investment Co Ltd. The court's decision prevents Noble from proceeding with its debt restructuring plan, which includes halving debt and handing over a 70% equity stake to senior creditors. Goldilocks opposes the plan, claiming it prioritizes creditors over shareholders. Noble had previously rejected Goldilocks' nomination of directors and is pursuing a US$3.4 billion debt rescue plan.

site_title: UK house prices edge up in April, seen slow in 2018-Nationwide
summary: UK house prices rose 2.6% in the year to April, matching median forecast expectations, after touching a seven-month low in March. The growth is slower than before the 2016 Brexit vote, with Nationwide predicting 1% growth in 2018. A shortage of homes for sale is expected to continue to support the market, while interest rate hikes by the Bank of England could further slow growth.

site_title: Daimler sees currency effects tempering Mercedes revenue growth
summary: Daimler reported a 12% decline in first-quarter operating profit due to currency effects and the absence of one-off gains. The company now expects a €1 billion hit from the strong euro this year. Despite this, Daimler stuck to its full-year earnings targets. The strong euro also impacted earnings at French rival Renault and auto supplier Continental. Currency burdens are expected to cause a significant hit to Mercedes-Benz Cars' revenue growth this year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end week on positive note
summary: Hong Kong's stocks ended the week on a positive note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.91% to close at 30,280.67. Energy firms led the gains, mirroring oil price increases. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose, driven by investor optimism from Wall Street and favorable market sentiment.

site_title: BreadTalk to open 1st Din Tai Fung restaurant in London by end-2018
summary: The BreadTalk Group will open its first Din Tai Fung restaurant in London by the end of 2018, at Covent Garden in the West End. This marks the brand's entry into the UK market, following a franchise agreement announced in November 2016. A second location is planned at Centre Point. The move is part of a joint venture between BreadTalk's subsidiary Together Inc and Din Tai Fung Restaurant Co, with other partners involved. The first London restaurant is expected to deliver a customer experience tailored to fans in the city.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Continental profit drops as shareholders discuss revamp
summary: Continental, a German automotive supplier, reported a 9% decline in adjusted quarterly underlying profit to €1.06 billion due to exchange rate effects. The company now expects the adjusted EBIT margin to be above 10%, down from 10.5% previously forecast. Continental is also considering a possible structural overhaul, including listing or spinning off divisions, which could result in more independent units for its powertrain, electronics, and rubber operations.

site_title: Europe: Shares eye fifth week of gains as results season gathers pace
summary: European shares rose for a fifth consecutive week, driven by strong results from Spanish banks and a recovery in tech stocks. The pan-European STOXX 600 index increased 0.2% and Germany's DAX rose 0.8%. Key performers included BBVA and Caixabank, while RBS fell 0.5% after its first-quarter update. Industrial stocks like St Gobain and SES also saw significant gains, with SES rising nearly 13% after beating first-quarter expectations.

site_title: Australian shares at 6-week high on strong health care sector; NZ jumps
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% to a six-week high, driven by a strong healthcare sector. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached its highest since March 19, with healthcare stocks like CSL Ltd and Cochlear Ltd leading gains. The benchmark also rose 1.4% for the week, its largest since February. New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index firmed 1.1% and gained 0.6% for the week, with healthcare stocks and industrials contributing to the gains.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Trek 2000, YZJ Shipbuilding, GuocoLand, BRC Asia, Jardine C&C
summary: Singapore stocks faced new developments on Friday, with several key companies seeing changes. Trek 2000 International's CEO Henn Tan faces a vote on his continued appointment, and the Singapore Exchange has instructed the company to review its corporate governance practices. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 10.9% fall in net profit due to currency fluctuations and raw material price increases. GuocoLand's third-quarter net profit rose 7% despite revenue decline, while BRC Asia's voluntary offer to buy Lee Metal Group was approved by the Competition and Consumer Commission. Jardine Cycle and Carriage's net profit plummeted 36% due to fair-value losses.

site_title: MAS announces senior management changes
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced changes to its senior management team, effective June 1, 2018. Ng Nam Sin, assistant managing director of Corporate, Human Resource and IT Services, will lead the Institute of Banking & Finance Singapore (IBF) on a full-time basis. Chia Der Jiun will take over from Ng in Corporate, HR & IT Services, while Leong Sing Chiong will lead Markets & Investment, succeeding Chia. Ng Yao Loong will replace Leong in the Development and International Group.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won rise on hopes of better ties with North
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index and the won rose on Friday following a meeting of leaders at the inter-Korean summit, with investors optimistic about improved ties with North Korea. The KOSPI gained 0.68% and the won rose 0.4% against the US dollar. Shares of railroad industry-related companies surged, while Samsung Electronics rose 1.7% ahead of a 50:1 stock split. The won's weekly loss of 1.4% was offset by a 0.08% gain in offshore trading.

site_title: Southeast Asian leaders to rally against protectionism at Singapore summit
summary: Southeast Asian leaders will rally against protectionism at a Singapore summit, amid fears of a global trade war. The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) leaders will pledge to fight protectionism and uphold free and open trade, citing concerns over US-China trade tensions and the impact on regional growth. The summit comes as tensions between the US and China escalate, with both countries imposing tariffs on each other's exports. The leaders will also address issues in the South China Sea and welcome a historic summit between North Korea and South Korea.

site_title: SIA to begin world's longest non-stop flights by end-2018: Singapore to New York in 19 hours
summary: Singapore Airlines plans to launch the world's longest non-stop flights by the end of 2018, with a 19-hour flight from Singapore to New York. The airline will operate the route using its new Airbus 350-900ULR aircraft, which has a range of over 18,000km. SIA is also expected to start non-stop services to Los Angeles next year. The flights will feature a two-class configuration with business and premium economy seats, and will mark the airline's return to non-stop flights to the US after a decade.

site_title: Gold steady near 5-week lows, heads for biggest weekly fall in 4
summary: Gold prices are steady near a five-week low, set for a decline of over 1% this week, due to a strong US dollar, high US Treasury yields, and easing geo-political concerns. Spot gold is near US$1,316.34 per ounce, while US gold futures are down 0.1% at US$1,317.20 per ounce. Analysts attribute the decline to the US dollar's strength, high interest rates, and reduced geo-political tensions, which could prompt faster interest rate rises and reduce gold demand.

site_title: Hot stock: Valuetronics down 11.5%; brokers maintain 'buy'
summary: Valuetronics' shares fell 11.5% to S$0.655, one of the most actively traded stocks on the Singapore bourse, after the Singapore Exchange issued a query on unusual price movement. The company confirmed compliance with listing rules and stated it's unaware of any undisclosed information. Analysts from CIMB and Maybank Kim Eng maintain "buy" calls, citing potential catalysts such as stronger earnings delivery and new customer wins, despite downside risks from order delays or cancellations.

site_title: Tianjin Zhong Xin Pharmaceutical Group posts 30% increase in Q1 net profit to 173.4m yuan
summary: Tianjin Zhong Xin Pharmaceutical Group reported a 30% increase in Q1 net profit to 173.4 million yuan, up from 129.8 million yuan in the same period last year. Revenue expanded 9% to 1.62 billion yuan, and earnings per share rose to 0.23 fen from 0.17 fen. The company attributed the increase to the reversal of an allowance for impairment on other receivables. No dividend was declared for the quarter, and the company is holding an online conference on May 8 to provide a comprehensive understanding of its FY2017 performance.

site_title: Singapore private home prices rise 3.9%; steepest gain since Q2 2010
summary: Singapore's private home prices rose 3.9% in Q1 2018, the steepest gain since Q2 2010. Non-landed homes led the way with a 4.4% increase, outperforming landed properties which rose 1.9%. The vacancy rate for private homes fell to 7.4%. Experts predict a further 8-10% rise in prices this year, driven by strong demand from buyers and investors.

site_title: China, India leaders to hold summit after border row
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi will meet for an informal summit in Wuhan on Friday and Saturday, aiming to repair strained ties after last year's border dispute. The summit comes amid concerns over China's Belt and Road initiative, which includes a major project through disputed territory in Pakistan-administered Kashmir. Both nations have committed to solving their long-standing border disagreements through dialogue, but progress has been slow. The meeting is seen as an attempt to reset relations and avoid future conflicts, particularly after a tense standoff in Doklam last year.

site_title: Singapore shares close up 0.2% on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 7.19 points, or 0.2%, to 3,577.21 on Friday, driven by positive economic indicators, including quarterly real estate growth and a central bank reaffirming its positive economic outlook. Gainers outpaced losers 243 to 191, with casino operator Genting Singapore and hot stock Valuetronics seeing gains. Venture Corporation was the notable loser, down 3.69%. Total shares traded were 2.55 billion for S$1.38 billion, with 26.08 million shares changing hands for Genting Singapore.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: In remote China, a high-tech auto plant flags global challenge
summary: China's Lynk & Co, a subsidiary of Zhejiang Geely Holding Group, has opened a new high-tech auto plant in Zhangjiakou, employing 1,800 people and featuring digitally-connected robots. The 12 billion yuan investment showcases the challenge to long-established auto factories in mature industrial economies as automakers adopt new manufacturing technology. The plant, which will produce 200,000 cars per year, demonstrates the ability to build cars in remote locations with advanced systems and robots. The move is part of Geely's strategy to target younger and less affluent buyers in China and expand globally.

site_title: Fewer women in good-paying jobs, not unequal wages, behind gender pay gap: Korn Ferry
summary: A global study by Korn Ferry found that the average woman is paid 16.1% less than men globally, but the gap narrows to 1.5% when considering job levels and company. The study suggests that women are less represented in better-paying jobs, rather than discriminatory wages, behind the gender pay gap. The gap varies by region, with Asia's mature markets having the widest gap, but fast-growing markets like China and India showing lower gaps.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 12.88 points to 1,865.15. Gainers outnumbered losers 127 to 31, with a total volume of 40.26 million lots worth RM15.25 million.

site_title: Southeast Asian leaders to vow to fight protectionism
summary: Southeast Asian leaders are expected to rally against protectionism at a summit in Singapore, amid fears of a global trade war between the US and China. The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) will pledge to fight protectionism, citing concerns over the impact on regional growth. The leaders will also address tensions in the South China Sea and welcome the historic summit between North and South Korean leaders. The move aims to promote free and open markets and uphold the rules-based multilateral trading system.

site_title: Personal data panel seeking views on Do Not Call Provisions, Spam control Act
summary: The Personal Data Protection Commission (PDPC) is conducting a review of the Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA) to enhance protection against unsolicited commercial messages. The review seeks public feedback on proposals to merge the Do Not Call provisions with the Spam Control Act, streamline requirements, and introduce an administrative regime for infringements. Key changes include a shorter withdrawal of consent period, regulating unsolicited messages on IM platforms, and prohibiting dictionary attacks. The review also aims to provide greater clarity and certainty for organizations through the introduction of an Enhanced Practical Guidance (EPG) framework.

site_title: Airbus Q1 profit hit by engine delays, cuts A330 output
summary: Airbus reported a first-quarter profit of 14 million euros, despite delays in engine deliveries for its A320neo passenger jet. The company cut A330 production due to weak demand, reducing deliveries to around 50 per year in 2019. Revenues fell 12% to 10.119 billion euros. Airbus reaffirmed its forecasts, contradicting analysts' expectations of a 23.9 million euro operating loss. The company's adjusted quarterly operating profit was a significant improvement from a restated year-earlier loss of 19 million euros.

site_title: Australia watchdog has hardly used its punitive powers, misconduct inquiry hears
summary: Australia's corporate regulator, the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC), has not used its full punitive powers to tackle misconduct in the financial advice industry, a powerful inquiry heard. ASIC has only suspended two company licenses for breaches and banned 10 people from the industry. The regulator has not brought a single civil court action against a company for failing to act in the best interest of customers. The Royal Commission's findings have led to pressure on major lenders, including Commonwealth Bank of Australia and AMP, to increase regulation and enforcement.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes flat on Friday afternoon at 3,570.29
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading flat on Friday afternoon at 3,570.29, with 176 gainers and 166 losers, after 1.63 billion shares worth S$661.1 million changed hands. Ezion fell 5.5%, while Singtel rose 0.9% and Venture Corp dropped 0.5%.

site_title: MYP unit to sell MYP Plaza at Cecil Street for S$247m
summary: MAINBOARD-listed MYP Ltd agreed to sell its freehold MYP Plaza at 135 Cecil Street for S$247 million to a Filipino billionaire's group of companies. The sale price is deemed strategic, aligning with the group's future plans and maximizing shareholder interests. The property, a 14-storey office tower, has a net lettable area of 82,334.28 sq ft and is situated near key MRT stations. The sale is subject to due diligence and execution of a definitive agreement.

site_title: Tokyo stocks close higher as investors focus on Korean summit
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Friday, driven by gains on Wall Street and investor confidence in corporate earnings. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.66% to 22,467.87, while the Topix index gained 0.29% to 1,777.23. The summit between North Korea's Kim Jong Un and South Korea's President Moon Jae-in was seen as a positive development, improving market sentiment. However, the long-term impact of geopolitics surrounding North Korea on the market remains uncertain, according to analysts.

site_title: HDB resale volume falls 22.3% in Q1 as prices drop 0.8%
summary: HDB resale flat sales declined 22.3% in Q1 2018, with 4,458 transactions, compared to 5,738 in Q4 2017. This drop is 1.6% lower than the same period last year. HDB resale prices also fell 0.8% for the sixth consecutive quarter, the steepest decline in six quarters.

site_title: LHN to acquire Cambodian condominium block for US$12.5m
summary: LHN is acquiring 108 freehold apartment units in Cambodia's Axis Residences for US$12.5 million. The units will be developed by LHN's subsidiary, LHN Cambodia, and will be operated as serviced residences under the 85SOHO brand. The acquisition is subject to bank financing and approval from LHN's board and shareholders. If the seller fails to complete construction within 12 months, LHN can rescind the agreement and claim damages. The deal is expected to broaden LHN's property portfolio and increase its brand value.

site_title: Jail for top Indonesia politician 'turning point' in war on graft
summary: Indonesia's top politician, Setya Novanto, has been sentenced to 15 years in prison for corruption, marking a significant victory for the country's anti-graft agency. Novanto, known as "Mr. Teflon," was convicted of taking millions of dollars in kickbacks and bribes linked to the national roll-out of government ID cards.
