His conviction has sparked widespread anger and is seen as a turning point in the country's war on corruption, with observers hailing it as a milestone for the Corruption Eradication Commission.

site_title: Noble, ad hoc group in process of selecting new board members
summary: Noble, a company undergoing restructuring, is selecting new board members through an ad hoc group of senior creditors. Global executive search firm Spencer Stuart will assist in the search for a chairman and at least four independent non-executive directors. The new board aims to focus on Noble's key market segments, where the company has historically been profitable, and tightly control growth initiatives to balance profitability and future growth. The company's CEO, Will Randall, and his management team will receive equity and cash bonuses based on cash profits generated from the restructured business.

site_title: Malaysia's Najib says markets to decide on ringgit
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak stated that the country's currency, the ringgit, will be determined by financial markets, as he focuses on improving the economy and implementing reforms. He outlined a plan to boost liquidity in the equity market and promised tax cuts. Meeting the target for a balanced budget by 2020 is challenging, but achievable by 2023 ahead of the May 9 election. Najib also plans to increase income and corporate tax cuts over the next half-decade.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Najib Razak said Malaysia will let financial markets decide the direction of the currency as he focuses on improving the economy and on his reform agenda.

site_title: Japan factory output up in March as jobless rate stays flat
summary: Japan's factory output rose 1.2% in March, beating market expectations, while the jobless rate remained at 2.5%, the lowest in 25 years. The labor market stayed tight, with 159 job offers for every 100 job seekers. Japan has notched its longest period of GDP expansion since the late 1980s, but struggles to achieve 2% inflation. The Bank of Japan is expected to maintain its ultra-loose monetary policy.

site_title: China's March industrial profits up 3.1%
summary: China's industrial profits rose 3.1% in March to 589.75 billion yuan, a slowdown from the first quarter's 11.6% growth. This marks a decrease from the initial pace seen early in the year. Industrial firms' liabilities also increased 5.8% in March, slower than the 6.0% increase in the first two months of 2018. The data suggests China's economic growth may be slowing down, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Singapore's economic outlook for 2018 remains positive despite global trade risks: MAS
summary: Singapore's economic outlook for 2018 remains positive despite global trade risks, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). The MAS expects full-year GDP growth to be "slightly above the middle of the forecast range" of 1.5-3.5%. Core inflation is expected to rise gradually, and digital activities in modern services are seen as a growth engine. The MAS notes that global trade tensions pose some downside risk, but domestic GDP growth is expected to continue on a steady expansion path for the rest of the year.

images.alt_text: Singapore's economic outlook for 2018 remains positive despite global trade risks, said the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) in the April edition of its half-yearly macroeconomic review, released on Friday.
Janice Heng

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open more than 1% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 1% higher on Friday, following a rally on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.98% to 30,300.83, driven by energy firms' upward swing due to higher oil prices. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained, adding 0.24% and 0.47%, respectively.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand dollars near multi-month lows as greenback gains
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars have fallen to near five-month lows, with the Australian dollar easing to US$0.7548 and the New Zealand dollar at US$0.7060. The declines are attributed to a rise in US 10-year yields above 3% and weakening iron ore and Chinese equity prices. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to hold interest rates at a record low 1.50% when it meets on Tuesday. The decline in the currencies is also linked to a gloomy mood in China, which is Australia's leading trading partner.

images.alt_text: The Australian dollar slipped again on Friday to a near five-month trough while its New Zealand cousin paused after eight straight sessions of losses as the greenback looked set to continue climbing.

site_title: CyberAgent soars on partnership with Nintendo for mobile games
summary: CyberAgent Inc, a Tokyo-based mobile game maker, surged 16% in early trade after announcing a partnership with Nintendo Co to jointly develop smartphone games. Nintendo will take a 5% stake in Cygames Inc for an undisclosed sum. The deal is a push for Nintendo into mobile gaming, following its existing partnership with DeNA Co, which slumped 5.7% after the announcement. A new role-playing title, Dragalia Lost, will be released this summer, co-developed with Cygames. The partnership is seen as a significant boost for CyberAgent, which has aggressive monetization tactics and is expanding into online television.

images.alt_text: Nintendo's outgoing President Tatsumi Kimishima has hinted that the three-year partnership with DeNA hasn't delivered as much as the company anticipated.

site_title: Moya Holdings non-executive director resigns after share sale
summary: Moya Holdings announced that non-executive director Ziyad Fekri Z Omar has resigned following a share sale worth S$31.47 million. Omar is the founder of Gulf One Investment Bank BSC, which held a 41% stake in Moya Holding Company BSC. The company has appointed managing director Irwan Atmadja Dinata to its audit and remuneration committees, which does not comply with corporate governance guidelines. Moya stated it will make necessary arrangements to comply with the guidelines in due course.

site_title: Flash: URA office rental index for Central Region up 2.6% q-o-q in Q1
summary: Office rentals in the Central Region rose 2.6% quarter-over-quarter in Q1, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA). The islandwide vacancy rate eased to 12.5%. This increase suggests a strengthening market, with demand for office spaces on the rise. The URA's office rental index will be closely watched for future trends in the Singapore property market.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Singapore retrenchments in Q1 lowest in nearly 7 years, unemployment rate dips: MOM
summary: Singapore's labour market saw a significant drop in retrenchments in Q1 2018, with 2,100 cases, the lowest in nearly 7 years. This represents a decline from 3,680 in the previous quarter and half of 4,000 in the same quarter last year. The unemployment rate among residents also hit a two-year low, with the Manpower Ministry reporting the latest figure.

site_title: Plastoform still in the red for Q1, could see entry into SGX watch list
summary: Plastoform Holdings reported a Q1 loss of HK$11.2 million, its third consecutive year of losses. Revenue increased by 54.8% to HK$18.7 million due to strong demand. The company faces potential listing on the Singapore Exchange's watch list for breaching profitability requirements. Plastoform plans to develop virtual reality products and expand into commercial and industrial sectors to boost revenues. The company has until June 4, 2020 to exit the watch list.

site_title: Flash: URA's retail rents for central region up 0.1 % q-o-q in Q1
summary: Singapore's retail rentals increased 0.1% quarter-over-quarter in Q1, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA). The vacancy rate rose to 7.5%. These findings suggest a stable market, with rentals remaining relatively unchanged despite fluctuations in other markets.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Facebook says there may be more Cambridge Analytica-sized leaks
summary: Facebook warns of potential data leaks similar to the Cambridge Analytica scandal, which affected 87 million users. The company is auditing popular apps and expects to discover more instances of misuse of user data. This could harm user trust, engagement, and Facebook's reputation, as well as lead to regulatory risks, fines, and penalties. The discovery may also negatively impact Facebook's business and financial results. The warning comes after Facebook announced its earnings, which showed strong sales and user growth.

images.alt_text: Facebook Inc. is on the hunt for other Cambridge Analytica-sized data leaks, and the company warned Thursday that users and investors might not like what it finds.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Friday; STI up 0.5% to 3,586.51
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.5% to 3,586.51 on Friday, driven by gains in Ezion and other actively traded counters. About 60.2 million shares changed hands, worth S$106.4 million. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Two Koreas' leaders in historic handshake
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and South Korean President Moon Jae In met in a historic handshake on the Military Demarcation Line, the first North Korean leader to set foot in the South since the Korean War. The meeting, ahead of a summit between Kim and US President Donald Trump, aimed to improve inter-Korean relations and achieve peace and reunification. The talks will focus on nuclear diplomacy, with denuclearization expected to be a key agenda item, although the North's KCNA news agency did not mention it. The summit is seen as a crucial step in nuclear diplomacy.

site_title: Office rentals post 2.6% rise q-o-q in Q1, islandwide vacancy eases to 12.5%: URA
summary: Singapore's office rental index rose 2.6% in Q1 2018, the same pace as in Q4 2017, marking the third consecutive quarterly increase. The vacancy rate decreased to 12.5% from 12.6% in the previous quarter. The central region saw a 1.3% increase in office space prices, while the total supply of office space in the pipeline rose 32.5%. Experts attribute the growth to renewed business strength and limited new supply, with rents expected to continue growing until 2020.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: P Ramlee Revisited
summary: Local composer Julian Wong has reimagined several of P Ramlee's classic songs into a suite in three movements, blending elements of a violin concerto. The piece, titled "Azizah," will be performed by re: mix at the Esplanade Recital Studio on April 29. Wong dedicates the piece to his late mentor Iskandar Ismail. This performance marks a unique blend of Western classical music and Malaysian genres. Tickets are available for S$20.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: URA retail rental index inches up 0.1% q-o-q in Q1 after 12 straight quarters of declines
summary: Singapore's Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) retail rental index rose 0.1% in Q1 2018, its first increase after 12 consecutive quarters of decline. The Central Region's price index also increased 0.1% quarter-over-quarter. Total retail space supply grew 4.1% to 530,000 sq m, while occupied space remained unchanged. The vacancy rate increased to 7.5% from 7.4%. Experts expect stable growth in the mid- to long-term, with prime floors remaining highly sought after.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Oil prices gain on Iran sanctions worries
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday as US sanctions worries on Iran, plunging Venezuelan output, and robust global demand boosted crude futures. Global benchmark Brent crude gained 74 cents to settle at $74.74 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 14 cents to $68.19 a barrel. The rally is expected to continue despite a stronger dollar and uncertainty around the Iran deal.

site_title: Amazon delivers hefty profits, led by web services
summary: Amazon reported a 4.4-fold increase in first-quarter profit to $1.6 billion, driven by soaring revenue from online commerce and cloud services. The company's Amazon Web Services (AWS) division saw remarkable growth, with revenue doubling in two quarters. Amazon's online sales rose 18% to $26.94 billion, while its Prime membership base reached 100 million. The company also introduced a "Free Time" version of Alexa for children, and a new partnership with the NFL to stream Thursday night football games.

site_title: In Good Company
summary: Co-working spaces in Singapore have evolved from casual, millennial-centric setups to sophisticated operations catering to entrepreneurs, SMEs, and larger companies. The concept has attracted a diverse range of clients, including those in the fitness and wellness industry. New spaces like Core Collective and Paperwork offer unique amenities and services, such as Pilates Reformer machines and treatment rooms, and design studios and creatives. WeWork is expanding in Singapore, offering private offices, dedicated and hot desks, and regular workshops and thought leader panels. In contrast, SILO is designed for introverted businesses that value luxury and privacy, with flexible leases and a meditative work environment.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Working adults short of critical illness insurance cover, says LIA
summary: A study by the Life Insurance Association (LIA) found that working adults in Singapore have critical illness insurance coverage that meets only 20% of their needs, leaving a significant 80% gap. The LIA recommends a coverage of $316,000, which is less than the average annual pay of $81,663. The gap is most pronounced among young working adults, and the LIA plans to implement targeted solutions, including education efforts and a digital calculator, to help consumers better allocate resources for adequate protection.

site_title: Volatile ride for Venture as analysts reduce price targets
summary: VENTURE Corp fell 12.1% in early trading on April 26, 2018, after missing street-estimated earnings. The counter recovered to close 1.6% lower at S$22.22. Approximately 9.2 million shares changed hands worth S$196.9 million.

site_title: Brazil to release mozzies via drones to combat Zika
summary: Brazil plans to release up to 1 million sterile male mosquitoes a week via drones for three months to combat the Zika virus, with the goal of reducing the mosquito population by up to 99%. The mosquitoes, bred in labs, will mate with females but not produce viable eggs, effectively controlling the population. The use of drones has been hailed as a breakthrough, allowing for large-scale releases and reducing costs. The program aims to combat the Zika epidemic, which affected thousands of babies in Brazil in 2015-2016.

site_title: US: Stocks boosted by Facebook, tech shares
summary: US stocks surged on Thursday, led by a 1.6% gain in the Nasdaq Composite Index, driven by Facebook's blowout earnings report, which saw a 63% rise in first-quarter profits. Other tech companies, including Amazon, Alphabet, and Microsoft, also rose 2% or more. Chipotle Mexican Grill surged 24.6% after reporting a 28.9% increase in earnings, while Visa jumped 4.9% after raising its profit and revenue forecast. However, American Airlines fell 6.4% after reporting a 45.2% drop in earnings.

site_title: Living large, going public with her woes, selling art
summary: Ashley Longshore, a 46-year-old artist, thrives on taking action and living life to the fullest. She works 16-hour days, producing a copious amount of art that showcases pop feminism and female empowerment. Her colorful sculptures, featuring celebrities like Kate Moss and Anna Wintour, have gained her a large following on social media, and she has recently partnered with Bergdorf Goodman to showcase her work. Longshore's unapologetic and upbeat personality has made her a beloved figure, and she has become a symbol of hope and fun for young women.

images.alt_text: Above: Ashley Longshore in her New Orleans gallery. Her glittery, bawdy feminist artwork gets 'likes' on Instagram and love at the uppity Bergdorf Goodman store.
Above: The outside of studio hints at her personality.

site_title: Deutsche Bank calls time on Wall Street in retreat to Europe
summary: Deutsche Bank announced plans to retreat from its Wall Street presence, cutting back on bond and equities trading, and shifting focus to retail banking and asset management in Europe. CEO Christian Sewing cited a 79% fall in first-quarter net profit and the need to ensure competitiveness as the reasons for the move. The bank plans to cut around 300 US-based investment bankers and 100 in Germany, with restructuring costs estimated at 800 million euros. The decision is seen as a strategic shift, but analysts question how the new focus on retail will lift revenue and profit.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank moved to end its nightmare on Wall Street on Thursday as its new chief executive Christian Sewing called time on three expensive decades struggling to become a global investment bank with a retreat to Europe.

site_title: Bill Cosby found guilty at sexual assault retrial
summary: Bill Cosby was found guilty on all three counts of aggravated indecent assault against Andrea Constand, a former Temple University employee, in a retrial that concluded with a verdict in his favor in a previous trial ending in a hung jury. Cosby, 80, faces a possible life sentence for drugging and molesting Constand at his Philadelphia mansion in 2004. The verdict is seen as a vindication for the prosecution, with prosecutors declaring "justice has been done" after Cosby spent decades preying on women. Cosby's lawyer has pledged to appeal the conviction.

site_title: North Korea's Kim heads for historic summit with Moon
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un is set to meet with South Korean President Moon Jae In at the Demilitarized Zone, marking the third historic summit since the end of the Korean War. The meeting aims to pave the way for a potential summit between Kim and US President Donald Trump. Key issues on the agenda include North Korea's nuclear arsenal and security guarantees. Pyongyang has demanded unspecified guarantees in exchange for discussing its nuclear program, while Seoul has expressed skepticism about the possibility of a complete denuclearization agreement.

images.alt_text: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un (right) headed for the Demilitarised Zone Friday, Pyongyang's state media reported, for a historic summit with the South's President Moon Jae In in the strip of land that divides their countries.

site_title: Blurred Lines
summary: Real men like perfume, challenging traditional gender associations. Perfume's origins date back to ancient civilizations, with pharaohs using scents like spikenard. Even Old Spice, a classic masculine scent, originated from a "female" inspiration. Over time, men's scents shifted to wood and women's to flowers, reinforcing stereotypes. Today, a growing number of male fragrance collectors and connoisseurs are embracing more neutral scents, breaking down barriers and challenging traditional notions of masculinity.

site_title: Lakeside Towers, Jalan Besar Plaza go en bloc
summary: Two Singapore developments, Lakeside Towers and Jalan Besar Plaza, have gone en bloc, with owners seeking S$305m and S$380m respectively. Lakeside Towers, a 99-year leasehold project, offers 321,797 sq ft of GFA, while Jalan Besar Plaza, a freehold mixed-use development, has an existing approved GFA of 16,694 sq m. Both sites are strategically located in high-growth areas, with Lakeside Towers near Jurong Lake Gardens and Jalan Besar Plaza close to the CBD. Tender closures are set for May 28 and June 5.

images.alt_text: Jalan Besar Plaza is a five-minute drive to the CBD, and is in the vicinity of Kallang Riverside Park and Jalan Besar Stadium.

site_title: Trump admits Cohen represented him in 'crazy Stormy Daniels deal'
summary: US President Donald Trump acknowledged that his personal lawyer, Michael Cohen, represented him in the "crazy Stormy Daniels deal," a $130,000 payment to adult film star Stormy Daniels to prevent her from talking about an alleged 2006 affair with Trump. Trump claimed Cohen did "absolutely nothing wrong" and that there were no campaign funds involved. The payment was made just days before the 2016 presidential election, raising concerns about potential campaign finance law violations. Trump also sought to distance himself from Cohen, calling him a "good person" and stating that he has many attorneys.

site_title: Europe: Earnings, euro fall propel shares higher
summary: European stock markets rose 0.9% on Thursday, driven by encouraging earnings results and a fall in the euro, which reached a session low after the European Central Bank kept policy unchanged. Bank earnings were a key focus, with Deutsche Bank falling 2% after reporting a 79% drop in net profit, while Norway's DNB jumped 6.7% after beating profit expectations. Industrials sector was strong, with Safran rising after results, but Lufthansa fell 5.5% due to expansion of its Eurowings budget carrier.

site_title: Oriental Delights
summary: The 6th Singapore Chinese Film Festival (SCFF2018) kicked off on April 27 with 58 films, including 44 Singapore premieres. The festival featured documentary "Manfei" and Wong Kar Wai's "Happy Together," which closed the event. Other notable films include "The Bold, The Corrupt and The Beautiful," which won major awards at the Golden Horse Awards. The festival ran from April 27 to May 6 at various venues, offering a lineup of Singaporean and international films.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Total's Q1 profit beats forecasts, lifted by record output
summary: Total's Q1 profit beats forecasts, with net adjusted profit reaching US$2.9 billion, exceeding analysts' estimates. The company produced 2.703 million barrels of oil equivalent per day, a 5% increase from the same period in 2017, driven by new projects and acquisitions. Total also expects to surpass its 2018 production target and maintain cost discipline, with plans to invest US$15-$17 billion and reduce operating expenses.

site_title: Microsoft gets earnings boost from 'cloud'
summary: Microsoft reported a 35% increase in earnings to $7.4 billion in its fiscal third quarter, driven by gains in its core cloud computing operations for business. Revenue rose 16% to $26.8 billion, with the "Intelligent Cloud" segment producing $7.9 billion in revenues, up 17%. The company also saw growth in LinkedIn, Xbox, and Surface devices, with shares remaining little changed in after-hours trade. Microsoft is shifting its focus to business services using its cloud computing platform and artificial intelligence, with the goal of delivering differentiated value to customers.

site_title: FLASH: Private home prices up 3.9% in Q1 2018: URA
summary: Singapore private home prices rose 3.9% in Q1 2018, the steepest gain since Q2 2010, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA). This marks the first time since 2010 that the market has seen a year-over-year increase. The price rise is attributed to a combination of factors, including a low interest rate environment and a lack of new supply in the market. The URA's data suggests that the private home market is showing signs of recovery, but experts caution that the growth is still modest and may not be sustainable in the long term.

site_title: MPA steps up measures to align marine fuel industry with new rules
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has announced measures to align its marine fuel industry with the upcoming 0.5% global sulphur cap, set to be enforced in 2020. MPA will require the use of mass flow meters (MFMs) for delivering cleaner-burning distillates bunker to international ships from July 2019. To support the transition, MPA has set aside S$9 million for co-funding the costs of MFM adoption. This is six months ahead of the International Maritime Organization's (IMO) global sulphur cap.

site_title: Singapore, Zhejiang to cooperate on Belt and Road opportunities
summary: Singapore and China's Zhejiang province will deepen cooperation under the Belt and Road Initiative, focusing on innovation and urban solutions. The two sides aim to encourage Chinese e-commerce and technology firms to expand in Southeast Asia through partnerships with Singapore companies. Zhejiang companies will also be urged to set up regional headquarters in Singapore to raise funds for Belt and Road projects. The move follows a surge in bilateral trade, which almost doubled to S$5.2 billion in 2022, with Singapore firms investing S$7.2 billion in Zhejiang projects.

site_title: Nomura Q4 profit slumps 63%
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc, Japan's largest brokerage and investment bank, reported a 63% fall in fourth-quarter net profit to 22.7 billion yen, the steepest slowdown in almost four years, due to a decline in risk appetite among retail clients amid volatile markets. The company's annual net profit fell 8% to 219.3 billion yen. Nomura's overseas division recorded a pre-tax loss of 18.7 billion yen, while its wholesale division saw a 57% increase in pre-tax profit to 44.2 billion yen.

site_title: New and seasoned hands at the helm to steer ship of state
summary: Singapore's Cabinet has undergone significant changes, with 15 out of 16 ministries now led by new ministers, including three full-time women and four first-time office holders from the private sector. The changes signal a shift towards the next generation of leaders, with many ministers being fourth-generation leaders. However, seasoned hands remain at the helm, with retired Trade Minister Lim Hng Kiang staying on as a special adviser and Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong maintaining control over the Future Economy Council. The new Cabinet aims to maintain Singapore's business-friendly environment and address the country's challenges, including disruptive technology and globalisation.

site_title: PM Najib expects 'better results' this election
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak expects a "better result" in the upcoming election, his toughest fight in six decades in office. He faces opposition leader Mahathir Mohamad, his former mentor, and a battle for ethnic Malay votes. Najib has promised income and business tax cuts if he wins, and is seeking to preserve Umno's unbroken rule since independence. Despite economic growth and a reduced 1MDB scandal, Najib's confidence is undermined by opposition unity and public discontent. The election has become highly personal, with Najib and Mahathir engaged in a bitter rivalry.

site_title: Fit To Party
summary: Oasia Hotel Downtown is hosting a fitness fiesta on April 28 to celebrate its 2-year anniversary. The event features a high-intensity workout session led by fitness influencer Natalie Dau, along with a spread of healthy treats and a workshop on maintaining a healthy gut. Participants receive a goodie bag worth over S$100, with an entry fee of S$20. The event is open to registration starting at 8:30am.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust Q4 DPU up 4%
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust's fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) rose 4% to 1.937 Singapore cents, driven by organic growth, redevelopment contributions, and acquisitions. The trust plans to acquire 11 logistics properties in China for about S$206 million, doubling its net lettable space to 8.8 million sq ft and increasing e-commerce revenue exposure to 42%. Gross revenue and net property income increased 11% and 14% respectively, with a 27% year-on-year increase in distributable amount to unitholders.

site_title: Making History
summary: IWC Schaffhausen is marking its 150th anniversary with a retrospective exhibition from May 1-13 at ION Orchard. The event showcases the brand's history, featuring the work of founder Florentine Ariosto Jones and iconic watches such as the Special Watch for Pilots Ref. 436 and the Lepine Pallweber III pocket watch. The exhibition also highlights novelties from IWC's Jubilee collection, including the diamond-encrusted Da Vinci Automatic Moon Phase 36 Edition "150 Years".

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: China's electric carmakers bloom at Beijing auto show
summary: China's electric car market is thriving, with local carmakers showcasing their latest plug-in models at the Beijing auto show. Chinese firms dominate electric car sales, while foreign companies like Mercedes-Benz, Tesla, and Volkswagen are struggling to keep up. Beijing's policymakers are pushing for a quota system and subsidies to encourage electric vehicle adoption, aiming to reduce dependence on imported oil and cut pollution. China aims to control 70% of the electric vehicle market by 2020 and 80% by 2025 under its "Made in China 2025" policy.

images.alt_text: Car company Nio, backed by IT giants Tencent and Lenovo, sported a line of electric SUVs and supercars at its booth at the Beijing auto show. It included this Nio Eve concept car.

site_title: Raised bid of S$0.55 hoists Tat Hong stock 11% to S$0.54
summary: Tat Hong Holdings' shares rose 11.3% to 54 Singapore cents after bidders raised their offer price by 5 cents to 55 cents per share, aiming to privatize the crane supplier. The new offer price represents a 13.4% premium over the last traded price. The deadline for accepting the offer has been extended to May 14. The bidder, THSC Investments, plans to delist the company and cited low trading volume and compliance costs as reasons for taking the company private.

site_title: Shanghai Disney to keep expanding to keep up with China demand
summary: Shanghai Disney Resort is set to expand to meet China's growing demand for high-quality themed entertainment. The $5.5 billion resort logged over 11 million visitors in its first year, with a new Toy Story Land expansion driven by Chinese consumers' need for family entertainment options. CEO Bob Iger stated that Disney will continue to expand to satisfy this demand, although no plans for a second park in China have been announced. Disney emphasizes its efforts to incorporate Chinese elements into the park's design, with joint venture partner Shanghai Shendi Group owning 57% of the resort.

site_title: Delving deeply into the delights of Donnhoff
summary: Helmut Donnhoff, a charming German wine-grower, offers a memorable experience at his Nahe estate. Established in the 1920s, the Donnhoff estate has grown from 25 hectares under Helmut's leadership since 1966. His wines, particularly from the Schlossbockelheimer Felsenberg and Niederhauser Hermannshohle vineyards, showcase exceptional minerality and balance. The reviewer praises Donnhoff's wines for their soft texture, light to medium sweetness, and long-lasting acidity, ranking him among the top German producers alongside Egon Muller-Scharzhof.

site_title: Poetry In Gems
summary: The Today Art Museum in Beijing has opened an exhibition featuring over 360 luxury jewelry pieces from Van Cleef & Arpels and private collections. The exhibition, which debuted in Paris in 2012, showcases the history of the jewelry brand, from its founding in 1906 to the present day. The high jewelry pieces are displayed chronologically, highlighting the brand's technical innovations and craftsmanship. The exhibition runs until August 5.

images.alt_text: Poetry In Gems
Poetry In Gems

site_title: MAS proposes guidelines for FIs on accountability and standard of conduct
summary: MAS proposes guidelines for financial institutions (FIs) on accountability and standard of conduct in Singapore, aiming to foster ethical behavior and responsible risk-taking. This comes over a decade after the Global Financial Crisis, where FIs were under-capitalized and inadequately supervised. The proposed guidelines seek feedback to transform the industry's culture of personal accountability, following global regulators' push for top-tier accountability.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: UK mortgage approvals fall to second- lowest level since 2015
summary: UK mortgage approvals fell to the second-lowest level since 2015, with 37,567 approvals in March, according to UK Finance. This is the lowest since December 2015. The decline is attributed to icy weather, which may have exacerbated the muted housing market. The number of mortgage approvals is the second-lowest since January 2015, indicating a slowdown in the UK housing market.

site_title: Govt subsidies not needed for int'l shipping, says Maersk Line CEO
summary: Maersk Line CEO Søren Skou stated that governments no longer need to subsidize international shipping due to a competitive and effective market. The industry has experienced consolidation, with major mergers and acquisitions, such as Maersk Line's acquisition of Hamburg Süd, reducing capacity. Skou argued that the market can take care of consumers and that there is no basis for government subsidies. However, he noted that the industry may face new challenges, including a 0.5% sulfur cap on marine fuel set by the International Maritime Organization, which could lead to the adoption of greener fuels like liquefied natural gas.

site_title: Cutting food waste benefits the environment, food security, economy
summary: Breakfast buffets in hotels are a significant source of food waste, contributing to a global challenge that costs the economy $940 billion annually. The food waste generated in Singapore has risen by 40% in the past decade. To address this issue, innovative schemes like the Grand Hyatt's food-waste management system have been introduced. A new report by the Waste and Resources Action Programme (WRAP) found that for every $1 invested in reducing kitchen food waste, hotels save $7 in operating costs, with 95% of sites recouping their investment within two years. Simple measures such as measuring food waste, training staff, and redesigning menus can achieve impressive results, with some hotels reducing food waste by 50%.

site_title: Women On Top
summary: Bottega Veneta has introduced new handbag designs for the season, including the Anaconda Loop Bag, Intrecciato Wing-tip City Knot, and Velvet Postier Bag. The brand's signature motifs, such as the butterfly, are featured in various designs. Limited edition bags include the Piazza in patchwork Ayers snakeskin and the Burano in hand-painted python. Prices range from S$3,350 to S$11,430.

site_title: Qualitas Medical delays SGX IPO, cites non-optimal pricing and market volatility
summary: Qualitas Medical has delayed its initial public offering (IPO) on the Singapore Exchange's main board due to non-optimal pricing and market volatility. The regional clinic operator had expected to raise S$100-133 million, but decided to delay the deal. Despite the delay, Qualitas plans to execute its business plan through "robust organic growth" and mergers and acquisitions.

site_title: Decline in industrial property prices, rents slows as sector activity rises
summary: Industrial property prices and rents in Singapore are showing signs of slowing decline, with a 0.1% decrease in Q1 2018, according to market reports. Analysts predict a pick-up in leasing enquiries and a rental recovery, driven by growing manufacturing sector activity and business sentiment. New supply is expected to ease in the next few years, allowing demand to catch up, and rents are predicted to stabilize and post modest gains. Business parks, particularly, outperformed in the first quarter with a 2.4% rental rise, driven by limited supply and demand from the digital economy.

site_title: Party At Arts Fest
summary: The Singapore International Festival of Arts kicks off on April 27 with various free arts shows, including Cirque Rouages and Tamil Rogeon's performances. The festival features talks by notable speakers such as Shabana Azmi and Felipe Cervera, and musical performances by Tcheka and Sultan of the Disco. The event runs until April 29, offering a range of artistic experiences for attendees.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Volkswagen sees 'good start' to 2018 despite slip in profits
summary: Volkswagen reported a 3% drop in net profit to 3.22 billion euros in the first quarter of 2018, but cited strong sales and a "good start" to the year. Revenues rose 3.6% to 58.2 billion euros, driven by the Asia-Pacific region, particularly China, where demand for SUVs fueled growth. The company attributed the profit drop to accounting changes and negative currency effects. New CEO Herbert Diess vowed to steer the company towards a greener future, with investments of 15 billion euros in electric and autonomous vehicles in China by 2022.

site_title: The slippery road to a data-ready future
summary: Financial institutions are struggling to become data-driven organizations due to unmet goals and poor returns on investment. Despite implementing data technologies, few can achieve optimal enterprise-wide data analytics capabilities. Common challenges include a lack of a robust business case, inadequate talent, and poor data management capabilities. Successful data-driven enterprises must have a clear strategy, technology infrastructure, and specialist talent. A four-step approach to achieving this includes defining the purpose of data analytics, determining what data to use, deploying the right organization model and processes, and building in-house or outsourcing capabilities.

site_title: New disruptors lining up to eat Grab's lunch
summary: Five new ride-hailing companies, including Go-Jek, Dacsee, Jugnoo, Ryde, and MVL, are set to enter Singapore's market, reviving competition after Uber's exit. These players aim to reduce commission fees for drivers and create a transparent mobility ecosystem. MVL plans to charge zero commission on rides and reward drivers and riders with cryptocurrency. Dacsee aims to reduce commission to 1-2% and redistribute it to drivers, commuters, and authorities. Jugnoo will launch with a "reverse bidding" model, while Ryde will offer luxury car services. The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) is monitoring the situation, which is expected to increase competition in the market.

images.alt_text: Just when Uber's exit appears to have left Singapore's ride-hailing field wide open for Grab, new players are preparing to enter the turf.

site_title: Public bickering between Noble and Goldilocks benefits no one
summary: Noble Group is embroiled in a public dispute with its third-largest investor, Goldilocks Investment Company, over a restructuring plan. The back-and-forth has led to a stalemate, with Noble and its creditors insisting that shareholders must choose between the proposed plan or nothing. However, experts argue that a more collaborative approach is needed, as all parties have a vested interest in Noble's survival. The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX Regco) has offered to mediate a dialogue, and creditors are warning of potential "irreparable damage" from further delays. Ultimately, a compromise on the restructuring plan is necessary to ensure Noble's continued survival.

site_title: March factory output beats forecasts with 5.9% gain
summary: Singapore's factory output grew 5.9% in March, beating economists' forecasts of a 5.7% rise, according to the Economic Development Board. Excluding biomedical manufacturing, output rose 8.6% year-over-year. Electronics was the strongest performer, with a 12.4% year-over-year gain, while biomedical manufacturing declined 5.4%. Economists expect manufacturing growth to slow further in the coming months, with some predicting a 7.9% year-over-year growth in Q2.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Solar's rise giving traders a 'devil horns' problem
summary: Europe's power traders face a "devil horns" problem as solar power rises, distorting electricity prices. The formation occurs when intraday power prices crash during the day due to solar farms' increased supply and then rise as the sun sets. This phenomenon is causing traders difficulties in adapting to the changing market. The rise of solar power is also affecting global markets, including oil prices, which have fallen amid bearish Trump tariff outlook. Chinese solar stocks have surged as Beijing moves to calm price wars, while Indonesia is becoming an aluminium giant under Chinese tycoons.

site_title: Barclays' better than expected Q1 profit marred by US fines
summary: Barclays reported a better-than-expected first-quarter pre-tax profit of £1.7 billion despite fines and legal costs related to historic misconduct issues. The bank took a £1.4 billion hit from US Justice Department fines and £400 million in costs for mis-selling of payment insurance products. Barclays still plans to pay a 6.5 pence per share dividend, but its capital reserves shrank due to increased risk-weighted assets. The bank's underperforming investment bank showed signs of progress, with a profit before tax excluding litigation costs of £1.4 billion.

site_title: Shell profit jumps 42% on stronger oil prices
summary: Royal Dutch Shell reported a 42% rise in first-quarter profit, its highest in over three years, due to higher oil prices and production. The company beat Exxon Mobil in 2017 with cost cuts and efficiencies, and expectations are high for Shell to continue generating strong profits and cash flow.

site_title: Vietnam is good for smart cities, clean energy
summary: Singapore Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong said Vietnam offers strong growth prospects for Singapore companies, particularly in clean energy, smart cities, and digital economy sectors. The country has signed 16 memoranda of understanding to enhance strategic partnerships, including a 750 megawatt gas-fired power project. Singapore is Vietnam's third-largest investor, with $43 billion invested in over 1,800 projects. Wong highlighted opportunities in clean energy, smart cities, and digital economy, including fintech, e-services, and e-payment space, for potential collaboration between Singapore and Vietnamese companies.

images.alt_text: Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong speaking at the Vietnam-Singapore Business Dialogue.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Key corporate developments include Midas Holdings subsidiary Jilin Midas Light Alloy being placed under judicial management, shares of Midas suspended amid investigations. Far East Hospitality Trust reported a 1.1% increase in distribution per stapled security and 4% rise in net property income. Frasers Hospitality Trust's distribution per stapled security dipped 7.8% due to weaker performance across its portfolio. SIA Engineering Co inked a S$484 million agreement with SilkAir for maintenance services on 37 Boeing 737 MAX aircraft. Pacific Radiance received in-principle support for debt restructuring, while CapitaLand Retail China Trust reported a 7.7% decline in net property income. GuocoLand's net profit rose 7% despite revenue decline.

site_title: Hyphens Pharma International eyes Catalist listing
summary: Hyphens Pharma International is seeking a listing on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange, with IPO proceeds to fund expansion. The company's core business includes pharmaceutical and consumer healthcare products. A cornerstone offering and placement will be part of the IPO, with three cornerstone investors committing to 30.4 million shares. The company plans to use funds for business expansion, potential acquisitions, and research and development, with a target of distributing at least 30% of net profit as dividends.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Agilent opens solutions development centre
summary: Agilent Technologies has opened its first global solution development centre in Singapore, investing S$85 million in the expansion. The 11,000 sq ft facility will develop full laboratory solutions and workflows for customers in various fields, aiming to reduce time-to-market and increase efficiency. As part of its five-year expansion plan, Agilent is hiring 100 more people, exceeding its initial target of 100 new hires. The centre will focus on developing solutions for pharma, biopharma, lipidomics, and food testing, and will produce equipment such as mass spectrometry instruments and automation products.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng
The new 11,000 sq ft global solution development centre is part of Agilent Technologies' S$85 million investment and expansion plan in Singapore.

site_title: Huawei said to be probed by FBI for possible Iran violations
summary: The US Justice Department, along with the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the US Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control, is probing Huawei Technologies Co for possible violations of sanctions banning sales to Iran. The investigation grew out of a previous sanctions-violation probe that led to penalties against ZTE Corp. If Huawei is found to have wrongdoing, it could have significant ramifications for its suppliers, including chip suppliers Skyworks and Qorvo, and optical suppliers NeoPhotonics and Lumentum.

site_title: You can't see corporate culture but you know it's there
summary: Corporate culture, like black holes, cannot be seen but its presence is felt through its impact on an organization. Unlike black holes, which are proven through inference, corporate culture is described as "implied, not defined" and develops organically over time. The tone at the top sets the culture, and its effects are seen in strategy, remuneration, and value creation. Assessing and reporting corporate culture is crucial, and the proposed revisions to the UK Corporate Governance Code provide guidance on how to do so, including monitoring and taking corrective action when necessary.

site_title: Seven rules for retail brands in China
summary: China's retail market is undergoing significant changes, driven by consumer trends such as online purchasing, mobile payments, and a desire for convenience. Digital sales are expected to expand by 41% annually through 2020, while physical retailers face declining sales. Convenience store grocery sales are projected to grow 13% through 2025. To adapt, brands must partner with key players, invest in digital marketing, and adopt an omnichannel vision. Developing a "challenger" mindset, prioritizing agility and swift decision-making, will be crucial for success in the new retailing era.

images.alt_text: A huge percentage of China's grocery industry growth is now generated by small brands and agile young players.

site_title: Local market has busy but flattish session
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) gained 2.01 points, or 0.06%, to 3,570.02, despite a busy but flattish session, with 244 losers beating 180 gainers. Casino operator Genting Singapore and Venture Corporation were among the gainers, while Falcon Energy and KrisEnergy fell. Analysts are cautiously optimistic about Venture's performance, while Fitch Ratings predicts low-to-mid single-digit growth in Singapore gaming revenues.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Probing Singapore, One Play At A Time
summary: The Singapore Theatre Festival returns with a lineup of eight plays exploring topics such as racism, media, and migrant workers. The festival features Tan Tarn How's "Press Gang," a play about journalists deciding whether to run a scandalous story, and Thomas Lim's "Supervision," which centers on the privacy and dignity of domestic workers. Other plays include "Building Character," "GFE," "When The Cold Wind Blows," "An Actress Prepares," "FAGHAG," and "One Metre Square: Voices From Sungei Road." The festival runs from July 5 to 22 at Lasalle College of the Arts and includes lively forum discussions and free performances.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: SGX objects to Henn Tan as Trek CEO; orders EGM on the matter
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has ordered an extraordinary general meeting for Trek 2000 International to vote on the appointment of Henn Tan as CEO, citing "serious concerns" over his continued role. The bourse regulator has also barred Tan from serving as a director or executive officer in any listed company for three years. Additionally, Tan, Foo Kok Wah, Poo Teng Pin, and Gurcharan Singh have been banned from being appointed in such roles for the same period.

site_title: New mood of optimism in South Africa
summary: South Africa's new President, Cyril Ramaphosa, has brought a new mood of optimism to the country, marking a turning point after the scandal-plagued presidency of Jacob Zuma. Ramaphosa, a 65-year-old businessman, was sworn in as the country's fifth post-apartheid president, promising to improve the lives of South Africans. The South African stock market jumped 4% on the news, and the country's currency, the Rand, has strengthened against the US dollar. Moody's has taken South Africa off the downgrade watchlist, and the country is expected to host an investment summit to attract foreign investment.

site_title: Bottling The Spirit Of Japan
summary: Japanese whisky and gin producers, Suntory, are gaining global recognition for their high-quality spirits. The company's Roku Gin, featuring six native botanicals, and The Chita Single Grain Whisky, aged in wine and oak casks, are notable examples of Japanese spirits. Suntory's success can be attributed to its focus on quality, with a philosophy of "to create original Japanese Spirits the whole world can enjoy, uniquely made from Japan's nature and her people." The company's attention to detail, from harvesting ingredients at peak seasons to using top-secret distillation techniques, has contributed to the global demand for Japanese whisky.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: The Gentleman
summary: Gabriel Tan, a creative director, finds satisfaction in designing products used by people worldwide. His designs include the Stove chair and Ariake chair, which showcase versatility and functionality. Tan is inspired by various sources, including architecture, music, and books, and values the interconnectedness of work and life. He believes his work is driven by the desire to create products that bring joy to users.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: DBS aiming 40% energy use from renewable energy by end-2018
summary: DBS Group Holdings has announced that 40% of its energy consumption in Singapore will come from renewable sources by the end of 2018, a milestone in its goal to use 100% renewable energy by 2030. This move marks a significant step forward in the bank's transition to using renewable energy. The installation of solar panels at DBS Asia Hub is part of this effort.

images.alt_text: DBS' solar energy installation consists of some 1,200 solar panels across 30,000 square feet. The energy that is generated each year - over 460 MWh - will help offset DBS Asia Hub's power consumption.

site_title: New ride-hailing app Jugnoo lets drivers bid a price for rides
summary: Jugnoo, a new ride-hailing app in Singapore, introduces a reverse bidding model that gives drivers and commuters more control over pricing. This model aims to reduce surge pricing control held by ride-hailing companies. The app's founder, Samar Singla, stated that this change will provide more flexibility and fairness for drivers and commuters. Jugnoo's goal is to be a niche player in the Singapore ride-hailing market, distinct from larger competitors like Grab and Uber.

site_title: From boring to booming, in BT Weekend
summary: Data centers have transitioned from niche real estate to mainstream investment opportunities, with vast banks of servers supporting digital infrastructure. Swiss Re chairman Walter Kielholz attributes reinsurance's importance to the economy, citing its impact on governments, businesses, and consumers. Meanwhile, the Blackrock Dynamic High Income fund is assessed in the Investing and Wealth section, and a market manipulation issue is discussed in CFA Singapore Insights. The article explores the growing significance of data centers and their role in the global economy.

site_title: White Night
summary: Le Diner en Blanc, a worldwide epicurean phenomenon, returns to Singapore on May 12. The event, where guests dine in all-white attire, requires diners to bring their own table, chairs, and dinnerware. Registration is available at singapore.dinerenblanc.com/register. For those who prefer not to bring their own food, exclusive menus curated by celebrity chef Emmanuel Stroobant are available for pre-order.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: US jobless claims lowest since 1969
summary: US jobless claims fell to a 48-year low, with initial claims for unemployment insurance dropping 24,000 to 209,000 in the week ending April 21. This marks the lowest level since December 1969 and is below the 225,000 expected by analysts. Despite volatility, the trend suggests a tight labor market, potentially putting pressure on the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. However, some economists question the significance of the decline, citing a reversal in New York claims. The low claims have been below 300,000 for nearly three years and are likely the lowest ever when demographic changes are considered.

site_title: Atout rules the roost with rustic French bistro fare
summary: Chef Patrick Heuberger has reopened his French bistro, Atout, in Dempsey, Singapore, after a gap of several years. The restaurant serves rustic, homestyle French cooking, including Andouillette sausage, rillettes, and saucisson. The menu also features a charcuterie bar and a variety of main courses, such as lobster bisque, beef tartare, and grilled squid. While the portions are large, the pricing may seem high, but the restaurant's all-day opening allows diners to digest and savor their meals. Atout has been a boon for French expats and foodies alike, offering a unique dining experience.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Suntec Reit's Q1 results met expectations, with underlying operations firming up in its office and retail segments. OCBC Investment Research upgrades its stance from "sell" to "hold" with a fair value of S$1.84. Ascendas India Trust is recommended to buy with a target price of S$1.22 due to expected distribution growth of 8% per unit. AEM Holdings' Q1 core net profit fell short of expectations, but its earnings per share forecasts are maintained with a target price of S$7.24.

site_title: Hokkaido's Hidden Gem
summary: Kiroro, a lesser-known ski resort in Hokkaido, Japan, offers a unique skiing experience due to its proximity to the Sea of Japan, resulting in higher snowfall and the best powder snow. The resort averages 21m of snowfall annually and boasts the longest ski season in Hokkaido, making it an attractive alternative to popular ski resorts like Niseko. Its hidden location allows for a more secluded and peaceful skiing experience, perfect for those looking to avoid crowds.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: New board at SICCI focuses on recruitment, gender diversity
summary: A new board at the Singapore Indian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SICCI) has prioritized recruitment and gender diversity, aiming to increase women membership to at least a third of its 17 board seats. The board, led by T Chandroo, also plans to sharply increase membership from 550 to 2,000 within two years, targeting over 8,000 Indian companies in Singapore. To attract more women, SICCI is offering reduced fees for the first year. The chamber aims to support local SMEs in growth through skills, innovation, and expansion into overseas markets.

images.alt_text: Led by Modern Montessori International chairman and chief executive T Chandroo, SICCI's new board for the 2018 to 2020 term will include three women directors for the first time in the trade group's history.

site_title: Vard's minorities band to oppose Fincantieri's delisting proposal
summary: Vard Holdings minority shareholders are rallying against the company's board proposal to delist at an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on Monday. The minority shareholders aim to block controlling shareholder Fincantieri Oil & Gas' move to buy out the firm with a 10% total shareholding. However, the numbers appear stacked against them, with Fincantieri holding an 83% stake. The outcome of the EGM is uncertain, and the proposal's fate remains to be decided.

site_title: Euro holds near 8-week lows ahead of Draghi meet
summary: The euro held near eight-week lows on Thursday, trading flat at US$1.2164, ahead of European Central Bank president Mario Draghi's speech. The ECB kept interest rates unchanged, as expected, but the euro remains 2.5 cents below its highs from last week due to a surge in US dollar buying. Investors are searching for signals on when the ECB will unwind its stimulus, which could impact the euro's rally.

site_title: Accounting change sends Jardine C&C profits down by 36%
summary: Jardine C&C reported a 36% decline in first-quarter profits to US$135.4 million, mainly due to fair-value investment losses. Revenue rose 12% to US$4.64 billion, driven by improvements in direct motor interests and other strategic investments. Despite a 4% decline in Indonesian affiliate Astra's contribution, the group's underlying profit increased by 8% to US$219 million. Net income declined in several divisions, but the heavy equipment, mining, and energy business saw a significant increase.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: US April auto sales seen down nearly 8%
summary: US auto sales in April are expected to decline nearly 8% from the same month in 2017, with 1.31 million units sold, according to industry consultants JD Power and LMC Automotive. Despite big discounts, the long-term sustainability of these discounts remains a concern. Full-year 2018 US new vehicle sales are forecasted to drop further, with LMC expecting around 17 million units, due to rising interest rates and increased competition from late-model used cars.

site_title: Prince William to be brother Harry's best man
summary: Prince Harry has asked his brother Prince William to be his best man at his upcoming wedding to Meghan Markle. The request was confirmed by Kensington Palace, citing the strong bond between the brothers, forged by the death of their mother Diana in 1997. William will also be holding the wedding ring during the ceremony, which is set to take place on May 19 at St George's Chapel, Windsor.

site_title: Women honoured for ideas with a cause
summary: Cartier has awarded six women US$100,000 each for their social entrepreneurship, recognizing their innovative ideas and impact on society. The winners include NEIDE Sellin for robotic guide dogs in Brazil, Paula Gomez for epilepsy prediction tools, Luz Rello for dyslexia testing and treatment, and five others from India, Austria, Lebanon, the US, and Cameroon. The awards, launched in 2006, provide significant funding and support to women entrepreneurs making a social impact, with 80% of past competitors still in operation and providing jobs for over 6,000 workers.

images.alt_text: Launched in 2006 by Cartier, the Women's Initiative Awards are not just for women with entrepreneurial flair; they must also make a big social impact with their enterprise.

site_title: Taste Of The Past
summary: A new restaurant, Circa 1912, is set to open in Singapore on May 1, celebrating traditional Chinese cooking from the early 20th century. Chef David Yip, who has spent over a decade researching and collecting recipes, will be serving dishes made with handmade ingredients and techniques, such as hand-chopped dim sum fillings and knife skills. The menu will feature classic Cantonese dishes with premium ingredients and traditional cooking methods, including sweet and sour pork, Golden Coin Chicken, and modernized desserts. Yip aims to bring back the elegance and complexity of traditional Chinese cuisine, and to educate diners about its flavors and techniques.

site_title: Bidders tussle for 2 out of 3 residential sites under govt land sales programme
summary: In Singapore's latest government land sales (GLS) tender, developers bid aggressively for three 99-year leasehold residential sites. The top bid for the Cuscaden Road site was S$410 million (S$2,377 per square foot per plot ratio), shattering the previous record for a residential GLS site. The Mattar Road site received 10 bids, with the top bid at S$223 million (S$1,109 psf ppr). In contrast, the Silat Avenue site received only one bid, at S$1.04 billion (S$1,138 psf ppr). Consultants expect the breakeven price for the Cuscaden Road site to be between S$3,100 and S$3,300 psf.

site_title: Oxley sticks a foot in the door at UE AGM
summary: Oxley Holdings' CEO Ching Chiat Kwong appealed to the board of United Engineers (UE) to reconsider his application for a board seat during the company's annual shareholder meeting. Oxley, which owns 16.56% of UE, has a 34.87% stake in the company. The board rejected his application previously, citing diversity of skills and backgrounds, but the nominating committee will consider his appeal again. Oxley also expressed concerns over UE's low share price and high debt-to-equity ratio, suggesting a rights issue instead of a share placement to avoid dilution to shareholders.

site_title: Make in India campaign misses its targets
summary: India's "Make in India" campaign, launched in 2014, aims to boost manufacturing and create 100 million jobs by 2022. However, the campaign has failed to meet its targets, with manufacturing growth averaging just 1.6% over the past five years and unemployment increasing to 5% in 2015-16. The government has removed bureaucratic bottlenecks, but challenges remain, including entrenched bureaucratic behavior, outdated economic systems, and a lack of accountability. A report by KPMG found that state-controlled Defence Public Sector Units (DPSUs) receive unfair advantages in awarding tenders, hindering the campaign's progress.

images.alt_text: A defence ministry presentation has identified long delays in procurement, blaming it on a disjointed approach and lack of planning. Acquisitions under the Buy and Make in India category still take the longest to become productive.

site_title: Fed at odds with itself as it eases bank rules and raises rates
summary: The Federal Reserve is at odds with itself as it eases bank rules to promote economic growth, while also raising interest rates to restrain credit creation. The Fed plans to free up tens of billions of dollars for banks to lend, but critics argue that this could lead to pro-cyclical policies that exacerbate financial conditions. The Fed's efforts to engineer a soft landing for the economy are complicated by the timing of these actions, which come as the economy is already being boosted by tax cuts and government spending.

site_title: SGX hits Trek 2000 with notice of compliance, seeks EGM and independent review
summary: SGX has issued a notice of compliance against Trek 2000 International, citing concerns over the company's internal controls and corporate governance practices. The exchange demands an extraordinary general meeting to vote on the continued appointment of key executives implicated in a recent forensic review, which found potential breaches of Singapore laws. Key executives, including Trek 2000 chairman and CEO Henn Tan, president Foo Kok Wah, and executive directors Poo Teng Pin and Gurcharan Singh, are barred from holding director or executive officer positions in listed companies for three years.

site_title: CapitaLand signs MOUs to explore projects in Zhejiang
summary: CapitaLand has signed two Memoranda of Understanding (MOUs) with Zhejiang province in China to explore large-scale business park and township projects in Ningbo and Jiaxing. The company's wholly owned subsidiary, CapitaLand China, will develop and manage these projects through strategic partnerships. This move aims to expand CapitaLand's master planning and urban design capabilities in China, capitalizing on the region's growing economic potential.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Ho Bee Land posts 12% drop in Q1 net profit, to begin marketing balance units in Sentosa soon
summary: Ho Bee Land reported a 12.3% drop in Q1 net profit to S$49.37 million due to a gain on the sale of an investment property. The company will begin marketing its unsold residential apartments in Sentosa Cove, with a focus on the 48 unsold units in Turquoise condo and 103 unsold units in Seascape. The company has around 80% of these units leased out, offering potential buyers a choice between generating rental income or vacant units.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Michelin Brunch
summary: Michelin-starred Song of India is celebrating its 13th anniversary with a one-day-only Sunday brunch on April 29. Chef Manjunath Mural and guest chefs will create dishes with a Singaporean theme, including Calcutta Kathi Roll, Sambal Stingray "Pau," and "Frenched" Kaya Toast. The buffet is priced at S$68 ++ and reservations can be made by calling 6836-0055. This event pays tribute to Manjunath Mural's time in Singapore and showcases regional Indian cuisine.

site_title: US core capital goods orders, shipments fall in March
summary: US core capital goods orders fell 0.1% in March, the first decline in six months, due to a 1.7% drop in machinery orders and a 0.7% decline in shipments. Economists had forecast a 0.5% increase. Despite a lower corporate tax rate, rising interest rates and material costs are expected to squeeze profit margins for manufacturers. Orders for durable goods increased 2.6% in March, driven by a 7.6% surge in transportation equipment demand.

site_title: Lakeside Towers up for public tender, with owners expecting S$305m for the development
summary: The owners of Lakeside Towers, a 99-year leasehold project in Jurong Lake Gardens, Singapore, have put the site up for public tender with an expected sale price of S$305 million. The 14,236.1 sq m site has an allowable gross plot ratio of 2.1 times, yielding approximately 321,797 sq ft of gross floor area. Strategically located near several malls and educational institutions, the site offers an excellent redevelopment opportunity for developers, according to Huttons Asia. The tender closes on May 28.

site_title: American Airlines Q1 profits hit by higher fuel costs
summary: American Airlines reported a 45.2% drop in Q1 profits to $186 million due to higher fuel costs, despite a 5.9% increase in revenues to $10.4 billion. Fuel costs rose nearly 10% due to a 30% increase in jet fuel prices. The airline expects higher customer fares if fuel prices stay high, with CEO Doug Parker predicting a "new normal" of higher energy costs. This contrasts with US carrier Southwest Airlines, which reported a 36.6% jump in earnings and record revenues.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler drives profits higher
summary: Fiat Chrysler reported a 59% increase in net profit to 1.021 billion euros in the first quarter, despite unfavorable exchange rate changes. The company sold 1.2 million vehicles, a 5% increase from last year, but revenue dipped 2% to 27.027 billion euros, falling short of analyst expectations. Exchange rate changes hurt revenue, with sales in the US impacted by the stronger euro. The company plans to release a new strategic outlook on June 1, with CEO Sergio Marchionne set to step down next year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.34 points to 1,852.27. Volume reached 2.05 billion lots worth RM2.13 billion, with 442 gainers outnumbering 349 losers.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Q1 bottom line falls 11% to 595.1m yuan
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 10.9% decline in net profit to 595.1 million yuan in Q1 2018, mainly due to currency appreciation and rising raw material costs. Revenue expanded 6% to 4.96 billion yuan, despite fewer vessels delivered. The company's earnings per share fell to 14.99 fen from 17.42 fen last year. Despite this, revenue from shipbuilding business increased, and net asset value per share edged up to 6.67 yuan. No dividend was declared for the quarter, and shares ended 0.9% higher at S$1.18.

site_title: Jalan Besar Plaza up for public tender for a fourth time
summary: Jalan Besar Plaza, a 16-storey mixed-use development in Singapore, is up for public tender for a fourth time. The site, with a land area of 4,927.8 sq m, has an existing approved Gross Floor Area (GFA) of 16,694 sq m and is zoned for commercial and residential use. The owners expect a price of S$380 million, translating to a land rate of S$2,115 psf ppr, and the public tender closes on June 5.

site_title: Working adults in S'pore have inadequate cover if critical illness strikes: study
summary: A study by the Life Insurance Association found that working adults in Singapore have inadequate critical illness coverage, with policies that would meet only 20% of their needs. The recommended coverage is about 3.9 times the average annual pay, but the current average coverage is just S$60,000. The study highlights the need for targeted solutions to ensure adequate protection for individuals and their loved ones, with plans to introduce an industry-wide digital calculator to empower Singaporeans to take more responsibility for their health and protection needs.

site_title: Peugeot's UK Vauxhall car workers agree pay deal as dispute in Germany continues
summary: Workers at Peugeot's Vauxhall car plant in Britain have agreed to a pay deal, receiving a £750 lump sum and a 1.5% pay rise in January 2019. The deal mirrors a similar agreement at the firm's southern English van site. In contrast, Opel workers in Germany continue to protest against PSA's plans to rein in wages in exchange for new production investments. The UK deal aims to secure investment and ensure the plant's long-term future, while the German dispute remains unresolved.

site_title: Europe: Stocks diverge at open before ECB
summary: Europe's main stock markets diverged at the start of trading on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index shedding 0.3% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 dipping 0.2%. Paris' CAC 40 rose 0.1%. Investors were awaiting the European Central Bank's interest rate call, while results from energy giant Shell and banking group Barclays also influenced trading.

site_title: Oxley chiefs appeal for board seat at United Engineers AGM
summary: Oxley Holdings' chairman and CEO Ching Chiat Kwong and deputy CEO Eric Low made a surprise appearance at United Engineers' (UE) annual shareholder meeting, appealing for a director's seat on the board. Oxley, a substantial shareholder, owns 16.56% of UE, following a 33.5% stake acquisition by Perennial Real Estate and Yanlord Land. The board rejected Ching's application last time, citing diversity of skills and backgrounds. However, the nominating committee will reconsider his appeal. Oxley also expressed concerns over UE's debt-to-equity ratio and suggested a rights issue instead of a share placement.

site_title: US: Nasdaq up 1% as tech earnings impress, yields pull back
summary: US stocks rose, with the Nasdaq up 1% as tech earnings impressed investors. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also opened higher. Bond yields pulled back from the 3% level, contributing to the market's gain. Facebook's 9% jump in shares after strong results also boosted the Nasdaq. Despite ongoing US-China trade tensions, investors remained optimistic, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging towards fresh records.

site_title: Pacific Radiance debt restructuring receives 'in-principle' support from major lenders, anchor investors
summary: Pacific Radiance, an offshore marine operator, has received 'in-principle' support from major lenders and anchor investors for its debt restructuring. The deal involves debt forgiveness and debt-to-equity conversion, with investors providing an equity injection to pare down debt and cover future working capital. The company will also make an impairment on the value of its assets. This move aims to restructure the company's debt and improve its financial stability.

site_title: ECB's Draghi says growth has moderated, outlook solid
summary: ECB President Mario Draghi stated that economic growth in the euro zone has moderated but remains solid, while external threats such as protectionism have increased. The ECB maintained its current policies, including buying 30 billion euros in government and corporate bonds per month, and kept interest rates at zero percent. The institution expects to wind down its bond-buying program by the end of the year and raise its policy rate in mid-2026. Risks to euro area growth remain balanced, but global factors, including protectionism, have become more prominent.

images.alt_text: Economic growth in the euro zone has moderated but is expected to remain solid, while external threats including protectionism have become more prominent, ECB President Mario Draghi said on Thursday.

site_title: Competition watchdog approves BRC Asia's takeover offer for Lee Metal
summary: Singapore's Competition and Consumer Commission has approved BRC Asia's takeover offer for Lee Metal Group at 42 Singapore cents per share. The offer, conditional on achieving requisite acceptances, aims to delist the company. BRC Asia has pledged not to make significant changes to Lee Metal's business, employees, or assets. Undertakings from 48.06% of Lee Metal's shareholders have accepted the offer, clearing the preconditions for the deal.

site_title: CapitaLand Retail China Trust Q1 DPU almost flat, gross revenue down
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) reported a marginal increase in its first-quarter distribution per unit to 2.75 Singapore cents, a 0.4% rise from the same period last year. However, its gross revenue declined 7.9% to S$55.4 million, mainly due to the divestment of CapitaMall Anzhen in 2017 and lower revenue from CapitaMall Grand Canyon. Despite this, the trust's annualised distribution yield for the quarter was 7.2%. The malls' occupancy and tenants' sales increased year-on-year by 2.1% and 7.7%, respectively.

site_title: GuocoLand Q3 net profit up 7% to S$31.5m
summary: GuocoLand's third-quarter net profit rose 7% to S$31.5 million, driven by strong sales of completed residential projects, particularly in Singapore, and higher revenue from its property investment business. Revenue decreased 15% to S$230.6 million, and gross profit fell 5% to S$60.1 million. Earnings per share was 2.62 Singapore cents, down from 2.66 cents a year earlier, but net asset value per share increased to S$3.35.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit Q3 DPU dips to 1.09 Singapore cents
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a 7.6% decrease in distribution per unit to 1.09 Singapore cents for the third quarter, with gross revenue and net property income also declining 3% and 2.3% respectively. The Reit attributed the decline to weaker office contributions and disruption from asset redevelopment works. Despite the challenges, the Reit's portfolio has been relatively resilient, and its focus on niche prime locations and rejuvenation efforts is expected to help it weather the transformation of the retail landscape.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: NOBLE Group responded to Goldilocks Investment Company's lawsuits, calling them "without merit" and an attempt to delay restructuring. Singapore's factory output rose 5.9% in March, meeting economists' predictions. The Monetary Authority of Singapore proposes guidelines to boost individual accountability at financial institutions. RydeX, a private-car hire service, will launch on May 2, offering two options. Meanwhile, CapitaLand plans to invest in high-tech business parks in China, and a Midas subsidiary was placed under judicial management in China.

site_title: DBS accelerates transition to renewable energy, targets 40% energy use from renewables by end-2018
summary: DBS Group Holdings has accelerated its transition to renewable energy, aiming to generate 40% of its energy consumption in Singapore from renewable sources by the end of 2018. The bank had previously pledged to use 100% renewable energy by 2030 and was the first Asian bank and Singapore company to join the global RE100 initiative in 2017.

site_title: Cosco Shipping issues profit guidance for Q1
summary: Cosco Shipping International has issued profit guidance for the first quarter, expecting a net profit despite a previous net loss in the same period last year. The company's recent acquisitions, Cogent Holdings and PT Ocean Global Shipping, are attributed to the expected profit. Cosco shares closed flat at S$0.465 on the day of the announcement, set to release its earnings on May 15.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks hit by fresh losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined by 1.06% on Thursday, following broad losses across Asia, with technology firms and energy giants among the big losers. The Hang Seng Index closed at 30,007.68, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 1.38% and the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 2.15%. This marks the latest in a series of losses for Hong Kong stocks, which have been affected by global market volatility and trade tensions.

site_title: Singapore shares close flat on Thursday
summary: Singapore stocks ended flat on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.06% to 3,570.02, despite a 2.01-point gain in afternoon trades. The bourse saw 244 losers compared to 180 gainers, with 2.73 billion shares traded for S$1.53 billion. This follows a 0.4% gain on Wednesday, as investors remained optimistic despite tariff uncertainty and mixed Federal Reserve views.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: TTJ Holdings secures new contracts, raises value of order book to S$217m
summary: TTJ Holdings secured new contracts, increasing its order book to S$217 million. The company expects to complete most orders between FY2018 and FY2021. Chairman Teo Hock Chwee stated that the new wins demonstrate the company's market strength and competitive strategy. With anticipated construction demand in Singapore, TTJ plans to pursue new business opportunities to sustain its order book momentum. The company's shares closed unchanged at S$0.305.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance Q1 net profit increases 57% to S$25.9m
summary: Hong Leong Finance reported a 57% increase in Q1 net profit to S$25.9 million, driven by a 37% gain in net interest income/hiring charges. Interest on loans rose 11.4%, while hiring charges increased 16%. The company's net asset value per share edged up to S$4.14, and its shares ended 0.7% down at S$2.74. Despite the increase, the company's earnings per share rose only to 23.22 Singapore cents from 14.83 Singapore cents in the previous year.

site_title: Hyphens Pharma International lodges preliminary offer document
summary: Hyphens Pharma International has lodged its preliminary offer document for a listing on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange. The pharmaceutical and consumer healthcare group will raise funds for business expansion, including potential acquisitions and product development. Three cornerstone investors, including Nikko Asset Management Asia and Maxi-Harvest Group, have subscribed to 30.4 million shares, while Inomed Holding will retain 196.21 million shares. The company plans to distribute at least 30% of its net profit as dividends and use the funds for business growth and general corporate purposes.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Jardine C&C's Q1 earnings drop 36% to US$135m on fair-value investment loss
