summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage's (Jardine C&C) Q1 earnings dropped 36% to US$135.4 million due to fair-value losses from equity investments. Revenue rose 12% to US$4.64 billion, despite a 4% decline in Indonesian subsidiary Astra's earnings. The company's underlying profit increased 8% to US$219 million. Other strategic interests, such as Vinamilk and Siam City Cement, contributed to the overall performance, with growth expected in the full year.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: PODCAST: Should you invest in ICOs or IPOs? (Money Hacks, Ep 7)
summary: In the Money Hacks podcast episode 7, chairman of the Association of Cryptocurrency Enterprises and Startups Singapore, Anson Zeall, discusses investing in ICOs (Initial Coin Offerings) versus IPOs (Initial Public Offerings). Zeall emphasizes that ICOs are not suitable for retail investors, as they involve high risks. He advises consulting a financial advisor before making any investment decisions. Zeall notes that Asia, particularly Singapore, is driving dollar asset diversification, which may impact global markets.

site_title: MPA extends MFM mandate to distillates bunker fuel
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has extended its mandate for mass flow meters (MFMs) for distillate bunker fuel deliveries to international ships starting July 2019. To aid suppliers, MPA has set aside S$9 million to co-fund MFMs adoption costs. This move aligns Singapore's marine fuel industry with a global regulation aimed at reducing ship emissions.

site_title: Top bids for Cuscaden site, Mattar Road site and Silat Avenue come in at S$410m, S$223m and S$1.04b respectively
summary: SC Global Developments, FEC Properties, and New World Development submitted the top bids for prime residential sites in Orchard Road, Cuscaden Road (S$410m), Mattar Road (S$223m), and Silat Avenue (S$1.04b), outbidding eight other bidders. The sites closed under the Government Land Sales programme, with the highest bid per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr) reaching S$2,377 for the Cuscaden Road site. The bids will determine the future development of these prime locations in Singapore's Orchard Road district.

site_title: Apsil inks MOUs for partnerships in China, proposes name change
summary: Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments (Apsil) has inked two partnerships in China, one with Hangzhou Grand Canal Comprehensive Protection & Development Group for the development of areas surrounding the Grand Canal, and another with Shenzhen-listed YaGuang Technology Group to jointly market and promote river yachts. Apsil has also proposed a name change to China Real Estate Group to better represent its new strategic thrust as a lifestyle property developer. The group aims to create a premier integrated leisure-cum-lifestyle hub in the Huzhou Project, located in the Yangtze River Economic Belt.

site_title: MOU between Epicentre and Coterie Dining Concepts lapses
summary: Epicentre Holdings announced that a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with Coterie Dining Concepts and Coterie's shareholders has lapsed. The six-month agreement, signed on October 27, 2017, was not extended. As a result, Epicentre shares, which traded at S$0.085 on April 17, will no longer be bound by the agreement.

site_title: MLT's Q4 DPU up 4%, to acquire 50% stake in 11 China properties for 985.3m yuan
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) reported a 4% increase in fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.937 Singapore cents, driven by organic growth, redevelopment in Singapore, and acquisitions. The trust plans to acquire a 50% stake in 11 Chinese logistics properties for 985.3 million yuan, doubling its net lettable space in China and increasing e-commerce revenue exposure. MLT's gross revenue and net property income rose 11% and 14% respectively in the quarter, with a 27% increase in distributable amount to unitholders.

site_title: Ford gets record fine in Australia for 'unconscionable' conduct
summary: Ford has been fined a record A$10 million (S$10.04 million) in Australia for its "unconscionable" handling of gearbox complaints on its PowerShift transmissions. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) accused Ford of failing to properly deal with thousands of complaints about shuddering in the transmissions, which were fitted to its Fiesta, Focus, and EcoSport models. The fine is the largest ever handed down under Australian consumer law, and about 10,000 people may be eligible for remediation.

site_title: Activist investor Elliott buys UK bookshop chain Waterstones
summary: Elliott Advisers, a US activist hedge fund, has acquired British bookshop chain Waterstones, providing all financing for the transaction. The deal represents a "happy outcome" for the bookshop chain, according to CEO James Daunt. Waterstones had previously returned to profitability after facing challenges in 2011. The acquisition follows Elliott's recent involvement in other UK companies, including Costa Coffee and GKN. The deal is expected to be completed in May.

site_title: MAS proposes guidelines to boost individual accountability at financial institutions
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) proposes guidelines to boost individual accountability at financial institutions, requiring them to identify and hold senior managers accountable for the actions of their staff and the conduct of business. The guidelines also promote a culture of responsibility and ethical conduct among employees, with a framework for promoting and sustaining desired conduct and incentive systems to encourage proper behavior. The consultation period is open until May 25, 2018.

site_title: Noble hits back at Goldilocks' 'without merit' lawsuits; Elman says Goldilocks doesn't represent shareholders
summary: NOBLE Group has responded to lawsuits filed by its major shareholder, Goldilocks Investment Company, as "without merit" and an attempt to hinder its restructuring plan. Founder Richard Elman stated that Goldilocks does not represent the views of other substantial shareholders. NOBLE will vigorously defend its claims and seek costs orders against Goldilocks. The company's restructuring plan aims to avoid a full insolvency process, which would result in no return for its shareholders.

images.alt_text: NOBLE Group has returned fire at Goldilocks Investment Company, blasting lawsuits its major shareholder has filed against it as "without merit" and an "intentional attempt to obfuscate, delay, derail and/or prevent" the company from implementing what is says is a do-or-die restructuring plan.

site_title: SilkAir inks 12-year services contract with SIAEC for 737 MAX fleet
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) has signed a 12-year, S$484 million contract with SilkAir to provide maintenance, repair, and overhaul services for its 37 Boeing 737 MAX aircraft. The agreement includes an option to renew for an additional five years, covering a range of services. This marks the continuation of SIAEC's existing partnership with SilkAir, which also owns SIAEC and operates Airbus A320 and Boeing 737-800 aircraft.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Euro edges off eight-week lows ahead of ECB meeting
summary: The euro edged off eight-week lows ahead of the European Central Bank meeting, where investors are seeking signals on when the bank will begin unwinding its stimulus. The euro rose 0.1% to $1.2168, but remains 2.5 cents off its recent low. The ECB's decision is expected to reiterate patience and prudence in monetary policy, with analysts predicting a lack of signals on the next policy move. The euro has been stuck in a trading range against the US dollar since a strong rally into February.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise on tech rally; won flat
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 1.1% on Thursday, driven by a tech rally, with Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix shares gaining 3.5% and 5% respectively. LG Electronics also posted a record quarterly profit, while Hyundai Motor's first-quarter net profit halved, leading to a 4.6% drop. The Korean won remained stable, and bond yields fell.

site_title: New board at Singapore Indian Chamber focuses on recruitment, gender diversity
summary: The newly elected board of the Singapore Indian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SICCI) has set recruitment and gender diversity as its top priorities for the 2018-2020 term. Led by T Chandroo, the board aims to have women occupying at least a third of its 17 board seats and increase membership from 550 to 2,000 over the next two years. To achieve this, the Chamber will offer reduced fees for women members and establish a women-run committee to drive women-focused entrepreneurial and leadership programs.

site_title: Nintendo appoints new chief with switch console on solid ground
summary: Nintendo appoints Shuntaro Furukawa, 46, as its new president, replacing Tatsumi Kimishima, after reporting solid Switch console sales and profits on track to be the highest since 2010. Furukawa, a senior executive with 24 years of experience, aims to balance Nintendo's traditions of originality and flexibility. The company forecasts 225 billion yen in profit for the fiscal year, driven by strong game sales and the introduction of Labo cardboard accessories. Nintendo expects to sell 100 million software titles for the Switch in the coming year.

site_title: Opportunities for deeper collaboration between S'pore & Vietnam in clean energy, smart cities and digital economy
summary: Singapore and Vietnam have strengthened their economic ties with 16 memoranda of understanding signed during the Vietnam-Singapore Business Dialogue. The dialogue celebrates 45 years of diplomatic relations and five years of strategic partnership between the two countries. Singapore is Vietnam's third-largest investor, with $43 billion invested in over 1,800 projects, and bilateral trade has doubled to $19.8 billion in 2016. Opportunities for collaboration in clean energy, smart cities, and the digital economy have been highlighted, with Singapore companies looking to contribute to Vietnam's development in these areas.

site_title: Singapore Maritime Week 2018: Singapore shares its collaboration initiatives to promote sustainable shipping
summary: Singapore has shared its collaboration initiatives to promote sustainable shipping during the Singapore Maritime Week 2018. Senior Minister of State for Transport and Health Lam Pin Min highlighted three examples of Singapore's efforts, including a focus group on liquefied natural gas bunkering, enhanced technical cooperation with the International Maritime Organization (IMO), and a Green Ship Programme that encourages efficient ship designs. The country has also seen an increase in low-sulfur marine fuel calls, with over 4,100 calls in 2018, double the number in 2013.

site_title: UK rents fall for first time since 2012 - report
summary: UK rents fell 0.5% in the January-March period, marking the first decline since 2012, according to the Deposit Protection Service. The slowdown began in mid-2016, linked to the EU referendum result, and is attributed to general economic uncertainty. Rents in London fell 1.4% and in Northern Ireland by 3.1%. A separate report showed falling demand for retail properties, while demand for industrial space rose. The decline in rents could be linked to fewer people moving and landlords seeking to reduce rent prices.

site_title: Singapore Maritime Week 2018: Record number of graduating seafarers
summary: Singapore Maritime Week 2018 marked a record number of graduating seafarers from Certificate of Competency (CoC) (Special Limit) programmes at Singapore Polytechnic, with 80 seafarers graduating. The programmes prepare seafarers for ships up to 30 nautical miles off Singapore waters and include courses at the Singapore Maritime Academy and on-the-job training. The graduates can pursue deck or marine engineer officer tracks, with 44 completing special limit courses and 18 graduating from Class 5, allowing them to be 2nd engineers or chief mates. The certificates are internationally recognized and valid for five years.

site_title: Nomura Q4 profit slides 63% as retail investor risk appetite falls
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc, Japan's largest brokerage and investment bank, reported a 63% fall in fourth-quarter net profit to 22.7 billion yen due to declining risk appetite among retail clients amid volatile markets. The annual net profit fell 8% to 219.3 billion yen. The retail division's pre-tax profit slid 17% in the fourth quarter, while the overseas division recorded a pre-tax loss of 18.7 billion yen. Nomura also announced plans to buy back up to 70 billion yen of its own shares.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher as yen stays weak
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.47% and the Topix index up 0.25%, driven by a weaker yen. Investors sought shares in companies expected to report strong earnings. The benchmark indices ended at 22,319.61 and 1,772.13, respectively.

site_title: Asia: Stocks climb as tech rises; US dollar steadies
summary: Asian stocks rose as technology companies reported positive earnings, with South Korean shares leading gains after Samsung Electronics topped estimates. US dollar steadied near its highest in three months, while Treasuries pared losses. The euro edged higher ahead of the European Central Bank rate decision, and crude oil pushed higher above $68 a barrel. Despite pockets of concern around technology companies, investors remain optimistic about global equities, which trade at elevated valuations.

site_title: What Amazon's new headquarters could mean for rents
summary: Amazon's new headquarters in Nashville, Tennessee, has sparked concerns about rising rents and affordability. City leaders see the project as a step towards economic growth, but locals fear it will exacerbate the housing crisis. Paulette Coleman, a local advocate, warns that the influx of new people and higher-income earners will further strain the city's housing market. The project's impact on rents is uncertain, but it highlights the challenges of balancing economic growth with affordable housing.

site_title: Singapore factory output up 5.9% in March amid strong semiconductor growth
summary: Singapore's factory output grew 5.9% in March, surpassing economists' predictions of a 5.7% rise, according to preliminary Economic Development Board figures. Excluding biomedical manufacturing, output increased 8.6% year-over-year. On a seasonally adjusted basis, manufacturing output edged up 0.3% in March. This growth is attributed to strong semiconductor growth, with the sector contributing significantly to the country's overall output.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Australian shares end lower, weighed by financials; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% to 5,910.80, weighed down by financial stocks, a weak Australian dollar, and mortgage concerns. Westpac Banking Corp dropped 3.6% to its lowest in over two years, while Healthscope posted a 14.8% gain to boost the healthcare sector. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.1% to 8,282.05, with utilities accounting for most of the losses. The decline in financials and banks offset gains in healthcare, with the S&P/ASX 200 index ending at a 0.2% loss.

site_title: 3 retired permanent secretaries join boards of ComfortDelGro and its subsidiaries
summary: ComfortDelGro Corp has appointed three retired permanent secretaries to its board and the boards of its subsidiaries. The appointees include Mr Chiang Chie Foo, former permanent secretary at the Prime Minister's Office and Ministry of Defence, security expert Benny Lim, and Dr Tan Kim Siew, former permanent secretary for defence development. The new directors bring decades of experience and expertise in various disciplines. The company's group chairman, Lim Jit Poh, praised the appointees for their significant contributions and pioneering efforts, noting they have collectively served the company for 171 years.

site_title: Hamptons home shoppers want luxury, but they also want discounts
summary: Luxury-home buyers in New York's Hamptons spent $5 million or more on properties, but all deals were at less than the asking price. The market saw 37 deals in the first quarter, the most in four years, with luxury listings increasing 13% from last year. The median price of luxury transactions rose 28% to $6.6 million, while overall sales fell 21% to 528 homes. Buyers were cautious due to changes in the federal tax law and stock-market volatility, with some delaying closings until they understood the implications.

site_title: Duterte greenlights 736b pesos of airport, rail projects
summary: President Rodrigo Duterte approved a multi-billion-dollar proposal to build an alternative to Manila's congested airport, investing 735.6 billion pesos in Bulacan province. The government also approved a 12.6 billion pesos tender to operate Clark international airport and a 50 billion pesos railway project connecting Clark to the Subic free port. A total of 20 projects and funding plans were given the go-ahead, including 12 airport and rail projects.

site_title: 'Game of Thrones' author announces new book
summary: Game of Thrones author George RR Martin has announced a new book, "Fire and Blood", set several centuries before the series, to be released in November. The book is a historical text detailing the history of Westeros' Targaryen dynasty, not the long-awaited sixth installment of the "Game of Thrones" series. Martin also stated that "The Winds of Winter" will not be released in 2018, contradicting previous expectations.

site_title: Gold is little changed near five-week low as higher US dollar, bond yields weigh
summary: Gold prices remain little changed near a five-week low due to a stronger US dollar and rising bond yields. Spot gold rose 0.05% to $1,323.66 per ounce, while US gold futures gained 0.1% to $1,324.7 an ounce. A stronger dollar makes gold more expensive for holders of other currencies, and higher bond yields reduce demand for non-interest yielding bullion. The US Treasury yield edged above 3% on Wednesday, and Asian stocks rebounded from three-week lows.

site_title: Sias urges Vard minority shareholders to show up at EGM and vote on proposed delisting
summary: Sias, a securities investors association, is urging Vard Holdings minority shareholders to attend their upcoming general meeting to vote on a proposed delisting. The group claims minority shareholders are dissatisfied with a $0.25 per share offer, stating it doesn't reflect the company's real value. If enough shareholders vote against the delisting, it could still be blocked.

site_title: Ryde to launch private-car hire service RydeX on May 2
summary: Ryde will launch its private-hire car service RydeX on May 2, offering two options: RydeX Scheduled and RydeEXEC. RydeX Scheduled lets commuters book a ride 10 minutes to 7 days in advance, while RydeEXEC provides luxury car options. The service aims to attract 10,000 to 15,000 private-hire car drivers, with fares starting from S$8 and averaging 60 Singapore cents per kilometre. Ryde will charge a 10% commission on drivers and offer post-trip tipping, allowing users to request specific drivers or block unwanted ones.

site_title: Midas subsidiary placed under judicial management in Jilin province, China
summary: Midas Holdings subsidiary Jilin Midas Light Alloy Co has been placed under judicial management by the People's Court of Jilin Province in China. The move comes amid investigations into financial irregularities, with shares suspended. The company reported that four senior executives in China resigned following internal checks revealing a failure to report material information. Midas faces an arbitration application in Beijing over a 100 million yuan loan agreement. Operations at the subsidiary remain normal, and the company is arranging to obtain information related to litigations and undisclosed subsidiaries.

site_title: Barclays first-quarter profit surprise marred by US fines
summary: Barclays reported a better-than-expected first-quarter pretax profit of £1.7 billion, driven by improved income at its investment bank. However, the bank took significant hits from US fines and legal costs related to historic misconduct issues, resulting in a statutory loss. The fines, totaling £1.8 billion, included a £1.4 billion settlement with the US Justice Department and £400 million for claims against mis-selling of payment insurance products in Britain. Barclays still plans to pay a dividend of 6.5 pence per share in 2018.

site_title: Industrial prices, rents 'relatively stable' in Q1: JTC
summary: Industrial prices and rentals in Singapore remained relatively stable in Q1 2018, with industrial rents dipping 0.1% and prices falling 0.1% from the previous quarter. Occupancy rates rose to 89% and transaction volumes stabilized, increasing 1.2% from the last quarter. New industrial space is expected to come on-stream, with 1.4 million sq m estimated for 2018, compared to 1.7 million sq m of average annual supply and 1.2 million sq m of average annual demand in the past three years.

site_title: Qualitas Medical delays IPO on SGX, cites non-optimal pricing & market volatility
summary: Qualitas Medical is delaying its initial public offering (IPO) on the Singapore Exchange's mainboard due to non-optimal pricing and market volatility. The clinic operator had expected to raise S$100 million to S$133 million, but decided to delay the deal. Despite the delay, Qualitas plans to execute its business plan through organic growth and mergers and acquisitions. This is the second Singapore-listed company to delay its IPO this week, following Summit Power International. Qualitas had previously spent three years on the SGX's Catalist board before being taken private in 2011.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.79 points, or 0.26%, to 1856.19, with 84 gainers outnumbering 40 losers. The market opened higher on Thursday, with 63.7 million lots traded worth RM14.2 million.

site_title: Generation gap: South Koreans fear, welcome and ignore the North
summary: In South Korea, differing attitudes towards the North Korea summit vary among generations and politics. A 52-year-old businessman, Lee Jeong Jin, welcomes the diplomatic developments, seeing reunification as a step towards lasting peace. In contrast, a 84-year-old retired professor, Lew Je Bong, remains wary, citing Pyongyang's history of broken promises and nuclear threats. Younger South Koreans, like hip hop artist Choi Won Young, show little interest, with many opposing reunification due to concerns about job competition and the North's authoritarian image.

images.alt_text: In the freewheeling democracy of South Korea, views of the authoritarian North, the prospects for reunification, and Friday's summit between President Moon Jae In and Pyongyang's leader Kim Jong Un vary widely.

site_title: Las Vegas Sands sees record Q1 results as earnings at Marina Bay Sands jump 48.6%
summary: Las Vegas Sands Corp reported record Q1 results, with net income rising 179.1% to US$1.62 billion and revenue growing 16.7% to US$3.58 billion. Marina Bay Sands in Singapore saw EBITDA jump 48.6% to US$541 million, driven by a surge in betting. Casino revenue in Macau grew 22% in the first quarter, with EBITDA rising 26% to US$789 million. The company's shares rose 2.3% to US$74 in extended trading.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: CapitaLand to explore investments in high-tech business park, township in Zhejiang
summary: CapitaLand, a Singapore-based real estate company, has signed two Memoranda of Understanding with Ningbo and Jiaxing in China's Zhejiang province to explore investments in high-tech business parks and townships. The partnerships aim to support the region's push for higher-tech manufacturing industries and transform its manufacturing sector into a smart, high-quality industry. CapitaLand, one of Asia's largest real estate fund managers, has a strong track record in integrated developments and capital management, and plans to expand its business presence in Zhejiang.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand is set to broaden its master planning and urban design capabilities in China through new strategic partnerships in China's Zhejiang province.
Ann Williams

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes flat on Thursday afternoon at 3,567.29
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading in negative territory on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 0.72 points to 3,567.29. The market saw a slight decline despite a 5-day rally, as investors were cautious due to tariff uncertainty. Losers outnumbered gainers 179 to 150, with approximately 1.38 billion shares worth S$746 million changing hands.

site_title: Australian shares flat as financials fall; NZ tepid
summary: Australian shares were flat on Thursday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index falling 1.40 points to 5,920.20, as a decline in financial stocks and a fall in the local currency offset gains in energy firms. Banks, led by Westpac's 4.4% drop, accounted for most of the losses, while energy stocks like Woodside Petroleum and Origin Energy rose 1.6% and 1.8% respectively. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 3.68 points to 8,292.32, driven by gains in the healthcare sector.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS, Maybank raise target price on Suntec Reit; OCBC upgrades to 'hold'
summary: Brokers DBS Group Research and Maybank Kim Eng have upgraded their target prices on Suntec Reit to S$2.30 and S$1.94, respectively. DBS maintains its 'buy' call, while Maybank keeps its 'hold' stance. The upgrades follow Suntec Reit's Q1 2018 distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.433 Singapore cents, in line with forecasts. OCBC Investment Research has also upgraded Suntec Reit to 'hold' with a target price of S$1.94, citing an 11.6% rise in the Reit's share price and less demanding valuations.

site_title: Huawei said to be probed by FBI for possible Iran violations
summary: The US Justice Department is investigating Huawei Technologies Co for possible violations of sanctions banning sales to Iran, along with the US Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control and the Department of Commerce. The FBI and OFAC probes began in 2017, focusing on transactions with rogue nations, including Syria, Iran, and North Korea. Huawei has denied any wrongdoing and claims to comply with all applicable laws and regulations, while some analysts warn that a finding of wrongdoing could have wide ramifications on various suppliers.

site_title: Singapore and Zhejiang to cooperate on Belt and Road opportunities
summary: Singapore and Zhejiang province, China, will deepen cooperation under the Belt and Road Initiative, focusing on innovation, urban solutions, and e-commerce. Senior Minister of State Sim Ann announced the plans during the annual meeting of the Singapore-Zhejiang Economic and Trade Council, where 14 projects were signed, including a joint venture between a Singapore software company and a Zhejiang real estate developer. The cooperation aims to encourage Chinese firms to tap Singapore's network in South-east Asia and use Singapore as a base for regional headquarters and funding.

site_title: Iran rejects new deal as France vows it will never get atomic weapons
summary: Iran's President Hassan Rouhani rejected a new nuclear deal with world powers, while French President Emmanuel Macron vowed to prevent Iran from acquiring atomic weapons. Macron proposed an additional deal extending Iran's nuclear restrictions, while Rouhani reiterated that the existing 2015 deal, known as the JCPOA, would either last or not. European officials, including EU diplomatic chief Federica Mogherini, urged US President Donald Trump to preserve the existing deal, which is set to expire in 2025.

site_title: Air France unions announce four days of strikes in May
summary: Air France pilots' unions have announced four days of strikes in May, calling for a 5.1% wage increase. The strikes, set for May 3-8, follow 11 previous days of strikes in a long-running pay dispute. The airline's CEO, Jean-Marc Janaillac, has threatened to resign if staff reject his wage proposals, which include a 2% increase for 2018 and 5% increases for 2019 and 2021. The dispute has set the airline back by 220 million euros and chiefly affects short-haul flights.

site_title: Agilent Technologies opens global solution development centre in Singapore
summary: Agilent Technologies has opened a global solution development centre in Singapore as part of its $85 million investment and expansion plan. The five-year plan, announced last July, demonstrates the company's commitment to Singapore. Agilent provides laboratories with instruments, analytics, and solutions, employing approximately 520 staff in Singapore. The new centre marks a significant expansion of the company's presence in the country.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Europe: Shares fall as bond yields rise, metals prices slide
summary: European shares fell to a one-week low due to rising bond yields and sliding metals prices, despite positive earnings updates from Kering and Credit Suisse. The Stoxx 600 index dropped 0.8% and Germany's DAX fell 1%. Higher US Treasury yields, breaching 3%, made equities less attractive, with concerns over higher bond yields lingering.

site_title: Samsung Elec flags mobile weakness as chips power record Q1 profit
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a record quarterly profit of 15.6 trillion won, driven by strong demand for semiconductors used in servers. The company flagged weakness in the smartphone market, citing softer demand for OLED panels, but expects its memory chip business to remain strong. Operating profit from the chip business reached a record 11.6 trillion won, while mobile business profit rose 82% year-over-year to 3.8 trillion won. Global smartphone demand fell 2% to 347 million units, but average sales prices rose 21% year-over-year.

site_title: Changi Airport handled 5.56m passengers in March, an 8.7% rise from year ago
summary: Changi Airport handled 5.56 million passengers in March, a 8.7% increase from the previous year. Aircraft movements rose 5.4% with 32,590 landings and takeoffs, while cargo shipments decreased 0.6% to 187,550 tonnes. Strong demand for flights to Europe, Australia, and Asia drove growth, with traffic to and from Europe up 13% and between Singapore and Australia up 9%. Overall, first-quarter traffic jumped 5% to 15.8 million passengers, with airfreight movements increasing 3.6% to 512,080 tonnes.

site_title: Hot stock: Venture slips 10% after posting 72% jump in Q1 earnings
summary: Venture Corporation's shares fell 10.2% to S$20.27 after posting a 72.2% growth in net profit to S$83.7 million in Q1 earnings. Revenue grew 1.5% to S$856 million, and analysts cut their target prices to S$25.64 and S$30, citing concerns over earnings peaking and a weaker USD. The company's chairman dismissed reports of a plateaued cigarette substitute product, and a short sale of 1 million shares worth S$26.9 million was recently uncovered.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise on tech rally; won steady
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 1.09% to 2,475.40, driven by tech shares, including Samsung Electronics, SK Hynix, and LG Electronics, after the company posted a record quarterly profit. The won held steady at 1,079.6 per US dollar, while bond yields fell. The economy grew 1.1% in the first quarter, boosted by exports and government spending, but private consumption remained sluggish.

site_title: Japan's Abe says he's not thinking of calling a snap election
summary: Japan Prime Minister Shinzo Abe denied plans to call a snap general election, contradicting a ruling party official who said it was an option. Abe's public support has been low due to scandals, and a snap election could give him a fresh mandate. However, Abe stated that dissolving parliament for an election was "not in my mind at all." This move could potentially affect his chances of winning a leadership election in September.

images.alt_text: Japan Prime Minister Shinzo Abe denied he was thinking of calling a snap general election, a day after a ruling party official told reporters it was an option.

site_title: NBA: LeBron's buzzer-beater gives Cavs 3-2 edge on Pacers
summary: LeBron James scored 44 points, including a buzzer-beating three-pointer, to lead the Cleveland Cavaliers to a 98-95 victory over the Indiana Pacers, securing a 3-2 series lead in the first round of the NBA playoffs. James also contributed 10 rebounds, eight assists, and a block on the Pacers' final possession. The Cavaliers shot 41.3% from the floor, with Kyle Korver adding 19 points and Kevin Love contributing 11 points and 10 rebounds.

site_title: UK announces £1b drive into artificial intelligence
summary: The UK government has announced a £1 billion investment into its artificial intelligence industry, partnering with tech giants and venture capital firms. This drive aims to boost the sector, which is seen as crucial for the UK's future growth. The investment will focus on ethics, safety, and regulation, with the UK potentially leading discussions on these topics. The government also plans to fund 1,000 PhD places and 8,000 new computer science teachers, and has agreed to open an AI supercomputer and a Center for Data Ethics and Innovation.

images.alt_text: Antony Phillipson, the UK Trade Commissioner for North America and Consul General in New York, said in an interview ahead of the announcement that the UK could not compete with China in terms of total funding or scale of some government-run AI projects.

site_title: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust places S$330m of units at S$1.06 apiece
summary: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust (MGCCT) raised S$330.3 million from a private placement of 312 million units at S$1.06 apiece, a 3.2% discount to its VWAP. The trust plans to use the funds to finance part of the acquisition cost of six Tokyo-based commercial real estate assets. The joint global coordinators and bookrunners are Citigroup Global Markets Singapore, DBS Bank, and The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation Limited, Singapore.

site_title: South Korean economy bounces back in Q1 on exports, govt spending
summary: South Korea's economy rebounded in Q1 with a 1.1% growth rate, driven by a 4.4% increase in export volumes, particularly in data memory chips. Government spending also contributed to the growth, with a 2.5% rise in quarterly gains. Private consumption, however, remained sluggish, and the service sector's food and lodging services declined 0.9%. Economists expect domestic demand to recover in the second half, with exports continuing to lead growth. The central bank forecasts a 3% economic expansion this year, despite global demand uncertainty.

site_title: Malaysia to double airport capacity for 2b fliers in Asia
summary: Malaysia plans to double Kuala Lumpur International Airport's capacity to 150 million by 10-20 years, from the current 75 million, to cater to the 2.1 billion expected passengers in Asia Pacific by 2040. The company aims to raise airport capacity through expansion and optimization studies, with the main terminal expected to reach full capacity in two years. This move follows neighboring cities Bangkok and Singapore in expanding airport capacity to meet growing air travel demand in the region.

images.alt_text: Malaysia Airports Holdings Bhd plans to double Kuala Lumpur International Airport's capacity as it seeks a bigger slice of the 2.1 billion more passengers expected in Asia Pacific in the next two decades.

site_title: 'A Quiet Place', 'Star Trek' sequels annouced
summary: Paramount Pictures has announced two new "Star Trek" sequels, along with sequels to the hit horror movie "A Quiet Place", in a bid to revitalize the studio's struggling franchise. The new "Star Trek" films will be produced in partnership with Skydance Media, while "A Quiet Place" sequels will also be developed. The announcements come as Paramount aims to bounce back from a year of high-profile flops, including "Ben-Hur" and "mother!". The studio's CEO, Jim Gianopulos, expressed confidence in the team and culture, citing "A Quiet Place" as a key factor in the studio's resurgence.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday; STI up 0.3% to 3,577.5
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.3% to 3,577.5 on Thursday, driven by a volatile US market session where Wall Street stocks finished higher despite interest rate concerns. The index gained 9.49 points, with about 95.1 million shares changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 78 to 46, as investors pursued shares in companies expected to report brisk earnings.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge up at start of trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose at the start of trading on Thursday, driven by a positive lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.16% to 30,378.15, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.05%. Energy firms benefited from rising oil prices. In contrast, the Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.27%. The gains followed a broadly positive session on US markets, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: US dollar near 3-1/2 month high, bolstered by rising US bond yields
summary: The US dollar traded near a 3-1/2 month high against a basket of currencies due to rising US Treasury yields, which broke the 3% threshold for the first time in four years. The 10-year US Treasury yield reached 3.035% on Wednesday, causing the US dollar's index to rise 0.9% this week, its biggest weekly gain in over two months. Analysts predict the Federal Reserve will maintain a June rate hike, further bolstering the dollar's strength.

site_title: Kim and Moon to meet at military demarcation line before summit
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and South Korean President Moon Jae In will meet at the Military Demarcation Line on Friday, marking the first time a North Korean leader has set foot in the South since the Korean War ended 65 years ago. The summit will focus on denuclearization, with Pyongyang having made significant progress in its nuclear arsenal. The meeting will be the third between the two leaders, following summits in Pyongyang in 2000 and 2007. A joint statement, dubbed the "Panmunjom Declaration," is expected to be issued after the meeting.

images.alt_text: North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un (left) and the South's president Moon Jae In will meet at the Military Demarcation Line that divides the peninsula for their summit Friday, Seoul said, in an occasion laden with symbolism.

site_title: Citic Envirotech Q1 profit more than doubles to S$39.3m
summary: Citic Envirotech's Q1 profit more than doubled to S$39.3 million, driven by 148% revenue growth to S$247.1 million, with sales from its engineering and membrane system segments increasing 127% and 361% respectively. Recurring treatment revenue rose 23% to S$46.4 million. The company's earnings per share increased to 0.76 cents, up from 0.73 cents in the same period last year.

site_title: 'Breakthrough' in mosquito-packed drones to combat Zika in Brazil
summary: Brazil plans to release up to 1 million sterile male mosquitoes per week using drones to combat the Zika virus, a breakthrough in mosquito population control. The mosquitoes, bred in labs and sterilized, will mate with females but not produce viable eggs, reducing the mosquito population by up to 99%. Successful field tests were conducted in north-eastern Brazil, and the technology is being scaled up for wider use, with several countries expressing interest in trialing drone releases to reduce mosquito populations.

site_title: US stocks end mostly up as Boeing surges
summary: US stocks ended the day mostly higher, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.3% to 24,083.83, despite investor anxiety over potential interest rate hikes. Boeing surged 4.2% after reporting a 56.9% surge in first-quarter earnings. Twitter fell 1.9% despite positive earnings, while General Electric slumped 4.3% after being placed on credit watch negative. Despite concerns about higher interest rates, the S&P 500 edged up 0.2% to 2,639.40, and the Nasdaq Composite Index dipped 0.1% to 7,003.74.

site_title: China's Huawei under US probe for Iran sanctions violations: report
summary: The US Justice Department has opened an investigation into suspected Iran sanctions violations by China's Huawei Technologies. The probe follows subpoenas issued to Huawei by the US Commerce and Treasury Departments. Huawei has been under scrutiny in the US due to concerns over its alleged close ties to the Chinese government and potential security risks. The company denies any wrongdoing, stating it complies with all applicable laws and regulations. This move signals growing unease in the US towards Huawei and fellow Chinese telecoms group ZTE Corp.

site_title: StanChart compliance chief said to be probed for misconduct
summary: Standard Chartered Plc's head of compliance, Neil Barry, is being investigated by the bank after allegations of misconduct by colleagues, including perceived harassment. Barry was placed on leave in March and has assumed a temporary role. The investigation follows a string of misconduct issues during CEO Bill Winters' three-year tenure, including US sanctions violations and lax oversight. Barry will be replaced by Tracey McDermott, who assumes his role on a temporary basis.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Thursday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.32% to 22,285.74, driven by a cheaper yen that boosted market sentiment. Investors sought shares in companies expected to report strong earnings.

site_title: Canada sees progress on Nafta auto rules; steel tariffs loom
summary: Canada's foreign minister Chrystia Freeland reported progress on revamping the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) on auto rules, with the US proposing a 75% regional content requirement for autos. However, the threat of proposed US steel and aluminum tariffs looms, and Canada remains opposed to a "sunset clause" allowing one member to quit the pact after five years. Freeland reiterated Canada's opposition to the tariffs and emphasized the need for a full and permanent exemption. The ministers are set to meet again on Thursday to continue negotiations.

site_title: Stormy economic horizon may give ECB reason to pause
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi is expected to temper expectations for a quick exit from its stimulus program, citing economic growth and inflation concerns. Interest rates will likely remain at historic lows, and the ECB will continue its quantitative easing program through September. Economic data suggests a slowdown, but forecasts predict 2.4% growth in 2018, and Draghi aims to balance confidence in inflation returns to its objective of just below 2%.

images.alt_text: With clouds gathering over the outlook for economic growth and inflation limping, European Central Bank President Mario Draghi will likely temper expectations Thursday for a quick exit from its massive stimulus programme for the eurozone, analysts say.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust Q2 DPS falls 7.8% to 1.11 S cent
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT) reported a 7.8% year-on-year decline in distribution per stapled security to 1.1126 Singapore cents for Q2, driven by weaker performance across its portfolio, except for Japan and Singapore properties. The trust's net property income fell 4% to S$27.8 million, despite a 3.1% increase in gross revenue.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Tat Hong, Far East H-Trust, Frasers Hospitality Trust, Sembmarine, Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust
summary: Tat Hong's CEO and Standard Chartered's private equity arm raised their offer for Tat Hong shares to 55 Singapore cents per share, extending the deadline to May 14. Far East Hospitality Trust's distribution per stapled security rose 1.1% to 0.94 Singapore cent, while Frasers Hospitality Trust's distribution fell 7.8% to 1.1126 Singapore cents. Sembcorp Marine's net profit plummeted 85.7% to S$5.3 million due to revenue growth. Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust raised S$330.3 million from a placement of 312 million units at S$1.06 apiece.

site_title: Oil prices rise on geopolitical worries, shrugs off US build
summary: Oil prices rose on Wednesday despite US inventory data, driven by geopolitical tensions and the prospect of fresh sanctions on Iran. French President Emmanuel Macron challenged US President Trump's policies, urging the preservation of an international nuclear deal with Iran. Trump is set to decide by May 12 whether to restore US sanctions, potentially paving the way for the deal's demise.

site_title: Boeing cruises past forecasts, sees no sign of cost trouble
summary: Boeing's profit surged past estimates in the first quarter, with core earnings jumping to $3.64 per share from $2.17 per share a year earlier. The company raised forecasts for cash flow and earnings, citing booming demand for commercial jets. CEO Dennis Muilenburg played down concerns about rising materials costs, which have been a concern for fellow manufacturer Caterpillar. The results sent shares 4.5% higher.

site_title: E-commerce firm Anchanto wants to be household name in the region
summary: Anchanto, a Singapore-based e-commerce solutions provider, aims to become a household name in the region. The seven-year-old company has partnered with local businesses and government agencies to expand its services, offering software-as-a-service platforms to clients in 13 countries. Its platforms, SelluSeller and e-commerce warehouse management system, have seen a significant rise in adoption, with over 6,500 SMEs and brands using its services. Anchanto targets to reach 10,000 SMEs and brands by the end of 2018, with plans to commercialize its technology in foreign markets.

site_title: France's Macron pushes back at 'America First' agenda
summary: France's President Emmanuel Macron urged the US to adopt multilateralism, warning against the dangers of trade war and "extreme nationalism" in a speech to Congress. Macron pushed back against Donald Trump's "America First" agenda, defending the rules-based world order and calling for cooperation on climate change and Iran. Despite their friendly relationship, Macron's speech marked a shift in tone, as he criticized Trump's policies and emphasized the importance of international cooperation. Macron vowed to uphold the Iran nuclear deal and warned against imposing trade tariffs on allies.

images.alt_text: France's President Emmanuel Macron urged the United States to embrace multilateralism and warned of the perils of trade war and "extreme nationalism" in an address to Congress pushing back against Donald Trump's "America First" agenda.

site_title: Google ramps up Gmail privacy controls in major update
summary: Google has rolled out a major update to Gmail, introducing enhanced privacy controls for businesses using G Suite services and personal Gmail users. The "all new" Gmail features confidential mode, allowing senders to set expiration dates and block forwarding, copying, or printing of messages. Confidential mode can also be used to protect data if a recipient's email account is hijacked. The update also includes artificial intelligence-powered features, such as nudging users to respond to neglected messages and automated reply suggestions. The confidential mode will roll out to personal Gmail users and select G Suite customers in coming weeks.

site_title: Comcast confirms £22b bid for Sky, sparking battle with Fox
summary: Comcast has submitted a £22 billion bid for Sky, surpassing its initial offer of £12.50 per share. The bid comes after Sky dropped its support for Fox's lower offer, which had already received a 39% stake in the company. Comcast's chairman, Brian Roberts, stated that the bid formalizes an offer first made in February and puts pressure on Fox to raise its offer. Sky's independent directors have welcomed the bid and will now engage with both Comcast and Fox, while cautioning shareholders to wait for a shareholder vote.

site_title: Turnbull woos Australians with tax relief as 2019 election looms
summary: Malcolm Turnbull's government has scrapped a planned 0.5 percentage point increase to the national health levy, a move seen as a signal to offer tax relief to Australians ahead of the 2019 election. The levy was designed to raise A$8.2 billion over three years. Treasurer Scott Morrison called the decision "very, very good news" in a radio interview. The move is expected to be announced in the upcoming budget, which is set to be delivered next month.

images.alt_text: Malcolm Turnbull's government is dumping a planned tax hike, giving a clear signal it will use next month's budget to offer relief to Australians ahead of an election due next year.

site_title: Profits up at Facebook, no impact from privacy scandal
summary: Facebook reported a 63% profit increase in the first quarter of 2018, reaching $5 billion, with revenues rising 49% to $11.97 billion. The company's user base grew 13% to 2.2 billion monthly active users, despite concerns over data misuse by Cambridge Analytica. CEO Mark Zuckerberg reassured investors that the company's business is unaffected by the scandal, citing strong ad growth and a broad view of responsibility. Facebook shares rose 5.5% after the earnings release.

site_title: EBay forecast disappoints, highlighting threat of Amazon
summary: EBay forecast disappoints, falling short of analyst projections with a second-quarter revenue forecast of $2.64-$2.68 billion, down from expectations of $2.68 billion. The company's shares plummeted 7.2% in extended trading. Despite CEO Devin Wenig's defense of the company's turnaround strategy, investors remain concerned about EBay's ability to compete with Amazon in the e-commerce market. The company aims to differentiate itself by offering a platform with 171 million shoppers, but its sales growth has been inconsistent, with some analysts questioning its execution.

images.alt_text: EBay Inc gave a disappointing forecast for revenue growth in the second quarter, taking the shine off chief executive officer Devin Wenig's turnaround strategy.

site_title: Far East Hospitality Trust's Q1 payout grows 1.1% to 0.94 cent per stapled security
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust's Q1 payout rose 1.1% to 0.94 Singapore cents per stapled security, driven by a 4% increase in net property income to S$23 million. Gross revenue grew 3.8% to S$25.72 million. Revenue per available room for hotels increased 3.3% to S$139, while revenue per available unit for serviced residences grew 7.6% to S$174. The trust expects hotel performance to balance out softer serviced residence demand, mainly due to corporate relocation activities.

site_title: Spot disruption patterns with advanced analytics
summary: Disruption patterns from advanced analytics threaten traditional businesses, including those with radical cost reductions, significant jumps in customer experience, and new business models combining services, technologies, and data. These patterns can be identified by understanding data intermediaries and new information platforms in an industry. Companies like Domino's and Netflix have successfully disrupted their respective industries with analytics, while others face challenges from bold strategies and determined leadership. To cope with this disruption, businesses must transform and run with the opportunities of advanced analytics, rather than being prey to disruption.

site_title: Vivian Balakrishnan on what Asean needs to stay relevant
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Vivian Balakrishnan emphasizes the need for Asean to remain relevant in the face of complex strategic challenges. The region has the right ingredients to harness opportunities and tackle challenges, with a young population, growing economy, and prime investment destination. A key focus is on establishing an Asean Smart Cities Network to leverage technology and improve lives. The network aims to foster collaboration, exchange best practices, and catalyze bankable smart city projects. Balakrishnan is optimistic about Asean's future, highlighting the importance of resilience and innovation in navigating the rapidly changing world.

site_title: US Air Force tests missile in California
summary: The US Air Force successfully test-launched an unarmed Minuteman III intercontinental ballistic missile from Vandenberg Air Force Base in California on April 25, 2018. The test, scheduled 3-5 years ago, marked the first such launch this year. The missile completed its flight path within a designated safety corridor and the equipment functioned properly, according to the Air Force. The test was part of the ongoing transition to the Ground Based Strategic Deterrent (GBSD) missile, expected to replace the Minuteman III fleet over the next 20 years.

site_title: Asean Single Window - a digital platform to simplify customs clearance
summary: The Asean Single Window (ASW) digital platform, launched on January 1, 2018, aims to simplify customs clearance and reduce paperwork across Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam. The platform enables traders to handle all cross-border customs documentation electronically, expediting cargo clearance and reducing costs. While benefits are uneven in the initial years, the ASW is expected to accelerate cargo release, cut transaction costs, and improve national track-and-trace capabilities. The platform also promotes compliance, transparency, and cooperation among government agencies and trading communities.

site_title: Offeror raises Tat Hong bid by 5 cents to S$0.55 per share
summary: A partnership between Tat Hong Holdings' CEO Roland Ng and Standard Chartered's private equity arm has raised its general offer for Tat Hong shares to 55 Singapore cents per share, a 13.4% premium over the last traded price. The deadline for the offer has been extended to May 14, 2018. Despite independent directors recommending acceptance of the earlier 50 cents per share offer, the new offer price has been deemed "final". The offeror plans to delist the company, with Mr. Ng expected to control around 70% of the takeover vehicle upon completion.

site_title: Building a global brand centered on trust
summary: Reebonz, a luxury e-commerce retailer, aims to expand globally by leveraging its scalable online model and building trust with customers. CEO Samuel Lim notes that gaining customer confidence in authenticity, returns, and refunds is key to adoption. The company has already expanded to 20 markets across the Asia-Pacific region and has 5-6 million members. Reebonz plans to enter new markets such as Japan and the US, while maintaining its Singapore base. Lim attributes the company's success to its ability to navigate cultural differences and manage complexities in cross-border e-commerce.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust Q4 DPU up 8% to S$0.0165
summary: Ascendas India Trust reported an 8% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0165 in its fourth quarter, driven by positive rental reversions and additional income from assets. This marks an improvement from the previous year's DPU of 1.54 Singapore cents.

site_title: Baltic Exchange launching container freight index
summary: The Baltic Exchange, a London-based subsidiary of the Singapore Exchange, is launching a global container freight index and an escrow service for vessel sales. Additionally, it will introduce a new Baltic Code, a modernized code of conduct for shipowners, charterers, and shipbrokers.

site_title: Singapore gears up to be Asean gateway for German firms
summary: Singapore is positioning itself as a gateway for German firms to tap into the Asean region, with a focus on supporting small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The city-state will host the Asia-Pacific edition of the Hannover Messe industrial-tech fair in October, featuring emerging technologies and thought leaders. The event aims to boost Singapore's reputation as a leading business hub and provide opportunities for SMEs to access distant markets and collaborate with partners worldwide. With Singapore assuming Asean chairmanship, the digital economy will be a key focus, enabling SMEs to unlock their potential through digitalization and Industry 4.0.

site_title: Philippine cops hold riot drills as Boracay closure is challenged
summary: Philippine police staged riot drills on Boracay island ahead of a six-month closure ordered by President Rodrigo Duterte due to environmental concerns. The closure is a constitutional challenge, with workers and residents arguing it will harm their livelihoods. The island's tourism industry is expected to lose $1 billion in revenue, with 28,000 workers affected. The government has promised $50.8 million in aid to workers, but many remain uncertain about their future.

site_title: Singapore to play a key role in Asia's infrastructure development
summary: Singapore is set to play a key role in Asia's infrastructure development with the creation of a new Infrastructure Office. The office will bring together local and international players to develop, finance, and execute regional projects, focusing on policy and regulatory framework design, institutional capacity development, and sustainable project structuring. The office aims to support firms in forging local and international partnerships and provide a platform for information exchange and infrastructure investments. Singapore's expertise in infrastructure development, digital technologies, and data collection will be leveraged to contribute to the region's development, making it an ideal nerve centre for regional infrastructure cooperation.

site_title: Smart technologies to enhance Singapore's living environment
summary: Singapore's Housing and Development Board (HDB) has been leveraging smart technologies to enhance the living environment for residents. The Smart HDB Town Framework, introduced in 2014, maps out smart initiatives in five domains: smart planning, smart environment, smart estate, smart living, and smart communities. HDB uses 3D town modeling software and environmental simulation tools to design comfortable living environments and optimize building layouts. The Integrated Environmental Modeller (IEM) platform simulates urban micro-climatic conditions to promote natural ventilation and mitigate heat gain. HDB has also introduced smart home solutions, such as trials in Yuhua estate and Punggol Northshore, to improve convenience and energy efficiency for residents.

site_title: Philippines closing Boracay to tourists under high security
summary: The Philippines is closing its popular tourist island Boracay for six months to undergo a massive clean-up, starting Thursday. About 600 policemen, including those equipped with assault rifles, have been deployed to ensure high security. The island's heavy commercialization and construction have led to environmental degradation, prompting the government's decision. Locals and tourists alike were shown mock drills by security forces, including riot officers and hostage scenarios. The closure aims to restore the island's pristine state and promote sustainable tourism.

site_title: BlackRock buying Admiralty industrial property for S$106m
summary: BlackRock is buying a seven-storey industrial building in Woodlands, Singapore, for S$106 million, or nearly S$226 per square foot. The property, known as Admirax, has a 60-year leasehold tenure and includes 360 car parking spaces and 18 lorry spaces. The sale marks a significant deal for Singapore's industrial property market, with the total value of investment sales for the year at S$480 million.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Asean to use fintech as financial inclusion boost
summary: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) aims to boost financial inclusion in the region by leveraging digital finance and fintech. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) notes that digital finance can accelerate access to financial services in South-east Asia, with potential boosts to GDP of 9-14% in Indonesia and 32% in Cambodia. Asean finance ministers and central bank governors have emphasized the importance of fintech innovation in areas such as credit scoring and simple payments. The Asean Financial Innovation Network (AFIN) was established to match Asean financial institutions with fintech firms, with the goal of developing solutions to spur financial inclusion.

images.alt_text: "Given the rapid digitalisation of our economy and financial sectors, we also need to pay greater attention to cyber-resilience. There is room for Asean regulators to enhance collaboration, share intelligence, and exchange best practices." - Singapore Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat in his opening remarks at the 22nd Asean Finance Ministers' Meeting

site_title: Smart technologies to enhance Singapore's living environment
summary: Singapore's Housing and Development Board (HDB) is leveraging smart technologies to enhance public housing and create a better living environment for residents. The HDB has introduced the Smart HDB Town Framework, which outlines initiatives in five key domains: smart planning, smart environment, smart estate, smart living, and smart communities. Using 3D town modelling software and environmental simulation tools, HDB planners aim to create a more liveable, efficient, and sustainable environment. Trials of smart home solutions are underway, with a focus on improving convenience, utilities savings, and elderly care.

site_title: The strong, silent type
summary: London's Heathrow airport is considering increasing fees for its £10 billion upgrade project. Tesla marked its formal entry into India with a launch event in Mumbai. The company plans to expand its robotaxi service to California and Arizona. FedEx partnered with Singapore's QuikBot to deploy robots for deliveries in commercial areas. Delta Air Lines offered an upbeat outlook on travel demand, boosting its shares. Japan's carmakers are reducing export prices to the US to offset the impact of tariffs.

site_title: Vard shareholders, please vote to reject delisting proposal
summary: Vard Holdings' parent company, Fincantieri, has proposed a delisting offer to privatize the company, but shareholders are advised to reject the proposal. The offer of 25 cents per share is considered unfair, especially given the company's world-class skills and recent improvement in the oil-and-gas industry. The company's board of directors is pushing for the delisting, but minority shareholders should vote against it to ensure the company remains listed on the SGX. The meeting to discuss the proposal is scheduled for April 30.

site_title: A strong Singapore presence in Africa's city-planning sector
summary: Singaporean companies Surbana Jurong, Hyflux, and Meinhardt are providing expertise in urban planning to cities in sub-Saharan Africa, addressing the region's rapid urbanization. By 2030, 715 million people will live in African cities, with 82 cities having over a million residents and at least five mega-cities. Singapore's firms are helping create comprehensive plans, including affordable housing, transportation systems, and environmental solutions, to support the growth of cities like Kigali, Rwanda, and Buipe, Ghana. This is a response to the region's infrastructure gap and growing demand for urban planning services.

images.alt_text: Kenya now needs about 10,000 km of roads and railways in order to speed up its development.

site_title: Indonesia's Go-Jek, ComfortDelGro in talks to explore tie-up: report
summary: Indonesian ride-hailing app provider Go-Jek is in talks with Singapore taxi giant ComfortDelGro to explore a potential partnership, according to a report by Techcrunch. The two companies have refused to comment on the news, citing refusal to discuss rumors or speculation. This potential tie-up could be a significant move for both companies, but no further details have been released.

images.alt_text: Christopher Tan

site_title: The offices of the future, in the Weekend magazine
summary: Co-working spaces have evolved into upscale operations housing entrepreneurs, SMEs, and larger companies, replacing the casual, bohemian setup of the past. These modern shared spaces cater to the growing needs of millennials and professionals. The article highlights the shift towards more sophisticated co-working spaces, while also mentioning other lifestyle topics, including the Singapore Theatre Festival, a new restaurant, and zero-waste initiatives.

site_title: A strong economy won't make you popular these days
summary: A strong economy no longer guarantees popularity among voters in major democracies. Despite low unemployment and inflation, the average approval rating for leaders in 20 major democracies has hit a new low of 35%, down from a peak of over 50% a decade ago. This trend is evident in countries led by Angela Merkel, Emmanuel Macron, Justin Trudeau, and Shinzo Abe, who all face low approval ratings despite producing relatively strong economic results. The rise of angry populism and the politicization of news may be contributing to this disconnect, and it raises concerns about the impact on democratic governance.

site_title: Pushing the boundaries
summary: The Singapore Business Awards honored corporate leaders who have expanded their companies globally. PhillipCapital Group's Lim Hua Min won the Singapore Businessman of the Year title for his company's multi-market, multi-product, and multi-channel approach. Changi Airport Group's Lee Seow Hiang won the Outstanding CEO of the Year award for his overseas expansion. Jaspal Singh, CEO of Metroline, won the Outstanding Overseas Executive Of The Year award for his success in the UK. HRnetGroup won the The Enterprise Award for its global expansion, employing 1,000 consultants across 10 cities.

images.alt_text: From left: CAG's Lee Seow Hiang; Businessman of the Year Lim Hua Min; HRnetGroup's Adeline Sim and ComfortDelGro's Jaspal Singh

site_title: GM, South Korea in talks to raise investment plan in local unit: source
summary: GM and South Korea's Korea Development Bank (KDB) are in talks to increase the size of GM's US$2.8 billion investment in its local unit, GM Korea. The investment, initially proposed to fund two new SUVs, may now exceed four trillion won (S$620 million). The move comes after GM Korea averted bankruptcy with a wage deal with its labour union. State-run KDB may offer up to 700 billion won to support the investment, proportional to its 17% stake in GM Korea.

site_title: STI falls after rising US yields hit Wall St
summary: SINGAPORE stocks fell 0.46% to 3,568.01 on Wednesday, tracking a decline in US Treasury note yields. The Straits Times Index (STI) dipped 16.55 points, with 307 losers beating 126 gainers. Blue-chip losers included Thai Beverage, Singtel, and CapitaLand Commercial Trust, while Techcomp Holdings surged 62.16% to S$0.60 after a reorganisation. The bourse's performance was attributed to post-earnings pessimism in the US markets.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Firm bond yields push US dollar to 4-month high
summary: The US dollar reached a four-month high on April 25, 2018, after benchmark US Treasury yields rose above 3%, driven by concerns over government debt and inflation. The US dollar index rose 0.4% to 91.130, its strongest level since January 12, as the yen and euro declined. Analysts suggest the dollar may break higher due to tightening of Fed policy and moderating growth in countries. However, the outcome will depend on Friday's US GDP data and Thursday's European Central Bank meeting.

site_title: Paving the way for the digital customer experience
summary: Financial service firms in Asia Pacific are prioritizing digital transformation to enhance customer experience, with over 70% looking to increase spending on digital initiatives. The industry is becoming increasingly complex and competitive, with firms needing to offer fast, secure, and seamless experiences. To succeed, firms must rethink legacy systems, adopt technology, and prioritize customer understanding, particularly in understanding cultural and behavioral attributes. A comprehensive data management strategy is also crucial for making instant decisions and identifying customers.

site_title: Unions actively supporting talent development
summary: Singapore's maritime industry is actively engaging in upskilling and reskilling to address a growing manpower shortage, particularly in the sea-going sector. The labour movement, led by unions such as the NTUC and SMOU, aims to build a strong Singapore core as the foundation for the industry. With the help of digital solutions and technology, companies like PSA are introducing customized programs to raise the technology quotient of their staff. A S$12.6 million boost is being provided to train 200 Singaporeans to become deck and marine engineer officers. The goal is to create meaningful career pathways in the maritime sector for Singaporeans and address the industry's manpower gaps.

site_title: Asean must be innovative, adaptive to stay relevant
summary: ASEAN must be innovative and adaptive to remain relevant in the face of complex strategic challenges, including competition between super-powers, trade friction, and natural disasters. The region has the right ingredients to harness opportunities and tackle challenges, with a demographic dividend and combined GDP of US$2.55 trillion. The upcoming 32nd Asean Summit in Singapore will focus on establishing an Asean Smart Cities Network to leverage technology and improve lives, with the goal of creating jobs and making a tangible impact.

site_title: China's Xiaomi promises to cap hardware income margin ahead of IPO
summary: Xiaomi, a Chinese smartphone and smart device maker, announced it will cap its hardware income margin at 5% of total profits starting in 2018, ahead of its highly-anticipated IPO. Any excess profits will be distributed to users. This move aims to position Xiaomi as an internet services provider, shifting its focus from hardware to services.

site_title: KST Liberty is first tug in South-east Asia to be dual-fuelled
summary: KST Liberty, a tugboat in South-east Asia, has been christened as the region's first dual-fuelled vessel, powered by both diesel and liquefied natural gas (LNG). The ceremony marked a significant step towards reducing maritime emissions, as LNG fuels are considered more environmentally friendly. The move follows the International Maritime Organization's global 0.5% sulfur cap on marine fuels by 2020. A terminal-service agreement was also signed between Jurong Port and FueLNG to support LNG-fuelled vessels at Jurong Port.

site_title: PhillipCapital chairman is Businessman of the Year
summary: Lim Hua Min, executive chairman of PhillipCapital Group, has been named Businessman of the Year in Singapore's 2018 Business Awards. He revolutionized the stockbroking industry with the introduction of POEMS, the first internet trading platform in Singapore, in 1996. Under his leadership, PhillipCapital has grown into an Asian house with a global reach, straddling 17 countries. Lim aims to "re-invent" PhillipCapital into a platform-centric ecosystem, expanding into new geographies, including the US, Europe, and Australia.

site_title: India's Indus, Bharti Infratel merge to become world's No 2 for mobile masts
summary: India's Indus Towers and Bharti Infratel Ltd merged to become the world's second-largest mobile masts company, with over 163,000 towers. The combined entity, Indus Towers, will remain listed on Indian bourses, with Bharti Airtel owning 33.8-37.2% of the shares. The deal has an equity value of $19.2 billion and is expected to close before March 2024. The merger comes ahead of an announced merger between Vodafone Group plc's Indian unit and Idea Cellular, which could potentially overtake Bharti Airtel as India's biggest phone carrier.

site_title: Plan for new 'Hong Kong Town' in mainland China sparks backlash
summary: A proposal to build a 'Hong Kong Town' in mainland China's Guangdong province has sparked backlash, with critics accusing it of ghettoizing poorer residents and compromising the city's autonomy. The MTR Corporation, which runs Hong Kong's railway network, has started talks with its Chinese counterpart to build a commuter town in Nansha and Foshan. The plan, aimed at retirees and young people, has been met with ridicule online, with many questioning the government's motives and the feasibility of the project.

site_title: Global wind capacity to rise by 56% in next five years
summary: Global wind energy capacity is projected to increase by 56% by 2022, reaching 840GW, driven by declining costs and growing demand to meet emissions cut targets. The industry added 52.5GW of new capacity last year, with China, the US, and the European Union being key markets. Despite a slight decline in 2017, wind power is expected to return to growth in 2019 and 2020, with cumulative installations reaching 840GW by the end of 2022. The industry's growth is attributed to the shift from government subsidies to auctions, reducing costs further.

site_title: Smart cities network to include 3 Vietnam cities
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced that three Vietnamese cities - Hanoi, Ho Chi Minh City, and Da Nang - will be part of the Asean network of smart cities. This move aims to enhance digital infrastructure and services across the region, with a forecasted digital economy of $200 billion by 2025. The partnership also includes six environmental protection and trade deals signed between Singapore and Vietnam. The smart cities network is part of Singapore's efforts to strengthen Asean's resilience and innovation.

site_title: Techcomp rises 62% on split; shareholders to get 2 cash offers
summary: Techcomp Holdings Ltd, a Singapore-based scientific equipment supplier, has risen 62% after announcing a reorganisation and two cash offers to shareholders. The company will split into two parts, with 61.6% of shares sold to China's state-owned Baodi International Investment Company, while the remaining shares will be controlled by Lo Yat Keung, the company's president and controlling shareholder. Baodi will make a mandatory cash offer of HK$3.267 per share, while Lo's company will offer HK$0.84 per share. Shareholders can choose to accept both offers, providing an opportunity to realise their investment at a combined price of up to HK$4.107.

site_title: Morals over laws, substance over form
summary: Singapore Businessman of the Year Award recipient Lim Hua Min warns that new regulations since the global financial crisis have yet to address the root of the problem, and new risks are emerging. He cites the encroachment of platform companies, such as Japan's Rakuten, as a major threat to financial incumbents. Lim advocates for a shift towards a "zero marginal cost society," where companies must become more platform-centric and less company-centric to stay competitive. He also criticizes the over-regulation of the industry, arguing that it creates more complexity and undermines values and character.

site_title: Venture Corp Q1 earnings up 72% on marginally higher revenue
summary: Venture Corp reported a 72.2% increase in net profit to S$83.7 million for Q1, driven by a 1.5% revenue growth to S$856 million. In US dollar terms, revenue would have increased by 9.1%. The company's results are considered sturdy, following a record-setting growth last year.

site_title: Mahathir is No 1 actor: Najib
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad is described as the country's "No 1 actor" by Prime Minister Najib Razak for his reconciliation with former Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim. Najib said Mahathir's public amends with Anwar, who was previously lambasted by Mahathir, demonstrate a lack of trustworthiness. Najib claimed Mahathir was being used by the opposition party DAP to split Malay support ahead of the 14th General Election. The public reconciliation occurred in 2016 when Mahathir shook hands with Anwar at the Kuala Lumpur High Court.

images.alt_text: ''He is No 1 actor. Best actor. This kind of person cannot be relied on. One must have ethics.'' - Najib Razak on Mahathir Mohamad (above)

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: LTC Corporation's buyout offer closing date is extended to May 11. Mountbatten Enterprises holds an 86.04% interest in the company. AEM Holdings reported a 98.6% increase in first-quarter earnings to S$8.2 million, driven by higher sales and profit margins. First Sponsor's net profit rose 20.3% to S$17.1 million, while Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust's distribution income fell 1.7% to S$53.8 million.

site_title: Wynn Resorts' new boss scales back on predecessor's projects
summary: Wynn Resorts' new CEO, Matt Maddox, has scaled back on projects begun by founder Steve Wynn, including a $3 billion lake resort in Las Vegas. Maddox is reviewing another project and aims to reduce "noise surrounding our business." The company's Q1 earnings rose to $2.30 a share, beating estimates, despite a 20% revenue increase that fell short of projections. Wynn Resorts is also taking steps to change its image after Wynn's departure amid allegations of misconduct.

site_title: E-commerce firm Anchanto wants to be household name in the region
summary: E-commerce firm Anchanto aims to become a household name in the region by offering software-as-a-service platforms to clients in 14 countries. The company, founded seven years ago, has seen its user base rise from a few hundred to over 6,500 small and medium enterprises (SMEs) and brands. Anchanto's platforms cater to retailers and logistics companies, providing localized solutions for Asian marketplaces such as Lazada and Amazon. The company has partnered with overseas launch customers and received support from the Singapore government to expand its operations.

site_title: FCT posts Q2 DPU of S$0.031, up 2%
summary: FRASERS Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported a higher distribution per unit (DPU) of 3.10 Singapore cents for the second quarter, up 2% from the previous year, driven by higher revenue and property income. Distribution to unitholders increased 2.5% to S$28.7 million in Q2 2018 and 3.4% to S$56.5 million in H1 2018.

site_title: Goldilocks sues to stop Noble AGM and further restructuring work
summary: Goldilocks Investment Company, Noble Group's third-largest shareholder, has launched two lawsuits against the commodity trader to stop its annual general meeting and further restructuring work. The lawsuits aim to protect shareholder rights, including the right to propose directors and restrain Noble from taking UK-based actions. A financial adviser warned that any delay in Noble's restructuring timeline will cause "irreparable damage" to the company, while Noble's chairman urged shareholders to support the current board and plan.

site_title: No malicious intent, financial impropriety: Trek 2000 CEO Henn Tan
summary: Trek 2000 International's CEO Henn Tan has denied any financial impropriety, stating that there was no malicious intent and only "shortcomings" in the company's dealings.
