The primary new challenge for Asean is reducing non-tariff barriers (NTBs) to increase trade in services and drive future intra-regional trade growth.

site_title: Rolls-Royce, Aero in talks on engines for wide-body aircraft
summary: Rolls-Royce Holdings plc is in talks with Aero Engine Corporation of China on a possible partnership to jointly supply engines for the CR929 wide-body aircraft, a project planned by China and Russia. The two companies met earlier this year to discuss cooperation on the turbine for the aircraft. The talks are at a preliminary stage and may not result in a deal.

site_title: The top jobs where women are outnumbered by men named John
summary: The Glass Ceiling Index, a study by The New York Times' Upshot, found that women are underrepresented in leadership roles across various industries, including politics, law, business, and media. Men with common names like John, Michael, and James dominate top positions, with women making up only 3.3% of the population. The study highlights the prevalence of men in power with particular names, revealing a skewed gender representation and whiteness in institutions. Discrimination is cited as a major obstacle to women's progress to positions of power.

site_title: JTC tenders 2 sites in Tuas, releases one site for sale application
summary: JTC has announced the tender of two industrial sites in Tuas, Singapore, as part of the first half 2018 Industrial Government Land Sale (IGLS) programme. The sites include a 0.47-hectare site at Tuas South Link 3 (Plot 26) with a 20-year tenure and a 2.41-hectare site at Tuas South Link 1 (Plot 13) with a 30-year tenure. Additionally, a 0.45-hectare site at Tuas South Link 3 (Plot 20) has been released for sale application with a 20-year lease. All sites are zoned for Business-2 development.

site_title: Wells Fargo investors back leaders despite protests
summary: Wells Fargo investors overwhelmingly supported the bank's directors and executives, with 89-92% of votes cast in favor of the pay of CEO Tim Sloan and other leaders. This strong backing comes despite a noisy annual shareholder meeting, where protesters and skeptics questioned the bank's leadership and reforms. The outcome indicates investors are giving the bank's new leadership time to rebuild from scandal, with some experts praising the move as a sign of trust in the company's efforts to restore its reputation.

site_title: Spotify ramps up free service in bid for expansion
summary: Spotify has expanded its free service, offering more options to users in a bid to grow its platform globally. The move comes weeks after the company's successful listing on the New York Stock Exchange. Spotify's chief research and development officer, Gustav Soderstrom, believes that the free, advertising-backed service is key to achieving its goal of getting billions of fans on the platform. This expansion aims to increase the company's market share and make music streaming a bigger industry worldwide.

site_title: Identity politics comes to the fore in Malaysia
summary: Malaysia's 14th General Election, set to take place next month, will highlight the country's identity politics landscape. The ruling Barisan Nasional (BN) coalition faces opposition from the Pakatan Harapan (PH) alliance, which represents ethnic Chinese and liberal interests, and Parti Islam Se Malaysia (PAS), which seeks to establish an Islamic state. The election will test Malaysia's national compact, built on ethnic Malay supremacy, against PH's redefinition of Malaysian ethnicity and PAS's strictly Islamic vision. The results will have regional implications, with neighboring Indonesia and Singapore closely watching the outcome.

site_title: NAB reviews advisory business as inquiry exposes misconduct
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) is reviewing its financial advice business amid a major inquiry into the country's financial sector, which has exposed widespread misconduct by advisers. The bank's wealth management assets are worth about A$4 billion, and it has paid A$19 million in compensation to customers for advisers' dishonest conduct. NAB's move comes as other major banks, such as ANZ, consider exiting non-core businesses with high compliance risks. Regulatory pressure and public disgust at bank abuse of market power have prompted the banks to re-evaluate their portfolio mix.

site_title: Trafigura's LNG head takes on new Asia role
summary: Trafigura has appointed Hadi Hallouche, head of its liquefied natural gas (LNG) division, to oversee both LNG and oil in Asia. Hallouche will also manage the company's global LNG business. Martin Urdapilleta, current head of Trafigura's oil division in Asia, has accepted a new role in Latin America. The moves come as Trafigura expands its LNG trading operations in Asia, driven by growing demand. The company's LNG trading volumes increased by 27% in 2017.

site_title: Cromwell European Reit buying freehold office building in Italy
summary: Cromwell European Reit is acquiring a freehold office building in Italy for 16.9 million euros, with a net lettable area of 17,990 sq m. The property is leased to two tenants and has a 100% occupancy rate. The acquisition is expected to be completed by June 30 and is not expected to affect Cromwell European Reit's net tangible assets or distributions per unit for the current financial year.

site_title: ESR-Reit acquires Tampines logistics facility for S$95.8m
summary: ESR-Reit has acquired a logistics facility in Tampines, Singapore for S$95.8 million. The purchase is expected to boost the company's exposure to the logistics/warehouse sector to 27.1% from 22.6%. The consideration includes S$86.2 million and an estimated S$9.6 million land premium for the remaining lease term.

site_title: SAP raises full-year forecasts after 33% jump in Q1 profit
summary: SAP has raised its full-year forecasts after a 33% jump in Q1 profit, with net profit surging to 708 million euros and operating profit increasing 52%. The company attributes the growth to predictable revenues and a stronger-than-expected cloud-computing product sales. SAP aims for a 5.5% increase in revenue to between 24.8 billion and 25.3 billion euros and a 8.5% boost in operating profits to between 7.35 billion and 7.5 billion euros.

site_title: Deutsche Bank considering cuts to US cash equities business
summary: Deutsche Bank is considering significant cuts to its US cash equities business, a move aimed at lowering costs and regaining competitiveness in a market it has lost. The decision, part of a broader restructuring effort, would leave new CEO Christian Sewing to find alternative ways to generate income. The bank's US arm has struggled to compete with large Wall Street firms, with revenue declining for 10 straight quarters. A decision could come as early as this week, with the supervisory board set to discuss the issue on Wednesday.

site_title: 50 years on, Asean gears up for new challenges
summary: ASEAN's 50th anniversary marks the second half of its journey towards centennial goals. Traditionally, assessments of regional cooperation focus on intra-regional trade and investment, but Asean's performance on these metrics is deemed low. However, the organization's broader objectives, such as promoting globalisation and multilateralisation of trade agreements, have been deemed successful. Asean has become the fourth-largest exporting region in the world, with most trade driven by supply chain-related trade and components. The primary new challenge for Asean is reducing non-tariff barriers (NTBs) to increase trade in services and promote intra-regional trade.

site_title: Astra's Q1 profit falls 2% amid lower car sales
summary: Astra International Tbk, an Indonesian conglomerate, reported a 2% decline in Q1 net profit to 4.98 trillion rupiah due to lower automotive sales, which fell 12% from the year-earlier period. The automotive business, accounting for 40% of total income, underperformed national car sales growth of 3%. However, PT United Tractors' profit grew 69% due to higher coal prices, providing a cushion for Astra's overall performance.

site_title: Investors should focus on capital preservation
summary: The global economy experienced a sudden downturn in February 2018, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average plummeting 4.2% due to concerns over the US Federal Reserve raising interest rates more frequently than expected. This led to increased volatility, with investors advised to focus on capital preservation and maintain high cash levels due to heightened uncertainty on economic and political fronts, including a possible US-China trade war and rising geopolitical risks. Valuations are also a concern, with the S&P 500 trading at a trailing price-earnings multiple of 24, significantly above the 10-year average.

site_title: Shipping steers a tentative carbon-free course
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) has adopted an initial strategy to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions from international shipping by at least 50% by 2050 compared to 2008. The strategy, agreed by IMO's Marine Environment Protection Committee, aims to phase out GHG emissions as soon as possible and includes a reference to a pathway of CO2 emissions reduction consistent with the Paris Agreement temperature goals. The move has been welcomed by the shipping industry and environment groups, with the International Chamber of Shipping hailing it as a "ground-breaking agreement" that sets a high level of ambition for reducing CO2 emissions.

site_title: Could a Singapore heritage shophouse Reit take off?
summary: A Singapore heritage shophouse Reit could be a viable investment option, driven by the growing demand for conservation shophouses in Districts 1 and 2, and the limited supply of such properties. The Reit could provide unitholders with a chance to own a piece of Singapore's history, with potential for capital appreciation. However, a major hurdle is the need for a substantial stock of shophouses, which could be addressed by spinning off assets from existing funds or acquiring properties from passive owners. The Reit could also promote the appreciation of Singapore's history through provenance and heritage conservation efforts.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Santander Q1 profit up 10%, driven by strong Brazil market
summary: Santander, the eurozone's largest bank by market value, reported a 10% rise in Q1 net profit to 2.05 billion euros, driven by strong performance in its Brazilian market. This exceeded analyst forecasts of 2.01 billion euros. The bank's first-quarter results mark a positive start to the year, despite global economic uncertainties.

site_title: Gold firms after 3-day slide as US dollar stabilises
summary: Gold prices rose after three days of losses, stabilizing at $1,325.81 an ounce as the US dollar steadied and Treasury yields stalled. The metal had fallen nearly 2% in the last three trading sessions due to a rally in US yields and rising interest rates. Analysts say gold is still vulnerable to risks, but some investors may buy in as a safe-haven asset amid geopolitical tensions and trade disputes.

site_title: CapitaLand Commercial Trust Q1 DPU down 11.7%
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) reported a 11.7% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) for the first quarter of 2018, to 2.12 Singapore cents. Despite this, the trust's distributable income increased 7.5% to S$76.6 million, driven by contributions from Asia Square Tower 2 and higher net property income from Capital Tower and 6 Battery Road. The trust's gross revenue rose 7.7% to S$96.4 million. CCT's portfolio occupancy rate was 97.3% in Q1 2018.

site_title: Brent oil hits highest since late 2014 as supplies tighten amid strong demand
summary: Brent crude oil prices surged to their highest since 2014, reaching $75.27 a barrel, driven by tightening supplies and strong demand. The price increase is attributed to OPEC's supply cuts and potential US sanctions on Iran, which could further reduce global supplies. The US is also increasing oil production, but this has limited the impact of OPEC's efforts. Demand in Asia has reached a record level, and prices are expected to remain high.

site_title: Agreements inked to set up links between Singapore and German firms
summary: Singapore has inked agreements with German firms to facilitate collaboration and innovation, aiming to boost the country's manufacturing sector. The agreements include Memorandums of Understanding (MoUs) on market access, industry 4.0 technologies, and a composite application centre. The partnerships are expected to open up opportunities for Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to work with and learn from their German counterparts, promoting innovation and global networking. The agreements were signed during the biennial Germany-Singapore Business Forum held in Hannover, Germany.

site_title: Business community welcomes steady hands at finance, trade, manpower ministries
summary: The Singapore government announced cabinet changes with two ministries directly impacting businesses having new ministers. The business community welcomed the changes, describing them as "steady hands." The ministries of finance and trade will have new ministers, but they are familiar faces to the local business community. This shift is seen as a positive move for businesses, indicating a stable and experienced leadership.

site_title: Some small firms want Trump to add more tariffs on China
summary: Small US manufacturers are urging the Trump administration to impose tariffs on Chinese imports, despite the National Retail Federation and other groups opposing the move. Makers of steel wheels, safes, and other products want to level the playing field by targeting goods by their Chinese competitors, which aren't on the proposed list. They argue that tariffs on steel imports have increased their costs but not finished goods made in China, potentially harming US businesses and the economy.

site_title: SGX RegCo says it wants to facilitate 'open dialogue' between Noble and Goldilocks
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulatory Co. (SGX RegCo) has initiated an "open dialogue" between Noble Group, a commodities trader, and its major shareholder Goldilocks Investment Company. The move comes after a dispute over Goldilocks' attempt to nominate non-executive directors at the upcoming annual general meeting. The dialogue aims to resolve the issue and prevent any potential disruptions to Noble's operations.

site_title: Europe: Shares choppy as earnings fail to set trend, yields rise
summary: European shares ended flat on Tuesday as company earnings failed to set a clear trend, despite a rise in US 10-year Treasury yields above 3% for the first time since 2014. Chipmakers were weighed down by AMS' warning of a downturn in orders. The rise in bond yields has been fueled by crude oil price spikes, boosting energy shares.

site_title: China's steel futures hit 1.5-month peak on falling inventories
summary: China's steel rebar futures reached a 1.5-month peak on April 24, 2018, due to declining inventories and concerns over weak demand. Rebar contracts closed 1.5% higher at 3,562 yuan (S$747) a tonne, while spot steel prices rose to their strongest level in a month. Inventories dropped 5.9% to 15.02 million tonnes, the lowest level since early February, amid a rebound in steel demand post Chinese New Year.

site_title: Innovation is propelling Asia's food industry
summary: Asia's food industry is driving innovation to address health issues such as diabetes and chronic malnutrition, and to mitigate the economic impact of not addressing these challenges. Companies are investing in food tech, plant-based ingredients, and alternative proteins, which can provide commercial opportunities while promoting sustainability. Singapore is establishing itself as a hub for food and agri-tech innovation, with startups and governments investing in sustainable packaging and reducing plastic waste. Industry leaders are making commitments to 100% recyclable packaging, and the first Food for the Future summit will be held in Singapore to crowd-source solutions and encourage enterprise and innovation.

site_title: China concerned trade and debt risks could hit economic growth: economists
summary: China's leaders are signaling concern over potential economic slowdown due to trade and debt risks, prompting a possible policy tweak to avoid a sharp deceleration. Despite robust growth in the first quarter, forecasters expect the economy to slow this year and next. The government has signaled a shift in tone, urging "bolder reform and opening-up efforts" and dropping a reference to deleveraging, which investors interpret as a signal to ease off tightening measures if warranted.

images.alt_text: Though growth remained robust in Q1, forecasters still see China's economy slowing this year as trade tensions with the US and the campaign to clean up the financial sector remain as downside factors.

site_title: Singapore bourse remains subdued
summary: The Singapore stock market remained subdued on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) inching up 5.02 points, or 0.14%, to 3,584.56. Despite a flurry of news items from various companies, few clear leads emerged, with losers beating gainers 246 to 187. DBS analysts noted that the macro tightening backdrop and trade war uncertainties make it a cautious time for markets. Thai Beverage helped to keep the index bubbly, while venture corporation Venture Corporation and Ezion Holdings were among the notable movers.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Forensics on Trek 2000 reveal millions in suspected fake sales, roundtripping
summary: A forensic review by RSM Corp Advisory has found millions in suspected fake sales and round-tripping transactions at Trek 2000 International, a Singapore-based company. The review, completed in 2018, uncovered fictitious sales to non-existent companies and possibly erroneous claims under the Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) scheme. The company's former and current officers, including chairman and CEO Henn Tan, may have breached various Singapore laws against fraud and round-tripping. Investigations are ongoing, and the Singapore Exchange has vowed to take disciplinary action.

images.alt_text: Mr Tan has been the sole director of S-Com HK since April 2008, and its sole shareholder until July 2015, but says he has no knowledge of where S-Com HK operated from or its day-to-day running.

site_title: iPhone manufacturers' slowing sales are a bad omen for Apple
summary: Apple's iPhone sales are slowing down, with its five largest device assemblers reporting a sharp slowdown in March quarter sales, suggesting a fading demand for the iPhone X. Despite a holiday-quarter spike, the high-end device struggled to draw customers in emerging markets, and competitors dominated China. Morgan Stanley cut its estimate on iPhone shipments by six million, and analysts are concerned that iPhone sales at Apple failed to meet expectations, with estimated production volumes growing only slightly to 54-56 million units in the March quarter.

site_title: Singapore to host Asean Summit this week; Vietnam PM to make official visit
summary: Singapore is hosting the 32nd Asean Summit this week, with Vietnamese Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc attending an official visit. The summit focuses on strengthening Asean's resilience and innovation, with discussions on smart cities, cyber-security, and regional developments. Vietnam and Singapore mark 45 years of diplomatic ties and have agreed to ink deals in various fields, including fintech and renewable energy. Other Asean leaders, including Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak and Myanmar's state counsellor Aung San Suu Kyi, will also attend the summit.

site_title: More Singapore women needed in top-paying jobs in high-growth industries: McKinsey
summary: McKinsey reports that increasing female representation in top-paying jobs and high-growth industries in Singapore could add over S$26 billion to the economy by 2025. Women in Singapore are underrepresented in STEM fields, with a near parity female-to-male ratio only in finance and insurance. The country's gender parity score is 0.68, slightly lagging behind the Philippines. To address this, universities and companies should implement measures to encourage girls and young women to pursue STEM careers, such as reviewing university policies and providing skills training.

site_title: Consumer confidence rises to second-highest level since 2000
summary: US consumer confidence rose to its second-highest level since 2000 in April, driven by improved assessments of current conditions and economic outlook. The confidence index rose to 128.7, with respondents expecting to purchase big-ticket items and a record 7.8% planning to buy a home. The labour differential narrowed to 22.9 percentage points, a three-month low, amid a strong job market and higher after-tax pay. The Conference Board's Lynn Franco attributed the rise to sustained sentiment and a solid pace of economic expansion ahead.

site_title: 'Maker movement' changing China's tech copycat reputation
summary: China is shifting its tech reputation from a hub for technology copycats to innovation, thanks to the "maker movement" in Shenzhen. The city has invested $145 million in grants and funds maker spaces to encourage innovation and collaboration among engineers, programmers, and children. This movement is a departure from the "shanzhai" culture, where counterfeiters produce high-quality replicas of products. The government aims to foster original technologies, such as dockless shared bicycles, and support Chinese firms and startups in developing mobile phones, drones, and other gadgets.

images.alt_text: A teacher working with children at MG Space, a small-scale workshop in Shenzhen that teaches digital fabrication.

site_title: Longer-acting Botox maker says demand is seeing a spike
summary: Revance Therapeutics' CEO Dan Browne says demand is seeing a spike for the company's longer-acting Botox treatment, RT002, which is expected to last up to six months, compared to Allergan's Botox, which lasts three to four months. The treatment is still in late-stage testing for glabellar lines and is expected to be approved in 2020. Revance plans to seek "premium pricing" and target the treatment for migraines, with CEO Browne expecting the results to be a "major de-risking event" for the company.

site_title: Summit Power defers planned US$260m Singapore IPO
summary: Summit Power International has deferred its planned US$260 million Singapore Exchange IPO, citing recent market volatility and lack of demand from institutional investors. The company will reassess its situation with key stakeholders and strategic partners, providing an update in due course. This move comes as other listing hopefuls, such as Cromwell Property Group and HNA Group Co, have also faced challenges in securing IPOs in Singapore, while nearby Vietnam has seen a surge in equity offerings.

site_title: VCs seek 'safe harbour' for virtual currencies
summary: Venture capitalists and entrepreneurs, backed by Andreessen Horowitz, are lobbying the SEC to establish a "safe harbour" for some virtual currencies, potentially exempting them from securities regulations. The proposal, presented to the SEC in March, suggests that tokens with "full decentralisation" or "full functionality" should be exempt from securities laws. If successful, this could impact the categorization of Ether, the second most widely used digital token, and potentially stabilize its value.

site_title: Private equity's dry powder challenge
summary: Private equity funds have raised a record US$1.1 trillion since 2012, but their inability to put money to work quickly is generating annual records in "dry powder". The industry's biggest challenge is its structural imbalance, with buyout funds sitting on an all-time high of US$633 billion in uncalled capital. To address this, megafunds could shift their strategy to buy platform assets and execute M&A as a primary source of business growth, leveraging their skills to compete with corporate buyers.

site_title: Make nine-year cap mandatory for independent directors: Sias
summary: Singapore's Securities Investors Association (Sias) proposes making a nine-year cap mandatory for independent directors on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) Listing Rules. This threshold would reassess whether an independent director (ID) still qualifies as independent after nine years in the role. Sias also suggests that the majority of the board should consist of IDs if the chairman is not independent. The revised Code will be launched in the second half of 2018, with public feedback on the proposals closing on March 15.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: MCT Q4 DPU up 0.01 cent, full-year DPU at 9.04 cents
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) reported a 0.01 cent increase in its fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.27 Singapore cents, driven by higher contributions from VivoCity and Mapletree Business City I (MBC I) due to step-up rents. The full-year DPU rose to 9.04 cents, with gross revenue increasing 14.8% to S$433.5 million and net property income expanding 15.9% to S$338.8 million. MCT expects the retail market to recover, despite rental recovery being selective, and the office space market to remain positive due to improved business confidence.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singapore real estate investment trusts (REITs) CapitaLand Commercial Trust, Ascendas Reit, and CapitaLand Mall Trust reported steady occupancy and rents in the first quarter. However, CapitaLand Commercial Trust is expected to write down assets due to the return of Bugis Village to the state, while Ascendas Reit is poised for inorganic growth in Europe and the US. CapitaLand Mall Trust's retail sector is expected to face challenges due to e-commerce disruption. Analysts have provided buy, sell, and hold recommendations for the REITs, citing varying growth prospects and market conditions.

site_title: IHH revises Fortis bid with binding proposal
summary: Malaysia's IHH Healthcare has made a revised and binding proposal to acquire India's Fortis Healthcare, offering an immediate equity infusion of 650 crore rupees and a subsequent non-binding plan for an additional 3,350 crore rupees. The proposal, which includes appointing two directors on the Fortis board, is subject to due diligence and aims to address the company's severe debt and legal woes. The move comes after recent remarks by Fortis directors indicating they would only consider binding bids, and IHH's revised proposal is seen as a more compelling proposition.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Initiatives launched to help local F&B firms innovate and take wing overseas
summary: Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Koh Poh Koon unveiled initiatives to help local food manufacturers innovate and expand overseas. A website was developed to connect local businesses with overseas buyers, utilizing the Alibaba portal and the Singapore Pavilion at Food & Hotel Asia 2018. This move aims to support Singapore's food and beverage industry in breaking into international markets.

site_title: DeClout's group CEO setting the record straight
summary: DeClout Limited, a Singapore-based company, has responded to criticisms regarding the deployment of a S$10 million loan. The company's CEO, Wong Kok Khun, stated that the loan was unanimously approved by the board to minimize shareholder dilution and was not excessive. The loan was secured with share charges and guarantees from subsidiaries, and the company has substantial tangible assets. The board also defended its corporate recovery strategy and recent Indonesian acquisition, citing emerging shareholder confidence.

site_title: New political appointments for four backbenchers
summary: Singapore has shuffled its Cabinet, appointing four backbenchers as senior minister of state, minister of state, and senior parliamentary secretary. The new appointees are Edwin Tong, Zaqy Mohamad, Sun Xueling, and Tan Wu Meng, all from the ruling party. This move marks a more extensive Cabinet reshuffle than usual, with many of the newly elected candidates receiving new or expanded roles.

site_title: Euro licks wounds at 2-month low
summary: The euro fell to a two-month low on Tuesday due to growing concerns that rising US Treasury yields would reduce demand for European bonds and stocks. The US 10-year Treasury yield reached 2.998%, its highest in over four years. Hedge funds have amassed record long bets in the euro, but investors are taking a closer look at the widening interest rate differential trends between the US and Europe. The euro stabilized around $1.22 after reaching a low of $1.2185, down 3% from its February high.

site_title: Wan Azizah dismisses speculation of rift in PKR
summary: Malaysia's PKR party leader Wan Azizah Wan Ismail has denied speculation of a rift within the party, stating there is only one camp and she will meet with dropped candidates to explain decisions. PKR president Mahathir Mohamad also addressed the issue, saying dropped candidates would be disappointed but would set aside personal feelings for the coalition's support. The controversy arose from reported tensions between Wan Azizah and deputy Mohamed Azmin Ali over the candidate list.

site_title: Midas hit by two letters of demand totalling S$27m
summary: Midas Holdings, a Singapore-based railway parts maker, has received two letters of demand totaling S$27 million. The letters pertain to a finance lease agreement and a financing agency agreement, with the lessee and financing agency claiming overdue payments. The company's former executive chairman, Chen Wei Ping, and other parties are also implicated. Midas Holdings has announced that it will issue further statements as the matter develops, with trading in its shares remaining suspended.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Time for Brexit talks to get serious
summary: Britain's Brexit talks have stalled, mainly due to the UK's proposed "soft border" solution with the EU, which has been rejected. The main difference of opinion is the border between the Irish Republic and Northern Ireland. The UK proposes a computerized system, while the EU wants a hard border. The EU's stance is seen as compromising the UK's integrity, and if negotiations fail, the UK could consider "hard Brexit" and declare full independence, potentially strengthening the economy and gaining international support.

site_title: Rider and horse are tested to their limits in show-jumping courses
summary: Show-jumping riders and horses face a mentally and physically demanding test as they navigate a carefully designed course with multiple jumps of varying heights, widths, and designs. The course requires riders to create a precise plan to achieve the fastest time while maintaining accuracy, with the goal of winning prizes worth hundreds of thousands of dollars. A well-designed course demands a balance between challenge and safety, with a good course designer aiming to push both horses and riders to their limits while ensuring their safety and adherence to rules.

site_title: Volvo Q1 results beat expectations on strong demand
summary: Volvo Q1 results exceeded expectations with strong demand for lorries and construction equipment across most markets, driven by fleet buyers stepping up purchases. The company raised its guidance for North American and Indian heavy-duty lorry markets, as well as construction equipment in nearly all markets. Operating profit rose to 8.3 billion Swedish kronor, but fell shy of analyst expectations due to supply chain constraints and higher costs. Volvo's supply chain is under pressure, and the company's future ownership and strategy are uncertain amid Geely's acquisition of shares in Daimler and AB Volvo.

site_title: Heat is on emerging market currencies with Indonesia stepping in
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, has intervened in the foreign exchange and bond markets to prop up the rupiah, which has slid to a two-year low. The move is seen as a potential harbinger for other emerging markets in Asia, including India, which also faces a current-account deficit. US 10-year yields are approaching 3% and giving the dollar added impetus, leading to declines in emerging Asian currencies. Other central banks, including those in India and the Philippines, are likely to step in to support their currencies, with the Reserve Bank of India planning to curb excess volatility rather than manage the exchange rate.

site_title: Lenovo tools boost AI deployment in businesses
summary: Lenovo has introduced Lenovo intelligent Computing Orchestration (LiCO), a tool designed to overcome challenges in deploying artificial intelligence (AI) projects in businesses. LiCO simplifies resource management and makes launching AI training jobs in clusters easy, supporting multiple AI frameworks. The tool reduces time-to-train requirements and allows for faster experimentation by efficiently scaling computing resources. LiCO also features transfer learning using pretrained models, reducing computing demands. The tool is being used by researchers at North Carolina State University to develop AI models for analyzing large amounts of geospatial image data.

site_title: Saudis said to delay exchange IPO on MSCI valuation hopes
summary: Saudi Arabia is delaying the initial public offering of its stock exchange, Tadawul, to 2019 or later in hopes of a potential MSCI upgrade, which could boost its value. The delay comes after the exchange's main stock gauge, the Tadawul All Share Index, became one of the world's top 10 best performers this year. A MSCI upgrade could attract US$41 billion of foreign capital and improve trading volumes, helping the bourse achieve a better valuation for its owner, the Public Investment Fund.

site_title: Trump: "Very good chance" of a US-China trade deal
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that the US has a "very good chance" of reaching a trade deal with China, with officials from both countries set to negotiate in a few days. China has welcomed US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin's visit to resolve the trade dispute. Trump also mentioned ongoing trade talks with the European Union and progress in negotiations with Mexico and Canada over the North American Free Trade Agreement.

site_title: US$35 movie tickets could become the norm in Saudi Arabia
summary: US$35 movie tickets could become the norm in Saudi Arabia, with AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc's CEO Adam Aron predicting prices to reach US$30 to US$35 by summer due to high demand. The company has completed refurbishments at a Riyadh theatre, where tickets sold out in under a minute. The high tax on entertainment in Saudi Arabia, 25% of the ticket price, is a concern for industry executives, including 20th Century Fox's president Andrew Cripps.

site_title: The new Cabinet and other office holders
summary: Singapore has established a centre to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific, while also providing early data showing better employment rates for graduates. Deputy Prime Minister (DPM) Gan Kim Kheng will visit the US for trade talks. The government has also announced a new grant of up to S$100,000 for businesses affected by tariffs. Additionally, Singapore has been identified as a potential global hub for advanced chip packaging. The government is also offering assistance to workers who need training, with the aim of future-proofing their careers before a potential crisis strikes.

site_title: Sustainable investments set to gain more traction at UBS
summary: UBS reports a sevenfold growth in client assets in sustainable investments between 2014 and 2017, with 80% of the growth occurring in 2017. The bank has now launched a 100% sustainable cross-asset portfolio, where investors' assets contribute to UN Sustainable Development Goals. UBS believes the market is reaching a convergence of supply and demand, with more sustainable companies and opportunities, and expects to deliver similar or better returns than traditional portfolios. The bank has committed to raising US$5 billion of client assets towards impact investing over the next five years.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Atlantic Navigation Holdings posted a full-year loss of US$13.2 million, with a loss per share of 5.08 US cents, compared to US$11.4 million in FY2016. EMS Energy reported a fourth-quarter net profit of S$39.37 million, reversing a net loss of S$115.84 million in the same period last year. Silverlake Axis secured a contract to modernize a South-east Asian banking institution's core banking systems, valued at an undisclosed amount.

site_title: Pei Fu building in S$76.25m collective sale
summary: SLB Development, a subsidiary of Oxley Holdings, has acquired the freehold Pei Fu Industrial Building in Singapore for S$76.25 million. The six-storey building, with a land area of around 62,346 sq ft, was completed in the early 1980s. Oxley Kyanite will redevelop the site, subject to necessary approvals, using internal resources and external borrowings. The acquisition is not expected to impact SLB's net tangible assets per share and earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Trump calls Iran deal 'a disaster'
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized the Iran nuclear deal as "a disaster" and "insane," calling it ineffective in addressing Iran's ballistic missile program and support for militant groups. French President Emmanuel Macron, visiting the White House to persuade Trump not to abandon the deal, warned that walking away would lead to a "trade war" and undermine US allies. Trump faces a May 12 deadline to decide on the deal's fate, with Iran threatening to relaunch its nuclear program if the US pulls out.

site_title: DeClout: Collateral, guarantee, change of control terms for S$10m loan not unusual
summary: DeClout, a Catalist-listed tech firm, has secured a S$10 million two-year loan from six private investors, which is secured by the company's 47% stake in Procurri and guarantees from Beaqon and VCC. The loan's terms, including change of control provisions, are not unusual for such transactions. DeClout maintains that the loan is in the best interest of the company and minority shareholders, and that it will help finance business expansion. The company has also disputed claims that it pledged its entire assets for the loan and that Procurri makes up over 70% of its net tangible assets.

site_title: G7 security ministers to press tech firms on combating extremism
summary: G7 security ministers are meeting in Toronto to press tech companies like Facebook, Twitter, and Google to combat extremism online. The meeting follows a call from the European Union for internet companies to remove extremist content more quickly, or face legislation. The G7 is also discussing cyber security and preventing militants from returning home after fighting abroad. Representatives from tech companies will discuss ways to prevent extremist use of the internet, including research and technological solutions. The meeting aims to increase cooperation between governments and tech firms to counter "terrorist use" of the internet.

site_title: France's gifted youth are set up to fail
summary: A study by Laurence Vaivre-Douret found that 39% of French gifted children are medically depressed, 80% experience anxiety, and 20% are deemed a suicide risk. The French education system is criticized for emphasizing rote memorization, leading to boredom and disengagement among gifted children. The system's extreme egalitarianism also fails to accommodate individual needs. Private schools, which receive government subsidies, exacerbate the problem with a focus on test scores and expulsion of problematic children. The study highlights the need for reform in France's education system to better support gifted children.

site_title: China's petrol, diesel exports hit record in March
summary: China's petrol exports reached a record high in March, with 1.7 million tonnes shipped, nearly double the amount from the same month last year. Diesel exports also soared, with 2.4 million tonnes shipped, up 12% from the same period in 2017. The surge in Chinese fuel exports is weighing on regional prices, particularly for petrol, and is affecting profit margins at regional refiners. This trend is expected to continue as Chinese refiners export surplus products, with some plants entering scheduled maintenance in the coming months.

site_title: US new home sales increase more than expected in March
summary: US new home sales increased 4.0% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 694,000 units in March, surpassing expectations. Sales in the West surged to their highest level in over 11 years, while the median new house price rose 4.8% to $337,200. Despite the increase, economists expect residential investment to decline in the first quarter due to a chronic shortage of properties and rising mortgage rates, making home purchasing less affordable, particularly for first-time buyers.

site_title: Walking the talk in support of autism
summary: Dow Chemical has partnered with the Autism Association in Singapore to raise awareness about autism through sports, a platform it believes fosters community interaction and bonding. The collaboration aims to promote understanding and acceptance of the condition.

site_title: US supreme court rules for Arab Bank over human rights claims
summary: The US Supreme Court ruled 5-4 in favor of Arab Bank Plc, dismissing a lawsuit claiming the Jordan-based bank helped finance militant attacks in Israel and the Palestinian territories. The lawsuit, brought under the 1789 Alien Tort Statute, accused Arab Bank of being the "paymaster" to militant groups. The court's decision narrowed the law's reach, requiring claims to "touch and concern" the US to overcome the presumption that it does not cover foreign conduct. The ruling left in place a lower court ruling that had thrown out the lawsuit.

site_title: Worrying signs China is moving backward on reforms, warns US official
summary: US Consul General Kurt Tong warned that China is moving backward on reforms, citing breaches of World Trade Organization (WTO) rules and stalled economic progress. Tong stated that China's WTO commitments reflect a "broken contract" and that the US is growing disappointed with the situation. The warning comes amid escalating tensions between China and the US over tariffs, which could lead to a full-blown trade war. Tong emphasized the importance of maintaining a healthy US-China relationship, particularly for Hong Kong, which enjoys a high degree of autonomy and freedoms.

site_title: Singapore firms to partner German firms in manufacturing push
summary: Singapore and German companies have partnered to enhance cross-country collaborations and co-innovation in manufacturing. The agreements, signed at the Germany-Singapore Business Forum, aim to promote innovation, knowledge exchange, and market access for startups. Partnerships include collaborations on Industry 4.0 technologies, microtechnology, and a Composite Application Centre to drive innovation and promote products in overseas markets. The move is expected to boost Singapore's manufacturing scene and leverage the complementary strengths of both countries.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's stocks closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 15.02 points to 1,865.34. The market saw 2.32 billion shares worth RM1.93 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 574 to 291.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets diverge at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets diverged at the start of trading on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 rising 0.2% to 7,412.67 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 increased 0.2% to 12,602.41 points. In contrast, Paris' CAC 40 dropped 0.2% to 5,428.18 points. The divergence in markets reflects varying economic conditions and investor sentiment, with mining and healthcare stocks driving gains in London and Frankfurt.

site_title: Hammond beats target as UK deficit hits 16-year low
summary: The UK's public borrowing fell to a 16-year low during the financial year ending in March, with a deficit of 2.1% of gross domestic product. This is the lowest since 2001/02. Cash borrowing was £42.6 billion, below the forecast of £45.2 billion. Finance Minister Philip Hammond's goal is to end the deficit by the mid-2020s, but faces pressure to spend more on health and services while easing austerity. Public debt remains high at 86.3% of GDP, but is expected to decline in the coming years.

site_title: Trump warns Iran against restarting nuclear program
summary: US President Donald Trump warned Iran against restarting its nuclear program, calling the 2015 deal negotiated by former President Barack Obama "terrible" and "insane". Trump expressed concerns that Iran might quit the treaty if the US scraps the agreement, stating that if they do, "they will have bigger problems than they have ever had before." French President Emmanuel Macron, who met with Trump, urged caution and cooperation to avoid nuclear proliferation in the region, but Trump remained firm in his stance, emphasizing the need to renegotiate the deal.

site_title: Stormy economic horizon to give ECB pause
summary: The European Central Bank is expected to maintain low interest rates and continue its massive stimulus program, despite economic growth concerns and inflation remaining below the 2% target. The ECB's cautious approach is driven by the ongoing slowdown in the eurozone economy, despite forecasts predicting 2.4% growth in 2018. The euro's strength against the dollar and President Trump's "America First" policy have raised concerns about global trade and the potential for a tit-for-tat escalation, leading the ECB to keep expectations of a quick exit from its stimulus program in check.

site_title: Deconsolidation of liquidated units yields Q4 profit for EMS Energy
summary: EMS Energy reported a net profit of S$39.37 million for Q4 2017, reversing a net loss of S$115.8 million in the same period the previous year. The profit was primarily due to the deconsolidation of its Koastal Industries Pte Ltd arm. Fourth-quarter revenue was negative S$428,000, largely due to the reclassification of a scrap sale to other income.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Midas flags two letters of demand
summary: Midas Holdings received two letters of demand in March and April 2018, regarding finance lease and financing agency agreements. The letters demand repayment of approximately $18.3 million and $6.9 million, respectively, due to unpaid rental charges and delayed payments. The company's board stated it will issue further announcements as the matter develops.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: AstraZeneca flop a fresh blow to cancer immunotherapy combination
summary: AstraZeneca's clinical study on combining immunotherapy drugs tremelimumab and Imfinzi to fight lung cancer failed to slow disease progression or extend life in patients who had already received at least two previous treatments. The study, known as ARCTIC, showed that Imfinzi on its own showed some signs of efficacy, while adding tremelimumab did not. This is a blow to the concept of combining the two drugs, which was once a promising approach.

site_title: Beware the politics of deficits and trade
summary: The Trump administration's fiscal stance is at risk of exacerbating the US trade deficit, particularly with China, amid a judicial investigation and midterm election year. As fiscal deficits widen, monetary policy may respond with interest rate hikes, boosting trade deficits. The US-China trade imbalance accounts for 60% of the overall US trade deficit, making China vulnerable to US punitive action. A mutually beneficial outcome may be possible if China offers compromises on its economic reform priorities. However, the US trade imbalance with the European Union is also significant, and high deficit levels could undermine confidence and investment, further amplifying calls for tougher action.

images.alt_text: In the event of a US-China trade war, exporters in both countries are obvious losers. However, import demand is rarely substituted by domestic producers and typically would draw on third-country providers.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on strong earnings, tech gains
summary: US stock indexes opened higher on Tuesday, driven by strong earnings from Verizon and Caterpillar, as well as gains in technology stocks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 131.25 points, or 0.54%, to 24,579.94, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, reaching fresh records.

images.alt_text: US stock indexes opened higher on Tuesday, helped by strong results from Verizon and Caterpillar as well as gains in technology stocks.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced a major Cabinet reshuffle, with 4G leaders now in charge of two-thirds of ministries. Forensic accountants found potential breaches at Trek 2000 International, involving current and former senior officers. Summit Power International delayed its $200m IPO due to market volatility. SLB Development and Oxley acquired a freehold building for $76.25m. Singapore firms partnered with German companies to boost manufacturing. Employment Claims Tribunals saw 1,190 cases in its first year, with 80% closed by March 31.

site_title: Singapore shares close up by 0.14% on Tuesday
summary: The Singapore stock market closed flat on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.14% to 3,584.56 points. 1.49 billion shares worth S$1.22 billion were traded, with Thai Beverage contributing to the gain, while Ezion Holdings led the losses. The market was influenced by global economic news, including the US-EU trade talks and the S&P 500's fresh record.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: IHH makes revised, binding bid for immediate equity infusion into Fortis
summary: IHH Healthcare, Asia's largest private healthcare operator, has made a revised, binding bid for an immediate equity infusion of 650 crore rupees (S$130 million) into Fortis Healthcare, India's second-largest hospital chain. The proposal includes the right to appoint two directors on the Fortis board and is subject to a non-binding subsequent equity infusion of up to 3,350 crore rupees. The deal is contingent on Fortis' agreement to provide immediate access to due diligence and the end-use of the infusion to be discussed with IHH's nominees.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Talkmed net profit falls 37.2% on lower patient visits
summary: Talkmed Group's net profit fell 37.2% to S$5.38 million in the first quarter of 2018 due to lower patient visits. CEO Dr. Ang Peng Tiam, a cancer specialist, was suspended for 8 months but resumed practice in March, with his departure affecting 40-50% of the company's revenue. The group also faces revenue pressure from neighboring countries with lower medical costs.

site_title: WeWork to open two Jakarta CBD locations by Q3
summary: WeWork is set to open two locations in Jakarta's central business district by Q3 2018, with 800 and 1,400 members, respectively. The spaces will feature community areas and Indonesian-inspired art. This expansion follows WeWork's US$500 million investment in Southeast Asia and South Korea, with plans to enter Bangkok, Kuala Lumpur, and Manila by the end of 2018. WeWork's managing director, Turochas "T" Fuad, sees Indonesia as a key market for innovation and collaboration.

site_title: Silverlake bags deal to upgrade South-east Asian bank's core systems
summary: Silverlake Axis has secured a contract with a South-east Asian bank to modernize its core banking systems. The project involves developing a customer-centric platform and migrating legacy systems to Silverlake's Integrated Banking Solution (SIBS) within 15 months. The first phase will focus on automated teller machines, retail payments, and mobile banking, while the second phase will upgrade the bank's core banking systems.

site_title: Indonesia jails former parliament speaker for 15 years over graft
summary: Indonesia sentenced former parliament speaker Setya Novanto to 15 years in jail for causing state losses of around $170 million linked to a national electronic identity card scheme. Novanto was also fined $36,000 and barred from holding public office for five years. The verdict reinforced perceptions of corruption in Indonesia's parliament, a country ranked 96th in Transparency International's corruption perceptions index. Novanto had repeatedly missed summonses for questioning and was accused of orchestrating a scheme to steal $173 million.

site_title: S Iswaran looks forward to challenge of helming MCI
summary: S Iswaran, the current Minister of Trade and Industry, will take over as Minister for Communications and Information (MCI) from May 1, succeeding Yaacob Ibrahim. Iswaran expressed his enthusiasm for the challenge, amidst a backdrop of "fake news" and communication issues. The appointment comes as the Cabinet reshuffle continues, with Iswaran's new role marking a significant shift in his portfolio.

site_title: YCH Group, Forchn Holdings sign accord on 3 strategic initiatives
summary: YCH Group and Forchn Holdings signed a framework agreement on three strategic initiatives in Hangzhou, China. The first initiative involves considering an acquisition of 13 YCH logistics real estate assets worth approximately S$400 million for EC World Reit, with a gross floor area of 280,000 square meters. The agreement marks a significant partnership between the two companies, with Forchn serving as a sponsor for the potential acquisition.

site_title: WeWork to open two Jakarta CBD locations by Q3
summary: WeWork will open two central Jakarta locations by the third quarter of this year, with the first at Sinarmas MSIG Tower accommodating 800 members and the second at Revenue Tower for 1,400 members. The locations will feature community spaces with Indonesian-inspired art and graphics. This expansion is part of WeWork's $500 million effort to enter Southeast Asia, with plans to also open spaces in Bangkok, Kuala Lumpur, and Manila by the end of 2018. WeWork's managing director, Turochas "T" Fuad, expressed excitement about creating communities to inspire innovation and collaboration in Indonesia.

site_title: UAE to fund US$50.4m project to rebuild Mosul's Grand al-Nuri Mosque
summary: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) has agreed to fund a $50.4 million project to rebuild Mosul's Grand al-Nuri Mosque, which was destroyed by Islamic State militants in 2017. The project, in partnership with the UN and Iraqi authorities, aims to restore the 12th-century mosque and its leaning minaret, known as the Hunchback. The reconstruction is expected to take at least five years, with the first year focused on clearing debris. The project is part of a larger $2 billion reconstruction effort needed to rebuild Mosul, which was severely damaged during the conflict.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust's 4Q DPU up 0.01 cent
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) reported a 0.01 cent increase in its 4Q DPU to 2.27 Singapore cents, driven by a 0.4% rise in income available for distribution to S$64.8 million. Gross revenue edged up 1.3% to S$108.9 million, while net property income increased 1.2% to S$84.3 million. For the full year, DPU rose to 9.04 cents and income available for distribution increased 14.6% to S$260.4 million.

site_title: US home sales increase strongly; inventory remains tight
summary: US home sales increased 1.1% in March to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.60 million units, the second consecutive month of growth. The Northeast and Midwest regions drove the increase, while the South and West saw declines. Despite a rise in housing inventory, a shortage of homes, especially at lower price points, remains a constraint. The median house price increased 5.8% to $250,400, and the 30-year fixed mortgage rate reached 4.47%, the highest level since January 2014.

site_title: F&N buys Vinamilk increases stake to 20%
summary: F&N, a subsidiary of Fraser and Neave, has acquired 705,080 shares in Vietnam's Vinamilk through open market purchases, increasing its stake to 20% of the company's share capital. This is part of F&N's plan to acquire up to 14.5 million additional shares, representing about 1% of Vinamilk's issued share capital. The acquisition was made through open market purchases, contrary to an earlier statement that it was through related parties.

site_title: China fails to get Indian support for Belt and Road ahead of summit
summary: China failed to secure India's support for its Belt and Road infrastructure project ahead of a visit by Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi to China. The Belt and Road, a massive project by Chinese President Xi Jinping, aims to connect China to Asia and beyond. India has refused to support the project, specifically due to the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor, which runs through Pakistan-administered Kashmir, a disputed territory claimed by India. This setback may impact India's participation in the project.

site_title: Singapore Cabinet reshuffle: 4G leaders now helming two-thirds of ministries
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has announced a significant Cabinet reshuffle, with 10 out of 19 ministries now led by fourth-generation ministers. The changes aim to expose and build a new team of leaders ahead of the term's end in January 2021. Three veteran ministers will retire, while new leaders will oversee public service, cyber security, and Muslim affairs. The reshuffle marks the most significant change in recent years, with the average age of Cabinet members decreasing to 55 and the number of members down to 19.

site_title: EU says "equivalence" a pragmatic solution for UK banks after Brexit
summary: The European Union's financial services chief, Valdis Dombrovskis, stated that the "equivalence" system, which grants market access to foreign financial firms, is a pragmatic solution for the UK after Brexit. This system, based on similar home rules, is deemed imperfect but effective in various circumstances. Dombrovskis acknowledged the UK's desire for a bespoke deal but believes equivalence can work for Britain as well, allowing for a smooth transition after Brexit.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks jump as energy firms rally
summary: Hong Kong shares surged on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.26% to close at 30,636.24, driven by energy firms boosted by fresh oil price gains. Russian aluminium giant Rusal rocketed 40% following a US offer to lift sanctions. The Shanghai Composite Index also rallied 1.99% and the Shenzhen Composite Index added 2.28%.

site_title: H&M to cut dividend for first time since 1974, analysts say
summary: Hennes & Mauritz AB, a Swedish clothing retailer, is expected to cut its dividend for the first time since 1974 due to struggles to attract shoppers and rising competition. Analysts predict a 7.5% reduction in dividend payments for fiscal 2018, with only one expecting an increase and 10 foreseeing a cut. The company's declining return on invested capital and high debt levels are contributing factors to the potential dividend cut, which would be offset by increased spending on its online platform.

images.alt_text: Hennes & Mauritz AB will probably cut its dividend for the first time next year as the Swedish clothing retailer struggles to attract shoppers to its stores.

site_title: Banks help push Australian shares to over 1-month high; NZ falls
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% to a one-month high, driven by banks, despite losses in materials due to a slump in aluminium prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 5,921.60, with Commonwealth Bank and Australia and New Zealand Banking Group leading gains. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.2% due to declines in consumer staples companies. The benign inflation data backed expectations of accommodative interest rates for some time.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.86% to 22,278.12, driven by a cheaper yen that boosted exporters. The broader Topix index rose 1.08% to 1,769.75. The market's gains were also supported by expectations for sound corporate earnings.

site_title: JTC tenders 2 industrial sites in Tuas and releases another for sale application
summary: JTC has announced the tender of two industrial sites in Tuas, Singapore, and released another site for sale application. The first site, a 0.47-hectare plot zoned for Business-2 development, has a 20-year tenure and a maximum permissible gross plot ratio of 1.4, while the second site, a 2.41-hectare plot, has a 30-year tenure and a maximum permissible gross plot ratio of 2.0. The third site, a 0.45-hectare plot, has a 20-year lease and a maximum permissible gross plot ratio of 1.4. The tenders close on June 5 and June 19, respectively.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: SAP more ambitious after soaring Q1 profits
summary: SAP has lifted its full-year forecasts after reporting a 33% year-on-year increase in Q1 profits, reaching 708 million euros. The company saw strong growth in cloud-computing products, with a 18% increase in sales to 1.1 billion euros. Operating profit also grew 52%, reaching 1.0 billion euros. SAP aims to boost revenue by 5.5% to between 24.8-25.3 billion euros and operating profits by 8.5% to between 7.35-7.5 billion euros. The company's new acquisition of Callidus Software has opened up new opportunities for growth in the customer relationship management market.

site_title: Flying taxi start-up hires designer behind modern Mini, Fiat 500
summary: German start-up Lilium hires Frank Stephenson, designer behind the modern Mini and Fiat 500, to lead design for its flying taxi. Lilium aims to develop electric aircraft capable of speeds of up to 300 km/h and range of 300 km on a single charge, with plans to begin online booking of commuter flights by 2025. Stephenson will design both the plane's exterior and interior, and the company has raised over $101 million in early-stage funding. Lilium's unique approach combines vertical take-off and wing-borne flight, setting it apart from rival start-ups.

site_title: Employment Claims Tribunals saw 1,190 cases filed in its first year
summary: The State Courts' Employment Claims Tribunals received 1,190 cases in its first year, with 80% closed by March 31. Most cases (78%) involved unpaid or short payment of salary, followed by overtime pay (37%) and salary in lieu of notice (27%). The tribunals granted 732 money orders and dismissed or withdrew other cases. The tribunals aim to provide a speedy, low-cost avenue for employers and employees to resolve disputes, with plans to take over wrongful dismissal claims in 2019.

site_title: Rival Botox maker says patients can't wait for it to hit shelves
summary: Revance Therapeutics CEO Dan Browne says patients are eagerly awaiting the company's longer-acting Botox treatment, RT002, which is expected to be approved for glabellar lines in 2020. The treatment, similar to Allergan's Botox, is currently in late-stage testing and is expected to last up to six months, compared to three to four months for Allergan's product. Revance plans to seek premium pricing and target the treatment for migraines, with a possible product launch in 2020. The company's stock has fallen 12% following its investor day presentation.

images.alt_text: Revance is targeting an FDA label to show the RT002, a botulinum toxin similar to Allergan's Botox, lasts up to six months, compared to a threeto four-month label claim for Allergan's best-selling product.

site_title: China unlikely to repeat LNG import surge this winter - Unipec
summary: China is unlikely to experience a repeat surge in liquefied natural gas (LNG) imports this winter, according to Unipec's president Chen Bo. Last year's surge in imports was driven by government policies that ordered millions of homes to switch to natural gas and electric heating from coal, causing a shortfall in supply and price increases. This year, demand is expected to rise but will be controlled by the government and companies, with Chinese companies planning to secure more gas ahead of next winter. Sufficient LNG supplies are available in the market, according to Chen.

site_title: Some funds bet on quick rebound in Russia's sanctions-hit markets
summary: Some global funds have started buying rouble-denominated sovereign bonds in Russia, taking advantage of the weaker currency after US sanctions plunged the rouble to 16-month lows. Despite initial market shock, investment flows have returned to rouble Treasury bonds, with overseas fund managers willing to overlook geopolitical tensions for the returns. Foreign investors hold a third of the OFZ market, attracted by the 4.7% real yield, and have been increasing their positions since the sanctions.

site_title: Australian regulator under fire over banking misconduct
summary: Australia's corporate watchdog, ASIC, is under fire for being "litigation shy" and failing to aggressively pursue banking misconduct. Former ACCC chairman Allan Fels stated that the regulator tends to settle cases with banks rather than prosecute them, allowing them to continue engaging in misconduct. ASIC has a "bad record" for 20-30 years, according to Fels. The government has vowed to increase penalties and expand ASIC's powers in response to the criticism.

site_title: New MRT signalling system to be tested on East-West Line starting this Sunday
summary: SMRT will conduct 'live' testing of its new signalling system on the East-West Line starting this Sunday, April 29, with five Sundays of full-day tests. The system, which allows trains to run closer together with intervals of up to 100 seconds during peak hours, will be tested when train services are operational. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) expects the system to be fully ready by June, with week-long 'live' testing commencing by end-May if all goes well.

site_title: Rolls-Royce is said to mull China venture for new wide-body jet
summary: Rolls-Royce Holdings Plc is in talks with Aero Engine Corporation of China on a possible partnership to jointly supply engines for the CR929 wide-body aircraft, a project aimed at breaking Boeing and Airbus's duopoly. The engine request for proposals has been issued with responses due in May, and the partnership could help China become a major player in aerospace manufacturing. Rolls-Royce is considering offering an updated version of its Trent 7000 engine, which powers the Airbus A330neo.

site_title: DeClout: Collateral, guarantee, change of control terms not unusual in S$10m loan
summary: CATALIST-listed technology firm DeClout has taken a S$10 million two-year loan from six private investors, citing it as the "best available financing option". The loan is secured by Procurri shares and guarantees from Beaqon and vCargo Cloud, and includes change of control provisions. DeClout disputes claims that the loan entrenches founder Vesmond Wong's position in the company, stating that the pledged assets and guarantees are not unusual for such transactions. The loan will help finance business expansion of subsidiaries Beaqon and vCargo Cloud.

site_title: Trafigura's LNG head takes on new Asian oil role
summary: Trafigura has appointed Hadi Hallouche, head of its liquefied natural gas (LNG) trading, to oversee the company's oil business in Asia. Hallouche, who joined Trafigura in 2011, will also manage the company's global gas business. Martin Urdapilleta, the current head of oil trading in Asia, is transitioning to a new role in Latin America, helping manage Pampa Energia S.A.'s downstream assets. This move follows Trafigura's expansion of its LNG trading desk and increased volumes of LNG traded in 2017, amid growing demand in Asia.

site_title: SLB Development, Oxley bag freehold Pei Fu Industrial Building in S$76.25m collective sale
summary: SLB Development's subsidiary, Oxley Kyanite, has acquired the freehold Pei-Fu Industrial Building for S$76.25 million, surpassing the reserve price of S$75 million. The unit land rate works out to S$489 per square foot per plot ratio. SLB intends to redevelop the site, subject to approvals, and will fund the purchase using internal resources and external borrowings. The acquisition is not expected to have a material impact on SLB's financials, and the deal was brokered by William Gan Realty.

site_title: Truck maker Volvo rides demand boom but supply chain under pressure
summary: Volvo, a Swedish truck maker, reported a strong first-quarter with demand for trucks and construction equipment across most markets. The company beat expectations with an operating profit of 8.3 billion Swedish crowns, but cautioned that its supply chain is under pressure due to high demand. Volvo raised its guidance for the North American and Indian heavy-duty truck market, as well as construction equipment in nearly all markets. The company's operating margin rose to 9.3%, but fell short of analyst expectations due to supply chain constraints.

site_title: The UK dance company putting a new spin on the art
summary: The UK dance company Candoco is redefining contemporary dance by showcasing performers with disabilities, such as wheelchair users and those with missing limbs. Founded in 1991 by Celeste Dandeker, who was left paralysed after a fall, the company aims to focus on artistic expression rather than disabilities. With a diverse range of performers, Candoco has become renowned for its innovative and inclusive approach to dance, working with leading choreographers and performing internationally. The company's artistic director, Ben Wright, describes Candoco's work as challenging perceptions of ability and disability, while dancer Laura Patay highlights the need for greater inclusivity in dance schools.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Trek 2000, CapitaLand Commercial Trust, mm2 Asia, ST Engineering
summary: Trek 2000 International faces potential breaches of Singapore laws, including round-tripping transactions and possible fraudulent claims, according to forensic accountants. CapitaLand Commercial Trust reported a lower distribution per unit in Q1. mm2 Asia secured a $2 million investment from R3 Asian Gems to become a pre-listing investor. ST Engineering's subsidiary JHK filed a bankruptcy petition in China to avoid further cash outlay.

site_title: The debate persists over GMO foods
summary: The US federal law requiring labeling of genetically engineered foods has sparked debate over its accuracy. While many consumers view GMO foods as "Frankenfoods," farmers and agricultural scientists have been using radiation and chemicals to induce gene mutations in crops for decades. Modern genetic engineering, however, involves introducing only one or a few new genes with a known function, often from unrelated species, differing from traditional breeding programs. Critics argue that the labeling requirement is misleading, while supporters believe it gives consumers the right to know what they're eating.

site_title: Software better tackling IS propaganda, Facebook says
summary: Facebook has successfully removed 1.9 million pieces of extremist propaganda from its platform in the first three months of 2018, nearly double the amount from the previous quarter. The company's counterterrorism team uses detection technology and has grown to 200 people from 150, with the median time to uncover newly uploaded terror content being under a minute. Facebook aims to remain neutral on ideology and politics, focusing on whether groups use violence to pursue their goals, and will continually improve its systems to counter terrorist groups' efforts to circumvent them.

site_title: Darco unit signs deal to distribute Aquaporin products in Singapore, Malaysia
summary: A Malaysian subsidiary of Darco Water Technologies, Ness Plus Trading, signed a deal to distribute Aquaporin products in Singapore and Malaysia. The products, featuring Aquaporin Inside Forward Osmosis Technology, will be available in both markets, marking Aquaporin's first exclusive distribution agreement in Malaysia. The technology is expected to be a game-changer for Malaysia's industrial wastewater treatment, offering lower operating expenses and capital expenditure costs.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes flat on Tuesday afternoon at 3,578.65
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Tuesday afternoon at 3,578.65, slightly falling due to a 0.89-point decline. The Straits Times Index (STI) ended flat on the day, with 208 losers outnumbering 124 gainers. About 778.6 million shares worth S$609.4 million changed hands.

site_title: Ex-AIA CFO Alistair Chamberlain joins HSBC Insurance as global head of product and actuarial
summary: HSBC Insurance has appointed Alistair Chamberlain, former Chief Financial Officer of AIA, as global head of product and actuarial, effective April 16, 2018. Chamberlain brings over 20 years of global insurance experience, including roles at Aviva and AIA. He will lead product development and management, as well as partner-sourced insurance products. HSBC sees his appointment as a demonstration of its commitment to growing its insurance business globally. Chamberlain's expertise in Asia is expected to be valuable in this role.

site_title: Summit Power defers over US$200m Singapore IPO, citing 'market volatility'
summary: Summit Power International, a Bangladeshi power producer, has indefinitely delayed its over US$200 million initial public offering (IPO) on the Singapore Exchange due to market volatility. The company had compromised on the deal size, lowering it to US$260 million, and had secured the Asian Development Bank as a cornerstone investor. Market participants cited a lack of demand from institutional investors, leading Summit to reassess its situation and provide a further update. The IPO was intended to raise funds for expanding and meeting growing power demand in Bangladesh's under-served market.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge up at open on Tuesday
summary: Hong Kong shares rose in the first few minutes of trading on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index adding 0.33% to 30,353.83, following two days of losses. Technology firms led the gain, while the Shanghai Composite Index inched up 0.06%. The Shenzhen Composite Index was slightly down.

site_title: Hwa Hong units complete acquistion, disposal of London properties
summary: A wholly owned subsidiary of Hwa Hong Corporation has acquired the remaining 30% interest in a freehold commercial property in London, 20 Midtown, for approximately £10.4 million. The acquisition is part of a deal where Vantagepro Investment, a wholly owned subsidiary of Hwa Hong, also disposed of the Herbal Hill property in London for £7 million, resulting in a gain of about S$6.6 million for the second quarter. The transactions aim to consolidate Hwa Hong's interest in income-producing properties in London and reinvest the proceeds into a newly refurbished asset.

site_title: Advancer Global clinches S$10.7m of facilities management contracts
summary: Advancer Global clinches S$10.7 million in facilities management contracts for the three months ended March 31, 2018. The contracts, valued between S$10,000 and S$100,000, were secured from existing and new customers, with 52.8% coming from existing customers. The company's facilities management division continues to drive growth, with a high renewal rate attributed to its expertise in real estate and building management services.

site_title: ESR-Reit acquires Tampines logistics facility for S$95.8m
summary: ESR-Reit acquired a logistics facility in Tampines, Singapore for S$95.8 million. The 455,396 sq ft facility, valued at S$96.4 million, is a four-storey multi-tenanted ramp-up logistics facility with a lease tenure expiring in 2041. The acquisition is expected to boost ESR-Reit's exposure to the logistics/warehouse sector to 27.1% and increase occupancy to 91.2%. The facility will provide further income diversification and leverage demand for logistics real estate.

site_title: Kenya coffee farmers going nuts yields record macadamia crop
summary: Kenyan farmers are shifting from coffee to macadamia production, driven by high demand from China. The country's macadamia crop has reached a record yield, with farmgate prices rising to 180 shillings per kilogram. In contrast, coffee farmers operate at a loss, earning about $0.55 per kilogram. The shift is expected to continue, with prices potentially reaching 200 shillings per kilogram. This change is attributed to China's growing demand for macadamias, which has led to increased investment and expansion in the East African nation's macadamia production.

site_title: Does alcohol cause PMS?
summary: Researchers found a moderate association between premenstrual syndrome (PMS) symptoms and heavy drinking, with a link more pronounced in women who consume one or more average-sized drinks per day. The study analyzed data from 19 studies in eight countries and suggested that PMS may contribute to increased drinking, but the relationship remains unclear. The study's findings indicate that moderate drinking is linked to PMS symptoms, but further research is needed to determine the causal relationship between the two.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on financials, materials underperform; New Zealand down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to 5,913.1, driven by banks, amid benign inflation data supporting interest rate stability. Core inflation remained below the central bank's target for a third consecutive quarter. Materials, however, were weighed down by a slide in aluminium prices.

site_title: Atlantic Navigation sinks further into the red with US$13.2m full-year loss
summary: Atlantic Navigation Holdings reported a full-year loss of US$13.2 million in FY2017, down from a US$11.4 million loss in FY2016, due to higher finance costs and marketing expenses. The company's gross profit declined 38.1% to US$3.3 million. Revenue increased 13.6% to US$33.9 million, driven by its marine logistics segment, which saw a 20.8% increase in turnover. The ship repair segment declined 50.8% due to a slowdown in the marine industry.

site_title: Singapore Maritime Week 2018: PSA, CrimsonLogic unit to build digital trade platform
summary: PSA International has partnered with CrimsonLogic to develop Calista, a global digital trade and supply chain platform. The platform aims to connect physical and non-physical elements of global supply chains in a digital ecosystem. Calista is seen as a 3D industry that goes beyond logistics, involving regulatory and financial activities. PSA has secured interest from DBS Bank, with more details to be shared in follow-up reports.

site_title: China's 'makers' battle mistrust in hi-tech community
summary: China's "makers" community, centered in Shenzhen, is working to challenge the country's reputation for intellectual property theft and counterfeit goods. The group, comprising engineers, programmers, and children, creates their own gadgets and devices from scratch, with government subsidies and support.
