However, critics argue that the abundance of funding can lead to a concentration of start-ups in areas with low demand, and that the process of bringing cases to court is too costly and time-consuming. Despite these challenges, many makers believe that China's innovative skills have improved significantly, with a growing interest in creative skills and a desire for hands-on learning experiences.

images.alt_text: At the "MG Space", a wall is covered by shelves with meticulously labelled bins containing assorted pieces of wood and foam, circuit boards, wires, soldering kits, plastic parts and joiners for communal use.

site_title: Brokers' take: OCBC, Jefferies, RHB raise their target price on Ascendas Reit
summary: Three broking houses, OCBC, Jefferies, and RHB, have raised their target price on Ascendas Reit, citing a 3.3% year-on-year revenue rise and a higher distribution per unit (DPU) of 3.91 Singapore cents. Despite risks such as sharp declines in occupancy and dilutive acquisitions, the brokers maintain a "buy" call and raise their target prices to S$2.71, S$2.95, and S$2.95, respectively. They expect Ascendas' portfolio to post a rental reversion of 2-5% in FY2019, driven by a positive market outlook and headroom for acquisitions.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks, won slip on rising US yields
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 0.14% to 2,470.67, while the won weakened 0.74% to 1,077 per dollar, as rising US Treasury yields and potential faster rate hikes by the Federal Reserves weighed on the market. Chipmaker SK Hynix fell 5% due to profit-taking, and the market capitalization of Kospi rose 0.3% so far this year.

site_title: Salad E.coli scare to end in weeks as California resumes output
summary: A recent US E. coli outbreak linked to romaine lettuce may soon come to an end as California farms resume production. The tainted lettuce originated near Yuma, Arizona, where the US's dominant leafy-green supplier operates from November to March. California's ideal growing conditions have taken over, replacing Arizona's production. The outbreak affected over 50 people, with 31 hospitalized, including five with kidney failure. Federal officials continue to investigate the exact origins of the outbreak.

images.alt_text: The concerns over the recent US outbreak of E. coli involving romaine lettuce may last no more than a few weeks, as the area of Arizona where the offending produce is believed to have come from is now out of production and California farms are taking over.

site_title: Trinity Mirror purchase of Express to get added UK review
summary: UK Culture Minister Matt Hancock has announced an additional public-interest review of Trinity Mirror's purchase of Express and Star tabloids, citing concerns over the need for free expression and plurality of views in newspapers. The deal, valued at 126.7 million pounds, would consolidate control of nine of 20 national newspaper titles, raising competition concerns. The Competition and Markets Authority is already reviewing the deal, with Hancock stating that Hancock will likely order media regulators to start probes, potentially casting a regulatory cloud over the transaction.

site_title: A surprising way to eat vegetables: for dessert
summary: US chefs are redefining traditional desserts by incorporating natural sweetness from vegetables like artichokes, squash, carrots, and sweet potatoes. Chefs aim to reduce added sugars, instead highlighting the inherent sweetness in these vegetables. By cooking vegetables with extended roasting times, chefs bring out their natural sugars, making them suitable for dessert. This approach encourages home cooks to experiment with cooking vegetables in new ways to enhance their natural sweetness, transforming them into sweet treats.

site_title: Stormy economic horizon to give ECB pause
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to maintain its cautious stance on interest rates and quantitative easing, citing threats to economic growth and sluggish inflation. The ECB may delay a quick exit from its stimulus program, keeping interest rates at historic lows and pushing back expectations of an interest rate rise. Analysts attribute this cautious approach to the re-emergence of downside risks, including the strengthening euro and US President Donald Trump's "America First" policy, which could undermine global trade.

site_title: Australia inflation stays soft in Q1, interest rates seen going nowhere
summary: Australia's consumer prices rose 0.4% in the first quarter, missing forecasts and staying below the central bank's 2-3% target for a third year. Core inflation averaged 1.9%, and wages growth slowed to historic lows, contributing to the low inflation rate. The Reserve Bank of Australia has kept interest rates at a low of 1.5% and sees no strong case for shifting anytime soon, with interest rate hikes unlikely before 2026.

site_title: UK government to offer Windrush generation free citizenship
summary: The UK government announced that members of the Windrush generation, who arrived in Britain before 1973, will be eligible for free British citizenship due to the controversy surrounding their immigration status. The move aims to provide compensation for those who have suffered due to the "hostile environment" policy. The government will also set up a compensation scheme and a customer contact centre to help individuals navigate the process. Interior Minister Amber Rudd stated that it is only right to recognize the significant contribution the Windrush generation made to the UK.

site_title: World's worst tech stock Lenovo may lose Hang Seng spot
summary: Lenovo, the world's worst-performing tech stock, is at risk of being dropped from Hong Kong's benchmark equity index due to its 56% slump since its addition in 2013, wiping out $5.8 billion in value. The company's shares have tumbled more than any other technology company, and its removal from the index could spur outflows of $107 billion in passive funds. Analysts attribute Lenovo's struggles to its poor smartphone models, loss of market share, and mobile business struggles, with some predicting the company may have to write off the value of its intangible assets.

site_title: DBS names South Korea AI firm's founder Bonghan Cho to board
summary: DBS Group has appointed Bonghan Cho, founder and CEO of Equalkey Corp, a South Korea-based AI firm, to its board of directors. Cho, a 53-year-old expert in artificial intelligence and computer science, will join the nominating committee and audit committee. His appointment, effective Thursday, is seen as a strategic move to complement DBS's boards with experience in emerging technologies and banking.

images.alt_text: Dr Cho's appointment to the boards of DBS Group Holdings and DBS Bank will take effect on Thursday.

site_title: New website, app to help Singapore food manufacturers catch overseas buyers: Koh Poh Koon
summary: Singapore's Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry and National Development, Dr Koh Poh Koon, announced initiatives to help local food manufacturers innovate and expand overseas. A new website and app were launched to connect local businesses with overseas buyers, featuring a B2B platform for traceability and authentication. The government is also working with major food suppliers to guide them through the digitalisation process, aiming to achieve cost savings of 5-15% for food service operators. Dr Koh emphasized the importance of partnerships between the government, industry stakeholders, and trade associations to support local SMEs in capturing growth opportunities overseas.

site_title: YouTube says computers are catching problem videos
summary: YouTube removed 8.28 million videos in the fourth quarter of 2017, with 80% initially flagged by computer systems, not humans. The platform is relying increasingly on artificial intelligence to police content, but experts warn against relying too heavily on machines to replace human judgment. Despite challenges, YouTube said its machines can detect and remove problematic content, including violent extremist videos, with 3/4 of flagged videos removed before human review. The company has hired 10,000 people to address policy violations and expand regional teams.

site_title: IPhone manufacturers' slowing sales are a bad omen for Apple
summary: Apple's iPhone sales have slowed, with its five largest device assemblers reporting a 8% rise in total sales in the March quarter, but growth later in the period slowed sharply. This slowdown suggests demand for the iPhone X may have faded quickly, despite a customary holiday quarter spike. Competitors from Huawei to Xiaomi dominate China, Apple's biggest foreign market, and the iPhone X has struggled to draw customers in emerging markets. Morgan Stanley has cut its estimate on iPhone shipments by 6 million, underscoring investor concerns.

site_title: US dollar stands tall as US 10-year bond yield nears 3%
summary: The US dollar reached a three-month high against a basket of currencies after the US 10-year Treasury yield climbed near the 3% mark, its highest in over four years. The yield peaked at 2.998% on Monday, driven by concerns over government debt supply and inflationary pressures from rising oil prices. The yield later backed off to 2.971% in early Asian trade, but the dollar remained strong.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher as exporters rise on lower yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.67% to 22,236.08, driven by a lower yen boosting exporters. Despite lacklustre trading on Wall Street, the broader Topix index rose 0.69% to 1,762.95.

site_title: Toronto police officer draws praise for refusing to shoot van suspect
summary: A Toronto police officer's restraint in refusing to shoot a suspect who claimed to have a gun was praised as an example of police restraint in the face of chaos. The suspect, Alek Minassian, 25, plowed a van into crowds of pedestrians, killing 10 people. The officer, whose identity was not released, stared down the suspect at gunpoint while he repeatedly pointed an object at police. The standoff ended with the suspect being arrested, with the officer responding, "No, get down" when the suspect said he had a gun.

images.alt_text: A Toronto police officer who refused to shoot the man suspected of plowing a van into crowds of pedestrians on Monday, killing 10 people, was praised for restraint in the face of a suspect who claimed to have a gun.

site_title: Sea of solar panels turns Mexican desert green
summary: A massive solar park, covering 2,200 football fields, has been built in the Mexican desert, featuring 2.3 million solar panels, making it the largest in Latin America. The Villanueva power plant, built by Enel, is part of Mexico's goal to generate 43% of its electricity from clean sources by 2024, marking a significant step towards a more sustainable energy future.

images.alt_text: With 2.3 million solar panels - covering the equivalent of 2,200 football fields in the arid northern state of Coahuila - the Villanueva power plant, built by Italian energy company Enel, is part of Mexico's push to generate 43 per cent of its electricity from clean sources by 2024.

site_title: Kim's 'bitter sorrow' as North Korea bus crash kills 32 Chinese tourists
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un expressed "bitter sorrow" after a bus carrying 32 Chinese tourists and four North Koreans plunged off a bridge, killing everyone on board. The accident occurred in North Hwanghae province, south of Pyongyang, and is believed to have been caused by the bus's poor road conditions. Kim met with the Chinese ambassador and visited crash survivors in hospital, acknowledging that the accident was a tragic misfortune for his people. China has urged North Korea to take all necessary means to handle the situation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 0.19 points to 1,880.17 on Tuesday, opening lower. The index saw 49.73 million lots traded worth RM19.86 million, with 86 gainers and 74 losers.

site_title: Europe: Shares supported by financials; UBS disappoints
summary: European shares rose 0.35% on Monday, driven by gains in financials despite a disappointing update from UBS, which fell 2.5%. Financials, benefiting from rising US Treasury yields, rose 0.75% and Italian banks reached their highest level in over 2 years. Consumer staples stocks, however, took points off the Stoxx index due to US yields hitting their highest level since 2014. The MSCI euro zone is expected to report earnings growth of 4.9% in the first quarter.

site_title: Prince's family sues hospital that treated his first opioid
summary: Prince's family sues Silver Cross Hospital in Illinois, alleging improper medical care following an opioid overdose on April 15, 2016, after a show in Atlanta. The lawsuit claims the hospital failed to diagnose and treat the overdose properly, leading to Prince's fatal overdose the following week. The suit also accuses the hospital of failing to investigate the cause and provide counseling. This comes days after authorities announced no one would be criminally charged in Prince's 2016 overdose death.

images.alt_text: Days after the authorities in Minnesota announced that no one would be criminally charged in the 2016 overdose death of Prince, his next of kin are suing an Illinois hospital that treated the singer for an opioid overdose the week before his fatal incident, according to a suit filed on Monday.

site_title: United Airlines CEO to skip bonus, chairman will step aside
summary: United Airlines CEO Oscar Munoz will forgo his 2017 bonus and Chairman Robert Milton will step aside, effective immediately. Milton will be replaced by independent board chief Laurence Simmons, who also plans to step down. The moves come a year after a passenger was dragged off a plane and amid controversy over a dog's death on a United plane. Munoz acknowledged shortcomings in 2017 and vowed to continue turning the company around. The board will select a new independent chairman and reduce its roster to 14 directors.

site_title: New destinations for Philippine workers are Russia, China
summary: The Philippines is exploring new job destinations, including Russia and China, to reduce its reliance on the Middle East. Russia is hiring skilled workers in construction and services, while China seeks 2,000 English teachers. The Czech Republic and San Marino are also negotiating labor deals. This move aims to diversify the country's workforce and reduce its economic dependence on the Middle East.

site_title: Cromwell European Reit buying freehold office building in Italy for 16.9m euros
summary: Cromwell European Reit is acquiring a freehold office building in Italy for 16.9 million euros. The property, located in Ivrea, has a 100% occupancy rate and a weighted-average lease expiry of over five years. The acquisition is expected to be completed by June 30 this year and is not expected to impact Cromwell European Reit's net tangible assets or distributions per unit for the current financial year. The deal will be financed through a third-party loan and a drawdown on a 75 million euro revolving credit facility.

site_title: UK government dealt another Brexit defeat in parliament
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May faces another Brexit defeat as the House of Lords voted 316-245 to retain the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, contrary to government plans. The EU Withdrawal Bill, which sets the framework for Britain's exit from the EU, is struggling to gain approval in parliament. The upper House of Lords' decision paves the way for further parliamentary battles over May's strategy, potentially setting the stage for a fresh round of debates in May and a final vote on the Brexit deal in October or November.

site_title: US: Stocks edge down as bond yields rise
summary: US stocks edged down on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average slipping 0.1% to 24,448.83, as rising US Treasury bond yields raised concerns about a potential acceleration of interest rate hikes. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also fell, with the Nasdaq dropping 0.3% to 7,128.60. Higher bond yields signal potentially higher interest rates, which could make debt payments more expensive and steer funds away from stocks.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Tuesday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.1% lower on Tuesday, retreating 3.59 points to 3,575.95. The most actively traded counter was ThaiBev, which rose S$0.015 to S$0.820. The market saw a mixed overnight performance from Wall Street, with concerns over soft smartphone demand weighing on tech stocks. Losers outnumbered gainers 67 to 55.

site_title: Trek 2000 chairman, others involved in breaches: forensic accountants
summary: Forensic accountants from RSM Corporate Advisory have found potential breaches at Trek 2000 International, a Singapore-based company, involving current and former senior officers, including Chairman Henn Tan. The review revealed issues with round-tripping transactions, fabrication and alteration of documents, and possible fraudulent claims under the Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) tax scheme. The company's inventory was also inaccurately recorded, and digital alterations were found in bank advices and supplier invoices. The investigation was launched after a preliminary report by TSMP Law Corporation and was conducted by RSM Corporate Advisory, with the findings released ahead of Trek's annual general meeting.

site_title: World's first penis, scrotum transplant done in US
summary: Doctors at Johns Hopkins University performed the world's first total penis and scrotum transplant on a US military serviceman wounded in Afghanistan. The 14-hour operation, completed on March 26, used a deceased donor's entire penis, scrotum, and partial abdominal wall. The recipient, who has requested anonymity, is expected to be released from the hospital next week. This breakthrough marks an additional advance in penis transplantation, following the US's first successful penis transplant in 2016 and the world's first successful penis transplant in South Africa in 2015.

site_title: George HW Bush hospitalised days after wife's death: office
summary: Former US President George HW Bush was hospitalized days after his wife Barbara's death due to a blood infection. He is receiving treatments and appears to be recovering. Bush's office released a statement on Monday, April 23, 2018.

site_title: CapitaLand Commercial Trust Q1 DPU down 11.7% at 2.12 Singapore cents
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) reported a 11.7% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.12 Singapore cents for Q1 2018, due to an enlarged number of units from a rights issue. Despite this, CCT's distributable income rose 7.5% to S$76.6 million, driven by contributions from Asia Square Tower 2 and higher net property income. Gross revenue increased 7.7% to S$96.4 million, while the portfolio committed occupancy rate remained 97.3%.

site_title: Southwest cancels more US flights as it inspects engines
summary: Southwest Airlines canceled 129 flights on Monday, or 3% of its total flights, as it inspected engines like the one that failed last week in a deadly accident. The cancellations were part of the airline's 30-day voluntary inspection program for CFM56-7B engines. Southwest also delayed 468 flights. In contrast, other major US carriers had fewer than five cancellations each. The airline's cancellations were the result of its decision to step up inspections of some engines.

site_title: Ten dead, 15 hurt by van plowing over Toronto sidewalk: police
summary: A white Ryder rental van plowed into a crowd on a busy Toronto sidewalk, killing 10 people and injuring 15 on a Monday afternoon. The driver, in custody, appeared to deliberately target victims on a roughly 1-mile-long rampage. The incident occurred near a Group of Seven foreign ministers meeting and is being investigated as a potential terrorism attack. Canada's public safety minister declined to comment on motivations, and the Islamic State militant group has been linked to similar attacks.

site_title: GM Korea reaches tentative wage deal, avoids bankruptcy
summary: GM Korea has reached a tentative wage deal with its labor union, averting bankruptcy. The agreement paves the way for Korea Development Bank to provide support, and GM Korea will allocate new models to help turn around the unit. The deal comes after the US automaker sought wage concessions and government funding to save its remaining three South Korean factories. The agreement was reached after a deadline to file for bankruptcy protection was missed, with 150,000 jobs at risk.

images.alt_text: The South Korean unit, once the backbone of GM's Asian strategy, has been hobbled by labour costs and hurt by the automaker's decision to pull its Chevrolet brand from Europe, a key export market.

site_title: Hainan hit hard by curbs
summary: China's tropical island of Hainan has implemented its first province-wide home-buying restrictions, targeting speculative investors attracted by favorable economic policies. The curbs cover an area roughly the size of Belgium, aiming to curb speculative investment and stabilize the market. The move comes after previous curbs were expanded, as part of a broader effort to manage the impact of these policies on the housing market.

site_title: Australia's central bank in 'no particular rush' to raise rates
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has no immediate plans to raise interest rates, despite predictions that the next move will be up. Assistant Governor Christopher Kent stated that there's "no particular rush" to hike rates, citing gradual job market improvement. Rates have been at a record low of 1.5% since August 2016, with markets expecting them to remain there until 2019.

images.alt_text: Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) Assistant Governor Christopher Kent said the central bank had been clear on the steady rate outlook for some time and there was no reason to alter it.

site_title: Noble rejects Goldilocks' nomination of 5 directors
summary: NOBLE Group has rejected a nomination of five non-executive directors by substantial shareholder Goldilocks at its upcoming annual general meeting. Goldilocks claims Noble's position is "oppressive and coercive" due to its stance on the issue, which Goldilocks argues damages all shareholders' rights. The Abu Dhabi-based fund is also urging Noble to provide details on its restructuring plan and disclose assets to support debts. Noble shares closed 4.8% higher on the news.

site_title: These seeds will captivate you even if you're not a gardener
summary: A book titled "The Book of Seeds" showcases the compact complexity of seeds, which hold genetic information that makes the plant world tick. Edited by Paul Smith of Botanic Gardens Conservation International, the book aims to conserve plants and their seeds to safeguard Earth's plant diversity. The non-profit organisation links over 500 botanic gardens in 96 countries to achieve this goal.

site_title: Chinese carrier leads live fire drill in East China Sea
summary: A Chinese naval flotilla led by the aircraft carrier Liaoning conducted a live combat drill in the East China Sea, engaging in anti-aircraft and anti-submarine warfare training with a simulated "opposing force". The drill, which took place on Sunday, was the latest show of force by Beijing's burgeoning navy in disputed waters. The Liaoning, a refurbished Cold War-era aircraft carrier, has been on a high-visibility tour in recent weeks, accompanied by support ships, and has been involved in several muscle-flexing drills in the disputed South China Sea and waters surrounding Taiwan.

site_title: US eases sanctions stance on Rusal; aluminum prices tumble
summary: The US Treasury announced it could lift sanctions on Russian aluminum giant Rusal if tycoon Oleg Deripaska relinquishes control of the company. This decision led to a 7.2% drop in aluminum prices on the London Metals exchange, while other metals also fell sharply. The sanctions, imposed in response to the attempted murder of former spy Sergei Skripal, had threatened Rusal's business and sparked concerns of tighter aluminum supplies on the global market. The easing of sanctions could provide relief to Rusal, whose shares had plummeted by two-thirds.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) posted strong third-quarter net earnings of S$100.5 million, a 21% year-on-year increase. Analysts have upgraded SGX to a "buy" due to its 12.4% total return, including a 3.7% dividend yield. MindChamps Preschool and mm2 Asia have also received "buy" recommendations, with target prices of S$0.95 and S$0.56, respectively, citing strong growth prospects and branding positions.

site_title: Madonna loses bid to stop auction of intimate items
summary: Madonna lost her bid to stop an auction of intimate items, including a breakup letter from Tupac Shakur, after a judge ruled that she targeted the wrong target, art dealer Darlene Lutz. The items were up for sale by auction house Gotta Have Rock and Roll, and Lutz had previously helped Madonna build a collection before falling out. The judge agreed with Lutz, stating that Madonna's claims were "time-barred and improper" and that she should have pursued her assistants instead. The auction is set to proceed in July.

site_title: Google parent Alphabet profit leaps on ad growth
summary: Google parent Alphabet reported a 70% surge in quarterly profits to $9.4 billion, exceeding forecasts. Revenue rose 26% to $31.1 billion, driven by strong growth in digital advertising. This marks a significant improvement from the same period last year. The strong ad growth is attributed to Alphabet's dominance in the digital advertising segment alongside Facebook.

site_title: Australian, NZ dollars at multi-week lows; PMIs, inflation data in focus
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell to multi-week lows as the US dollar strengthened amid rising inflation expectations. The Australian dollar slid 1.3% last week, its biggest weekly fall since mid-March, while the New Zealand dollar also dropped. The currencies' declines were linked to rising US inflation, which may lead to interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: The Australian dollar held at US$0.7676 after hitting a two-week trough of US$0.7655 on Friday. The currency slipped 1.3 per cent last week, its biggest weekly fall since mid-March.

site_title: Oil settles higher; fears of Iran sanctions end early slide
summary: Oil prices rebounded after early fears of US sanctions on Iran, with Brent crude futures rising 65 cents to $74.71 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures increasing 24 cents to $68.64 a barrel. Investors were reassured that sanctions would dampen Iran's output, despite the nation producing above its OPEC quota. Oil inventories declined at the Cushing storage hub, supporting prices. The market recovery is seen as a response to posturing from the US and OPEC members, with the US set to decide on new sanctions against Iran by May 12.

images.alt_text: Oil prices rebounded from an early slide to finish higher and strengthen further in post-settlement trade, as investors feared US sanctions could dampen Iran's output.

site_title: At age 20, Hong Kong SAR should be treated as an adult
summary: Hong Kong's 20th anniversary as a Special Administrative Region of China was marked by President Xi Jinping, who declared the territory an adult and expected it to make more decisions and assume greater responsibilities. However, this move has been met with concerns that Beijing is tightening its grip on the region, with officials calling on Hong Kongers to support the Communist Party. This contradicts Deng Xiaoping's 1984 statement that Hong Kong officials should respect the Chinese nation but not necessarily support the socialist system. The move has been criticized as a threat to Hong Kong's autonomy and has damaged its image.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: The directors of YuuZoo Corporation have called for an extraordinary general meeting on May 16 to approve a proposed restructuring that would shift the company's registration from Bermuda to the British Virgin Islands. The move aims to change YuuZoo's capital structure from par value to non-par value shares, providing flexibility for future capital adjustments. The exact reason for the change was not specified.

site_title: Greenback rallies to 7-week high as bond yields rise
summary: The US dollar surged to a 7-week high as the 10-year US Treasury yield rose to within a whisker of the 3% level, prompting buying of the greenback and leaving the euro and yen sharply lower. Rising bond yields are seen as a sign of inflationary pressures and a potential bear market for bonds, with the dollar index reaching its highest level since March 1. The euro fell to a 2.5-week low, and Asian emerging market currencies weakened against the US dollar.

site_title: Data: At the Centre of Smart Nation, Singapore
summary: Singapore's Smart Nation initiative relies heavily on data, which is processed, stored, and retrieved in data centres. The country has emerged as a top destination for data centres, with major players like Amazon and Google investing in the sector. To maintain its lead, Singapore must prioritize cybersecurity, innovation, and sustainability. The country has implemented advanced cybersecurity measures and is exploring new technologies such as edge computing and next-gen data centres. Additionally, the government is launching initiatives to reduce the carbon footprint of the data centre industry, aiming to improve energy efficiency and reduce costs.

site_title: OCBC Sec promotes ex-senior police official Dennis Hong to MD post
summary: OCBC Bank has promoted 38-year-old Dennis Hong, a former police official, to managing director of its securities arm, effective May 1. Hong succeeds Raymond Chee, who will oversee OCBC's US operations. Under Hong's leadership, OCBC Securities has grown into one of Singapore's leading brokerages, with a 43% increase in wealth management income to S$3.25 billion last year. The bank's wealth management business is expected to grow as customers seek to invest in Singapore and overseas stock markets.

site_title: Greece wants 'clean' bailout exit, won't return to spendthrift days
summary: Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras announced the country's intention to exit its bailout program without requesting a precautionary credit line, aiming for a "clean" exit by August 20. Greece hopes to regain full market access and set its own economic policy after eight years of supervision. EU officials express concerns that Greek politicians may revert to "spendthrift days" of the past, but Tsipras assures a clear completion of the program and a return to prudent fiscal policy.

site_title: Aspiring to be the best in its class
summary: APRO Training Centre, a security training organisation, aims to be the best in its class by offering security WSQ programmes from Certificate to Diploma level. The company, a winner of the Singapore SME 1000 - Net Profit Growth Excellence Award for Services, validates its efforts in achieving commercial success. APRO plans to diversify its product mix, focus on adult education, and explore internationalisation as part of its growth strategy. The company has trained over 5,000 students annually and is rolling out new electronic models of training.

site_title: Industry still moving slowly on digitalisation
summary: A poll of 125 senior maritime executives at the "Global Perspectives: The Future of Shipping" conference in Singapore revealed that a significant percentage harbor doubts about a digital future for the sector. The poll indicates the industry is taking small, incremental steps in going digital. This suggests the industry is moving slowly in adopting digitalization, with many respondents expressing uncertainty about its worth.

site_title: GIC to invest US$100m in Ping An's Good Doctor US$1.1b IPO
summary: Ping An Good Doctor, a unit of China's largest insurer by market value, has attracted cornerstone investors such as GIC and Khazanah Nasional Bhd to a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) that could raise up to US$1.1 billion. Seven investors, including BlackRock and Singapore sovereign fund GIC, have agreed to buy about US$550 million of stock, with GIC investing US$100 million. The IPO aims to fund acquisitions, strategic alliances, and research, and will begin trading on May 4.

site_title: China Jinjiang Environment issuing 214m new shares to raise S$107m
summary: China Jinjiang Environment Holding Company (CJE) is issuing 214 million new shares to Harvest Environmental Investment Fund SP to raise S$107 million. The issue price is S$0.50, a 5.78% discount to the volume-weighted average price of S$0.5307. The funds will be used for technical upgrading of eight waste-to-energy facilities in China, expanding capacity by 5,000 tonnes per day and reducing emissions. The deal is expected to improve gearing, enhance borrowing capacity, and diversify resources, with Harvest Global Capital Investments as a long-term investor.

site_title: MIT posts 2.4% rise in Q4 DPU
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) posted a 2.4% year-on-year rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.95 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter ended March 31, 2018. The increase was driven by contributions from a build-to-suit project for HP Singapore and a 40% interest in US data centres. Gross revenue and net property income both rose 2.9% to S$90.39 million and S$67.88 million, respectively. MIT's assets under management grew to S$4.32 billion, and its DPU rose 3.2% to 11.75 Singapore cents for the full fiscal year.

site_title: Blockchain is about to revolutionise the shipping industry
summary: Blockchain is set to revolutionize the shipping industry by replacing millions of paper documents with a digital system. AP Moeller-Maersk A/S and technology companies have teamed up to upgrade the logistics network, increasing efficiency and reducing costs. This move aims to modernize the industry, which still relies heavily on traditional methods. The use of blockchain technology could lead to faster and more secure transactions, improving overall supply chain management.

site_title: Ascendas Reit's Q4, full-year DPU up on acquisitions
summary: Ascendas Reit reported a 3.91 Singapore cent DPU for Q4 2018, up from 3.852 cents in the same period last year. Gross revenue rose 3.3% to S$215.7 million and net property income increased 2.5% to S$157.9 million, driven by the acquisition of properties in Brisbane, Australia. For the full year, DPU rose to 15.988 Singapore cents, and gross revenue and net property income increased 3.8% and 3% respectively.

site_title: CFA Institute reiterates warning on dual-class share structures
summary: The CFA Institute reiterated its warning against dual-class share (DCS) structures, citing concerns that weighted voting rights (WVR) will weaken checks and balances between shareholders and management. DCS gives disproportionate voting power to one group of shareholders, contradicting the "one-share, one-vote" principle considered a cornerstone of good corporate governance. This warning comes ahead of the Hong Kong stock exchange's opening to DCS-listed applicants.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: ThaiBev representatives join Sabeco beer board
summary: ThaiBev representatives have been added to the management board of Vietnam's largest brewer Sabeco, following a shareholder vote. ThaiBev, which owns over 50% of Sabeco, had initially complained about the delay in accepting its proposed board members. The three new board members, including Singaporean Koh Poh Tiong, were approved by shareholders last month. The move comes after ThaiBev won an auction in December to buy Sabeco for $4.84 billion.

site_title: Google CEO Sundar Pichai poised to cash in US$380m award this week
summary: Google CEO Sundar Pichai is set to receive a US$380 million payout from a 353,939 restricted share grant that will vest this week. The grant, which was worth approximately US$380 million at the time, has increased in value due to Alphabet's stock surge of 90% since the grant date. Pichai, 45, received the shares in 2014 before his promotion to senior vice-president of products. This payout is one of the largest single payouts to a public company executive in recent years.

site_title: Oxley tipped to clinch Pei Fu Industrial Building
summary: OXLEY Holdings is expected to buy the Pei Fu Industrial Building in Singapore for S$76.25 million, surpassing the reserve price of S$75 million. The deal works out to S$489 per square foot per plot ratio, based on a proposed gross floor area of 155,864 square feet. The transaction has been brokered by William Gan Realty, and the sale is the first collective sale of an industrial property this year. Owners controlling 88.5% of the strata area and share value have given their nod to the collective sale.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Philips Q1 results beat estimates on strong growth in China, US
summary: Philips' Q1 results exceeded expectations, driven by strong growth in China and the US. Core profit rose 15% to 344 million euros, with a 5% comparable sales growth and a 10% increase in new orders. The company's high-end hospital equipment saw increased demand, contributing to the positive results.

site_title: Twitter wins in information and comms category
summary: Twitter has won the Singapore 1000 - Sales/Turnover Growth Excellence Award in the Information & Communications sector, thanks to its strong growth in the Asia-Pacific region. The award recognizes Twitter's efforts to establish its footprint in the region, with managing director Arvinder Gujral attributing the success to the region's young and fast-growing population. Twitter plans to continue investing in the region, prioritizing initiatives that improve user experience and expand its business across new channels.

images.alt_text: Apart from overseeing the business for South-east Asia, Mr Gujral is in charge of forming strategic partnerships in Asia-Pacific at Twitter.

site_title: Profindo wins in international SME category
summary: Profindo Pte Ltd, a Singapore-based international trading and ship chartering company, won the SME Overseas Sales/Turnover Excellence Award in the Singapore International 100 award category. Established in 1998, Profindo has expanded its product range and attracted clients across Africa, India, and Sri Lanka. The company plans to recruit more professionals with entrepreneurship thinking to expand into more value-added products and increase its turnover. Profindo aims to grow its business by entering the venture capital business in developing countries with growth potential.

site_title: Sudden Modi-Xi meet signals diplomatic thaw between neighbours
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi will meet Chinese President Xi Jinping in Wuhan, China, for an informal summit on Friday and Saturday, marking a diplomatic thaw between the two neighbors. The meeting aims to reduce tensions after a border dispute last year and promote a mutually beneficial trading partnership. Both leaders have strong domestic reasons to put tensions aside, including China's trade war with the US and India's economic reforms. The summit is seen as a rare opportunity for the two countries to discuss strategic matters and set aside formalities, with the goal of a breakthrough before border tensions resurface.

site_title: To be global manufacturing hub, Singapore firms need deep capabilities: Iswaran
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry S. Iswaran emphasized the need for local companies to develop deep capabilities and expand into international markets to become a leading global manufacturing hub. At the Hannover Messe, 19 Singaporean companies showcased their advanced manufacturing products and services, while another 20 visited the fair to network and learn from German Mittelstand companies. Iswaran highlighted the importance of quality and capability in driving competitiveness, citing the Mittelstand's tradition of innovation and productivity.

images.alt_text: Minister for Trade and Industry (Industry) S Iswaran (in purple tie) dropping in on the Singapore companies who have set up booths under the Singapore Pavilion at the Hannover Messe trade fair.

site_title: Cash crunch the ugly face of India's bank morass
summary: India is experiencing a cash crunch, with ATMs running out of cash in several states, including Karnataka, ahead of elections. The central bank attributes the shortage to unusually large withdrawals and speculation about the hoarding of high-denomination notes. A possible demonetization effect and concerns over the banking system's stability are also contributing factors. The crisis has led to a decline in depositors' trust, with 18 out of 35 Indian banks seeing an increase in default risk. The government needs to address the underlying issues, including bad loans and fraud, rather than just providing temporary solutions like printing more cash.

site_title: Popular Chinese restaurant chain wins award
summary: Pu Tien Holdings, a Chinese restaurant chain, has won the Singapore SME 1000 - Sales/Turnover Growth Excellence Award in the Hospitality/Food & Beverage sector for its rapid expansion and financial performance. Founded in 2000 as a coffee shop, the chain has grown to 49 outlets in Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia, Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Taiwan, serving Fujian province-inspired cuisine known for its light, down-to-earth flavors. The award recognizes the company's commitment to creating an exceptional culinary experience and its ability to differentiate its cuisine from peers.

site_title: MPA inks MoU to develop 'future-ready' seafarers for Singapore's maritime sector
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the aim of developing 'future-ready' seafarers equipped with skills to cope with digitalisation and automation in the maritime sector. This move is part of MPA's efforts to ramp up digital transformation in the sector. The partnership seeks to enhance the employability of seafarers in the industry, which is expected to undergo significant changes due to technological advancements.

site_title: RIP: Annual reports on CD-ROM
summary: The use of annual reports on CD-ROM is declining in Singapore, with companies opting for digital versions instead. The Singapore Exchange's easing of rules on electronic communication has contributed to the demise, along with the collapse of CD manufacturing, easy online access, and the format's negative environmental impact. Companies are saving costs and reducing clutter, with some reporting a 15% reduction in annual report production costs. Despite some companies bucking the trend, the shift towards digital reports appears to be a fresh trend, with many firms embracing e-communications as normal practice.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: India to file dispute with WTO if US rejects tariff request
summary: India plans to file a trade dispute with the World Trade Organization (WTO) if the US rejects its request for exemptions from tariffs on steel and aluminum, citing strategic partnership and non-security concerns. The request was made despite India's small steel exports to the US. If rejected, India may consider temporarily raising customs duties on US goods or seek support from other WTO member nations.

site_title: Trump-Macron meeting has global ramifications
summary: US President Donald Trump and French President Emmanuel Macron are set to meet in Washington DC for the first official state visit of Trump's presidency. Despite their strong friendship, the summit may be tense due to ongoing issues such as the Iran nuclear deal and US tariffs on steel and aluminium. Macron is seeking to sway Trump's thinking on key issues like global warming and international trade, while Trump has given the EU until May 1 to negotiate permanent exemptions from US tariffs. The meeting highlights the global ramifications of their discussions, which embody the current "battle" between liberal centre ground and rising conservative, populist tide.

site_title: Toshiba weighs chip unit options with sale deadline out of reach
summary: Toshiba is unlikely to meet a May 1 deadline to sell its memory chips business to a Bain Capital-led group due to regulatory hurdles in China. The company may consider alternative options, such as renegotiating the terms, taking the business public, or retaining the division, which could yield billions of dollars. Toshiba shares rose 5.3% on the news, and analysts believe the company could fetch a higher price for the semiconductor unit if it seeks alternatives.

site_title: Singapore banks' offshore expansion a mixed bag
summary: Singapore's three largest banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, have mixed results in expanding their offshore businesses. OCBC has increased its offshore income by 38% in 2017, driven by growth in Greater China and Indonesia. UOB has also seen growth in all its markets, with Singapore and Greater China leading the way. DBS, however, has been slower to expand, with its Singapore income accounting for 65% of group total, up from 58% in 2012. Despite this, all three banks aim to tap into Asia's growing economies and benefit from the Asean Economic Community's integration agenda.

site_title: Cultural intelligence - a skill critical for SME leaders
summary: A Singaporean executive, Francois, was posted to manage Asia-Pacific business for a Swiss-owned pharmaceutical firm. Despite having experience in multiple European countries and the US, Francois struggled due to cultural differences and a disruptive industry. His failure led to his ousting, but it highlights the importance of cultural intelligence (CQ) for SME leaders. CQ is a sought-after soft skill for leaders managing regional and global operations. It involves understanding cultural contexts, adapting strategies, and building connections. SMEs must prioritize developing cross-cultural leaders to thrive in a global market, and CQ can be learned through motivation, self-awareness, and exposure to different cultures.

site_title: Eurozone business growth slows again: survey
summary: Eurozone business growth slowed in April, but remained strong, according to a survey. The composite flash Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) held steady at 55.2, defying expectations of a decline. The eurozone's two largest economies, Germany and France, showed improvements, but manufacturing growth waned due to a strong currency. The European Central Bank's asset purchase program is set to end this year, and interest rates may be hiked in 2019. Quarterly GDP growth is predicted at 0.6%.

site_title: Oceanus inks MOU with two parties to explore aquaculture opportunities
summary: Oceanus Group, a Singaporean seafood value chain manager, signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Shaw Investment Holdings and China Construction Seventh Engineering Division to explore global aquaculture investment opportunities worth US$500 million. This partnership aims to address growing food security concerns worldwide. The MOU was announced on April 23, 2018.

site_title: Freehold site in Jalan Besar for sale by expression of interest
summary: A freehold commercial site in Singapore's Jalan Besar area has been launched for sale via expression of interest, with an indicative guide price of S$13.5 million (S$1,392 psf ppr). The site, which occupies 3,230 sq ft, is zoned for F&B services, office, co-working, and retail uses. No development charge is payable, and foreigners are eligible to purchase. The EOI exercise closes on May 30.

site_title: Vard says CEO is 'independent', can offer his view on exit offer
summary: Vard Holdings, a Singapore-based shipbuilding and repairing company, responded to queries from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) regarding its proposed voluntary delisting. The company clarified that CEO Roy Reite is considered "independent" for making recommendations to shareholders due to the Singapore Code on Takeovers and Mergers, which requires the board to indicate whether or not to recommend the exit offer. Vard denied that Reite faces an "irreconcilable conflict of interest" despite being employed by the company for a long time, and stated that assessments on independence should be made by the offeree company directors themselves.

site_title: 'If you don't analyse the data, it's just data.'
summary: A 25-year-old engineer, Bryan Mok, transformed his role at JEP Precision Engineering from a machinist to a data analyst after the company introduced an Overall Equipment Effectiveness (OEE) Monitoring and Analysis system. Mok learned to analyze the system's data, which revealed specific points of inefficiency and time loss across departments. He expanded the system to other departments, meeting weekly with a data analysis team to discuss improvements. Mok's newfound role has been a significant change from his initial career path, but he now seeks to "help the company earn more money" by optimizing production processes.

images.alt_text: For Bryan Mok, who has a diploma in precision engineering, data analysis was an entirely foreign field: "That's something that I've never learnt in school before. I never thought it existed."
Janice Heng

site_title: Two freehold sites going en bloc
summary: Two freehold sites in Singapore have joined the collective sale frenzy. Park House in Orchard has a guide price of S$308 million, while St Michael's Condominium in Serangoon has a guide price of S$112 million. Owners of the 56 apartments in Park House and four shops in St Michael's Condominium will receive at least S$5 million and S$6.65 million respectively. Developers are expected to submit tender bids, with at least eight to 10 bids anticipated, with the tenders closing on May 31 and May 23 respectively.

site_title: Quite a feat for business in Chicken Street
summary: Kabul's Chicken Street, once a hub for foreign visitors seeking Afghan exotica, is now struggling due to security concerns. The street, lined with shops selling jewelry, antiques, and Oriental rugs, has seen a significant decline in customers, with many shops having zero patrons at any given time. The security situation, including worsening suicide bombings and a lack of faith in the police force, has driven shoppers away. Embassies and international organizations have banned their employees from shopping there, further exacerbating the problem. Many merchants, including Herat Carpets owner Wahid Abdullah, are relocating to Istanbul due to security concerns.

images.alt_text: (Above) Men and store owners gathering outside Hajji Abdul Razzaq's store, Kabul Leather, which sells fur and animal skins, on Chicken Street.
(Above) Stuffed cheetahs for sale in the basement of Hajji Abdul Razzaq's store.

Wahid Abdullah (above) showing foreigners rugs in his shop, Herat Carpets, on Chicken Street in Kabul. The shopping street in Kabul famed for its eclectic wares has fallen on hard times because of security worries.

site_title: China coal imports tumble on new rules; India unlikely to pick up slack
summary: China's new restrictions on coal imports have led to a 30% decline in seaborne coal imports, falling to 3.45 million tonnes in the week ended April 21. This slump is believed to be a direct result of the restrictions, which aimed to boost domestic thermal coal prices and production. Domestic thermal coal prices have risen 9.8% to a three-week high, while seaborne thermal coal prices have dropped 19.7% from their peak. The move is unlikely to lead to an increase in coal imports to India, as prices remain too high for Indian buyers.

site_title: Shanghai steel hits 5-week high, coke jumps
summary: Chinese steel futures reached a five-week high, supported by falling stockpiles and rising construction demand, while coke futures surged to a five-week high as small producers consider slashing output to revive prices.

site_title: Malaysian High Court allows Mahathir's PPBM to continue
summary: The Malaysian High Court has ruled in favor of Parti Pribumi Bersatu Malaysia (PPBM), allowing the party to continue operating despite a 30-day provisional disband order issued by the Registrar of Societies. PPBM president Tan Sri Muhyiddin Yassin confirmed that the party remains legal and will function normally.

site_title: NTUC names Ng Chee Meng, Koh Poh Koon to deputy sec-gen posts
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) in Singapore has appointed Education Minister Ng Chee Meng and Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Koh Poh Koon as deputy secretaries-general. Ng is expected to eventually fill the top role of secretary-general, while Koh will act as a liaison between the labour movement and government agencies. The appointments come after the NTUC requested suitable office holders to serve the labour movement, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong agreeing to release Ng and Koh to serve in the labour movement on a part-time basis.

images.alt_text: Mr Ng (left) says his immediate priority is to talk to union leaders and understand better the aspirations and needs of workers while Dr Koh sees the unions playing an important role in encouraging workers to take on new skills.

site_title: Conditions right for LNG to set sail
summary: The demand for liquefied natural gas (LNG) in Asia is growing, with Asia accounting for 55% of global demand growth in 2017. China's LNG demand surged by 50% in 2017, reaching 38 million tonnes, driven by the growth of the manufacturing sector, China's need for natural gas, and predictions that gas will become the largest single source of energy by 2034. This trend is expected to continue, with China predicted to become the leading gas importer by 2030.

site_title: China's Didi Chuxing launches ride service in Mexico
summary: China's Didi Chuxing launched its ride-hailing service in Mexico, specifically in the city of Toluca, marking the company's first international expansion outside of Asia. Didi aims to compete with Uber, the current leader in Mexico, and has introduced new safety features, including an emergency alert button and a safety monitoring system. The company plans to expand its services to other major Mexican cities later this year, and has already started recruiting drivers. Didi will offer a 20% commission rate, lower than Uber's 25%, in an effort to attract customers.

site_title: Gold sinks to 2-week low as rising bond yields support dollar
summary: Gold prices fell to a 2-week low, dropping 0.1% to $1,334.11 per ounce, as the dollar rose due to rising US bond yields and easing global political concerns. The US dollar traded near a two-week high, bolstered by climbing US bond yields and concerns easing over North Korea's nuclear and missile tests. Higher US bond yields weigh on greenback-denominated gold, with expectations of three more interest rate hikes in 2018 also supporting the dollar.

site_title: Gulf Air looks to Middle East routes to boost passenger growth
summary: Gulf Air aims to boost passenger growth by focusing on Middle East routes, adding eight destinations this year. The state-owned airline plans to fly to over 60 destinations by 2023, with its deputy CEO stating that it wants to re-establish its position in the region. The airline expects to carry 5.5 million passengers this year, up from 5.3 million in 2017, and its fleet will expand to 35 aircraft. Gulf Air hopes to increase origin and destination traffic by carrying more tourists to Bahrain, which has seen an increase in corporate travelers following a recent oil discovery.

site_title: China's 'men only' job ads run afoul of Human Rights Watch
summary: China's major tech firms, including Alibaba, Tencent, and Baidu, faced criticism for gender discrimination in job advertisements, with many featuring "men only" or "men preferred" language and requests for female applicants to be "trim" and "aesthetically pleasing". Human Rights Watch reported that these discriminatory practices contribute to a drop in the female workforce and widening gender pay gap, despite being illegal in China. The organizations also targeted government departments for similar offenses, with nearly one in five job ads for the 2018 national civil service calling for "men only" or "men preferred".

site_title: Sabana Reit's DPU constant at 0.88 Singapore cents
summary: Sabana Reit's first quarter ended March 31 showed flat DPU at 0.88 Singapore cents, despite lower income available for distribution and gross revenue due to reduced contributions from some properties. Property expenses fell 25.8% due to rental arrears recovery and lower impairment losses. The Reit aims to raise occupancy to 88.9% by year-end, with plans to divest and pare down loans.

site_title: Trump should show leadership, keep Iran nuclear deal in place
summary: President Donald Trump faces a diplomatic test as he sets a May 12 deadline for US European allies to agree on a supplemental deal to fix issues with the Iran nuclear pact. If an agreement is not reached, the US could withdraw from the deal, potentially leading to a nuclear race in the Middle East and escalating tensions with Iran. Trump has the opportunity to show leadership by keeping the nuclear deal in place, avoiding a costly confrontation with Tehran, and pursuing a strategy to thwart Iran's influence in the region.

site_title: Australian regulator backs tougher penalties after bank inquiry exposés
summary: The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) has backed tougher penalties for companies found guilty of misconduct, including doubling maximum prison terms to 10 years and increasing financial penalties to up to 10% of turnover. This comes after a Royal Commission inquiry into the financial sector exposed widespread wrongdoing, including deception of regulators and financial distress caused by poor advice. The ACCC chairman, Rod Sims, said the current penalties are "tens of millions" and need to be increased to "hundreds of millions" to deter wrongdoing.

site_title: Deliveroo serves up online-only eateries and menus
summary: Deliveroo has introduced virtual food brands and menus exclusively available on its platform, allowing chefs to be more creative and increase revenue for restaurants. Partnering with seven Singapore restaurants, Deliveroo Editions enables restaurants to launch new or complementary cuisines under separate virtual brands, leveraging data analytics and expertise. While experts warn of potential brand dilution, Deliveroo sees the move as a way to create incentives for restaurants to join its platform, moving up the value chain and curating dishes to create a unique virtual brand experience.

site_title: Walmart close to US$12b plus deal for Flipkart
summary: Walmart is close to finalizing a deal to buy a majority stake in Flipkart for at least $12 billion, valuing the Indian e-commerce company at $20 billion. The deal, which is expected to be completed in the next two weeks, would give Walmart a significant foothold in the emerging Indian market. Tiger Global and SoftBank, Flipkart's largest shareholders, are selling their stakes, while Walmart will likely end up with 60-80% of the company. The deal is seen as a strategic move to compete with Amazon in the Indian market, where Walmart faces fewer regulatory hurdles.

site_title: Soft leads make for muted trading session
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed almost flat on Monday, with a 6.16-point gain of 0.17% to 3,579.54. Despite muted trading, analysts remain optimistic about the market, citing the upcoming earnings reports and strong quarterly results from Keppel Corporation and the Singapore Exchange. Phillip Capital has pegged sentiment as "bullish," while KGI Securities analyst Joel Ng praised Keppel's "attractive long-term growth story."

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Changing hands
summary: US stocks open lower following President Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warns of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to H1, while Heathrow Airport plans to increase fees for its £10b upgrade. In Singapore, MAS and PBOC collaborate on green and transition finance. Meanwhile, OCBC appoints Tan Teck Long as its new CEO, replacing a former DBS veteran. The Singapore stock market rallies for the fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data, while Grab's earnings growth is expected to slow in H2, prompting a downgrade from CGSI to 'hold'.

site_title: Switch to smart factory helps JEP do more with less
summary: Singapore precision engineering company JEP Precision Engineering has successfully implemented a "Smart Factory Initiative" to improve efficiency and productivity. The initiative, launched in 2017, includes five projects, including an automated Overall Equipment Effectiveness (OEE) monitoring and analysis system, which has reduced machine breakdowns by 15-40% and idle time by 20%. The company also introduced a Mazak flexible manufacturing system, reducing set-up time and increasing productivity by 25%. JEP's transformation push is attributed to its forward-thinking management and efforts to attract and retain talent, with a focus on digitalization and automation.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: EU probes Apple plan to buy music app
summary: The European Union has launched an in-depth probe of Apple's planned $400 million acquisition of music app Shazam, citing concerns that the deal may reduce consumer choice. The investigation follows a request from several EU states and Norway, which fear Apple could gain access to commercially sensitive data about customers of rival streaming services. The EU will also examine whether Apple's competitors would be harmed if the app were to discontinue links to rival services.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on tech, industrial gains
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by gains in technology and industrial stocks, as investors became more optimistic about a strong earnings season. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.10%, the S&P 500 gained 0.20%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.39%. Rising US bond yields were largely overshadowed by these gains, easing concerns about the market's performance.

site_title: SP Group signs research agreement with S'pore Institute of Technology for Punggol multi-energy micro-grid
summary: SP Group, a Singaporean grid operator, signed a research agreement with the Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT) to develop a multi-energy micro-grid at the SIT's Punggol campus. The project aims to optimize district energy systems, convert waste to renewable energy, and increase energy efficiency. The collaboration will provide a platform for students and researchers to test new technologies and solutions. The agreement is part of Singapore's Energy Grid 2.0 initiative, which focuses on integrating multiple energy sources and adopting new technologies to enhance the country's energy infrastructure.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's stocks closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 7.39 points to 1,880.36. The decline followed a day of losses in Singapore and other regional markets. Losers outnumbered gainers 711 to 216, with a total of 1.94 billion shares traded for RM1.66 billion.

site_title: Olina Lodge sold for S$230.9 million
summary: The Olina Lodge in Singapore's District 10 has been sold for S$230.9 million, 5% above the reserve price of S$220 million. The sale price translates to a land rate of S$1,712 per square foot per plot ratio, with each of the 67 freehold units potentially receiving between S$3 million to S$5 million. The development is within walking distance to several MRT stations and offers panoramic views. The collective sale tender closed on April 19, 2018, after a 28-day period.

site_title: Melvin Poh now DeClout's 2nd largest shareholder
summary: Melvin Poh, founder of Fission Group, has become DeClout's second-largest shareholder after acquiring 78.15 million shares for S$9.2 million. This stake now puts him at 12.19% of the company, second only to founder and executive chairman Vesmond Wong, who holds 12.24%. Poh expressed support for Wong, citing the company's growth potential under his leadership. The move comes as minority shareholders have expressed concerns about Wong's leadership amid a downward share price.

site_title: EQUVO keeps to zero delinquency
summary: EQUVO Pte Ltd, a Singapore-based company, has won the Singapore SME 1000 - Sales/Turnover Growth Excellence Award for Services, ranking 555th in the services sector. The company, which provides lease financing, equipment management, and consulting services for the semiconductor and aviation industries, attributes its success to making necessary changes to align its business. EQUVO has a zero delinquency record and plans to continue growing profitably in the long term while maintaining its commitment to customer satisfaction and employee growth.

images.alt_text: Mr Low says the company will keep to its plans to grow the business more profitably in the long term for its shareholders, build a relevant business for its customers and be a company that its employees love to work for while achieving the first two objectives.

site_title: The company's saving grace
summary: Singapore SMEs are learning the importance of service recovery after a company, ezbuy, faced a major crisis in 2017 when it failed to deliver orders on time, resulting in over 10,000 customers abandoning the platform. The incident highlighted the need for effective customer service and complaint handling. A study found that companies with poor complaint handling scored lower in customer satisfaction, with customers more likely to leave negative comments on social media. To mitigate service failures, companies should decentralize their response strategy, empower frontline staff, and prioritize timely and accurate information.

site_title: Razer proposes to acquire MOL Global at valuation of US$100m, to expand gaming and e-payment business in South-east Asia
summary: Razer proposes to acquire MOL Global, a Malaysian e-payments platform, at a valuation of US$100 million. Razer, a gaming company, aims to expand its e-payment capabilities and accelerate business in South-east Asia. The acquisition will be made through a statutory merger, with Razer acquiring 65.1% of MOL Global's issued share capital. This move will allow Razer to increase its e-payment capabilities and further establish its presence in the region.

site_title: Oil stays below US$69 as rising US drilling counters Opec curbs
summary: Oil prices remain below $69 a barrel as US drilling activity increases, countering Opec's efforts to reduce global supply. US crude output has more than doubled since early February, reaching 10 million barrels per day, while Opec producers aim to maintain output cuts to revive investment in production. Despite Opec's commitment, US President Donald Trump criticized the group for artificially boosting prices, but analysts believe the cuts will support prices in the long term.

site_title: It's a boy!
summary: Kate, wife of UK's Prince William, gave birth to a baby boy on April 23, 2018, the couple's third child and second son. The baby weighed 8 lbs 7oz and Prince William was present for the birth. The royal family, including The Queen, The Duke of Edinburgh, and Prince Harry, have been informed and are delighted with the news. Her Royal Highness and her child are reportedly doing well.

images.alt_text: Kate, wife of UK's Prince William, gave birth to a baby boy on Monday, the couple's third child, her husband's office said.

site_title: Two related companies win commerce-retail SME 1000 awards
summary: Two related companies, UA Sports (SEA) Pte Ltd and Triple Pte Ltd, have won awards at this year's SME 1000 awards in the commerce-retail segment. UA Sports received the Net Profit Growth Excellence Award, ranking 80th in 2018, while Triple Pte Ltd received the Sales/Turnover Growth Excellence Award, ranking 38th in 2018. The awards recognize the companies' high-quality service and growth in the sports and retail industry.

site_title: Ron Sim's R3 fund makes S$2m pre-IPO investment in mm2's Vividthree studio
summary: Ron Sim's R3 Asian Gems fund invests S$2 million in mm2 Asia's Vividthree studio, a virtual reality and visual effects studio, ahead of its potential listing on the Singapore Exchange. The investment will give R3 a two-year mandatory convertible note in Vividthree Holdings, with a 15% discount to the IPO price. If the IPO doesn't happen, noteholders will receive principal plus a 2% annual coupon. This investment is part of R3's focus on supporting fast-growing companies in the region.

site_title: How destructive is Trump of globalisation?
summary: US President Donald Trump's policies have been criticized for exacerbating global instability and harming the global economy. His focus on trade and immigration has led to a rise in tensions with China, with tariffs imposed on each other's imports. The US economy, particularly the "Rust Belt" region, has suffered from job losses and economic discontent, which Trump has exploited to fuel his anti-globalization rhetoric. The consequences of Trump's policies are uncertain, with some predicting a global trade war and increased instability.

site_title: How can boards change the game?
summary: Boards must recalibrate strategies to thrive in the new digital world, prioritizing a fluid and agile mindset over heavy technology investment. Digital transformation is not just about IT, but about innovation and using technology as an enabler. Boards should not be paralyzed by increased cybersecurity risks, but rather incorporate them into risk management frameworks. They should also engage in collaborative relationships with governments and regulatory bodies, and be open to partnerships with startups and peers. The goal remains to increase shareholder value, but metrics for success will shift to include user experience and incremental progress, rather than just return on investment and equity.

images.alt_text: Boards should not be paralysed by the increased exposure to cybersecurity risks that comes with digitalisation.

site_title: Record profits for Singapore's top 1,000 companies
summary: Singapore's top 1,000 companies delivered a record combined profit of S$182.8 billion in 2018, a 10.5% increase from last year, driven by productivity and technology investments. The average profit margin grew to 11.4%, despite a flat turnover performance. In contrast, the top 1,000 small and medium enterprises (SMEs) saw a 11.8% decline in combined turnover and a 17.1% drop in combined profits. The hospitality/food and beverage sector was the best performer among SMEs, with a 12.1% increase in combined turnover. The government is urging companies to innovate and transform to stay competitive in a rapidly changing economy.

site_title: Razer sharpens e-payment focus with full ownership of MOL Global
summary: Razer has proposed to acquire the remaining shares of MOL Global, a South-east Asian virtual gaming credits and e-payment platform, for US$61 million. This acquisition will accelerate Razer's growth in e-payments and enable the company to build a nationwide cashless system in Singapore by 2020, as proposed by CEO Tan Min-Liang. The deal will also expand Razer's business in the region and give it access to MOL's offline-to-online payment model, which has enabled game companies to monetize their games and digital content in South-east Asia.

site_title: Body of Iran shah possibly found: heritage officials
summary: Iran's heritage committee announced the discovery of a mummified body at the site of former Shah Reza Shah Pahlavi's tomb, sparking interest over the possible rediscovery of the long-lost corpse. The tomb was destroyed in 1979 by Islamic authorities following the revolution. The discovery has raised questions about the authorities' efforts to erase memories of the Pahlavi monarchy.

site_title: St Michael's Condo to be launched for collective sale for at least S$112m
summary: ST Michael's Condominium, located near Boon Keng MRT, is launching for collective sale with an expected minimum price of S$112 million. The 60-unit freehold site has a land area of 35,665.4 sq ft and could be redeveloped into a site with 132 apartments. Unit owners can expect to receive between S$1.38 million and S$2 million. The site's high development baseline and central location are expected to attract strong interest from developers. The tender closes on May 23.

site_title: UK says social media firms 'turning blind eye' to children, threatens new rules
summary: UK Health Minister Jeremy Hunt threatens to impose new regulations on social media firms unless they do more to protect young people using their services. Hunt claims firms are "turning a blind eye" to the impact of social media on children's well-being. Firms including Facebook and Google respond by saying they are committed to protecting children and working on new features. Hunt gives the companies an end-of-April deadline to come up with measures to tackle cyberbullying and online time limits.

site_title: Australia competition regulator flags scrutiny of Uber Eats
summary: Australia's competition regulator plans to scrutinize contracts between Uber Eats and restaurants, amid allegations that Uber charges restaurants for late deliveries, despite being responsible for the issue. Several restaurateurs claim the contracts leave them liable for late deliveries, with Uber charged for the service. The regulator will examine the contracts to ensure fair practices and protect consumers.

site_title: Europe: Shares falter as UBS disappoints
summary: European shares fell 0.2% on Monday as UBS disappointed investors with its first-quarter earnings, which fell short of expectations. The bank's shares dropped 3.8% despite beating analysts' estimates. Consumer staples stocks, including Nestle and Unilever, took the biggest hits due to rising US Treasury yields. M&A news also impacted shares, with Temenos gaining 4.9% after rejecting a bid for Fidessa. The disappointing earnings report put pressure on the pan-European STOXX 600, starting a heavy week of earnings.

site_title: Indonesian motorcycle taxi drivers protest low online tariffs
summary: Hundreds of Indonesian motorcycle taxi drivers protested outside parliament in Jakarta, demanding an end to low online fares and tighter regulation of ride-hailing companies like Grab and Go-Jek. The drivers, who claim to be part of the national workforce, briefly disrupted traffic with around 1,500 drivers wearing green jackets and helmets. They called for "legal and social protection" for online "ojek" drivers, highlighting concerns over the companies' impact on their livelihoods. The protest highlights growing tensions between ride-hailing companies and the drivers they employ.

site_title: Park House launched for en bloc sale for S$308m
summary: Park House, a 56-unit apartment and four-shop complex in Orchard, Singapore, has been launched for en bloc sale with a guide price of S$308 million. Owners will receive at least S$5 million and S$6.65 million, respectively, based on their unit sizes. The site has an allowable plot ratio of 2.8 and is close to several amenities. Developers are expected to bid, with at least eight to 10 tender bids anticipated, with a closing date of May 31.

site_title: Nafta ministers set to meet again amid intensified push for deal
summary: US, Canada, and Mexico senior trade officials will meet in Washington to intensify Nafta negotiations, aiming for a deal in the next few weeks. The talks will focus on automotive rules, agriculture, and dispute settlement mechanisms. Mexican Economy Minister Ildefonso Guajardo and Canadian Minister Chrystia Freeland reported progress, with Mexico also securing a deal with the EU on a 17-year-old free-trade agreement. US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer has set a May deadline for a deal, but Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau remains cautious, warning that progress doesn't guarantee a deal.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust posts 2.4% rise in Q4 DPU
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust reported a 2.4% year-on-year rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.95 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter ended March 31, 2018. Gross revenue and net property income rose 2.9% to S$90.39 million and S$67.88 million, respectively, driven by the contribution from a build-to-suit project for HP Singapore and a 40% interest in US data centres. The trust's total assets under management grew to S$4.32 billion, up from S$3.75 billion in 2017.

site_title: Oceanus partners Shaw Investment Holdings, Chinese construction firm to enhance food security
summary: Oceanus Group has partnered Shaw Investment Holdings and China Construction Seventh Engineering Division to invest $500 million in global aquaculture projects, addressing food security concerns worldwide. The partnership aims to capitalize on growing aquaculture opportunities globally. Oceanus is also developing its Oceanus Aquapolis City project, a sea-based hi-tech aquaponics farm in Singapore, which will be a solution to food security and safety in Singapore and beyond. The project will be environmentally friendly, using hydroponics and aquaculture farming technologies.

site_title: Abe Cabinet approval rating slumps to 39% in new poll
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Cabinet approval rating has dropped to 39% in a recent nationwide opinion poll, marking its third consecutive decline since the last survey. This represents a 15 percentage point decrease from the previous survey. The latest figure is the second-lowest since Abe's Cabinet was launched.

site_title: YuuZoo board calls for EGM to approve proposed capital structure changes
summary: YuuZoo Corporation, an online media company under investigation by the Singapore police and Commercial Affairs Department, is seeking shareholder approval for a proposed restructuring. The move aims to change its capital structure from par value to non-par value shares, allowing for more flexibility in issuing new shares. The company's directors have called for an extraordinary general meeting on May 16 to vote on the proposed changes, which include moving the company's registration from Bermuda to the British Virgin Islands.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Sabana Reit Q1 gross revenue falls 4.4%; DPU unchanged at 0.88 Singapore cent
summary: Sabana Reit's Q1 gross revenue fell 4.4% to S$21.0 million, mainly due to lower contributions from some properties. Distribution per unit (DPU) remained unchanged at 0.88 Singapore cent. Despite a 0.8% decrease in income available for distribution, the trust's DPU was maintained. The trust attributed the results to reduced property expenses. Sabana Reit expects rent reversions for 2018 to remain negative, with a vacancy rate of 11.1% island-wide. The trust plans to boost occupancy and review non-core assets for divestment.

site_title: ST Engineering's Chinese unit files for bankruptcy after failing to dispose of assets
summary: ST Engineering's Chinese subsidiary, JHK, has filed for bankruptcy in Zhenjiang city, China, after failing to dispose of assets.
