The joint venture, which ended production in 2016, was unable to secure buyers due to weak demand for industrial properties. ST Engineering has fully written down its investments, with a one-off charge of S$61 million, and expects the bankruptcy to have minimal impact on its financials. The company cited operating losses and failure to secure buyers as reasons for the bankruptcy.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Professor defends role in Cambridge Analytica data scandal
summary: Aleksandr Kogan, a University of Cambridge lecturer, defended his role in the Cambridge Analytica data scandal, stating he "never heard a word" from Facebook about misuse of data. Kogan's app, This Is Your Digital Life, harvested data from 50 million Facebook users, which was then passed to Cambridge Analytica to aid Donald Trump's election. Kogan claimed Facebook framed him as a "rogue app" and that the social network failed to enforce its developer policy. He apologized for the data mining, saying the public believed their data was being sold and shared.

images.alt_text: The psychologist behind an app that harvested data from 50 million Facebook users defended his role in the scandal Sunday, saying he "never heard a word" of opposition from the social media giant.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's inflation remained muted in March, with consumer prices rising 0.2% compared to the preceding month. The cost of food and services rose more slowly than expected. Noble Group rejected a nomination of five non-executive directors by substantial shareholder Goldilocks, citing the use of a nominee account. A freehold commercial site at the former New World Amusement Park was launched for sale, priced at S$13.5 million. Meanwhile, Singapore shares closed up 0.17% on Monday, while Halcyon Agri completed the acquisition of Indonesian rubber factories for S$86.75 million.

site_title: OCBC Securities appoints former policeman Dennis Hong as new MD
summary: OCBC Bank has appointed Dennis Hong as managing director of its wholly-owned OCBC Securities, effective May 1, 2018. Hong, a former policeman, succeeds Raymond Chee, who will become general manager of OCBC Bank's New York Agency. Hong has served as deputy managing director since March 2018 and brings 18 months of structured training from OCBC's postgraduate management program. OCBC Securities has seen significant growth under Chee's leadership, and Hong is expected to continue this momentum, with the brokerage's market share of SGX equity trades increasing by 30% over the past six years.

site_title: Singapore shares close up by 0.17% on Monday
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.17% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,579.54. The bourse saw 1.57 billion shares traded, with Keppel Corporation and Venture Corporation leading the gainers. Losers outperformed gainers 215 to 156. Ezion Holdings topped the actives list, while Off the index, Ezion Holdings fell 1.73%. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data release.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: YuuZoo CFO resigns due to 'family emergency'
summary: YuuZoo Corporation's CFO, Kevin Haigeng Wang, has resigned due to a family emergency, according to a Singapore Exchange filing. This comes about half a year after his appointment in October 2017. The company is currently under investigation by the Commercial Affairs Department for possible breaches of the Securities and Futures Act, following office raids and the chairman's passport surrender.

site_title: HK: Shares end lower, led by tech stocks over trade spat worries
summary: Hong Kong shares ended 0.5% lower on Monday, led by technology stocks, amid concerns over the Sino-US trade dispute affecting Chinese telecom equipment maker ZTE. The Hang Seng index closed at 30,254.40, while China's A-shares traded at a 22.67% premium over Hong Kong-listed H-shares. The decline follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and follows new US threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: EU suspects tax fraud at China's new gateway to Europe
summary: European Union and Italian authorities are investigating suspected widespread tax fraud by Chinese criminal gangs using Greece's Piraeus port, a major gateway to Europe. The suspected scam, linked to China's Belt and Road infrastructure project, is estimated to have cost Italy tens of millions of euros in unpaid VAT. Chinese-owned firms are allegedly importing goods, often counterfeit, and underreporting their value to avoid import duties and VAT. The investigation is ongoing, with no evidence of wrongdoing by Piraeus port authorities.

site_title: Billions to rebuild post-quake Nepal being misdirected
summary: Billions of dollars pledged by international donors to rebuild Nepal after a devastating 7.8-magnitude earthquake in 2015 are being misdirected towards constructing new homes instead of retrofitting existing ones. Only 15% of eligible families have taken advantage of a US$2.1 billion subsidy program, with many opting to build smaller, quake-proof homes at a huge cost. Experts estimate that up to 500,000 homes could be retrofitted, but the government only approved retrofitting midway through last year. The effort is being hindered by bureaucracy, confusion, and a lack of awareness among quake victims.

site_title: Philips Q1 results beat estimates on strong China growth
summary: Dutch health technology company Philips reported a 15% increase in core profit to 344 million euros in Q1 2018, beating expectations. The company's sales grew 5% and new orders rose 10%, driven by strong demand for high-end hospital equipment in China and the US. Growth was strongest in the diagnosis and treatment division, with a 9% increase in sales. Philips reaffirmed its target of 4-6% sales growth for the year.

site_title: GM Korea, union reach tentative wage deal
summary: General Motors' South Korean unit, GM Korea, has reached a tentative wage deal with its labour union, meeting a key condition to prevent bankruptcy. The deal comes after GM Korea's board delayed a decision to file for bankruptcy protection. The agreement involves wage concessions from the union, which was a key requirement for GM to avoid filing for bankruptcy. The US automaker had sought wage concessions, government funding, and incentives to save its remaining three South Korean factories.

site_title: China targets 100 per cent clean power for Xiongan New Area near Beijing
summary: China aims to power its new Xiongan New Area, near Beijing, with 100% clean electricity as part of President Xi Jinping's vision to create a sustainable city and reduce carbon emissions by 2030. The Xiongan New Area, spanning three counties, will have a grid-planning system and infrastructure development covering 100 square kilometers initially, with plans to expand to 200 square kilometers and 2,000 square kilometers. The goal is part of China's ambitious plan to remake the region into a technology and innovation hub.

site_title: UBS's freshly-combined global wealth management unit disappoints
summary: UBS's newly combined global wealth management unit underperformed in the first quarter, missing analyst estimates and falling short of revenue targets. The division's profit before tax was 1.1 billion francs, just below estimates, and net new money was 19 billion Swiss francs, slightly lower than the previous year. The investment bank, however, beat expectations with a pretax profit of 589 million francs, driven by gains in equities trading and advising. The bank's shares fell 4.4% to their lowest in three months, and CEO Sergio Ermotti has vowed to refocus on growth and return capital to shareholders.

site_title: Asbestos found on St John's Island, more than half of the island sealed
summary: Authorities on St John's Island in Singapore sealed off more than half of the island after finding asbestos in construction debris. The discovery was made on April 16, prompting a safety precautionary measure. The affected areas, including the campsite and holiday bungalow, were closed, and two long-term residents moved back to the mainland. Asbestos removal and construction works are expected to be completed by mid-2019, with visitors able to access neighboring Lazarus Island.

site_title: German private sector outlook deteriorates in April
summary: Germany's private sector growth slowed to a five-month low in April, according to a survey by IHS Markit. New orders for businesses declined to an 18-month low, but the overall Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rose to a two-month high of 55.3. The slowdown in new orders growth raised concerns, but the data also showed a solid start to the second quarter. Economists expect the German economy to grow 0.5% in the first quarter, and the employment sub-index showed job creation rebounding to its highest level since January.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,581.86, up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Monday afternoon with the Straits Times Index advancing 8.48 points, or 0.2%, to 3,581.86. The index was down marginally by 4.14 points, or 0.12%, at the midday break. 150 stocks gained, while 147 lost value. Trading volume reached 819.2 million shares worth S$538.6 million.

site_title: Prince William's wife Kate taken to hospital to give birth to third child
summary: Prince William's wife Kate, the Duchess of Cambridge, was taken to hospital in London on April 23, 2018, in the early stages of labor, expecting her third child. The baby will be the fifth in line to the British throne. Kate, 36, was accompanied by Prince William and given care by a trusted team of obstetricians, including Guy Thorpe-Beeston and Alan Farthing. The hospital is a mile from the palace where they reside.

site_title: There are no chickens on Chicken Street; now there are no customers either
summary: Kabul's Chicken Street, once a popular destination for foreign visitors, has lost its main customers due to security concerns. The street, known for its eclectic mix of shops selling jewelry, antiques, and Oriental rugs, has seen a decline in foreign visitors and sales. The security situation in Afghanistan, including suicide bombings and kidnappings, has driven away shoppers, with some shops reporting zero patrons. Many merchants have been forced to close or relocate, including Herat Carpets, which moved to Istanbul due to security concerns. The street's decline has also led to proposals to rename it, but locals argue that the name "Chicken Street" is an integral part of the area's identity.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks ease on foreign selloff; won edges down
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index decreased 0.09% to 2,474.10, while the won slipped 0.16% to 1,069 per US dollar. North Korea-exposed shares initially surged after Pyongyang announced the suspension of nuclear and missile tests, but later showed mixed movements. The decline in the KOSPI index was partly due to a foreign selloff, with bond yields rising.

site_title: ThaiBev representatives join Sabeco beer board: source
summary: Thai Beverage representatives joined Vietnam's Sabeco beer board after shareholders approved their addition, following a delay due to complicated procedures. The move comes as ThaiBev, which holds a 50% stake in Sabeco, had complained about the initial rejection of its proposed board members. ThaiBev acquired a 50% stake in Sabeco in December for $4.84 billion, and one of the new board members is Singaporean Koh Poh Tiong, who is also adviser to Fraser and Neave Limited, a company owned by Thai magnate Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi.

site_title: Lenovo drives China tech slump as fallout from ZTE ban spreads
summary: Lenovo's shares plummeted 3.4% in Hong Kong, its lowest level since 2009, amid China tech slump. The US ban on ZTE Corp. has spread concerns about the technology sector, with investors worried about companies doing business in the US. Lenovo is not facing a ban, but market sentiment remains negative, with short interest surging. Chinese hardware makers Luxshare Precision Industry Co. and Han's Laser Technology Industry Group Co. also fell over 7% due to concerns over global smartphone demand.

site_title: Remittance payments hit record in 2017: World Bank
summary: Remittances to low- and middle-income countries reached a record $466 billion in 2017, with a 8.5% increase from 2016. Growth was driven by Europe, Russia, and the US. The top recipients were India ($69 billion), China ($64 billion), and the Philippines ($33 billion). However, the average cost of sending $200 remains high, at 7.1%, with sub-Saharan Africa being the most expensive region. The World Bank calls for simplifying the remittance process and reducing costs to benefit families.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end lower
summary: Tokyo stocks ended lower on Monday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index dropping 0.33% to 22,088.04, following a decline on Wall Street. Investors digested North Korea's pledge to halt nuclear tests and intercontinental missile launches. The broader Topix index remained flat. This move comes amid global market uncertainty, with US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: Britain says web firms "turning blind eye" to children, threatens regulation
summary: Britain's health minister Jeremy Hunt threatened to impose new regulations on social media firms unless they do more to protect young people using their services. Hunt accused web firms of "turning a blind eye" to the effect of social media on children's well-being. Google and Facebook have committed to protecting children and working on new features, while Twitter and other firms have not commented. Hunt gave the companies an end-of-April deadline to come up with measures to tackle cyberbullying and control online time.

site_title: Amazon to double down on groceries; foray deeper into fresh produce in India
summary: Amazon plans to double its focus on groceries and household products in India, with an aim to have these categories account for over half of its business in the next five years. The company currently offers groceries via Amazon Pantry and Amazon Now, with plans to expand into fresh produce. Amazon expects to deliver groceries to customers within two hours, similar to its US-based AmazonFresh service. With India's e-commerce market projected to grow to $200 billion in a decade, Amazon is looking to capitalize on the opportunity, with plans to woo new clients with product exchange and staggered payment offerings.

site_title: Freehold commercial site at former New World Amusement Park launched for sale
summary: A freehold commercial site at the former New World Amusement Park along Jalan Besar Road has been launched for sale via an expression of interest (EOI) exercise. The indicative guide price is S$13.5 million, reflecting a unit land rate of $1,392 per square feet per plot ratio (psf ppr). The site, occupying 3,230 sq ft, is expected to yield a blended break-even of S$1,925 psf. Potential uses include F&B services, office, co-working, and retail, and foreigners are eligible to purchase. The EOI exercise will close on May 30.

site_title: Singapore consumer prices edge up 0.2% in March, below economist expectations
summary: Singapore's consumer prices rose 0.2% in March, below economist expectations of 0.5%. Food and services inflation slowed, with food inflation dipping to 1.4% and services inflation easing to 1.4%. Core inflation, which strips out accommodation and private road transport costs, eased to 1.5%. Despite a brighter global economic outlook, inflation is expected to remain moderate, with core inflation forecast to rise gradually to the upper half of the central bank's 1-2% range.

site_title: Australian shares end higher on financials, materials; NZ falls
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% on Monday, driven by gains in financials and materials. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 5,886.0, with financial stocks up 0.7% and materials stocks climbing 0.9% on firmer commodities prices. Top lenders like Commonwealth Bank jumped 0.9-1.4%, while miners BHP and Rio Tinto rose 1.2-1.4%. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index declined 0.2% due to losses in dairy firm a2 Milk Company.

site_title: Australia's Myer names ex-House of Fraser head as new CEO; shares jump
summary: Australia's Myer Holdings has appointed John King, former head of British retailer House of Fraser, as its new CEO. The move comes after the company posted its biggest half-yearly loss since listing and amid calls for a board revamp. Shares rose 5.6% following the announcement, despite Myer's struggles against Amazon.com and other online competitors, with the company's market capitalization shrinking to less than a tenth of its 2009 listing value.

site_title: MPA inks MOU to develop 'future-ready' seafarers for Singapore's maritime sector
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with industry partners to develop a future-ready pool of seafarers. The tripartite agreement aims to equip seafarers with skills to cope with digitalisation and automation in the maritime sector. The MOU focuses on three areas: identifying new competencies, enhancing current training, and developing Singapore as a maritime training hub. The agreement also launched a new Specialist Diploma course in Maritime Superintendency to facilitate the transition of experienced seafarers to onshore jobs.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars at multi-week lows; PMIs, inflation data in focus
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell to multi-week lows amid rising inflation expectations in the US. The Australian dollar traded at US$0.7676, down 1.3% last week, while the New Zealand dollar slipped to US$0.7199, its weakest since April 3. Investors await surveys on global manufacturing and Australian consumer price data, which may influence interest rate decisions.

site_title: Walmart is said to be close to US$12 billion-plus deal for Flipkart
summary: Walmart is close to finalizing a deal to buy a majority stake in Flipkart, India's leading e-commerce company, for at least $12 billion. The deal, which could be completed in the next two weeks, would give Walmart a 60-80% stake in the company. Major investors, including Tiger Global and SoftBank, are on board with the sale, while Flipkart's founders are expected to lead the business after the purchase. The deal would give Walmart a foothold in the emerging Indian e-commerce market and bolster its presence in the country, where Amazon is also expanding.

site_title: Euro-Area economy stays in lower gear as order growth weakens
summary: The euro-area economy maintained a steady pace in April, with a composite Purchasing Managers' Index remaining unchanged at 55.2. Growth in services picked up, but manufacturing slowed to its weakest in over a year. Despite a slowdown in economic momentum, the euro-zone economy is expected to continue growing albeit at a slower pace, with European Central Bank officials advocating for prudence in normalizing monetary stimulus.

site_title: Australian shares rise led by financials; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to 5,893.7, led by a 0.8% gain in financial stocks, despite concerns over potential penalties for the 'Big Four' major banks. Materials stocks also gained due to stronger commodities prices. This follows a 0.2% decline on Friday.

site_title: Standard Life no longer CityDev substantial shareholder; sold S$4.7m of shares at S$12.90 each
summary: Standard Life Aberdeen sold S$4.7m of City Developments shares at S$12.90 each, reducing its stake to 4.9742% from 5.0141%. The sale marked the fund manager's loss of substantial shareholder status, as investors with stakes below 5% do not have to disclose changes in their interests. City Developments shares closed at S$12.65, down 0.08% from the previous day's close.

site_title: China's 'men only' job culture slammed in new report
summary: A new report by Human Rights Watch has criticized leading Chinese firms, including Alibaba, for perpetuating gender discrimination in job adverts, with many ads stating a preference for male applicants or requesting women to be "trim" and "aesthetically pleasing". The report found that such discrimination contributes to a drop in the female workforce and a widening gender pay gap, despite being illegal in China. The report's findings were based on over 36,000 job advertisements posted between 2013 and 2018, and were met with responses from companies, including Alibaba, stating they would conduct stricter reviews of recruitment ads to ensure equality.

site_title: A-Smart partners Google to bring Google Home to more Singapore households
summary: A-Smart Holdings partners Google Asia Pacific to bring Google Home and Google Home Mini smart speakers to more Singaporean homes, aiming to enhance smart living using Google technologies. The devices will be integrated into local housing and property development projects, as well as public outreach programs. The partnership also includes collaborations with real estate developers, contractors, and public organisations to promote the devices and their benefits. The Google Home and Home Mini will be powered by Google Assistant, understanding Singlish terms and enabling voice-activated tasks and connections to other smart devices.

site_title: Remittance payments hit record in 2017: World Bank
summary: Remittance payments reached a record $466 billion in 2017, a 8.5% increase from 2016, driven by growth in Europe, Russia, and the US. The top remittance recipients were India, China, the Philippines, Mexico, Nigeria, and Egypt. However, the global average cost of sending $200 remained high at 7.1%, with sub-Saharan Africa being the most expensive region. The World Bank calls for simplifying the remittance process to reduce costs and increase efficiency, citing the need for more efficient technology.

site_title: BHP, Vale given extension to settle Brazil mine disaster claim
summary: BHP and Vale have been granted an additional 66 days by a Brazilian court to negotiate a settlement for the Samarco mine disaster claim. The collapse in 2015 resulted in 19 deaths and a 155 billion reals (S$59.8 billion) claim for clean-up costs and damages. The companies had initially reported a US$210 million charge related to the disaster. The extension brings the negotiation deadline to June 25, with significant progress made on social and environmental recovery programs.

site_title: Deliveroo launches second delivery kitchen in Singapore, new self-collection service
summary: Deliveroo launched its second delivery kitchen in Singapore, a 3,657 sq ft space at CT Hub 2 in Lavender, housing seven restaurants including Kurry Korner and Wolf Burgers. This is more than 1.5 times larger than the company's first location at Katong. The new kitchen offers a self-collection service, allowing customers to pick up their orders.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.98 points to 1,890.73. The market saw 23.89 million lots traded worth RM7.25 million, with 79 gainers outnumbering 59 losers.

site_title: Halcyon Agri completes purchase of 4 Indonesian rubber factories for lowered S$86.8m
summary: Halcyon Agri Corporation completed the acquisition of four Indonesian rubber factories for S$86.75 million, lower than the initially indicated price of S$105.3 million. The deal, which was subject to due diligence findings, involved the purchase of PT Sumber Djantin and PT Sumber Alam, two companies that own four crumb rubber factories in West Kalimantan, Indonesia. The acquisition had been expected to increase Halcyon Agri's net asset value and net tangible asset per share.

site_title: Record US wage gains gnawing at corporate profits: survey
summary: US corporate profits are being eroded by record increases in wages and materials costs, despite robust sales, according to a survey of business economists. Sales continued to grow, but profit margins slowed in the first quarter of 2018 due to mounting price pressures. The survey found 65% of respondents had not changed hiring plans following the tax cuts and 68% following the tariffs imposed by President Trump. The materials cost index jumped to 50, its highest level in seven years, and the Federal Reserve is poised to raise interest rates up to three more times in 2018.

site_title: China cyberspies targeted Japanese firms for North Korea secrets
summary: Chinese hackers, believed to be part of the APT10 group, targeted Japanese defense companies between September and October 2017 to gather information on Tokyo's policy toward resolving the North Korean nuclear impasse. The attacks used spear-phishing emails and included lines of text mocking security researchers. FireEye, a cybersecurity firm, suspects the motive behind the intrusion attempt is gaining insider information to inform North Korea's nuclear policy. China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs did not comment on the allegations.

site_title: Bahrain's Gulf Air looks to Middle East routes in path to profitability
summary: Bahrain's Gulf Air aims to increase passenger growth and turn around its loss-making status by focusing on Middle East routes. The airline plans to add 8 destinations in the region this year, targeting over 60 destinations by 2023. Deputy CEO Waleed Abdulhameed al-Alawi said the airline is meeting its internal targets and expects to carry 5.5 million passengers this year. Gulf Air aims to boost origin and destination traffic by attracting tourists to Bahrain, leveraging the country's Formula One grand prix and heritage tourism. The airline's fleet will expand to 35 aircraft this year.

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB maintains 'buy' on SGX; CIMB, OCBC upgrade to 'add'
summary: Banks RHB, CIMB, and OCBC maintain positive views on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) following its strong third-quarter earnings, with a 21% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$100 million. Analysts expect a total return of 12.4% and a fair value estimate of S$8.22. SGX's derivatives revenue surged 20% year-on-year, and new products to be launched in June are expected to boost the exchange's prospects.

site_title: Noble rejects Goldilocks' nomination of 5 directors, cites use of nominee account
summary: NOBLE Group has rejected a nomination of five non-executive directors by Abu Dhabi-based investment fund Goldilocks at its upcoming annual general meeting on April 30. The rejection is based on Goldilocks not being a member of the company due to holding shares through a depository agent, contrary to Noble's by-laws and Bermuda law. Noble stated that Goldilocks is actually listed as a member through The Central Depository (CDP), not the nominee account.

site_title: These seeds will captivate you whether you're a gardener or not
summary: A new book, "The Book of Seeds," edited by Paul Smith, showcases the genetic information contained in seeds from around the world. The book highlights seeds from over 500 botanic gardens in 96 countries, many of which are threatened. It covers seeds from common spices to unusual specimens, and includes information on seed conservation, storage, and plant diversity. The book aims to raise awareness about the importance of preserving Earth's plant diversity, which is threatened by population growth and climate change. The seeds themselves have fascinating journeys, with some drifting continents and others remaining dormant for thousands of years.

site_title: China says many Chinese casualties in North Korea bus crash
summary: Chinese tourists were involved in a major bus accident in North Korea, resulting in a significant number of casualties, according to Chinese state media and the government. Chinese visitors account for approximately 80% of foreign tourists to North Korea, generating about $44 million in annual revenue. Chinese diplomats have rushed to the scene in North Hwanghae province, but the exact number of casualties remains unknown.

site_title: Axes, sunglasses and now a summit at Korea's DMZ
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un is set to meet South Korean President Moon Jae-in at the Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) in a historic summit. The meeting, the first to take place south of the border, comes ahead of a planned meeting between Kim and US President Donald Trump. The DMZ, which has divided the two Koreas since the 1950-53 Korean War, is a frequent destination for tourists and US presidents seeking to symbolically demonstrate Washington's commitment to defend Seoul. The summit aims to overcome decades of enmity and mistrust, with North Korea proclaiming itself the winner of the conflict.

site_title: Local firms fly Singapore flag at world's largest industrial tech show in Germany
summary: 19 local Singapore firms will showcase their advanced manufacturing products and services at the Hannover Messe fair in Germany from April 23-27, under the first Singapore Pavilion. Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran will lead a delegation and deliver speeches at the Germany-Singapore Business Forum and Asean Forum 2018. The event aims to promote business and capability partnerships, and deepen regional connectivity, especially in the digital economy.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall on foreign selling, North Korea-related shares rally
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 0.18% on Monday due to foreign selling, despite a boost from shares related to inter-Korea cooperation projects. Shares of companies with exposure to North Korea surged 22% and 5% after Pyongyang announced the suspension of nuclear and missile tests and the abolition of a nuclear test site. The Korean won weakened, while bond yields rose, and the Kospi is up 0.4% so far this year.

site_title: Alibaba gets its smart assistant into Chinese Mercedes, Audis
summary: Alibaba has partnered with Daimler AG, Volkswagen AG, and Volvo to integrate its digital assistant, Tmall Genie, into Chinese Mercedes-Benzes, Audis, and Volvos. The move aims to popularize voice-controlled services for 450 million-plus Alibaba users, including shopping and home security. Tmall Genie can perform tasks such as checking vehicle conditions and providing navigation. Alibaba's AI Labs is working on integrating the AliGenie platform into vehicles' operating software, enabling voice commands and entertainment features. This partnership joins over 100 brands that Alibaba has partnered with for the technology.

site_title: The rich are betting they can buy their way to a longer life
summary: Wealthy individuals are betting on living longer by spending more on healthcare and other services. A UBS Financial Services survey found that 53% of wealthy investors expect to live to 100, with 91% making financial changes due to increased life expectancy. Those with $1 million to $2 million in net worth are willing to give up a third of their fortune for an extra decade of life, while those with over $50 million are willing to part with nearly half. Despite this, rich Americans are more pessimistic about reaching 100 years old, with only 30% expecting to do so.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell at the open on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 0.22% to 30,352.05. This follows losses from the end of last week, primarily due to technology firms. The Shanghai Composite Index also fell 0.26%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index declined marginally.

site_title: Vatican's Sistine Chapel hosts first live online concert
summary: The Vatican's Sistine Chapel hosted its first live online concert, featuring Scottish composer James MacMillan's "Stabat Mater" performed by The Sixteen and Britten Sinfonia. The concert was streamed over the internet and attended by 300 people in the chapel. The event marked a digital milestone for the iconic sacred space, which attracts six million visitors annually. MacMillan described the performance as a "very special privilege" and praised the chapel's exceptional acoustics, saying it was an "emotionally charged experience." The Genesis Foundation commissioned the piece to support young artistic talent.

site_title: China Jinjiang Environment to issue 214m shares at 50 S cents apiece to raise S$107m
summary: China Jinjiang Environment Holding Company (CJE) will issue 214 million new shares to Harvest Environmental Investment Fund SP at S$0.50 apiece, raising approximately S$107 million. The funds will be used to upgrade eight waste-to-energy facilities in China, increasing capacity by 5,000 tonnes per day. The deal is expected to improve gearing and enhance borrowing capacity, while diversifying financial resources. The proposed subscription is conditional on regulatory approvals and may reduce earnings per share.

site_title: Toshiba weighs chip-unit options with deadline out of reach
summary: Toshiba is likely to miss its May 1 deadline to sell its memory chips business to a Bain Capital-led group due to regulatory hurdles. Chinese regulators are conducting a third review of the deal, which may lead Toshiba to consider alternative options that could fetch a higher price for the unit, potentially worth $22-24 billion. Toshiba shares rose 5.3% on the news, and the company's CEO, Nobuaki Kurumatani, has warned that if the deal falls apart, the company may re-negotiate terms or consider an initial public offering.

site_title: Gold slips to 2-week low as rising bond yields support US dollar
summary: Gold prices dropped to a 2-week low due to rising US bond yields supporting the US dollar. Spot gold fell 0.1% to $1,333.20 per ounce, while US gold futures declined 0.2% to $1,335.50 per ounce. The dollar index rose 0.1% as yields on 10-year Treasuries reached their highest level since January 2014. The Federal Reserve Governor expressed confidence in the US economy's ability to handle further interest rate increases, and US interest rates futures fell as traders anticipated potential rate hikes.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Monday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.1% lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index falling 4.75 points to 3,568.63. About 53.2 million shares worth S$112.9 million changed hands. Noble Group rose, while Ezion and OCBC Bank were among other active counters. Gainers outnumbered losers 64 to 52, with the market awaiting upcoming GDP data.

site_title: Wealthy Australia developer guilty of ex-business partner's murder
summary: A millionaire Australian property developer, Michael McGurk, has been found guilty of ordering the murder of his former business associate, Ron Medich, who was shot and killed in front of his son in 2009. McGurk, 45, was found guilty of directing the killing and intimidating his wife. The verdict marks the end of a nearly a decade-long trial, with Medich having pleaded not guilty to the charges. McGurk's conviction brings closure to the family of the victim, who was gunned down outside his Sydney home in 2009.

site_title: Paraguay's business-friendly Colorado Party keeps presidency
summary: Paraguay's Colorado Party candidate Mario Abdo won the presidential election with 46.49% of the vote, defeating center-left candidate Efrain Alegre by a margin of 3.77%. Abdo, a former senator, campaigned on an anti-corruption platform and promises to maintain pro-business policies, including low-tax policies aimed at stimulating foreign investment and agricultural production. The election result is seen as a continuation of the country's pro-business policies, which have been in place for five years.

images.alt_text: The country's elections authority said Mario Abdo, a 46-year-old former senator who campaigned on an anti-corruption platform, had an "irreversible" advantage over his main rival, Efrain Alegre, a lawyer from the centre-left GANAR coalition.

site_title: Google launching Android chat service to replace SMS
summary: Google is launching Android Chat, a new chat service to replace SMS, offering advanced features such as high-resolution photos, videos, and GIFs, read receipts, and typing indicators. The service, which will run on Android phones through partnerships with carriers, is a strategic retreat for Google, which has struggled to create a dedicated chat app. The service uses the Rich Communications Services (RCS) standard, which is expected to be used by 3 billion people by 2020, and will not be end-to-end encrypted, raising privacy concerns.

site_title: GIC to invest US$100m in Ping An's Good Doctor US$1.1b IPO
summary: Ping An Good Doctor, a Chinese online healthcare platform, raised up to US$1.1 billion in its Hong Kong initial public offering, attracting cornerstone investors including GIC and Khazanah Nasional Bhd. The platform, a unit of China's largest insurer by market value, is offering 160 million shares at HK$50.80 to HK$54.80 apiece. Seven cornerstone investors agreed to buy US$550 million of stock, with GIC and Canada Pension Plan Investment Board each investing US$100 million. The IPO aims to price on April 26 and begin trading on May 4.

site_title: ANZ to book A$632m charge on wealth business sales
summary: ANZ Banking Group is set to book a loss of A$632 million on the sale of two wealth businesses, OnePath pensions and investments, and life insurance, due to future separation and transaction costs. The loss includes A$355 million in costs and A$50 million in legal costs related to the Royal Commission inquiry into the Australian financial sector. ANZ will report its half-year results on May 1, citing uncertainty over the inquiry's outcome and impact on the bank or broader industry.

site_title: Spike in new, unknown Asia Twitter accounts sparks bot fears
summary: A surge in new, anonymous Twitter accounts across Southeast and East Asia has raised concerns of US-style mass social media manipulation. Many accounts, created in batches by mystery operators, have been following prominent Twitter users in the region, sparking fears of bot activity. Experts believe the accounts may be fake, and some have linked the phenomenon to potential election interference in countries such as Cambodia, Malaysia, and Indonesia. Twitter has launched an investigation, but many experts remain unconvinced, warning that the presence of fake accounts poses a threat to the platform's integrity.

site_title: Asia: Stocks subdued by rising yields, earnings deluge
summary: Asian stocks opened in a subdued manner on Monday, weighed down by rising yields and a surge in corporate earnings. Investors were cautious ahead of US bond yields approaching historic highs, which had triggered market volatility in the past. Oil prices edged down, but remained near their highest levels since 2014. The dollar strengthened against the yen, while the euro remained steady. Investors await surveys on global manufacturing and the European Central Bank's policy meeting on Thursday.

site_title: Britain may regulate young people's use of social media: minister
summary: Britain's health minister Jeremy Hunt threatened to impose new regulations on social media firms to protect young people, accusing them of "turning a blind eye" to the negative impact of social media on children's well-being. The government has set an April deadline for firms to come up with measures to tackle cyberbullying and limit screen time for youngsters. Hunt expressed concerns over the lack of effective measures to protect children from social media's harmful effects, despite some firms introducing features to help parents set limits.

site_title: Trump says 'long way' to go on North Korea crisis
summary: US President Donald Trump stated on Sunday that the North Korean nuclear crisis is a "long way" from being resolved, despite North Korea's pledge to end nuclear tests and pursue economic growth. Trump welcomed the announcement but emphasized the need for substantial dismantlement of North Korea's nuclear programs before US concessions. World leaders, including South Korean President Moon Jae-in, welcomed the announcement, but some expressed skepticism about Mr. Kim's intentions. The Trump administration said Pyongyang must dismantle its nuclear programs before US concessions, and a meeting between Trump and Kim is expected in late May or early June.

site_title: In Japan, new rules may leave home-sharing industry out in the cold
summary: Japan's new home-sharing law, set to take effect in June, is likely to stifle Airbnb and other home-sharing businesses, forcing many homeowners to stop offering their services due to a 180-day annual cap. Local governments are imposing stricter restrictions, citing security and noise concerns, which may ban weekday rentals and limit home-sharing to specific zones. The law is a disappointment for home-renting hosts, who may be forced to stop offering their services or switch to monthly rentals, which would only generate one-third of their income.

site_title: Indonesia sacks Pertamina chief after oil spill, other issues
summary: Indonesia's State Owned Enterprise Ministry has removed Pertamina chief executive Elia Massa Manik following a series of problems, including a recent oil spill and slow progress on refinery developments. Five Pertamina directors were replaced in the leadership shakeup. Nicke Widyawati, Pertamina's director of human resources, will serve as acting chief executive until a formal replacement is nominated.

site_title: Fresenius terminates US$4.3b Akorn takeover after probe
summary: Fresenius SE has terminated its US$4.3 billion acquisition of Akorn Inc after a probe found "material breaches" of US Food and Drug Administration data-integrity standards. Fresenius had offered to delay its decision, but Akorn declined. The deal collapse follows increased competition eroding Akorn's profit and revenue expectations. Fresenius will pursue a stronger position in the US generics market through organic growth and acquisitions.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble, DeClout, Keppel Corp, China Jinjiang Environment
summary: Noble Group rejected a substantial shareholder's attempt to nominate non-executive directors at its annual general meeting. DeClout saw its second-largest shareholder, Melvin Poh, acquire an 11.8% stake worth S$9.2 million. Keppel Corp is in talks with Golar LNG for floating LNG projects in Mauritania and Senegal. China Jinjiang Environment agreed to subscribe for a majority stake in a Brazilian waste-to-energy company and announced a 21% drop in first-quarter earnings.

site_title: Australia competition regulator flags scrutiny of Uber Eats
summary: Australia's competition regulator plans to scrutinize contracts between Uber Eats and restaurants in the country, following reports of restaurants being held responsible for late deliveries despite being charged by Uber. Head of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, Rod Sims, stated that the regulator will examine if the contracts are misleading, unconscionable, or unfair. This comes as Uber faces increasing competition and regulatory scrutiny globally, including a potential initial public offering in 2019.

site_title: Four killed by nude gunman at Nashville waffle house
summary: A gunman, identified as Travis Reinking, 29, killed at least four people at a Waffle House in Nashville, Tennessee, before fleeing after a patron, James Shaw Jr., wrestled the assault-style rifle from his hands. Shaw suffered non-life-threatening wounds. The shooter was last seen wearing a green jacket and discarded it with additional ammunition. Authorities issued murder warrants for Reinking, who was believed to live near the restaurant. He was considered extremely dangerous and still at large.

site_title: Scandals, bad debts at India banks threaten economic outlook
summary: India's banking system is facing severe challenges, including US$210 billion of soured or problem loans and a series of scandals, which have tarnished the public image of banks. The country's economy, which was showing early signs of recovery, is now at risk due to reduced growth projections to 7.6% for the year ending March 2019. ATMs in some parts of the country are running dry due to high demand for cash, which is being blamed on hoarding by some families and the looming national election. The government has announced a US$33 billion recapitalisation plan to tackle high-stressed loan ratios, but concerns remain that most of the capital will be used to provide for more losses.

site_title: Fed Cup to undergo reform in 2019, says French tennis chief
summary: The Fed Cup is set to undergo radical reforms for 2019, aiming to favor more teams in the World Group. French Tennis Federation president Bernard Giudicelli revealed plans to increase the number of teams, but did not specify the exact number. The reforms follow similar plans for the Davis Cup, which will see the tournament played in one week on neutral ground. Investors, including the Kosmos investment fund, have shown interest in supporting the Fed Cup, with the goal of giving the international federation the means to organize competitions with real impact.

site_title: Blockchain is about to revolutionise the shipping industry
summary: Blockchain technology is set to revolutionize the shipping industry by streamlining documentation and improving efficiency. Container shipping lines, including AP Moeller-Maersk A/S, have teamed up with technology companies to create a blockchain-based platform. This system will enable real-time tracking of cargo and documents, reducing paperwork and costs. The potential benefits include a significant reduction in documentation time, increased transparency, and improved border administration. Industry analysts predict the potential to generate an additional $1 trillion in global trade, while cost savings could be visible in companies' financial statements within two years.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open slightly higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.07% higher, with the Nikkei 225 index reaching 22,178.77, driven by North Korea leader Kim Jong Un's announcement of halting nuclear tests and intercontinental missile launches.

site_title: Temasek unit to open private equity door for retail investors
summary: Temasek's Azalea Investment Management is working to launch a private equity (PE) vehicle that allows retail investors to participate. The new fund will be backed by an asset-backed security, offering a diversified portfolio of PE funds. The move aims to broaden co-investor base and provide access to PE investments for a wider audience. Azalea's CEO, Margaret Lui, previously stated that the goal was to make PE available to retail investors, citing the potential for "financial inclusion on the savings side."

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: EU wants Britain to stay in customs union after Brexit
summary: The European Union is urging Britain to stay in the customs union after Brexit, citing the need for an open border between Ireland and Northern Ireland. This stance was reinforced after a large majority of peers in the House of Lords voted to remain in the customs union. The EU's chief Brexit negotiator, Michel Barnier, stated that Britain's proposals for avoiding a hard border were rejected, and the UK would not be able to negotiate independent trade deals if it stays in the customs union.

site_title: Merkel, Mexican president hail benefits of free trade
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel and Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto praised a new EU-Mexico free trade deal, calling it "truly good news" for Europe, Germany, and Mexico. The agreement, expected to be finalized by the end of the year, aims to modernize a 2000 free-trade deal. Merkel also expressed optimism about Mexico's chances of reaching a revised North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) deal, which the US has threatened to tear up. The agreement is seen as a boost to economic ties and a counter to US President Donald Trump's trade tensions.

site_title: Singapore startup plays Uber to the container-truck trade
summary: Singapore startup Haulio has revolutionized the container-truck trade by creating a web portal that functions like a consumer-focused ride-hailing or bike-sharing platform. Since its launch in May 2018, over 150 companies have registered on the platform, with over 60 hauliers using it, accounting for more than a quarter of Singapore's hauliers. Haulio connects smaller trucking companies with customers, offering a solution to extreme fluctuations in shipments and promoting the sharing of resources among hauliers.

site_title: Central Park's scenic drives will soon be car-free
summary: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio announced that Central Park's scenic drives will be car-free starting June 27. The ban applies to drives below 72nd Street, excluding the crucial east-west transverses. The decision aims to reduce traffic and promote a more pedestrian-friendly environment, with groups like the Central Park Conservancy and New York Road Runners celebrating the move. The change is part of a decades-long evolution in Central Park's car policies, which have shifted towards prioritizing pedestrians and cyclists over drivers.

site_title: Innovation key to transforming sector
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore is leading efforts to transform the maritime sector through innovation, working closely with industry players to drive productivity improvements and enhance the skills of the maritime workforce. The agency has collaborated in over 100 industry R&D projects and has deepened its maritime innovation and R&D capabilities. Key initiatives include the creation of the MPA Living Lab, partnerships with research centers, and the development of the Singapore Maritime Data Hub. The goal is to position Singapore as a premier global hub port and international maritime center, with a focus on sustainability, productivity, and resilience.

site_title: HNA cuts Deutsche Bank stake, reversing commitment from February
summary: HNA Group, a major shareholder of Deutsche Bank, cut its stake in the German lender from 8.8% to 7.9% due to a complex derivatives arrangement expiring. This move reverses an earlier commitment made in February, as HNA seeks to raise $16 billion to address financing issues at home. Despite the reduction, HNA remains committed to being a "major investor" in Deutsche Bank, citing the current market environment. The decision follows negative news about Deutsche Bank, including a management revamp and a transfer error that resulted in the loss of 28 billion euros.

site_title: Trade tensions, US earnings on tap this week
summary: US earnings season and trade tensions are set to drive investor sentiment and trading this week, with 35% of S&P 500 companies due to report earnings. Central banks in Europe and Japan are expected to keep interest rates unchanged amid soft data. Trade tensions escalated last week with China accusing the US of acting like a bully, and investors should watch for a potential full-blown trade war. Inflationary fears and rising 10-year Treasury yields also pose risks, with investors bracing for a rapid rise in yields.

site_title: SGX says IPOs picking up, but brokers say structural issues remain
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is optimistic about its listings pipeline, with Simon Lim, head of Equity Capital Market, stating that the exchange is on track to build on both the number of IPO listings and funds raised this year. However, brokers argue that structural issues, such as low retail activity and poor valuations, need urgent fixing. Despite this, experts believe the pipeline for IPOs across Asean, including Singapore, looks fuller in 2018 compared to 2017, with sector-specific listings expected in June and July.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Veteran investor Melvin Poh now DeClout's second largest shareholder
summary: Veteran investor Melvin Poh has become DeClout's second-largest shareholder after acquiring 78.15 million shares from Wong Poh Leng for S$9.2 million. The acquisition price was a 35.6% premium over DeClout's closing price. Poh now holds 80.8 million shares, or 12.19%, making him the second-largest shareholder, after founder Vesmond Wong. Poh, founder of Fission Group, believes DeClout is at an "inflection point" and sees an opportunity for growth under Vesmond Wong's management.

site_title: India's Modi to visit China this week as rapprochement gathers pace
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi will visit China this week for an informal meeting with President Xi Jinping, marking efforts at rapprochement after a testing year in ties between the two nations. The summit aims to deepen mutual trust and cooperation, particularly on issues such as the disputed border with Tibet and China's Belt and Road initiative. This visit comes after a 73-day military stand-off in 2017 and follows India's decision to ban Tibetan rallies with the Dalai Lama. Modi's nationalist government has reversed its hard line on China, and the meeting will be a rare honor for him to meet Xi outside of Beijing.

images.alt_text: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi (left) will visit China this week for an informal meeting with President Xi Jinping, as efforts at rapprochement gather pace following a testing year in ties between the two giant neighbours.

site_title: Qoo10 takes e-commerce fight to next level with bulked-up war chest
summary: Qoo10, a Singapore-based e-commerce platform, has bolstered its war chest after selling its Japanese business to eBay for approximately US$700 million. With this acquisition, Qoo10 now has a significant cash reserve, allowing it to focus on the Singapore market. The company aims to spend 80% of its budget on Singapore, which Mr. Cho believes holds meaningful growth opportunities for global brands. Despite being a smaller market, Singapore's e-commerce landscape is seen as more attractive due to its significant presence in the region.

images.alt_text: Qoo10 Singapore country manager Cho Hyunwook said many global brands have told him Singapore is their fourth largest market in Asia, after China, Korea and Japan.

site_title: Reduce, reuse, recycle
summary: Unilever President Pier Luigi Sigismondi has set a goal to make all plastic packaging reusable, recyclable, or compostable by 2025. This ambitious target aims to change human behavior about plastic use. However, it cannot be achieved alone, emphasizing the need for collective action to reduce global plastic pollution.

site_title: Asian oil demand to hit record, but industry can't take eyes off Middle East
summary: Asian oil demand is expected to reach a record in April, driven by strong growth in China's oil consumption. China's imports of crude oil are expected to hit 9 million barrels per day, accounting for nearly 10% of global consumption. This growth is attributed to China's economic performance, which has been stronger than expected, and the increasing use of non-state refiners, also known as "teapots." The record demand comes despite rising Middle East supply risks and oil prices, which have reached their highest levels in three years, driven by Saudi Arabia's output cuts and escalating conflicts in the region.

site_title: Capital World aims to score with maiden project
summary: Capital World, a Malaysian property developer, is launching its maiden project, Capital City in Johor Baru, featuring Malaysia's largest indoor theme park, MCM Studio. The integrated development, valued at RM2.4 billion, will also include a mall and a 315-room Hilton Garden Inn. The project aims to capitalize on the area's growing tourism industry and will be completed in phases, with the theme park opening in August 2018 and the serviced apartments by 2020. The company's CEO, Siow Chien Fu, believes that the unique offerings and joint venture model will help the company stand out in a market dominated by local giants.

site_title: Gold, silver look bullish with significant breakout soon
summary: Gold and silver are poised for a significant breakout, driven by rising geopolitical tensions and a weakening US dollar. Despite muted price action, silver is expected to outperform gold, with a better risk-reward proposition due to its low gold/silver ratio. A recent breakout above $17.00 in silver is seen as the start of a stronger rally, with targets of $17.70 and $18.65. The 200-month moving average is also seen as a solid floor, supporting a limited downside in silver.

site_title: Singapore Maritime Week kicks off; over 30,000 participants expected
summary: Singapore Maritime Week began on Sunday with over 30,000 participants expected. The 13th edition features an exhibition on Singapore's maritime industry and its transformation plans, including a showcase on Tuas Port and new technologies. Senior Minister of State Lam Pin Min emphasized the need for the industry to adapt to changing global maritime trends, highlighting the importance of overcoming challenges and seizing opportunities. The event marks a significant growth from the initial 2,800 participants in 2006.

site_title: Korean Air heiresses, one known for 'nut rage', lose their jobs
summary: Two Korean Air heiresses, Cho Hyun-ah and Cho Hyun-min, will be removed from management positions after accusations of physical and verbal abuse against them. Cho Hyun-ah, known for her infamous "nut rage" incident in 2014, and her sister Cho Hyun-min, a marketing executive, have become targets of criticism for their behavior. The decision comes after police investigated accusations of physical abuse and the family was raided by authorities. The company's chairman, Cho Yang-ho, apologized and announced the removal of his daughters from management, introducing professional managers to top posts.

images.alt_text: Cho, the company chairman, apologised in a statement Sunday: "I am deeply sorry that problems connected to my family have worried the people and employees of Korean Air," he said. "As chairman of Korean Air and as the head of my family, I feel crushed by the immature behaviour of my daughters."

site_title: Jurong Port to use video analytics to safeguard container cargoes
summary: Singapore's Jurong Port will use video analytics to track container trucks after they leave immigration checkpoints, aiming to prevent illicit cargo loading. The X-Transport software, developed by Xjeralabs, has shown a 90% accuracy level in a three-month trial and will be deployed in full production by the end of the year. The port operator has allocated S$50,000 to S$80,000 for the system, which will help monitor 70,000 containers entering Singapore annually through the West Gate. The move aims to bolster border security and combat crimes such as cigarette smuggling.

site_title: STI gains 3.8% over 5 sessions; large shareholders adjust stakes
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 3.8% over five sessions, led by a 6.1% total return for the year, surpassing other benchmarks. Share buybacks totaled S$12.2 million, with CapitaLand buying back 1.36% of its shares. Notable transactions included Saray Developed Markets Value Fund acquiring 370,800 shares of Overseas Education, and UnUsUaL's majority shareholder selling 55.5 million shares to Prince Abdul Qawi and Ron Sim. Meanwhile, Peter Lim's Kestrel Investments increased its stake in Secura Group to 39.71%, and Serba Dinamik International Ltd acquired 128.2 million shares of CSE Global for S$57.7 million.

site_title: Investors keeping eye on US-China trade, earnings and Treasury yields
summary: US stocks ended a volatile week flat as investors weighed strong earnings against escalating trade tensions with China. Despite reports of North Korea's nuclear disarmament, Treasury yields hit a 7-year high, raising concerns about a potential market correction. Wall Street strategists believe a grand détente between the US and China is imminent, but a trade deal is still uncertain. The situation is critical for farmers, airlines, and carmakers affected by tariffs and technology controls, while a deal would likely boost markets in the short term.

site_title: IMF to probe role of advanced economies in feeding corruption
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) will review the role of advanced economies in feeding corruption, assessing areas such as governance, financial oversight, and market regulation. The fund will also monitor corruption in countries it lends to and provide policy recommendations. Seven nations, including the US, UK, and Czech Republic, have volunteered for scrutiny. The IMF aims to crack down on corrupt cash and ensure international cooperation to combat corruption, as stated by IMF managing director Christine Lagarde. This move is part of a revised framework on governance around the world.

images.alt_text: The IMF will review the role advanced nations play in bribery and other forms of corruption as part of a revised framework on governance around the world.

site_title: KL to look into bot activity on Twitter if there are complaints
summary: Malaysian regulators plan to investigate automated accounts on Twitter, known as bots, if complaints arise, particularly in the run-up to the general election. The Communications and Multimedia Minister stated that bots can be used anonymously and that the ministry will work with Twitter and Facebook to respond to complaints. This move comes as Twitter has faced scrutiny over its handling of bots in the US, where lawmakers suspect Russian agents used the platform to sway the 2016 presidential election.

site_title: Should we stay or should we go?
summary: Families face a dilemma when their living space becomes too small, prompting discussions about whether to renovate or move to a larger home. The decision comes with significant costs, with closing costs on a new apartment or house reaching up to five figures. Some families opt for creative solutions, such as rearranging furniture or adding storage, while others consider moving to a new neighborhood. A reality TV show, "Get Out of My Room," features families redecorating each other's rooms to address space issues. Ultimately, the decision depends on individual circumstances and financial constraints, with some families choosing to stay put and others opting for a change of scenery.

site_title: Aussie govt under fresh pressure over banking scandals
summary: The Australian government faces pressure to hold a judicial inquiry into the banking sector amid widespread misconduct and regulatory shortcomings. Minister for Finance and Revenue Kelly O'Dwyer expressed a change of heart, crediting the government for establishing the Royal Commission, which would benefit customers. Labor's shadow finance minister Jim Chalmers criticized the government's response, saying they've "learnt absolutely nothing" from the scandalous revelations. The government has unveiled plans to increase penalties for corporate malfeasance and considers extending the commission's mandate.

site_title: Saudi amnesia and partying like it's 2008
summary: Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Khali Al-Falih, suggested the world can tolerate higher crude prices, echoing comments made by Libya's Shukri Ghanem in 2008, which led to a significant price crash. Opec's basket of crudes has reached $70 a barrel, with some members targeting $80 a barrel, despite robust global demand growth. The move is seen as "mission creep" and may have a chilling effect on petrol demand growth in the US, potentially leading to higher pump prices.

site_title: Trump rails against 'very high' oil prices as they near US$70 a barrel
summary: US President Donald Trump accused Opec of "artificially" boosting oil prices near $70 a barrel, drawing rebukes from Saudi officials and other energy exporters. Trump's tweet came as oil prices rose due to global tensions, sanctions on Venezuela and Iran, and a global supply glut. Opec officials said prices were higher due to these factors, not artificial inflation. The cartel is expected to restrain supply through the end of this year, with some officials expressing a desire for higher prices.

images.alt_text: Mr Trump's tweet came shortly after officials from top oil exporter Saudi Arabia said they would like to see prices climb even higher and that they were still far from their goal of ending the supply glut.

site_title: Golf has the pulling power for money
summary: The Singapore Golf Association (SGA) has commissioned a new study to highlight the benefits and economic impact of golf in Singapore. The report, expected to be ready by June, will examine the sport's charity fundraising potential and its overall economic value. Golf charity events have raised significant amounts for various causes, including the welfare of migrant workers, with the S$840,000 raised at the Migrant Workers Centre's event being matched by the government. The study aims to determine the demand and supply ratio of golf facilities and playing opportunities, showcasing golf's potential to contribute to the local economy.

site_title: DBS clients get means to track cross-border payments in real time
summary: DBS Bank has launched a real-time digital cross-border payment tracking solution, powered by Swift Global Payments Innovation (gpi), allowing clients in Singapore and Hong Kong to track cross-border payments in real-time. The solution will be extended to clients in China, India, Indonesia, and Taiwan in the coming months, enhancing cash flow visibility for clients across the region.

site_title: Building a vibrant ecosystem for the maritime industry
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with NUS Enterprise for the Maritime Technology Acceleration Programme (MTAP), aiming to foster innovation in the maritime industry. The program will support startups and SMEs in developing innovative solutions for the sector. A new Centre of Excellence in Modelling and Simulation for Next Generation Ports at NUS will also be established to help the maritime sector harness new technologies and innovations. The program's goals include encouraging the adoption of open innovation approaches, extending its reach globally, and promoting the adoption of new concepts and technologies.

site_title: Keppel Corp in talks with Golar on FLNG project for Tortue field
summary: Keppel Corp is in talks with Golar LNG to develop and execute a 20-year charter agreement for the Tortue field's floating liquefied natural gas (FLNG) project. The project, involving Keppel and BP, would utilize a FLNG unit, with an option for a second vessel. This is similar to Keppel's successful FLNG Hilli Episeyo project, and Keppel's shares rose 1.7% following the announcement.

site_title: Central banks fret trade war more deflationary than inflationary
summary: Central banks are warning that a trade war would be more deflationary than inflationary, casting a pall over the IMF's 3.9% growth forecast for this year and next. Policy makers, including Colombia's and Japan's central bank presidents, describe protectionism as "catastrophic" and "very undesirable." US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin's optimism about reaching an agreement with China may ease concerns, but central banks may need to keep monetary policy looser to mitigate the stagflationary blow from tariffs.

site_title: Aluminium and nickel gain amid fallout from US sanctions on Rusal
summary: US sanctions on Russia's United Co Rusal have disrupted global aluminium supply chains, leading to a surge in prices. Aluminium rose 23% since April, while nickel surged 6.4% for its biggest weekly advance since February. The sanctions have also impacted copper, with prices climbing 2.4% for the biggest gain in two months. The US Treasury Secretary hinted at further moves, while Russian Finance Minister stated that nationalization of Rusal is not being considered. The market is in shock, with millions of tonnes of metal unable to be used due to the sanctions.

site_title: Twin VEW preview draws over 7,500 visitors
summary: CSC Land's Twin VEW in Singapore attracted over 7,500 visitors during its showflat preview, exceeding expectations. The two 36-storey towers will feature 520 units ranging from 484 to 1,518 sq ft, with indicative prices from S$650,000 to S$1.55 million. The development is expected to be ready by 2021, with unit sales starting on May 5. The strong turnout is attributed to the development's proximity to the Jurong Lake District and early-bird discounts.

images.alt_text: The two 36-storey towers in the residential development will have 520 units, comprising one to four-bedders ranging from 484 to 1,518 sq ft. It will also have six penthouses, two shop spaces and a childcare centre.

site_title: Keppel in talks with Golar for FLNG project for Tortue field
summary: Keppel Corporation is in talks with Golar LNG to develop floating LNG (FLNG) projects for the Tortue field, located offshore Mauritania and Senegal. Golar has signed a preliminary agreement with BP to provide a FLNG unit for the Greater Tortue/Ahmeyin project development, in which BP holds a 60% stake as the operator.

site_title: Kim heralds more N Korea economic reforms: analysts
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has declared a new strategic line for the ruling Workers' Party, promising "socialist economic construction" and hinting at more Chinese-style economic reforms. Analysts believe this could lead to greater market-oriented reforms, including increased investment in infrastructure, industrial reforms, and greater autonomy for state-owned enterprises. Kim's economic reforms are seen as a departure from his father's socialist ideology, and while he has implemented some market-oriented changes, the North remains a closely-controlled society. The goal is to achieve sustainable economic growth and improve living standards, but the pace and extent of reforms are uncertain.

site_title: Deloitte & Touche appointed interim judicial managers for China Sports International
summary: Deloitte & Touche has appointed Andrew Grimmett and Lim Loo Khoon as interim judicial managers for China Sports International, a Singapore-based sportswear maker. The company had requested a voluntary suspension of its shares in December 2017 due to an audit process. The interim judicial managers will oversee the company's affairs and provide updates on material developments until the order is lifted. This move follows China Sports International's application to the Singapore High Court to have the company placed under judicial management.

site_title: Ahead of Malaysian polls, bots flood Twitter with pro-government messages
summary: Malaysian election ahead, thousands of pro-government Twitter bots flood platform with automated messages, including visuals and hashtags, in a bid to sway public opinion. Twitter acknowledged the issue but did not provide specific details on the accounts suspended. Researchers found 17,000 bots tweeting election-related content, with 9 top accounts using Russian-sounding names. The campaign appears to be having minimal impact, with opposition leaders dismissing it as "miniscule." The Malaysian government has not commented on the matter.

site_title: JEP terminates China aerospace precision machining services joint venture
summary: JEP Holdings has terminated its planned joint venture with Kun Shan Hang Fu Investment Co Ltd, a China-based aerospace precision machining services joint venture, effective April 20. The joint venture was announced in September 2017 but the termination was mutually agreed upon without disclosing the reason.

site_title: Global carmakers gear up as China opens up sector
summary: Global carmakers, including Volkswagen, Daimler, Toyota, Nissan, and Ford, will showcase their latest models at the Beijing Auto Show, days after China announced plans to lift foreign ownership restrictions in the sector. The move, seen as a potential olive branch to US President Donald Trump, aims to liberalize shareholding limits for new energy vehicle firms and commercial vehicles by 2020 and 2022, respectively. The event is expected to be dominated by "political" topics, including the specter of a trade war, which could impact foreign carmakers' plans for China.

site_title: Apple's shares slip again as concern mounts over iPhone sales
summary: Apple's shares dropped 3.9% on Friday, marking the third consecutive decline, amid concerns over iPhone sales. Analysts at Morgan Stanley cut their forecasts for iPhone shipments, citing weaker demand, particularly in the US$999 iPhone X market. Other tech companies, including Facebook and Amazon, rose, while analysts suggest Apple may accelerate its capital return program and pivot towards services in the future.

site_title: Brooks Brothers suits up for the future with eye on online sales, millennials
summary: Brooks Brothers, the iconic American clothier, has refocused on its classic menswear, accounting for 80% of its business. Under CEO Claudio Del Vecchio's leadership, the company revamped its merchandise, introducing luxurious fabrics and styles, such as three-ply Italian cashmere sweaters and slim-fit suits. Online sales now represent the company's largest percentage of revenue, with detailed product descriptions and lifestyle photos helping increase sales. Despite challenges in the retail market, Brooks Brothers remains committed to producing high-quality, American-made products, with domestic factories employing over 1,000 workers.

site_title: Dunearn Gardens finds collective sale success on third attempt
summary: Dunearn Gardens, a 114-unit freehold residential development, was sold on its third attempt to a fully owned subsidiary of EL Development Pte Ltd for S$468 million. The sale translates to a land price of about S$1,914 per square foot per plot ratio. The new development will be a 34-storey luxury condominium comprising 348 units, with unobstructed city views. The sale price will result in gross sale prices ranging from S$2.69 million to S$7.98 million per apartment.

site_title: US grain ships change direction mid-voyage after China tariffs
summary: Two US grain ships, the N Bonanza and RB Eden, changed course mid-voyage after China imposed a 179% tariff on US sorghum supplies. The ships, loaded with sorghum at the Corpus Christi, Texas port, altered their routes after the tariff announcement on April 17. Their new destinations are unclear, but the US Department of Agriculture reports at least 10 other vessels have been loaded with sorghum for China in the past month. Archer-Daniels-Midland Co, the terminal operator, declined to comment on the vessels' new routes.

site_title: Lombard Odier and Bank Mandiri to offer onshore private bank services
summary: Lombard Odier, a Swiss private bank, has partnered with Indonesia's largest bank Bank Mandiri to offer onshore private bank services. The partnership aims to expand Lombard Odier's Asia footprint and provide risk-based investment solutions and wealth management expertise to high-net-worth and ultra-high-net-worth clients in Indonesia. The minimum required for private bank customers is S$2 million or 20 billion rupiah. The partnership will also enable Bank Mandiri customers to access global investment exposure via Lombard Odier's funds on a discretionary mandate basis.

site_title: China Jinjiang Environment makes foray into Brazil; Q1 earnings drop 21%
summary: China Jinjiang Environment, a waste-to-energy operator, has agreed to subscribe for a majority stake in a Brazilian waste-to-energy company, Foxx URE-BA Ambiental Ltda. The company reported a 21% drop in Q1 earnings due to a large-scale upgrading project affecting its financial performance. Revenue rose 35% to 754.87 million yuan, and the company expects its financial performance to improve as upgraded plants restart operations. The investment marks the group's entry into the Brazilian market, where it plans to develop the local waste-to-energy industry.

site_title: A note to the classically insecure
summary: A common affliction known as the Classical Music Insecurity (CMI) Complex affects many people who believe they don't "get" classical music. This complex is characterized by a lack of description of musical ingredients, leading to feelings of insecurity and intimidation. The author argues that people's reactions to classical music are valid and deserving of recognition, and that knowledge of technical terms is not essential for enjoyment. By addressing the CMI Complex, people can overcome their barriers and appreciate classical music for its emotional impact.

site_title: India's ATMs are running out of cash. Again.
summary: India faces a cash shortage, with empty ATMs and bank restrictions reported in eight states. The crisis is attributed to government policy decisions and growing public mistrust of banks following costly scandals. The shortage is particularly affecting informal workers who rely on cash, potentially denting the income of a critical part of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's governing Bharatiya Janata Party's voter base. Economists warn that the shortage poses a significant threat to the ruling party and could lead to a bank run if not quickly eased.

site_title: ECB is said to see scope to wait for July to signal end of QE
summary: European Central Bank policy makers consider delaying the announcement of ending their bond-buying program until July, citing uncertainty over the economy's slowdown. The decision could be made at the June meeting, but some governors argue it's too soon and want to wait for updated economic forecasts. The euro briefly dropped to its lowest level in two weeks due to the uncertainty, but ECB President Mario Draghi remains optimistic about the region's growth momentum. Economists predict a short taper in the final quarter to end the program, with a potential rate hike around mid-2019.

site_title: Takeda adds more cash in boosting Shire bid over US$60b
summary: Takeda Pharmaceutical Co. has increased its offer for Shire Plc to over $60 billion, with a cash component of $21 per share and new stock, to win over US investors. This is the fourth bid, following previous rejections. The new proposal offers a higher cash component, lifting it to 45% of the total offer, in an effort to appease shareholders who may be hesitant to receive Takeda stock. Shire's board of directors is considering the proposal and will issue a further announcement in due course.

site_title: Avicii, electronic dance music producer and DJ, is dead at 28
summary: Swedish DJ and electronic dance music producer Avicii, whose real name was Tim Bergling, died at 28 in Muscat, Oman. The cause of death was not specified, but he was in Oman to visit friends. Bergling rose to fame with hits like "Levels" and "Wake Me Up," and was nominated for two Grammy Awards. He had previously retired from international touring due to health scares, including a gallbladder removal and acute pancreatitis. Bergling is survived by his parents, sister, and brothers.

site_title: Jubilee strikes new placement agreement to raise S$1 million with private investor
summary: Jubilee Industries Holdings has agreed to place S$1 million in shares to private investor Pek Hak Bin, replacing a previous S$5 million share placement. The deal involves Pek subscribing to 30.03 million new shares at 3.33 Singapore cents, a 4.86% discount to the weighted average price. The placement aims to improve cash flow, product mix, and explore new business opportunities, with all net proceeds used for general capital working purposes.

site_title: US, Europe order emergency checks on engine type in Southwest accident
