summary: US and European airline regulators ordered emergency inspections of nearly 700 aircraft engines similar to the one involved in a fatal Southwest Airlines engine blowout earlier this week. The inspections, which must be completed within 20 days, are due to concerns over a similar engine failure in 2016 and a recent fatal accident. The affected engines, CFM56-7B models, have been in service for up to 20 years and have undergone over 30,000 cycles. The move aims to mitigate risks of a similar mishap and partially resolves a gap in previous responses to the 2016 accident.

site_title: Growing interest in Rugby by engaging the family experience
summary: The HSBC Singapore Rugby Sevens tournament is set to take place this weekend, featuring 16 top Rugby Sevens teams. The event aims to engage families and increase mainstream acceptance of rugby among young and old, with family packages selling well and three Fun Zones, including a Kids Zone, to be set up. The tournament also features a family-friendly atmosphere, including a Sports Zone and World Zone showcasing local cuisine. The event's ambassador, DJ Forbes, believes that encouraging family participation while maintaining the traditional base of fans is a good balance for the event, which is part of World Rugby's Sevens circuit and has raised the profile of rugby in the region.

images.alt_text: "The focus on the family theme is to encourage mainstream acceptance of Rugby among the young and old," says Rugby Singapore chairman David Lim (in red) with youth members of the Titans, a local rugby team in Singapore.
A family selfie with former All Black Sevens captain DJ Forbes at last year's HSBC Singapore Rugby Sevens event. Mr Forbes is an ambassador for this year's Singapore 7's event (April 28-29).

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report covers the tanker and dry bulk market from last week. VLCC rates hovered around WS 39/40 to China, with a GSC fixed at WS 35.5 to South Korea. Meanwhile, in unrelated news, Tesla marked its formal entry into India with a launch event, while FedEx partnered with a startup to deploy robots for deliveries. Delta Air Lines offered an upbeat outlook on travel demand, lifting shares. Japan's carmakers reduced export prices to the US to offset tariffs, and BYD and other EV battery makers face pressure to cut emissions.

site_title: Wells Fargo's big fine puts fresh focus on power of Trump tweets
summary: US regulators have fined Wells Fargo $1 billion to settle allegations of abusing consumers in its auto-lending and mortgage businesses. The enforcement actions, imposed by President Trump's appointees, mark a significant shift in the bank's treatment, with some lawmakers and regulators previously criticizing big corporate fines as targeting blameless shareholders. The fines, $500 million each from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, are record sanctions for each agency and demonstrate the potential consequences of being targeted in a presidential tweet.

site_title: Barclays chief Jes Staley survives whistleblowing inquiry with fines
summary: Barclays CEO Jes Staley will be fined by British regulators for attempting to unmask a whistleblower, but will keep his job. The country's banking watchdogs concluded his actions represented a breach of individual conduct under the "senior managers regime." A bank spokesman said the size of the fine had yet to be determined, but Staley could face a 30% discount if he accepts the findings. The fine is the first for a sitting chief executive of a major bank in Britain, following a year-long probe.

site_title: KinderWorld Education considering Singapore IPO: sources
summary: KinderWorld Education Group, a South-east Asian school operator, is considering a Singapore initial public offering (IPO) that could raise about S$70 million. The planned IPO could value the company at S$300 million, with shares potentially selling in the second half of 2018. This move follows other South-east Asian school operators, such as MindChamps PreSchool Ltd, which went public last year. KinderWorld, founded in 1986, has 17 campuses in Vietnam, Malaysia, and Thailand, and is working with advisers on the IPO process.

site_title: US-China trade tension dominates IMF gathering
summary: US-China trade tensions are dominating a gathering of world finance officials at the IMF, despite the Group of 20 avoiding the topic. Officials have urged disputes to be resolved through dialogue rather than unilateral tariffs, warning of the threat to the global economy. French Economy Minister Bruno Le Maire criticized the US-China spat, calling it "vain and pointless". The tensions come as China's GDP growth is set to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: US dollar hits 2-week peak on higher US yields
summary: The US dollar rose to a two-week high against a basket of currencies due to rising US yields, reaching 90.314 on the dollar index. The euro fell to a two-week low of $1.2248, while sterling declined 0.4% to $1.4032. The eurozone's economic growth is expected to continue, but analysts doubt the ECB will signal further policy changes. US two-year Treasury yields reached 2.453%, the highest level since 2008, and the dollar's overall prospect remains cloudy due to growing trade and budget deficits.

site_title: Ferragamo names veteran Gucci executive as general manager
summary: Salvatore Ferragamo appoints Gucci executive Micaela Le Divelec as general manager, postponing the search for a new CEO. The move comes after CEO Eraldo Poletto's departure due to a profit warning and a failed plan to boost sales. The company is battling falling sales and profitability, and the Ferragamo family owns nearly 70% of the group. The new general manager will work alongside chairman Ferruccio Ferragamo, vice-chairman James Ferragamo, and finance chief Ugo Giorcelli to find a new CEO and implement a product revamp.

site_title: North Korea says will stop nuclear tests, scrap test site
summary: North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un announced the country will immediately suspend nuclear and missile tests, scrap its nuclear test site, and pursue economic growth and peace. The decision comes ahead of planned summits with South Korea and the US, and is seen as a significant reversal for Kim, who has staked his security on his nuclear arsenal. The US has welcomed the statement, but experts say it falls short of Washington's demand for complete denuclearisation. The move is seen as a sign of progress towards denuclearisation of the Korean peninsula, but many doubt Kim's sincerity about giving up his nuclear program.

site_title: NY to ban cars from Manhattan's Central Park
summary: New York City will ban cars from Manhattan's Central Park, effective June 27, as part of a commitment to reducing pollution and prioritizing people over cars. The ban applies to three concrete lanes in the south, while four below-grade roads will remain open. The measure aims to improve air quality and safety for the millions of visitors to the park, aligning with the city's sustainability and climate goals. Mayor Bill de Blasio cited the need to "prioritise people over cars" and "take it back" from cars, which have dominated parts of the park for over a century.

site_title: Oil recovers after sliding on Trump tweet criticising Opec
summary: US oil prices stabilized after a brief slide driven by President Donald Trump's criticism of Opec's role in pushing up global oil prices. Brent crude oil futures rose 0.4% to $74.06 per barrel, while West Texas Intermediate crude futures gained 0.4% to $68.40 per barrel. Trump's tweet, which questioned Opec's intentions, was met with a muted response from analysts, who attributed the price stability to a tightening market and geopolitical risk.

site_title: Google, Twitter pressed to follow Facebook into Senate hearings
summary: Senate Commerce Chairman John Thune is considering a public hearing on data privacy, potentially requiring CEOs of Google and Twitter to testify alongside Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg. The hearing follows revelations about Cambridge Analytica's harvesting of 87 million Facebook users' data without consent. Thune has spoken with Google representatives, and Senate Judiciary Chairman Chuck Grassley has sent letters to Google and Twitter CEOs asking about their data practices and actions to counter foreign interference.

site_title: Nafta ministers to meet again as elections quicken pace
summary: US, Canadian, and Mexican Nafta ministers will meet again this weekend before regrouping on Tuesday as negotiations intensify ahead of looming elections. The talks aim to produce a comprehensive agreement, not just new rules for the auto sector, with key chapters on telecommunications, energy, and digital trade already concluded. Ministers expressed optimism but cautioned that flexibility is needed to reach a deal by early May, with Canada's Chrystia Freeland and Mexico's Ildefonso Guajardo downplaying expectations of an imminent agreement.

site_title: A US recession ahead? Fed policymakers say not to worry
summary: US Federal Reserve policymakers say a recession is unlikely, citing strong growth prospects and rate hikes that are flattening the yield curve. Two policymakers, including a non-mainstream Fed voice, expressed confidence in the economy, while disagreeing on the issue. The Fed's rate hikes are seen as a positive sign, rather than a warning of impending economic downturn.

site_title: Stellar, sustainable fashion
summary: Stella McCartney, the fashion designer, emphasizes the need for the industry to adopt more sustainable materials and manufacturing practices. She recently purchased the remaining 50% of her company from the French luxury group Kering, marking the end of a 17-year partnership. McCartney's brand operates 51 freestanding stores globally and distributes her collections in 77 countries. Her commitment to sustainability is reflected in her decision to go solo, highlighting the industry's shift towards smaller labels and a desire for more environmentally-friendly practices.

site_title: Gold rush for black art as collector stampede drives up prices
summary: The art market is experiencing a surge in demand for black art, with collectors and museums clamoring for works by African-American artists. This "gold rush" has led to unprecedented sales, with billionaire Yusaku Maezawa paying $110.5 million for a Jean-Michel Basquiat canvas in May. US institutions are realizing their collections have largely overlooked black artists, and are now making significant efforts to acquire and exhibit their work. The Museum of Modern Art in New York has acquired over 430 works by black artists since 2010, and other museums, including the Broad and the Studio Museum of Harlem, are also taking steps to rectify the imbalance.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Accordia Golf Trust's management reported that its golf courses in Nagoya, Japan, can maintain or raise prices due to their proximity to expressways and less challenging design. The company received feedback from analysts and investors on valuation, pricing trends, and revenue-raising strategies. Meanwhile, IHH Healthcare proposed a non-binding letter to Fortis, aiming to infuse funds for the buyout of its assets, working capital, and infrastructure upgrades, which could enhance IHH's position in India and turn around Fortis' operations.

site_title: Singapore premier warns against protectionism masquerading as political and security concerns
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong warned against protectionism masquerading as political and security concerns, urging Commonwealth nations to promote trade and liberal investment flows. Restricting investments can lead to strategic and great power rivalry, damaging the multilateral system of trade and investments. Lee emphasized the importance of balancing national interests with open trade and investment, cautioning against unilateral trade restrictions that may lead to tit-for-tat responses. He encouraged nations to leverage similarities in regulatory systems and economic outlook to promote free trade and investment flows.

site_title: Frasers Commercial Trust's Q2 DPU dips to 2.4 Singapore cents
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) posted a Q2 DPU of 2.40 Singapore cents, down 4.4% from the previous year. Gross revenue fell 18% to S$33 million, and net property income (NPI) fell 25.3% to S$22.4 million, mainly due to lower occupancy rates and higher repair and maintenance expenses. Total distributable income for Q2 was up 2.9% to S$20.6 million, driven by a contribution from Farnborough Business Park. FCOT's units ended 1.4% lower at S$1.46.

site_title: Tharman reappointed MAS chairman; Chaly Mah to join board as Lim Chee Onn retires
summary: Tharman Shanmugaratnam has been reappointed as the Chairman of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). Four board members, including Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat and Enterprise Singapore chairman Peter Ong, have also been reappointed. Lim Chee Onn will retire and step down as chairman of the risk committee on May 31. Chaly Mah, a former Deloitte executive, has been appointed to the MAS board, replacing Lim as chairman of the risk committee.

images.alt_text: Mr Mah's term of appointment on the MAS board will be from May 1, 2018, to May 31, 2020.

site_title: US: Worries about interest rates, Apple hit US stocks
summary: US stocks closed the week down, with the Dow Jones dropping 0.8%, the S&P 500 falling 0.9%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index tumbling 1.3%, due to worries about higher interest rates and tech giant Apple's declining prospects. The yield on the 10-year US Treasury rose to 2.95%, reigniting fears of economic impact from Federal Reserve interest rate increases. Apple's decline was attributed to analyst doubts about iPhone sales, while General Electric rose despite reporting a loss, and Wells Fargo gained after agreeing to pay $1 billion to settle with regulators.

site_title: Singapore's casinos will face greater global competition, disruption: Josephine Teo
summary: Singapore's casinos face increased global competition and technological disruption, Second Minister for Manpower and Home Affairs Josephine Teo said. The country's current piecemeal approach to regulating different gambling products will not be sustainable, she stated. Teo called for greater consolidation of casino regulatory functions and urged the Casino Regulatory Authority to build up its capabilities to adapt to new demands. The challenge also includes competition for tourism revenues and the need for a holistic and coherent system to balance innovation and regulation.

site_title: AT&T, Verizon said to face US probe over mobile technology
summary: US antitrust officials are investigating AT&T and Verizon for allegedly working with an industry standards group to make it harder for consumers to switch wireless carriers. Apple and other equipment makers complained to the government about the carriers' practices, prompting demands for information. The move comes after regulators pressured the phone companies to make it easier for consumers to switch carriers, with the 2013 agreement allowing consumers to use smartphones on other networks after contracts expire. The investigation seeks to determine if the carriers colluded to hinder consumer switching.

images.alt_text: AT&T Inc and Verizon Communications Inc are under investigation by US antitrust officials over whether the companies worked with an industry standards group to make it tougher for consumers to switch wireless carriers, according to two people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Too battered to fail: Bonds in the Gulf are a safe place to hide
summary: Sovereign bonds in the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) have become attractive investments, offering "excellent value" compared to other emerging-market debt. Despite geopolitical risks, investors are drawn to the region's economic reforms and fiscal consolidation efforts. Saudi Arabia and Qatar have recently sold a combined $23 billion of bonds, easing concerns about new issues. The region's debt market is less volatile due to buy-and-hold investors, and yields on GCC bonds are now comparable to those of lower-rated countries, making them a safe haven during times of excessive volatility.

site_title: KKR-backed Radiant Life Care makes offer for Fortis
summary: KKR-backed Radiant Life Care Private Ltd has made an all-cash offer to buy more than a quarter of Fortis Healthcare Ltd's hospital business, valuing the company at 165 rupees per share. The proposal includes spinning off the hospital business into a new company, excluding Fortis' stake in SRL Ltd. This is the fifth suitor for Fortis, which is also being targeted by China's Fosun International and Malaysia's IHH Healthcare. The offer is contingent on Radiant being able to buy 26% or more shares of the proposed new company.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Creative Technology warns of potentially lower-than-expected H2 revenue, with operating losses similar to the first half. The company's revenue guidance may be below target, citing uncertain market conditions.

site_title: StarHub picks CEO after global hunt
summary: StarHub has appointed Peter Kaliaropoulos, a former executive and CEO of Kuwait's Zain Saudi Arabia, as its new CEO, effective July 9. Kaliaropoulos, 58, has a wealth of experience in the telecommunications industry, including overseeing StarHub's commercial launch in 2000. Analysts predict he will focus on growing market share in Singapore, rather than expanding internationally, and investing in 5G infrastructure. His appointment caps a global search for a successor to Tan Tong Hai, who resigned in November.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Evidence-based medicine and rising healthcare costs
summary: A shift towards evidence-based medicine in the healthcare industry is increasing costs, but it's essential for making better decisions and achieving improved outcomes. With diagnostic imaging like CT scans and MRIs, doctors can confirm injuries and develop targeted treatment plans. This approach is particularly crucial for high-profile cases, such as sports injuries, and for patients seeking medical board evaluations. While the added expense may be a concern, the benefits of precise diagnosis and treatment far outweigh the costs.

site_title: Banking on fundamentals
summary: This article discusses key factors for investing in the banking sector. Banks play a vital role in the economy, underpinning its efficient functioning. The article highlights the importance of understanding various factors, including spheres of operation, services offered, and subsidiaries. It emphasizes the need for informed investment decisions in the banking sector.

site_title: Asian Healthcare Specialists and SLB debut above IPO prices
summary: Asian Healthcare Specialists (AHS) and SLB Development debuted on the Catalist market, closing above their initial public offering (IPO) prices. AHS shares rose 47.8% to S$0.34, while SLB shares closed 8.7% higher at S$0.25. The IPOs raised S$9.5 million and S$892 million respectively, with AHS using the proceeds to expand into integrated healthcare services and SLB focusing on property development projects.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Civmec worker dies in accident at Perth wastewater treatment plant
summary: A Civmec worker has died in an industrial accident at the Woodman Point wastewater treatment plant in Perth, Western Australia. The incident occurred when a scaffold collapsed, trapping the worker under beams. Civmec has offered counselling support to its workforce and is cooperating with authorities to determine the cause of the accident. The construction project, which began in December 2016, is scheduled for completion by the end of 2019. Civmec CEO Patrick Tallon has visited the family residence and expressed condolences to the family and colleagues.

site_title: CNOOC posts strongest Q1 revenue since 2014
summary: CNOOC Ltd posted its strongest Q1 revenue since 2014, with a 10.8% increase from the same period last year, reaching 42.54 billion yuan. The revenue growth was driven by a rebound in international oil prices and rising domestic gas prices. Natural gas revenues rose 12% and total crude oil production fell to 99 million barrels. Capital spending increased 11% to 9.66 billion yuan. No profit figures were disclosed.

site_title: SGX Q3 net profit up 21% to S$100.5m - highest in 10 years
summary: Singapore Exchange's (SGX) net profit for the third quarter ended March 31, 2018, rose 21% to S$100.5 million, its highest in 10 years. Revenue climbed 10% to S$222.2 million, driven by strong performances in derivatives and securities segments. Earnings per share increased to 9.4 Singapore cents, and the bourse declared an interim dividend of 5 Singapore cents per share. CEO Loh Boon Chye attributed the growth to increased liquidity providers, outreach to investors, and longer trading hours.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Frasers Logistics buys nearly S$1b in European properties
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) has acquired 21 industrial properties in Germany and the Netherlands for S$972.8 million, marking its first foray into Europe. The acquisition portfolio includes 100% occupied properties with a weighted average lease expiry of eight years. FLT expects the deal to be distribution per unit (DPU) accretive, with a projected DPU rise of 1.7% and a gearing ratio increase of 6.9%. The acquisition is expected to be completed by June, subject to unitholder approval and successful equity fund raising, and will diversify FLT's portfolio beyond Australia.

site_title: Datapulse board keeps its seats and motions despite shareholder discontent
summary: Datapulse Technology's board retained its seats and motioned forward its diversification agenda despite shareholder discontent at a special meeting. Minority shareholders criticized the board's independence, competence, and commercial logic, particularly over the contentious Wayco acquisition. However, the board secured votes to push ahead with its agenda, with majority owner Ng Siew Hong expressing confidence in the board's abilities. The outcome was seen as a victory for the board, with only 41% of minority shareholders voting against the current board and its proposed diversification.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: HK homeowners now a minority as prices continue to soar
summary: Hong Kong homeowners are now in the minority, with only 49.2% of domestic households owning their homes as of 2017, the lowest since 1999. The city's property prices have tripled since 1999, making it the world's least affordable real estate market for the eighth consecutive year. Despite attempts to cool the market, Hong Kong's chief executive Carrie Lam admits that prices cannot be curbed, and recent interventions by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority may lead to higher mortgage rates.

site_title: Critical points for all parties when navigating collective sales
summary: Singapore's collective sale process has undergone significant changes since 2007, introducing greater transparency and fairness for both objecting and majority subsidiary proprietors (SP). The revised Land Titles (Strata) Act prohibits collective sales causing financial loss or lacking good faith. Financial loss is defined as net proceeds less original purchase price, with deductions including stamp duty, legal fees, and CPF funds. The court will also consider incentive payments and whether the transaction is in good faith, depending on unique circumstances. Stakeholders are advised to understand their rights and duties and seek legal advice to protect their interests.

site_title: CapitaLand Mall Trust Q1 DPU up 1.8%, gross revenue hits S$175.2m, up 1.8%
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) reported a 1.8% increase in first-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.78 Singapore cents, driven by higher occupancy and car park income. Gross revenue rose 1.8% to S$175.2 million, while net property income increased 4.7% to S$125.7 million. Despite a 2.1% decline in shopper traffic, portfolio occupancy remained at 98.9%. The company has started asset enhancement works at Tampines Mall and completed renovation works at Raffles City Singapore.

site_title: Drop in tech, bank counters dampen market
summary: The Singapore bourse fell 25.35 points or 0.7% to 3,573.38 on Friday, weighed down by tech stocks and local banks. Semiconductor-related stocks, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, plummeted 6.3% after weak smartphone demand forecasts. Bank counters also dipped, with DBS Bank, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank falling 1.1%, 0.3%, and 0.07% respectively. Utilities and offshore conglomerates Sembcorp Industries and Keppel Corporation bucked the trend, rising 2.5% and 1.7% respectively.

site_title: Going out on a high note
summary: Singapore will host its last edition of the WTA Finals in October, marking the end of a five-year run at the Singapore Sports Hub. The tournament, which has grown into a world-class sporting and entertainment event, has benefited local communities through initiatives such as the Tennis For Every Child programme and the ActiveSG Tennis Academy. The final event will feature the top eight players in women's tennis, with a charity element and a silent auction for signed tennis rackets. After the tournament, the rights will be held by the WTA, with Shenzhen set to host the event for the next decade starting in 2019.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Among the front-runners to qualify for the WTA Finals this year is current world No 1 Simona Halep.
Shenzhen, the next host city, is even building a new venue for the WTA Finals, and that is a reflection of the success of the tournament in Singapore, says Ms Clements of Lagardère Sports.

site_title: Philip Morris takes a drag on Venture, but it's not up in smoke
summary: Philip Morris' "heat not burn" tobacco products, produced by Venture Corp, saw sales slower than expected, causing Venture's shares to drop 12.25% on Friday. Despite this, Venture's overall revenue is estimated to be only 3-4% from IQOS, and other customers' growth prospects remain healthy. Analysts note that IQOS sales have peaked and that the US market is yet to be fully launched, reducing concerns about Venture's dependence on the product.

site_title: Ferragamo chairman hopes new CEO will come from within company
summary: Ferragamo chairman Ferruccio Ferragamo expressed hope that the company's new CEO will come from within the company, rather than an external candidate, as the luxury group presses ahead with its industrial plan. The company, which has been struggling with falling sales and profitability, issued a profit warning in December and saw CEO Eraldo Poletto unexpectedly leave the company in March. Ferragamo, who took temporary charge after Poletto's departure, intends to hold the reins for a short period and excluded the possibility of a Ferragamo family member taking the role.

site_title: Keppel tightens internal controls to stamp out corrupt behaviour
summary: Keppel Corporation strengthened its internal compliance and controls in response to concerns about corrupt behavior involving its offshore and marine unit in Brazil. Chairman Lee Boon Yang expressed regret and disappointment, stating that such conduct is "avoidable" and will be avoided. The company has implemented more stringent due diligence on agents, a new agent fees policy, and other enhancements to its compliance program since 2015. Despite this, shareholders questioned the annual remuneration of CEO Loh Chin Hua, which increased by 12.1% despite a 6.6% rise in net profit excluding a one-off penalty.

site_title: Escalating trade dispute could derail recovery, put 'many jobs at risk': WTO
summary: The World Trade Organization's chief, Roberto Azevedo, warns that a major escalation in the US-China trade dispute could derail the global recovery and put "many jobs at risk." A breakdown in trade relations among major players could also disproportionately affect poor countries, exacerbating their economic struggles.

site_title: Tame inflation keeps pressure on BOJ to maintain stimulus
summary: Japan's headline inflation slowed in March to 0.9%, matching economists' median estimate, keeping the Bank of Japan under pressure to maintain its ultra-easy monetary policy. Core consumer price index rose 0.9% year-on-year, and analysts expect inflation to peak later this year, raising hurdles for the BOJ's path to exiting easy monetary policy. The central bank is likely to maintain its view that inflation will reach 2% target next fiscal year, which could lead to debates on reducing stimulus.

site_title: Some crypto hedge funds keep making money as bitcoin plunges
summary: Crypto hedge funds are generating profits despite bitcoin's decline, with some managers using market-making and arbitrage strategies to profit from wild swings in cryptocurrencies. Funds like Pivot Digital Trading-2 and Market Neutral Liquidity SP-Institutional delivered first-quarter gains, while others, like Silver 8 Partners, lost money. These funds provide investors with protection when prices of digital assets fall, and their results suggest that some managers are finding ways to profit from volatility without predicting market direction.

images.alt_text: "High levels of uncertainty and low market liquidity make investments in blockchain-related assets volatile." - Silver 8 Partners, which invests in digital assets.

site_title: Almost 20% of American families were jobless in 2017
summary: US families experienced chronic joblessness in 2017, with almost 20% of American families having no one bringing home a paycheck, despite a 17-year low unemployment rate of 4.1%. This trend was most notable among families led by women, at 23.2%, while men's joblessness rates decreased to 15.4% from 16.4% in 2016.

site_title: Goldilocks proposing alternative restructuring plan for Noble
summary: Goldilocks Investment Company, Noble Group's third-largest shareholder, is proposing an alternative restructuring plan for the commodity firm. The plan calls on shareholders to repopulate the Noble board to support its initiatives. Goldilocks has offered working capital and trade finance to Noble and is reviewing its business plan and earnings potential. The plan aims to preserve and enhance shareholder value, and Goldilocks has nominated five non-executive independent directors for the upcoming annual general meeting. Noble has dropped a provision that would have treated shareholders differently depending on their vote, following objections from the Singapore Exchange Regulation.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Wells Fargo fined US$1b over consumer-business missteps
summary: Wells Fargo has agreed to pay US$1 billion to settle US probes into consumer-business missteps, the largest sanction of a US bank under President Trump. The settlement covers issues in auto-lending and mortgage units, including forced unwanted insurance on customers and improper interest rate charges. The bank will pay US$500 million in penalties to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, with a retroactive booking in the first quarter.

site_title: Nissan to cut hundreds of jobs at UK plant as diesel demand slides
summary: Nissan is set to cut hundreds of jobs at its Sunderland plant in the UK due to declining demand for diesel models in Europe. Sales in Britain have fallen 35% this year, outpacing the overall sector decline of 12%. This move follows similar cuts by Jaguar Land Rover, which blamed diesel policy confusion for its 1,000 job losses. Nissan's Sunderland plant builds Qashqai and Juke models, and the company is tackling the decline in diesel demand to remain competitive.

site_title: Are today's airlines attractive businesses?
summary: Warren Buffett has changed his tune on the airline industry, now believing that today's carriers are less likely to go bankrupt. Despite still facing risks, industry consolidation, yield management, and prudent management have improved airline performance. Over the last decade, the return on equity for airlines has shown significant improvements, with some generating double-digit returns on equity. However, the industry remains closely tied to the state of the economy, and investors should tread carefully when valuing airlines. Buffett's investments in US carriers, such as United, American, Southwest, and Delta, are clustered around the median EV/EBITDAR of 4.2, making them reasonably priced.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines also sports an attractive EV/EBITDAR of around 3.9. In other words, someone looking to acquire the national carrier, lock, stock and barrel, would be paying S$3.90 for every dollar of operating profit.

site_title: Lithe, light wonder
summary: Dell's XPS 13 ultrabook is a prime example of the "strangeness in the proportion" coined by 17th-century philosopher Francis Bacon, striking a balance between aesthetics and features. The laptop boasts a luxurious rose gold finish, a comfortable keyboard, and a stunning 4K display. However, its quest for thinness led to the removal of full-size USB ports and a poorly positioned webcam. Despite its flaws, the XPS 13 is a top-performing and visually stunning Windows laptop, making it a worthwhile investment for those willing to overlook its shortcomings.

images.alt_text: The beautiful rose gold-coloured aluminium colour works well here to bring some style to a product category which really hasn't seen many bold design choices.
Dell's latest XPS 13 is sleek and modern, and despite several shortcomings, is one of the best-performing and good-looking Windows laptops you can buy today.

site_title: Emotional UOB AGM as patriarch Wee Cho Yaw absent
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) held its annual shareholders meeting, with CEO Wee Ee Cheong visibly emotional as he thanked his father, Wee Cho Yaw, who stepped down from the board after 60 years. Wee Cho Yaw, 89, was absent from the meeting for the first time, citing feelings of emotion. The bank's senior leadership and Wee Ee Cheong addressed shareholders' concerns, including issues with a relationship manager and the bank's dividend payments. Despite some shareholders' complaints, the meeting concluded with a positive tone, with Wee Ee Cheong assuring shareholders that UOB is in good hands.

site_title: A sexist skirt for that pretty casual look
summary: The United Nations' World Meteorological Organization (WMO) has retired the names of four hurricanes - Harvey, Irma, Maria, and Nate - due to their devastating impact, replacing them with Harold, Idalia, Margot, and Nigel. This change highlights the shift in hurricane naming conventions from female to male names in the US, which began in the 1970s to combat sexist connotations. Feminist groups, including Roxcy Bolton, fought against the use of female-only hurricanes, and the change has been seen as a step towards greater diversity in naming conventions, including the labeling of robots and digital personal assistants.

site_title: Air France CEO threatens to resign if strikes continue
summary: Air France CEO Jean-Marc Janaillac threatened to resign if staff reject his wage proposals, amid nine days of strikes over pay since February. The airline has returned to profitability, but staff claim their wages have been effectively frozen since 2011. Unions argue workers deserve a pay increase after years of belt-tightening. Janaillac's resignation threat comes as the dispute continues, with no clear resolution in sight.

site_title: Grab launches GrabShuttle school-bus service
summary: Grab launches GrabShuttle, a school-bus service for students and staff in Singapore, offering more convenient and flexible transport options. The service allows users to choose from different vehicle sizes and commit for as little as two months. Prices start from S$130 a month for one-way trips, with a one-month deposit required. The service provides real-time tracking and allows verified parents/guardians to contact drivers, while ensuring student privacy. This move aims to meet consumer demand and provide a more efficient and personalized service, helping schoolchildren and staff get to their destination more quickly.

site_title: AccorHotels to pursue acquisitions, no special dividend
summary: AccorHotels, Europe's largest hotel group, will pursue further acquisitions using cash from the sale of its 55% AccorInvest property business, which was sold for 4.4 billion euros in February. The company will not pay a special dividend and instead focus on smaller deals to boost growth and expand its brand portfolio. CEO Sebastien Bazin aims to double operating profit and possibly the share price within five years, with plans to increase its brand portfolio to 40 from 25.

site_title: Singapore Medical Group faces alleged trademark infringement for SW1 acquisition
summary: Singapore Medical Group faces a lawsuit alleging trademark and copyright infringement over its acquisition of SW1 clinic in March. Eastlife and Maxglobe claim SMG conspired with Dr. Low and Dr. Lee to pass off the new SW1 Clinic as a Sloane Clinic, and the plaintiffs withdrew their application for most interlocutory injunctions. SMG denies the claims, stating they are without merit and unlikely to impact its financial performance, with shares falling 1.98% to S$0.495.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed 25.35 points or 0.7% lower at 3,573.38 on Friday, with 1.5 billion shares worth S$1.4 billion traded. Losers outpaced gainers 271 to 144. This marks the second consecutive day of losses, following a 0.4% gain on Thursday.

site_title: PSA demanding 3,700 job cuts in Germany
summary: PSA Group, the parent company of Opel, is demanding 3,700 job cuts at the German subsidiary by 2020. Around 2,000 positions have already been reduced through contract buyouts and early retirement. The Opel works council chief, Wolfgang Schaefer-Klug, expressed concerns about meeting the cost targets, citing a lack of clear vision for the brand's future. The move is part of PSA's recovery plan to shift Opel's model lineup onto its own architecture and achieve 1.7 billion euros in savings from the purchase. Germany's IG Metall union objects to PSA's negotiation tactics.

site_title: 16 Umno members seek to challenge party's legality
summary: Sixteen Umno members have filed a judicial review to challenge the party's legality, seeking a provisional dissolution and suspension of activities. They claim the Registrar of Societies extended the party's election deadline twice, exceeding Umno's constitution limits of 54 months. The applicants, from 11 branches in six states, are seeking a court order to cancel the second extension and declare the party's branches and divisions invalid. They also ask for the Registrar of Societies to investigate and provide written feedback on the matter.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sembcorp Marine expects a net loss in the first quarter due to lower revenues from phosphorus sales. AusGroup won a $27 million contract for a lithium plant expansion in Western Australia. China Environment ceased business operations in its Chinese subsidiaries and faces enforcement orders totaling 151 million yuan. ESR-Reit's distribution per unit fell 15.6% due to increased units issued, while its gross revenue rose 21.2% year-on-year. Sembcorp Marine's board welcomed new independent director Patrick Daniel, a journalism veteran.

site_title: US:Wall Street opens flat on tech, oil weakness
summary: US stock indexes opened flat on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 7.50 points, or 0.03%, to 24,657.39, and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 17.41 points, or 0.24%, to 7,220.64. This decline was attributed to weakness in technology stocks and oil prices, despite strong earnings from industrials General Electric and Honeywell.

site_title: European firms fight for LNG supplies, Norway's Yara says
summary: European energy-intensive industries are securing LNG supplies to store for next winter due to high natural gas prices, which have spiked in the first quarter. Norwegian fertilizer maker Yara said less LNG was available than expected, contributing to weaker earnings. Higher coal prices and CO2 costs are also driving the demand for LNG. Europe's winter is ending with low stocks, leading to a competition for buying gas for direct usage and storage for next winter, keeping the forward curve flat. Chinese and South Korean demand for LNG contributed to the price increase.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 7.43 points lower at 1,887.75 on Friday, with 668 losers outweighing 272 gainers. The index saw 2.44 billion shares traded worth RM2.16 billion.

site_title: Starbucks takes the pain with the blame
summary: Starbucks closed all 8,000 company-owned stores for an afternoon to hold "racial-bias" training following the arrest of two black men at a Philadelphia cafe, sparking praise from crisis management and diversity experts as a "courageous" gesture. However, critics argue that the move may not be enough to address systemic racism and that the company's initial response could have been stronger. The real test will be what happens next, with a second allegation emerging of a black customer being denied restroom use in California.

images.alt_text: Sceptics say one afternoon of racial-tolerance training won't change much.

site_title: Opec, Russia find reasons to keep cutting output after hitting goal
summary: Opec and Russia have agreed to continue cutting oil production, despite achieving their goal of eliminating a 97% surplus in oil stockpiles. Saudi Energy Minister Khalid Al-Falih and Russian counterpart Alexander Novak said the cuts should continue to boost investment in oil and gas production. Despite crude prices hitting a three-year high, the ministers believe higher prices won't hurt demand, citing the global economy's capacity to absorb them. The production cuts are expected to continue until at least the end of 2018, with some analysts suggesting a potential extension in 2019.

images.alt_text: Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) secretary general Mohammed Barkindo (L), Saudi Energy Minister Khaled al-Faleh (C) and Russian Energy Minister Alexander Novak (R) attend a meeting of OPEC and non-OPEC members to assess compliance with production cuts and to discuss potential long-term cooperation, in Jeddah on April 20, 2018.

site_title: Tharman reappointed MAS chairman; Chaly Mah to join board as Lim Chee Onn retires
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam has been reappointed as chairman of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), replacing Lim Chee Onn. Four other MAS board members, including Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat and Enterprise Singapore chairman Peter Ong, have also been reappointed. Chaly Mah, a former Deloitte executive, has joined the MAS board as chairman of the risk committee, while Quek See Tiat will be reappointed chairman of the audit committee. Lim Chee Onn will retire from the MAS board on May 31.

site_title: Europe: Stocks decline in early trading
summary: Europe's stocks declined 0.2% in early trading, following a down session in Asia. Technology and materials shares were under pressure. The UK's FTSE 100 Index jumped 0.3% to its 11-week high, while Germany's DAX Index dipped 0.1%. France's CAC 40 Index rose 0.1% to its 11-week high.

site_title: Gold slips as US rate rise hopes, easing global tensions weigh
summary: Gold prices slipped 0.1-0.2% on Friday, heading for the first weekly decline in three weeks, due to expectations of higher US interest rates and easing global tensions. Market jitters over Western missile strikes in Syria eased, while the geopolitical outlook on the Korean Peninsula brightened. Investors are also relieved that no new US demands on trade came out of a summit between Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and US President Donald Trump.

site_title: TT International's Big Box winding up application hearing date fixed on May 11
summary: TT International has set a May 11 hearing date for Big Box's winding up application. TT International owns 51% of the retail and concert venue operator, which received a statutory demand from SCB Building Construction in March. This follows a dispute over construction work. The outcome of the hearing is uncertain, but it may impact TT International's financials and operations.

site_title: Emotions run at UOB shareholders' meet, first time in 60 years without Wee Cho Yaw
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) held its annual shareholders' meeting, with an emotional tone as chairman emeritus Wee Cho Yaw, 89, missed the event for the first time in 60 years. Wee's absence was due to feeling emotional, but he assured shareholders he remains committed to the bank's success. Shareholders raised concerns over misappropriation of funds, proxy processes, and dividend payments. UOB's new chairman, Wong Kan Seng, addressed the issues, and the bank clarified its share buybacks and dividend policies. Despite the concerns, the meeting concluded with a positive tone, and UOB's share price remained stable.

site_title: P&G ends its YouTube advertising boycott, but with a catch
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) has ended its 1-year YouTube advertising boycott, but only after reviewing and approving ads for select videos from under 10,000 channels, down from 3 million previously. The move comes after YouTube overhauled its policies and hired more human moderators to address concerns about extremist content. P&G's return to YouTube is seen as a coup for Google, which is working to regain advertiser trust after the ad boycott cast a shadow over its fastest-growing business.

site_title: Indonesia urges SE Asian economies to bargain together on TPP
summary: Indonesia's trade minister, Enggartiasto Lukita, urged Southeast Asian economies to join the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) and collectively negotiate accession terms. The six ASEAN countries that have not signed the pact, including Indonesia, Thailand, the Philippines, and others, would have a better bargaining position. Indonesia has been assessing the merits of joining the revised CPTPP, which was formed by 11 countries excluding the US. Thailand has already expressed interest in seeking membership this year.

site_title: CapitaLand Mall Trust Q1 DPU up 1.8% at 2.78 Singapore cents
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) reported a 1.8% increase in first-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.78 Singapore cents. Gross revenue rose 1.8% to S$175.2 million, driven by higher occupancy and car park income. Net property income increased 4.7% to S$125.7 million. However, shopper traffic fell 2.1% and tenants' sales per square foot dipped 0.2%. The portfolio occupancy remained at 98.9%. CMT's earnings per unit and net asset value per unit also rose.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore shares closed lower on Friday with the Straits Times Index down 25.35 points or 0.7% to 3,573.38. Meanwhile, Goldilocks Investment Company is working on an alternative restructuring plan for Noble Group, and Singapore casinos will face greater global competition. Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam has been reappointed MAS chairman, while Asian Healthcare Specialists and SLB Development debuted above their placement and IPO prices on Catalist.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks slip at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks slipped at the open on Friday, easing 0.20% to 30,647.94, following strong gains the previous day and tracking losses on Wall Street. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.38% each. The losses come as investors await US-EU trade talks and tariff developments.

site_title: SGX net profit rises 21% to record S$100.5m in Q3
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a record-breaking net profit of S$100.5 million in Q3, up 21% from the same period last year. Revenue increased by 10% to S$222.2 million, driven by a 5% rise in equities and fixed income, and a 17% increase in securities daily average traded value. An interim dividend of five Singapore cents per share was declared, unchanged from last year. CEO Loh Boon Chye attributed the growth to increased liquidity providers and investor outreach, with market activity expected to improve as investors seek to manage portfolio risk.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks hit as tech, real estate firms fall
summary: Hong Kong shares ended the week with sharp losses, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.94% due to a sell-off in technology firms following Apple's decline. Real estate firms were also affected by rising interest rate worries. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell, with losses of 1.47% and 2.00%, respectively. The losses were attributed to global economic concerns and US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks slump, won weakens, but both post weekly gains
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index declined 0.39% to 2,476.33, despite a weekly gain of 0.9%, as the won weakened against the dollar. The won lost 0.6% onshore and 0.02% offshore, while US stocks ended the previous session with losses. Foreigners were net sellers of 488 million won worth of shares. The KOSPI is up 0.8% so far this year and 2.18% in the past 30 days.

site_title: GE's adjusted profit tops estimates, shares rise
summary: General Electric Co posted quarterly results that topped expectations, with earnings from aviation, healthcare, and transportation offsetting weak power and oil-and-gas profits. The company earned an adjusted 16 cents per share, beating analyst estimates of 11 cents. GE reaffirmed its 2018 forecast and saw its shares rise 5.4% to $14.75 in premarket trading. The company's aviation, transportation, and healthcare businesses produced double-digit profit growth, while its power and oil-and-gas businesses faced challenges.

site_title: Hong Kong home owners now a minority as prices keep on rising
summary: Hong Kong home owners are now in the minority, with only 49.2% of domestic households owning their quarters as of 2017, the lowest since 1999. Property prices have tripled since 1999 due to abundant liquidity and limited supply, making Hong Kong the world's least affordable property market for an eighth year. The city's household home-ownership rate is lower than that of the US and Singapore, with the Hong Kong government unable to curb prices despite several market-cooling measures.

site_title: Wenger to end 22-year Arsenal stay at end of season
summary: Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger will end his 22-year tenure at the end of the season, citing it's the right time for him to step down. Wenger won three Premier League titles and seven FA Cups, but the team has struggled in recent years, missing out on Champions League qualification for the second consecutive season. The club's majority shareholder Stan Kroenke praised Wenger's contributions, and a search for a new successor will begin soon. Wenger's departure comes as Arsenal faces a crucial Europa League semi-final against Atletico Madrid.

images.alt_text: Arsene Wenger will finally bring his 22-year stay as Arsenal manager to a close at the end of the season, the Frenchman announced on Friday.

site_title: Datapulse board members keep their roles as proposed diversification pushed through at EGM
summary: Datapulse Technology's existing board members maintained their roles after a heated EGM meeting, where proposed diversification and new director appointments were also approved. The meeting saw over 200 shareholders, led by Ng Bie Tjin, grill the current board on independence and a controversial buyout. The proposed new directors addressed concerns, and the company agreed to release meeting minutes. The EGM also approved the current board's diversification agenda and a proposed special dividend. The existing board members will remain in place, with the proposed diversification pushed through.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: The 5 fastest-growing 'green jobs' in Singapore identified
summary: Indeed.com has identified the five fastest-growing "green jobs" in Singapore ahead of Earth Day. These roles include environmental consultants (115% growth), environmental specialists (109%), water treatment specialists (108%), environmental engineers (70%), and energy managers (94%). The growth highlights companies' increasing commitment to sustainability, with Singapore taking proactive steps to promote sustainability, including the implementation of a carbon tax by 2019. This trend is expected to continue, with more jobseekers considering roles in the high-growth and high-purpose sector.

site_title: Emas Offshore succeeds in appeal against Oslo delisting
summary: EMAS Offshore has successfully appealed against being delisted from the Oslo Stock Exchange, with the Stock Exchange Appeals Committee repealing the original resolution. The company, which is undergoing restructuring as a unit of Ezra Holdings, will remain listed on the Oslo Stock Exchange. The decision comes after Emas failed to disclose financial information within the prescribed deadlines, leading to the initial delisting.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Asia: Markets fall in line with Wall St as tech firms take a hit
summary: Asian markets fell on Friday, mirroring Wall Street's decline, as technology firms took a hit following Apple's 2.9% drop. The decline was fueled by concerns over the smartphone sector and a near-$1 billion sales forecast cut by chip supplier Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing. Other tech firms, including Samsung and LG Display, also fell. On broader markets, Taipei, Hong Kong, and Seoul declined, while Shanghai and Manila rose. The pound extended its losses against the dollar after the Bank of England's Mark Carney tempered expectations of an interest rate hike.

site_title: Civmec worker dies in accident at Perth wastewater treatment plant
summary: A Civmec worker has died in an industrial accident at the Woodman Point wastewater treatment plant near Perth, Western Australia. The incident occurred when a scaffold collapsed, trapping the worker under beams. Civmec has offered counselling support to its workforce and is cooperating with authorities to determine the cause of the accident. The company's CEO has sent condolences to the family and expressed support for all involved during this difficult time. The construction project is scheduled to be completed by the end of 2019.

site_title: Airlines need more women pilots at the controls
summary: Airlines are under pressure to increase the number of female pilots, with women making up just 5.2% of commercial pilots, despite being half of the cabin crew. The industry's lack of diversity is attributed to long training periods, seniority systems, and outdated attitudes. To address this issue, airlines are exploring quotas, funding for flight schools, and improving family policies. There are also sound self-interested reasons for carriers to increase the number of female pilots, as research has shown that women tend to have faster reaction times and take fewer risks, qualities beneficial for pilots.

site_title: Malaysian corruption allegedly spreads to Canada
summary: A Swiss environmental group, Bruno-Manser-Fonds, has sued several major Canadian financial firms, including Royal Bank of Canada, Toronto-Dominion Bank, and Manulife Financial Corp, alleging that Malaysian Governor Abdul Mahmud Taib's family funneled proceeds of corruption into Canadian real estate through their company, Sakto Group. The lawsuit claims that Taib's family used the money to fund Sakto's C$250 million real estate empire in Ottawa. Sakto has denied the allegations, calling the lawsuit a "fishing expedition" with insufficient evidence.

images.alt_text: Sarawak governor Abdul Mahmud Taib's family used the money to fund the expansion of the Ottawa-based real estate company Sakto Group's C$250 million (S$268 million) real estate empire, according to a lawsuit unsealed this week by an Ontario judge and provided to Bloomberg by the nonprofit and its law firm.

site_title: On sexual harassment complaint, Japan's Aso objects to font size
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso downplayed a sexual harassment complaint, stating that the font size of a complaint letter was too small. The complaint, filed by TV Asahi, alleged that a ministry official, Junichi Fukuda, harassed a reporter. Aso, who has denied the allegations, said a separate official would investigate the matter. The incident adds to other problems facing Aso and the finance ministry, including a scandal over document doctoring. Despite opposition calls for his resignation, Aso stated he has no intention to quit.

images.alt_text: When asked about a complaint from a TV station that the most senior official at his ministry sexually harassed a reporter, Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso said the font used on the complaint letter was too small.

site_title: Kathmandu airport closed after Malaysian jet skids off runway
summary: Kathmandu's Tribhuvan Airport was closed after a Malaysian Boeing 737 with 139 people on board skidded off the runway during takeoff. The incident occurred late Thursday, with the jet coming to a stop in mud about 30m from the runway. Nobody was hurt, but incoming flights were diverted while authorities attempted to move the plane. The cause of the problem is not immediately known, and the airport's closure status is uncertain. This incident follows a crash at Kathmandu airport last month, which killed 51 people.

site_title: Sterling extends slide after BOE governor Carney punctures rate hike bets
summary: Sterling fell 0.3% to a two-week low after Bank of England governor Mark Carney indicated the central bank may not raise interest rates in May due to mixed economic data. Investors had bid up the pound to a 2016 high, expecting a rate hike to curb inflation. Carney's comments, made after weaker wage growth and inflation data, suggested the rate rise was far from certain, causing sterling to slide.

site_title: Australia shares down as materials rally loses momentum; NZ down
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% on Friday, snapping a five-day winning streak, as material stocks lost momentum. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,868.8. Wall Street's three major indices closed lower, with tobacco and technology stocks leading the decline. The week finished 0.7% higher. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.6%. The Australian inquiry into financial sector misconduct claimed its first scalp, with AMP's CEO stepping down over board-level deception and misappropriation of funds.

site_title: New York city's landmarks chairwoman to resign
summary: New York City's Landmarks Preservation Commission chairwoman Meenakshi Srinivasan announced her resignation after nearly four years, citing a planned departure that had been months in the making. The decision comes amidst controversy over proposed rule changes that critics said would weaken historic building protections. Srinivasan had faced opposition from speakers at a hearing in March, with some calling for her removal. Her departure has been seen as part of a larger trend of departures among Mayor Bill de Blasio's appointees, including several female officials and prominent men.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end flat as attention shifts to earnings
summary: Tokyo stocks closed flat on Friday, ending a five-day winning streak, as investors awaited earnings reports by major companies. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.13% to 22,162.24, while the Topix index rose 0.05% to 1,751.13. Investors cashed in on recent gains, with some attributing the decline to a shift in attention away from US stocks, which had also experienced a decline.

site_title: Boxing legend Manny Pacquiao says age no barrier to success
summary: Manny Pacquiao, 39, is gearing up for a fight against Lucas Matthysse for the World Boxing Association welterweight belt on July 15 in Kuala Lumpur. Despite concerns about his age, Pacquiao dismissed such concerns, saying discipline in training and preparation matter more. He stated that the fight against Matthysse would not be his last, and he plans to retire in the Philippines, where he wants his final bout to take place. Pacquiao has been a senator in the Philippine parliament and has expressed a desire to return to politics, but prioritizes boxing for now.

site_title: Indonesia urges Southeast Asian economies to bargain together on TPP
summary: Indonesia's trade minister, Enggartiasto Lukita, urged Southeast Asian countries to join the revised Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for the Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) to negotiate better accession terms. Indonesia, along with Thailand, the Philippines, Myanmar, Cambodia, and Laos, has not signed the pact. Lukita noted that the six ASEAN members could collectively bargain for better terms. This comes as the US has not re-signed the pact under President Trump's administration. Indonesia had previously expressed interest in joining the CPTPP, but instead focused on bilateral and multilateral agreements like the China-led Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP).

site_title: China's ZTE slams US ban on sales, says company's survival at risk
summary: China's ZTE Corp has responded to a US ban on sales, saying the ban is unfair and threatens its survival. The US Commerce Department imposed a seven-year ban on sales to ZTE for breaking a settlement agreement, citing repeated false statements. ZTE vows to safeguard its interests through all legal means, despite a senior US Commerce Department official stating it's unlikely the ban will be lifted. The ban has raised tensions between China and the US, with trade war fears escalating.

site_title: Alliance Mineral not taking loan from Burwill after separate debt funding secured
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets, a CATALIST-listed firm, has decided not to proceed with a proposed A$4.8 million loan from Hong Kong-listed Burwill Commodity after securing A$13 million in debt funding and an A$25 million underwritten share placement. Both parties have mutually agreed to discontinue talks on the loan, citing the secured funding as a sufficient alternative. This decision comes after a binding term sheet and letter of variation were signed in October 2017.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,573.92, down 0.7%
summary: Singapore stocks closed down 0.7% at 3,573.92, with the Straits Times Index dropping 24.81 points. Losers outnumbered gainers 214 to 117, with about 777.9 million shares worth S$764.9 million traded. Ezion rose 2.9%, while Venture Corp fell 11.7% and Keppel Corp gained 1.9%. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: 'Fearless Girl' to move, and she may take the Wall Street bull with her
summary: The "Fearless Girl" statue, which has been a popular attraction in Lower Manhattan since its placement near the Charging Bull in March 2017, will be relocated to a spot facing the New York Stock Exchange. The move is due to safety concerns and the potential for crowds to pose a hazard. The Charging Bull, created by Arturo Di Modica, is also at risk of being moved, with Di Modica's lawyers threatening to take legal action. The city aims to keep the two statues together, with Mayor Bill de Blasio stating that the "Fearless Girl" should stand up to the bull.

site_title: Australia vows crackdown on corporate misconduct as bank inquiry claims AMP scalp
summary: Australia's government vows to crack down on corporate misconduct following revelations of board-level deception and misappropriation of funds at AMP Ltd, the country's largest wealth manager. CEO Craig Meller steps down amid a Royal Commission inquiry that has exposed widespread misconduct, including 80,000 consumers losing A$5 billion in bad advice. The government plans to double prison terms, raise financial penalties, and increase regulatory powers to combat financial crimes, with Treasurer Scott Morrison announcing new measures including 10-year prison sentences and fines of up to A$210 million.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks edge down, won falls
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 0.30% to 2,478.67, while the Korean won depreciated 0.57% to 1,067.6 per dollar. Bond yields rose, and foreigners were net sellers of 164.81 billion won worth of shares. The US dollar has risen 0.1% against the won this year, with the won's high for the year at 1,053.55 per dollar.

site_title: Japanese companies see big things in small-scale industrial robots
summary: Japanese companies are increasingly adopting small-scale industrial robots, known as collaborative robots or "cobots," to help with assembly line tasks without replacing human workers. As workforces age, cobots are seen as a key way to maintain productivity. Despite initial underestimation by Japanese robot manufacturers, the cobots segment is expected to grow to over $10 billion by 2028, driven by their safety, simplicity, and ability to directly assist human workers. Companies like Fanuc and Yaskawa Electric are now trying to catch up, with Universal Robots leading the market with its cobot technology.

site_title: Hong Kong exchange to announce new listing rules on Tuesday
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd (HKEX) announced new listing rules on Tuesday, which will take effect from April 30. The new rules aim to encourage early-stage biotech companies to list on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, and also make it easier for companies listed overseas to consider Hong Kong as a secondary listing venue. The changes are expected to pave the way for more stock market debuts by biotech companies, and provide a more favorable environment for companies with dual-class shares.

site_title: Singapore casinos will face greater global competition, disruption, says minister
summary: Singapore's casinos face increased global competition and technological disruption, according to Second Minister for Manpower and Home Affairs Josephine Teo. The country's piecemeal approach to regulating gambling products will not be sustainable, she said. Teo highlighted the need for greater consolidation of casino regulatory functions to address the growing complexities of the gaming landscape. The Ministry of Home Affairs is studying the broader gaming regulatory regime in Singapore to prepare for these developments. Teo urged the Casino Regulatory Authority to adapt to new demands, emphasizing the need for a "holistic and coherent" system.

site_title: Struggling Mattel names fourth CEO in four years
summary: Mattel, the maker of Barbie, has announced its fourth CEO in four years as Margo Georgiadis steps down to pursue a new opportunity. She will be replaced by Ynon Kreiz, a former head of Maker Studios and current Mattel board member. Kreiz brings expertise in digital, media, and entertainment, and is also in line to replace executive chairman Christopher Sinclair, who will retire in June. Mattel struggles to turn around a slump that has seen it overtaken in sales by Hasbro, with a reported loss of $1.1 billion in 2017.

site_title: Deutsche Bank flub said to briefly send away 28b euros
summary: Deutsche Bank accidentally sent 28 billion euros (S$45.4 billion) to an exchange as part of its daily derivatives dealings, exceeding the amount it was due to post. The error occurred in the final weeks of former CEO John Cryan's tenure and was quickly spotted, with no financial harm suffered. The incident raises questions about the bank's risk and control processes, prompting an internal review and steps to prevent recurrence. Analysts criticize Cryan's leadership and the bank's internal controls, with some suggesting the problem is too big to be immediately fixed.

site_title: Asian Healthcare Specialists, SLB debut above placement, IPO prices on Catalist
summary: Asian Healthcare Specialists (AHS) and SLB Development debuted above their placement and IPO prices on the Catalist market. AHS traded at S$0.35, up from 34.5 Singapore cents, with 12.9 million units changing hands. SLB Development traded at S$0.24, down from S$0.26, but above its IPO price, after 30.5 million units changed hands. The public tranche of SLB's IPO was 20.6 times subscribed.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Grab launches GrabShuttle school-bus service
summary: Grab, a ride-sharing app, has launched GrabShuttle for Schools in Singapore, offering a more convenient and flexible option for students and school staff. The service allows users to choose from various vehicle sizes and commit for a minimum of two months. Prices start from S$130 per month, with real-time tracking and direct contact with drivers available for parents. This service differs from traditional bus operators, which often require quarter-year payments. By offering personalized and flexible transport options, Grab aims to help schoolchildren and staff arrive at their destinations more quickly and efficiently.

site_title: Former New York mayor Giuliani joins Trump legal team
summary: Former New York mayor Rudy Giuliani is joining President Donald Trump's personal legal team, according to Trump lawyer Jay Sekulow. This move comes after a week of federal agents raiding Trump lawyer Michael Cohen's offices and residence. Giuliani expressed his appreciation for Trump's decision to allow him to assist in the matter, stating he hopes to negotiate an end to the challenges for the country's good. The addition of Giuliani, along with lawyers Jane Serene Raskin and Marty Raskin, aims to bolster the team facing numerous legal challenges, including the Russia investigation and allegations against Trump's family businesses.

site_title: China Environment ceases China units' operations; no intention to pay off civil suit liabilities
summary: China Environment, a MAINBOARD-listed company, has ceased business operations in its China subsidiaries due to court-ordered auctions of properties secured under loans. The company awaits completion of auctions before making further decisions, citing limited liability entities and no intention to pay off civil suit liabilities. Enforcement orders totaling 151 million yuan have been taken out against subsidiaries, and the company is finalizing its financial statements for FY13-FY17. Annual general meetings for fiscal years 2013-2017 are expected by the end of June 2018.

site_title: US to drop curbs on drone tech to boost arms sales
summary: The US has relaxed restrictions on the sale of advanced drones to its allies, aiming to boost arms sales and compete with China in the global arms market. The move, announced by the White House, will allow US arms firms to directly market drones to authorized allies, enabling them to compete against Chinese "knock-offs." The policy change is seen as part of President Trump's "America First" slogan and aims to promote US exports and jobs, with the potential to grow the drone market to $50 billion in a decade.

site_title: Nasa lunar "Gateway" space station will soon begin construction
summary: NASA's Lunar Orbital Platform-Gateway, a space station intended for moon studies and deep-space missions, will begin construction in early 2019. The first contract for the platform will be awarded for power and propulsion elements, followed by habitation components, with the platform expected to orbit the moon by 2025. The Gateway will carry a four-astronaut crew on 30-day missions and support NASA's goal of returning humans to the moon and eventually sending them to Mars. The project aims to improve orbital mechanics around the moon and reduce travel times for deep-space missions.

images.alt_text: Nasa's goal of returning to the moon should see a major push in early 2019, when the agency awards its first contract for the lunar "Gateway" program.

site_title: Australia: Shares lose steam as materials retreat; New Zealand down
summary: Australian shares fell 0.1% to 5,873.6, despite being on track to finish the week higher for the third time in a row, due to a weak finish on Wall Street. The rally in commodity prices paused, with nickel and aluminium retreating after soaring to multi-year highs. Gold miner Evolution Mining was the top loser, down 8.9% in its biggest intraday drop since 2017. In New Zealand, the benchmark index fell 0.3% due to losses in healthcare stocks.

site_title: Singapore lawyers Satbir Walia, Thomas England make partner at Clifford Chance
summary: Singapore lawyers Satbir Walia and Thomas England have been promoted to partners at Clifford Chance, effective May 1. The duo, along with 26 other lawyers worldwide, will focus on key areas such as technology, antitrust, pensions, and restructuring. Walia advises on corporate and private equity deals, while England focuses on banking work, particularly in South-east Asia. The promotions aim to drive the firm's progress in a fast-shifting legal landscape, bolstering partner capabilities in critical areas for clients.

images.alt_text: Clifford Chance in Asia Pacific welcomes six new partners and two in Singapore. From left to right: Bryan Koo in Hong Kong, Hans Menski in Tokyo, Hong Zhang in Beijing, Satbir Walia in Singapore, Thomas England in Singapore and Yong Bai in Beijing

site_title: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust buys 21 Europe properties from Frasers Property
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) has acquired 21 European properties, valued at 596.8 million euros (S$972.8 million), from its sponsor Frasers Property. The portfolio consists of 17 German and four Dutch properties. FLT plans to fund the acquisition through a private placement of new units and/or a non-renounceable preferential offering, with completion targeted by June 2018. The acquisition was made through FLT Europe, the trustee of FLT, and is subject to an extraordinary general meeting.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Stocks to watch: Datapulse, ESR-Reit, Frasers Commercial Trust, Asian Healthcare Specialists, SLB Development
summary: Datapulse Technology reaffirmed no intention of paying a proposed interim 20 Singapore cents dividend, citing an extraordinary general meeting to vote on replacing directors and a diversification plan. ESR-Reit's distribution per unit fell 15.6% to 0.847 Singapore cents for the first quarter. Frasers Commercial Trust's distribution per unit decreased 4.4% to 2.40 Singapore cents. Asian Healthcare Specialists placed 46.9 million new shares ahead of a listing on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board. SLB Development will commence trading on the Catalist board on April 20.

site_title: Smiling Orchids
summary: The Singapore Garden Festival (SGF) Orchid Show will take place from April 21 to 29 at the National Orchid Garden and parts of the Singapore Botanic Gardens. The event coincides with the 125th anniversary of Singapore's national flower, the Vanda Miss Joaquim, and features local and international orchid growers competing in a landscape display. An educational exhibition, talks, demonstrations, guided tours, and a marketplace will also be available, offering insights into the orchid breeding industry and plant-related products.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.17 points to 1,895.01. Trading volume was 121.94 million lots worth RM41.36 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 109 to 87. The market reaction was not directly related to the article's other content, which covered Singapore stocks, Asia, Europe, and the US.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, following drops on Wall Street, as investors await major company earnings reports. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.26% and the Topix index dropped 0.10%. This decline comes amid uncertainty over global economic trends and US trade policies.

site_title: StarHub names Peter Kaliaropoulos as chief executive after global search
summary: StarHub appoints Australian Peter Kaliaropoulos as its new chief executive, effective July 9, 2018, after a global executive search. He replaces Tan Tong Hai, who stepped down to pursue personal interests. Kaliaropoulos brings 35 years of experience in the telecom industry, having held senior roles at companies including Zain Saudi Arabia and BT Asia Pacific. The board is confident in his ability to lead StarHub in pursuing new opportunities and managing industry challenges.

site_title: Rockets hit airport in Libya's capital, damaging passenger jet
summary: Rockets hit Libya's Mitiga airport, damaging a passenger jet, an Airbus 320, at around 2am on April 19, 2018. No one was injured in the attack, which was blamed on men loyal to a militia leader. The incident highlights the fragile security in Libya, where armed groups have regularly attacked transport hubs. The airport, the only operating airport in Tripoli, has struggled to maintain services due to attacks on planes, and rival governments have controlled the city since 2011.

site_title: Wells Fargo close to US$1b US settlement: reports
summary: Wells Fargo is close to settling a US$1 billion probe over its risk management policies in the mortgage and auto lending businesses. The settlement, reportedly finalized soon, comes after regulators proposed the penalty and follows a series of regulatory issues, including a fake account scandal and a Federal Reserve order to halt expansion until governance improves. This is the latest blow to the banking giant, which has faced criticism from investors and lawmakers, and comes ahead of its annual shareholder meeting.

site_title: Europe: Publicis leads as earnings dominate trading session
summary: European stocks ended flat, despite strong earnings reports from Publicis, WPP, and industrial groups ABB and Siemens. Publicis led the pack with a 7.3% gain, while ABB rose 4.6% and Siemens 1.4%. However, tobacco sector stocks fell after Philip Morris' weak earnings, and tech stocks were weighed down by Taiwan Semiconductor's disappointing results. The Stoxx 600 index stalled at six-week highs, with the main indexes closing little changed.

site_title: Goldilocks says working on alternative restructuring plan for Noble; includes trade finance, working capital
summary: Goldilocks Investment Company is working on an alternative restructuring plan for Noble Group, including trade finance and working capital. The plan aims to preserve value for shareholders and ensure the company's long-term survival. Goldilocks and a consortium of investors will provide Noble with working capital and trade finance, and have proposed five non-executive directors to be nominated at Noble's upcoming AGM. The plan is seen as a response to Noble's chairman Paul Brough's turnaround proposals, which were previously ignored by the board.

images.alt_text: Noble Group has rejected substantial shareholder Goldilocks' attempt to nominate five non-executive directors at its upcoming annual general meeting (AGM) on April 30.
Janice Heng

site_title: Qualcomm says China regulators prompt delay of NXP merger
