summary: US mobile chipmaker Qualcomm has delayed its planned merger with Dutch rival NXP to July 25, after Chinese regulators prompted the extension. The merger, valued at over $50 billion, aims to broaden Qualcomm's product portfolio with NXP's sensors and microprocessors. The deal has received antitrust clearance from eight of nine required government bodies worldwide, but remains pending in China. Qualcomm has agreed to pay NXP a termination fee if the merger doesn't clear all regulatory hurdles by the new deadline.

site_title: US police chief apologises after Starbucks arrests uproar
summary: Philadelphia's police chief, Richard Ross, apologized for the arrest of two black men at a Starbucks store, admitting he "failed miserably" in his initial response. The arrest sparked uproar after a video showed officers questioning and handcuffing the pair despite no resistance. Ross acknowledged the issue of race is a larger problem and vowed to implement new policy guidelines to handle similar situations in the future. Starbucks CEO Kevin Johnson has also apologized and ordered racial-bias education for all US stores and corporate offices.

site_title: Japan consumer prices edge up 0.9% in March
summary: Japan's consumer prices rose 0.9% in March, slightly weaker than the previous month, but still below the 2.0% target. This marks the eighth consecutive quarter of economic growth. Core inflation, excluding volatile food prices, stood at 0.9%, down from 1.0% in the previous month. The Bank of Japan's ultra-loose monetary policy appears to be having limited impact, and the central bank has signaled no plans to drop it. Japan continues to struggle with deflation, with inflation rates remaining below the desired level.

images.alt_text: Japan's consumer prices edged up 0.9 per cent in March, government data showed Friday, but inflation was slightly weaker than the previous month and still far below a longstanding target.

site_title: IMF's Lagarde warns against harming trade, investment
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde warned against harming trade and investment, citing escalating US-China tensions as a key downside risk to the global economic recovery. She urged governments to resolve disputes through dialogue and avoid protectionism, which could erode business confidence and choke off investment. The IMF listed trade tensions as a major risk, particularly for the poorest countries, and urged countries to address their own trade barriers. Lagarde also praised US corporate tax reform and urged the US to reduce its debt and deficits.

site_title: Lance Armstrong to pay US$5m settlement in US fraud case: lawyer
summary: Lance Armstrong has agreed to pay a $5 million settlement to settle a federal fraud case related to his alleged doping during his Tour de France wins. The settlement avoids a potential $100 million in damages and covers the costs of former teammate Floyd Landis. Armstrong had previously admitted to using performance-enhancing substances and was banned from competitions for life. The settlement marks a conclusion to the case, allowing Armstrong to move forward with his life, including his work as a cancer survivor and his passion for sports.

site_title: Ex-SPH deputy CEO Patrick Daniel joins SembMarine board as independent director
summary: SembCorp Marine announced the appointment of Patrick Daniel as an additional independent director, effective April 20, 2018. Daniel, a former deputy CEO of Singapore Press Holdings, joined the audit and executive resource & compensation committees. He brings experience as editor of The Business Times and managing editor of English and Malay newspapers.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: NTUC working on services for workers and their families
summary: NTUC Secretary-General Chan Chun Sing announced plans to integrate various social enterprises to provide services to workers and their families, utilizing data analysis. The Kampung Admiralty project, set to launch, will feature NTUC-run outlets and services, including childcare, food, and healthcare. NTUC has also established a Data and Analytics Centre of Excellence to study spending patterns of its 2 million NTUC Plus cardholders, aiming to offer personalized promotions and discounts.

site_title: AMP CEO resigns over bank misconduct revelations
summary: AMP CEO Craig Meller resigned following revelations of widespread abuses, including charging thousands of customers for services never received. The bank admitted to misleading the stock market watchdog and intervening in a report on the Royal Commission. Senior executives also charged clients for non-existent services, affecting 15,700 clients between 2009 and 2016. A non-executive board member, Mike Wilkins, was appointed acting CEO, and an independent expert will review AMP's regulatory reporting and governance processes. The Royal Commission's findings have led to harsh new penalties for bank misconduct announced by the Australian government.

site_title: May-July COE quota to drop 4%
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has announced a 4% drop in the Certificate of Entitlement (COE) pool for the coming three months, with 24,614 COEs available from May to July. Car COEs have fallen by 7.9% and the Open category has decreased by 1.7%. Motorcycle COEs have increased by 2.7%, while commercial vehicle COEs have risen by 23.7% to 610. This is the second time a zero-growth policy has been applied to the COE pool.

site_title: The future of warfare in BT Weekend
summary: Artificial intelligence and robotics are transforming warfare, altering battle lines and creating new defense sector businesses. This is part of an emerging trend that will reshape the future of conflict.

site_title: Admaterials Technologies R&D efforts pay off with increase in revenues
summary: Admaterials Technologies, a Singapore-based materials testing firm, has seen a significant increase in revenues after investing in research and development (R&D) efforts. Through collaboration with A*Star, the company has expanded its services to include environmental and microbiological testing, resulting in a 25% increase in productivity and a 30% rise in revenue over three years. The company's R&D expenditure has quadrupled to S$300,000 annually, and its revenue has grown from S$3.1 million to S$12.7 million over the past five years. This success demonstrates the impact of R&D investments on SMEs.

site_title: Frasers Commercial Trust DPU down 4.4% to 2.40 Singapore cents for Q2
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.40 Singapore cents for Q2, down 4.4% from the previous year. Gross revenue fell 18% to S$33 million, and net property income (NPI) fell 25.3% to S$22.4 million. Lower occupancy rates, lease termination, and the weaker Australian dollar contributed to the decline. However, total distributable income for Q2 increased 2.9% to S$20.6 million, driven by the maiden contribution from Farnborough Business Park.

images.alt_text: The gross revenue and NPI figures are before contribution from FCOT's 50 per cent indirect interest in Farnborough Business Park, which is held as a joint venture and equity-accounted. The acquisition was completed on Jan 29, 2018.
Janice Heng

site_title: Oil pulls back from gains; Opec says glut nearly gone
summary: Oil prices surged to 2014 highs on Thursday, with US West Texas Intermediate crude futures reaching $69.56 a barrel and Brent crude futures hitting $74.75 a barrel. The global oil glut is nearly gone, according to an Opec and non-Opec technical panel, thanks to a supply cut deal in place since 2017. Traders expect prices to reach $70, but may face resistance, with some speculating that the market may level out in a few weeks.

site_title: P&G to buy Merck's consumer health business for 3.4b euros
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) agreed to acquire Merck's consumer health business for approximately 3.4 billion euros, ending a joint venture with Teva Pharmaceutical Industries. The deal includes vitamin brands like Seven Seas and expands P&G's presence in Latin American and Asian markets. Merck's pharma unit will focus on its pipeline, and about 3,300 employees could join P&G upon completion. The acquisition price suggests a valuation of 4.7 times sales and 19 times operating profit.

site_title: ESR-Reit DPU down 15.6% to 0.847 Singapore cent for Q1 with larger unitholder base
summary: ESR-Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) fell 15.6% to 0.847 Singapore cents for Q1, due to a larger unitholder base after new units were issued. Gross revenue rose 21.2% to S$33.6 million, while net property income rose 20.8% to S$23.8 million. Despite this, distributable income was up 2.4% year-on-year. The adjusted DPU for the first quarter would have been higher at 1.008 cents.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Monsanto faces strong resistance movement
summary: Monsanto, a US agribusiness giant, is facing a lawsuit alleging its pesticide causes cancer. Over 300 plaintiffs in a federal court in San Francisco have filed a lawsuit, with the case being closely watched globally. The company has denied harm from its genetically modified seeds, pesticides, and food products. The US is not the only country to ban GM products, with over half of European Union countries and more than 30 countries in total having banned GM products. The outcome of the lawsuit is uncertain, but the case highlights ongoing debate over the safety of GM products.

site_title: Band of England's Carney dampens expectations for May rate hike, sees "mixed" data
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney dampened expectations for a May interest rate hike, citing "mixed" economic data and highlighting that there are other meetings this year. Sterling dropped against the US dollar to its lowest level since April 9, with Carney noting that a rate hike this year is "likely". However, he emphasized that the timing is less important than the overall path of interest rates.

site_title: China challenges Australia warships in South China Sea: report
summary: Australian warships in the South China Sea were challenged by the Chinese military, according to Australian defence officials. The ships, Anzac, Toowoomba, and Success, sailed through the disputed waters while on a three-month deployment in South-east Asia. The interactions with the Chinese navy were described as "polite but robust." The Australian Defence Force has maintained a program of international engagement in the region, exercising rights under international law to freedom of navigation and overflight. China has been constructing islands and military facilities in the South China Sea, sparking concerns about free movement and strategic reach.

site_title: Riksbank warned against creating e-krona
summary: The Swedish central bank, Riksbank, has been warned against creating an electronic currency, or e-krona, by the Swedish Bankers' Association, citing concerns it would compete with private banks and create unnecessary complexity. The association's CEO, Hans Lindberg, argues that the Riksbank should focus on wholesale banking and avoid forcing banks to handle cash, as this could run into EU law. The move comes as Sweden moves towards becoming a cashless society, with declining cash circulation and recent warnings from the Bank for International Settlements about the risks of a central bank digital currency.

site_title: Transformation in Singapore tourism
summary: Singapore's tourism sector is undergoing a transformation, driven by shifts in global market trends, consumer behavior, and technological advancements. The country aims to attract more quality visitors, particularly from Asia, while adapting to disruptions in the industry. Key strategies include new marketing approaches, destination refresh, business refresh, and leveraging data and technology. These efforts focus on enhancing Singapore's appeal, investing in new developments, and supporting local events and industries to drive growth and competitiveness. The sector will continue to evolve, and those who adapt most nimbly to change are likely to succeed.

site_title: A cousin of the martini, the Alaska, strikes gold
summary: The Alaska, a gin-based cocktail, has gained popularity in recent years, appearing on menus in major US cities such as San Francisco, Chicago, and New York. The drink, which typically combines gin, yellow Chartreuse, and orange bitters, has its roots in the 1910s and was previously considered a "forgotten classic." Young cocktail bartenders have championed the drink, highlighting its unique flavor profile and versatility. Different variations of the Alaska are being created, with some using London Dry gin and others opting for sweeter Old Tom gin, which has recently experienced a revival.

images.alt_text: An Alaska cocktail is poured at Golden Teardrops, a subterranean cocktail bar that opened late last year in Chicago.

site_title: EU, Singapore a step closer to signing free trade agreement
summary: The European Commission has presented the outcome of EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA) negotiations to the European Council, marking a step closer to signing and concluding the agreement. The initialled agreement needs approval by the Council of Ministers and ratification by the European Parliament. This move aims to strengthen trade ties between the EU and Singapore, promoting economic growth and cooperation in various sectors.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: US: Stocks drop on mixed earnings, higher bond yields
summary: US stocks declined on Thursday, with the Dow Jones falling 0.3% to 24,664.89, the S&P 500 shedding 0.6% to 2,693.13, and the Nasdaq Composite Index dropping 0.8% to 7,238.06. Mixed corporate earnings reports and a jump in Treasury bond yields, which revived concerns about higher interest rates, contributed to the decline.

site_title: German homes market making up for lost ground, says developer
summary: German home prices are rising at the fastest pace in decades, with a 60% appreciation since 2010. This surge has revived concerns about a potential property bubble, with Fitch predicting 5% price gains this year and Deutsche Bank warning of rising risk. However, developers like Michael Zahn of Deutsche Wohnen see upside potential, citing rising population, low unemployment, and high liquidity. The Bundesbank has expressed concern that some locations, such as Berlin and Frankfurt, may be overvalued by 35%.

site_title: China may be set for rare property defaults, says fund manager
summary: China may experience rare property defaults due to rising interest rates and government leverage curbs. Fund manager Neuberger Berman warns that smaller property firms may miss payments on bonds this year, citing high leverage and weak cash flows. With 110 billion yuan of onshore note maturities and 205 billion yuan of bonds to sell, developers with high debt-to-asset ratios face high default risks.

site_title: Euro stumbles as yield rise supports US dollar
summary: The euro briefly reached $1.24 against the US dollar but fell 0.1% to $1.2365 due to a rise in long-term US bond yields supporting the dollar. Investor caution and concerns about the eurozone economy's rebound and potential European Central Bank rate hikes contributed to the modest moves. Analysts attribute the dollar's strength to uncertainty surrounding US President Trump's trade and economic policies, as well as geopolitical events. The euro is expected to rise towards $1.30 in 12 months, but may fall in the short-term due to the ECB's potential delay in raising rates.

site_title: Australian banks told to restore trust as scandal inquiry continues
summary: Australian banks face ongoing scrutiny as a scandal inquiry continues, with executives set to face questioning over misappropriation of fees and providing bad advice to clients. The Royal Commission, launched two months ago, has found over 80,000 consumers affected by bad advice, resulting in losses of over A$5 billion. Financial Services Minister Kelly O'Dwyer stated that banks must regain public trust, with jail terms possible for executives found guilty. The inquiry, which could lead to legislative changes and prosecutions, aims to restore confidence in the sector.

images.alt_text: Jail terms are possible after executives at AMP Ltd admitted it had lied to the corporate regulator to cover up charging thousands of customers for services they did not provide..
Ms O'Dwyer says Australian banks need to explain how they are going to regain the trust of their customers.

site_title: The Little Red Dot In Milan
summary: Singaporean designers showcased their work at Milan Design Week, highlighting the country's unique cultural elements. Students from the Kyoto Design Lab and Design Incubation Centre created interpretations of Japanese culture, such as a chess table and wall lights, which were then exchanged with students from Italy and Singapore. Other designers, including Gabriel Tan and Lanzavecchia + Wai, showcased innovative furniture pieces that incorporated local materials and designs. The Urban Design Festival, hosted by Lopelab, featured talks, workshops, and installations, while the Handmade exhibition featured unique one-off pieces by Singaporean designers.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: For The Record
summary: Fred Perry is partnering with independent record stores to give away tote bags designed by local illustrator Ella Zheng on Record Store Day. The tote bags are part of a scratch-and-win contest, offering prizes including a turntable, vouchers, and more. Fans can follow @fredperrysg on social media for more details.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Keppel Corp Q1 profit up 34% buoyed by property division
summary: Keppel Corp's Q1 net profit rose 33.7% to S$337.5 million, driven by its property division's 298% surge in net profit. The group's multi-business strategy helped deliver "creditable results amid the volatile environment." The O&M division incurred a net loss of S$23 million, while the investment division swung into a net loss of S$44 million. Despite this, the group's property division is planning to launch homes in Singapore and is well-positioned to seize opportunities when the market picks up.

site_title: Rediscovering Your 'Hood
summary: The Singapore Heritage Festival concluded with its 15th edition, featuring curated programs at five locations across the island. The festival showcased the island's industrial heritage, with events at Jurong including a recreated defunct drive-in cinema. The event also highlighted local culture through guided tours, exhibitions, and performances. This year's festival aimed to give the public a new perspective on Singapore's history and identity.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: More questions over DeClout's deployment of loan proceeds
summary: DeClout, a Singaporean company, has faced criticism over its loan agreement with S$10 million, which pledges all its assets, including its SGX-listed subsidiary Procurri, to unnamed individuals. The loan's deployment has raised corporate governance concerns, with questions about its impact on minority shareholders and the company's core asset Procurri. DeClout has started deploying the loan proceeds, including a US$850,000 investment in an inactive Indonesian company, with no clear due diligence performed. The lead independent director at both DeClout and Procurri is also a single individual, further sparking concerns.

site_title: Comcast bid more than Disney for 21st Century Fox
summary: Comcast made an all-stock proposal to buy 21st Century Fox worth $34.41 per share in November, but was rebuffed by the company's board due to concerns over a breakup fee in case of regulatory rejection. In contrast, Disney offered a $2.5 billion fee and was ultimately chosen as the buyer in a deal valued at $52.4 billion. Comcast's proposal was deemed unacceptable due to its plans for divesting problematic assets, and Fox's board deemed Disney's stock more valuable and a better strategic fit for its assets.

site_title: In Australia, axe marks the sport
summary: Australia is experiencing a wood-chopping renaissance, with more women and children competing in the male-dominated sport. The sport, which originated as a survival skill for European settlers, has seen a surge in popularity, with increased sponsorship and prize money. Teenage sensation Curtis Bennett, 18, and his family, including his father Simon and sister Madii, are among the rising stars of the sport. The sport's physical and technical demands require athleticism and skill, with events such as the Jack and Jill Double Handed Sawing competition attracting top competitors.

images.alt_text: "Even now when I pick up an axe I want to start crying because I know how hard it is and just everything hurts in your body when you're doing it." - Madii Bennett (left) partnering Brayden Myer in the Jack and Jill Double Handed Sawing competition.
Curtis Bennett practising his wood-chopping skills for competition.

site_title: Hong Kong's HK$51.3b intervention mops up 30% of cash
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) intervened with a record HK$51.3 billion in buying the local currency to defend its peg to the US dollar, draining about 30% of liquidity. This move came as the city's three-month borrowing cost spiked to its highest level this year, and the aggregate balance of interbank liquidity will be reduced to HK$128.5 billion. The HKMA expects the liquidity to drop to low levels, potentially narrowing the gap between US and HK rates.

site_title: When construction noise impacts electricity consumption
summary: Construction noise in Singapore has been found to increase electricity consumption by nearly 7% in households near construction sites, resulting in an additional S$77 per household annually. This is due to households using air-conditioners and fans to cope with the noise, leading to higher energy bills. Even after construction ends, households tend to continue using more electricity and being less adaptable to natural ventilation, indicating habit persistence. The study suggests that measures such as smart electricity devices andQuieter Construction Fund initiatives can help reduce noise and energy consumption.

site_title: DLF to explain how it's cashing in on India land
summary: India's largest property developer DLF will provide investors with a roadmap for developing its 235 million sq ft land bank, aiming to unlock value in its large assets. The company will share details on new residential projects and expected cash flow, following concerns about the slow pace of monetization. DLF plans to construct several projects, including a 7 million sq ft residential project in Delhi and commercial properties in Chennai and Hyderabad, to cut dependence on the National Capital Region.

site_title: Shop And Stretch
summary: A new boutique fitness studio, Absolute You, has opened in Orchard, Singapore, offering three types of classes: rhythm cycling, yoga, and Pilates Reformer. The studio's focus is on 360-degree fitness, emphasizing flexibility, core strength, and cardiovascular fitness. According to Claire Bostock, chief business officer, the classes cater to these three areas, providing a comprehensive fitness experience for members.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Kampong Bugis master developer tender to be launched in 1 to 2 years
summary: A tender for a master developer to redevelop Kampong Bugis into a car-lite residential precinct is expected to be launched in 1-2 years. The 13-hectare site, including the former Kallang Gasworks area, will have a 99-year leasehold. Remediation works are required before redevelopment can begin, as the site needs to be cleared of pollutants from the former gasworks facility. The project aims to create a car-lite residential precinct with a focus on sustainability and community living.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of the Kallang Riverside Park. The area will be car-lite, meaning only one parking space will be provided for every two residences - 50 per cent below the current minimum standard.

site_title: North seeks 'complete denuclearisation', says Moon, as US vows continued pressure
summary: North Korea has expressed commitment to "complete denuclearisation" of the Korean peninsula, according to South Korean President Moon Jae In. The US vows to maintain "maximum pressure" on Pyongyang, while Moon believes a peace agreement and international aid are possible if the North denuclearises. A summit between the two Koreas and the US is planned for May or June, with US President Donald Trump warning that he will call it off if it doesn't produce results.

site_title: Sip & Sup
summary: Plum & Toro, a Japanese-inspired cocktail bar, has opened at the Intercontinental Robertson Quay, offering plum wine and fatty tuna-based menu items such as uni corn and grilled lobster. The bar also features a kappo-style dining setup and trendy high balls. Located at #02-07 Intercontinental Robertson Quay, Plum & Toro provides a unique dining experience with modern bites and a range of drinks.

site_title: Facebook to put 1.5 billion users out of reach of new EU privacy law
summary: Facebook plans to exclude 1.5 billion users from the new EU privacy law, which would protect almost 1.9 billion users worldwide. The law restricts what companies can do with people's online data. Facebook members outside the US and Canada, governed by the company's international headquarters in Ireland, will be affected. The company is making changes to ensure the number of users protected by the law is smaller, effectively putting them out of reach.

site_title: Lian Beng JV buys Sembawang Shopping Centre from CapitaLand Mall Trust
summary: Lian Beng JV, a 50-50 joint venture of Lian Beng Group and Apricot Capital, has bought Sembawang Shopping Centre from CapitaLand Mall Trust for S$248 million, nearly doubling the property's valuation from S$126 million. The purchase price works out to S$1,203 per sq ft and S$1,727 per sq ft based on gross floor area and net lettable area, respectively. The mall is 99% occupied and will be used for property-investment purposes.

images.alt_text: The 999-year leasehold Sembawang Shopping Centre has four floors of retail units and three carpark levels with 165 parking spaces. It is now more than 99 per cent occupied.

site_title: US, Japan to start talks on 'trade deals': Abe
summary: US and Japanese leaders agree to start talks on "trade deals," with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe saying Tokyo is ready to negotiate free, fair, and reciprocal trade agreements. However, Abe refused to commit to a bilateral deal or a broader Trans-Pacific Partnership, which US President Donald Trump currently opposes. Trump seeks to target sensitive Japanese issues, such as agricultural and car markets, and has repeatedly emphasized the need for a bilateral deal over a multilateral agreement.

site_title: Oil futures up 3% on US stockpiles, Saudi target
summary: Oil futures rose 3% on Wednesday, driven by a decline in US crude inventories and Saudi Arabia's desire for a higher crude price. Brent crude futures settled at $73.48 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures reached $68.47 a barrel, their highest since 2014. US oil stockpiles dropped by 1.1 million barrels, with petrol and distillates drawing down more than expected on stronger demand. Saudi Arabia, a top oil exporter, is seeking a price closer to $100 a barrel, and Opec's production cuts are expected to be sustained.

site_title: Nestle gets US boost from more spending on pets
summary: Nestle reported a 2.8% organic sales increase in the first quarter, beating analyst expectations of 2.5%. The company attributed the boost to US consumers spending more on their pets, contributing to a stronger household finance. This growth was reflected in the company's shares rising 0.5% in Zurich.

site_title: China to impose anti-dumping measures on synthetic rubber imported from Singapore, US, EU
summary: China has imposed temporary anti-dumping measures on synthetic rubber imported from the US, EU, and Singapore, effective April 20. The measures aim to protect China's domestic industry from discounted prices. Global firms operating synthetic rubber facilities in Singapore, including ExxonMobil and Lanxess, may be affected. China's move comes amid an escalating trade dispute with the US, with both sides expected to reach a compromise.

images.alt_text: Meanwhile, ExxonMobil has been building a new halobutyl rubber facility at its petrochemical complex on Jurong Island, which will add production capacity of 140,000 tons per annum.

site_title: IHH ups ante in Fortis courtship with 40-billion rupee stake offer
summary: Singapore-listed IHH Healthcare has offered up to 40 billion rupees (S$796 million) to acquire a stake in India's Fortis Healthcare, which is struggling with cash flow and rising debt. The offer, valued at 48.2% of Fortis, aims to fund the buyout of assets and provide immediate liquidity. This is IHH's second attempt to acquire Fortis, following a previous offer of US$1.3 billion. The move comes ahead of a Fortis board meeting to consider its options, which also include a US$350 million investment from Chinese conglomerate Fosun International.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Big Brother Is Here
summary: The Singapore International Festival of Arts opens with a stage adaptation of George Orwell's classic novel 1984, which premiered in the UK in 2014 and has drawn rave reviews. The production, scripted by Robert Icke and Duncan McMillan, explores a world controlled by authoritarian governments through mass surveillance and information suppression. As authoritarian powers seek to cement their control, Orwell's novel has become increasingly relevant. The 1984 stage adaptation runs from April 26 to 29 at the Esplanade Theatre.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) reported a 1Q18 distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.35 Singapore cents, slightly missing expectations. Despite organic weakness in Japan, the Philippines, Vietnam, and the US, China achieved healthy operating performance. ART has net gain proceeds of S$56.1 million from divestment of Chinese properties, with S$350 million available debt headroom. Analysts at CGS CIMB Research and OCBC Investment Research maintain a "Hold" call, citing limited catalysts and a disciplined approach to acquisitions. They also highlight upside risks from a pick-up in core markets and downside risks from higher rate hikes.

site_title: Excitement over Sats' potential deal with HNA units could be overblown
summary: SATS' shares surged following reports of Temasek's potential acquisition of stakes in Swissport and Gategroup, backed by Chinese conglomerate HNA. However, analysts caution that the excitement may be premature, with CIMB analyst Lim Siew Khee stating that a deal could be years away. Sats' shares have risen from S$5.21 to S$5.49, with analysts expecting the company to maintain its focus on Asian markets. A potential collaboration between Sats, Swissport, and Gategroup is possible in the long run, but for now, the three companies may operate independently.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: SP Group to launch platform for home owners to sell solar energy certs
summary: SP Group, Singapore's power grid operator, plans to launch a blockchain-based platform to connect residential solar energy producers with businesses with carbon footprints by the end of this year. The platform aims to speed up the use of solar panels and offer a variation of carbon emissions trading. This digital platform is expected to be a global first, linking up small producers of solar energy with businesses looking to offset their carbon emissions.

site_title: Sacred Treasures From Angkor
summary: The Asian Civilisations Museum in Singapore is hosting an exhibition titled "Angkor: Exploring Cambodia's Sacred City" in collaboration with the Guimet Museum. The show features over 140 ancient Khmer art pieces, including sculptures and historic memorabilia dating back to the 6th century. The exhibition is structured to recreate the discovery of Angkor by the French missions in the late 19th century. It runs until July 22, 2018, and offers a glimpse into the progression of Khmer art and the craftsmanship of the ancient temple city of Angkor Wat.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Latest version of La Strada looks sharper, tastes better
summary: La Strada Ristorante, a Singaporean restaurant, has undergone a renovation and now boasts a more authentic Italian experience. Chef Dalton Fong, a non-native Italian chef, has taken over and serves classic dishes such as pasta carbonara, tomato-based seafood spaghetti, and raviolo. The restaurant's new menu features high-quality ingredients and confident cooking, with standout dishes including squid ink tagliolini, lobster pasta, and tiramisu. The new La Strada offers an affordable three-course set lunch and a more elaborate dinner experience, with a focus on showcasing the kitchen's capabilities.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: China Sunsine Chemical Holdings expects a substantial increase in consolidated net profit in the first quarter due to a supply shortage caused by rivals' suspension of production in China. ComfortDelGro is expanding its UK operations with a £1.2 million acquisition of Dial-a-Cab, adding 1,100 taxis to its London fleet. Datapulse Technology has reaffirmed its decision not to pay an interim dividend despite minority shareholder requests. Meanwhile, ST Electronics secured smart technologies contracts worth S$635 million in the first quarter.

site_title: SIA stays on board as Singapore F1 title sponsor till 2019
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has extended its title sponsorship of the Singapore Formula 1 Grand Prix for two more years until 2019, a move that will continue the partnership until 2021. The airline's CEO, Goh Choon Phong, praised the event as the "highlight of Singapore's sporting calendar," while Singapore GP chairman Teo Hock Seng highlighted the partnership's role in showcasing the country. The estimated annual cost of hosting the race is around S$135 million, with the Singapore government footing 60% of the bill.

site_title: Worst of US-China trade tensions is over: JP Morgan
summary: US-China trade tensions appear to be easing as both sides ramp up negotiations, according to JP Morgan Asset Management. While volatility in the stock market is still expected due to "headline noise" and monetary tightening, the worst of the tensions seems to be over. JPMAM expects a "watered-down version" of recent tariff announcements and a relatively moderate economic impact. China is likely to reduce tariff rates on US exports and increase imports to reduce trade imbalances. The US and China are expected to avoid a full-blown trade war, with JP Morgan maintaining an overweight stance on equities.

site_title: InterContinental sees 'incredible' long-term market in UK
summary: InterContinental Hotels Group CEO Keith Barr believes the UK has an "incredible" long-term market, despite Brexit uncertainty. He notes that 5% of the company's global business is in the UK, but sees opportunities for growth in luxury and mid-range hotels, particularly in Saudi Arabia and the UAE, where tourism is expected to drive economic growth. The company plans to expand 25% in the Middle East within the next five years, with 75% of the expansion in Saudi Arabia and the UAE.

site_title: Queen Elizabeth II hopes for reinvigoration of the Commonwealth
summary: Queen Elizabeth II expressed hope that her son Prince Charles would carry on the work of reinvigorating the Commonwealth, a network of 53 nations, during the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in London. The Queen, 92, has cut down on long-haul travels, and the meeting is expected to be her last as monarch. Prince Charles described the Commonwealth as a fundamental part of his life, and the Queen praised its benefits, including trade and global initiatives. The summit, hosted by British Prime Minister Theresa May, will discuss topics such as climate change and trade.

site_title: What A Gem
summary: Tiffany & Co's vice president, Melvyn Kirtley, offers insights on investing in jewels. The brand has a long history of discovering rare colored gemstones, including the Tiffany Legacy gemstones, such as kunzite, morganite, and tanzanite. Kirtley emphasizes the importance of introducing rare and finest colored gemstones to customers in a way that is appealing, wearable, and collectable. This approach aligns with the brand's DNA, which prioritizes showcasing exceptional gemstones to customers.

site_title: Hip-hop, not rock, is the voice of our era
summary: Hip-hop has surpassed rock as the voice of the era, with Kendrick Lamar's Pulitzer Prize-winning album Damn marking a shift in American popular music. Hip-hop's innovative and socially conscious nature, as well as its ability to comment on current events in real-time, has made it the dominant force in contemporary music. Rock's decline in relevance among younger generations, coupled with its lack of engagement with social issues, has led to hip-hop's rise as the preferred genre for those seeking music that reflects the complexities of modern life.

images.alt_text: No present-day rock musician can compete with Lamar's astonishing verbal dexterity.

site_title: London's skyline soars with more than 500 skyscrapers in pipeline
summary: London is on track to have over 500 skyscrapers in the pipeline, a first for the city, according to research by New London Architecture. This represents a 12% increase from 2016, with 510 towers planned or built in 2017. The trend to build skyscrapers is spreading into the suburbs, driven by increasing demand for high-rise developments. The surge in skyscraper construction is expected to continue, with the city's skyline set to undergo significant changes in the coming years.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as chip stocks, Apple drag
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 36.77 points, or 0.15%, to 24,711.30. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq also declined, with the Nasdaq Composite dropping 36.62 points, or 0.50%, to 7,258.62. The decline was attributed to weakness in chipmakers and Apple's decline.

site_title: Spambots hijack movement helping M'sians to return home to vote
summary: Cyber troopers are targeting the #PulangMengundi movement in Malaysia, which aims to encourage Malaysians to return home to vote in the GE14 election. The non-partisan movement has been flooded with spambots on Twitter, stifling communication between voters and sponsors. Despite this, the movement remains committed to its cause, with a social media consultant stating that the organization keeps tight accounts and is transparent about its finances. The issue has prompted a call for more donors to support the movement, with the goal of ensuring every Malaysian has equal access to vote.

site_title: UOB names Wee Ee Lim as non-independent, non-executive director
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has appointed Wee Ee Lim, 56, as a non-independent, non-executive director, effective July 1. Lim is the son of UOB's chairman emeritus and banking tycoon Wee Cho Yaw, and brother of CEO Wee Ee Cheong. He will join the bank's board risk management and strategy committees, and owns 171.4 million UOB shares. Lim brings international business experience, having been president and CEO of Haw Par Corporation since 2003. His appointment is part of UOB's board renewal process.

site_title: Even millionaires have cost worries if they live to a 100
summary: A UBS study found that 46% of Singapore's millionaires expect to live to 100, with 42% worrying their wealth won't support them until age 100. 45% plan to adjust their financial plans, and 83% have a financial plan in place. Singaporean millionaires prioritize health, with 83% worrying about declining health and 92% saying investing in health is more important than growing wealth. The majority (68%) expect to work longer than traditional retirement age to maintain lifestyle.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: US economic growth on track despite tariff concerns: Fed report
summary: The US economy remains on track for continued growth, according to the Federal Reserve's "Beige Book" report, with robust business borrowing, rising consumer spending, and tight labor markets. While many businesses expressed concern about the Trump administration's use of tariffs, the overall outlook among businesses remained positive. The report also showed evidence that tax cuts may have begun filtering through to business spending and investment, with commercial and industrial loan growth accelerating to 3.4% year-over-year, its fastest in over a year.

images.alt_text: In its periodic Beige Book summary of contacts with businesses in its 12 regional districts, the Fed said the overall outlook among businesses remained positive.

site_title: French Flair
summary: French pop artist Charles-Baptiste will perform a free concert in Singapore on April 21 as part of the Voila! Festival, celebrating all things Gallic. The concert, at the Shaw Foundation Symphony Stage, will feature Charles-Baptiste's eclectic music on a unique setup of one keyboard, two voices, one laptop, and one bass. Admission is free, making it an event worth attending. This performance marks Charles-Baptiste's first concert in Singapore, showcasing his quirky showmanship and energetic performance.

images.alt_text: Charles-Baptiste plays the Shaw Foundation Symphony .
Dylan Tan

site_title: Blockchain to revolutionise shipping
summary: A consortium of container shipping lines, tech companies, and organizations is developing a blockchain-based platform to revolutionize the shipping industry. The platform aims to integrate all related businesses onto one vast platform, reducing documentation time from days to minutes and potentially cutting costs dramatically. The use of blockchain technology will bring transparency and efficiency to the industry, with the potential to increase global trade by $1 trillion. However, integrating the platform will require significant changes to current processes and may cause major upheaval among related businesses.

site_title: 'Insurtech' will transform insurance, but pace of adoption is slow
summary: The insurance industry is ripe for disruption due to its reliance on data, high cost base, and inefficient processes. Despite this, the pace of digital adoption has been slow, with only 43% of insurers embracing fintech at the heart of their corporate strategy. However, the use of technology such as artificial intelligence, big data, and wearables is expected to transform the industry, enabling more customized products and pricing. Startups like Oscar and Lemonade are already making waves, and a partnership between Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway, and JPMorgan Chase aims to rein in health costs and improve services.

site_title: Gates backs gene tech in fight to end malaria
summary: Bill Gates emphasized the potential of gene-editing technologies, such as CRISPR and "gene drive" technologies, to combat malaria. He stated that while ethical concerns exist, they shouldn't hinder progress in these gene-modifying research tools. Gates believes gene drive technologies could prove critical in reducing malaria populations and believes that their impact on the ecosystem would be limited to a few species. He also highlighted the importance of genetic data and surveillance systems in tracking malaria strains and drug resistance.

site_title: Chop down trees to save the forest, scientists tell palm oil producers
summary: Japanese scientists are encouraging palm oil producers in Southeast Asia to chop down trees to help save forests. A new system allows for the processing of scrapped palm trees into methane gas and wood pellets, generating income for producers while reducing the need for expanding plantations. This approach aims to curb the industry's environmental impact and make it sustainable. The project, led by Japan International Research Center for Agricultural Sciences, has already started operations in Malaysia and estimates that it can produce 10,000 tonnes of pellets annually.

site_title: Pernod sees stronger profit, dividends as China sales surge
summary: Pernod Ricard, the world's second-largest distiller, reported a stronger-than-expected profit and increased its dividend payout due to a surge in demand for its spirits in China, particularly during the Lunar New Year celebrations. The company forecasts a 6% growth in profit from recurring operations and plans to pay between 37-50% of its earnings in dividends, up from a previous rate of one-third. This move aims to capitalize on the company's accelerating profit growth and reduced debt load, with the goal of lifting annual payouts to 50% of earnings over the next three years.

site_title: Tesla charges into Singapore
summary: Tesla has entered Singapore through parallel importer Hong Seh Motors, selling three models including the Model S 85D and Model X 75D. Prices start at S$426,800 (including Certificate Of Entitlement) and leasing plans are available with a 20% down payment, starting at S$5,388 a month. The company is currently undergoing homologation and expects to complete the process in six weeks. This marks Tesla's second attempt at entering the Singapore market, following a failed attempt in 2010.

site_title: Nissan aims to triple China sales
summary: Nissan's premium brand Infiniti aims to triple sales in China within the next five years by producing four new models locally and focusing on electrified offerings. The brand plans to boost sales to approximately 150,000 vehicles per year, up from 48,000 in 2017. Infiniti will make all models launched after 2021 electric or hybrid vehicles, with over half of global sales expected to be electric by 2025.

site_title: Rock Of Ages
summary: Record Store Day returns on Saturday, celebrating independent record shops and the revival of vinyl. The event, started in 2007, releases limited edition, in-store-only titles, often selling out quickly and reselling on eBay at high prices. The day honors the revival of vinyl and reissues classic or out-of-print titles, making it a must-visit for music enthusiasts and collectors.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Noble drops controversial move in restructuring proposal
summary: NOBLE Group, a Singapore-based commodities firm, has dropped a provision from its restructuring proposal that would have treated shareholders differently based on their voting records. The company, facing criticism, has also rejected Goldilocks Investment Company's nominees for its upcoming annual general meeting. Noble shares fell 6.9% after the move, which aims to move assets into a new company with existing shareholders receiving a 15% stake. The restructuring plan must be approved by shareholders; if rejected, Noble may pursue an alternative restructuring or enter into a formal insolvency process.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: CSE Global eyes new projects with Serba Dinamik
summary: CSE Global, a process control and communications network system integrator, has become the associate company of Malaysia-listed Serba Dinamik after a block sale for S$57.7 million. CSE's group managing director Lim Boon Kheng stated that any new contract opportunities will take 18-24 months to materialize, and the company is currently focusing on working together in the Middle East, where Serba has a strong presence. CSE has been seeking to recover from a S$11.7 million impairment on trade receivables in the Middle East and hopes to leverage Serba's customer base there.

site_title: Gold flat, dollar steady on higher US yields
summary: Gold prices remained flat at $1,348.80 per ounce, while the US dollar index rose 0.1% at 89.673, supported by higher US Treasury yields. Linger US-China trade tensions limited the dollar's gains. The US economy is expected to continue growing, according to the Federal Reserve. Meanwhile, North Korean leader Kim Jong-un and US President Donald Trump are set to meet, and the US and Japan are intensifying trade consultations. British inflation unexpectedly cooled to a one-year low in March, and Russia's Polymetal reported a 19% increase in first-quarter revenue.

site_title: Power Play
summary: Edith Podesta's new play, Leda And The Rage, explores a woman's recovery from a traumatic incident through art, literature, and cinema, examining post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) from diverse perspectives. The play, which includes references to rape and sexual assault, is suitable for audiences aged 16 and above and includes sign-language interpretation. Leda And The Rage runs from April 26 to 29 at the Esplanade Theatre Studio.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Hong Kong stocks surge, boosted by energy sector rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged more than 1% on Thursday, following a rally across Asian markets. Energy firms were boosted by big gains in oil prices, while concerns over Syria and trade fears eased. The Hang Seng Index jumped 1.40%, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes rose 0.84% and 0.60%, respectively. The rally follows four straight losses for Hong Kong stocks.

site_title: In Demand
summary: Tod's has revamped its Singapore flagship boutique, introducing a new store concept with a minimalist and luxurious design. The brand has launched a capsule collection, Surf, inspired by California's sun, sand, and surf culture, featuring its iconic Gommino collection. To celebrate the opening, Tod's has also released two exclusive designs of embellished Wave backpacks and limited-edition Surf collection pieces. The brand's marketing efforts, including collaborations with social media influencers and celebrities, have contributed to its relatability and desirability, propelling it to a top-of-mind position among its target demographic.

site_title: De Beers goes to home of blood diamonds to fix hand-mined stigma
summary: De Beers, the world's top diamond miner, plans to launch a pilot program in Sierra Leone to improve the reputation of artisanal mining, known as "blood diamonds." The program, called GemFair, aims to digitally track the route from mine to consumer, providing a secure route to market and fair prices. The goal is to raise standards and enhance the prospects for artisanal miners, potentially opening up a new source of supply for De Beers. The program will work with the Diamond Development Initiative, a non-governmental organization.

site_title: Cartier Champions Women Entrepreneurs
summary: The Cartier Women's Initiative Awards recognizes 18 women entrepreneurs from over 130 countries for their socially responsible startups. The finalists, including Audrey Cheng, Hanan Khader, and Diana Yousef, will participate in a program offering business coaching, media visibility, and networking opportunities. The awards, launched in 2006, aim to empower women and mirror Cartier's values of curiosity, audacity, and willpower. The winners will receive US$30,000, US$100,000, and personalized business mentoring, with the results announced on April 26.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Deficit addiction - a bipartisan norm in the US
summary: The US has become a bipartisan norm in deficit addiction, with both Democrats and Republicans contributing to the problem. Despite the misconception that Democrats have replaced Republicans as fiscal conservatives, the reality is that both parties have played a significant role in this transformation. According to an op-ed essay by David Leonhardt, Democrats have been central in this shift, with Leonhardt arguing that they have lost their legitimate claim to being fiscal conservatives. The bipartisan deficit addiction is a significant concern for the US economy.

site_title: Macron, Merkel differ on fiscal policy in EU reform push
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Emmanuel Macron stressed their willingness to reform the EU, but failed to bridge their differences on economic and fiscal policy. Macron proposed sweeping eurozone reforms, including a common budget and finance minister, while Merkel emphasized the need for individual member states to boost their competitiveness. The two leaders will present a joint roadmap before a June EU summit, with Merkel acknowledging that "the sum of our proposals can ultimately lead to a good result," despite differing views on debt pooling and eurozone investment.

site_title: Jaguar expected to launch I-Pace in Singapore in early 2019
summary: Jaguar plans to launch the I-Pace, a mid-size electric SUV, in Singapore in early 2019. The I-Pace features a space-efficient design with one electric motor at each axle, producing 400 hp and accelerating to 100 kmh in under five seconds. The car is expected to have a range of over 470 km on a single charge. Pricing in Singapore is estimated to be around S$400,000, making it a high-end electric vehicle. The I-Pace is designed to offer neutral handling and a roomy interior.

site_title: Tender deadline for KL-Singapore High Speed Rail company extended to December
summary: The deadline for tender submissions for the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail company, AssetsCo, has been extended to December 28, 2018, from June 29. The extension allows bidders more time to develop their proposals for designing, building, financing, and maintaining the rail assets. The project aims to reduce travel time between Kuala Lumpur and Singapore to 90 minutes. The initial deadline was set in December 2017, and the HSR Express Service is still set to commence on December 31, 2026.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of the high-speed rail terminal in Jurong East.

site_title: STI rises on higher oil prices, US economy
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 40.91 points, or 1.15%, to 3,598.73, driven by higher oil prices and an upbeat assessment of the US economy in a Federal Reserve report. The US yield curve also made headlines due to concerns over a flattening trajectory, which is seen as a recession indicator. Despite this, global debt levels remain at historic highs, according to the IMF. Banking stocks led gains, with DBS and UOB up 1.9% and OCBC rising 1.6%.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Yanlord Land upsizes tranche size of 6.75% notes due 2023 to US$350m
summary: Yanlord Land Group has upsized the tranche size of its 6.75% notes due 2023 to US$350 million, with an additional US$50 million notes to be issued. The notes are expected to be issued on or around April 23, with estimated net proceeds of about US$345.6 million. This move increases the total tranche size and provides more liquidity for the company.

site_title: Silverlake Axis wins contract to implement QR Cloud for Metro
summary: Silverlake Axis' subsidiary QR Retail Automation has won a contract to implement QR Cloud, a cloud-based retail automation solution, for Singapore retail chain Metro. The deal will enhance customer services and operational efficiencies, with the SaaS version also available to Metro's supply chain partners. The contract value was not disclosed, but is expected to contribute positively to Silverlake Axis' results in the current financial year.

site_title: From Hawker To Haute Cuisine
summary: Several Singapore chef-owned restaurants, including Restaurant Ards, Jiakpalang, BirdBird, and Selfish Gene, have closed, sparking concerns about the viability of "Singaporean cuisine" beyond its novelty phase. The chefs behind these restaurants express disillusionment and financial struggles, leading some to put their dreams on hold. The closures raise questions about the long-term sustainability of this cuisine, which was once touted as a dynamic and creative representation of Singapore's culinary scene.

site_title: Tender deadline for KL-Singapore High Speed Rail company extended to December
summary: The deadline for tender submissions for the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail (HSR) Assets Company has been extended to December 28, 2018, from the original June 29 deadline. The extension allows bidders more time to develop their submissions. The project aims to reduce travel time between Kuala Lumpur and Singapore to 90 minutes, with the HSR Express Service set to commence on December 31, 2026. Eight stations will be built along the 350km line, with the AssetsCo responsible for designing, building, financing, and maintaining the rail assets.

site_title: Wynn Resorts adds three women to board in post-scandal shake-up
summary: Wynn Resorts has added three women to its board of directors following a post-scandal shake-up. The new members, including former Clinton spokeswoman Dee Dee Myers and investor-relations chief Wendy Webb, join an enlarged and diversified board. The move comes after former CEO Steve Wynn stepped down amid allegations of harassment, and the company's largest individual shareholder, Elaine Wynn, expressed her desire for new board appointees. The new appointments aim to address concerns over corporate governance and potentially mitigate the impact on the company's casino licenses.

site_title: Hit The Reset Button
summary: COMO Shambala Estate in Bali is introducing four new wellness programs, including Ayurvedic, Be Active, Cleanse, and Bespoke, starting this month. The programs, priced from US$2,280, include meals, consultations, daily wellness treatments, and personal assistance. The resort aims to help frazzled executives reset and achieve their wellness goals, whether it's weight loss, fitness, detoxification, or holistic healing.

images.alt_text: COMO Shambala Estate in Bali.

site_title: Why your next Porsche might have tyres from Japan
summary: Japanese tyre maker Yokohama aims to grow sales by 700 billion yen to 2020, with a strategic emphasis on supplying tyres to European carmakers. The company has secured fitments on luxury models such as Audi, Mercedes-Benz, and Porsche, and plans to increase its European business fourfold. Despite this, local distributors face challenges due to increased tyre variety and rising costs. Yokohama is also exploring new technologies, including the use of orange oil to improve grip power, and is seeking to increase brand recognition through partnerships such as its tie-up with Chelsea FC.

site_title: No intention to pay out S$0.20 dividend proposed by Ng Bie Tjin: Datapulse
summary: Datapulse Technology has responded to a minority shareholder's open letter regarding its dividend payment and diversification plan. The company has reaffirmed its intention not to pay an interim 20 Singapore cents dividend proposed by Ng Bie Tjin. Datapulse plans to deploy its cash to invest in new core businesses, aiming to deliver returns to shareholders in the medium-term. The company's board will table 10 resolutions at an EGM, including those to approve new board members and the current diversification agenda.

site_title: Fragrance Group prices its S$125m 6.1% 2021 notes
summary: Fragrance Group has priced its S$125 million 6.125% fixed-rate notes, maturing on April 26, 2021, under its S$1 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme. The notes will be issued at 100% of their principal amount in denominations of S$250,000. They may be redeemed at 103.063% of their principal amount on or after the fourth interest payment date.

site_title: AT&T abandons plans for Vrio IPO in blow to efforts to cut debt
summary: AT&T canceled its initial public offering (IPO) of South American pay-television unit Vrio Corp due to market conditions. The company had planned to use the funds to reduce debt related to its planned $85.4 billion Time Warner acquisition. AT&T had reduced the number of shares being offered and the targeted price range, but ultimately decided to withdraw the IPO plans. The move comes as AT&T's shares have declined over 9% this year, and the company has been lukewarm about its Latin American assets.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 15.86 points to 1,895.18 on Thursday, driven by a volume of 2.52 billion shares worth RM2.69 billion. Gainers outpaced losers 505-374. The rally came as investors remained optimistic despite US tariff uncertainty and mixed Federal Reserve views.

site_title: China Sunsine issues positive profit alert
summary: China Sunsine Chemical Holdings expects to report a substantial increase in consolidated net profit for the first quarter due to higher average selling prices and sales volumes. The company attributes this growth to a supply shortage in the rubber chemicals industry caused by frequent environmental inspections, which forced some players to suspend production. This shortage worked to China Sunsine's advantage, resulting in increased profit. The company will report its results on Wednesday.

site_title: UnUsUaL subsidiary and Sun Entertainment organise Mandopop singer's 8-city tour in China
summary: UnUsUaL Limited, a mainboard-listed company, has partnered with Sun Entertainment to organize an 8-city concert tour in China for Taiwanese Mandopop singer Rainie Yang. The "Youth Lies Within" world tour will take place between May 2018 and early 2019 in major cities such as Guangzhou, Beijing, and Shanghai. The tour aims to bring Yang's popular concert to China, with UnUsUaL working closely with Sun Entertainment on other projects. The company's shares ended 2.1% lower on the day following the announcement.

site_title: Union Steel issues profit warning for Q3
summary: Union Steel Holdings, a metal recycler, has issued a profit warning for the third quarter, citing a slowdown in market demand for its steel products. The company expects to report a net loss for the quarter and nine months ended March 31. Further details will be disclosed on or after May 9.

site_title: Singapore O&G inks 1-year deal to provide on-site medical services to SATA CommHealth
summary: Singapore O&G has signed a one-year deal to provide on-site medical services to SATA CommHealth, a social enterprise, for an initial period of 12 months. SATA will provide equipment and supplies, while paying a service fee to Singapore O&G for medical consultations and procedures. The agreement aims to expand Singapore O&G's patient reach, particularly in heartland areas, while SATA furthers its social mission.

site_title: Jokowi seeks to curb cash in anti-graft push for Indonesia vote
summary: Indonesia plans to cap daily cash transactions at 100 million rupiah (S$9,494.72) to curb black money and promote transparency ahead of elections. The proposed rules, if passed, will require individuals and companies to use credit cards or bank transfers, reducing reliance on cash in the country, which is the second-largest cash-based economy in the world. The move aims to reduce vote-buying and money laundering, with President Joko Widodo's administration seeking to burnish its anti-graft image.

site_title: Oxley, SC Global, Super Group bosses take shares in Lian Beng spin-off
summary: Singapore property developer SLB Development's initial public offering (IPO) received a strong response, with the public tranche being about 20.6 times subscribed. The offering comprised 238 million new shares at S$0.23 apiece, with 8 million shares reserved for the public and 230 million placed out. The results suggest a promising start for SLB Development's IPO.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Noble Group has dropped a provision from its restructuring plan that criticized shareholders differently based on their vote, according to the company's chairman. Singapore-listed IHH has offered to invest 40 billion rupees in Fortis for equity. The Land Transport Authority has reduced COE vehicle quotas for May to July by 4% due to zero growth policy. China has imposed anti-dumping measures on synthetic rubber imported from Singapore, the US, and the EU. The European Union and Singapore are closer to signing a free trade agreement.

site_title: Oxley, SC Global, Super Group & United Envirotech bosses take shares in Lian Beng spin-off
summary: SLB Development, a spin-off from Lian Beng Group, successfully completed its initial public offering (IPO) with a public tranche 20.6 times subscribed. The IPO price of S$0.23 was 1.46 times the company's pro forma net asset value. Prominent investors including Super Group's David Teo, United Envirotech's Lin Yucheng, and Oxley Holdings' Eric Low took shares in the company. SLB shares will trade on the Catalist board starting April 20, with a market capitalization of S$210 million.

site_title: Japan contemplates post-Abe world, but rivals' positions still murky
summary: Japan is considering a leadership change following Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's declining support due to scandals and low ratings. Former foreign minister Fumio Kishida is seen as a leading contender, but no clear policy alternatives have been proposed. Kishida unveiled slogans calling for checks on power and bottom-up decision-making. Abe's chances of gaining a third term are uncertain, with some speculating he may step down sooner. The Liberal Democratic Party will vote in September to determine Abe's successor.

site_title: Adventus Holdings puts US$2.2m into JV to build apartment in Vietnam
summary: Adventus Holdings' unit ADV S3 has entered into a joint venture agreement with Panthera Company and two of its shareholders to develop a residential apartment in Danang, Vietnam. The joint venture vehicle, AP NHS, will acquire a 3,825 sq m plot of land for US$2.9 million. ADV S3 will hold a 45% stake in AP NHS and pay 50.715 billion Vietnamese Dong (approximately US$2.9 million) for the stake.

site_title: Keppel Corp's Q1 net profit jumps 34%, buoyed by property division
summary: Keppel Corp reported a 33.7% jump in Q1 net profit to S$337.5 million, driven by a 298% surge in property division net profit to S$378 million. Revenue improved by 17.8% to S$1.47 billion, with the property division contributing the most. The O&M division posted a net loss of S$23 million, while the investment division posted a net loss of S$44 million. Despite this, the O&M division secured new contracts worth S$580 million year-to-date.

site_title: COE vehicle quota for May to July falls by 4% as zero growth policy continues
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has announced a 4% decrease in Certificate of Entitlements (COEs) for the coming three months, from May to July, as part of its zero growth policy. This marks the second consecutive quarter with no growth in the COE pool. The decrease affects car COEs, with a 7.9% drop, while motorcycle COEs increased by 2.7%. Commercial vehicle COEs, however, saw a 23.7% increase, with the growth rate remaining unchanged at 0.25% until 2021.

site_title: Tender to redevelop Kampong Bugis to be launched in 1 to 2 years
summary: The Singapore Land Authority plans to launch a tender for a master developer to redevelop Kampong Bugis into a car-lite residential precinct within the next 1-2 years. The 13-hectare site, currently mostly empty, will feature 4,000 high-density private homes and environmentally sustainable features. The redevelopment excludes parts of the area already developed or under construction. Remediation works at the former Kallang Gasworks site, which includes treating soil contaminated with chemicals, are expected to be completed by 2022.

site_title: North seeks "complete denuclearisation", says Moon, as US vows continued pressure
summary: North Korea has expressed commitment to "complete denuclearisation" of the Korean peninsula, according to South Korean President Moon Jae-in. The US vows to maintain "maximum pressure" on Pyongyang, while Moon believes big-picture agreements can be reached through summits. Moon stated that denuclearisation has the same meaning for both North and South Korea, and the North is willing to complete denuclearisation. The US and North Korea have agreed to talks, with a "landing zone" in US trade talks also being sought by South Korea's trade chief.

site_title: S'pore's wealthy expect to live to 100, but worry if wealth will last
summary: A UBS study found that 46% of Singapore's millionaires expect to live to 100, driving changes in spending, investing, and legacy behavior. However, 42% worry their wealth will not support them until age 100, with concerns over healthcare costs and affording their current lifestyle in retirement. The research also found that 45% plan to adjust their financial plans and 46% their spending patterns. Almost 80% of respondents have a financial plan in place, but 20% do not, highlighting the need for more discussions on life expectancy and long-term planning.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Koh Brothers will no longer pursue beauty business JV
summary: Koh Brothers Group announced it will not proceed with a planned beauty business joint venture with Koracle, citing a lapse of the memorandum of understanding due to the failure to enter a definitive agreement during the exclusivity period. This decision follows an agreement in January last year to establish beauty clinics and wellness spas in Singapore and Malaysia.

site_title: ST Electronics secures smart technologies contracts worth S$635m in Q1 2018
summary: ST Electronics secures S$635m smart technologies contracts in Q1 2018, including mobility and rail electronics solutions, as well as satellite communications projects. The contracts were signed for projects in New Taipei City, Bangkok, and Kazakhstan. These deals demonstrate the company's focus on enhancing global connectivity through innovative technologies.

site_title: Design Studio Group's Q1 net profit dives 84%
summary: Design Studio Group reported a net profit of S$322,000 in Q1, down 84.5% from the previous year, due to a 67.8% increase in subcontractors' costs. Revenue rose 17% to S$41 million. The company secured S$59 million of new projects, bringing its order book to S$149.5 million. Despite a 7.79% rise in its counter, the company remains cautious about its outlook, citing a need for further restructuring and expansion into international markets.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won close at multi-week highs
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index closed at a multi-week high on Thursday, up 0.25% at 2,486.10, driven by gains in market heavyweight shares such as Samsung Electronics and Hyundai Engineering & Construction. The won also rose against the dollar, and bond yields increased. Optimism ahead of the inter-Korean summit next week contributed to the market's positive sentiment.

site_title: European stock markets rise modestly at open
summary: European stock markets rose modestly at the start of trading on Thursday, with the FTSE 100 index climbing 0.2% to 7,331.65 points. The DAX 30 and CAC 40 also edged up, driven by gains in mining and healthcare sectors. Dealers await key retail sales data in Britain.

site_title: Moody's says Russian economy resilient to latest US sanctions
summary: Moody's Investors Service says Russia's economy is resilient to the latest US sanctions, citing strong public and external finances. The rating agency notes that the sanctions will be credit negative for some Russian debt issuers, but the Russian banking system can absorb credit losses. Moody's expects the Russian government to increase support to regions facing revenue losses due to the sanctions, which were imposed on seven Russian oligarchs and 17 senior government officials. The assessment contrasts with Fitch Ratings' prediction that the sanctions will limit Russia's economic growth.

site_title: Singapore shares close 1.2% higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 41 points or 1.2% to 3,598.73, marking its third consecutive day of gains, driven by easing geopolitical tensions and positive corporate earnings. Rising oil prices and a US Federal Reserve report reaffirming the world's largest economy also boosted risk appetite. The rally follows a 0.4% increase on the previous day, as investors remain positive despite tariff uncertainty and split views on the Federal Reserve.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: UOB names Wee Cho Yaw's son Ee Lim as non-independent, non-executive director
summary: UOB appoints Wee Ee Lim, 56, as a non-independent, non-executive director effective July 1. He is the son of UOB's chairman emeritus Wee Cho Yaw and brother of CEO Wee Ee Cheong. Wee Ee Lim owns 171.4 million UOB shares and brings experience in international business and listed companies. He will serve on the bank's board risk management and strategy committees. His appointment comes as part of UOB's board renewal process.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,600.32, up 1.2%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading Thursday afternoon, rising 1.2% to 3,600.32, driven by gains in UOB and Singtel. The Straits Times Index gained 42.5 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 210 to 137, with 785.6 million shares changing hands. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and despite uncertainty surrounding US trade policies.

site_title: Korean Air headquarters raided in probe into 'nut rage' sister: Yonhap
summary: South Korean police raided Korean Air Lines headquarters as part of a probe into Cho Hyun-min, a senior vice president, for possible assault after a business meeting. Cho is accused of spraying a drink towards colleagues, but claims she only pushed a cup of water. This incident is related to the "nut rage" incident involving her sister Heather Cho in 2014. The raid also involves an investigation into customs duties not paid by Cho and other family members on luxury goods. Korean Air shares fell 4.1% and Jin Air shares dropped 5.3%.

site_title: European Union, Singapore a step closer to signing free trade agreement
summary: The European Union and Singapore are moving forward with the signing of a free trade agreement. The European Commission has presented the outcome of negotiations to the European Council, with the initialled agreement needing approval by the Council of Ministers and European Parliament. The aim is to have the agreement in force before the EU's mandate ends in 2019.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Greece needs post-bailout arrangement to help reforms: EU
summary: Greece needs a post-bailout arrangement with euro zone creditors to ensure reforms continue and budget discipline is maintained after exiting its bailout in August. EU Economic Commissioner Pierre Moscovici stated that a new arrangement is necessary to support the implementation of reforms and sound fiscal policies. The creditors are considering additional debt relief, potentially linked to Greece's economic growth, to maintain control and prevent the country from veering off the reform track. This could involve further conditions and ongoing economic surveillance.

images.alt_text: Greece needs a new arrangement with its euro zone government creditors after it exits its bailout on Aug 20 to make sure that reforms continue to be implemented and budget discipline is maintained, EU Economic Commissioner Pierre Moscovici said.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher after Abe-Trump meeting
summary: Tokyo stocks rose marginally on Thursday after a joint press conference by Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and US President Donald Trump. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index increased 0.15% to 22,191.18, while the Topix index rose 0.03% to 1,750.18. The meeting delivered few surprises, with no significant economic announcements. The rally was attributed to investors' optimism despite ongoing trade tensions between the US and Japan.

site_title: Resources rally boosts Australia shares; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to a five-session high, driven by a rally in commodity prices and a 2.8% gain for BHP Billiton after reporting an 8% increase in iron ore shipments. Chinese iron ore futures rose 4% and aluminium prices surged, boosting stocks like Alumina Ltd. Financial stocks fell, however, amid an inquiry into the sector. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index rose marginally, with dairy firm a2 Milk Company ending up 2.8%.

site_title: SIA stays on board as Singapore F1 title sponsor till 2019
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has extended its title sponsorship of Singapore's Formula 1 grand prix for two more years until 2019. The deal, which was first signed in 2014, was renewed as SIA's chief executive Goh Choon Phong praised the event as the "highlight of Singapore's sporting calendar." The 2018 Singapore grand prix will take place from Sept 14 to 16 at the Marina Bay Street Circuit. SIA's partnership with the event aims to showcase Singapore's tourism and sports offerings.

site_title: Blockchain is about to revolutionise the shipping industry
summary: Global container shipping lines, including AP Moeller-Maersk, are teaming up with technology companies to upgrade the logistics network using blockchain technology. The goal is to revolutionize the industry, reducing documentation time from days to minutes and lowering costs. The blockchain-based platform will integrate multiple systems, including those of manufacturers, banks, insurers, and port authorities. If successful, the project could add $1 trillion to global trade and increase transparency and efficiency. The project is expected to start piloting by the end of this year, with potential cost savings visible in financial statements within two years.

site_title: Subaru shares fall after NHK report of mileage cheating
summary: Subaru shares fell 3% after a report by Japan's NHK alleged the company falsified mileage and emissions readings on hundreds of vehicles, including its popular Forester compact SUV. This is the second instance of misconduct by Subaru in a year, following an inspection scandal last year. The automaker denied the allegations, stating the report was not based on information provided by the company, but a transport ministry official said it was yet to receive a final report. The incident could taint Subaru's and Japan's manufacturing industry's image, following recent scandals.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 9.76 points to 1,889.08 on Thursday, with a trading volume of 51.12 million lots worth RM19.01 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 118 to 51, indicating a positive market trend.

site_title: Reluctant Abe says US, Japan to start talks on 'trade deals'
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe agreed to start talks on "trade deals" with the US, despite US President Donald Trump's pressure for a bilateral agreement. Abe said the talks would focus on free, fair, and reciprocal trade, without committing to a bilateral deal. The US seeks to target Japan's sensitive markets, including agriculture and autos, but Abe's goal is to keep the talks open to a broader trans-Pacific pact.

site_title: China says ready to deal with any fallout from US trade row
summary: China is prepared to handle any negative effects from its trade dispute with the US, Commerce Ministry spokesman Gao Feng said. China's tariff hikes on US imports will not significantly impact domestic industries, and Beijing hopes Washington will not underestimate China's resolve to fight back. China has imposed anti-dumping tariffs on US sorghum and synthetic rubber imports, and has warned it will take necessary measures against US companies selling parts to Chinese telecom equipment maker ZTE.
