The move aims to position Singapore as a key node for technology, innovation, and enterprise in Asia and globally, leveraging an integrated approach to bring diverse capabilities together.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.28 points to 1,883.77, driven by a higher volume of 63.55 million lots worth RM24.75 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 145 to 59, indicating a positive trading session.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise as Wall Street, North Korea provide positive lead
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday following a rally on Wall Street, driven by easing trade tensions and positive earnings reports from US companies such as Netflix and Goldman Sachs. China also announced a timetable to open its car market, boosting liquidity for businesses. US-North Korea talks also provided support, with reports of a secret meeting between CIA chief Mike Pompeo and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. Markets in Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Singapore rose, with Tokyo and Seoul also gaining ground, as traders shifted focus to earnings and data.

site_title: Choon Kim House at Upper Serangoon on collective sale offer for over S$55m
summary: FREEHOLD Choon Kim House, a four-storey mixed-use development in Upper Serangoon, Singapore, has been launched for collective sale with an estimated S$55 million bid price. The site offers a land rate of S$1,287 psf ppr and could support a total GFA of 47,661 sq ft, with 35 residential and 22 commercial units. The location is near major transport hubs and amenities, making it an attractive option for owner-occupiers and investors seeking asset enhancement plans. The tender closes on May 21.

site_title: US-North Korea talks 'at highest levels' but not Trump-Kim: White House
summary: The US has had high-level contacts with North Korea, but there has been no direct communication between President Donald Trump and Kim Jong Un, according to the White House. This clarifies earlier comments by Trump, who appeared to confirm speaking with Kim. The clarification comes as the two nations prepare for a historic meeting in the coming weeks.

site_title: Bitcoin's true believers vow to ride out currency rollercoaster
summary: Bitcoin enthusiasts remain optimistic despite the cryptocurrency's recent price slump, with some seeing the volatility as a buying opportunity. The Bitcoin Centre, a hub for bitcoin enthusiasts, has seen a decline in crowds but still attracts around 100 people a week. Longtime investors, including those who bought in at $19,000, have not lost money and are advising others to "ride out the waves" of volatility. The community views bitcoin as a long-term investment, with the goal of achieving "monetary independence."

site_title: Glitch means extra day for Americans to file taxes
summary: US tax authorities have given Americans an extra day to file their 2017 tax returns due to a computer system glitch that caused online conduits to fail on the deadline. The system crashed due to a high volume of last-minute filings, and it was eventually restored. As a result, the deadline for filing tax returns has been extended until midnight Wednesday, giving people an extra day to submit their returns.

site_title: SPH ties up with Google to deliver news, podcasts via Google Home
summary: SPH has partnered with Google to deliver news and podcasts to users of Google Home in Singapore. Starting April 20, users can listen to news from The Straits Times and The Business Times, as well as podcasts from The Straits Times, using voice commands through the Google Home app. The partnership also includes a segment called Need to Know, offering career development tips. New subscribers to The Straits Times All-Digital package will receive a Google Home Mini, or can top up SGD 79 for a Google Home.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: South Korea: Stocks surge to 4-week high, won firms
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index surged to a 4-week high, reaching 2,484.89 points, driven by easing US-North Korea tensions and gains on Wall Street. The won also edged higher, while bond yields fell. SK Hynix shares gained over 3% in support of the overall market sentiment. Despite a 0.6% decline this year, the Kospi index remains up 1.27% for the day.

site_title: Starwood launches offer for CA Immo, Immofinanz shares
summary: US property investment firm Starwood Capital Group has launched a bid for minority stakes in Austrian property companies CA Immo and Immofinanz, aiming to increase its real estate exposure in central and eastern Europe. Starwood is seeking up to 26% of CA Immo and up to 5% of Immofinanz, with minimal premiums to share prices, excluding dividends.

site_title: Japan's March exports disappoint on strong yen, trade friction a risk
summary: Japan's exports rose 2.1% in March, below the 4.7% annual increase expected, due to a strong yen. The trade surplus with the US narrowed slightly to 623.1 billion yen, still drawing criticism from President Trump. The data comes amid rising trade tensions and a US-China tariff standoff, raising concerns about Japan's export-reliant economy. Economists expect a slower pace of expansion for Japan's exports, citing a tapering off in demand for semiconductors and electronic parts.

site_title: P2P lender Funding Societies nets US$25m Series B funding led by Softbank Ventures Korea
summary: Funding Societies, a peer-to-peer lending platform, raised US$25 million in Series B funding led by Softbank Ventures Korea. Existing investors and new participants included Sequoia India, Alpha JWC Ventures, Golden Gate Ventures, Qualgro, and LINE Ventures. The platform, which connects small and medium-sized enterprises in Singapore, Indonesia, and Malaysia with lenders, has seen a 300% growth in its loan book, reaching S$100 million in crowdfunded SME loans. Co-founder Kelvin Teo expressed gratitude for the funding and commitment to enabling growth for SMEs and creating wealth for lenders.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher after Wall Street gains
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on April 18, 2018, following gains on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.38% to 21,930.59, while the Topix index increased 0.23% to 1,734.01. The gains were attributed to investors digesting news from US-Japan summit talks.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Shares rally at open
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai shares rallied at the open on April 18, 2018, following strong gains on Wall Street and the People's Bank of China's decision to cut the cash reserves of some lenders to boost business liquidity. The Hang Seng Index rose 1.21%, the Shanghai Composite Index climbed 0.82%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index increased 0.63%. These gains were likely influenced by the positive market sentiment and the recent economic developments in the region.

site_title: China's ZTE may lose Android license as US market woes build
summary: The US Commerce Department has banned American firms from selling parts and software to ZTE Corp for seven years due to its violation of an agreement related to shipping US goods to Iran. This move, combined with proposed new rules by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), could cut into ZTE's sales and potentially bar it from using Google's Android operating system in its mobile devices. The FCC's proposal aims to prevent ZTE and rival Chinese smartphone maker Huawei from gaining significant market share in the US, amid growing tensions between the two countries over trade and security concerns.

site_title: The swankiest home address? It's Marina Bay, not Orchard Road
summary: Non-landed luxury home prices in District 1 and 2 in Singapore's Core Central Region (CCR) rose 9.3% and 14.5% year-over-year, respectively, in Q1 2018, outperforming the CCR's 6.2% increase. The districts saw record prices of S$2,147 psf and S$2,653 psf, respectively, driven by the "work-live-play" concept, mega-office complexes, and attractions such as Marina Bay Sands and Gardens by the Bay. Experts predict prices will continue to rise, with OrangeTee & Tie forecasting an 8-12% increase this year.

site_title: South Korean customs looking into Korean Air "nut rage" family
summary: South Korea's customs agency is investigating Cho Hyun Min, the youngest daughter of Korean Air Lines' chairman, and other family members, over allegedly unpaid customs duties on luxury goods brought into the country. Cho Hyun Min, a senior vice-president of Korean Air, is already under police investigation for possible assault after allegedly throwing water at people during a business meeting. Cho previously denied throwing water, claiming she only "pushed" a cup of water. The customs agency's investigation is separate from the police probe.

site_title: Europe: shares rise as sentiment improves, Italian banks rally
summary: European shares rose 0.8% to their highest since February, boosted by a calming of US-Russia tensions and optimism about first-quarter earnings. Italian banks rallied, with Intesa Sanpaolo agreeing a sale of bad loans, and other European benchmarks also rose. Meanwhile, China's economic health was mixed, with growth hitting 6.8% but industrial output missing expectations. The Stoxx 600 index reached its highest level since February, driven by strong gains on Wall Street.

site_title: JB-Singapore RTS Link on track to open by 2024: Khaw
summary: Singapore's Johor Baru-Singapore RTS Link is on track to open by 2024, according to Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan. The 5-minute train journey will reduce traffic congestion on the Causeway and shift commuters to a preferred mode of transport. A bilateral agreement to build the RTS Link was signed in January, with Malaysia expecting to call civil contract tenders for the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail project in the first half of 2025. Construction is expected to start in 2026, with completion by 2026.

images.alt_text: Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan visiting the site of the future Johor Baru-Singapore Rapid Transit System Link and Thomson-East Coast Line stations in Woodlands North.

site_title: Spackman bags camera-equipment supply contracts worth 580m won
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group has secured contracts worth 580 million Korean won (S$714,000) to supply camera systems and equipment for three upcoming South Korean drama series. The contracts were awarded to Frame Pictures, Spackman's wholly owned subsidiary, and are subject to changes in the final filming schedule. The dramas include a remake of "Suits", "Mistress", and "Life", set to air on various channels in April and July 2018.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.8%
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.8% higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 26.78 points to 3,524.98. The rally was driven by strong corporate earnings from Wall Street, including Netflix's positive results, which shifted market focus away from trade war fears. The gains were also influenced by Tokyo stocks opening higher on Wall Street's gains. Gainers outnumbered losers 99 to 53, with an average unit price of S$2.35 per share.

site_title: Austria revives debate on shielding banks from eastern Europe losses
summary: Austrian authorities are reviving a decade-old debate over who pays for the failure of local subsidiaries in Eastern Europe, with a focus on shielding parent banks from losses. The approach, known as Multiple Point of Entry, would have host countries manage failures and cover costs with locally issued securities. Austrian banks' eastern holdings amount to 200 billion euros, or two-thirds of Austria's economy. The approach aims to prevent serial bailouts and accumulate deficits in Vienna, while also ensuring local control over subsidiary failures.

site_title: GIC-backed Vietnam developer Vinhomes planning US$2b IPO
summary: Vinhomes JSC, a luxury residential developer backed by Singapore's GIC, plans a US$2 billion initial public offering (IPO) for its arm. The valuation could reach US$13-16 billion, making it the largest first-time share sale in Vietnam. The offering, expected to start marketing around April 27, will comprise entirely of stock being sold by existing investors, with a pricing decision expected early next month and trading to begin in mid-May.

site_title: JB-Singapore RTS Link on track to open by 2024: Khaw
summary: Singapore's Johor Baru-Singapore Rapid Transit System (RTS) Link is on track for completion by 2024, according to Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan. The 5-minute train journey between Woodlands North Station and Bukit Chagar Station is expected to reduce Causeway jams and shift commuters away from the congested road. The project was signed by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Malaysian counterpart Najib Razak in January. Meanwhile, Malaysia is set to call civil contract tenders for its Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail (HSR) project in the first half of 2019.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UnUsUaL, Ezion, shopper360, First Reit, Keppel-KBS, Ascott Reit
summary: UnUsUaL's shares rose after Prince Abdul Qawi and Ron Sim bought a 5.39% stake for S$25.8 million. Ezion Holdings slipped down despite trading volume, while shopper360's executive officer Samuel Chan resigned amid internal investigation. First Reit's distribution per unit increased to 2.15 cents, and Keppel-KBS US Reit beat its forecast with a distribution per unit of 2.32 US cents. Ascott Reit's distribution per unit rose 9% to 1.28 cents, up from 1.17 cents in the same period last year.

site_title: US flights diverted as Russia permissions to expire
summary: US airlines are diverting flights away from Russian airspace ahead of a deadline to renegotiate access agreements, set to expire at 7:59pm on Tuesday. The US State Department had been in last-minute talks with Russian officials, but they canceled the meeting. The US ambassador to Moscow, Jon Huntsman, was involved in the discussions, but the Russians have not indicated whether they will extend the approvals. Despite the deadline, the US hopes for a last-minute arrangement and is expecting a Russian response later today.

site_title: Trump requests extension to file 2017 taxes
summary: President Donald Trump requested a six-month extension to file his 2017 taxes, citing complexity, and plans to file by mid-October. This decision breaks with years of tradition established by his predecessors, who have routinely released their tax returns publicly. Trump's tax returns remain a closely guarded secret, despite previous extensions and claims that he was advised not to release them due to an ongoing IRS audit. The move has sparked criticism and underscores the contrast with previous presidents who have made their tax returns publicly available.

site_title: LPG, fuel oil tankers collide off Singapore coast
summary: A collision between an LPG tanker, Crystal Sunrise, and a fuel oil tanker, Astro Saturn, occurred off the coast of Singapore on Tuesday. The incident led to a leak of 1,796 tonnes of butane gas, but measures were taken to stop the leak and assess that it posed no danger to shipping. The ships sustained damage, but both have been stabilized with no reported injuries. Eight PSA Marine staff were given medical check-ups as a precaution. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore is investigating the incident.

site_title: United Food's COO steps down
summary: United Food Holdings announced that its COO, Li Ai, 52, has resigned to pursue other career opportunities. Li Ai, who joined the company in 1993, held various roles including product management, procurement, sales, and marketing. The company reported narrower losses in FY2017, with a 68.64 million yuan loss compared to 229.26 million yuan a year ago. Li Ai's resignation comes after United Food's FY2017 earnings announcement.

site_title: Oil prices rise on crude supply worry, Wall Street strength
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday, with Brent crude oil futures gaining 16 cents to $71.58 a barrel and US crude futures rising 30 cents to $66.52 a barrel. The rally was driven by concerns over supply disruptions, including air strikes on Syria and US sanctions against Iran, as well as a strong equities market. Despite profit-taking following last week's rally, analysts expect uncertainty over the Iran nuclear deal to support prices through May 12. However, an increase in supplies in Cushing, Oklahoma, may contain bullish enthusiasm.

site_title: One dead in jet engine failure on Southwest Airlines New York-Dallas flight
summary: A Southwest Airlines flight from New York to Dallas experienced a catastrophic engine failure on Tuesday, resulting in one fatality and an emergency landing in Philadelphia. The Boeing 737 encountered a problem with an engine after take-off from LaGuardia airport, with parts reportedly coming out. The National Transportation Safety Board confirmed one death and is investigating the cause of the failure.

site_title: Tepco shares up 4% after Niigata governor says he is thinking of resigning
summary: Tepco shares rose 4% after Niigata Governor Ryuichi Yoneyama indicated he may resign, potentially clearing the way to restart the world's largest nuclear power plant, Kashiwazaki-Kariwa. The plant's reactors can generate 20% of Japan's nuclear capacity. Yoneyama previously opposed the restart due to a need for better understanding of the Fukushima disaster. Tepco has regulatory approval to start two reactors but requires governor approval. The company's recovery plans rely on the restart.

site_title: Mixed data drives flat trading; STI up 1 point
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.01 point to 3,498.2, ending flat on Tuesday. Mixed data releases, including China's 6.8% Q1 GDP growth and US retail sales rebound, boosted benchmark indices on Wall Street. However, Singapore's exports fell for the second straight month, while Ezion Holdings and Keppel Corp declined. Events production firm UnUsUaL rose after announcing a stake sale.

site_title: shopper360's Samuel Chan quits amid alleged misconduct probe
summary: SHOPPER360's executive officer Samuel Chan has resigned amid an internal investigation into alleged misconduct. Chan, who was responsible for managing the company's subsidiaries and expansion into Singapore and Myanmar, will be replaced by Chew Sue Ann, the executive chairman and group managing director. Chan, who owns 250,000 ordinary shares, stepped down voluntarily and the company will search for a new replacement.

site_title: Former US first lady Barbara Bush dead at 92: family
summary: Former US First Lady Barbara Bush died on April 17, 2018, at the age of 92, after battling chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and congestive heart problems. She was the wife of President George HW Bush and mother of President George W. Bush. Known for her sharp wit and independent streak, Bush promoted literacy and reading, but avoided discussing politics. A devoted mother and wife, she was the only woman to be both wife and mother of US presidents, following in the footsteps of Abigail Adams.

images.alt_text: Former US first lady Barbara Bush died Tuesday at the age of 92, her husband's office said.

site_title: China police probed Midas ex-boss over loans, board says
summary: China's Economic Crime Investigation Unit has been probing former Midas Holdings executive chairman Chen Wei Ping over suspected fraud related to loans. The investigation began before his resignation in April 2018, but he did not disclose it to the board. Midas Holdings is under investigation by Singapore authorities and its shares remain suspended. The probe was initiated by two Chinese banks in Jilin province, which requested information on loan repayment plans and financial conditions. Chen's involvement in the investigation is still under investigation.

site_title: Unlocking nascent digital power in every organisation
summary: A digital enterprise requires more than technology, it demands a cultural shift. Companies can foster innovation by establishing a shared purpose, promoting open exchange, and practicing meritocracy. Employees should be encouraged to share their ideas, and decision-making processes should consider their opinions. Rapid prototyping and a culture of experimentation can help organisations stay agile in a rapidly changing world. Ultimately, it is the collective effort of employees making incremental changes that can help organisations succeed in the digital age.

site_title: US: Tech rally boosts stocks, Netflix surges
summary: US stocks surged on Tuesday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 1.7% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.9%, as strong corporate earnings lifted the market. Netflix reported a 63% increase in net income and added 7.4 million new subscribers, driving a 9% surge in its stock price. Other tech companies, including Amazon and Alphabet, also saw significant gains. Analysts attribute the rally to a shift in focus away from trade war concerns and towards fundamentals, with the S&P 500 advancing 1.1% to a fresh record.

site_title: Barclays gauging clients' interest in crypo trading desk: sources
summary: Barclays is reportedly gauging client interest in starting a cryptocurrency trading desk, potentially joining Goldman Sachs in pioneering a new business on Wall Street. The bank has conducted a preliminary assessment of demand and feasibility, but no concrete plans have been made. A crypto trading desk would require approval from investment bank boss Tim Throsby and CEO Jes Staley, given the novelty of the asset class and risk requirements. Demand for such services is high, with hedge funds seeking banks to handle transactions and serve as custodians of digital assets.

site_title: Keppel-KBS US Reit posts DPU of 2.32 US cents
summary: Keppel-KBS US Reit reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.32 US cents for the period from November 2017 to March 2018, beating its forecast by 0.4%. The Reit's net property income surpassed its IPO forecast by 5.2%, driven by a stable portfolio performance and a one-off compensation income of US$1 million. The Reit's committed portfolio occupancy was 89.8% as of March 31, 2018, and it continues to actively market available space to improve net property income.

site_title: Glaxo, Novartis join US$4b Gates-led push to fight malaria
summary: GlaxoSmithKline and Novartis have joined a US$4 billion global effort to combat malaria, led by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation. The companies will invest an additional US$250 million and US$100 million, respectively, to combat the disease, which has seen a significant rise in cases and deaths. The effort aims to develop an alternative to artemisinin, a potent medicine under threat from resistant strains, and a malaria vaccine. The vaccine, developed by Glaxo, will begin testing in Africa later this year, while gene editing research holds promise for preventing malaria transmission.

site_title: Netflix's boost in original programming pays off with subscriber surge
summary: Netflix exceeded analyst expectations with a 7.4 million new subscriber surge from January to March, driven by its original programming. The company's revenue grew 40% year-over-year to $3.7 billion, and its market capitalization reached $137.2 billion. Netflix's debt levels remain modest, and its shares jumped 7% in after-hours trading. The company's content spending is fueling growth, with analysts noting that subscribers are accelerating even at higher pricing.

site_title: Goldman Sachs reports higher Q1 earnings
summary: Goldman Sachs reported a 26.6% increase in Q1 net income to $2.7 billion, driven by a 25% rise in revenues to $10.0 billion. The bank's fixed income division and equity trading saw significant growth, with Goldman's chief financial officer stating that the current dynamics are "more durable" than in 2015. The bank also reported a 1.4% drop in shares to $254.35. Additionally, Goldman is investing in its online lending business, Marcus, which saw $500 million in loan growth, and is exploring potential growth opportunities in credit cards.

site_title: Industrial output cools in March, but stays strong
summary: US industrial output slowed in March, rising 0.5% despite a sudden drop in manufacturing, which edged up only 0.1%. Higher energy consumption contributed to the increase, with utilities producing more due to cooler weather. Despite the slowdown, industrial output remains 4.3% above the same month last year, and the auto sector experienced a 2.7% jump.

site_title: China to hold military drills in Taiwan Strait
summary: China is set to hold live-fire drills in the Taiwan Strait on Wednesday, amid escalating tensions with Taiwan. The drills coincide with Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen's visit to Swaziland, one of the island's few international allies. China views Taiwan as part of its territory, and has warned Taipei about seeking independence or closer ties with the US. The drills are part of Beijing's psychological warfare against Taiwan, and may also serve as a signal to Washington. China's military has increased patrols around Taiwan and used diplomatic pressure to isolate the island internationally since Tsai took office in 2016.

site_title: Ascott Reit's DPU up 9% to 1.28 Singapore cents for Q1
summary: Ascott Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) rose 9% to 1.28 Singapore cents for Q1, driven by contributions from acquisitions in 2017 and a realised exchange gain. Gross revenue edged up 1% to S$112.8 million, while gross profit rose 3% to S$48.7 million. The trust has 73 properties in 37 cities across 14 countries and 86% of its total borrowings are on fixed interest rates. Ascott Reit's units finished down 0.88% at S$1.13 on Tuesday before the Q1 results were released.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Brunei prince and Ron Sim buy into Singapore-listed UnUsUaL in S$25.8m deal
summary: Brunei Prince Abdul Qawi and Singapore's Ron Sim have teamed up to buy a 5.39% stake in concert promotion and events company UnUsUaL for S$25.8 million. The shares were sold at a 1% discount to the Monday closing price of S$0.47, with Prince Qawi acquiring 49 million shares for S$22.8 million and Mr. Sim's R3 Asian Gems buying about 6.5 million shares for S$3 million. The deal is not expected to impact UnUsUaL's earnings per share and net tangible asset per share for the current financial year.

images.alt_text: Prince Qawi (left) acquired 49 million of UnUsUal shares for S$22.8m, representing a 4.76% stake. Mr Sim's R3 Asian Gems bought about 6.5 million shares for S$3m - a 0.63% shareholding.

site_title: Taking connectivity to the next level
summary: The Singapore maritime industry is leveraging digitalization to enhance connectivity and competitiveness. The blurring of lines between shipping and logistics sectors requires a holistic view to create a diverse and robust maritime ecosystem. PSA, a global port operator, emphasizes connectivity as it serves as a gateway to vast markets and hinterlands. This shift aims to give Singapore a competitive edge in the industry, capitalizing on its world-class infrastructure and inter-connected network.

site_title: With Uber off the roads, will ComfortDelGro shift gears?
summary: ComfortDelGro's shares have risen 10% this year after institutional investors bought a net S$18.4 million of its shares in April. The transport giant's taxi rental business is expected to bottom out, with revenue continuing to fall but potentially rebounding. ComfortDelGro's fleet has contracted by 3.5% to 12,775 taxis, while rival taxi companies have seen a smaller decline. The company is considering partnering with Go-Jek or Grab, and may take on debt to fund growth. Despite its challenges, ComfortDelGro's management is optimistic about its future, with plans to expand into new markets and consider projects with lower margins.

site_title: Europe could be counterweight to global wave of nationalism
summary: Europe is poised to counter the global rise of nationalism and authoritarianism, with the European Union (EU) showing resilience and a strong desire for democratic values and international cooperation. Despite concerns about the EU's "democratic deficit," a majority of respondents view the EU positively, with 75% holding a favorable opinion. The election of French President Emmanuel Macron and the formation of a pro-European coalition government in Germany have strengthened the EU's prospects. Europe has the opportunity to lead a reinvigoration of democratic values and international cooperation, potentially becoming a third "pole" in the new world order, and asserting itself more effectively on the international stage.

site_title: Earth, wind and liars amid moneyed politics
summary: The article discusses the progress of renewable energy, particularly wind and solar power, in reducing costs and increasing efficiency. Despite technological advancements, the fossil fuel industry's influence and lobbying efforts are hindering the transition to renewable energy. The article argues that politicians and business leaders who support fossil fuels are trying to slow down the transition, prioritizing profits over environmental and economic benefits. The author concludes that the delay in transitioning to renewable energy will result in significant costs, including thousands of lives lost and increased risk of climate catastrophe.

site_title: What expats like and are peeved about in Singapore
summary: International expats in Singapore generally rate the city highly, with an average score of 8.2 out of 10, citing its safety, public transport, and low tax rates as positives. However, they express frustration with high property and living costs, as well as the cost of locally produced media and fashion. The majority of expats (55%) work longer hours than they did back home, and 35% earn more in Singapore. The top industries attracting international professionals are finance, education, and healthcare.

site_title: IMF spots trouble ahead as solid world growth poised to slow
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) predicted the world economy will experience its strongest upswing since 2011 for the next two years, with global growth forecasted at 3.9% this year and next. However, beyond that horizon, the fund warned that growth will fade due to central banks tightening monetary policy, the US fiscal stimulus subsiding, and China's slowdown. The IMF cautioned that a trade war could derail the expansion, citing the risk of tit-for-tat sanctions and the potential for global trading order to be "torn apart".

site_title: Higher costs eat into Keppel T&T's bottom line
summary: Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation (Keppel T&T) posted a net profit of S$9.43 million for the first quarter of 2018, a 16.3% decline from the previous year. Revenue rose 5.1% to S$42.81 million, driven by higher facility and project management fees in its data centre division. The logistics segment, accounting for most revenue, faced lower container throughput in China and higher expenses. The company reported a 1.7 Singapore cent earnings per share and a 0.63% decline in its counter price to S$1.57.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Euro climbs to 3-week high as US dollar weakens
summary: The euro rose to a 3-week high against the US dollar, reaching $1.2412, driven by solid Chinese economic data and reduced concerns about US strikes in Syria. This rally was also fueled by a weaker US dollar, with investors believing the US administration wants to see a weaker currency. The euro's gains were tempered by a monthly survey showing declining German investor morale. Meanwhile, the Swiss franc fell to its lowest level since 2015, and several Asian currencies, including the Korean Won, rose on hopes of a calming US-China trade conflict.

site_title: Hong Kong's tiny golf carts at HK$2m cost more than a Porsche Boxster
summary: In Hong Kong's upscale residential development of Discovery Bay, tiny golf carts are selling for over HK$2 million (US$260,000), surpassing the prices of luxury cars like the Porsche Boxster. The carts are in high demand due to the area's limited private car access and the lack of affordable housing options, making them a sought-after investment. Residents, including business executives and expatriates, are willing to pay top dollar for the convenience and potential rental income, despite the high cost of ownership.

site_title: IMF hits out at New Zealand ban on foreign home buyers
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) criticized New Zealand's ban on foreign home buyers, calling it "discriminatory" and unlikely to improve housing affordability. The IMF said foreign buyers play a minor role in the market and a broader policy agenda would address issues. The ban aims to curb speculation but may deter overseas investors, which could worsen housing supply. The IMF also warned against further easing or tightening of mortgage lending restrictions and recommended the Reserve Bank of New Zealand maintain its current stance on household debt.

site_title: Iron Man swears in 37 new Avengers
summary: Iron Man surprised 37 children from the Make-A-Wish Foundation by swearing them in as Avengers at Avengers Academy in Singapore. The event, a collaboration between Make-A-Wish Singapore, Marina Bay Sands, and The Walt Disney Company, was attended by the children and their parents. Robert Downey Jr., who played Tony Stark/Iron Man, handed out goodie bags and recited a pledge with the children. This unique event aimed to bring joy and inspiration to children with life-threatening illnesses.

site_title: SMRT CEO Desmond Kuek stepping down
summary: Singapore's SMRT CEO Desmond Kuek is stepping down after 5.5 years, with former Chief of Defence Force Neo Kian Hong expected to take over. Neo, 54, has a 30-year military career and was permanent secretary for education development. Under Kuek's leadership, SMRT faced major challenges, including repeated breakdowns and accidents, but also implemented changes such as privatisation and a new rail financing framework. Kuek's successor will face the challenge of maintaining the improved rail performance and addressing "deep-seated cultural issues" within the workforce.

images.alt_text: Under his watch, SMRT faced major challenges and repeated breakdowns, even as it tried to shore up its ageing infrastructure

site_title: Deutsche Bank calls off India portfolio sale: sources
summary: Deutsche Bank has called off talks to sell its retail and private wealth businesses in India to IndusInd Bank, citing a potential increase in investment in the country. The businesses, valued at around $6 billion, were previously part of a plan to focus on the home market. The decision comes after former CEO John Cryan stepped down, and new CEO Christian Sewing considers revising a five-year turnaround plan. This move may signal a shift in Deutsche Bank's strategy in India, where it operates with a significant workforce and generates substantial income.

site_title: China beats forecasts with 6.8% growth in first quarter
summary: China's economy grew 6.8% in the first quarter of 2018, beating forecasts and driven by strong consumer demand and property investment. Despite rising trade tensions with the US, the growth is seen as a positive sign for Beijing, giving policymakers room to address financial and environmental risks without stalling growth. Resilient consumption and a 10.4% rise in real estate investment supported the economy, with March retail sales rising 10.1% and industrial output expanding 6% in March. The growth sets a good foundation for the full year, with the government's target of 6.5% growth likely to be met.

site_title: Boeing 787's range capped by FAA after latest Rolls glitch
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration has restricted Boeing 787 Dreamliner planes with potentially faulty Rolls-Royce engines from operating more than 140 minutes from a diversionary airport, down from 330 minutes previously. This measure affects about a quarter of in-service 787s, with about 14 US planes impacted. The restrictions come after durability issues were found in the Trent 1000 "package C" engines, which have been found to vibrate at high levels of thrust under certain conditions. The directive will be reassessed once Rolls-Royce presents a fix for the fault.

site_title: Bayer's magic formula in Singapore - open collaboration
summary: Bayer Pharmaceuticals has invested over S$27 million in Singapore over 10 years through public-private partnerships, particularly in clinical research, with a focus on collaborations with the government, academic and scientific communities, and the private sector. The company's senior vice-president Claus Zieler emphasized the importance of open collaboration in driving innovation and improving patient outcomes. Despite not manufacturing in Singapore, Bayer views the country as an attractive location for research and development due to its excellent medical and technical infrastructure.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Asia Gardens sold en bloc for S$343m to consortium
summary: Asia Gardens, a 23-storey freehold development in Singapore, was sold en bloc for S$343 million to a consortium led by Sustained Land. The sale price reflects a land rate of S$1,722 per square foot per plot ratio. The development, with 80 apartment units and four penthouses, can be redeveloped into a 36-storey condo with 264 units, subject to authorities' approvals. Owners are expected to receive S$3.476 million to S$7.73 million per unit, with no development charge payable due to the high development baseline.

site_title: Ezion loses steam after early gains on return to trading
summary: Ezion Holdings, a Singapore-based offshore and marine group, saw its stock price slip to negative territory after trading resumed, closing 0.3 cents down at 19.4 cents. The stock reached an intra-day high of 25.5 cents but mostly hovered at around 20 cents. Despite high trading volume, Ezion failed to hold early gains, falling to a marginally lower price.

site_title: Cocoa prices jump after Citigroup sees supply shortages ahead
summary: Cocoa prices surged after Citigroup predicted a decade-long supply shortage, citing declining Western African production due to El Nino weather patterns and aging trees in Indonesia. The market reversal comes after two years of 40% price drops, affecting growers who cut spending on farm maintenance, leading to lower crop quality and yields. Demand for chocolate remains strong, with analysts predicting a bullish market, potentially reaching a 32-year high in 2011.

images.alt_text: Cocoa prices have surged as dryness is hitting crops in West Africa, which accounts for more than two-thirds of global supplies.

site_title: Brokers take
summary: Analysts at Maybank Kim Eng maintain their "hold" rating on M1 Singapore's shares despite Q1 2018 results being in line with low expectations. The implementation of new contract accounting standards had less impact on M1's profits than peers. However, increasing competition in the wireless space constrains operational and share price performances. Meanwhile, Maybank Kim Eng upgrades IHH Healthcare to "buy" with a target price of RM7.00, citing long-term advantages from potential acquisition of Fortis.

site_title: Enhancing non-physical links the way forward
summary: Leading maritime companies such as APL, NOL, YCH, and BHP are focusing on enhancing non-physical links to improve connectivity and efficiency in global trade. APL and NOL emphasize the importance of seamless information flow across stakeholders, while YCH and BHP highlight the benefits of integrating physical, information, and financial flows in supply chain management. The companies also see opportunities in the blurring of boundaries between shipping and adjacent sectors, citing Industry 4.0 and digitalization as key drivers of change. They believe that greater connectivity can lead to improved safety standards, lower shipping emissions, and new value creation opportunities.

site_title: Brunei prince and Ron Sim buy into Singapore-listed UnUsUaL in S$25.8m deal
summary: Brunei Prince Abdul Qawi and Singaporean businessman Ron Sim have invested S$25.8 million in UnUsUaL, a Singapore-listed concert promotion and events company, acquiring a 5.39% stake. The shares were sold at a 1% discount to the Monday closing price of S$0.47. The deal does not affect UnUsUaL's earnings per share and net tangible asset per share, according to mm2 Asia, the company's parent. The new shareholders see strong potential in UnUsUaL's business prospects and are excited to help the company expand its regional footprint.

site_title: New Singapore jobs portal to better match job-seekers and employers
summary: Singapore has launched a new national jobs portal called MyCareersFuture.sg to better match job-seekers with employers. The portal, developed by Workforce Singapore and GovTech, uses machine learning to analyze job descriptions and identify required skills, then compares them with job-seekers' skills. The site aims to encourage job-seekers to reflect on their skills and experience, and will also display upfront application numbers and posting dates. The new portal replaces the existing Jobs Bank and will complement the MySkillsFuture.sg portal, which provides career pathways and training information.

site_title: Pedestrian safety is paramount in personal mobility devices framework
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore is revisiting the rules for personal mobility devices (PMDs) after a surge in accidents involving the devices. The LTA has introduced harsher penalties for PMD users who ride on roads and expressways, but concerns remain about PMD riders speeding on footpaths, posing a risk to vulnerable pedestrians, particularly the elderly and young. An online survey is being conducted to gather public feedback on how PMD users and cyclists should behave in crowded areas and footpaths, with proposals to limit PMD speeds to a walking pace.

site_title: Net-a-Porter founder makes comeback
summary: Net-a-Porter founder Natalie Massenet, who stepped down as executive chairwoman in 2015, is making a comeback in e-commerce as a venture capitalist. Despite initially planning to retire, Massenet is returning to the industry she co-founded.

site_title: Q1 profit at largest US health insurer beats estimates
summary: UNITEDHEALTH Group Inc, the largest US health insurer, reported a quarterly profit of US$2.84 billion, beating Wall Street estimates. The company raised its earnings forecast to a range of US$12.40 to US$12.65 per share, up from US$12.30 to US$12.60 per share. Total revenue rose 13.3% to US$55.19 billion, and the medical care ratio improved to 81.4% from 82.4% last year. The company's adjusted earnings per share were US$3.04, exceeding analyst expectations.

site_title: Temasek hikes Bayer stake in 3b euro share sale
summary: Temasek, a Singaporean state investment company, has agreed to invest 3 billion euros (S$4.8 billion) in Bayer, a German drugmaker, as part of Bayer's planned US$62.5 billion takeover of seed maker Monsanto. Temasek will own approximately 4% of Bayer after the transaction. The investment is part of Bayer's business strategy and growth prospects, according to CEO Werner Baumann. The proceeds from the placement will be used to fund the Monsanto takeover, which has not yet received antitrust clearance.

site_title: PM Lee in London for Commonwealth leaders' summit
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong is attending the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting (Chogm) in London, starting a three-day visit. This year's meeting is likely to be the last for Queen Elizabeth II, and leaders will discuss global and regional issues, including trade, investment, and climate change. Britain is expected to make a pitch for greater trade with Commonwealth nations, despite lagging behind in trade with European neighbours.

site_title: China Sports files for judicial management in S'pore High Court
summary: China Sports International, a Singapore-based sports apparel manufacturer, has filed for judicial management in the Singapore High Court. The company, which manufactures under the Yeli brand, has proposed the appointment of two Deloitte & Touche LLP partners to manage its affairs during this period. This comes after the company failed to convene its annual general meeting for FY17 and received a statutory demand for unpaid fees. The court has yet to fix a date for the hearing of the application, which was filed after the company announced it may be involved in past or ongoing lawsuits.

site_title: Tech and data key to transforming the travel trade
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board aims to transform the travel industry using technology and data. The Tourism Information and Services Hub (TIH) platform provides up-to-date information on Singapore's tourism offerings and enables businesses to access plug-and-play travel software services. The STB will also share data analytics with the industry, and partners such as Expedia will share booking data to personalize experiences for visitors. This is part of the board's efforts to sharpen marketing efforts, refresh tourism products, and boost productivity, following record tourism spending and visitor arrivals in 2017.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Dr M in retort to Hadi: 'Go back to school; teach religion'
summary: Veteran Malaysian politician Tun Dr Mahathir Mohamad retorted to PAS president Datuk Seri Abdul Hadi Awang, advising him to "go back to school and teach religion" instead of pursuing politics. Dr Mahathir made the comment during a Pakatan Harapan presidential council meeting, criticizing Hadi's lack of understanding of administration and politics. Dr Mahathir also questioned Hadi's record as Mentri Besar of Terengganu, implying he should focus on teaching rather than politics.

images.alt_text: Mr Hadi had asked Dr Mahathir to serve at Klinik 1Malaysia instead of contesting in GE14, which riled the 93-year-old Dr M.

site_title: Singapore exports fall for 2nd consecutive month in March
summary: Singapore's exports fell for the second consecutive month in March, with non-oil domestic exports (NODX) decreasing by 2.7% due to cooling electronics demand, a strengthening Singdollar, and high base effects. Global trade tensions also pose a risk to the small, trade-dependent economy. Despite this, economists expect shipments to grow for the rest of 2018 at a more muted pace. The moderation of electronics shipments aligns with economists' projections, and manufacturing growth is expected to remain positive but ease to the low single-digit by year-end.

site_title: India calms currency crunch tensions; ensures adequate supply
summary: India's government and central bank have assured an adequate supply of currency notes after reports of automated teller machine shortages in various parts of the country. The shortage occurred due to an unusual rise in currency demand during the crop harvest season and festival season. The government and central bank have taken measures to ensure sufficient cash availability, alleviating tensions caused by the shortage.

site_title: NTU launches new master's programme for asset and wealth management
summary: NTU launches a new Master of Science in Asset and Wealth Management, with classes in Singapore, London, and New York. The program, starting in January 2019, offers two specialisation tracks and includes internships and work-related projects. Students can complete the course in a year or three years while working full-time. The program is aligned with industry skills frameworks and offers accreditation and certification, with course subsidies available to Singapore citizens.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: A stratospheric calling to document viruses and how they affect humans
summary: An international team of researchers collected a large number of viruses in Spain, discovering that some 800 million viruses fall onto every square meter of the planet daily. The viruses, mostly from sea spray and dust storms, circulate above weather systems but below airline travel levels, with little known about this realm. The team's findings suggest a previously unknown stream of viruses circling the planet, highlighting the need for further research into this unexplored environment.

site_title: Olam launches AtSource platform in sustainability push
summary: Olam International launched the AtSource platform, a digital effort to provide customers with data on the supply chain and sustainability of its products. The platform offers three tiers of data, from basic information to detailed indicators and customizable programs, aiming to improve customer stickiness and differentiate Olam from competitors. The company aims to achieve full traceability to farmers by 2025 and hopes the platform will help regenerate farming systems, attract talent, and create long-term value.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: OCBC Bank priced A$600 million of senior floating rate notes due 2021 under its Global Medium Term Note Programme. The notes will bear interest at the three-month Bank Bill Swap reference rate plus 0.7% per annum, payable quarterly. The issuance is part of OCBC's US$30 billion Global Medium Term Note Programme.

site_title: MPA, Namic ink MOU to develop 3D printing applications for maritime sector
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) and the National Additive Manufacturing Innovation Cluster (Namic) signed a memorandum of understanding to develop 3D printing applications for the maritime sector. The partnership aims to boost the development of additive manufacturing and grow Singapore's position as a hub for digital manufacturing. Namic, led by Nanyang Technological University, will translate 3D printing research into commercial applications, while MPA will provide support for skills development and certification. The partnership is expected to create efficiency and productivity gains for the shipping community.

site_title: Finding emerging market equities with a social conscience
summary: Investors seeking emerging market equities with a social conscience can now find funds that prioritize environmental, social, and governance (ESG) performance. According to Morningstar, 10 mutual funds and exchange-traded funds (ETFs) focus on emerging markets with high ESG scores. Studies show that ESG-indexed funds outperformed the standard emerging markets index from 2016 to 2020, with a 4.9% average annual return compared to 8.6% for the ESG index. Actively managed and indexed ESG funds offer different approaches, but investors should expect divergent performance from conventional benchmarks.

site_title: UK wages rise most since 2015 as end to squeeze nears
summary: UK wages are rising at their fastest pace in almost three years, with annual pay growth excluding bonuses accelerating to 2.8% in the three months through February. This marks a significant improvement after wages lagged behind prices for over a year, suppressing consumer spending and holding back overall economic growth. The rise in wages may reinforce speculation of a Bank of England interest rate hike next month, despite a forecasted fall in inflation to 2% this year.

site_title: EU seeks terror e-evidence faster from US internet firms
summary: The European Union proposed new rules to facilitate the swift exchange of digital evidence, such as emails and text messages, from US and other internet firms to aid in terror and crime investigations. The proposed law requires service providers to respond within 10 days or 6 hours in emergencies, streamlining the process. The new rules, unveiled in the European Parliament, aim to balance data protection with law enforcement needs, following the US adoption of the CLOUD Act.

site_title: Oil rebounds as Opec's hints of extended cuts stoke optimism
summary: Oil prices rebounded 0.5% after OPEC hinted at extending output cuts into 2019, boosting optimism and US stockpile forecasts. Analysts predict US crude inventories fell last week, and OPEC's compliance rate rose to 85% in March. Oil surged to a three-year high last week due to geopolitical risks, but record US production remains a concern. West Texas Intermediate futures rose 42 cents to $66.64 a barrel, while Brent climbed 32 cents to $71.74 a barrel.

site_title: Hegemonic designs in the Middle East clash
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin is focusing on increasing Russia's strategic visibility and sphere of influence in the Middle East, despite internal contradictions and clashing goals with Iran and Turkey. US President Donald Trump's transactional foreign policy is contributing to the demise of traditional US strategic dominance in the region. This shift in global power dynamics has significant implications for regional stability, and Putin's efforts may be seen as a response to the US's diminished influence. The Iran-Russia-Turkey nexus is a complex and potentially potent alliance, but its long-term prospects remain uncertain.

site_title: Thailand approves tax incentive plan to encourage bank mergers
summary: Thailand's Cabinet approved a tax incentive plan to encourage mergers among the country's commercial banks, aiming to improve their competitiveness with regional rivals. The plan includes tax breaks for shareholders with stakes in commercial banks, with the goal of increasing their assets to at least 4 trillion baht. This move follows the comparison between Thailand's largest commercial banks and those in Malaysia and Singapore, where the entry level for banks is significantly higher. The plan aims to boost the country's banking sector and improve its position in the region.

site_title: Pyongyang plans formal nod to denuclearization, Seoul says
summary: North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un plans to formally announce his willingness to denuclearize the country when he meets with South Korean President Moon Jae-in on April 27. The statement will be part of a joint declaration, with negotiators agreeing on a rough framework. However, significant issues remain, including whether the two Koreas will commit to regular summit meetings and whether North Korea will commit to dismantling its nuclear weapons program. The declaration will likely be broad and abstract, with substantial deals requiring direct talks between Kim and US President Donald Trump.

site_title: Evonik opens new research hub in Singapore
summary: Evonik Industries, a German specialty chemicals firm, has opened a research hub in Singapore as part of its efforts to internationalize research and development activities. The hub, located in Biopolis, will focus on functional surfaces and additive manufacturing, with a headcount of 50 people. The center will collaborate with local research institutions and organizations, including Nanyang Technological University, to develop new technologies. Evonik aims to strengthen its position as a global leader in specialty chemicals through innovative research and partnerships.

site_title: China's property investment up 10.4% in Q1
summary: China's property investment grew 10.4% in Q1, the fastest year-to-date growth in three years, with new construction accelerating. Despite slowing property sales, which rose 3.6% in January-March, the solid activity supported broader growth in the first quarter. New construction starts rose 9.7% year-on-year, and investment is estimated to grow 5% in 2018. Chinese policymakers aim for a soft landing without disrupting the economy, with a focus on addressing housing demand and containing soaring home prices.

site_title: Robo-breadmaker firm Zimplistic gets US$30m in series C funding
summary: Zimplistic, a Singapore-based firm that creates the automated flatbread-making robot Rotimatic, has secured US$30 million in series C funding led by Credence Partners and EDBI. The investment will support the company's expansion into new markets and converting 25% of the world's flatbread-eaters into Rotimatic users. With over 30,000 customers and 15 million flatbreads made, Zimplistic plans to leverage the funding to further develop its IoT appliance with online access and machine intelligence.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: First Reit improves Q1 DPU to 2.15 cents
summary: First Reit, a Singaporean healthcare real estate investment trust (REIT), reported a 1.8% increase in Q1 income available for distribution to S$16.9 million, driven by 5.8% growth in gross revenue and 5.8% rise in net property income. The company's earnings per unit increased to 1.96 Singapore cents, while net asset value per unit remained stable at 101.4 Singapore cents. CEO Victor Tan attributed the growth to the trust's long-term strategy of making yield-accretive acquisitions.

site_title: DeClout lenders get charge over Procurri shares
summary: DeClout, a technology firm, has given charge over 46.83% of its shares in Procurri to two private lenders as part of a two-year, S$10 million loan. The charge is related to a loan entered into last week, with DeClout using its entire stake in Procurri as collateral.

site_title: IMF spots trouble ahead as solid world growth poised to slow
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has revised its forecast, predicting a 3.9% global growth rate for this year and next, but warns of a slowdown in the following years. The fund attributes this to central banks tightening monetary policy, the US fiscal stimulus subsiding, and China's gradual slowdown continuing. The IMF's forecast suggests the world economy's strongest upswing since 2011 will continue for two years before fading.

site_title: Sustainable development: What does it really mean?
summary: Sustainable development, a concept widely adopted by governments and companies, lacks definition and its ambiguity allows for exaggerated claims. The term originated from the 1987 Brundtland Commission report, defining it as development that meets present needs without compromising future generations' needs. However, practical applications are often misused, such as the US ethanol policy, which has little discernible benefit to energy security or reducing CO2 emissions. Organic farming, touted as a sustainable alternative, is not viable for the world at large, yet it has contributed to improved agricultural productivity and saved millions of lives through the Green Revolution.

site_title: US industrial output cools in March but stays strong
summary: US industrial output slowed in March, rising 0.5% despite a drop in manufacturing, due to higher energy consumption. This was above analyst expectations and still 4.3% above the same month last year. Manufacturing growth nearly halted, with only a 0.1% increase, while oil and gas production drove the mining sector one percent higher. Total capacity in use rose to 78%, overshooting forecasts.

site_title: Tesla idles Model 3 as Musk unable to make on-the-fly fixes
summary: Tesla has temporarily suspended production of the Model 3 sedan for 4-5 days, marking the second time in two months, due to production issues and "excessive" automation. The pause is another setback for Elon Musk's attempt to mass-manufacture the car, with analysts criticizing the company's approach to production. The shutdown will impact Tesla employees, who may use vacation days or stay home without pay, and comes as the company seeks to boost production and address bottlenecks in its vehicle and battery factories.

site_title: Singapore 3rd most expensive in Asia for business travel in 2017
summary: Singapore ranked third most expensive city in Asia for business travel in 2017, alongside Seoul, with Hong Kong and Tokyo holding the top spots globally. The city-state's average business trip cost rose to US$479, primarily due to increased restaurant prices. New York maintained its position as the most expensive location for global business travel, with an average cost of US$793 per day. Asian cities like Bangkok and Shanghai became more expensive, while Malaysian cities remained the cheapest in the region.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end flat as traders await US-Japan summit
summary: Tokyo stocks closed flat on April 17, 2018, as investors awaited the US-Japan summit, which focused on trade tensions and North Korea. The benchmark Nikkei 225 rose 0.06% to 21,847.59, while the Topix fell 0.36% to 1,729.98. The summit's outcome was expected to impact global markets, but no significant announcements were made at the time.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.73 points to 1,880.49, driven by higher volume of 3.09 billion shares worth RM2.79 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 506 to 424, marking a positive close on Tuesday.

site_title: Europe: Stocks mostly up in early trade
summary: European stock markets rose in early trade on Monday, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 up 0.6% to 12,461.71 points and Paris' CAC 40 up 0.3% to 5,327.38 points. London's FTSE 100 index remained flat at 7,196.22 points. The gains were driven by mining and healthcare stocks, with investors focusing on US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Focusing on a manager's best stock ideas may not be a good idea
summary: A study by Morningstar found that actively managed stock funds with concentrated portfolios (30-40 holdings) failed to beat more diversified rivals in the first quarter and in one, three, and five years, ending March 31. Despite this, some focus funds did exceptionally well, revealing the potential for both great heights and depths. Concentrated funds can accentuate the gap between the best and worst performers, making them more volatile. However, some focus funds have been consistently successful, such as Guinness Atkinson Global Innovators and Baron Fifth Avenue Growth, which charge higher fees due to their higher expense ratios.

images.alt_text: Despite the so-so performance of focus funds as a group, some did exceptionally well, and that reveals the good and bad news about them: Their portfolio concentration can accentuate the gap between the best and worst.

site_title: China police probed former Midas boss over subsidiary's loans: Midas board
summary: China's Economic Crime Investigation Unit has been probing former Midas Holdings executive chairman Chen Wei Ping over suspected fraud related to loans issued by Midas subsidiary Jilin Midas Light Alloy (JMLA). The investigation began before Chen's resignation on April 2, with two Chinese banks in Jilin province being advised to provide explanations within five days. Chen did not disclose the investigation to the board. Midas is currently under investigation by Singapore authorities and its shares remain suspended.

site_title: Inch by inch, an operatic jewel is polished
summary: The nearly 300-year-old Margravial Opera House in Bayreuth, Germany, has reopened to the public after a six-year, 29.6 million euro renovation. The 500-seat theater, a UNESCO World Heritage site, has been restored to its original brilliance, featuring its ornate details, murals, and trompe l'oeil effects. The renovation included enlarging the proscenium, replacing chairs, and modernizing stage machinery and lighting. The opera house will host various performances, including a postmodern staging of Johann Adolf Hasse's "Artaserse" and productions of Monteverdi's "L'Orfeo."

site_title: SMRT's Desmond Kuek stepping down
summary: SMRT's CEO Desmond Kuek is stepping down after five-and-a-half years, with former Chief of Defence Force Neo Kian Hong expected to take over. Kuek's tenure was marked by major challenges, including repeated breakdowns and accidents, but also fundamental changes such as the privatisation of SMRT and the implementation of a new rail financing framework. Under Kuek's watch, SMRT's rail performance has improved significantly, with reliability targets set for 2020.

site_title: All aboard for Singapore Maritime Week
summary: Singapore Maritime Week, starting next week, will bring together the international maritime community for conferences, dialogues, exhibitions, and social events. The event, now in its 17th year, aims to promote Singapore as a global maritime hub and increase public awareness of the industry. The week-long event will feature over 30 activities, including lectures, symposiums, and a public exhibition showcasing maritime Singapore. Additionally, the Amazing Maritime Challenge, a game-based event, will be held to educate the public about the industry.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,505.12, up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Tuesday, April 17, 2018, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.2% to 3,505.12. Gainers outnumbered losers 176 to 154, with 1.14 billion shares changing hands. Key movers included Ezion, up S$0.008, and DBS Group Holdings, up 1.09%. The index was boosted by positive sentiment, with investors shrugging off tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Abu Dhabi's Aldar Properties eyes new acquisitions-CEO
summary: Aldar Properties, an Abu Dhabi-based developer, plans to make new acquisitions in the slowing property market, according to its CEO. The company has recently bought an office tower and expects to attract more retail and institutional investors after increasing foreign ownership in its stock. Aldar is focusing on affordable housing, which is under-serviced, and expects "real investors, real demand and end-users" in the market. The company will also continue to invest in new projects and acquisitions, driven by ample opportunities in the market conditions.

site_title: Nestle, retailers nearing compromise in price row - source
summary: Nestle and European retailers, including Edeka, are nearing a compromise in their price dispute. The negotiations, which have been ongoing for months, remain open, with no agreement yet reached. Nestle is facing pressure to boost revenue and profit margins following its weakest annual sales growth in decades. The talks are centered on issues such as cooperative marketing campaigns and price concessions, with Nestle reportedly willing to make concessions. A breakthrough is expected, but details of the potential deal have not been confirmed.

site_title: YuuZoo launches social commerce halal lifestyle app YuuHalal in Singapore
summary: YuuZoo Corporation has launched YuuHalal, a social commerce app catering to Singapore's halal-lifestyle community, in beta testing. The app, launched at The Muslim World event, provides access to halal-only products and services. The platform aims to bridge various services into one dynamic platform, with user feedback expected to shape its development. YuuZoo shares are suspended on the Singapore Exchange amid the launch.

site_title: First Reit Q1 DPU up 1 cent to 2.15 Singapore cents
summary: First Reit's Q1 DPU rose 1 cent to 2.15 Singapore cents, a 1.8% increase from the previous year, driven by 5.8% growth in gross revenue from its Indonesian and Singaporean properties. Net property income also increased 5.8% to S$28.4 million. Earnings per unit rose to 1.96 Singapore cents, while net asset value per unit remained stable at 101.4 Singapore cents. The company's CEO stated that its long-term strategy of making yield accretive acquisitions will continue to enhance income stability and maximize returns for unitholders.

site_title: Deutsche Bank said to shelve $4.6b India portfolio sale
summary: Deutsche Bank has cancelled talks to sell its $4.6 billion retail and private wealth businesses in India to IndusInd Bank. The decision comes after former CEO John Cryan stepped down, and the bank is now considering increasing its investment in India. This reversal follows initial plans to sell the units in January as part of a focus on its home market.

site_title: Singapore shares close flat on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's stock market closed flat on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 1.01 points to 3,498.20. Trading volume reached 2.1 billion shares worth S$1.1 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 219 to 185.

site_title: Banyan Tree increases stake in Laguna Resorts & Hotels to 86%
summary: Banyan Tree Holdings increased its stake in Laguna Resorts & Hotels to 86.3% after a voluntary tender offer for shares it didn't own. The offer price was 34% higher than the last traded price of 29.75 baht. Banyan Tree will hold about 45% of Laguna directly, while its subsidiary will hold 30%. The acquisition was completed following acceptances from shareholders representing 20.53% of the total issued share capital. The company has no plans to delist Laguna.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Shares retreat despite China data
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks fell on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index down 0.83% and the Shanghai Composite Index down 1.41%. The decline followed a better-than-expected growth figure for China's economy in the first three months, which failed to boost investor confidence. This marks a fourth straight loss for the Hang Seng Index.

site_title: IMF takes a swipe at New Zealand ban on foreign house buyers
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has criticized New Zealand's ban on foreign home buyers, labeling it "discriminatory" and unlikely to improve housing affordability. The IMF suggests the ban may deter foreign investment, which could worsen the housing supply issue. The country's Labour-led government has implemented a range of measures to address the housing crisis, including a ban on foreign speculators. The IMF's report concludes that New Zealand's economic growth will remain around 3% in the near term, with risks broadly balanced.

site_title: Amazon in talks with airline Azul for shipping in Brazil -sources
summary: Amazon is in talks with Brazilian airline Azul to ship goods in the country, marking the retailer's big plans in Latin America's largest economy. The talks, which involve a network of over 100 airports, aim to overcome logistical challenges and sell products directly to consumers nationwide. This move comes after Amazon leased a warehouse and met with manufacturers to discuss in-house storage and distribution. The partnership could help Amazon gain a foothold in Brazil's competitive e-commerce market, which has seen online sales double in four years and are expected to grow at a double-digit pace.

site_title: Singapore Maritime Week 2018 to draw 30,000 visitors
summary: Singapore's Maritime Week 2018 will draw 30,000 visitors from April 21 to 29, focusing on digitalisation and industry transformation. The event, themed "Positioning for Future Growth - Driving Connectivity, Innovation and Talent," will feature 19 forums, 11 networking receptions, and four public outreach activities. Keynote speakers include AP Møller-Maersk's CEO Søren Skou and an artificial intelligence expert from IBM. The week aims to enhance Singapore's physical and non-physical connectivity, innovation ecosystem, and talent pool.

site_title: Temasek interested in buying into HNA's Hong Kong airlines: source
summary: Singapore state investor Temasek Holdings has expressed interest in buying into Hong Kong Airlines and Hong Kong Express Airways, controlled by debt-laden Chinese conglomerate HNA. The potential deal, subject to due diligence, would see Temasek emerge as a minority holder and gain an aviation foothold closer to mainland China. This move would complement Temasek's majority stake in Singapore Airlines, which sources the investment is unrelated to. A partnership between Temasek and HNA was signed last week to explore business collaborations in aviation and logistics.

site_title: Keppel-KBS US Reit posts 2.32 US cents in DPU post-listing
summary: Keppel-KBS US Reit delivered a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.32 US cents, beating its forecast by 0.4%, in its first quarterly results since listing. The Reit's net property income of US$22.3 million surpassed its IPO forecast by 5.2%, driven by stable portfolio performance and a one-off compensation income of US$1 million. The Reit's committed portfolio occupancy was 89.8% as of March 31, 2018, and its aggregate leverage stood at 33.6%. The manager plans to seek acquisition opportunities to capture further upside in improving office market conditions.

site_title: Walmart spruces up website in bid to capture traffic from Amazon
summary: Walmart is launching a redesigned website in an effort to capture traffic from Amazon. The new site will feature a more personalized shopping experience, including lifestyle-focused imagery, a new fashion section, and quick links to purchase previously ordered items. The redesign aims to convince frugal in-store shoppers to buy online, where they spend nearly twice as much. The new site is expected to feature top-selling items in each customer's location and will include premium brands like Bose speakers. The redesign follows a strategy to compete with Amazon in key categories like fashion and food.

site_title: Olam launches supply chain improvement tool AtSource
summary: Olam International has launched AtSource, a sustainable sourcing solution that tracks the social and environmental footprint of agricultural raw materials and food ingredients from farm to table. The digital dashboard provides supply chain insights, driving transformational change for farmers and the planet. AtSource will enhance Olam's ability to assess and positively influence the environmental footprint of its 4.7 million farmers in emerging markets, primarily smallholders growing crops such as cocoa, coffee, and cashew.

images.alt_text: Manufacturers will now be able to trace the journey of their agricultural raw materials and food ingredients from farm to table - thanks to Olam International's new sustainable sourcing solution, AtSource.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on strong earnings
summary: US stock indexes opened higher on Tuesday, driven by strong earnings from Netflix, Goldman Sachs, and health majors, boosting optimism for a strong earnings season. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 108.75 points, or 0.44%, to 24,681.79, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, reaching fresh records.

site_title: Jurong GRC MP Tan Wu Meng attacked at Meet-the-People session, suffers bruises and abrasions
summary: Jurong GRC MP Tan Wu Meng was attacked during a Meet-the-People session in Clementi on April 16, 2018. A resident in his 30s hit him with his fists, causing bruises and abrasions. The attacker was arrested by police and Dr. Tan was taken to the hospital for evaluation. Despite the incident, Dr. Tan returned to the session to continue writing appeal letters for residents, including his attacker. He plans to maintain the accessibility of the area, citing its existing security measures, including CCTV cameras.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Economists predict slower export growth for the rest of 2018 after Singapore's exports contracted for a second month in March, declining 2.7%. A 23-storey development, Asia Gardens, was sold en bloc for S$343m. mm2 Asia sold a 5.39% stake in UnUsUaL for S$25.8m to a Brunei prince and Ron Sim fund. Singapore state investor Temasek is interested in buying into HNA's Hong Kong airlines. A new jobs portal and tourism resource platform were also launched.

images.alt_text: Non-oil domestic exports (NODX) fell 2.7 per cent last month, partly due to a high base from a year ago, according to the latest data from Enterprise Singapore.

site_title: At Home, even in the sky
summary: Scientists have discovered a stream of viruses circling the planet, above weather systems, and estimate 800 million viruses fall onto every square meter daily. These viruses, mostly from sea spray and dust storms, can travel great distances, making intercontinental travel "quite easy." The study, led by Curtis Suttle, is the first to count the number of viruses falling to earth, aiming to understand the "virosphere" or the world of viruses on the planet.

site_title: JTC to launch public tender for industrial site at Tuas South Link 1 on Apr 24
summary: JTC Corporation will launch a public tender for an industrial site at Tuas South Link 1 on Apr 24 with a six-week tender period. The 2.41-hectare land parcel, zoned for Business-2 development, has a 30-year tenure and a maximum permissible gross plot ratio of two times. The land was made available for application in 2016 and accepted a committed bid price of at least $15.6 million.

site_title: Keppel T&T's Q1 net profit shrinks by 16% as operating loss widens
summary: Keppel T&T's Q1 net profit dropped 16.3% to S$9.43 million, despite a 5.1% increase in revenue to S$42.81 million. The company's operating loss widened to S$3.43 million, more than double the previous year. The logistics division, accounting for most revenue, ran at a net loss of S$2.46 million due to lower container throughput in China. The company is conducting a strategic review of its Chinese logistics portfolio and has increased its stake in UrbanFox.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: British official unemployment dips to 4.2%
summary: Britain's unemployment rate dropped to 4.2% in February, the lowest level since 1975, according to the Office for National Statistics. This marks a slight decrease from 4.3% in the previous quarter. The news comes as a positive economic indicator, but also follows a second consecutive month of economic shrinkage for the UK, adding to concerns about the impact of the Brexit transition on the country's economy.

site_title: Japan to trial 'world's first urine test' to spot cancer
summary: Japan's Hitachi is conducting the world's first trial to test for cancer using urine samples, aiming to simplify screening for the deadly disease. The technology, developed two years ago, will analyze waste materials in urine to detect biomarkers of breast or colon cancer. The trial will use 250 urine samples and is intended to be used for pediatric cancers as well. If successful, the method could save lives and reduce medical costs by making early detection easier, with potential implementation in the 2020s.

site_title: UK security startup may help Brexit's Irish border problem
summary: A UK-based facial recognition startup, Iproov, has expressed interest in helping the UK government manage border crossings between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland post-Brexit. The company's technology, already used by banks and government agencies, can verify identities using a mobile phone and pre-existing photographic records, potentially reducing waiting times and increasing security. Iproov's system has been shown to be 100 times more accurate in checking identities than human passport officers, and the UK government has shown interest in its technology to address the Irish border issue.

site_title: Asia Gardens in District 2 sold en bloc to Sustained Land-led consortium for S$343m
summary: Asia Gardens in District 2 was sold en bloc to a Sustained Land-led consortium for S$343 million. The sale price reflects a land rate of S$1,722 per square foot per plot ratio. Owners can expect gross sale proceeds of between S$3.476 million and S$7.73 million per unit. The development has a land area of 72,059 square feet and can potentially be redeveloped into a 36-storey residential condominium project subject to authorities' approvals.

site_title: Thai telco True defends security measures after user data breach
