summary: True Corp, Thailand's second-largest mobile operator, has defended its security measures after a data breach exposed stored copies of 11,400 national identification cards belonging to customers who bought "TrueMove H" mobile packages via its e-commerce platform. The data was made public, allegedly by an expert who "hacked" True's system. True Corp stated that the incident was not a result of its own security breach, but rather the actions of an individual. The company has assured customers that it is taking steps to prevent similar incidents in the future.

site_title: New programme to develop advanced manufacturing applications, services for maritime sector
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) and the National Additive Manufacturing Innovation Cluster (Namic) have signed a memorandum of understanding to develop advanced manufacturing applications and services for the maritime sector. The partnership aims to boost the development of additive manufacturing (AM) in Singapore, growing the country's position as a hub for digital manufacturing. Namic will partner with schools and training providers to develop customized courses, and a certification framework will follow to professionalize the industry workforce. This collaboration is expected to create efficiency and productivity gains for the shipping community.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks edge down, won rises further
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index fell 0.15% to 2,453.77, while the won strengthened against the greenback, reaching 1,067 per dollar. The currency erased losses from Monday, and bond yields rose. MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index fell 0.25%, while US stocks ended with mild gains. The KOSPI is down 0.4% so far this year and has fallen 3.47% in the past 30 days.

site_title: Flatbread-making robot creator Zimplistic secures US$30m in series C funding
summary: Zimplistic, the creator of the flatbread-making robot Rotimatic, has secured US$30 million in series C funding led by Credence Partners and EDBI. The investment follows US$20 million in revenue in its first year and expansion into five new markets. The company aims to convert 25% of the world's flatbread-eaters into Rotimatic users. With over 30,000 customers and 15 million flatbreads made, Zimplistic plans to leverage the new funding to further develop its kitchen automation robots with machine intelligence and IoT capabilities.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: New Singapore jobs portal to better match jobseekers and employers
summary: Singapore launched a new high-tech national jobs portal, MyCareersFuture.sg, to better match jobseekers with employers. The portal uses machine learning to analyze job descriptions and compare them with jobseekers' skills, prioritizing relevant matches. It also displays upfront the number of applications and when a job was posted. The new portal aims to complement the existing Jobs Bank, which has received 280,000 visitors since its launch. Workforce Singapore plans to roll out more features, including recommending suitable candidates and giving jobseekers tips on improving their CVs, by the end of this year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat as investors await US-Japan summit
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on April 17, 2018, as investors awaited the US-Japan summit, focusing on trade tensions and North Korea. The Nikkei 225 rose 0.04% and the Topix fell 0.06%. The summit's outcome was expected to influence the market.

site_title: US-based cryptocurrency exchange Kraken quits Japan
summary: US-based cryptocurrency exchange Kraken is quitting its trading services in Japan, citing rising costs of doing business there. The exchange plans to exit Japan by the end of June, but may return in the future. Kraken stated that suspending services for Japan residents will allow it to focus on other geographical areas.

site_title: UK think tank sees a third of millennials never owning a home
summary: A UK think tank, the Resolution Foundation, reports that up to half of millennials will be renting into their 40s, with a third never owning a home by the time they claim their pensions. This could lead to the UK's housing benefit bill for pensioners doubling to £16 billion by 2060. At 30, four in 10 millennials live in private rented accommodation, a record high. The think tank calls for a housing strategy that includes support for renters, first-time buyers, and increased housebuilding to match the country's needs.

site_title: Most new CEOs are overwhelmed, say job is harder than expected: poll
summary: Most new CEOs feel overwhelmed and unprepared for their roles, with only 33% saying they felt fully prepared to take the job. A survey of 402 CEOs in 11 countries found that about half struggle to find time for reflection and drive culture change. The high turnover rate of CEOs, with an average tenure of just four years, may contribute to this sentiment. The added pressure of taking a stand on social media issues and responding quickly to online debates further exacerbates the problem, with only 23% of CEOs seeking support from their boards.

site_title: Stocks to watch: mm2 Asia, UnUsUaL, Keppel DC Reit, M1, Raffles Education
summary: mm2 Asia sold 5.39% stake in UnUsUaL for S$25.8 million. Keppel DC Reit posted a Q1 distribution per unit of 1.80 Singapore cents, down 4.8% from last year. M1, Raffles Education, and Keppel DC Reit are among the companies to watch for trading developments.

site_title: China's property investment fastest in 3 years, land shortage supports values
summary: China's property investment grew 10.4% in the first quarter, the fastest in three years, driven by rising land values and government efforts to frontload public housing projects. Total land transaction values rose 20.3% and new construction starts increased 9.7% year-over-year. However, property sales slowed as existing curbs hit transactions, and analysts expect investment growth to ease as sales continue to cool. The growth is seen as a sign of a "soft landing" for the economy, but policymakers are cautious not to overcool the market.

site_title: SIA, SilkAir to codeshare with Fiji Airways
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and its subsidiary SilkAir have signed a codeshare agreement with Fiji Airways, allowing passengers to travel from 10 Asian and European destinations to Fiji via Singapore. SIA and SilkAir customers can access Fiji Airways' non-stop flights to Nadi, while Fiji Airways customers can access SIA and SilkAir-operated flights to destinations in China, Germany, Japan, South Korea, Thailand, and the UK. The agreement is subject to regulatory approvals and tickets will be available for sale through various booking channels.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Parental diet before conception affects child's health
summary: Researchers found that a parent's diet and obesity before conception can affect a child's health. Studies published in The Lancet revealed that a mother's and father's diet, as well as their weight status, can have "profound implications" on a child's growth, development, and long-term health. The findings emphasize the importance of awareness of "preconception risk factors" to improve child health outcomes.

images.alt_text: A child's health can be compromised not only by a mother who smokes or drinks during pregnancy, but by the obesity and poor diet of both parents well before the act of procreation, researchers said Tuesday.

site_title: Indonesia expected to drop 264t rupiah worth of infrastructure projects
summary: Indonesia's chief economic minister, Darmin Nasution, announced that 14 infrastructure projects worth 264 trillion rupiah (S$25.1 billion) will be dropped from the government's strategic development plan due to lack of progress. The projects, including railways and airport projects, will be reassessed by the next government if deemed necessary. The move aims to prioritize infrastructure projects and limit contingent liability risk, but may impact medium-term growth. Moody's and S&P have previously warned about the risks of state-owned enterprises' financial strength worsening.

images.alt_text: Infrastructure development is one of Widodo's main economic platforms as the economy struggles to remove logistical bottlenecks.

site_title: Wing Tai, Abacus Property acquire Australian office building for A$95.4m
summary: Wing Tai Holdings and Abacus Property Group have acquired an office building in Melbourne, Australia for A$95.38 million. The property, 464 St Kilda Road, is expected to be completed by the end of May 2018 and will be held as tenants in common by both parties. The acquisition is part of Wing Tai's business operations and does not represent a significant strategic shift.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: US department store chain Bon-Ton heads to liquidation -sources
summary: US department store chain Bon-Ton will go out of business after only liquidators bid on its court-supervised auction, failing to secure a bid that would have kept open a large portion of its locations. The company, with 200 regional stores, had been working with mall owners to secure a deal. The auction, which has not yet concluded, will raise funds to repay creditors. Bon-Ton's demise is the latest sign of retail industry upheaval, following the liquidation of Toys 'R' Us and other struggling retailers.

site_title: Oil rebounds as Opec signaling deal extension stokes optimism
summary: Oil prices rebounded 0.5% after Opec hinted at extending output cuts, fueling optimism and anticipating a drop in US stockpiles. Futures rose to a three-year high after geopolitical risks subsided, with US crude production remaining a major concern. Analysts forecast US inventories fell last week, and Opec is expected to manage supply despite declining US crude inventories, supporting oil prices. Oil prices surged to US$66.64 a barrel for West Texas Intermediate and US$71.65 a barrel for Brent, with Opec and allied producers considering extending production limits beyond the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Oil rebounded from the biggest loss in more than a week as Opec (Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries ) hinting at extending output cuts fans optimism and investors anticipate a drop in US stockpiles.

site_title: Net-a-Porter founder gets a second act
summary: Natalie Massenet, founder of Net-a-Porter, is returning to e-commerce as a venture capitalist through her new firm Imaginary Ventures, co-founded with Nick Brown. The firm has raised $75 million for its first fund to invest in direct-to-consumer startups, focusing on e-commerce companies like Glossier and Keeps. Massenet's experience and contacts are seen as key advantages, helping Imaginary Ventures stand out in a competitive market. The firm has already invested in companies like Glossier and Everlane.

site_title: China's March industrial output up 6.0%, misses expectations
summary: China's industrial output grew 6.0% in March, missing expectations, while fixed-asset investment growth slowed to 7.5% in the first quarter. Retail sales rose 10.1% in March, beating forecasts. The country's economic growth target for this year remains around 6.5%, lower than the 6.9% achieved in 2017.

site_title: Hungry chicken army deployed as China seeks locust solution
summary: China deploys 2,200 hungry chickens to control locusts in northern regions ahead of peak season in May. The system has been used previously in Xinjiang and Inner Mongolia. A warmer winter is expected to hit more areas, including grasslands around Aksu prefecture, with a forecast of 1.12 million hectares affected. The move aims to reduce locust outbreaks, which can cause significant damage to crops and livestock.

site_title: Australia shares flat as AMP slump offsets most gains, NZ falls
summary: Australian shares closed flat on Tuesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 0.2 points to 5,841.5. Gains in material and telecom stocks were offset by a 4.4% drop in AMP Ltd, Australia's largest wealth manager, after it was found to have misled regulators. In New Zealand, the benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.7% to 8,344.52, its worst close in two weeks, due to losses in dairy and industrial stocks.

site_title: Toyota to start deploying chips in battle to get cars 'talking'
summary: Toyota plans to deploy short-range communications chips in US vehicles starting in 2021, enabling "talking cars" to share data on location and speed to curb crashes. The technology, known as DSRC, will be used in Toyota and Lexus models and aims to prevent or mitigate 80% of vehicle crashes not influenced by driver impairment. The move escalates a campaign by Toyota to make cars safer and clashes with phone companies and tech giants opposing the technology, instead advocating for 5G cellular networks.

site_title: China may be set for rare property defaults, says fund manager Neuberger
summary: Chinese property developers may face rare defaults on debts due to rising interest rates making it harder to roll over record borrowings. Smaller firms with high leverage and poor cash flows are at risk of missing payments on bonds this year. The government's leverage curbs have pushed up borrowing costs, and a crackdown on shadow banking has reduced a major cash lifeline for the weakest developers. Property firms with high debt-to-asset ratios face high default risks, with some firms issuing bonds at record-high yields.

site_title: Cocoa goes crazy as it's time to be a 'raging long-term bull'
summary: Cocoa prices surged 5.4% to $2,714 a metric ton on Monday, marking the highest since October 2016, due to Citigroup's prediction of a tight supply situation in a decade. West African crops, which account for over two-thirds of global supplies, are plagued by dryness, leading to a 43% gain in 2018. Demand for chocolate remains strong, while crop yields are expected to drop due to reduced spending on farm maintenance. The market is heading for supply shortages this year and next, with back-to-back deficits making for the tightest supply situation since 2008.

site_title: Boeing 787's range capped by FAA after latest Rolls glitch
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has restricted Boeing 787 Dreamliner planes with potentially faulty Rolls-Royce engines from flying more than 140 minutes from a diversionary airport. The restriction affects about 14 US planes and potentially foreign planes serving US airports. The move comes after a European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) directive ordered additional maintenance checks due to durability issues with the Trent 1000 "package C" engines. The FAA will re-assess the restrictions once Rolls-Royce presents a fix for the fault.

site_title: China posts better-than-expected 6.8% growth in Q1
summary: China's economy grew 6.8% in the first quarter, exceeding forecasts of 6.7%. The country's sustained growth shows it has remained resilient despite pollution cuts and US trade tensions. Analysts warn that tariffs threatened by US President Donald Trump could dent economic growth on both sides of the Pacific. China's industrial production grew 6% in March, while retail sales grew 9.8% year-on-year, driven by consumer spending. Despite financial risk concerns, China's policymakers are counting on its 1.4 billion consumers to support growth.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 5.25 points to 1,873.51 on Tuesday, opening lower. The market saw 83.05 million lots traded worth RM34.42 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 142 to 65.

site_title: Chicago restaurant staff get US$2,000 tip
summary: A Chicago restaurant, Boka, received a $2,000 tip from a patron, Mike, who visited from Seattle. The tip was given after a meal with 17 staff members, initially leaving $300 on the $759 bill. The gesture was described by the restaurant's general manager as a show of appreciation for the staff's hard work, particularly during a time when the restaurant is nominated for a prestigious James Beard Award for service. The timing was seen as fortuitous, highlighting the importance of staff recognition.

site_title: Trump hosts Abe with North Korea, trade on the agenda
summary: US President Donald Trump hosts Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe at his Mar-a-Lago resort, with trade and security on the agenda. The visit comes as Abe's approval rating is at its lowest level in years, and Trump faces controversies and crises, including the North Korea summit. Trump has announced billions in tariffs on Chinese imports and warned of protectionism, but has been flexible on a free trade agreement with Japan. Abe's reluctance to begin negotiations has raised concerns, with Trump's protectionist policies potentially targeting Japan's agriculture and auto markets.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks tread water, won strengthens on dollar weakness
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index remained steady, closing 0.03% higher at 2,456.81. The Korean won strengthened against the dollar, reaching 1,069.7 per dollar, amid dollar weakness. Analysts note that foreign investors' dividend remittance could weigh down the won later. The Kospi is down 0.4% so far this year and 3.47% in the past 30 days.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares up soon after open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose in the first few minutes of trading on Tuesday, following three days of losses. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.13% to 30,354.89, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up. Traders are awaiting Chinese economic growth data.

site_title: STB launches one-stop tourism resource platform for businesses
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) has launched a one-stop tourism resource platform, the Tourism Information and Service Hub, to support businesses in providing up-to-date information about tourism offerings. The platform allows businesses to upload content, including operating hours and events, and download information to reflect on their websites and mobile apps. The service is free for businesses to use and also provides access to services such as navigation functions. The launch is part of several initiatives by the STB to leverage technology and enhance the tourism industry.

site_title: Economists expect slower export growth for the rest of 2018 as March NODX shrinks 2.7%
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) contracted for the second month in March, with a 2.7% decline, exceeding economists' expectations of a 1.2% growth. Electronic NODX fell 7.1%, while non-electronic NODX decreased by 1.3%. Shipments to top markets, except China, Hong Kong, Thailand, and Malaysia, increased, driven by growth in the US, Japan, and the European Union. Economists expect slower export growth for the rest of 2018, citing waning global electronics sales and rising trade war uncertainty.

site_title: NTU launches new master's programme for asset and wealth management
summary: NTU is launching a new Master's programme in Asset and Wealth Management, with classes in Singapore, London, and New York. The programme, starting in January 2019, offers two specialisation tracks and includes internships and work-related projects. The degree is industry-accredited and certified, with course subsidies available to Singapore citizens. The programme aims to address the changing skills required in the financial services industry, leveraging NTU's expertise in AI, data science, and social science.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: US, Britain warn of Russian campaign to hack networks
summary: US and Britain warn of a Russian campaign to hack key hardware in government and business computer networks, gaining virtual control of data flows through compromised routers and firewalls. The operation aims to support espionage, extract intellectual property, and maintain access to networks. Russian state-sponsored actors are conducting "man-in-the-middle" attacks to achieve these goals.

images.alt_text: Russian government-sponsored hackers are compromising the key hardware of government and business computer networks in like routers and firewalls, giving them virtual control of data flows, the US and Britain warned Monday.

site_title: Abterra's auditors resign over non-resolution of outstanding audit matters
summary: Abterra Limited's auditors, Mazar LLP, have resigned due to outstanding audit matters related to coal trader Tianjin Bolangxin International Trading Ltd, a 51% subsidiary of Abterra. The matters include trade transactions, prepayments, and receivables totaling around S$44.09 million. Abterra claims it was trying to resolve these issues before the auditors' resignation. The company has engaged legal advisers to review related party transactions and intends to apply for a waiver to hold its annual general meeting, citing its ability to continue as a going concern.

site_title: First Sponsor rights issue oversubscribed
summary: MAINBOARD-listed First Sponsor Group's one-for-four rights issue to raise up to S$162.2 million was oversubscribed by 25.9% upon its close on April 12. The valid acceptances comprised 98.9% of available convertible securities, with 1,628,800 excess securities allotted to satisfy excess applications. The rights issue aims to provide financial flexibility for the company's expansion plans.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Hot stock: Ezion up 14% on trading resumption
summary: Ezion Holdings' shares rose 14.21% in early trade on Tuesday after a months-long trading suspension and debt revamp. The company's shareholders voted overwhelmingly in favor of a debt refinancing plan, which aims to deleverage by swapping debt to equity. DBS Group Research upgraded their call on Ezion to "buy" and increased their 12-month target price to S$0.29. The plan calls for significant dilution of existing equity.

site_title: Japan Foods extends long stop date for JV to bring ramen restaurant to Indonesia
summary: Japan Foods Holding has extended the long stop date for its joint venture with PT Arena Gourmet to develop its Japanese ramen restaurant Menya Musashi in Indonesia to May 14, from April 16. The extension is due to the "longer than expected time required for the fulfilment of these conditions precedents." All other terms and conditions of the agreement remain unchanged.

site_title: Tepco shares surge after report Niigata governor may resign
summary: Tepco shares surged over 4% after reports that Niigata Governor Ryuichi Yoneyama, who blocked the restart of the Kashiwazaki Kariwa nuclear station, may resign. The governor's intention to step down could ease regulatory hurdles for Tepco, allowing the utility to revive its recovery plans, which had relied on the Kashiwazaki Kariwa station. The news came as a relief to investors, who had been waiting for a breakthrough in Tepco's efforts to recover from the Fukushima nuclear disaster in 2011.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 9.47 points, or 0.3%, to 3,506.66. The gains followed overnight US stocks, driven by confidence over first-quarter earnings and easing concerns over Syria. About 63 million shares changed hands, with Ezion leading the gainers, up 27%. Other active index stocks, including OCBC Bank and Singtel, also rose.

site_title: Facebook confirms it collects data beyond what users share
summary: Facebook has confirmed it collects data beyond what users share on their profiles, including information from websites and apps users visit when logged out or don't have a Facebook account. CEO Mark Zuckerberg had previously explained this during congressional hearings, but product management director David Baser provided further details in a blog post. The data is used to improve Facebook's services, safety and security, and enhance its products. Facebook denies selling people's data, but notes that many websites and apps, including Google and Twitter, also collect and use user data in similar ways.

site_title: Retail sales jump 0.6% after three straight months of declines
summary: US retail sales rebounded 0.6% in March after three consecutive monthly declines, driven by increased purchases of motor vehicles and big-ticket items. This marks a reversal of February's 0.1% drop and a 0.4% increase from a year ago. Core retail sales, excluding automobiles, gasoline, and food services, also rose 0.4% in March. Despite this, economists expect consumer spending to slow to below a 1.5% rate in the first quarter, following a robust 4.0% annualized growth in the fourth quarter.

site_title: New Zealand inflation likely to reach mid-point of RBNZ target band: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) believes New Zealand's inflation will likely reach the mid-point of the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's target range of 1-3% due to the country's strong economic growth. According to IMF mission chief Thomas Helbling, this is achievable if the economy evolves as expected. The IMF's comments were made during its annual visit, known as an 'Article IV' consultation. This prediction suggests that New Zealand's inflation rate may soon return to the central bank's target range of 2%.

site_title: Netflix programming binge pays off with subscriber surge
summary: Netflix reported a 7.4 million new subscriber surge in the first quarter, exceeding analyst expectations, with revenue growing 40% year-over-year to $3.7 billion. The company's spending on original programming, up to $8 billion in 2018, is fueling growth, with subscribers accelerating even at higher pricing. Netflix's market capitalization stands at $137.2 billion, and the company plans to continue raising debt to fund content production, despite growing competition from tech giants like Apple and Amazon.

site_title: mm2 Asia unit sells 5.4% stake in UnUsUaL to Brunei prince, Ron Sim fund for S$25.8m
summary: A 51% subsidiary of mm2 Asia sold 5.39% stake in concert promotion company UnUsUaL for S$25.8m to Brunei's Prince Abdul Qawi and Ron Sim's fund. The shares were sold at a one per cent discount to Monday's closing price. Following the sale, UnUsUaL's largest shareholder, mm2's subsidiary UnUsUaL Management, now holds 76.8% stake. The sale is not expected to impact earnings per share or net tangible asset per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Oil drops as Syria risk seen muted after weekend air strikes
summary: Oil prices dropped on Monday as investor concern about escalating tensions in the Middle East waned after air strikes on Syria over the weekend. The US, France, and Britain launched 105 missiles targeting suspected chemical weapons facilities, prompting a nearly 10% rise in oil prices before the strikes. However, the market reacted cautiously, with Brent crude oil futures settling down $1.16 at $71.42 a barrel. Analysts attributed the easing of concerns to the limited scope of the strikes and the lack of escalation.

site_title: Russia begins blocking access to Telegram
summary: Russia's communications watchdog began blocking access to Telegram, a popular messaging app, after a court banned the service for refusing to give security services access to private conversations. The ban, which started on Monday, was met with protests, with around 10 activists arrested outside the FSB security service headquarters. Telegram's creator, Pavel Durov, denounced the move as anti-constitutional and vowed to defend users' right to private messaging. The ban follows a long-running battle between authorities and Telegram, which has a reputation for securely encrypted communications and has attracted over 200 million users.

site_title: China Sports files for judicial management in Singapore High Court
summary: China Sports International, a sports apparel manufacturer, has filed for judicial management in the Singapore High Court. The company, which manufactures under the Yeli brand, proposes the appointment of two Deloitte & Touche LLP executives as joint and several judicial managers. The filing comes after the company's shares were suspended in December 2017 and a statutory demand was issued for unpaid fees of S$50,839.25. A hearing date has not been fixed. The move may be related to undisclosed past or ongoing lawsuits.

site_title: Billionaire Slim jumps into Mexico election spat over airport
summary: Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim defended his investment in a new Mexico City airport against presidential candidate Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador, who threatened to cancel the $4.7 billion project. Slim stated that canceling the project would harm the country's economic growth. The airport's construction company, CICSA, is in a consortium with six other companies to build the terminal. Slim made his comments without directly mentioning Lopez Obrador, but the remarks are seen as a rare foray into politics by the billionaire.

site_title: Are we alone? Nasa's new planet hunter aims to find out
summary: NASA's Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (Tess) is set to launch, aiming to find Earth-like planets and search for signs of extraterrestrial life. The $337 million spacecraft, launched on a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket, will scan nearby stars for periodic dimming, indicating planets in orbit. Tess is expected to discover 20,000 exoplanets, including over 50 Earth-sized planets and up to 500 smaller planets. Its findings will be studied by ground- and space-based telescopes for signs of habitability, potentially answering the question of whether we are alone in the universe.

site_title: New Zealand PM pushes for EU trade deal
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern is pushing for a "progressive" free-trade agreement with the European Union, with talks set to begin as early as May. The deal aims to balance environmental and social concerns with mutual benefits. Ardern also plans to pursue a separate trade deal with Britain, which is leaving the EU, and acknowledges the potential for resistance from French and European farmers. The EU has agreed to fast-track negotiations, with both leaders emphasizing the importance of sequencing trade agreements.

site_title: Dollar heads towards 2-week lows as short bets rise
summary: The US dollar weakened to a two-week low against a basket of rivals, edging 0.3% lower at 89.54, due to growing signs of relief over a potential escalation of the US-led strike on Syria. Investors returned to shorting the dollar, adding to a trend of risk aversion in global markets. The dollar's performance is closely correlated to swings in risk appetite, with a weaker dollar coinciding with increased demand for riskier assets. A net short position of $27.21 billion was reported, the largest since August 2011.

site_title: Division slows Trump's push for quick Nafta deal
summary: US-Nafta talks have stalled due to disagreements over regional content rules for vehicles and other key issues. Despite Vice President Mike Pence and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's optimism about a possible deal within weeks, US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer's absence from a planned meeting has derailed talks. The US is pushing for a deal by early May to meet congressional timelines, while Mexico has fewer legal requirements and could potentially reach a deal by August. The stalemate has raised concerns that the US will need to compromise on its demands to secure a deal.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Bonvests Holdings acquired 29 units of residential townhouses in Perth, Australia for A$33.5 million. CSE Global's new shareholder, Serba Dinamik Holdings, requested two board seats, pending review. Soilbuild Business Space Reit reported a 11% drop in DPU to 1.324 Singapore cents, with gross revenue and net property income also declining 11.5% and 11.6% respectively. Genting Hong Kong delisted from the Singapore Exchange on April 17, while Japan Foods extended its joint venture with Arena Gourmet and Menya Musashi Indonesia due to delays.

site_title: M1 profit flat at S$34.1m for Q1
summary: M1, a Singaporean telecommunications company, reported stable net profits of S$34.1 million for the first quarter of 2018, a 0.9% increase from the previous year. Revenue rose 0.5% to S$254.1 million, driven by higher fixed services and mobile telecommunications revenue.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip ahead of new US sanctions on Russia
summary: European shares fell 0.4-0.9% on Monday as investors awaited new US sanctions on Russia, which were expected to target companies dealing with equipment related to Syrian President Bashar-al Assad and chemical weapons use. The Stoxx 600 index dropped 0.4%, while Germany's DAX fell 0.4% and the FTSE tumbled 0.9%. Some Russia-exposed companies underperformed, including Polymetal and Evraz. Meanwhile, shares in WPP fell 6.1% after its CEO and founder Martin Sorrell quit, while Whitbread rose 6.2% after US activist investor Elliott Management took a majority stake.

site_title: Temasek hikes Bayer stake in 3b euro share sale
summary: Bayer, a German drugmaker, raised 3 billion euros by selling a 3.6% stake to Singapore's state investment company Temasek as part of its planned $62.5 billion takeover of seed maker Monsanto. The deal will give Temasek about 4% ownership in Bayer, affirming the company's business strategy and growth prospects. The proceeds from the sale will be considered when setting the size of a previously announced rights issue to fund the Monsanto takeover, which Bayer has not yet decided on.

site_title: May to put economic ties first in Modi meeting
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi is on a landmark trip to the UK, focusing on strengthening bilateral economic ties. The visit comes after his 2015 trip, which preceded the UK's Brexit referendum. Modi will meet with Prime Minister Theresa May, Queen Elizabeth II, and Prince Charles, with a televised session with 1,500 Indian diaspora members. The trip highlights the importance of the bilateral relationship, given India's historical ties with the UK and its large diaspora population. The visit aims to strengthen economic ties and follow up on previous agreements.

site_title: Boy unearths legendary Danish king's trove in Germany
summary: A 13-year-old boy and amateur archaeologist Rene Schoen discovered a significant treasure trove in Germany that may have belonged to Danish king Harald Bluetooth, who brought Christianity to Denmark. The treasure was found using metal detectors on the northern island of Ruegen in January. Initially thought to be worthless, it was later revealed to be a shimmering piece of silver. The discovery is considered significant and may shed new light on the life of the legendary Danish king.

site_title: Robots in the dockyards: shipbuilders embrace automation to cut costs
summary: Hyundai Heavy Industries Co and Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering Co are adopting automation in shipbuilding to cut costs and boost productivity. The companies aim to reduce labor costs by using robots to perform welding and paint jobs, with potential annual savings of $12.2 million. Hyundai Heavy plans to start using a 670-kilogramme industrial robot to curve and weld steel plates, while Daewoo Shipbuilding uses a 16-kg robotic arm to weld steel parts. The automation efforts are seen as a response to the industry's severe pricing pressure due to a drop in oil prices.

site_title: MNC, bank recruiters go all out to woo young talent away from startups
summary: Multinational corporations and banks in Singapore are changing their hiring strategies to compete with startups and the gig economy for young talent. To appeal to millennials, firms are incorporating entrepreneurial elements, such as hackathons, innovative internships, and digital storytelling, into their recruitment processes. This includes using social media, AI, and video interviewing to reach out to candidates. Companies like IBM, UOB, and DBS Bank are also using gamification, such as hackathons, to provide a more interactive and fun experience for candidates.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust's Q1 DPU flat
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) reported a flat distribution per unit (DPU) of 0.93 Singapore cents for Q1 2018, unchanged from the same period last year. Profit attributable to unit holders rose 10.9% to S$7.5 million, driven by higher contributions from City Gas and lower professional fees. Revenue climbed 3.2% to S$160.3 million. KIT is in a dispute with Tasmania over a cable failure, but expects no material financial impact on distributions. Units fell 0.5 cents to 53.5 Singapore cents before the results announcement.

site_title: US: Stocks gain on optimism over Q1 earnings
summary: US stocks rose solidly on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average finishing up 0.9% at 24,573.04, driven by optimism over first-quarter earnings and a strengthening US economy. The S&P 500 advanced 0.8% to 2,677.84, while the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.7% to 7,158.28. Companies are expected to report a 17.3% increase in profits, thanks to tax cuts and a strong economy. Relief over weekend strikes in Syria and better-than-expected retail sales data also contributed to the gains.

site_title: ASTI says S$17.2m fee in business disposal not 'typical', but helped get better deal
summary: ASTI Holdings, a semiconductor equipment maker, has acknowledged that a S$17.2 million success fee paid to financial adviser VSA Capital Shanghai for a S$90 million deal is not aligned with market rates. However, the fee was intended to incentivize VSA Capital Shanghai to achieve a better commercial deal, which was achieved. The deal is considered significantly better than previous offers, with the company's core semiconductor technologies and instruments businesses being sold for S$90 million in cash and an additional S$38 million in dividends.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Eva Longoria gets star on Hollywood Walk of Fame
summary: Eva Longoria received a star on Hollywood's Walk of Fame in an event celebrated by the Latino community. The 43-year-old actress, known for her role in "Desperate Housewives," was honored in the presence of her husband, Jose Baston. This recognition was seen as a milestone for the Latino community, with Longoria stating that "representation matters" and each new star is a "win" for the community. The actress is expecting her first child in May.

images.alt_text: Eva Longoria, best known for her role in the TV series "Desperate Housewives," got a star on Hollywood's Walk of Fame on Monday, in an event hailed by the Latino community.

site_title: Trudeau seeks talks with Kinder Morgan to build oil pipeline to Pacific
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau plans to start financial talks with Kinder Morgan to build the Trans Mountain oil pipeline to the Pacific, despite opposition from British Columbia Premier John Horgan. Trudeau met with Horgan and Alberta Premier Rachel Notley, stating the project is in Canada's national interest. Kinder Morgan has halted work on the pipeline and set a May 31 deadline for a resolution. Trudeau is preparing legislation to underscore federal jurisdiction over the project, and financial incentives will be offered to meet the deadline. The dispute has put a vital project at risk, with Canada potentially losing billions of dollars a year if new routes to overseas markets aren't developed.

site_title: Greek banks expected to pass ECB's stress test: National Bank chief
summary: Greek banks, including National Bank, are expected to pass the European Central Bank's stress test, according to the bank's CEO. The test will assess the financial health of the country's four largest lenders before Greece exits its 86 billion-euro bailout program in August. Greek banks have been recapitalized three times since 2010 and are working to reduce their soured debt from 96 billion euros to 65 billion euros by 2019. The results of the test will be published in May, allowing time for any capital shortfall to be addressed.

site_title: Bridging the SME talent gap
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) face a significant talent gap, with 99% of businesses falling under this category. To stay competitive, SMEs must evaluate their talent management strategies regularly. The Singapore government has provided support through grants such as the Productivity Solutions Grant and the Enterprise Development Grant. A good talent management strategy for SMEs involves identifying the right fit, offering more than just financial incentives, scientifically assessing talents, and prioritizing long-term growth. With the right approach, SMEs can reap the benefits of investing in talent and boost business growth.

site_title: GM confirms plan to cut 1,500 workers, but says it won't abandon small car market
summary: GM confirms plans to cut 1,500 workers at its Lordstown, Ohio plant, idling the second shift due to lower demand for compact cars. The decision, related to "historic" market changes, aims to match market demand with a more stable operating approach. The company emphasizes it won't abandon the passenger car market, citing the importance of the 36% market share of the industry retail sales.

site_title: London house prices keep falling
summary: London house prices continue to fall, with the average property losing almost 2% of its value over the past year. Despite this, property prices across the UK rose just 0.4% in April, the lowest at this time of the year since 2008. The London market is particularly affected, with prices falling 0.6% and averaging £10,000 lower than a year ago. The slump is attributed to uncertainty surrounding Britain's exit from the EU and a shortage of properties for sale.

site_title: In Silicon Valley, US$800k buys you a burned shell of a house
summary: In Silicon Valley, a US$800,000 home in San Jose's Willow Glen neighborhood is listed for sale, despite being a burned-out shell of a house. The listing has sparked ridicule and comparisons to other high-priced real estate markets, highlighting the extreme affordability crisis in the Bay Area. Local real estate agents say the price reflects the market, but critics argue it's unconscionable, with one commenter noting a similar home in Texas could be purchased for US$250,000.

site_title: UOB teams up with China fintech to grow credit assessment in SE Asia
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has partnered with Chinese fintech firm Pintec Technology Holdings to launch a joint venture, Avatec.ai, aimed at tackling the under-banked market in South-east Asia. The venture will provide a digital credit-assessment solution to support consumers and small- and medium-sized enterprises in Indonesia and other South-east Asian markets. With UOB holding a 60% share and Pintec holding 40%, the JV plans to invest up to S$12 million over two years. The solution uses non-traditional data points to assess potential borrowers' creditworthiness, with a goal to reduce delinquency rates and increase access to credit for the under-banked population.

site_title: Samsung dials into blockchain to run supply chain
summary: Samsung is exploring the use of blockchain technology to track its global supply chain, which is valued at tens of billions of dollars annually. The system, developed by Samsung SDS, could reduce shipping costs by 20% and improve the efficiency of the company's vast logistics network. This is one of the first major global manufacturers to adopt blockchain technology, with potential benefits including faster product launches and improved supply chain management.

site_title: WeWork venture pays £580m for London complex
summary: WeWork has completed a £580m deal to purchase a London office complex, with the company owning 10% and two other companies holding 45% each. The deal marks the US business's efforts to diversify its portfolio of short-term co-working spaces. WeWork's senior executive Rich Gomel described the opportunity as "the WeWork effect." The purchase is part of the company's strategy to expand its global portfolio and increase its ownership in buildings.

site_title: Singapore fintech startup Silot raises nearly US$3m in pre-Series A funding
summary: Singapore fintech startup Silot has raised nearly US$3m in pre-Series A funding from investors Arbor Ventures and Eight Roads Ventures to expand in Southeast Asia. The funds will be used to fuel the company's expansion in Thailand, Malaysia, Hong Kong, and other markets. Silot's co-founder and managing partner Wei Hopeman believes the startup will play a leading role in the mobile payments and new technology adoption in the region. The company's proprietary Silot Banking Platform connects payments, on-boarding, operations, and anti-fraud solutions, and is backed by a blockchain solution to lower operational costs.

images.alt_text: Silot now provides its proprietary Silot Banking Platform (SBP), which connects the silos of payments, on-boarding, operations and anti-fraud or anti-money laundering. Its founder and CEO is Andy Li (extreme left).

site_title: Singapore renews its focus on engagement
summary: Singapore's business community is shifting its focus towards employee engagement, recognizing its importance in driving success. After years of neglect, engagement has become a priority, with 23% of Singaporeans now engaged in 2014-2016, up from 9% in 2011-2012. To capitalize on this trend, Singaporean business leaders must optimize HR development, train and support managers to create engaging workplaces, and support small and medium-sized companies in adopting these practices. Leadership must also take action on engagement data to drive cultural change.

site_title: Tencent- backed fashion app seeks US$4b IPO
summary: Meilishuo, a Tencent-backed online fashion retailer, is in talks with investment banks for a US$4 billion initial public offering (IPO). The company, which merged with rival Mogujie in 2016, has seen its valuation rise to US$3 billion since the deal. Meilishuo aims to tap into the growing wave of Chinese technology companies seeking public listings, following Xiaomi Corp's US$100 billion valuation and Meituan Dianping's US$60 billion valuation. The IPO could value the company at US$4 billion, with the target potentially changing if a deal proceeds.

site_title: Noble wins founder Elman's support with proposal tweak
summary: NOBLE Group has won over its founder and largest shareholder Richard Elman to its debt restructuring plan after tweaking the proposal to provide current shareholders 15% of new equity in the new Noble entity. The revised plan, which now requires 83% creditor approval, has sent Noble's shares up 4% to close at 13.1 cents. Elman, who had previously pushed for a 15-20% stake, has given an irrevocable undertaking to support the restructuring, citing the allocation as "fair to all shareholders."

site_title: Fortis board to meet this week to consider all options amid 3 offers
summary: Fortis Healthcare Ltd's board is set to meet this week to consider all eligible options after receiving three bids from interested parties. The move comes amid an investigation into the company over financial fraud. Indian rival Manipal Health Enterprises Pvt Ltd had previously offered to buy Fortis' hospital business. The company's board will examine all available options to determine the best course of action.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: DBS Group Research has upgraded two Singaporean stocks: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPH) and Manulife US Reit. HPH Trust's share price is seen as undervalued with a potential dividend yield of 8%, while its operations generate sufficient cash flows. Manulife US Reit has entered a sale and purchase agreement for two properties, expected to accrete to distribution per unit and increase the Reit's resilience. However, some investors may question the relatively low accretion and rising gearing.

site_title: STI down 0.12% as market moves sideways
summary: The Singapore stock market closed lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index down 0.12% to 3,497.19 points. Investors took a risk-off stance amid geopolitical uncertainties following US-led missile strikes in Syria. Trading volume was around 1.6 billion shares worth S$863.2 million.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Business Times reports on various global business and economic news. US stocks opened lower amid fresh US tariffs on Canada. Singaporean companies face challenges, including Creative Technology warning of lower-than-expected H2 revenue and potential operating loss. Heathrow Airport considers increasing fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detains an employee of Trafigura in a graft case. OCBC appoints Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, as its new CEO, marking a significant leadership shift. MAS and PBOC also announce plans to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Stay inclusive amid tech changes, MAS tells banks
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has emphasized the need for banks and fintechs to ensure basic banking access for underserved communities as technology changes the finance industry. MAS deputy managing director Ong Chong Tee stated that financial institutions should not overlook the needs of these communities. The warning comes as the finance industry undergoes significant transformations.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit DPU down 4.8% in Q1
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a Q1 DPU of 1.80 Singapore cents, down 4.8% from the same period last year. Excluding a one-off capital distribution, the adjusted DPU would be 1.74 cents, 3.4% higher than the previous year. Gross revenue jumped 17.9% to S$38 million, while net income rose 18.2% to S$34.1 million. Portfolio occupancy remained at 93.7% with a weighted average lease expiry of 9.6 years. The Reit manager also announced the departure of chairman Chan Hon Chew and the appointment of Christina Tan as his replacement.

site_title: Strict short-term rental rules likely to have limited impact
summary: Singapore's Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has proposed a framework to regulate short-term rentals, which may have limited impact on the country's leasing landscape. The proposed framework includes a 90-day cap on short-term use, a 2-year endorsement requirement for 80% of property owners in strata-titled properties, and a licensing framework for short-term stay platforms. Experts believe the measures may deter speculation, but are unlikely to significantly alter the market, with property owners potentially opting for smaller units and investors making informed buying decisions.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: UFC returns to Singapore on June 23
summary: The Ultimate Fighting Championship (UFC) is set to return to Singapore on June 23, marking its third event in the city-state. The event will be staged as part of a multi-year deal signed by the Las Vegas-based MMA company, with live events also planned for 2019 and 2020. This marks the organization's first event in Singapore since 2018, when two previous shows were held in 2014 and 2017.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: UK lawmakers warn against tech giants dominating AI industry
summary: UK lawmakers warn that tech giants dominating AI industry could lead to widespread unemployment. A House of Lords report advises regulators to prevent large tech companies like Alphabet, IBM, and Microsoft from monopolizing AI data, which could stifle innovation and harm the economy. The committee highlights the need for greater competition and access to data to ensure AI benefits society, not just a few large corporations.

site_title: Why India is far from being named a currency manipulator
summary: India was added to the US Treasury's currency watch list due to its significant trade surplus with the US ($28 billion in 2017) and increased foreign currency purchases. However, it is unlikely to be labeled a currency manipulator as it runs a current account deficit and has not met the Treasury's criteria of a current account surplus of 3% of GDP. Experts predict India may drop off the list in the coming year due to a widening current account deficit and reduced foreign capital inflows.

site_title: Civmec wins shareholders' approval for dual listing
summary: Australian construction company Civmec has received unanimous approval from its Singapore shareholders to pursue a dual listing in Australia. The move aims to boost trading liquidity and attract new investors, particularly Australian funds and retail investors using their superannuation funds. Civmec will list its shares on the Australian Securities Exchange without issuing new equity, and the company expects improved trading liquidity both in Australia and Singapore.

site_title: Stepping up: preparing the next generation to lead
summary: A growing number of ultra-high net worth families are facing the challenge of succession planning, with about a third of family businesses potentially surviving into the second generation. Many founders are reaching retirement age, but without a clear succession plan, the family business may close or be sold off, threatening the sustainability of the family's wealth. Effective succession planning involves embedding the next generation in the business, rotating them into different teams, and having open discussions about roles, responsibilities, and values to ensure a smooth transition.

site_title: Koufu serves up coffeeshop fare with a dash of futuristic flair
summary: A Singaporean coffeeshop, Koufu's Happy Hawkers, has introduced modern updates to its traditional trade, including self-ordering systems, tray-return robots, merged stalls, and shared kitchens. The innovative approach reduces labor costs and allows staff to multitask. However, the introduction of technology may pose challenges for older patrons and staff, who may struggle to adapt to the new system. Despite these challenges, Koufu's productivity push aims to preserve the traditional culture while embracing the future, and the company plans to continue investing in technology to stay competitive.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: E-commerce gives boost to warehouse Reits
summary: US industrial property REITs, such as Prologis, Rexford Industrial Realty, and Terreno Realty, are outperforming those that focus on malls, residential rentals, and office buildings, with returns exceeding 16% in the past year. E-commerce is driving the growth, with demand for warehouse space increasing three times over traditional brick-and-mortar stores. Companies like Prologis are well-positioned to capitalize on this trend, with proximity to major population centers being a key factor in their success.

site_title: China's 'sea parade' for projecting power and striking fear
summary: China recently showcased its modernized naval forces in a "sea parade" in the South China Sea, featuring 76 fighter jets, 48 surface ships, and submarines, including its first aircraft carrier. The display, presided over by President Xi Jinping, demonstrated China's rapid progress in modernizing its armed forces. The move is seen as a demonstration of China's military capabilities and a warning to potential adversaries, particularly the US, which has strengthened its support for Taiwan. China's military ambitions and plans for reunification with Taiwan are expected to continue to escalate, with the US unlikely to accept a Chinese takeover.

site_title: Easier, leaner and cleaner
summary: Singapore's Koufu, a food court chain, has implemented automated systems to streamline operations, making it easier for staff to manage cash and oversee cleanliness. Floor managers use automatic deposit boxes and tray-return robots to speed up tasks, reducing labor costs. The chain has also introduced a compact food waste digester, allowing for easier waste disposal and potential conversion to fertilizer. This has led to fewer hygiene issues and more time for supervisors to focus on food quality and sales.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Analysts make light of March fall in developers' home sales
summary: Singapore's private home sales plummeted 59.8% in March 2018, with 716 units sold, but industry analysts attribute the decline to a lack of new launches, citing a surge in sales for recently launched projects. The Tapestry in Tampines saw 329 units sold at a median price of S$1,408 psf, and other projects like The Verandah Residences and Park Place Residences also received positive responses. Experts expect a rebound in sales for April and May with new launches, maintaining their full-year forecast of 12,000 to 13,000 new private homes.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Bombardier Global 7000 claims crown as longest-range luxury jet
summary: Bombardier's Global 7000 has claimed the title of longest-range luxury jet, boasting a range of 7,700 nautical miles (14,260 km). This surpasses the Gulfstream G650, allowing for non-stop flights from New York to Hong Kong or Singapore to San Francisco. The aircraft's improved range is attributed to a 300-mile increase, which is expected to drive sales and contribute to Bombardier's goal of increasing annual private jet sales by US$3.5 billion by 2020.

site_title: Tech on tap to help local food manufacturers
summary: Singapore's food manufacturers can now extend the shelf-life of their products using High-Pressure Processing (HPP) technology at a shared facility in Jurong. The technology, which applies high pressure instead of heat or chemicals, can extend shelf life by up to four times and retain nutritional qualities and taste. The facility, launched by Enterprise Singapore and partners, aims to accelerate product development and commercialization, supporting the growth of the food manufacturing industry, which accounts for over half of Singapore's food manufacturing sales.

images.alt_text: The shared facility housing this equipment for High-Pressure Processing (HPP) of food products was set up by Enterprise Singapore, Warehouse Logistics Net Asia, and Singapore Polytechnic's Food Innovation Resource Centre. It is the first in a line of shared facilities to be rolled out for the industry over the next three years under the Food Manufacturing Industry Transformation Map.

site_title: Meituan steers onto collision course with Alibaba
summary: Meituan, a Chinese food delivery company, is on a collision course with Alibaba as it makes deals to become a comprehensive consumer services app, rivaling Alibaba's e-commerce giant. Meituan has raised $4 billion, is set for a Hong Kong IPO, and has acquired bike-sharing app Mobike. The company aims to expand into offline retail, travel, and other services, competing with Alibaba's online shopping monopoly. With backing from Tencent and a significant market share, Meituan's ambition poses a threat to Alibaba, which has also expanded into local services and brick-and-mortar retail.

site_title: Kimberly-Clark to ramp up Tuas factory output
summary: Kimberly-Clark is investing S$18 million in its Tuas factory in Singapore to double production capacity for baby wipes by Q2 2019. The investment includes a dedicated "formulation lab" to boost product innovation, aiming to enhance the company's baby wipes offerings.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Raffles Education plans to sell Australia property for A$82m
summary: RAFFLES Education has entered into a heads of agreement to sell its Australian property for A$82 million. The six-storey commercial building in Parramatta, New South Wales, is currently leased to Raffles Education's subsidiary, Raffles College. Propertylink will benefit from an income support arrangement for 12 months after the sale, with the income ceasing upon lease commencement if certain conditions are met. A definitive agreement has not been reached, and the sale is contingent on further negotiations.

site_title: US business inventories rise solidly; sales rebound
summary: US business inventories rose 0.6% in February, the largest gain since 2013, driven by a 1.0% increase in wholesale stocks. Retail inventories gained 0.4% and motor vehicle inventories climbed 0.9%. This suggests inventory investment will contribute to growth in the first quarter. Business sales rebounded 0.4% in February after falling 0.3% in January, indicating a potential rebound in the economy.

site_title: Metro unit to invest S$114m in Jakarta residential project
summary: Metro Holdings has invested S$114 million in a Jakarta residential project, with 90% funded by its unit Metro Property Investment. The Bintaro project will feature two residential towers with 1,400 apartment units and 170 SoHo units. The project, developed by Trans Corp, is expected to be completed in three years and targets the middle to middle-upper level market. Metro chairman Winston Choo sees solid fundamentals in Indonesia's real estate market, driven by economic growth, urbanization, and infrastructure development.

site_title: Korean Air unions call for sister of 'nut rage' heiress to step down after alleged abusive behaviour
summary: Korean Air's senior vice-president Cho Hyun Min, sister of the "nut rage" heiress, is facing calls to step down after allegedly abusive behavior towards an advertising agency official. Cho Hyun Min apologised for her actions, claiming she "pushed" water, but unions say her behavior harmed the airline's reputation. A police investigation is underway, and Korean Air plans to take measures after the outcome is known. The incident has reignited public impatience with South Korea's family-run conglomerates, known as chaebol, over what some see as unchecked bad behavior by the rich and powerful.

site_title: Jockeying for ECB, BOE successors is underway
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) and the Bank of England (BOE) are set to undergo significant changes in 2019, with the successors of Mario Draghi and Mark Carney taking office. The choice of appointments is crucial for European monetary stability, particularly given the fragile British and eurozone economies. Mr Draghi's term ends in October 2019, while Mr Carney's ends in June 2019. German Bundesbank president Jens Weidmann is the frontrunner to succeed Draghi, but other nations may oppose him due to concerns about German dominance at the ECB. The BOE is expected to appoint Andrew Bailey as its new governor, while the ECB's vice-president Vítor Constâncio is set to depart, paving the way for a new leader.

images.alt_text: The favourite to succeed Mario Draghi as ECB president is Bundesbank's Jens Weidmann (left). Meanwhile, Andrew Bailey (right) is tipped to take over from Mark Carney as governor of the BOE.

site_title: Midas board uncovers 334m yuan cash shortfall in China unit's accounts
summary: The board of directors of Midas Holdings has filed a police report against its Chinese subsidiary Jilin Midas Light Alloy (JMLA) after discovering a 334m yuan cash shortfall in its accounts. JMLA had only 11,485.40 yuan in its cash balance at the end of December, a significant discrepancy from the 334.4 million yuan it had originally reported. The board also found unexplained transfers of 23 million yuan to an unrelated company and a previously undisclosed bank account.

site_title: Advertising giant WPP treads new path without founder at the helm
summary: WPP, the world's largest advertising company, begins life without its founder Martin Sorrell, who stepped down after an investigation into an allegation of misconduct. Sorrell's departure leaves the company rudderless at a time of industry change, with the rise of Google and Facebook dominating online advertising. The board has appointed joint chief operating officers Mark Read and Andrew Scott to lead the company until a new CEO is found. Analysts question whether the group should seek an outside CEO to address the challenges facing the industry, which may lead to the sale of underperforming assets.

site_title: How not to take Facebook to task
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg faced harsh criticism from lawmakers, accusing him of failing to protect users' personal data and stopping Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election. Despite Zuckerberg's apology and promises to rectify past mistakes, lawmakers are pushing for government regulation to protect consumers' privacy. However, experts argue that such regulation would retard innovation and kill the goose that laid the golden eggs, as Silicon Valley companies have become integral to modern life. The criticism also disregards the fact that consumers are content with the services provided by tech giants, and that many have been pressuring their representatives to "do nothing."

site_title: Rampage sneaks up on A Quiet Place to win weekend US box office
summary: Dwayne Johnson's "Rampage" snuck past "A Quiet Place" to take the top US box office spot with $34.5 million, despite initial predictions. Johnson's star power was credited for the win, with Warner Bros. president Jeff Goldstein stating he's a "global draw." "A Quiet Place" still performed well, earning $32.9 million and bringing its domestic gross to $100 million. "Rampage" needs to rely on international earnings to cover its $120 million budget, but debuted with $148.6 million worldwide.

site_title: Circles.Life hopes to bring partners aboard its digital platform
summary: Circles.Life, a Singaporean mobile network operator, is expanding its digital platform to offer integrated services options, including partnerships with EZ-Link, a transport card company. The telco aims to reach 3-5% market share by 2019 and plans to work with companies that serve digital, data-savvy consumers. Circles.Life's co-founder Abhishek Gupta believes flexibility and ease of integration are key to attracting partners, and the company is selective in choosing partners to provide a full experience, rather than just discounts.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Japan 'rare earth' haul sparks hopes of cutting China reliance
summary: Japan has discovered an estimated 16 million tonnes of rare earth elements in sea sludge off its coast, sparking hopes of reducing its reliance on Chinese supply. The minerals, used in technology such as mobile phones and electric vehicles, are buried miles deep in the ocean, making extraction costly and difficult. Experts warn that extracting the minerals could take up to 10 years and may not be economically viable, with only a weak concentration of rare earths in the sea mud.

site_title: Faber Garden on the market for S$1.18b
summary: Faber Garden, a 34-year-old freehold residential development in Singapore, is being launched for sale by public tender with a reserve price of S$1.18 billion. The 233 apartment owners and three commercial shop units are expected to receive gross payouts ranging from S$4.38 million to S$6.75 million and S$1.99 million to S$4.83 million, respectively. The sale could be Singapore's largest collective sale deal this year and second largest ever, potentially surpassing the record held by Farrer Court.

images.alt_text: The site in Angklong Lane, which is next to the Central Nature Reserve, is being launched for sale by public tender on April 17, and could potentially yield more than 1,150 units.

site_title: JD.com to take 33% stake in Allianz China unit
summary: JD.com Inc is investing 536.6 million yuan (S$112 million) for a 33% stake in Allianz China, its insurance unit, as part of its push into financial services. This investment makes JD.com the second largest shareholder in Allianz China, complementing its consumer-facing financial products on its e-commerce platform. The partnership aims to develop digital insurance in China, giving consumers greater confidence when buying online, pending approval from the China Banking Regulatory Commission.

site_title: 'Full Metal Jacket' star R Lee Ermey dead at 74
summary: US actor R Lee Ermey, best known for his role as Gunnery Sergeant Hartman in "Full Metal Jacket," has died at 74 due to complications from pneumonia. Ermey, a retired Marine, served from 1961 to 1971 and appeared in over 60 films, including "Apocalypse Now" and "Toy Story." He was a Golden Globe nominee and hosted several TV shows, including "Lock n' Load with R Lee Ermey" and "GunnyTime with R Lee Ermey." Ermey's death was announced by his manager, who described him as a "golden boy" and expressed sadness at his passing.

site_title: US bans American companies from selling to Chinese phone maker ZTE
summary: The US Department of Commerce has banned American companies from selling components to Chinese phone maker ZTE Corp for seven years due to a sanctions violation case. ZTE pleaded guilty to conspiring to violate US sanctions by shipping US goods and technology to Iran, paying $890 million in fines and penalties. The ban affects ZTE's reliance on US products and software, which could severely impact the company's production and stock price, according to an exports control lawyer. The move further exacerbates US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Invest in electric cars or lose out, German minister tells carmakers
summary: German economy minister Peter Altmaier urged carmakers to invest heavily in electric car technology and battery production facilities in Europe to remain competitive globally. He emphasized the need for "two-digit billion amounts" of investment, expressing surprise at the industry's delayed response. This move aims to support the country's automotive sector and keep pace with global competitors.

site_title: Lufthansa's Alitalia bid the 'most promising': Minister
summary: Lufthansa emerged as the most promising candidate to acquire Alitalia, Italy's struggling airline, after an Italian government minister called its bid "the most promising". The Italian government is seeking new investors after Alitalia entered insolvency proceedings last year due to competition from low-cost operators. The bid from Lufthansa, which includes plans for a restructured "NewAlitalia", is contingent on a new government being formed, as the current political deadlock prevents any sale.

site_title: Just what the patient ordered
summary: Singapore-based telehealth startup Doctor Anywhere has launched a mobile app that allows users to connect with Singapore-registered doctors instantly for on-demand healthcare services. The app, launched in October 2017, has over 6,000 users and more than 30 doctors on the platform. Users can access video consultations, receive electronic medical certifications, and have medication delivered to their doorstep for a flat fee of S$20 per consultation. The startup aims to complement the current healthcare system, not replace it, and has launched additional services such as lactation consultations and mental wellness services.

site_title: Will a poisoned chalice await Draghi successor in 2019?
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) faces a challenging future, with concerns about Franco-German strains, delayed interest rate rises, and a potential US recession in two to three years. The ECB's successor, set to take over in October 2019, will inherit a "poisoned chalice" and must navigate the complex web of European integration and monetary policy. French and German policymakers are engaged in a power struggle, with Chancellor Merkel's coalition under pressure to provide guarantees and funds to alleviate budgets and support banks. The Bundesbank's president, Jens Weidmann, is campaigning to replace Draghi, but faces opposition from Berlin.

site_title: With smartphone battle lost, Japan now trails on connected cars
summary: Japan's carmakers, including Toyota and Nissan, are struggling to adopt digitally connected services in their home market due to consumer reluctance to pay for such features. Only 10% of cars on Japan's roads have embedded connectivity, compared to 49% in the US and 31% in Europe. This leaves Japanese carmakers at risk of being pulled behind by global competitors, including General Motors, which is betting on connectivity for new revenue streams. The data generated from connected cars is projected to reach $750 billion by 2030, but Toyota's T-Connect service has yet to gain traction, with only 70% of new cars expected to be connected by 2020.

site_title: Washington's Taiwan Travel Act threatens regional stability
summary: Washington's Taiwan Travel Act encourages US officials to meet with Taiwanese counterparts and allows Taiwanese officials to enter the US, potentially undermining the One China principle. The law is seen as a threat to regional stability, with China's President Xi Jinping declaring any attempt to split China will be met with condemnation and punishment. The move is part of a broader shift in US policy towards Taiwan, which has been driven by anti-China hawks and intelligence reports suggesting China may take Taiwan by force by 2021.

site_title: Palm oil board says British supermarket misleading consumers
summary: The Council of Palm Oil Producing Countries (CPOPC) has criticized British supermarket chain Iceland for removing palm oil from its own-brand products, claiming it misleads consumers on the environmental benefits of other vegetable oils. CPOPC executive director Mahendra Siregar stated that replacing palm oil would lead to 10-20 times greater land use to produce the same amount of oil, contradicting Iceland's claim to reduce deforestation. This move is part of Iceland's efforts to reduce its palm oil usage, which has sparked concerns over the environmental impact of palm oil production.

site_title: Arab LGBT activists tell peers they are 'not alone'
summary: Arab LGBT activists have released a video to tell peers they are "not alone" in their struggles with identity. The video, made by Human Rights Watch and the Arab Foundation for Freedoms and Equality, features individuals from Morocco to Iraq sharing their experiences with discrimination and persecution. Same-sex acts are criminalized in most Arabic-speaking countries, but the video aims to raise awareness and promote acceptance. The video's release coincides with a report highlighting a growing LGBT rights movement in the region, despite challenges and restrictions.

site_title: Metro to invest 1.2 trillion rupiah in Jakarta residential project
summary: Metro Holdings has invested 1.2 trillion rupiah in a Jakarta residential project, with 90% of the funding coming from Metro Property Investment. The project, developed with Trans Corp, will feature two residential towers with 1,400 apartment units and 170 office units in Bintaro, South Jakarta. Construction is expected to be completed in three years, targeting the middle to upper-middle class market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's stocks closed higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 10.29 points to 1,878.76. The market saw a gain of 2.67 billion shares worth RM2.06 billion, despite 518 losers compared to 409 gainers.

site_title: BofA profit beats estimates on higher interest rates, loan growth
summary: Bank of America reported a 34% rise in first-quarter profit, beating Wall Street estimates, due to higher interest rates and loan growth. Revenue rose at three of its four major businesses, with consumer banking seeing a 9% increase. The bank's net interest income rose 5%, and total loans and leases increased 3%. Non-interest expenses declined 1%, while income tax expenses fell 26%. The bank's efficiency ratio improved to 60%, indicating increased efficiency.

site_title: Global economy to grow 3.5% in 2018 but trade is key risk - IIF
summary: The Institute of International Finance (IIF) forecasts global economic growth to reach 3.5% in 2018, driven by the US economy's 2.9% growth, largely due to lower tax rates. However, trade tensions pose a significant risk, with exports in Germany and Japan showing signs of weakness. The IIF also warns of potential inflation risks, particularly in the US, but expects oil prices to moderate in the second half of the year.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as Syria fears wane
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 123.01 points, or 0.50%, to 24,483.15, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gaining 13.80 and 47.22 points, respectively, or 0.52% and 0.66%. Investors were reassured that the weekend's US-led missile attack on Syria would not escalate into a broader conflict, shifting focus to the upcoming earnings season.

site_title: UK's May looks to Commonwealth as new source of trade
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May is seeking support from the Commonwealth, a network of mostly former British colonies, to establish new trade deals as the UK looks to finalize its divorce terms with the European Union. May emphasized the benefits of free trade and urged the use of common standards across the 53 countries. The meeting in London comes as Brexit negotiators prepare to begin work on a future trade agreement with the EU, which has said Britain cannot enjoy the benefits of its single market after leaving.

site_title: Qian Hu net profit dips 2.8% in Q1
summary: Qian Hu Corp, an ornamental fish service provider, reported a 2.8% dip in net profit in the first quarter to S$35,000, despite flat revenue of S$21.6 million. The company cited competition in its plastics business and a positive contribution from its new edible fish business in Hainan Province as reasons for the decline. Qian Hu aims to exit the Singapore Exchange's minimum trading price watch-list within 36 months.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit DPU down 4.8 % in Q1 in absence of one-off distribution
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a Q1 distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.80 Singapore cents, down 4.8% from the same period last year, mainly due to a one-off distribution recorded in Q1 2017. Gross revenue jumped 17.9% to S$38 million, while net income rose 18.2% to S$34.1 million. Portfolio occupancy was 93.7% with a weighted average lease expiry of 9.6 years. The Reit manager announced changes to its board, with Christina Tan replacing Chan Hon Chew as chairman.

site_title: Midas board finds 334m yuan cash shortfall in China unit's account; police report filed
summary: The board of directors of Midas Holdings has filed a police report against its Chinese subsidiary Jilin Midas Light Alloy (JMLA) after discovering a 334m yuan cash shortfall in its account. JMLA had only 11,485.40 yuan in cash at the end of December, despite originally reporting 334.4 million yuan. The discrepancies date back to December 2016 and include a transfer of 23 million yuan to a company unrelated to Midas. The police report was filed but not acknowledged.

site_title: Dudley sees three or four Fed rate hikes in 2018 -CNBC
summary: New York Fed President William Dudley predicted the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates three or four times this year, aiming for a policy rate of about 3% by the end of the year. Dudley stated that five or six rate hikes seem unlikely, and the Fed will maintain a gradual approach as long as inflation remains relatively low. The forecasts also showed the Fed expects inflation to rise above the 2% target next year, after five years below it.

site_title: Europe: Stocks diverge in initial trade
summary: European stock markets diverged on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 0.1% to 7,254.83 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 rose 0.3% to 12,478.99 points. The divergence followed US-led strikes on Syria. UK advertising giant WPP plummeted 4% after CEO Martin Sorrell's resignation. Despite the mixed reaction, shares in mining and healthcare sectors rose, while US stocks edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.
