site_title: M1's Q1 net profit flat at S$34.1m
summary: M1, a Singaporean telecommunications company, reported flat net profits of S$34.1 million for the first quarter of 2018, a 0.9% increase from the previous year. Revenue rose 0.5% to S$254.1 million, driven by higher fixed services and mobile telecommunications revenue. Earnings per share increased 2.7% to 3.8 Singapore cents. No dividends were declared for the period.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.12% lower on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed 0.12% lower on Monday, finishing at 3,497.19, with 1.6 billion shares worth S$863.2 million traded. Losers outpaced gainers 275 to 139. This was a reversal from Thursday's 0.4% gain.

site_title: US retail sales rebound after three straight monthly declines
summary: US retail sales rebounded 0.6% in March after three straight monthly declines, driven by increased purchases of motor vehicles and other big-ticket items. This suggests consumer spending momentum heading into the second quarter. Core retail sales, excluding automobiles and other items, rose 0.4% after being unchanged in February. The rebound was not enough to change expectations of a sharp slowdown in consumer spending in the first quarter, which is forecast to grow below a 2% rate.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher, won drops
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index ended higher on Monday, closing up 2.42 points or 0.10% at 2,457.49. The won dropped 0.42% against the US dollar, while bond yields rose. Foreign investors' counter remittance of dividends likely weighed on the currency. The MSCI Asia-Pacific shares index fell 0.64% after US stocks ended the previous session with losses.

site_title: First Irish beef exports to China approved - minister
summary: Ireland has become the first European Union country to gain access to China's beef market after its agriculture minister announced that Beijing had approved imports from three Irish processors. The approval follows years of lobbying and comes as demand for red meat in China has risen strongly due to rising incomes and a richer diet. This move gives Ireland access to the world's fastest-growing beef market and second-largest importer, and is seen as a key part of its response to Brexit uncertainties.

site_title: Australia shares end slightly firmer as miners support; NZ slips
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.2% on Monday, driven by gains in miners such as BHP Billiton and South32 Ltd, while Commonwealth Bank of Australia fell 0.7%. The move followed relief over limited fallout from US-led strikes on Syria. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index slipped 0.1% due to losses in healthcare stocks. Dairy firm a2 Milk Company helped cushion some losses with a 2.2% gain after announcing South Korea expansion plans.

site_title: WeWork venture is said to pay US$826 million for London offices
summary: WeWork Cos. has completed a $826 million deal to purchase a 10% stake in the Devonshire Square Estate in London, along with two other companies. The US-based co-working space company is diversifying its portfolio by buying buildings from landlords. WeWork will own 10% of the estate, while TH Real Estate and PFA Ejendomme A/S will hold 45% each. The deal marks the company's expansion into the UK market and aims to unlock the estate's potential.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit's DPU falls 11% to 1.324 Singapore cents
summary: Soilbuild Reit posted a 11% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.324 Singapore cents in Q1, driven by lower revenue from 72 Loyang, divestment of KTL Offshore, and lower occupancies. Gross revenue fell 11.5% to S$19.4 million, while net property income dropped 11.6% to S$17.0 million. The company's CEO noted that the industrial property market remains soft, but is making headway with portfolio restructuring and strengthening tenants.

site_title: UK lawmakers warn against tech giants dominating AI industry
summary: UK lawmakers warn against tech giants dominating the AI industry, urging regulators to prevent large companies from controlling vast datasets. The House of Lords Select Committee on Artificial Intelligence recommends that the Financial Conduct Authority monitor AI use in insurance and banking, but stopped short of recommending a new ministry. Lawmakers also warn of potential widespread job losses due to AI adoption and call for increased investment in adult retraining programs, as well as more visas for AI researchers and skilled workers.

site_title: Japan keeps assessment economy is "gradually recovering"
summary: Japan's economy is gradually recovering, according to the Cabinet Office's April economic report. The assessment remains unchanged from the previous month, with consumer spending and capital expenditure expected to expand. The report cites signs of improving home electronics sales and increased dining out spending. The economy is forecast to grow at an annualised rate of 0.5% in the first quarter, down from 1.6% in the fourth quarter. A prolonged weakness in the first quarter is unlikely, which should encourage policymakers to maintain moderate economic growth, despite potential risks from trade friction with the US.

site_title: Faber Garden at Upper Thomson to be up for collective sale with S$1.18b reserve price
summary: The 12.5-acre Faber Garden in Upper Thomson will be put up for collective sale with a reserve price of S$1.18 billion, making it Singapore's largest collective sale deal this year and the second largest ever. The freehold site, which is next to a nature reserve and near the upcoming Bright Hill MRT Station, is expected to yield over 1,150 units. The sale will close on May 23, 2018, and will beat the record set by Farrer Court in 2007 if it succeeds.

site_title: 'Drug flats' blight the heart of Spanish cities
summary: A decade after Spain's property bubble burst, vacant apartments in Madrid and Barcelona city centres have become "drug flats", causing concern among residents. Dealers sell illicit substances in these apartments, leading to abandoned syringes and frequent brawls. Residents describe feeling afraid at home and living in a state of fear. The issue persists, with some buildings being seized by banks from indebted families. Local authorities have not addressed the problem effectively, leaving residents to deal with the consequences.

images.alt_text: A decade after Spain's property bubble burst, dozens of vacant apartments in Madrid and Barcelona city centres have turned into "drug flats", to the dismay of local residents who complain of abandoned syringes and frequent brawls.

site_title: Australia's Ellerston has 5.1% stake in NZ's Fletcher Building
summary: Australian investment firm Ellerston Capital has acquired a 5.1% stake in New Zealand's Fletcher Building Ltd, amid speculation of a potential takeover. The move comes after shares in the embattled construction firm surged following reports of a potential acquisition by Wesfarmers Ltd. Fletcher Building had been struggling due to bungling the country's biggest construction boom. The acquisition has sparked interest in a possible takeover, with Ellerston's stake raising questions about the company's future.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.60% on Monday, mirroring declines in other Asian markets due to concerns over US-led strikes on Syria. The Hang Seng Index fell to 30,315.59, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 1.53% to 3,110.65. Rising interest rates also affected property firms, contributing to the market downturn.

site_title: Billionaire Agarwal hires AngloGold's CEO to run Vedanta
summary: Indian billionaire Anil Agarwal has named AngloGold Ashanti's Srinivasan Venkatakrishnan as Vedanta Resources Plc's new CEO, replacing interim CEO Kuldip Kaura. Venkatakrishnan, 53, leaves AngloGold on August 30 to join Vedanta on August 31. Agarwal praised Venkatakrishnan for his "impressive set of values" and "wealth of experience" in managing complex assets. The move comes after Agarwal took a 21% stake in Anglo American Plc last year, supporting South Africa's assets. Vedanta's shares have lost 4% in the past year, while AngloGold's has dropped 37%.

site_title: Banks, fintechs must focus on financial inclusion amid tech changes: MAS
summary: MAS deputy managing director Ong Chong Tee emphasized the need for banks and fintechs to prioritize financial inclusion as technology changes the finance industry. He noted that fully digital banks are gaining traction and new digital services, such as AI and blockchain, can fundamentally change how banking is done. MAS aims to promote responsible use of technology tools and is developing a guide to ensure fairness, ethics, and transparency. The regulator also supports open banking, where consumers can share data with third parties, and seeks to right-size regulations to fit emerging business models and technologies.

site_title: Asia: Stocks fall after Syria strike
summary: Asian markets fell on Monday after a US-led strike on Syrian targets, amid fresh geopolitical concerns over the Middle East. The US, Britain, and France carried out the strike in response to a toxic gas attack by the Russia-backed Assad regime, but Moscow condemned it as illegal. Most markets declined, with Hong Kong and Shanghai falling, while Tokyo and Sydney rose. Analysts expressed hope that the crisis won't escalate, but warned that a potential Russian retaliation could impact markets.

site_title: Noble wins Elman's support after giving shareholders 15% of New Noble
summary: NOBLE Group has won over its founder Richard Elman's support for its restructuring plan after agreeing to provide current shareholders 15% of new equity in New Noble. Elman, who had previously resigned from the board, will now support the plan and join the board as an executive director. The revised proposal also includes Elman's irrevocable undertaking to support the restructuring. Noble's management aims to rebuild the business around its Asian trading franchise, which has demonstrated resilience. The company has also gained support from over 75% of its creditors and senior creditors representing 83% of its debt.

site_title: IHH Healthcare confirms interest in Fortis but says not in talks
summary: IHH Healthcare has expressed interest in acquiring Fortis Healthcare, India's second-largest hospital chain, by issuing a non-binding letter to Fortis' board on April 11. However, Fortis has entered into binding agreements with other parties, including Manipal Health Enterprises and TPG Asia, and has indicated its inability to engage with IHH. IHH has stated it has not entered into any discussions or negotiations and will make announcements if there are any further material developments.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Adecco Group to buy US-based General Assembly in US$412.5m deal
summary: Adecco Group has agreed to buy US-based technology education provider General Assembly in a deal valued at $412.5 million. The acquisition is aimed at boosting growth and addressing lagging performance compared to rivals. General Assembly, founded in 2011, provides training in data science and analysis, and its revenues were $100 million in 2017. The deal is expected to be dilutive to earnings in 2018 but accretive from 2019, with General Assembly continuing to operate as a separate division under its CEO, Jake Schwartz.

site_title: Trump 'morally unfit' for office, fired FBI chief Comey tells ABC
summary: Former FBI Director James Comey stated that Donald Trump is "morally unfit" to be president, citing Trump's inability to embody respect and adhere to the values of truth. Comey made the comments in an interview, 11 days after Trump fired him in May 2017. Trump had previously lashed out at Comey in a series of tweets, calling him a "slime ball." The statement comes amid a backdrop of controversy surrounding Trump's behavior and the FBI's investigation into possible collusion with Russia during the 2016 presidential election.

site_title: 2 Singaporeans infected by bacteria strain similar to Australia outbreak
summary: Two Singaporeans were infected with a listeria bacteria strain similar to the Australia outbreak, according to the Ministry of Health. Genetic analysis on five patients revealed the strain, with one patient recovering and the other passing away due to unrelated causes.

site_title: Construction for Singapore's end of high-speed rail expected to start in 2019
summary: The Land Transport Authority of Singapore has called tenders for the design and construction of tunnels and facilities for the end of the high-speed rail project, with construction expected to start in 2019. The project aims to connect Singapore to Kuala Lumpur. Twin bored tunnels and cut and cover tunnels will be built for the Jurong East terminus. The construction will be carried out by a selected design and construction firm, with details to be announced after the tender process is completed.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) is consulting on a 90-day rental cap for short-term rentals, and 80% approval for strata-titled homes for Airbnb-style rentals. A freehold Faber Garden in Singapore is up for collective sale with a reserve price of S$1.18 billion. Noble Group has secured support from its founder Richard Elman for its restructuring plan. Meanwhile, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and the UK economy has shrunk for the second month in a row.

site_title: PODCAST: Tips for starting out in property investment in Singapore (Money Hacks, Ep 6)
summary: In a podcast episode, "Money Hacks Ep 6," a financial expert shares tips for starting out in property investment in Singapore. Key takeaways include understanding the local market, working with a reputable agent, and diversifying your portfolio. The episode also touches on broader market trends, including dollar asset diversification and the rise of stablecoins. Additionally, Amundi expects significant growth in retail investors' adoption of ETFs in Asia and Europe, while the S&P 500 reaches a record high, suggesting the worst of the trade war may be behind us.

site_title: Beer lovers can toast Prince Harry and Meghan's wedding with new brew
summary: A special ale, "Harry & Meghan's Windsor Knot," has been brewed in Windsor, England, to celebrate Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's wedding on May 19, 2018. The pale ale combines local barley from Windsor's royal farm with hops from the west coast of America, reflecting Markle's heritage. The brew is a sequel to a previous "Windsor Knot" beer made for Prince William's wedding in 2011, which became a popular and ongoing release. The beer has received positive reviews from customers, with one saying it would likely get the couple's approval if they tried it.

images.alt_text: Royal fans with a taste for beer will be able to celebrate Prince Harry and fiancee Meghan Markle's wedding day with a special ale brewed in the town where the couple will get married next month.

site_title: Ola wants a million electric rides on India's roads by 2021
summary: Ola, India's largest ride-hailing service, aims to roll out 10,000 electric three-wheeled rickshaws within a year and a million battery-powered vehicles by 2021. The startup is in policy discussions with state governments and is exploring partnerships with automakers and battery producers. This goal aligns with the Indian government's objective to increase the number of electric vehicles on the road by 2030, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi directing senior ministers to achieve this goal. Ola's pilot project in Nagpur already covers 4 million kilometers with electric vehicles.

site_title: Construction for Singapore's end of high-speed rail expected to start in 2019
summary: Singapore's high-speed rail project is expected to start construction in 2019, with the Land Transport Authority (LTA) calling tenders for tunnel and facility design and construction. The project, which aims to connect Singapore with Kuala Lumpur by 2026, will use tunnel-boring machines for longer stretches and cut and cover tunnels for shorter distances. The LTA remains on track to complete the project by 2026, with remaining civil tenders to be called in the coming months.

site_title: China's Sina Weibo reverses gay content clean-up after outcry
summary: China's Sina Weibo reversed its decision to remove gay content after widespread criticism, citing the need to maintain an "open space" for all users. The company initially targeted gay content in a three-month campaign, lumping it with pornography and violence, in response to government censorship directives. The backlash, fueled by hashtags and open letters, led Sina to reverse its policy, with advocates hailing the move as a victory for gay rights in China. The decision reflects a growing fear that censorship will ban all gay content, threatening efforts to promote tolerance and acceptance in China's traditionally conservative society.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes afternoon trading at 3,488.95, down 0.4% on the day
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.4% to 3,488.95 in afternoon trading on Monday, led by a 17.4% decline in Rowsley and a 33.3% gain in mDR. Losers outnumbered gainers 238 to 93, with about 792.9 million shares changing hands. This marks the first decline in the Straits Times Index in three days, following a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Boom: Rare Volcanic Wines Are Getting Poured Around the Globe
summary: Rare and unique volcanic wines are gaining popularity globally, with 2018 marking a significant year for the industry. The International Volcanic Wine Conference in New York highlighted the potential of wines grown in volcanic soils, which contribute to some of the world's best vineyards. Volcanic soils preserve indigenous grape varieties, offering distinct flavors and high acidity. Wines from regions such as Santorini, Mount Etna, and the Canary Islands are gaining buzz, with sales increasing by over 40% in 2017. The movement is driven by a desire for wines with minerality and a sense of romance surrounding their volcanic origins.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher as investors shrug off Syria strikes
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.26% on Monday as investors anticipated limited impact from US-led strikes on Syria. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 21,835.53, while the Topix gained 0.40%. Despite global tensions, investors remained optimistic, shrugging off concerns over the strikes and US trade policies.

site_title: Six Singapore firms form Circle of Practice to address accounting for sustainability
summary: Six Singapore companies, including DBS Bank and CapitaLand, launched a "Circle of Practice for Accounting for Sustainability" on April 13, 2018, to address environmental and social risks. The group aims to adopt and improve financial processes and decision-making on sustainability. The founding members are DBS Bank, CapitaLand, Japfa, Olam International, Sysmex Asia Pacific, and SATS, potentially making it the first environmental-focused accounting group in Asia.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Hong Kong shares opened lower on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index easing 0.59% due to geopolitical fears fueled by US-led strikes against the Syria regime. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.20% and 0.26%, respectively. Investors are monitoring the Middle East situation and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Developers' private home sales rise 86.5% to 716 units in March from previous month
summary: Developers in Singapore sold 716 private homes in March, a 86.5% increase from February, with The Tapestry condo in Tampines leading the way. This is a decline of nearly 60% from March last year. The preliminary sales figure for the first quarter stands at 1,627 private homes, down 12.7% from the fourth quarter and 45.1% year on year. Analysts expect a pick-up in sales in April, driven by new project launches and a rebound in market activity after Chinese New Year.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: South Korea: Stocks edge higher, won slips
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.24% to 2,461.08 at 01:15 GMT, while the won slipped 0.18% to 1,071.4 per dollar. The local stock market edged higher despite a weaker currency and rising bond yields.

site_title: China Q1 central government-owned firms' profits rise, debt levels ease
summary: China's central government-owned firms saw a 20.9% increase in profit to 377.06 billion yuan (S$78.8 billion) in the first quarter, the highest in five years. Debt levels fell to 65.9% average debt-to-assets ratio, down 0.4 percentage points from the beginning of the year. The strong profit numbers may give Beijing leeway to push forward corporate deleveraging reforms and make state-owned enterprises more profitable and responsive to the market.

images.alt_text: Total profit from China's central government-owned firms accelerated in the first quarter while debt levels fell from the beginning of the year, suggesting Beijing is having some success with revamping its debt-ridden and lumbering state sector.

site_title: Australia shares rise as Syria taken in stride; NZ down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% on Monday, reaching an over three-week high, following relief over limited fallout from US-led strikes on Syria. Miners BHP Billiton and South32 led the gains, with aluminium prices also rising on sanctions against Russia's UC Rusal. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.2% due to losses in healthcare stocks.

site_title: Models slink down Riyadh runway at first Saudi fashion week
summary: Saudi Arabia's first-ever fashion week showcased local and foreign designers, featuring 1,500 attendees paying $174.50 per show. The event aimed to ease social restrictions, following the lifting of a ban on women driving and mixed-gender concerts under Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. However, traditional societal norms prevail, with women required to be chaperoned in public. The fashion week was a success, with Princess Noura bint Faisal expressing hopes for a "fashion city" in Saudi Arabia, and a top fashion school to be established in the country.

site_title: Advertising giant WPP embarks on new journey without Sorrell at the helm
summary: WPP, the world's largest advertising company, embarks on a new journey without founder Martin Sorrell, who stepped down after a board investigation into misconduct allegations. Sorrell's departure leaves the company rudderless amid industry change, with WPP hunting for a new CEO. Interim joint CEOs Mark Read and Andrew Scott have been appointed to oversee the company's operations, but questions remain about whether the holding group can remain intact. The sudden departure sparks concerns about the company's future, with analysts questioning whether a new CEO from outside the company is needed to address the challenges facing the industry.

site_title: Indonesia-Malaysia palm council says UK supermarket misleads consumers
summary: The Council of Palm Oil Producing Countries (CPOPC) criticized British supermarket chain Iceland for removing palm oil from its products, claiming it misleads consumers about the environmental benefits of other vegetable oils. CPOPC Executive Director Mahendra Siregar stated that replacing palm oil would lead to 10-20 times greater land use to produce the same amount of oil, contradicting Iceland's environmental claims. This move comes as Indonesia and Malaysia, the world's largest and second-largest palm oil producers, face concerns over rainforest destruction and greenhouse gas emissions.

images.alt_text: Indonesia and Malaysia are the world's largest and second-largest producers of palm oil.

site_title: Singapore fintech startup Silot raises almost US$3m in pre-Series A funding
summary: Singapore-based fintech startup Silot has raised US$2.87 million in pre-Series A funding from investors Arbor Ventures and Eight Roads Ventures. The funds will be used to expand the company's presence in Thailand, Malaysia, Hong Kong, and other markets in the region. Silot's co-founder and CEO, Andy Li, plans to leverage technology to build a fintech ecosystem, providing quality financial services to institutions. The company's proprietary Silot Banking Platform and blockchain solution aim to lower operational costs and enhance data sharing among financial institutions.

site_title: Trump seeks to delay own Justice Department in Cohen probe
summary: US President Donald Trump has asked a judge to block his own Justice Department from reviewing evidence seized during an April 9 FBI raid on his personal lawyer Michael Cohen's home and office. Trump's attorneys claim that reviewing the evidence first by federal prosecutors in New York would be unfair and that the president should be the one to assess the attorney-client privilege. The move is part of a larger investigation into Cohen's activities, which also involves adult-film actress Stormy Daniels and possible ties between the Trump campaign and Russian interference in the 2016 election.

site_title: Japan and China's foreign ministers pledge to pursue improved ties
summary: Japanese Foreign Affairs Minister Taro Kono and Chinese State Councillor Wang Yi have pledged to improve ties between their nations, reaffirming a commitment to UN resolutions aimed at forcing North Korea to abandon nuclear weapons. The two leaders agreed to pursue wide-reaching cooperation and improved relations, despite ongoing disputes over the South China Sea and uninhabited islets in the East China Sea. The talks come ahead of a summit between the two Koreas and US-North Korea talks.

site_title: Former first lady Barbara Bush, 92, 'in failing health'
summary: Former US First Lady Barbara Bush, 92, is in "failing health" after hospitalizations and has decided not to seek additional medical treatment. She will focus on comfort care at her family home in Houston. The office of former President George HW Bush released a statement saying she is surrounded by her family and appreciates the prayers and kind messages. Bush had previously been hospitalized for bronchitis, heart surgery, and other health issues, including Graves' disease.

site_title: Former Japan PM Koizumi says embattled Abe may quit in June: magazine
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's ratings have sunk to 26.7% and 31% in recent polls, raising doubts about his ability to win a third term as leader of the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP). Former Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi believes Abe may quit in June, potentially before a September party vote. Abe has repeatedly denied wrongdoing in several scandals, including cronyism allegations and a land sale controversy. Speculation has emerged that Abe may call a snap election or resign ahead of a summit with US President Donald Trump.

site_title: Indonesia-Malaysia palm council says UK supermarket misleads consumers
summary: The Council of Palm Oil Producing Countries (CPOPC) has accused British supermarket chain Iceland of misleading consumers by removing palm oil from its products due to environmental concerns. CPOPC claims that replacing palm oil with other vegetable oils would lead to 10-20 times greater land use. Iceland has already removed palm oil from half of its products, citing concerns over rainforest destruction. The move is part of the European Parliament's plan to phase out unsustainable palm oil by 2020.

images.alt_text: Indonesia and Malaysia are the world's largest and second-largest producers of palm oil.

site_title: IPO wave is coming, and investors spy a payday
summary: Venture capitalists expect a surge in initial public offerings (IPOs) this year, with tech IPOs already raising over $7 billion in the first quarter. Following successful IPOs from Dropbox and Spotify, and significant valuations for Uber and Lyft, the market is optimistic about future listings. Companies such as Airbnb and Dara Khosrowshahi, Uber's CEO, are positioning themselves for a potential IPO in the next year or two. The trend is a stark contrast to 2017, when Snap's IPO failed and Blue Apron's share price collapsed.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars consolidate, lot riding on China data
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars consolidated on Monday, with the Australian dollar rising 0.1% to US$0.7776, driven by wagers that a US-led strike on Syria would be a one-off event. The AUD briefly touched a three-week high at US$0.7810, but faces stiff chart resistance. Meanwhile, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers, which could impact the region's currencies.

site_title: Trudeau in 'financial' talks to resolve heated pipeline dispute
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau is holding "financial discussions" to resolve a dispute between provinces Alberta and British Columbia over the Trans Mountain pipeline project. The pipeline, which would triple its capacity, is opposed by British Columbia's government and indigenous groups due to environmental concerns. Trudeau's government approved the project in 2016, but Alberta has boycotted trade with British Columbia. Trudeau is weighing legislation to assert federal jurisdiction and has instructed the finance minister to initiate talks with Kinder Morgan, the project's developer. A resolution is needed by May 31 to avoid project suspension.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Monday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.22 points to 1,868.69. Gainers outnumbered losers 52 to 39, with a total trading volume of 34.99 million lots worth RM8.41 million.

site_title: Giant US banks hire most workers since 2011 after tax cuts
summary: US giant banks JPMorgan Chase & Co, Wells Fargo & Co, and Citigroup Inc hired 4,200 employees in the first quarter, their largest workforce growth since 2011, following tax cuts that benefited banks more than other industries. The trio now employs over 728,000 people, easing long-standing pressure to cut costs. However, Wells Fargo plans to shut 300 branches this year, and Citigroup contributed mostly by not cutting workers. Other major US banks will report their quarterly results and headcounts next week.

site_title: ISR Capital may need up to US$15m more to carry out work in mining project
summary: ISR Capital may require an additional $10 million to $15 million to complete a new phase of work for its 60% stake in mining business Tantalum Holding Mauritius. The phase includes pilot production, feasibility studies, and environmental impact assessments. The company's loan to THM has not been fully disbursed, with approximately $660,000 remaining unused. ISR may direct THM to explore alternative repayment methods, including converting loan to equity or repaying once mining operations commence. The company values the project at $48.1 million, and a share pledge remains a valid security in case the project is terminated.

site_title: Man City crowned champions as United crash to West Brom
summary: Manchester City were crowned Premier League champions without playing, as West Brom's 1-0 win over Manchester United at Old Trafford ensured City couldn't be caught at the top of the table. Jay Rodriguez scored the winning goal in the 83rd minute, handing Pep Guardiola his first Premier League title in his second year in English football. United's defeat was a shocking blow, coming just a week after they had beaten City 3-2 at the Etihad, and will likely sting for the team and its fans.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, Yanlord Land, Datapulse
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has entered into a joint venture agreement with Pintec Technology Holdings, with UOB holding a 60% stake. Yanlord Land Group has mandated DBS Bank, The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corp, and Standard Chartered Bank to raise US dollar-denominated senior notes. Datapulse Technology's board has proposed an interim dividend of 20 cents per share, amid a dissident shareholders' proposal to gain board control.

site_title: Mencast taps AI to ride out O&M downturn
summary: Mencast Holdings, a Singapore-listed MRO specialist, plans to commercialize digital twin technology to ride out a downturn in the industry. The technology, which involves a virtual model of a product, will help with data analysis and corrective actions to extend ship lifespans. Mencast has teamed up with HTC Asia to roll out the first MRO projects later this year, and aims to license the technology to offshore and shipping firms to generate new income. The company plans to divest properties and secure debt restructuring to free up resources for the new business.

site_title: Civmec wins contract to supply and process steel for 12 offshore patrol vessels
summary: Civmec wins a contract from Luerssen Australia for the supply and processing of steel for 12 offshore patrol vessels. The contract is valued in excess of A$800 million and will see Civmec fabricate and construct the vessels, with consolidation to take place in its new shipbuilding facility in Western Australia. The company's order book now stands over A$800 million, with mobilization of resources underway to ensure timely steel supply. CEO Pat Tallon hailed the deal as great news for the company and its employees.

site_title: New Zealand's a2 Milk enters deal to expand into South Korea
summary: New Zealand's a2 Milk Company has entered an exclusive agreement with South Korean pharmaceutical firm Yuhan Corporation to distribute a2's products in South Korea. The product range will be sourced from Australia and New Zealand, and initial sales are expected to commence in the second half of 2018.

site_title: Tencent-backed fashion app is said to seek a US$4 billion IPO
summary: Meilishuo, a Tencent-backed online fashion retailer, is in talks with investment banks for a US$4 billion initial public offering (IPO). The company, which merged with Mogujie in 2016, aims to value itself at around US$4 billion, despite Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. and JD.com Inc.'s dominance in the market. Meilishuo has seen significant growth, with sales reaching US$3 billion at the time of its merger. The IPO target is an initial valuation and could change if a deal proceeds.

site_title: URA seeks views on 90-day rental cap, 80% approval for strata-titled homes for Airbnb-style rentals
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) is consulting the public on a proposed framework to regulate short-term rentals of private residential properties in Singapore. The proposed 90-day annual rental cap and six-person occupancy limit are part of the framework, which also requires homeowners to register with the URA and approved hosts to provide guest details. For strata-titled properties, at least 80% of owners must support the use of the property for short-term accommodation. The public can view the consultation document and share their views until May 31, 2018.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Malaysia's Mahathir to contest on holiday island of Langkawi in election
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, 92, has announced his candidacy in the upcoming general election on the island of Langkawi, where he was instrumental in developing the tourist destination during his time in office. Mahathir, who is running against his former protege Prime Minister Najib Razak, is seeking to oust the scandal-plagued government amid allegations of corruption. The May 9 poll will be a test for Najib's coalition, which has governed Malaysia for six decades.

site_title: Despite job cuts, GM won't abandon small car market
summary: General Motors confirmed plans to eliminate a shift at its Ohio plant, idling 1,500 employees, due to lower demand for compact cars. The decision, related to "historic" market changes, is part of a broader trend of declining small car sales in the US, which have fallen 28% since 2018. Despite this, GM emphasizes that it will not abandon the passenger car market, citing its importance in retail sales and as a driver of new and conquest customers for Chevrolet.

site_title: Korean Air 'nut rage' sister apologises for angry outburst
summary: Korean Air Lines' senior vice-president Cho Hyun-min, also known as Emily Cho, has apologized for her alleged abusive behavior against an advertising agency official. Cho, the sister of the "nut rage" heiress, was accused of throwing water at the manager's face during a business meeting. Cho denied throwing water but said she had pushed it. Labour unions have called for her to step down from management due to the public outrage caused by her actions.

site_title: Samsung jumps on blockchain bandwagon to manage its supply chain
summary: Samsung Electronics is considering a blockchain ledger system to manage its global supply network, which could cut shipping costs by 20%. The system, developed by Samsung SDS, aims to track shipments worth tens of billions of dollars a year and improve supply chain efficiency. This move could have a significant impact on the manufacturing industry, according to Samsung's blockchain chief, Song Kwang Woo. If successful, the system could also enhance consumer confidence and reduce the time lag between product launches and actual shipments.

site_title: Broker's take: RHB initiates coverage on Kimly with 'buy'
summary: RHB Research has initiated coverage of Kimly, a Singapore-based coffee shop and food court operator, with a "buy" recommendation. The broker cites Kimly's defensive business model, rich cash flows, and planned expansions. A target price of 43 Singapore cents is set, based on a discounted cash flow valuation, below the peer average of 24 times. Kimly's stable gross margins and expected growth make it an attractive investment opportunity, according to RHB analysts.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Yanlord to raise debt in Singapore, HK; mandates DBS, HSBC, StanChart
summary: Yanlord Land Group has mandated DBS Bank, HSBC, and Standard Chartered as joint global coordinators to raise US dollar-denominated senior notes in Singapore and Hong Kong. The notes will be guaranteed by a subsidiary and rated "BB-" by Standard & Poor's and "Ba3" by Moody's. This marks Yanlord's first debt raise since its credit rating was upgraded to "BB" in March.

site_title: US dollar firms after Syria strikes, nears 2-month high versus yen
summary: The US dollar rose to a two-month high against the yen, near 107.515 yen, following military strikes on Syria by the US and its allies. US President Trump declared "mission accomplished" after the strikes, suggesting a limited response. The reaction in currencies was limited due to advance notice from Trump, and speculators showed less response to yen-supportive factors. The dollar index against a basket of six major currencies was slightly higher at 89.807.

images.alt_text: The US dollar firmed on Monday, hovering near a two-month high against the yen, after the market gained some clarity following military strikes on Syria by the United States and its allies at the weekend.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open up as investors shrug off Syria strikes
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.23% to 21,828.25, driven by a cheaper yen and limited impact from US-led strikes on Syria. The broader Topix also rose 0.14%. Investors appear to have shrugged off the strikes, focusing on other market factors.

site_title: Meituan steers onto collision course with Alibaba
summary: Meituan, a Chinese food delivery company, is on a collision course with Alibaba, the e-commerce giant. Meituan, backed by Tencent and the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, aims to become a "super app" with a range of local services, including food delivery, travel, and retail. This pits it against Alibaba, which is expanding into local services and has recently acquired its rival Ele.me. Meituan's ambition is daunting, given its lack of a stable core business and history of cash-burning subsidies. However, with Tencent's backing, Meituan could pose a significant threat to Alibaba's dominance.

images.alt_text: Meituan's ambition to become a "super app" for Chinese consumers has caught the attention of the US$441 billion Alibaba, which is trying to extend its online shopping monopoly into bricks-and-mortar retail and local services.

site_title: Art dealer's death reveals Trump Tower price swoon
summary: Art dealer Todd Brassner's death in a fire at his Trump Tower apartment revealed the building's declining luxury appeal after Donald Trump's presidential campaign. Brassner's 50th-floor condo, valued at $2.5 million, sold for $1.8 million, a 30% drop in price per square foot compared to comparable properties. The Trump Organization attributes the decline to foreign buyers, but real estate agents say the constant presence of armed guards and Secret Service agents, as well as Trump's presidency, have deterred buyers.

site_title: In age of Amazon, you could invest in tech - or in warehouses
summary: Industrial warehouse investments are outperforming other types of real estate, with Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs) specializing in industrial properties returning over 16% in the past year. Companies like Prologis Inc, Rexford Industrial Realty Inc, and Terreno Realty Corp are leading the way, beating their peers and other types of REITs. This trend is attributed to the growing demand for e-commerce and logistics, making warehouses a prime investment opportunity in the age of Amazon.

site_title: Starbucks CEO apologises for 'reprehensible' arrest of two black men
summary: Starbucks CEO Kevin Johnson apologized for the arrest of two black men at a Philadelphia cafe, calling the incident "reprehensible." The men were arrested after a Starbucks employee called police, claiming they were trespassing despite not ordering anything. A video posted on Twitter showed police questioning and handcuffing the men, who were waiting for a friend. The company will investigate and make changes to avoid a recurrence, with Johnson saying Starbucks "stands firmly against discrimination or racial profiling." The men were released after Starbucks declined to prosecute.

site_title: Moderate quake hits off Indonesia, no tsunami warning
summary: A 5.9-magnitude earthquake struck Indonesia's Molucca Sea on April 15, 2018, at a depth of 36.5km, with no tsunami alert issued. The Pacific Tsunami Warning Centre deemed no tsunami threat, and there were no immediate reports of damage. Indonesia's location on the Pacific "Ring of Fire" makes it prone to seismic activity.

site_title: Funds take nothing for granted in Malaysia vote as ringgit halts
summary: Malaysia's general election is set for May 9, with polls predicting Prime Minister Najib Razak's return to office. However, investors are bracing for a range of possible outcomes due to recent global political shocks. The ringgit, currently Asia's third-best performer this year, lost ground in April as uncertainty increases. Fund managers and analysts expect a win by Najib to be a net positive for Malaysian assets, with the ringgit potentially strengthening by 1.5%. A hung parliament or opposition win could create a volatile environment, while a short-term negative reaction to an opposition victory is possible, but Malaysia's economic fundamentals are expected to remain unaffected.

site_title: Positioning Asean for a trade war
summary: US President Donald Trump has announced plans to impose $100 billion in tariffs on Chinese goods, escalating a trade spat between the two economic superpowers. The move has sent shockwaves through the global economy, particularly in Southeast Asia, where the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) is deeply embedded in the China-US value chain. Asean has sent a strong message to the US and China, reaffirming its commitment to international trade and negotiating the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) to create the world's largest regional trading bloc.

site_title: ECB asks Deutsche Bank to gauge investment banking exit costs: source
summary: The European Central Bank has asked Deutsche Bank to calculate the potential costs of winding down its investment banking operations. This request is not related to the recent change in top management. Deutsche Bank has been exploring options as its investment banking business shrinks, and other lenders are expected to face similar requests from regulators. The bank is currently undergoing a global review of its investment bank, known as Project Colombo.

site_title: Goldman Sachs buys personal finance start-up Clarity Money
summary: Goldman Sachs acquired Clarity Money, a personal finance startup, to bolster its Marcus online lending business. The acquisition is expected to add over 1 million customers to Marcus, which offers tools to help customers save and borrow. Clarity Money will be re-branded as Marcus by Goldman Sachs over time. Goldman launched Marcus in 2016 to help credit card borrowers consolidate debt into a single loan with a lower interest rate. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, and Clarity Money CEO Adam Dell will join Goldman Sachs as a partner.

site_title: Japan PM decides finance official accused of sexual harassment must be sacked: paper
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has decided that Administrative Vice Finance Minister Junichi Fukuda must be fired after he was accused of sexually harassing female reporters. Fukuda was accused of touching a reporter's breasts and kissing her at a bar, and he denied the allegations. Finance Minister Taro Aso confirmed Fukuda spoke to him about the matter, but did not elaborate on the outcome. The decision marks a significant step in Abe's efforts to address the issue of sexual harassment in Japan's government.

site_title: UOB, China fintech Pintec in joint venture to offer credit services in South-east Asia
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has formed a 60-40 joint venture with China-based fintech firm Pintec Technology Holdings, named Avatec.ai. The joint venture will offer credit services in South-east Asia, with UOB holding a majority stake. Avatec.ai has an issued and paid-up capital of up to S$10 million and will be a subsidiary of UOB. The partnership aims to expand UOB's presence in the region and tap into Pintec's expertise in the fintech sector.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: France convinced Trump to stay in Syria, says Macron
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron stated that Paris convinced US President Donald Trump to remain engaged in Syria "for the long-term" following unprecedented air strikes against regime targets. Macron emphasized that the intervention was legitimate and urged international powers to push for a diplomatic solution to the seven-year war. He also clarified that the strikes did not amount to a declaration of war against the regime of Bashar al-Assad.

site_title: Asean power grid will raise use of renewables: International Renewable Energy Agency
summary: A top official from the International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA) has urged Asean countries to adopt a regionally interconnected grid to increase the use of renewable energy. This grid would allow countries to balance power and buy or sell electricity from one another, similar to European countries. IRENA director-general Adnan Z Amin believes that a well-regulated market can lead to a massive impact on large-scale renewable energy adoption, particularly in countries with hydropower capabilities. Asean aims to achieve 23% renewable energy in its energy mix by 2025, requiring $290 billion in investments.

site_title: Singapore retail investors have low trust in financial services industry
summary: Singapore retail investors have low trust in the financial services industry, with only 10% believing investment advisers put their interests first. The survey found that 47% of investors trust or completely trust the industry, which is lower than the global average of 44%. The top reasons for mistrust include lack of communication, underperformance, and data breaches. To increase credibility, the industry must prioritize fees that reflect value, returns similar to or better than benchmarks, and the employment of investment professionals with respected credentials.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Trump lashes out at ex-FBI chief Comey in new Twitter storm
summary: US President Donald Trump launched a Twitter storm against former FBI Director James Comey, calling him a "slime ball" and accusing him of lying to Congress and leaking classified information. The feud comes as the Mueller probe gains momentum and Trump faces pressure on other legal fronts. Trump also attacked Comey's handling of the investigation into Hillary Clinton's email server, with Comey admitting that his belief in Clinton's election helped inform his decision to reopen the probe. The exchange is the latest in a long-standing feud between Trump and Comey.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump launched into another furious Twitter tirade against James Comey on Sunday, hours before the broadcast of an extended interview with the fired former FBI director and with a memoir detailing his interactions with the president soon to hit US bookstores.

site_title: Oil, gold open lower despite Syria strikes; Russian retaliation in focus
summary: Global markets opened lower on Monday, with oil and gold prices easing slightly after Western powers launched a missile attack on Syria. Despite the attack, equities are unlikely to experience significant losses unless the West strikes again or Russia retaliates. Gold is poised to gain, but the rally is expected to be modest, with some analysts predicting a potential sell-off in oil if the situation escalates. The attack was deemed "surgical" and did not appear to have significant consequences for Russia, with markets taking a cautious approach.

site_title: In daytime discos, South Korea's elderly find escape from anxiety
summary: South Korea's elderly find solace in daytime discos, where they can escape anxiety and social isolation. In a hidden basketball court-sized hall in eastern Seoul, hundreds of grey-haired couples dance to local hits from the 1960s. The "playground" offers a much-needed break from senior centers, where they often find only smoking. The disco, open seven days a week, provides a sense of community and entertainment for those with limited mobility or family commitments. For Kim Sa Gyu, 85, the disco is a vital escape from his daily routine.

site_title: Dollar index downtrend just started, to retest multi-year low
summary: The US dollar index (DXY) has started a downtrend, retesting its multi-year low. Despite four interest rate hikes by the Fed since 2015, the DXY has declined 14% since 2017, following a top in January 2017. Historically, the DXY tends to follow an 8-year cycle, with previous declines ranging from 12% to 42%. The downtrend is believed to have started, with significant bearish price action expected at the cyclical top.

site_title: On trade 'remedies' US barks, but where is the bite?
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration claims to have doubled its efforts to fight unfair trade, but data shows its efforts are lagging behind the Obama administration. The administration has initiated 84 new trade-remedy cases, but many have been blocked by the independent US International Trade Commission. The combined annual value of imports in these cases is just over $6 billion, compared to $6.6 billion in 2016. Economists argue that these cases drive up prices and have a negative impact on the economy.

site_title: Fortis' woes pile pressure on Singapore-listed RHT Health Trust
summary: RHT Health Trust's planned S$950 million deal to buy Fortis Healthcare's assets is under threat due to the hospital chain's deepening debt and legal woes. Regulators in India are probing Fortis, and the company's credit rating has been slashed. This has raised concerns about the deal's viability, putting pressure on RHT. The planned sale could unlock value and benefit unitholders, but the uncertainty surrounding the deal's outcome has cast a cloud over the transaction.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Oil, gold to gain on Western strike on Syria
summary: Western powers' missile strike on Syria has led to gains in gold and oil, with gold expected to rally towards $1,400 per ounce. The strike was deemed surgical, avoiding Russian targets, and is unlikely to cause significant losses in equities and bonds. World stocks ended with the best weekly gain in over a month, driven by potential US company earnings. The impact on safe-haven assets has been short-lived and modest, with the yen rising initially before ending near seven-week lows to the dollar.

site_title: Latvia overhauls banking amid money-laundering accusations
summary: Latvia is overhauling its banking sector in response to US allegations of large-scale money laundering by ABLV Bank, with ties to North Korea's nuclear program. The country is eliminating deposits in US dollars, cracking down on shell companies, and limiting non-resident depositors. Latvia's "boutique banking" sector, which attracted foreigners seeking EU access, is being reformed to prevent money laundering. The country aims to slash non-resident accounts to 5% and increase scrutiny over the origin and legality of deposits.

site_title: Martin Sorrell quits as CEO of ad firm WPP
summary: Martin Sorrell, 73, stepped down as CEO of WPP, the world's largest advertising agency, after allegations of personal misconduct through misuse of company assets. The investigation concluded that the allegations did not involve material amounts, but Sorrell decided to step aside for the company's interest, clients, and stakeholders. He will be treated as having retired, with chairman Roberto Quarta becoming executive chairman until a new CEO is appointed. Sorrell denied wrongdoing, but acknowledged the need for the investigation.

site_title: Rivercove Residences EC units 80% sold at average S$965 psf
summary: Rivercove Residences in Sengkang has sold 80% of its 628 EC units at an average price of S$965 psf, exceeding expectations. The second-time buyer quota was fully allocated, while first-time buyers can book units starting April 15. The sales gallery is open to first-time buyers. The developer's joint venture secured a top bid for an EC site in Punggol earlier this year. Analysts attribute the strong demand to a shortage of EC sites and rising prices, predicting S$1,000 psf and above for future projects.

site_title: Becoming a role model for sustainability
summary: Singapore-based real estate developer City Developments (CDL) is a role model for environmental sustainability, aiming to provide "clean, green and healthy spaces" for its customers and the public. The company launched its CDL Future Value 2030 sustainable blueprint, setting a carbon emissions reduction target of 38% by 2030. CDL also promotes recycling and waste-cutting through initiatives like EcoBank Bazaar, which collected over 17,500kg of items and saved 7,012 tonnes of carbon emissions in Singapore. The company's commitment to sustainability has helped generate stronger branding and goodwill, and its corporate giving has evolved to prioritize environmental, social, and governance (ESG) considerations.

site_title: StanChart rides return of trade flows
summary: Standard Chartered Singapore has seen a 20% boost in transaction banking revenue due to increased financing activity, with a focus on China-related trade deals. The bank's efforts to become a "flow bank" to clients have driven revenue growth in this segment. StanChart's global presence and services such as virtual accounts have also contributed to the growth. The bank's cash management segment saw a 30% increase in revenue, driven by cash sweeping and escrow deals. Overall, the bank's transaction banking revenue has returned to levels seen two years ago, with a mix of growth across all sub-segments.

site_title: Hermès plays a hipster tune
summary: Hermès reimagines its Madison Avenue store with a hipster twist, featuring vintage records, turntables, and electronic tracks, a departure from its traditional luxury image. The store's design and music aim to appeal to a younger audience, particularly millennials, while maintaining the brand's classic aesthetic. The event, which included a photo booth and DJ set, was seen as a successful attempt by Hermès to stay relevant in the fashion industry, where younger brands like Supreme are gaining popularity.

site_title: Memstar reminded by SGX to arrange for its de-listing
summary: Memstar Technology has been reminded by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to arrange for its de-listing due to its inability to provide a reasonable exit offer for its shareholders. The company had previously been notified to delist in 2016 after a reverse takeover deal fell through, and has since been engaged in negotiations to recover a refundable deposit. Trading for Memstar has been suspended since June 2016. The company will keep shareholders updated on any material developments.

site_title: China's economy slows in first quarter: survey
summary: China's economy slowed slightly in the first quarter, growing 6.7% compared to 6.8% in the previous quarter, according to a survey of 13 economists. Analysts attribute the deceleration to Beijing's efforts to manage debt and financial risk, as well as a slowing property market. Trade tensions with the US, despite increased tariffs, have yet to significantly impact the economy, with China's trade surplus with the US surging by a fifth in the first quarter. The economy is expected to grow above the 6.7% forecast, with President Xi Jinping promising to cut tariffs on imports and further open up the economy.

site_title: China to support horse racing, sports lotteries in Hainan
summary: China has announced plans to support horse racing and expand sports lotteries in Hainan, a move that may pave the way for gaming on the mainland for the first time. The central government will promote horse racing and other projects, including beach and water sports, and explore the development of sports lottery and instant lottery on large-scale international games. This shift could impact the US$33 billion casino industry in Macau, a special administrative region of China, which is the only area where casino gambling is currently allowed.

site_title: US politics, conflict in Syria and big earnings to steer Wall Street
summary: US stocks rose last week despite volatility, driven by President Trump's limited bombing in Syria and positive comments from Chinese Premier Xi Jinping on trade policy. However, concerns about a trade war between the US and China, as well as internal crises within the Trump administration, persist. Earnings season is expected to provide further market fodder, with corporations such as Bank of America and Netflix set to report high earnings hopes. The response to earnings season could decide whether stocks are headed for new highs or back to February lows, with some strategists predicting a year or more before a recovery is complete.

images.alt_text: US stocks rose last week but volatility persisted, thanks to the tweeted slings and arrows and the outrageous fortunes of President Donald Trump.

site_title: BNP Paribas sees value in sustainability agenda
summary: BNP Paribas has strengthened its commitment to sustainability in Asia-Pacific, boosting its market share in green bonds and raising activity in renewable financing in Asean. The bank's CEO, Pierre Veyres, stated that sustainability is a strategic priority, not just for PR purposes. BNP Paribas has also committed to doubling its financing to the renewable energy sector to 15 billion euros by 2020 and has financed solar and wind projects in markets such as Thailand and Vietnam. The bank is also working with Singapore to develop the National Trade Platform, which aims to streamline digital information tied to trade-related services.

site_title: Pipeline jobs, or spills? Internal commercial feud embroils Canada
summary: Canada's provinces of British Columbia and Alberta are locked in a dispute over a US$7.4 billion pipeline expansion, with the federal government siding with Alberta. The pipeline, which runs from Alberta's oil sands to a tanker port near Vancouver, is opposed by many British Columbians due to concerns of potential spills. The dispute has put Prime Minister Justin Trudeau in a difficult position, forcing him to choose between the economy and the environment. Talks between Trudeau and provincial leaders have been initiated, but a resolution is uncertain, with a court challenge planned by British Columbia to block the project.

site_title: Drug company 'shenanigans' in US come under scrutiny
summary: The US government is targeting pharmaceutical companies that refuse to provide samples of their products to generic drug manufacturers, hindering the creation of inexpensive generic copies. The FDA and Federal Trade Commission are investigating the practice, which can prevent generic competition and preserve brand-name monopolies. Legislation has broad support in Congress, which could require brand-name drugmakers to provide samples on commercially reasonable terms and award damages for refusal. The move aims to lower drug costs and increase access to affordable medicines, with potential savings estimated at $3.8 billion over 10 years.

site_title: Transgender news anchor challenges barriers in conservative Pakistan
summary: A 21-year-old transgender woman, Marvia Malik, became Pakistan's first transgender news anchor on a private television channel, Kohenoor News, in Lahore. Malik, who was disowned by her family at 16, achieved her childhood dream of promoting her community through journalism. Despite mixed opinions, her debut sparked social media praise, highlighting the growing acceptance of transgender individuals in Pakistan. The country's recent legislation guarantees rights to transgender citizens, but not all Pakistanis are accepting of the change, with some viewing it as a Western influence.

images.alt_text: Marvia Malik was disowned by her family when she was 16. She trained and worked as a make-up artist to pay for her journalism degree at Punjab University.

site_title: Top of the agenda
summary: Singapore's government faces key challenges in the second half of its term, including addressing rising costs of living and job security, bridging the digital divide, and fostering inclusiveness among different groups. Experts emphasize the need for a "moon-shot" vision to reinvigorate the country's appeal, while also addressing talent shortages in the technology sector. Other pressing issues include economic restructuring, cybersecurity, and maintaining a conducive business environment to support innovation and growth. To thrive, Singapore must adapt to global uncertainties and geopolitical tensions, while ensuring a smooth political succession and addressing the needs of its aging population.

site_title: War fears, US politics to remain dominant themes
summary: US war strikes on Syria and rising White House politics will likely negatively impact the Singapore bourse, alongside a series of economic data releases, including China's first quarter growth results and US retail sales. Despite this, Singapore's stock market has seen a 5-day rally, with Daiwa Research calling for an overweight call on the country's earnings growth. Trade war fears may persist, but a positive trade cycle is expected to support Singapore export earnings.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Demand for Wi-Fi on board planes triggers 'gold rush' among suppliers
summary: A growing demand for in-flight Wi-Fi has triggered a "gold rush" among satellite and connectivity providers, with companies like Viasat, Inmarsat, and Panasonic Avionics vying for business. The technology has matured, allowing airlines to offer faster and more reliable connectivity, with 43% of available seat miles worldwide offering Wi-Fi, up 10% from 2017. As competition intensifies, industry experts predict a wave of mergers, with only a handful of companies remaining in the future. Airlines can generate significant revenue through ancillary services, with forecasted profits of $30 billion by 2035.

site_title: Zuckerberg keeps a cool head while in hot seat
summary: Mark Zuckerberg testified before Congress, facing intense scrutiny for Facebook's practices. Unlike Bill Gates, who refused to change Microsoft's ways for Washington, Zuckerberg apologized repeatedly. The hearing drew large crowds and extensive media coverage, reminiscent of the 1990s Microsoft hearing. Zuckerberg's appearance was the most intense public scrutiny for a tech-related hearing since Gates' hearing 20 years ago.

images.alt_text: Shedding his hoodie for a suit, Mark Zuckerberg appeared humbled and deferential to his congressional interlocutors, even when facing the technically unsophisticated questions.
Bill Gates was in the Senate hot seat 20 years ago in a trial to examine if Microsoft was abusing its market power.

site_title: EU senses Facebook scandal shifts privacy tide in its favour
summary: The European Union is introducing tough new data protection rules, the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which comes into force on May 25, in response to the Facebook scandal. The rules give web users greater control over their personal information and impose heavy fines on companies that break the rules. Facebook's CEO Mark Zuckerberg has welcomed the regulation, stating he wants to expand EU rules globally. The GDPR is seen as a positive step for the internet's development, shifting the transatlantic winds in the EU's favor, and is being studied by US lawmakers.

site_title: Positioning Asean for a trade war
summary: A trade spat between the US and China has sent shockwaves through the global economy, with Asean nations facing dire consequences. US President Donald Trump's protectionist rhetoric has set the stage for a possible trade war with China, prompting Asean to reaffirm its commitment to international trade. The grouping is negotiating the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership and resuming free trade agreements with the European Union to diversify its growth engines and reduce reliance on major trading partners. Asean is also capitalizing on the digital economy to create new market-based solutions and reduce its dependency on external economies.

site_title: US dollar steadies as traders await Syria outcome
summary: The US dollar remained steady against a basket of major currencies on Friday as traders awaited clarity on a potential Western military intervention in Syria. The dollar index rose 0.03% to 89.78, with investors seeming less concerned about the possibility of war. Despite this, the Federal Reserve is likely to raise interest rates at least three more times this year due to a robust US economy. Consumer sentiment in the US fell to 97.8 in April, but remains high, and the dollar strengthened against the Japanese yen and Swiss franc.

site_title: ICBC Singapore to launch investment banking services
summary: ICBC Singapore, the branch of China's largest bank, is launching investment banking services in the city-state. The bank, which received accreditation as an issue manager from Singapore Exchange (SGX), will initially focus on real estate developers and property owners in China as potential listing candidates for real estate investment trusts (Reits) and business trusts. ICBC plans to offer corporate finance advisory services to companies in China and Southeast Asia, capitalizing on the Belt and Road Initiatives and increased economic cooperation between China and Singapore.

site_title: Shophouse deals cross S$500m year to date
summary: Singapore's shophouse market has seen a surge in deals worth over S$500 million this year, with industry players predicting total transactions may match or surpass last year's S$1 billion. Strong demand for conservation shophouses in Districts 1 and 2 is cited as a key factor, driving up prices and sales.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Asean power grid will raise use of renewables, says energy body
summary: A top official from the International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA) has called on ASEAN countries to work towards a regionally interconnected grid to increase the adoption of renewable energy. Director-General Adnan Z Amin stated that a well-regulated market with multiple countries can lead to a significant impact on large-scale renewable energy adoption, particularly in countries with hydropower capabilities such as Myanmar and Laos. This interconnected grid can help ASEAN countries tap into each other's renewable energy resources, ultimately promoting the use of renewables.

site_title: Falling US dollar means investors should look abroad
summary: The US dollar has lost over 12% of its value against a basket of foreign currencies since last year, making foreign investments more attractive. Stocks that invest abroad have outperformed domestic stocks, with European equities returning nearly 18% in dollars. However, the falling dollar also poses challenges, as international companies face headwinds from US businesses with cheaper goods. Investors should focus on specific types of companies, such as international small caps and commodity-based businesses, to benefit from the weak dollar while minimizing potential problems.

site_title: Datapulse board calls dissidents' interim dividend proposal '11th-hour manoeuvre'
summary: Datapulse's board rejected dissident shareholders' proposal to declare a 20 Singapore cents per share interim dividend before June 14, labeling it an "eleventh-hour manoeuvre" to solicit support at the upcoming Extraordinary General Meeting (EGM). The board questioned whether a new board, led by challenger Intan Ng, would properly discharge fiduciary duties if they carried out the plan. The board also raised concerns about the feasibility of the plan and its implications for the company's business and shareholder value.

site_title: The real worry for oil prices isn't missiles over Syria
summary: US President Donald Trump's potential sanctions on Russia's key oil company, Rosneft, could boost oil prices further due to Russia's significant oil exports. Russia exports over 4.5 million barrels a day of crude oil, with a quarter going to China. Sanctions targeting Russia's oil sector could impact global oil markets, particularly if they target key players like Rosneft. However, the impact would likely be limited, and the oil price spike may not be sustained without further action against Russia's key sponsors, Iran and Syria.

site_title: Bitcoin's best week of the year is helping to ease plunge pain
summary: Bitcoin has experienced its best weekly gain of the year, rising 20% over the last five days. The surge is seen as a potential end to the bear-market slump, which has seen the cryptocurrency drop 52% in the first quarter. Regulatory concerns and social media bans have weighed on prices, but investors are optimistic as tax reporting deadlines approach and a record short position on Bitcoin is squeezed. Experts, including John Spallanzani and Tom Lee, believe the recent lows mirror 2013-2015 troughs and that capital gains-related tax selling is alleviating pressures, suggesting a bottom to the current bear market.

site_title: Ricciardo savours 'shoey' after storming to sensational Chinese GP win
summary: Daniel Ricciardo won the Chinese Grand Prix, his 6th career victory, after starting from 6th place. He overtook Valtteri Bottas with 10 laps to go and filled his shoe with champagne for a signature "shoey" celebration. Ricciardo praised his team for their work after a blown engine in practice, while Vettel dropped to 8th after a collision. Mercedes now leads the constructors' championship by a single point.

site_title: Dreamliners' longest trips face curbs on Rolls-Royce woes
summary: Regulators are imposing restrictions on Boeing 787 Dreamliners powered by the troubled Rolls-Royce Trent 1000 variant, limiting travel time away from the nearest airport to around 140 minutes. The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) and European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) are requiring additional inspections and cutting the inspection interval to every 80 trips. The measures come after Rolls-Royce revealed 380 engines needed extra inspections due to durability issues, and are expected to cause headaches for some Dreamliner operators, particularly on trans-Pacific routes.

site_title: Rolls-Royce to bid for engines for China-Russia wide body jet
summary: Rolls-Royce Holdings plans to bid for engines for China's CR929 wide-body jetliner, which is being developed with Russia. The first round of bidding is expected to begin in May, following a request for proposals issued by Chinese state-owned plane maker COMAC. Rolls-Royce's chief technology officer, Paul Stein, stated that the company is taking the bid seriously and views it as an opportunity to innovate. China aims to develop its own wide-body jet to challenge Boeing and Airbus dominance.

site_title: Abe aims to move Japan off sidelines with trip to US
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is visiting the US, seeking to strengthen ties with President Donald Trump and maintain pressure on North Korea. The two leaders will discuss bilateral trade friction and stress the need for "maximum pressure" on Pyongyang. Abe aims to move Japan off the sidelines amid a flurry of diplomacy on the North Korean issue, but the article does not provide further details on the outcome of their talks.

images.alt_text: Mr Abe will seek to win guarantees from Mr Trump that his commitment to security in East Asia remains ironclad and that there is no question of weakening the "nuclear umbrella" in place for decades.

site_title: 80% of EC units at Rivercove Residences sold
summary: Rivercove Residences in Sengkang saw nearly 80% of its 628 EC units sold at an average price of S$965 psf in the first ballot and booking exercise. The site was jointly developed by Hoi Hup Realty and Sunway Developments. First-time buyers can book remaining units from April 15, while second-time buyers can proceed a month later. The top bid for an EC site tender in Sumang Walk was S$509.37 million, with prices expected to rise to S$1,000 psf or above if demand continues to be strong.

site_title: S'pore remains top destination for Muslim tourists outside OIC countries: survey
summary: Singapore remains the top destination for Muslim tourists outside OIC countries for the fourth year, according to the Mastercard-CrescentRating Global Muslim Travel Index. It tied with Qatar for the sixth most popular destination overall. The index also shows Malaysia as the top destination globally, with Indonesia and the UAE in joint second place. The global Muslim travel market is expected to grow to 156 million visitors by 2020, representing 10% of global travelers.

site_title: Fed's Rosengren digs in over warning US economy may overheat
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Boston President Eric Rosengren expressed concerns that the US economy may overheat, contradicting forecasts of a benign mix of low unemployment and low inflation. He warned that the central bank may be too slow in raising interest rates, fearing wage and price increases that could lead to financial stability concerns. Rosengren, who will vote on policy in 2019, advocates for a slightly quicker path of rate hikes than projected, aiming to prevent a recession and maintain a sustainable unemployment rate of around 4.7%.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Bank of Boston President Eric Rosengren doesn't buy the argument that the US economy's benign mix of low unemployment and low inflation will continue, and worries the central bank may be too slow in raising interest rates.

site_title: Memstar reminded by SGX to arrange for its de-listing
summary: Memstar Technology has been reminded by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to arrange for its de-listing, following a 2016 reverse takeover deal that fell through. The company, which sold its membrane manufacturing business, had been unable to provide a reasonable exit offer due to cash limitations. Memstar's controlling shareholders have not expressed an intention to make an exit offer, and the company is engaged in ongoing negotiations to recover a refundable deposit of $5 million. Trading has been suspended since June 2016.

site_title: Moody's upgrades Spain's debt rating, citing growth
summary: Moody's upgraded Spain's debt rating to Baa1, citing improved growth prospects and a stronger banking sector. The agency attributed this to the government's efforts to address banking weaknesses and an increasingly balanced growth profile. Despite remaining institutional weaknesses, the rating outlook remains stable. This upgrade reflects Spain's growing economic stability and potential for sustained growth, according to Moody's.

site_title: Hedge funds cut bullish bets on US crude
summary: Hedge funds cut their bullish bets on US crude for the second week in a row, with a combined futures and options position of 441,634 contracts, the lowest level since early January. US crude prices rose 3% amid Middle East tensions but gains were limited by a looming trade war between the US and China. Despite US President Trump's threat of tariffs on China, oil prices surged 4.3% on ICE Brent crude futures to a record high.

site_title: Russia likely to call UN meeting over Syria attack: Russian lawmaker
summary: Russia is likely to call for a UN meeting to discuss US, British, and French air strikes on Syria, according to Russian lawmaker Vladimir Dzhabarov. Russia is analyzing the situation and will demand a meeting of the UN security council, he stated.

site_title: Trump zig-zags on trade jarring but could get results, experts say
summary: President Donald Trump's hardline stance on trade with China has sparked concerns of an economically damaging trade war, but experts say the pressure on China to reform could lead to positive changes. Trump's zig-zagging statements on trade have left businesses uncertain, but some analysts believe his tough talk may be working, with China promising to reduce tariffs and loosen restrictions on US investment. However, economists caution that the focus on the US trade deficit with China may not be an effective strategy, and the end game remains unclear.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump's hard line on trade with China has fueled fears of an economically-damaging trade war, while his swings from threat to praise have generated uncertainty among businesses.

site_title: Reciprocal visits between Chinese, Japanese leaders seen as ties warm
summary: Chinese and Japanese leaders are expected to pay reciprocal visits, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and Chinese President Xi Jinping set to meet in the coming months. The two countries aim to improve relations, which have been strained by maritime disputes and Japan's wartime legacy. A trilateral summit between Abe, Chinese Premier Li Keqiang, and South Korean President Moon Jae In is planned, with a focus on North Korea's nuclear program. Stability in the East China Sea is seen as crucial for improving Japan-China relations.

site_title: US refrains from currency manipulator label on major trade partners
summary: The US Treasury has refrained from labeling major trade partners as currency manipulators, including China, Japan, and Germany, in its semi-annual currency report.
