The company has also signed a preliminary agreement with Temasek Holdings to cooperate in areas including aviation, logistics, and airport infrastructure.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares extend gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.64% on Wednesday, building on a three-day rally, as fears of a China-US trade war eased. Energy firms were boosted by a surge in oil prices. The Hang Seng Index rose to 30,924.19, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained. The rally followed easing of US-China trade tensions, despite new threats from President Trump.

site_title: Singapore corruption probes hit fresh low of 103 cases in 2017
summary: Singapore's corruption probes hit a record low of 103 cases in 2017, with 778 complaints received, down 3.7% from the previous year. Of these, 368 were deemed "corruption-related" and 95 probes involved the private sector, mainly over bribery for business contracts. The Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) also launched a landmark investigation into Keppel Corporation, resulting in a three-nation resolution deal. The CPIB emphasized the need for constant vigilance against corrupt practices, both in Singapore and overseas, and encouraged companies to implement robust anti-corruption frameworks.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Australian consumer sentiment eases in April: survey
summary: Australia's consumer sentiment eased slightly in April, with a 0.6% dip in a survey of 1,200 people. Despite optimism about the economic outlook, worries about family finances outweighed gains in employment and economic conditions. The index of family finances dropped 5.8% over the next 12 months, while the index of whether it was a good time to buy a major household item fell 1.8%. The overall sentiment index remained up 3.4% from last year.

site_title: PACC Offshore files notice of 3 years' losses; 6-month market cap still above SGX watch-list threshold
summary: PACC Offshore Services Holdings reported three consecutive years of losses, despite improved turnover, and filed a notice with the Singapore Exchange. The company's pre-tax loss for the year to Dec 31, 2017, was US$225.43 million. Its six-month average daily market value still exceeded the SGX watch-list threshold of S$40 million. The downgrade by DBS Group Research to "hold" rating and lower price target follows the disposal of Malaysian Bulk Carriers' 21.23% stake.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Singapore private apartment rents fall by 0.2% m-o-m in March: SRX flash estimates
summary: Singapore private apartment rents fell 0.2% in March, according to SRX flash estimates, marking a decline after three consecutive months of gains. Rents dropped in core and non-core central regions, but rose in non-core central region. Despite the decline, overall rents still rose 0.2% year-over-year. Rental volumes improved, with a 28.3% increase in March compared to February, but were 4.4% lower than last year.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Panama to temporarily ban Venezuelan airlines in retaliation
summary: Panama has temporarily banned several Venezuelan airlines, including state-owned Conviasa and private companies Avior, Laser, Santa Barbara, and Turpial, from operating in the country for 90 days, starting April 25. The move comes after Panama put over 50 Venezuelans, including President Nicolas Maduro, on a "high risk" list for money laundering and financing terrorism. This ban further isolates Venezuela, which has already seen most international airlines pull out due to economic and security concerns. The Venezuelan government has not responded to the request for comment.

images.alt_text: Panama will ban several Venezuelan airlines from working in the country for at least 90 days, the government said on Tuesday, the latest twist in a dispute that began when Venezuelan officials were put on a"high risk" money laundering list.

site_title: Richest Indonesians chase tower assets as internet users swell
summary: Indonesian billionaire brothers Michael and Budi Hartono are expanding their telecom business, PT Sarana Menara Nusantara, in response to the country's growing number of smartphone users and e-commerce unicorns. The company has a cash reserve of 2.3 trillion rupiah and is open to acquisitions to consolidate its leadership position. As Indonesia's population continues to adopt high-speed data, the Hartono brothers are seizing the opportunity to capitalize on the growing demand for telecom services.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.4% to 3,481.13 points, following a positive overnight performance in US stocks as investor concerns about US-China trade tensions eased. The most actively traded counters included Aus Group, Sembcorp Marine, and Singtel, which rose 2.27%, 2.2%, and 0.9% respectively.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,485.22, up 0.54%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading with a 0.54% gain, reaching 3,485.22, as 724.5 million shares worth S$543.1 million changed hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 205 to 149, with Rowsley and AusGroup being among the top movers. This marks the 5th consecutive day of gains ahead of GDP data, with investors brushing off new US trade threats.

site_title: HDB rentals dropped 0.8% in March from February but rental volume up 45.3%: SRX
summary: HDB rentals in Singapore dropped 0.8% in March from February, despite a 45.3% increase in rental volume. This marks a 2.4% decline in rents compared to the same period last year. Despite the decline, HDB rental volume remained high, with an estimated 2,036 flats rented in March. Rentals for three-room, four-room, and five-room flats fell 0.7%, 1.4%, and 0.9% respectively from the previous month.

site_title: Oil prices near 2014 highs over warnings of western air strikes against Syria
summary: Oil prices near 2014 highs due to escalating Middle East tensions, with Brent crude futures rising to $71.09 per barrel, up 7 US cents from their last close. The US and its allies consider a strike against Syria, while easing concerns over US-China trade tensions. US crude inventories rose, and the US Energy Information Administration forecasts increased domestic crude oil production in 2019, potentially making the US the world's biggest oil producer by 2019.

site_title: Zuckerberg resists effort by US senators to commit him to regulation
summary: Mark Zuckerberg navigated a nearly five-hour congressional hearing without making specific promises to support new legislation or change Facebook's business practices. Despite repeated apologies for data breaches and election interference, Zuckerberg deflected questions on regulation, citing the need for his team to follow up. Investors were impressed with his performance, as Facebook's shares rose 4.5% after the hearing. The US Federal Trade Commission is investigating Facebook for violating an agreement related to the Cambridge Analytica scandal.

site_title: VW CEO Mueller's abrupt exit heralds sweeping change at carmaker
summary: Volkswagen's board has ended the tenure of CEO Matthias Mueller, a caretaker who revived the carmaker after its worst crisis on record. Mueller, who had grown weary of regular grillings by board members, agreed to step aside, paving the way for Herbert Diess, chief of the Volkswagen brand, as the new CEO. The controlling Porsche-Piech clan, the state of Lower Saxony, and powerful labor leaders settled on Diess, who will implement deeper changes, including an IPO of the heavy trucks division. Mueller's exit marks a sweeping change at the carmaker.

site_title: Japanese tourist dies on Leaning Tower of Pisa
summary: A 63-year-old Japanese tourist died on the fourth floor of Italy's Leaning Tower of Pisa after falling ill and dying on the spot. The cause of death is still unknown, but the effort of climbing the stairs may have been a factor. The monument was briefly closed to the public due to the incident.

site_title: Stocks to watch: PACC Offshore, SPH, ComfortDelGro
summary: PACC Offshore Services Holdings reported a pre-tax loss of US$225.43 million for the year to Dec 31, 2017, with a 5% year-on-year rise in revenue to US$192.24 million. Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) reported a near 25% year-on-year fall in net profit to S$40.19 million for the second quarter ended Feb 28, 2018. ComfortDelGro Corporation acquired AZ Bus Pte Ltd's private bus chartering assets for S$10.25 million.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.01 points to 1,864.99. Gainers outnumbered losers 338 to 57, and trading volume was 262.867 million lots worth RM9.01 million.

site_title: ADB sees Asia's 2018 growth at 6%, but warns of trade risks
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) raised its 2018 economic growth estimate for developing Asia to 6.0%, citing solid export demand, but warned of trade risks posed by US protectionist measures. Growth is expected to ease to 5.9% in 2019. The bank also raised its growth estimate for China to 6.6% this year and 6.4% in 2019, despite concerns about diminishing capital inflows and the impact of US interest rate hikes.

site_title: SGX to list new Indian derivatives in June; exploring Gujarat tie-up with NSE
summary: SGX to list new Indian derivatives in June 2018, replacing Nifty futures due to India's decision to stop supporting offshore derivatives linked to their benchmark indices. The new products will provide continuity and allow for seamless transition of current India risk management exposures, according to SGX.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Boeing, Embraer get boost as key Brazil official sees 'marriage'
summary: Brazil's Defence Minister Joaquim Silva e Luna said Boeing and Embraer are likely to reach a deal, potentially forming the second major alliance between planemakers in six months. Negotiators are "getting closer" to an agreement, with Silva e Luna calling it a "marriage" between the two companies, which could boost their prospects. This development comes after months of talks and follows a similar alliance between Airbus and Bombardier in 2017.

site_title: Google is said in talks to buy Nokia's airborne broadband system
summary: Google is in talks to acquire Nokia's airborne broadband system, aiming to offer in-flight high-speed internet services. Nokia's technology could provide a faster alternative to existing Wi-Fi on airplanes. The deal, if reached, would help Google expand its reach and services. A final decision has not been made, and representatives for Alphabet and Nokia declined to comment.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks flat at the open
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Wednesday, following a conciliatory speech by Chinese President Xi Jinping, easing fears of a trade war with the US. The Nikkei 225 gained 0.1% and the Topix index rose 0.1%. The news came after US President Trump made new threats, but traders chose to brush them off, extending the recent stocks rally.

site_title: LVMH sets upbeat tone for luxury market as China demand rolls on
summary: LVMH, the world's largest luxury goods company, reported a 13% increase in sales for the first quarter, beating analysts' estimates of 8.5%. The company attributed the growth to strong demand from Chinese consumers, particularly for Louis Vuitton handbags and Givenchy makeup. Despite expected slowdown in China's economic growth, luxury demand remains high, with LVMH's e-commerce business and digital efforts also contributing to the growth. The company's chairman, Bernard Arnault, highlighted the importance of innovation and creativity in the luxury industry.

site_title: China opens door to new 2.85t yuan funding buffer for banks
summary: China has introduced new guidelines for banks to issue securities with a large loss-absorbing capacity, a type of bond that can absorb losses in the event of a crisis. The move is seen as a step towards meeting global regulators' requirements, with China's four biggest banks needing an estimated 2.85 trillion yuan in funding buffer by 2025. The first TLAC bond sale from China is expected to come in the next two to three years, with potential issuance volumes estimated to be huge, according to Moody's Investors Service.

site_title: Federal Reserve proposes new capital rules for Wall Street
summary: The Federal Reserve proposed new capital rules for Wall Street, allowing some large banks to reduce capital levels. The proposal aims to simplify regulations, reduce paperwork, and improve monitoring of bank health. The new "stress capital buffer" standard is expected to increase capital for the 30 largest banks and decrease it for smaller ones. The changes are likely to take effect next year, with a 60-day comment period. The move is part of the Fed's first reform of capital standards since the 2008 financial crisis.

site_title: US companies found ways to avoid taxes before tax cut bill: report
summary: US corporations, including Amazon and Duke Energy, avoided paying US$1.4 billion in taxes in 2017 by using various tax breaks. The Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy reported that these companies had combined profits of US$24.5 billion, but only paid a combined tax rate of minus 5.6%. The new US tax regime is expected to allow corporations to avoid even more taxes, with the depreciation tax break expanded by last year's tax legislation. The tax avoidance strategies used by these companies include writing off executive stock options and using renewable energy production tax credits.

site_title: Uber harassment complaints not so terrible, says women's lawyer
summary: Uber's alleged sexual harassment complaints may not be as severe as initially thought, according to a lawyer representing women suing the company. In a class-action settlement, $1.9 million is set aside for employees who file detailed reports of harassment, with awards determined by a point system. However, a lawyer for the plaintiffs stated that only a few people expressed enthusiasm for coming forward, raising concerns about the case's validity. The settlement also allocates $5 million for pay equity and $3 million for attorneys, awaiting preliminary approval from a US District Judge.

images.alt_text: Allegations about rampant sexual harassment at Uber Technologies helped drive Travis Kalanick out of his job as boss last year, but a lawyer for women suing the company told a judge he couldn't find many workers who said "something terrible" happened to them.

site_title: Japan February core machinery orders up 2.1% m-o-m
summary: Japan's core machinery orders rose 2.1% in February from the previous month, exceeding economists' expectations of a 2.5% decline. This increase suggests a pick-up in capital expenditure, which could be a positive sign for the economy. Core machinery orders also rose 2.4% from a year earlier, beating the median estimate of no change. The data is considered a good indicator of capital spending in the coming six to nine months.

site_title: Not much evidence of productivity boost from robots: economist
summary: An economist, Roger Josefsson, questions the productivity boost from robots and artificial intelligence, citing a lack of evidence. Despite rapid growth in industrial robots and investments in technologies, productivity growth remains stagnant. Josefsson's analysis of the Conference Board's Total Economy Database and the EU's KLEMS database reveals that the contribution from information and communication technology to GDP growth and total factor productivity has been falling behind. However, some sectors, such as wholesale trade and recreational services, show promising productivity growth.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won edge higher as trade war fears ease
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 4.54 points, or 0.19%, to 2,455.28 at 0129 GMT on Wednesday, following Chinese President Xi Jinping's efforts to ease fears over a US-China trade war. The won edged higher against the US dollar, while bond yields fell. MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan also rose 0.23%. The Kospi is down 0.7% so far this year, but foreign investors were net buyers of 25,506 million won worth of shares.

site_title: France's Hollande lashes Macron in tell-all book
summary: Former French President Francois Hollande has released a memoir, "Lessons on Power", criticizing his successor Emmanuel Macron for deepening inequality with pro-business reforms. Hollande accuses Macron of rushing through policies without consultation, resulting in worsening inequalities and policy u-turns. Hollande warns Macron of facing trouble with his reforms and advises him to prioritize negotiation over haste. The criticism comes as Macron faces protests over his education and train reform policies.

site_title: Annica Holdings extends redemption date for convertible bonds till March next year
summary: Annica Holdings has extended the redemption date for its convertible bonds to March 31, 2019, to improve short-term cash flow. The conversion period remains unchanged at December 24, 2018. The company, which operates in power generation and trading, entered into an agreement with Premier Equity Fund Sub Fund F and fund manager Value Capital Asset Management to make the change.

site_title: US$292b opinion gap behind volatility in China property stocks
summary: China's major listed property firms have the widest share-price target ranges in Asia, with a US$292 billion opinion gap, making their stocks highly volatile. Analysts are divided between optimists who see soaring land values and demand for homes in third- and fourth-tier cities, and pessimists who worry about high debt burdens and government curbs on property speculation. The industry's volatility has created trading opportunities for those with a strong opinion on China's real estate sector.

site_title: China's Xi pledges greater openness amid Trump trade dispute
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping pledged greater openness to the world economy in a speech at the Boao Forum for Asia, amid trade disputes with the US. He reiterated plans to increase imports, lower foreign-ownership limits, and expand protection for intellectual property, aiming to counter US concerns. The conciliatory tone helped boost Asian markets, but economists warn that concrete actions are needed to resolve the trade dispute. Xi's speech also marked a 40-year milestone for China's economic reforms, and he cautioned against a "Cold War mentality" and zero-sum thinking.

site_title: In ageing Thailand, developers race to supply locals and elderly expats
summary: Thailand is experiencing rapid ageing, with developers racing to cater to the growing population of elderly locals and foreign retirees. At 79, Boon Vasin, chairman of the Thonburi Healthcare Group, is launching a US$500 million venture to provide comprehensive care. The country's agreeable climate, low living and health costs, and service-oriented culture make it an attractive retirement option. As the population ages, Thailand's developers are focusing on healthcare and elderly services, aiming to "look after" them from waking hours to bedtime. This trend is expected to continue as Thailand's population continues to age.

site_title: European property latest lure for Japan funds: Tokio Marine
summary: Japanese institutional investors are shifting their focus to European real-estate funds due to attractive yields and lower hedging costs. Tokio Marine Asset Management reported a "multi-fold" increase in inflows to its overseas real-estate equity funds, reaching around $2.4 billion at the end of March. This trend is driven by a desire to take risks on real estate but not currency, and a wariness about the US property market peaking out, with over half of homeowners expecting home prices to decline in the next two years. European assets are seen as a more attractive option.

site_title: Beijing to watch impact of tariffs on soybean supplies
summary: China's Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs expects soybean supplies to remain "basically normal" in the short term despite a proposed 25% tariff on US imports. The ministry acknowledged the escalating trade friction with the US, citing concerns about the impact on the domestic market. South America remains China's main soybean supplier during the first part of the year, but further developments will be monitored for the rest of the year. The proposed tariffs are in retaliation for US trade actions amid an escalating trade dispute between the two economies.

site_title: Najib can still turn the tables on the opposition
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak has an opportunity to reinvent himself ahead of a general election, potentially securing a legacy as a reformer despite corruption allegations. Najib's well-executed reforms, such as the goods and service tax, and his China connection could turn out to be game-changers. He aims to reduce the role of the state in business and push for transparency, but faces resistance from vested interests. If successful, Najib could lead Malaysia to become a high-income economy by 2020 and improve its economic prospects.

site_title: UN shipping agency under the gun over CO2 emissions, resistance from govts
summary: The United Nations' shipping agency is under pressure to agree on a plan to cut carbon emissions from the sector, which has avoided specific emissions-cut targets in a global climate pact. The sector's emissions could fall short of what's required to limit global warming, with the agency's strategy potentially insufficient. The shipping sector, like aviation, was exempt from specific emissions targets in the 2015 climate pact, which aims to limit a global average temperature rise to "well below" 2 deg C from 2020.

site_title: Making hope spring eternal for children
summary: The Make-A-Wish Foundation grants life-changing wishes to children with life-threatening illnesses, not just as a last wish. The organization's purpose is to lift the spirits of these children, allowing them to heal faster and better. Since its founding in 1980, Make-A-Wish has granted over 500,000 wishes in 50 countries, with its Singapore branch celebrating its 16th year. The foundation relies on donations and referrals to grant more wishes, with each wish taking six to nine months to complete.

site_title: Twitter follows Facebook in endorsing Senate's 'Honest Ads Act'
summary: Twitter has endorsed the Senate's 'Honest Ads Act', a bill requiring broader disclosures in online political advertising. The company will work with legislators to refine the proposal, which would subject online political ads to the same disclosure rules as TV and radio. Following Facebook's endorsement of the bill, Twitter's move aims to address concerns over Russian operatives using social media platforms to spread discord in the 2016 US presidential election. The company has also introduced measures to increase transparency in its own advertising practices.

site_title: STI rises 0.5% as trade fears ease
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.5% to 3,466.38, marking its fourth consecutive day of gains, following a speech by Chinese President Xi Jinping at the Boao Forum that alleviated global trade war fears. The speech hinted at gradual economic opening, easing concerns about the US-China trade spat. Analysts warn that investors should prepare for more volatility, as headline risks related to trade are not resolved.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Apple says all its facilities now powered by clean energy
summary: Apple has achieved its goal of powering all its facilities with renewable energy, including data centres, offices, and retail stores in 43 countries. This milestone marks a significant step towards reducing the company's carbon footprint. Nine suppliers have also committed to running their operations entirely on renewable energy sources, bringing the total to 23. This move is part of Apple's efforts to increase its use of clean energy and reduce its environmental impact.

site_title: US: Stocks end higher on easing trade fears, Facebook jumps
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday amid easing trade tensions with China, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 1.8% and the Nasdaq Composite Index rising 2.1%. Facebook surged 4.5% after its CEO apologized to Congress over a data breach scandal. Chinese leader Xi Jinping's speech aimed to quell trade conflict with US President Donald Trump, but analysts noted the comments were largely rehashed. Industrial shares and energy companies also gained, while airlines were hit by higher oil prices.

site_title: Hong Kong poised to be China's strategic and regional hub
summary: Hong Kong is poised to become a strategic and regional hub for China, driven by mainland firms' increasing commercial ambitions. Mainland investors have significantly increased their market share in commercial real estate and government land, with a total of HK$200 billion spent in 2017. The city's low tax regime, free flow of information, and corruption-free government are major attractions for Chinese companies. The number of companies with regional or local operations has increased by 24% since 2008, with mainland newcomers making up one-third of the total increase. Government incentives, such as a planned cut in corporate profit tax rate, are also expected to lure more mainland firms to the city.

site_title: Germany cheers for end to Deutsche Bank's Goldman pursuit
summary: Deutsche Bank AG has shelved its ambitions to compete with Goldman Sachs Group in international investment banking, following the appointment of veteran Christian Sewing as CEO. This move comes after three turnaround plans in less than three years. German lawmakers, including Ingrid Arndt-Brauer, welcome the decision, stating that Germany doesn't need an investment bank in the image of Goldman Sachs. The bank is expected to focus on lending to German companies at home and abroad.

site_title: Ikea prepares for future of mega cities and 'thin wallets'
summary: Ikea is shifting its business strategy to a three-year approach due to a rapidly transforming society, where people live in small spaces, have thin wallets, and little time. By 2030, 60% of the world's population will live in large cities, prompting the company to adapt. Ikea plans to increase its digital focus, online shopping, and home delivery services, while maintaining a focus on low costs. The company will prioritize city center stores and warehouses, and scale up its operations globally, ensuring its low-cost obsession remains a priority.

site_title: British business wants to keep EU rules after Brexit
summary: British businesses overwhelmingly prefer to maintain EU rules after Brexit, according to a Confederation of British Industry analysis. 18 of 23 industry sectors believe regulations should largely remain the same as EU ones, outweighing the benefits of breaking free from EU rules. Shipping, agriculture, and tourism could potentially benefit from rule changes, but the cost of losing single market access is deemed too high. The findings suggest a shift in the UK's Brexit strategy, with businesses prioritizing regulatory stability over economic freedom.

images.alt_text: British businesses overwhelmingly want to stick to European rules after Brexit, according to the most detailed sector-by-sector analysis of what companies need the UK to fight for in negotiations.

site_title: Latin America's digital economy beckons; will Singapore outfits go?
summary: Singapore tech companies can capitalize on Latin America's growing digital economy by offering niche, high-quality solutions in e-commerce, fintech, and healthcare. With the region's digital economy forecast to grow to S$154 billion by 2021, Singapore companies can fill the gap in in-market solutions. Key markets to focus on include Brazil and Mexico, which are among Latin America's largest and most tech-savvy markets. To succeed, Singapore companies must invest in local hires, partners, and knowledge to navigate the region's unique challenges and capitalize on the growing demand for innovative solutions.

site_title: Five ways your job will be impacted by 2030
summary: By 2030, automation will displace nearly a fourth of current work activities, significantly impacting jobs across sectors. Rapid technological advancements, including AI, virtual and augmented reality, and automation, will drive the "second machine age." This shift will require professionals to adapt and develop new skills to remain relevant. The impact will be felt not only in the workplace but also at home, as technology continues to evolve and influence various aspects of life.

site_title: Germany cheers as Deutsche Bank ends Goldman pursuit
summary: Deutsche Bank has abandoned its plans to become a major player in international investment banking, with CEO Christian Sewing signaling a shift towards focusing on lending to German companies at home and abroad. The move is seen as a welcome change by many in Germany, who believe the bank should prioritize its core business of lending to secure the German economy. With its international ambitions scaled back, Deutsche Bank is expected to intensify its focus on retail banking and financing for the German economy, particularly working with small and medium-sized companies.

site_title: Addvalue Tech sending its IDRS project back to space
summary: Addvalue Tech, a Singapore-based satellite communications company, is sending its IDRS project back to space for a commercial feasibility study. The study aims to explore new uses for the inter-satellite data relay system beyond low-earth orbit satellite communication. A successful study is expected to pave the way for commercialization and material financial effects on the company's performance from 2019. This move follows recent deals with Inmarsat and a four-year grant from the Economic Development Board's Office for Space Technology and Industry to support IDRS development and commercialization.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: America's least-favourite candy is suddenly its most sought after
summary: The US's oldest candy company, New England Confectionery Co, may shut down, sparking a surge in demand for its Necco Wafers, despite the candy's unpopularity. Consumers are hoarding the chalky wafers, which have been described as unappealing, in anticipation of the company's potential closure. Sales of Necco products have increased significantly, with wafer sales rising 63% and overall sales up 50%. The company's plant in Massachusetts is set to close in May if a buyer is not found, leading to a nostalgic demand for the 170-year-old candies.

site_title: ECB officials confident though economy softens
summary: The European Central Bank's top officials expressed cautious confidence in the euro-area economy despite recent data showing growth levelling out and retail sales missing estimates. Officials stated that the economy remains solid, but inflation remains too low and a global trade spat poses a threat. The ECB will continue to move slowly towards ending its stimulus, with a focus on gradual price pressures. Despite this, economists have noted a softening of indicators, particularly in Germany, and the ECB's outlook may be subject to change due to increasing downside risks.

images.alt_text: ECB's Mr Praet says he sees no reason to change the bank's economic outlook.

site_title: Frasers' serviced residence for millennials to open in China Sq
summary: Frasers Property will open Capri by Fraser, China Square in the first quarter of 2019, catering to millennials' desires for convenience and lifestyle options. The 16-floor, 304-room residence will feature technology such as a chatbot app, motion sensors, and RFID tags for optimized cleaning and linen delivery. Frasers Hospitality aims to be customer-centric, responding to the growth of young executives and cost-conscious companies scaling back on long-term overseas assignments. This is part of the company's expansion of its Capri brand, with eight locations worldwide planned by 2021.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: ComfortDelGro acquires AZ Bus Pte Ltd's private bus chartering assets for S$10.25 million, marking one of the largest local bus charter industry deals. YuuZoo Corporation promotes COO Mohandas to CEO amid company investigations. Anchor Resources secures a deal with a Malaysian granite quarry lease holder for East Coast Rail Line projects. Vard Holdings wins a contract to build a stern fishing trawler for Havfisk AS at S$67.2 million.

site_title: The BOE's easy money made life harder for some
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) released a study concluding that nine years of asset purchases, known as quantitative easing (QE), did not widen inequality in the UK economy. However, the study found that QE had a negligible impact on net wealth when netting out various effects, but had a significant impact on different income and age groups. Young people benefited from QE, while older households saw interest on their savings stagnate, and wealthier people invested in assets or real estate, exacerbating inequality. The BOE's study suggests that QE was not effective in reducing inequality and that alternative solutions, such as investing in education and infrastructure, may be more effective.

site_title: ECB mulls cash injections to smooth bank rescues
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is considering a new policy tool to inject cash into banks being rescued from insolvency. The proposal, called Eurosystem Resolution Liquidity (ERL), would allow the ECB to fund the viable parts of a lender spun out of a failing financial institution. The framework includes a public guarantee to safeguard against central bank losses. The measure aims to improve confidence in the euro-area resolution framework and address gaps in existing rules for dealing with troubled lenders.

site_title: Talent index ranks Singapore tops in Asia-Pacific
summary: Singapore ranks first in Asia-Pacific for the fifth consecutive year in attracting and developing talent, according to the Global Talent Competitiveness Index. The country, along with Switzerland, is the only non-European country in the top 10 globally. Singapore's strong diversity policy and multicultural environment are cited as key factors in its success. However, the index also highlights areas for improvement, including access to growth opportunities and social protection for labor.

site_title: A US-China trade war will hurt ties in many other areas
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong of Singapore expressed concerns that a US-China trade war could have catastrophic consequences for the world, damaging ties in various areas such as climate change, nuclear non-proliferation, and regional security. Lee warned that a full-scale trade war would make it difficult for both countries to cooperate, while economists pointed out that the focus on bilateral trade imbalance is misplaced. Lee called on China to liberalize its markets further and contribute more to the multilateral trading system to sustain Asia's economic dynamism.

site_title: Singtel and VMware setting up 'virtual sandbox' for clients
summary: Singtel and VMware are launching a "virtual sandbox" in Singapore to help clients accelerate digital transformation and bring products to market faster. The foundry, a hybrid cloud environment, enables enterprises to test products and implement cloud-enabled solutions more easily, reducing costs and improving productivity. The collaboration aims to meet the needs of Asia-Pacific customers, improving IT capabilities and enabling businesses to be more agile, cost-effective, secure, and responsive. Similar foundries are planned for Australia and Hong Kong, with a focus on cloud services for modernizing data centers and creating digital workspaces.

site_title: Euphoria of Trump stock market is dissipating
summary: The US stock market's recent declines are attributed to a broader slowdown in the economy, rather than specific factors like a trade war or tech controversy. As the economy grows more slowly, business profits are expected to decrease, causing stock prices to fall. The Trump administration's claims of tax cuts and regulatory policies boosting growth and profits are being contradicted by the market's reaction. This may vindicate critics who believe an economic slowdown is unavoidable, indicating a shift in investor expectations and a darker outlook for the economy.

site_title: Xi seeks to ease trade tensions, vows to open up China economy
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping pledged to ease trade tensions with the US by lowering import tariffs for vehicles and enforcing intellectual property rights for foreign firms. In a speech at the Boao Forum, Xi announced plans to increase foreign ownership limits in the automobile sector and push measures to open the financial sector. This comes after US President Donald Trump asked for another $100 billion in tariffs on Chinese goods, prompting China's Commerce Ministry to threaten a major response. The move was seen as a step to ease tensions, with markets closing higher after the speech.

site_title: Ex-Japan PM aide denies favour for Abe's friend as scandal clouds gather
summary: A former aide to Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe denied intervening to help a friend's plan for a new veterinary school, amid a growing cronyism scandal. The school, Japan's first in over 50 years, was approved in a government-designated deregulation zone, sparking doubts about Abe's influence. The scandal, combined with other controversies, has eroded Abe's support and raised questions about his ability to remain in power.

site_title: Noble restructuring in doubt as founder Elman said to be pushing for new deal
summary: Richard Elman, founder of Noble Group Ltd, is pushing for a new debt-for-equity restructuring deal worth US$3.5 billion, which would wipe out existing equity investors. If shareholders reject the plan, Noble plans to file for insolvency in London. The deal requires support from at least half of the shareholders. Elman's push casts doubt on the company's survival.

site_title: Apsil ends RTO deal with Chinese property firm
summary: Apsil, a Singapore-listed investment firm, has ended its deal to buy a Chinese real estate firm due to lack of approval from China's Ministry of Commerce since 2016. The planned S$33.3 million acquisition aimed to capitalize on the firm's reputation and government connections. The move follows Apsil's cancellation of a share subscription meant to finance the acquisition and comes after the firm abandoned a proposed deal to buy a stake in IPC Corporation. Apsil will instead focus on developing waterside properties in China.

site_title: Rewarding good corp governance is right move
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has introduced the SGX Fast Track programme to reward listed companies with good corporate governance (CG) practices and compliance track records. The programme provides accelerated approval for certain corporate actions and prioritised clearance for circulars and applications. The selection is based on a company's CG standards, compliance track record, and quality of submissions, with continuous review and potential removal from the list if breaches occur. The initiative aims to encourage companies to invest in CG and build credibility with investors.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: More hay please, frequent-flier horses on board
summary: A KLM Royal Dutch Airlines Boeing 747 flew from Amsterdam to New York City with 268 passengers and nine bales of hay, but unbeknownst to most, a group of six European horses were hidden in the cargo hold. The horses, valued at millions, were shipped by the Dutta Corp, a logistics company that specializes in transporting equines globally. To minimize jet lag, the company schedules feeding according to the horses' home time zone and maintains a constant circadian rhythm with lights and chilled cabin temperatures. The flight's in-flight groom, Sebastian Bolse, ensured the horses received fresh hay and water during the 7.5-hour journey.

images.alt_text: Cadillac Boy, a Rheinlander gelding, on a flight to New York. Equine frequent flyers fuel an industry of horse transportation that sees these prize horses being sent around the world for sale and competition.

site_title: Global carmakers get a break amid US-China trade spat
summary: China has pledged to significantly lower car import tariffs, aiming to boost imports and ease tensions in the US-China trade spat. The move, announced by President Xi Jinping, could benefit global carmakers such as BMW and Toyota, particularly luxury brands like Lexus. However, local Chinese carmakers like BAIC Motor and BYD saw their shares slump as a result. The tariff cut is part of a broader effort to open up China's auto sector, with plans to loosen foreign ownership limits and roll out the policies as soon as possible.

images.alt_text: Audi China president Joachim Wedler presenting an Audi Q8 concept in Guangzhou. Luxury sales leader Audi, part of Volkswagen, has been making cars in the country since 1996. High-end models benefit most from cuts to the current 25 per cent import tariff as less of the production is in China.

site_title: Further home price spikes may spell risk of renewed cooling measures
summary: Singapore's private home prices surged 3.1% in Q1, with analysts predicting further increases, sparking concerns of renewed cooling measures. The Urban Redevelopment Authority's (URA) overall private home price index has risen 4.7% from its recent trough in Q2 2017, driven by bullish land prices. If similar price hikes continue, the risk of government intervention increases, particularly if the index grows at a double-digit pace. Analysts suggest potential cooling measures could include reducing seller's stamp duty and loan-to-value limits, but warn of potential negative impacts on the construction sector and financial institutions.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Hedge fund picker banks on activists in bet that Japan Inc will change its ways
summary: Hedge fund manager Ed Rogers is betting on Japan's corporate governance overhaul, increasing assets to 10% in activist funds, as the country continues to implement reforms. The drive to improve governance, following scandals and a declining population, is expected to lead to restructuring and profit growth. Many investors, including JPMorgan and Standard Life Aberdeen, share Rogers' assessment, but also point out that more work needs to be done, including improving representation on boards and reducing unnecessary convertible bonds.

images.alt_text: Mr Rogers of Wolver Hill group: "Corporate governance has taken root in Japan. From an alpha point of view, we think there's a tremendous amount of restructuring going on."

site_title: Yotel teams up with US platform to groom hospitality startups
summary: Yotel, a digital-first hospitality group, has partnered with Plug and Play, a Silicon Valley innovation platform, to groom hospitality startups that can disrupt the travel and hospitality space. This partnership aims to support and scale disruptive technologies that can positively influence the industry. By working together, Yotel and Plug and Play will discover, support, and scale innovative technologies that can enhance the travel and hospitality experience. This collaboration is expected to drive growth and innovation in the hospitality sector.

site_title: Trade war could reduce US role as agricultural supplier: Olam
summary: A potential US trade war with China and the EU could reduce the US's role as a global agricultural supplier, forcing customers to diversify away from US exports. Olam International's CEO, Sunny Verghese, warns that targeted agricultural tariffs could slow global trade and economic growth, as the US is a significant supplier to top importers China, Canada, and Mexico. The company aims to stay diversified across producing countries and increase domestic trade participation to mitigate the impact of trade tensions.

site_title: SPH Q2 profit down 25% but H1 earnings edge up 1.4%
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) reported a 25% year-on-year decline in Q2 net profit to S$40.19 million, but a 1.4% increase in H1 earnings to S$100.62 million. The group is focusing on growth in aged care and property asset management sectors, with CEO Ng Yat Chung stating plans to explore opportunities locally and overseas. Despite a 1.8% dip in operating revenue, the group's digital circulation rose 112,000 copies year-on-year, and a new retail and condo project is expected to contribute to growth in the next few years.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore-listed Cromwell European Reit (CERT) is poised to benefit from an improving European economy, with a diversified portfolio of office, light industrial, and retail properties. The trust has a strong income visibility with a weighted average lease expiry of 4.9 years and is backed by Cromwell Property Group. Analysts initiate coverage with a target price of 0.63 euro, citing a positive outlook for the sector, although key risks include lower-than-expected rental income.

site_title: Communications Stop Order a big step to prevent information leaks
summary: Singapore's parliament passes the Public Order and Safety (Special Powers) Bill, which includes a Communications Stop Order (CSO) to prevent information leaks during emergency incidents like terrorist attacks. The CSO makes it illegal to share pictures, films, or text/audio messages about ongoing security operations. The measure aims to reduce the spread of misinformation and protect security forces. The move follows similar incidents overseas, where leaked information endangered lives. The Singapore Police Force is expected to use its social media channels to disseminate accurate information during crises.

site_title: Boosting retirement adequacy via a lifetime investment scheme
summary: Singapore's CPF Lifetime Retirement Investment Scheme aims to enhance retirement adequacy through low-cost, passively managed funds. The scheme will offer a disciplined savings mechanism, encouraging early contributions and compound interest growth. By launching this scheme, Singapore aims to help members accumulate a larger nest egg for retirement, potentially meeting a 40% or 60% income replacement target. The scheme's objectives align with CPF's goal of helping Singaporeans save for retirement, with a long-term investment horizon expected to maximize returns.

site_title: US inflation set to break free from mobile phone drag
summary: US inflation is expected to rise, with the core Consumer Price Index (CPI) increasing 2.1% in the 12 months ended March, surpassing the Federal Reserve's 2% goal. A sharp decline in mobile phone costs in 2017, which weighed on CPI, is fading, and other factors, such as moderation in core CPI and energy prices, may be contributing to the increase. This pick-up in inflation could lead to faster interest-rate hikes by the central bank, but may be exaggerated by the wireless-costs comparison, according to economists.

site_title: Canada bets big on canola as China-US spat creates opening
summary: Canada is expected to increase its canola production due to the China-US tariff spat, with growers potentially planting 9.7 million hectares in 2018, a 4.4% increase from last year. Higher prices and the demand for a soybean substitute in cooking oil and animal feed are driving the shift. China's purchases of Canadian oilseed shipments could climb by several hundred thousand tonnes, boosting demand for canola. This move could also limit gains in canola prices if US soybean prices sag.

site_title: Jet Airways rules out bid for Air India
summary: Jet Airways has ruled out a bid for debt-laden national carrier Air India, dealing a blow to the Indian government's privatisation plans. This comes after IndiGo, India's largest airline, withdrew from the bidding process due to interest only in Air India's international routes. The government had sought a 76% stake in Air India, with the buyer required to take on all operations. The airline has struggled with losses and debts of $7.67 billion, and the government has released bid documents for the asset sale.

site_title: Ireland may be last big block to final Brexit deal
summary: Ireland may be the last major hurdle to a final Brexit deal, as the UK's departure from the EU approaches. Despite the Good Friday Agreement's 20th anniversary, progress on the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland has been slow. All parties want to avoid a harder border, but Brussels insists that a frictionless border is incompatible with the UK's exit from the EU Customs Union. The UK and EU are working towards a post-Brexit trade deal, with the UK's Prime Minister Theresa May's promise of leaving the EU Customs Union at odds with Brussels' stance.

site_title: IMF warns of heightened credit risk in easy-money era
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned of heightened credit risk in an "easy-money" era, citing rebounding riskiness of credit globally after the 2008 financial crisis. The IMF report notes that credit expansion has raised concerns among policymakers and market analysts, particularly in advanced economies. The report recommends monitoring credit origination standards and intensifying scrutiny during episodes of credit expansion, with conditions being less risky in independent banking supervision and stronger minority shareholder protection. This comes as central banks begin to tighten monetary policy.

site_title: 1st major facelift soon for Great World City
summary: Great World City in Singapore is undergoing its first major refurbishment in 20 years, starting mid-April 2018. The 2-year project will add 50 new tenants, 3 MRT access points, and new design and facade elements. The mall will remain open and unaffected during the renovation, with some tenants closing temporarily for renovations. Improvements include reconfigured walkways, dual-level retail pods, and increased F&B offerings, with a new food hall concept and outdoor playground to be completed by the third quarter of 2020.

site_title: US govt is spending more than it earns
summary: The US federal government is expected to run a $1 trillion deficit in 2020 and continue with yawning deficits for years to come, according to the Congressional Budget Office. The country's debt is projected to reach $28 trillion by 2028, the highest level since World War II. The government's spending exceeds its revenue, mainly due to aging population and increased military spending, and experts warn of potential economic crisis if the debt is not addressed. Possible solutions include raising taxes, trimming social programs, and implementing a balanced budget amendment, but none are expected to pass.

site_title: US producer prices increase more than expected in March
summary: US producer prices increased 0.3% in March, exceeding expectations, driven by a rise in healthcare and airline fees. The year-on-year increase in the PPI rose to 3.0%, the largest since August 2014. Economists expect inflation to pick up this year due to a tightening labor market, weak dollar, and fiscal stimulus. The core PPI, excluding food, energy, and trade services, rose 0.4% for a third straight month, increasing by 2.9% over the past 12 months, the largest increase since 2014.

site_title: Genting HK to suspend trading on Wednesday following delisting
summary: Genting Hong Kong will suspend trading of its shares on Wednesday following its delisting announcement in October. The company held a secondary listing in Singapore for about three years, retaining its primary listing in Hong Kong.

site_title: Sliding premiums could point to cooling in en bloc fever
summary: A property analyst predicts that en-bloc fever in Singapore will peak in the second or third quarter of 2018, citing smaller premiums paid by developers and increased selectivity. The supply of private homes is rising, with recent collective sales adding 15,000 to 20,000 units, and many developers have restocked their land banks. The analyst expects the value of collective sales to reach S$8.2 billion in 2018, but notes that the market may be nearing a peak due to factors such as interest rate hikes and a weaker rental market.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Services, food boost producer prices in March
summary: US producer prices rose 0.3% in March, exceeding expectations, driven by a 0.4% increase in the core PPI, which excludes food, energy, and trade services, its largest gain since August 2014. The year-on-year increase in the PPI rose to 3.0%, pointing to steady inflation pressures. The data supports views that inflation will pick up this year, with the Federal Reserve forecasting two more rate hikes. The increase in producer prices also lifted prices for healthcare and food costs, boosting the year-on-year increase in the PPI.

images.alt_text: Rising healthcare and transportation costs fed a surge in US wholesale prices in March, pointing to stronger pressures on inflation.

site_title: Credit card signatures may soon be obsolete
summary: Credit card signatures may become obsolete as four major networks, including American Express, Discover, Mastercard, and Visa, plan to stop requiring them for transactions. The move follows the widespread use of microchipped cards, which create unique codes for each transaction, making signatures less necessary. The change is optional, and retailers can decide whether to stop collecting signatures. Some, like Target and Walmart, have already stopped recording signatures, while others, like smaller retailers, may lag behind. The signature's usefulness has been diminishing for years, with card issuers and networks increasingly relying on forensic systems to detect and adjudicate fraud.

site_title: IMF warns of heightened credit risk in easy-money era
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned of heightened credit risk in the current "easy-money" era, citing rebounding riskiness of credit globally after the financial crisis. The riskiness of corporate debt has increased, potentially jeopardizing growth, and policymakers and market analysts are concerned about the allocation of credit to risky firms. The IMF recommends continuous monitoring of credit origination standards and intensified scrutiny during periods of credit expansion.

site_title: SPH's Q2 net profit falls on lower investment income
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) reported a near 25% year-on-year fall in net profit to S$40.19 million in Q2 2018, due to lower investment income. Operating revenue declined 1.8% to S$233.7 million, with media business revenue falling 7.4% and operating profit decreasing 6.9% to S$49.36 million. Despite this, the company declared an interim dividend of six Singapore cents per share and plans to focus on digital growth and expansion in aged care and property asset management.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Norway says wealth fund should not invest in unlisted companies
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund, valued at over $1 trillion, should not invest in unlisted companies due to cost and lack of transparency, according to the country's finance ministry. The fund's central bank had requested investment in unlisted companies for potential higher returns, but the government rejected the proposal. The fund will continue to invest in stocks, bonds, and real estate, but may consider investments in unlisted renewable energy infrastructure. The decision must still be approved by parliament.

site_title: CAD orders Midas to hand over documents, staff details
summary: Midas Holdings, a Singapore-based railway-parts maker, has been ordered by the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) to hand over financial documents, staff details, and IT equipment as part of an investigation. The company, under investigation by Singapore authorities, has uncovered several litigations and court documents involving its Chinese subsidiaries. Midas has extended cooperation with the CAD and will make further announcements as the investigation unfolds. Trading in shares remains suspended.

site_title: Don't rule out a yuan devaluation despite Xi's overtures
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping's recent speech to the Boao Forum did not address currency policy, leaving room for a potential yuan devaluation as a deterrent against US trade tensions. The yuan has weakened in the past four days, but rebounded 0.3% on Tuesday. China needs to maintain economic ammunition to counter any escalation in the trade war, which could impact the country's own economy. A cheaper yuan could be beneficial, as it slowed the pace of the Fed's rate increases in 2015, and may be seen as a response to the US's own currency manipulation.

site_title: May 9 face-off between Najib and former premier Mahathir
summary: Malaysia's May 9 general election will be a showdown between caretaker Prime Minister Najib Razak and former premier Mahathir Mohamad, marking the end of 60 years of unbroken rule by Barisan Nasional coalition. Najib seeks a third term, while Mahathir leads opposition coalition Pakatan Harapan, promising to remove Najib. The shortened campaign period, from 11 days, starts on April 28, and Najib has unveiled a manifesto targeting his vote bank. The opposition is capitalizing on the 1MDB scandal and promises to abolish the goods-and-services tax.

images.alt_text: Malaysians will cast their vote on May 9 in what will be a showdown between caretaker Prime Minister Najib Razak and Mahathir Mohamad, the nation's longest-serving premier.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher as tech stocks gain
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, driven by gains in technology stocks, following Chinese President Xi Jinping's promise to cut import tariffs. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.66%, the S&P 500 gained 1.38%, and the Nasdaq Composite added 1.59%. The news eased investor concerns about rising US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Indonesia's Lion Air buying 50 Boeing 737's in US$6.2b deal
summary: Indonesia's Lion Air has signed a deal with Boeing to purchase 50 Boeing 737 MAX 10 aircraft valued at approximately US$6.2 billion. The order, the largest for the MAX 10, is expected to be delivered from 2020 and is seen as a strategic move to capitalize on Indonesia's growing aviation industry. The airline, which started with just one plane in 1999, aims to increase flights in the coming years to meet the country's increasing demand for air travel.

site_title: Total and Aramco sign US$5b deal to build Jubail petrochemical complex
summary: Total and Saudi Aramco signed a $5 billion deal to build a 1.5 million-ton-per-year petrochemical complex at the Jubail Satorp refinery, with 8,000 jobs to be created. The complex will integrate refining and petrochemical platforms and expand operations in the Asian polymer market. The investment, totaling $9 billion, will be made by Total and third-party investors, with the project set to begin front-end engineering and design in the third quarter of 2018.

site_title: Gearing up for change
summary: Singapore Maritime Week 2018 will address industry challenges, including technology, disruption, and sustainability. Industry professionals discuss the industry's future growth, citing market consolidation, digitalization, and emerging trade flows as key drivers. Singapore faces competition from regional ports and other international maritime clusters, but can stay relevant by offering a strong value proposition, innovative solutions, and a skilled workforce. The Sea Transport Industry Transformation Map aims to grow the sector's value-add by $4.5 billion and create 5,000 jobs by 2025. The Maritime Transformation Programme will develop future capabilities in maritime traffic management, enhancing operational efficiencies, and improving safety and security.

images.alt_text: "At the heart of the maritime industry is its people. We need to build up a good pipeline of local talent even as we remain open to talent. This gives us a competitive edge," says Mr Tan.

"We live in a very competitive world and it will be crucial for us to stay nimble if we are to continue not only to maintain our position as a leading maritime centre, but to further grow it," says Mr Poulsson.
"We need to attract the right people to the industry, and to put together teams which combine knowledge of the industry with technology skills," says Mr Sohmen-Pao.

"The calls for better visibility and connectivity in the supply chain are getting louder. Stakeholders must be prepared to embrace these challenges and opportunities, or face obsolescence," says Mr Ong.
"Singapore's ITM for the maritime industry helps to define how the industry is anticipating and preparing for the new opportunities in the years ahead," says Mr Ooi.

site_title: The happier the ship, the safer it is
summary: International Day of Happiness, observed on March 22, aims to promote economic growth by prioritizing worker happiness and well-being. Research suggests that happy crews are safer and more productive at sea, implying that mistreatment can lead to safety and maintenance issues. The initiative encourages an inclusive approach to economic growth, ultimately benefiting society as a whole.

site_title: Saudi Arabia said to signal ambition for US$80 oil price
summary: Saudi Arabia aims to reach oil prices near $80 a barrel to support its government agenda and Aramco's valuation before its IPO. Officials have discussed this goal with OPEC delegates and oil market participants, despite not specifying a target. Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman and Oil Minister Khalid Al-Falih have expressed hawkish views on oil prices, citing the need for higher prices to stimulate investment and meet domestic policy imperatives. Riyadh plans to continue current oil cuts until the price goal is closer, relying on declining Venezuelan oil production, US sanctions on Iran, and demand growth to absorb US shale production.

site_title: US dollar dips to 2-week lows on Xi's comments
summary: The US dollar fell to a two-week low against a basket of currencies on Tuesday after Chinese President Xi Jinping's comments on cutting import tariffs eased concerns about a trade conflict. Xi pledged to open the economy further and lower tariffs, giving clear backing for open economies. The US dollar-yen rate rose 0.2%, while the Australian and Canadian dollars benefited from the revival in risk appetite. The move eased concerns about a trade conflict and was seen as risk-friendly by market analysts.

site_title: Central bank heavyweights head back to euro government debt
summary: Major global central banks are increasing their purchases of euro zone government bonds, attracted by rising yields, a strong euro, and uncertain US debt markets. China and Norway have been particularly active, with China looking for alternative investments beyond US Treasuries. Central banks bought significant chunks of bonds from Belgium, France, and Germany, with European governments welcoming the increased participation. Analysts predict higher yields could lure more money into euro markets, potentially benefiting the currency and the region's economic recovery.

site_title: Sinochem hires 7 banks for US$2b IPO: sources
summary: China's state-owned Sinochem Group has hired seven banks to manage a $2 billion Hong Kong stock listing of its key oil assets. The planned IPO will include oil refining, trading, storage, and logistics businesses, but not the struggling upstream business. Sinochem has chosen BOC International, CLSA, and Morgan Stanley as joint sponsors of the initial public offering (IPO). The move is part of the company's shift to higher-value businesses, including petrochemicals production.

site_title: Private home resale prices hit fresh highs in March: SRX flash
summary: Resale prices for private, non-landed homes in Singapore reached fresh highs in March, with a 1.5% increase, according to SRX Property data. Prices rose across the island, with the central core region seeing a 2.2% increase and the rest of the central region a 1.3% increase. This marks an 8.5% year-on-year price increase and a 3.5% quarter-on-quarter rise. Resale volume also swelled by 11.4% to 1,310 units, but remains 36.1% lower than the peak in April 2010. Experts expect resale prices to continue rising due to demand from displaced homeowners and rising benchmark prices.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: UK consumer spending cools as freezing weather keeps shoppers at home
summary: UK household spending grew at its slowest pace in almost two years in March, with annual consumption growth slowing to 2% due to freezing weather keeping shoppers at home. Spending in stores fell 1.9% as online shopping increased. The "Beast from the East" snowstorm had a significant impact on consumer behavior, with shoppers opting for online shopping instead of visiting physical stores.

site_title: San Miguel seeks up to US$3.6 billion in share sale at merged unit
summary: San Miguel Corp., the Philippines' largest company, plans to raise up to US$3.6 billion by selling 30% of its merged food and drinks unit, San Miguel Food and Beverage Inc. The unit, now worth US$12 billion, is valued at US$3.6 billion for a 30% stake and US$2.4 billion for a 20% stake. The sale is part of the company's diversification efforts, which have helped boost its shares 21% in 2017 and 27% so far this year.

site_title: Watch Boao Forum, Lima summit for big picture on commodities
summary: US sanctions on Russian companies and oligarchs are disrupting the aluminum market, with shares in United Co Rusal plummeting. The sanctions are also affecting Glencore Plc, one of Rusal's top holders. Meanwhile, China's leadership, including President Xi Jinping, will discuss trade tensions at the Boao Forum for Asia, while a US-Mexico-Canada summit in Lima may provide a breakthrough on Nafta talks. Global trade tensions are also affecting the copper industry, with investors tracking the market's outlook and potential labor tensions.

site_title: CEO exit signals new era for star Indian banks
summary: Axis Bank CEO Shikha Sharma unexpectedly exits after almost 10 years, with the Reserve Bank of India reportedly asking for her term extension to be reconsidered. The move could signal tougher oversight of India's top private sector banks, with some analysts predicting a takeover interest from rival banks like Kotak Mahindra. ICICI Bank's Chanda Kochhar may also face similar scrutiny, amid an ongoing storm over a conflict of interest. The exit marks a new era for India's top banks, with stronger institutions expected as a result of the regulator's increased scrutiny.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality's Capri residence in China Square Central to open Q1 2019
summary: Frasers Hospitality will open its Capri residence, Capri by Fraser, China Square Central in Singapore's first quarter of 2019. The 304-room, 16-floor hotel will feature new technologies, including a chatbot app for guest services and motion sensors for optimized cleaning. The goal is to cater to millennials' desire for convenience and lifestyle options. The Capri brand is expected to grow globally, particularly in Europe and North Asia, due to the prevalence of interstate business travel. The Capri residence is one of eight in the works and slated to open by 2021.

site_title: TV goes royal 'crazy' in run-up to Harry and Meghan marriage
summary: Royal documentaries are flooding TV schedules worldwide in the run-up to Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's marriage, with nearly 9 hours of programs in the pipeline. The "Meghan factor" has been a major draw, with the wedding being described as an "American story." New royal documentaries, such as "The Queen's Green Planet," are also gaining attention, showcasing the Queen's passion for trees and highlighting her relevance to modern audiences. The increased interest in the royals has been attributed to the success of Netflix's "The Crown" and the unique qualities of Meghan Markle, who is seen as bringing a fresh perspective to the royal family.

site_title: CAD orders Midas Holdings to hand over financial documents, list of certain staff
summary: Singapore authorities have ordered Midas Holdings, a railway parts maker under investigation, to hand over financial documents, staff lists, and IT equipment. The company has agreed to cooperate fully with the investigation, which includes documents related to a subsidiary in China with a previously undisclosed liability of 30 million yuan. Midas Holdings had previously disclosed several litigations and enforcement orders involving its group companies.

site_title: ComfortDelGro buys local bus charter business for S$10.25m
summary: ComfortDelGro Corporation has acquired the private bus chartering assets of AZ Bus Pte Ltd for S$10.25 million, marking one of the largest acquisitions in the local bus charter industry. The deal includes existing contracts, 94 buses, and associated drivers. ComfortDelGro is now Singapore's largest private bus charter operator, with AZ Bus's charter contracts and fleet to be integrated into its business.

site_title: Europe: Stocks advance at open on Xi speech
summary: Europe's major stock markets advanced in opening deals on Tuesday following Chinese President Xi Jinping's speech at the Boao Forum, where he pledged new measures to open China's economy "wider and wider". The FTSE 100 rose 0.6%, the DAX 30 increased 1.1%, and the CAC 40 gained 0.7%. Analysts saw Xi's comments as an effort to calm US-China trade tensions, boosting hopes for a balanced outcome that avoids disruption to global growth.

site_title: Dozens dead in Indonesia after drinking bootleg liquor
summary: Dozens of Indonesians have died and many have been hospitalized after consuming homemade alcohol tainted with mosquito repellent and other ingredients. At least 12 men have been detained on suspicion of making and selling the liquor. The cause of the deaths is unclear, but authorities suspect it may be due to methanol or insect repellent. The incident has raised concerns about bootleg liquor in the country, with more victims expected to come forward.

site_title: Vard to build new-design stern trawler for just under 400m Norwegian kroner
summary: Vard Holdings has secured a contract to build a new stern trawler for Havfisk AS, valued at approximately 400 million Norwegian kroner (S$67.2 million). The vessel, designed with an integrated energy storage system, is scheduled for delivery in the first quarter of 2020. The hull will be built in Romania, while outfitting and completion will be carried out in Norway, marking a significant project for Norway's largest trawler company, Havfisk AS.

site_title: A US$292 billion difference of opinion roils China property stocks
summary: A significant divide among analysts in Asia exists regarding China's property market outlook, with some predicting a $596 billion valuation in a year and others foreseeing a $304 billion valuation. The split is reflected in the volatility of Chinese property stocks, with Sunac China Holdings Ltd. and Future Land Development Holdings Ltd. experiencing the largest price-target gaps in Asia. Analysts point to factors such as soaring land values, buoyant demand, and industry consolidation as reasons for the bulls' optimism, while debt burdens and government curbs on property speculation are cited by bears.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's condo and apartment resale prices reached a new high in March 2018, with a 1.5% monthly rise, according to SRX. Co-living startup Hmlet is launching its second building near Newton. Moody's upgraded Noble Group's outlook to 'stable' and reaffirmed its investment grade rating. The company's founder, Richard Elman, is pushing for a new restructuring deal. A public tender for the Casa Meyfort condominium in Singapore relaunched at S$340m. Singapore remained the top destination for talent in Asia-Pacific and globally, according to Insead's index.

site_title: Trade wars in a winner-takes-all world
summary: US President Donald Trump's new trade tariffs have transformed the US from a global multilateral trading system's champion to its nemesis. This shift is partly due to an economic shift towards "old economy" industries, such as steel, plagued by excess capacity, particularly in China. The US' erratic politician can't suddenly overturn long-established structures, but this fundamental economic shift provides an opportunity for change.

site_title: Hong Kong: Mainland stocks end higher on Xi comments
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 1.65% and Shanghai Composite Index 1.66% following comments from Chinese President Xi Jinping on opening up the economy, potentially tempering US trade war concerns. The increases were also driven by gains in the Shenzhen Composite Index. The rally came ahead of key economic data releases and amid ongoing US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Beijing to watch soybean supplies closely as tariff plan triggers price surge
summary: China's agriculture ministry expects soybean supplies to remain "basically normal" in the short-term due to South America being the main supplier during the first part of the year. However, Beijing will monitor the impact of a proposed 25% tariff on US imports, citing "highly concerned" domestic market sentiment. The ministry's monthly crop report acknowledged escalating trade friction with the US, which has triggered a price surge.

site_title: Malaysia: Stock end higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 11.27 points to 1,860.98 on Tuesday, driven by a 3.73 billion-share volume worth RM2.71 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 955 to 221. The market's rally follows a 5-day rally in Singapore and amid positive sentiment in the US, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite US-EU trade uncertainty.

site_title: Apsil ends RTO deal to buy Chinese property firm
summary: Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments (Apsil) has ended its deal to buy a Chinese real estate firm via a reverse takeover due to lack of approval from China's Ministry of Commerce, which had not approved the acquisition since 2016. The firm had planned to acquire the Chinese real estate firm for S$33.3 million in 2016, citing the potential to capitalize on its reputation and relationships with the national and local governments. Apsil had completed the acquisition of 72% of two companies in Huzhou, China, focusing on waterside developments.

site_title: YuuZoo poses 80 questions to independent reviewer on "a budget and a timeline"
summary: YuuZoo Corporation, under investigation for possible Securities and Futures Act breaches, has responded to regulator Ernst & Young Advisory (EY) with 80 questions and a timeline, after EY sent a report draft with statements considered inaccurate or misleading. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) had restricted the scope of the EY review, and YuuZoo has refused to give EY an unrestricted timeline or budget. The company has also been raided by the Commercial Affairs Department, and its chairman and former head of franchise management were interviewed.

site_title: America's least-favorite candy is suddenly its most sought after
summary: America's oldest continuously operating candy company, New England Confectionery Co. (Necco), is facing potential shutdown, sparking a surge in sales of its unpopular Necco Wafers. Despite being described as "tropical drywall" and "plaster surprise," the wafers are being hoarded by consumers, with sales increasing 63% at one retailer and 50% at another. The sudden interest in the wafers, which have remained unchanged since the Civil War, has left the company unable to reach for comment. The company's potential closure has struck a nostalgic chord with consumers.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.5% higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 16.4 points or 0.5% to 3,466.38, its fourth consecutive day of gains, following China's President Xi Jinping's speech at the Boao Forum, which alleviated fears over a global trade war. The speech calmed markets by addressing US President Donald Trump's concerns without mentioning him. The index's gains come as US stocks closed higher despite news of an FBI raid on Trump's lawyer's office. The rally is seen as a result of increased risk appetite, with 254 counters gaining and 174 losing.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Billionaires' demand for art to jewels in India lures Sotheby's
summary: Sotheby's is entering the Indian art market with its first auction in Mumbai in December, following Christie's decision to discontinue its annual sales in the country. The auction will feature a modern master, Tyeb Mehta's "Durga Mahisasur Mardini", expected to exceed his previous auction record of US$3.6 million. India's growing affluence and increasing number of billionaires, with 15% growth in the number of billionaires last year, are driving the demand for art. The Indian art market, valued at US$223 million, is expected to grow with India's economy projected to outpace China's this year.

site_title: European property latest lure for Japan funds, Tokio Marine says
summary: Japanese institutional investors are increasingly drawn to European real estate funds due to attractive yields and lower hedging costs. Tokio Marine Asset Management Co. reported a "multi-fold" increase in inflows to its overseas real estate equity funds, totaling around $1.9 billion at the end of March. This trend is driven by a desire to take risks on real estate but not currency, and a wariness about the U.S. property market peaking out, with demand now neck-and-neck with Europe. Lower hedging costs for the euro make European assets more appealing.

site_title: Australian linked to fake 'Black Lives Matter' Facebook page
summary: A high-level Australian union official was suspended amid claims he was involved in a fake "Black Lives Matter" Facebook page that raised over $100,000 in donations. The page, with almost 700,000 followers, was allegedly linked to Australian bank accounts and was discovered by CNN. The union, National Union of Workers, launched an investigation and suspended two officials pending the outcome. The incident raises questions about Facebook's integrity and content hosting, following the platform's recent data protection issues.

site_title: Singapore again best in Asia-Pacific in attracting talent, 2nd globally: Insead
summary: Singapore has been ranked as the top country in attracting and developing talent in the Asia-Pacific region for the fifth consecutive year, according to the Global Talent Competitiveness Index 2018 by Insead. Globally, Singapore ranks second, behind only Switzerland. The study highlights Singapore's strong commitment to diversity as a key factor in its success, with efforts to stimulate and support diversity dating back to the nation's multicultural and multiethnic roots. However, the country still needs to improve in areas such as access to growth opportunities and social protection for labor.

site_title: BMW, Toyota get reprieve in crosshairs of US-China trade spat
