summary: BMW and Toyota received a reprieve from the US-China trade spat after Chinese President Xi Jinping pledged to significantly lower car import tariffs and loosen foreign ownership limits. The move is seen as a positive step for global carmakers, with shares of local Chinese carmakers slumping due to the potential loss of competitiveness. Xi reiterated plans to roll out the policies as soon as possible, aiming to boost imports and support the world's biggest auto market.

images.alt_text: Global carmakers from BMW AG to Toyota Motor Corp got some good news from China after President Xi Jinping reiterated a pledge to reduce import tariffs on vehicles this year, heeding decades-long pleas from companies seeking better access to the world's biggest auto market.

site_title: Robots are now everywhere, except in the productivity statistics
summary: Economist Roger Josefsson finds a paradox in the increasing use of robots and artificial intelligence, despite stagnant productivity growth over the past 10-15 years. Despite investments in technologies and personnel, labour productivity and total factor productivity have not grown significantly. However, sectors such as wholesale, retail trade, and recreational services show promising total factor productivity growth, suggesting that these technologies can still have a positive impact, but evidence is needed to support the claims of a productivity boost.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,459.62, up 0.3% on the day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Tuesday with the Straits Times Index rising 0.28% to 3,459.62, driven by gains in United Overseas Bank, DBS Group Holdings, and OCBC Bank. The index saw 167 stocks gain and 172 decline, with 867.6 million shares worth S$574.7 million traded. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and amid global market positivity despite US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Co-living startup Hmlet to launch second co-living building near Newton
summary: Hmlet, a co-living startup, is launching its second fully co-living building in Singapore at 6 Sarkies Road in the Newton neighborhood. The 30,000 square foot building will offer living space for up to 80 members, with monthly rental rates starting at S$1,300 for common rooms and up to S$2,500 for master rooms with rooftop access. This is Hmlet's second building in Singapore, following its inaugural project in Joo Chiat. The company aims to expand its portfolio in Hong Kong and Indonesia, and currently has a capacity of 300 members.

site_title: Jingle bells: Japan's unusual station music
summary: In Japan, Minoru Mukaiya's compositions, known as "Hassha Merodii" or "train departure melodies", play at busy stations, including Tokyo's Shibuya. These catchy electronic jingles, often broadcast for departures, become ingrained in commuters' minds, with many not realizing they are composed by a renowned musician. With millions listening daily, Mukaiya's work has a profound impact on Japan's daily commute, yet his music remains largely anonymous.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won recoup losses as Xi's speech eases trade jitters
summary: South Korean stocks and the won recouped losses after Chinese President Xi Jinping's speech eased market worries over an escalating US-China trade dispute. Xi promised to open China's economy further, lower import tariffs, and widen market access for foreign investors, signaling possible room for a compromise. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed up 0.3% at 2,450.74 points, while the won rose 0.1% to 1,066.4 against the dollar.

site_title: China's Xi urges Taiwan business community to shun independence
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping urged Taiwan's business community to reject independence and promote peace with the mainland, citing the "1992 consensus" that both sides are part of "one China". This comes amid tensions between Beijing and self-ruled Taiwan, which has been frosty since the 2016 election of the independence-leaning Diplomatic Progressive Party. Xi views Taiwan as a breakaway province and has warned of "punishment of history" for any attempts at separatism, amid increased US overtures towards strengthening ties with the island.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks gain on Xi's pledge to open Chinese economy
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.54% on Tuesday as Chinese President Xi Jinping pledged to open China's economy further, easing fears of a trade war between the US and China. The Nikkei 225 index rose 116.06 points to close at 21,794.32, while the Topix index rose 6.06 points to 1,731.94. The move boosted investor confidence and led to a rally in Asian markets.

site_title: ECB says don't worry as Euro area hits economic soft patch
summary: The European Central Bank expressed cautious confidence in the euro-area economy despite reports of a weak start to the year. President Mario Draghi stated that the region's economic upturn will remain strong in 2018, while chief economist Peter Praet maintained the ECB's economic outlook. The comments come ahead of the Governing Council meeting to discuss ending the bond-buying program, with officials emphasizing the need for a slow and gradual approach due to low inflation and a global trade threat.

site_title: Australia shares end at over 2-week high on Xi's speech, resources firms; NZ up
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.8% to 5,857, driven by higher metal prices and comments from China's President Xi Jinping, seen as calming trade tensions with the US. Materials stocks gained after Shanghai aluminium prices touched their highest in a month, while global miners BHP and Rio Tinto rose. The Australia dollar also advanced. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.2%.

site_title: S Korean pension fund stops trading with Samsung Securities after fat finger error
summary: South Korea's National Pension Service has stopped trading with Samsung Securities after a fat finger error resulted in the accidental issuance of 2.8 billion shares to employees, worth around $100 billion. The mistake occurred when Samsung Securities was supposed to pay dividends, and authorities have launched an investigation. The incident has led to a 10% decline in Samsung Securities' stock value, wiping about $330 million from its market value. The pension fund had invested $167 billion in the local stock market, and the incident has raised concerns over trading stability.

site_title: Luye Medical Group takes majority stake in Novena Heart Centre
summary: Luye Medical Group has completed a majority equity investment in Novena Heart Centre (NHC) in Singapore for an undisclosed amount. The acquisition aims to cater to the rising demand for cardiovascular treatment, as cardiovascular diseases continue to rise globally. Luye Medical plans to expand NHC's cardiology practice into China in the mid-term and set up more clinics in major private hospitals in Singapore. The acquisition strengthens Luye Medical's presence in Singapore and aligns with its strategy to focus on high-growth medical specialties and integrated services.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines launches widebody tender process, could oust Boeing 787 deal: source
summary: Malaysia Airlines has launched a tender process for 20-30 widebody jets, potentially replacing a deal with Boeing Co agreed upon by the country's former prime minister last year. The airline had agreed to buy eight 787 jets valued at $2.25 billion but has also considered Airbus A330neo and A350 models. The move may supersede the Boeing deal, as the airline already operates an all-Airbus fleet. A Malaysia Airlines spokeswoman declined to comment on whether the Boeing deal would be firmified.

site_title: Yotel partners US innovation platform Plug and Play to groom hospitality startups
summary: Yotel, a digital-first hospitality group, has partnered with Silicon Valley's innovation platform Plug and Play to groom hospitality startups that can disrupt the travel and hospitality space. The partnership aims to improve operational efficiencies and build brand loyalty. Yotel will match promising startups with its global hotel portfolio, which includes 15 hotels under development. The collaboration will also support Yotel's continued innovation, having pioneered early innovations such as self-service check-in and guest-facing robotics.

site_title: Singtel, VMware to set up 'virtual sandbox' for customers to test products in cloud setting
summary: Singtel and VMware International are setting up a "virtual sandbox" in Singapore to help enterprises test products in a hybrid cloud environment, aiming to lower costs and improve productivity. The Digital Transformation Foundry will enable customers to conduct proof-of-concept experiments, speeding up the digital transformation process. The partnership aims to provide solutions to enterprises across the Asia-Pacific region, promoting digital transformation and hybrid cloud adoption.

site_title: Spanish renewables giant looks to expand anywhere but at home
summary: Acciona SA, a Spanish renewable energy giant, plans to expand globally rather than in its home market due to saturation and economic challenges. The company aims to add 1,000 megawatts of solar and wind power in over 20 countries, including Mexico, Argentina, and Peru. Financing is not seen as a problem, but securing long-term contracts and favorable conditions is key. Acciona is also looking to participate in auctions and explore mergers and acquisitions to fuel its growth, but has no plans to build in Brazil due to its large size and local utilities.

site_title: Alibaba-backed China car startup to raise 17b yuan this year
summary: Xiaopeng Motors, a Chinese car startup backed by Alibaba Group and Foxconn, plans to raise 17 billion yuan (S$3.54 billion) in funds this year to take on rivals in the electric vehicle market. The company aims to start pre-sales of its first model, the G3 crossover, by the end of the month. Xiaopeng is part of a group of startups trying to become China's Tesla and reshape the auto industry as the country promotes new-energy vehicles to reduce its reliance on oil imports.

site_title: US airline industry boasts overall improvements -study
summary: US airlines have improved in several key areas, including bumping fewer passengers and losing less baggage, according to a study released on Monday. The Airline Quality Rating found that US carriers in 2017 recorded improvements in denied boarding, mishandled baggage, and customer complaints, but declined in on-time arrivals. Alaska Airlines topped the list, followed by Delta Air Lines, while Frontier Airlines and Spirit Airlines ranked lowest. Despite negative publicity, airlines are making efforts to improve public perception, with incremental improvements shown in the study's findings.

site_title: Moody's raises ESR-Reit outlook to 'stable', affirms 'Baa3' investment grade rating
summary: Moody's has raised its outlook for ESR-Reit to "stable" from "negative", while affirming its "Baa3" investment grade rating. The revision follows ESR-Reit's equity capital raise in March, which reduced debt levels and alleviated ratings pressure from debt-funded acquisitions. Moody's analyst Rachel Chua noted that the improvement in the trust's credit profile and capital structure alleviates ratings pressure, reflecting the positive impact of the equity raise on the company's credit profile.

site_title: Berlin risks being a capital city without an airport, minister warns
summary: Berlin risks losing its status as a capital city without an airport if its new flight hub, Berlin-Brandenburg Airport, fails to open on schedule. Transport Minister Andreas Scheuer warned that if the airport doesn't open by the end of 2019, Berlin may shut down its old Tegel Airport too soon, resulting in a loss of airport status. This is a reference to Berlin's struggle to deliver major infrastructure projects on time, with the airport saga dating back to 2012.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS upgrades Ezion to 'buy'; raises 12-month target price to S$0.29
summary: DBS Group Research has upgraded its call on offshore and marine group Ezion Holdings to "buy" and increased its 12-month target price to S$0.29 from S$0.13. The upgrade follows an investment by Temasek-linked Pavilion Capital and Ezion's successful refinancing exercise. The analyst cited improving utilisation and day rates of liftboats, which will drive the company's recovery, as key to the upgrade. Ezion is also in talks with strategic partners to offer financial support or liftboat assets, enhancing its growth prospects.

site_title: Malaysia goes to the polls on May 9, nominations on April 28: Election Commission
summary: Malaysia will hold its 14th general election on May 9, with nomination day set for April 28. The 11-day campaign period will start after nomination day, marking the first time polls are held on a weekday in almost 20 years. The election will see the ruling Barisan Nasional (BN) face opposition from Pakatan Harapan (PH) and Parti Islam SeMalaysia (PAS) in multiple three-cornered fights nationwide.

site_title: LVMH sets upbeat tone for luxury as China demand rolls on
summary: LVMH reported double-digit sales growth, beating analyst estimates with a 13% organic increase in first-quarter sales. The luxury company attributes this growth to China's booming middle class, with prosperous consumers driving record sales last year. Despite expected economic growth slowdown in China, LVMH's strong sales demonstrate the demand for luxury products remains high. The company is also investing in e-commerce and digital efforts, with new products and platforms to attract young consumers, such as luxury sneakers and iPhone cases.

site_title: US dollar sags amid lingering trade conflict concerns, Xi speech in focus
summary: The US dollar sagged against peers amid lingering trade conflict concerns, with Chinese President Xi Jinping's remarks at a conference in Boao, China, drawing investor attention. The dollar was 0.05% lower against the yen, its third consecutive loss. US President Trump's promise of quick military action in Syria and ongoing trade tensions with China have fueled geopolitical risks. The euro remained steady, while the Canadian and Australian dollars rose on higher oil prices and interest rate hike expectations, respectively.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars enjoy relief rally on Xi comment
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose on Tuesday after Chinese President Xi Jinping's conciliatory comments on trade, easing concerns about a potential trade war with the US. The Aussie dollar jumped around a third of a cent to $0.7738, its highest in two weeks, while the kiwi dollar rose 0.7% to US$0.7330. Analysts attributed the gains to Xi's pledge to open China's markets and reduce import tariffs, sparking a relief rally in risk assets.

site_title: Alibaba-Backed China car startup to raise US$2.7 billion this year
summary: Xiaopeng Motors, a Chinese electric vehicle startup backed by Alibaba Group and Foxconn, plans to raise 17 billion yuan (S$3.54 billion) in funds this year. The company aims to start pre-sales of its first model, the G3 crossover, by the end of this month. This move is part of the company's efforts to compete in China's massive electric vehicle market, which accounted for over half of worldwide sales last year.

site_title: Australia shares helped higher by resources, financials; NZ also up
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.8% on Tuesday, driven by higher metal prices and President Xi Jinping's comments on opening China's markets to foreign companies. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 46 points to 5,854.7. The move was also influenced by investor sentiment, as investors sought to alleviate concerns over the escalating US-China trade row.

site_title: Canada bets big on canola as China-US spat creates opening
summary: Canada is capitalizing on the US-China trade tensions by increasing canola production, with plantings projected to reach 24 million acres in 2018, a 4.4% increase from last year. The country's top grower, Canada, is the world's largest producer of canola, with China being its No. 1 export destination. Higher prices and demand from countries like Japan and Mexico have also driven interest in the crop. The increased production could boost canola demand and prices, but a trade war could limit gains.

site_title: Xi vows to further open China economy amid US trade spat
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping vowed to further open the country's economy "wider and wider" amid a US trade spat. He announced measures to liberalize automobile investment, reduce tariffs on cars, and protect intellectual property. Xi also pledged to increase imports and not seek a trade surplus. The announcement comes after US President Donald Trump suggested an end to the trade dispute, but Beijing's foreign ministry warned that talks are "impossible" under current conditions.

site_title: En bloc market will cool around mid-2018 amid developer fatigue: RHB
summary: The collective-sale market in Singapore is expected to peak by mid-2018, with developers becoming more selective and paying smaller premiums for smaller sites. The market's overall value is expected to reach S$8.2 billion, but the supply pipeline is being steadily built up, leading to tighter policy measures and a decrease in developer fatigue. This is reflected in the halved premium from 10% to 5% this year, with developers focusing on sites with good location attributes and amenities. The market is expected to support a 5-10% price rise in the near term.

site_title: N Korea foreign minister in rare visit to Moscow amid diplomatic thaw
summary: North Korean Foreign Minister Ri Yong Ho made a rare visit to Moscow, meeting with Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov to discuss ways to resolve tensions on the Korean peninsula. The visit comes ahead of planned nuclear summits between North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and South Korean and US presidents. Moscow supports "direct dialogue" between Pyongyang and the US and "normalization" of relations with Seoul. The visit marks a thaw in diplomatic relations between North Korea and Russia, with the two nations sharing a border and providing food aid to North Korea.

site_title: Visa appoints Kunal Chatterjee country manager for Singapore and Brunei
summary: Visa appoints Kunal Chatterjee as country manager for Singapore and Brunei, replacing Ooi Huey Tyng who left for Grab in 2017. Chatterjee, a 10-year Visa veteran, previously held roles as head of business development and vice-president of global client management. He is expected to drive expansion of electronic payments and support Singapore's Smart Nation objectives, according to Mandy Lamb, group country manager for South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 2.93 points lower, or 0.16%, to 1847.53 on Tuesday. The index saw 32.4 million lots traded worth RM12 million, with 80 gainers for every 63 losers.

site_title: Addvalue Tech inks deal for commercial feasibility study of its satellite communications system
summary: Addvalue Tech has entered into a deal with an unspecified US-based aerospace company to carry out a feasibility study for its inter-satellite data relay system terminal (IDRS) for commercial purposes. This marks the first use of IDRS beyond low-earth orbit satellites, and the study's success could pave the way for new applications and material financial effects on the company's performance in 2019 and beyond. The deal represents the beginning of Addvalue's commercialisation of the IDRS business, with the company pursuing additional prospects and applications to expand business opportunities.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: UK consumer spending cools as snow keeps shoppers at home
summary: UK household spending grew at its slowest pace in almost two years in March, with annual consumption growth slowing to 2% due to the "Beast from the East" snowstorm. Spending in stores fell 1.9% as shoppers opted for online shopping, while a separate survey found modest sales growth despite the cold weather. Consumer confidence remains cautious, but Barclaycard's managing director notes that households have become more confident in their finances.

site_title: Japan, China to hold high-level economic talks on April 16: media
summary: Japan and China are set to hold high-level economic talks on April 16 for the first time in eight years amid growing concern over the escalating US-China trade row. Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso confirmed the meeting, stating he was aware of the proposed talks but had no further details. The talks come as the US and China threaten each other with tariffs over trade and intellectual property policies.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge down at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.08% at the open, following a two-day gain, amid anticipation of a speech by Chinese President Xi Jinping on the trade spat with the US. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 30,205.09, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices rose 0.19% and 0.07% respectively. The dip is seen as a precautionary measure before Xi's speech, which may discuss the trade tensions.

site_title: Fed's Kaplan says trade issues with China won't resolve soon
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas President Robert Kaplan warned that trade issues between the US and China won't be resolved soon, potentially causing damage if prolonged. He expressed concern over the "chilling effect" of rhetoric, citing a lack of action on tariffs. Kaplan still expects the Fed to raise interest rates two more times in 2018, citing a solid year for economic growth, despite a simmering trade dispute. The Fed has penciled in two or three interest-rate increases this year, with officials keeping a watchful eye on the trade spat's impact on the economy.

site_title: FBI raids offices of Trump's personal lawyer
summary: FBI agents raided the offices of Michael Cohen, Donald Trump's personal lawyer, seizing files related to a $130,000 payment made to an adult film actress before the 2016 election. Cohen's attorney said the raid was related to special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into links between Russia and the Trump campaign. Trump called the investigation a "disgrace" and a "witch hunt." The raid is part of Mueller's broader probe into potential collusion between Russia and the Trump campaign.

site_title: Singapore condo, apartment resale prices hit new high with 1.5% monthly rise in March: SRX
summary: Resale prices for condominiums and private apartments in Singapore rose 1.5% in March, hitting a new high, according to SRX Property. This marks a year-on-year price increase of 8.5%. The core central region saw record prices, with a 2.2% monthly gain and an 8% yearly increase. Resale volume also increased by 11.4% to 1,310 units, with prices expected to continue rising in the coming months due to high demand from en-bloc sellers.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow
Resale prices for condominiums and private apartments moved up again, to hit a new high in March 2018, a private real estate portal survey has said.

site_title: Asia: Shares pressured as Wall Street ends off highs, focus on Xi speech
summary: Asian shares declined on Tuesday, pressured by a Wall Street retreat from highs, amid US-China trade tensions and the FBI's raid on President Trump's lawyer. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index fell 0.2%, with South Korea's Kospi and Japan's Nikkei shedding 0.8% and 0.4%, respectively. The pull-back on Wall Street dampened market sentiment, with investors bracing for potential tariffs and escalating trade tensions.

site_title: Russia, US headed for clash at UN over Syria gas attacks probe
summary: The UN Security Council is set to vote on rival US and Russian proposals to investigate chemical weapons attacks in Syria, potentially leading to a clash that could trigger vetoes from both countries. The US proposal, which includes a one-year panel to identify perpetrators, has been rejected by Russia, which claims it would give the Syrian government an upper hand. The US is pushing for a vote amid heightened tensions over possible military action, with President Trump warning of a "big price to pay" if the Syrian government is not held accountable.

site_title: Lithium glut fears tempered by optimism over surging demand
summary: Lithium glut fears are being tempered as surging demand for lithium in electric vehicle batteries is expected to outpace supply. Experts say processing lithium into usable products is the main concern, not a shortage of the metal itself. While there's an oversupply of mined lithium, refined products remain tight, and demand is expected to grow double-digit in the next few years. Companies like Nemaska Lithium and Neo Lithium are optimistic about the market, with some predicting a tight market in the next 4-5 years. This optimism counters warnings of a lithium glut.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Tuesday; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.3% lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index down 10.08 points to 3,439.88, amid trade issues weighing on stock markets in Asia. The Dow Jones rose 0.2% on Wall Street, while regional markets, including Japan, Australia, and South Korea, fell.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble, Kingboard Copper, ASTI, ISEC, Anchor Resources, China Gaoxian
summary: Noble Group's restructuring support agreement has seen over 70% of creditors accede, with 10% showing broad support. Kingboard Copper Foil Holdings' shares rose to a decade high after its controlling shareholder bought 5.58% of the company. ASTI Holdings successfully disposed of its subsidiary for S$90 million, with a success fee of S$17.2 million. ISEC Healthcare is claiming S$159,465.30 from vendors of four clinics. Anchor Resources is partnering with a granite quarry licence holder to tender for Malaysian East Coast Rail Line projects. China Gaoxian Fibre Fabric Holdings believes it can operate as a going concern despite queries over its 2017 full-year results.

site_title: ISEC claiming S$159,465 from vendors of clinics that failed to meet profit targets
summary: ISEC Healthcare is claiming S$159,465.30 from vendors of four clinics that failed to meet profit targets set in 2016. The clinics, acquired for S$13.9 million, were supposed to earn at least 90% of their profit guarantee. Only one of the clinics met this target in 2017, while the other three were affected by lower patient visits. ISEC served notice to the vendors after auditing their profits, resulting in a total shortfall of S$159,465.30.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, Korean won slip; Xi speech awaited
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index declined 0.40% to 2,434.31, while the Korean won slipped against the US dollar. Shares in Samsung C&T Corp and Samsung BioLogics Co Ltd rose 3.6% and 6.8%, respectively, after Samsung C&T announced plans to raise up to 3 trillion won to acquire a 30% stake in Samsung Bioepis Co Ltd. Markets are awaiting Chinese President Xi Jinping's speech at the Boao Forum, which may provide insight into Beijing's response to the US-China trade conflict.

site_title: Anchor Resources, granite quarry lease holder to jointly bid for Malaysia's East Coast Rail Line projects
summary: CATALIST-listed Anchor Resources is teaming up with a granite quarry licence holder to jointly bid for Malaysia's East Coast Rail Line projects. The proposed consortium will supply granite for rail tracks and three train stations, covering 250,000 sq m of granite tiles and 4.3 million tonnes of granite aggregates. The joint venture will obtain necessary approvals and financing, with the East Coast Rail Line estimated to need 250,000 sq m of granite tiles and 4.3 million tonnes of granite aggregates.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower ahead of Xi speech
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on April 10, 2018, ahead of Chinese President Xi Jinping's speech at an Asian forum, amid trade tensions with the US. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.42% and the Topix index down 0.30%. Investors awaited Xi's speech for insights into China's trade policies.

site_title: Facebook's Zuckerberg to Capitol Hill: 'It was my mistake, and I'm sorry'
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg acknowledged the company's mistakes in allowing third-party apps to access user data without permission and in failing to quickly respond to Russian interference in the 2016 US election. Zuckerberg expressed regret for the harm caused, stating it was his mistake and that the company is taking steps to improve its responsibility and protect user data. The testimony comes ahead of two hearings and as Facebook faces investigations and potential legislation over user data and privacy concerns.

site_title: Go your own way: Buckingham leaves Fleetwood Mac, again
summary: Fleetwood Mac has parted ways with guitarist Lindsey Buckingham for the second time, with the band citing internal creative evolution as the reason. Buckingham will not perform on their upcoming summer tour, instead being replaced by Crowded House's Neil Finn and Tom Petty's Mike Campbell. The band's internal tensions, famously documented on the 1977 album "Rumours," have led to several lineup changes over the years. Buckingham initially left the band in 1987 but rejoined briefly in the 1990s before being let go again.

site_title: China blames US for trade frictions, but Trump voices optimism
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed optimism over a potential trade deal with China, despite China blaming the US for escalating tensions. The two countries have been at odds over billions of dollars in threatened tariffs, with China accusing the US of provoking a trade war. Trump vowed to protect US farmers from Chinese retaliation, while Chinese officials said they would not back down from proposed tariffs. The trade dispute has raised concerns about global growth and sparked debate over the "nuclear option" of China selling its US government debt holdings.

site_title: UK consumer spending cools as snow keeps shoppers at home
summary: UK household spending grew at the slowest pace in almost two years in April, slowing to 2% annual consumption growth, according to Barclaycard. Freezing weather kept shoppers at home, with spending in stores falling 1.9%. Despite this, consumer confidence remains high, with a report finding confidence in household finances at its highest level since October. A separate survey by the British Retail Consortium found modest sales growth in March, despite the extreme cold.

site_title: Temasek stake values 'Salt Bae' Turkish restaurant owner at US$1.2b
summary: Singapore's Temasek and Britain's Metric Capital have bought a 17% stake in Nusr-Et steakhouse owner D.ream for US$200 million, valuing the Turkish firm at US$1.2 billion. Nusr-Et gained international recognition through its owner, Nusret Gokce, also known as "Salt Bae," who became a social media sensation in 2017. The deal marks a significant investment in the firm, which has over 170 locations in 12 countries.

site_title: What the pho? Vietnam streetfood cocktails make a splash
summary: Vietnamese bartender Pham Tien Tiep has created a pho-inspired cocktail that combines the aromatics of cinnamon, star anise, cardamom, and coriander with gin and triple sec, offering a luxury and elegant alternative to traditional Vietnamese beer. The cocktail, served at his bar Ne in Hanoi, has gained popularity and inspired copycat versions across Vietnam. Its success has contributed to the growth of Vietnam's upscale cocktail scene, with other creative takes on Vietnamese cuisine appearing on menus worldwide.

site_title: Chinese tycoons bet big on Hainan's gaming prospect
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping is set to visit Hainan Island, where tycoons like Zeng Xianyun hope for new tax concessions to boost tourism. The island has struggled to live up to its economic potential, with gaming remaining banned across mainland China. Investors like MGM Resorts International have spent heavily on developments, with some predicting that Hainan could become a hub for Chinese gamblers. Xi's visit may signal a shift towards regulated casinos, which could benefit the island's economy and reduce capital outflows to foreign operators.

site_title: Singapore uncertainty index climbs as trade war clouds outlook
summary: Singapore's Economic Policy Uncertainty Index rose to a five-month high in March, reaching 155, driven by US-China trade tensions. The index, which tracks newspaper articles in Singapore's major trading partners, is trade-weighted and reflects the country's reliance on trade. Economist Steven Davis notes that while the index is at a relatively low level, concerns about US trade policy and a major trade war between the US and China are cutting in the opposite direction, potentially impacting investment, employment, and growth.

site_title: Casa Meyfort in Meyer Road relaunches en bloc tender, asking S$340m
summary: The owners of Casa Meyfort condominium in Singapore are relaunching a collective sale tender with a reserve price of S$340 million, the same as the previous failed bid in December 2017. The site, a freehold development near East Coast Park, comprises 76 apartments on an 85,249 square foot site. The relaunched tender will close on May 21, with the applicable development charge increased to S$57.2 million. The owners believe the site offers a great opportunity, citing a gross plot ratio of 2.8 times under the Urban Redevelopment Authority's Master Plan 2014.

site_title: GOP tax cuts to balloon US deficit, debt: Congressional Budget Office
summary: The US budget deficit is expected to balloon, growing 20% this year and reaching $1 trillion by 2020, largely due to the December tax cuts. The Congressional Budget Office predicts a 4.2% deficit in 2018 and 5% by 2022. GDP growth is forecast to rise to 3.3% in 2018 and 2.4% in 2019, but economists say this is unrealistic. The US will need to continue borrowing to make up for lower tax revenues, leading to a 96% of GDP debt by 2028, the largest since 1946.

site_title: ASTI: S$17.2m was 'success fee' paid to financial adviser for disposal of semiconductor unit
summary: ASTI Holdings reported that S$17.2 million was a 'success fee' paid to financial adviser VSA Capital Shanghai for the disposal of its semiconductor unit. The deal was for a cash consideration of S$90 million, leaving net proceeds of about S$72.8 million. The success fee was to motivate the adviser to get the best deal for the company, and ASTI believes it is justifiable considering the lower offers received for the STI Group.

site_title: Forget cars, Mitsubishi Hitachi sees autonomous power plants
summary: Mitsubishi Hitachi Power Systems Ltd. is developing an autonomous power plant in Japan that will be run by artificial intelligence. The facility, scheduled for completion by 2020, will use hydrogen generated from wind or solar power to meet increasing demand. The plant's AI system will optimize power distribution and improve flexibility in the power grid. This innovation is seen as a precursor to autonomous cars, with Mitsubishi Hitachi Power Systems CEO Paul Browning stating that AI will make power systems "more flexible and better coordinated."

site_title: Islamic scholars debate if cryptos meet sharia rules
summary: Islamic scholars are debating whether cryptocurrencies, such as Bitcoin, meet Sharia rules. The discussion at the AAOIFI conference in Bahrain aims to determine if these financial tools are sharia-compliant, which could influence investment decisions by Islamic financial firms. Scholars are scrutinizing whether cryptocurrencies fall under the "ribawi" category, which requires equal exchange and immediate possession, to avoid the prohibition of riba (usury) in Islam. The deliberations may clarify what types of cryptocurrencies are acceptable and shape future product development in the industry.

site_title: Gold prices rise as US dollar wilts, awaits US data
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,336.80 per ounce as the US dollar declined, but remained cautious due to the potential escalation of the China-US trade dispute and upcoming US data. The US dollar index slipped, and global equities rose as the US government downplayed fears of a trade war with China. Gold futures settled up 0.3% at $1,340.10 per ounce, while other precious metals like silver, platinum, and palladium also gained.

site_title: Trendlines says its most valuable portfolio company is Stimatix
summary: Trendlines Group, an Israel and Singapore-based incubator, has identified Stimatix GI as its most valuable portfolio company. Stimatix, a medical device company, sold its assets to B Braun subsidiary in November 2014 for a valuation of US$42.6 million. Trendlines retains a 28.2% stake in Stimatix, which is expected to receive royalty payments from B Braun. The sale marked a significant achievement for Trendlines, with an estimated return of 79.1 times and an internal rate of return of 80%.

site_title: Tax harmonisation in Asean: Singapore should take the lead
summary: Singapore is urged to lead in tax harmonization efforts within the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) to reduce tax compliance costs and complexities. A middle-ground approach, focusing on withholding tax rates and common standards for tax administration, could encourage foreign investment. Harmonization of income tax policies, while challenging, could promote a single large growth market in Asean. Singapore's pro-business stance and quality reputation make it an ideal candidate to take the lead in this initiative.

site_title: Vietnam's street-food cocktails making a splash
summary: Vietnamese street-food flavors are gaining popularity in high-end cocktails, with Hanoi bartender Pham Tien Tiep's pho-inspired cocktail being a leading example. Tiep's unique blend of aromatics and spirits has sparked interest in upscale bars across Vietnam, with copycat cocktails appearing on menus nationwide. This trend is part of a broader global movement of street-food flavors being incorporated into classic cocktails and dishes, with Tiep promising to continue pushing boundaries in the beverage world.

images.alt_text: Pham Tien Tiep, owner of Ne bar in Hanoi, preparing a "pho cocktail". The hipster bar is creating a stir with its signature tipple: the pho cocktail, inspired by the national dish of beef noodles in fish sauce broth.

site_title: World's hottest chilli pepper gives man 'thunderclap' headaches
summary: An American man, 34, experienced excruciating "thunderclap" headaches after eating the world's hottest pepper, the Carolina Reaper, at a 2016 hot pepper contest. He was diagnosed with reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome, a temporary brain condition caused by narrowing of blood vessels, which cleared up on its own. The case highlights the potential dangers of consuming extremely spicy foods and doctors warn the public to be cautious when eating chilli peppers and seek medical attention immediately if symptoms occur.

site_title: Consumer groups seek probe into YouTube over ads for kids
summary: Consumer groups have filed a complaint with the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) alleging that YouTube allows advertising to be targeted at children, potentially violating US law. The groups claim that YouTube, despite claiming to be only for users 13 and up, generates significant profits from kid-targeted ads and collects personal information from minors without their parents' consent. The complaint cites popular child-oriented channels and premium ad placements on the site. Google has responded by launching the YouTube Kids app, but critics argue that this does not address the issue of targeted ads to minors.

site_title: India makes headway in fending off predatory biopiracy firms
summary: India takes legal action against US companies accused of patenting turmeric-based products without permission, as part of efforts to combat biopiracy. The Indian company Arjuna Natural Extracts Ltd. claims US firms have infringed on its patents, threatening to take action to protect its intellectual property rights. This case is part of a larger issue of biopiracy, where foreign companies plunder natural resources from developing countries without paying royalties. India has established the Traditional Knowledge Digital Library to document and protect its traditional knowledge, and has successfully overturned patents on traditional remedies in the past, including a 1997 case that revoked a US patent on powdered turmeric for healing wounds.

site_title: Vietnam stocks may be in for some inclement weather
summary: Vietnam's stock market is expected to face challenges as it continues its strong performance, with the Vietnam Stock Index up 22% and foreign investors purchasing over $440 million in shares since January. The country's economy expanded 7.4% in the first quarter, and the government aims to achieve double-digit export growth this year. However, speculators are concerned about the market's high valuation, with the MSCI Vietnam Index trading at 30.5 times 12-month trailing earnings. The market's correlation with US stocks has also increased, raising concerns about its resilience to global economic events.

site_title: Indonesia to regulate non-subsidised fuel prices to control inflation
summary: Indonesia plans to regulate non-subsidized fuel prices to control inflation, following President Joko Widodo's earlier efforts to cut government fuel spending. The government will have the right to decide whether retailers can change fuel prices, and any increases will require prior approval. The move aims to boost people's purchasing power and address household consumption growth below 5% per year. The regulation is part of efforts to control inflation and meet the president's goal of boosting private consumption.

site_title: US: Stocks weather late-breaking storm, end higher
summary: US stocks rose on Monday despite a late-breaking news report that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had raided the offices of President Donald Trump's personal lawyer, Michael Cohen. The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished up 0.2%, while the S&P 500 gained 0.3% and the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.5%. The news cut into gains, but analysts attributed the market's resilience to a calm session and strong earnings season expectations. Several stocks, including Merck and AveXis, surged on positive news, while Monsanto jumped 6.2% after the US Justice Department approved its acquisition by Bayer.

site_title: Apple says all its facilities now powered by clean energy
summary: Apple has achieved its goal of powering all its facilities with renewable energy, including data centers, offices, and retail stores in 43 countries. Nine suppliers have also committed to running their operations on renewable energy, bringing the total to 23. This milestone is driven by declining costs of solar and wind energy, making it possible for companies to buy clean power at competitive prices. Apple's vice president for environment, policy and social initiatives, Lisa Jackson, said the company is not spending more than it would have on renewable energy, and suppliers who pledge to use more clean energy will have a competitive advantage for Apple's business.

site_title: Oil gains more than 2% as stock market rebounds
summary: Oil prices rose more than 2% on Monday, driven by a rebound in the stock market and easing concerns over a US-China trade war. Brent crude futures gained $1.54 to settle at $68.65 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose $1.36 to settle at $63.42. The US stock market broadly rose over 1% after a softer stance by US policymakers on China trade tariffs. Analysts attributed the price increase to concerns over global instability, particularly in Syria, and the weakening dollar.

site_title: China Gaoxian able to operate as going concern, says board of directors
summary: China Gaoxian Fibre Fabric Holdings' board of directors has stated that the company can operate as a going concern, citing operating cash flows from its Huaxiang plant, surplus cash from a tie-up, and financial support from a shareholder. These sources will help repay or refinance short-term loans and support the company's financial stability. The decision comes in response to queries from the bourse operator regarding the company's full-year results for 2017.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Eurozone govt bond yields down on economic worries
summary: Eurozone government bond yields declined on concerns over European and global economic growth, with German 10-year bond yields hovering around 0.5%. Investors sought safe-haven assets amid tensions between the US and China, threatening a potential trade war. Analysts expect yields to remain low due to a large week of European sovereign debt redemptions, with Commerzbank estimating around 60 billion euros in maturing bonds.

site_title: Pakistan's economy can thrive even in lean times but it needs political will and marketing efforts
summary: Pakistan's economy has significant growth potential, projected to become the 16th largest economy by 2050 with a GDP of $4.2 trillion, surpassing Italy and Canada. However, realization of this growth requires structural reforms, macroeconomic stability, and effective institutions. The country's large population, with half under 25, also presents opportunities. Foreign investments are on the rise, with the equity market expected to rally before the general elections, which could boost the domestic stock market and increase consumption. A sustained and aggressive marketing effort is necessary to attract foreign inflows.

site_title: Oil trades below US$63 as investors size up US-China trade battle
summary: Oil prices traded below US$63 a barrel amid rising tensions between the US and China, threatening growth that drives energy demand. Investors evaluated the potential impact of a trade war, with US President Trump predicting China would be the first to buckle. Oil futures dropped 4.4% last week, with money managers slashing bets on rising prices and short-selling surging. Despite a slight increase in WTI prices, the market remains bearish, with hedge funds cutting their bullish bets by 9.4% in the week ended April 3.

site_title: Cheng family's LTC buyout bid declared unconditional
summary: The controlling Cheng family's buyout offer for mainboard-listed LTC Corporation has been declared unconditional after the acceptance threshold was lowered from 90% to 50%. As of Monday, 84.47% of shares have been validly tendered, with the offeror and its concert parties holding 50.01% of the company's shares. The offer, set at S$0.925 per share, represents a 44.5% premium over the previous close. The offer must remain open for acceptance for at least 14 days, and shareholders have eight days to withdraw their acceptances after receiving the reduced acceptance condition notification.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Vanadium batteries need Elon Musk moment to kick-start market
summary: Vanadium batteries need a significant boost, likened to Elon Musk's impact on the lithium-ion market, to gain traction. A major player is needed to recognize vanadium-flow batteries' advantages, such as longer lifespan and recyclability. Australian Vanadium Ltd aims to produce 5,000-6,000 metric tons of vanadium pentoxide, accounting for 5-6% of global market share. The company expects a pre-feasibility study to be completed by mid-2018, with production starting in early 2021. A lack of recognition and high costs have hindered vanadium's adoption, making a "Tesla moment" necessary for the metal to gain prominence.

site_title: Noble restructuring in doubt as founder Elman said to push for new deal
summary: Richard Elman, founder of Noble Group Ltd, is pushing creditors for a new restructuring deal, casting doubt on the company's survival. Elman wants a 15-20% stake in Noble after the restructuring, up from 10%, and a seat on the board. The company needs at least half of shareholders to vote in favor of the $3.5 billion debt-for-equity plan, which would wipe out existing equity investors. If rejected, Noble plans to file for insolvency in London, and Elman's efforts may reopen discussions with senior creditors.

site_title: STI rises as traders keep eye on trade war
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 7.5 points or 0.2% to 3,449.96, mirroring gains in other regional indices. The gains followed a 2% drop in US stocks last Friday due to concerns over the US-China trade war. Traders will continue to monitor the situation, with potential escalation expected to impact global equities. Despite this, Citi Research expects an 8% rise in global equities by the end of the year, citing synchronised global growth and US tax cuts.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: ComfortDelGro expands into patient transport in Australia with A$30m buy
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singaporean land transport company, has acquired National Patient Transport in Australia for A$30 million, expanding its services into non-emergency patient transport. The deal, valued at 4.6 times earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization, will be paid from internal resources. Analysts see the acquisition as a small but accretive move, with some speculating that ComfortDelGro's appetite for larger deals may be affected by the pending merger between Uber and Grab.

site_title: Chinese AI startup snags Alibaba, Temasek funding
summary: Chinese AI startup SenseTime has raised US$600 million from Alibaba Group Holding and other investors, valuing the company at over US$3 billion. The funding will support investments in autonomous driving, augmented reality, and expanding its computing power. SenseTime's technology is used in over 100 million mobile devices and is a key contributor to China's surveillance system. The company plans to build at least five supercomputers to drive its services, including a platform called Viper that processes thousands of live camera feeds.

images.alt_text: SenseTime's valuation of US$3 billion makes it the world's most valuable AI startup. The company is developing a service to parse data from thousands of live camera feeds for use in mass surveillance.

site_title: Competition watchdog to conduct studies to launch protection role
summary: Singapore's Competition and Consumer Commission (CCCS) launched its new consumer protection role with two market studies, focusing on online travel booking and data portability. The studies aim to examine commercial arrangements and competition issues, as well as consumer protection and data protection concerns. The CCCS will investigate and enforce rules related to unfair trade practices, gather evidence, and file injunction applications against non-compliant businesses. The new role aims to enhance consumer protection and foster competition in the market.

site_title: Infrastructure finance and the new economy: A case for tokenising
summary: A significant funding gap exists in the infrastructure space, with 90% of financing coming from the public sector. To address this, private sector participation is prescribed, but requires a supportive ecosystem. Blockchain technology, specifically asset tokenisation, can help develop this ecosystem by providing transparency, security, and immutability. By putting securities onto the blockchain, they become "tokens" backed by the underlying infrastructure assets, reducing the need for intermediaries and increasing efficiency. This approach can help bridge the funding gap and increase private sector investment in infrastructure projects.

site_title: China should invest in assets, not US govt debt: PBOC adviser
summary: China's central bank adviser, Fan Gang, recommends the country invest its large capital reserves in real assets rather than US government debt, citing a high wealth-to-income ratio. China's debt load is a concern, but Fan believes the country's ample savings and mostly domestic debt will prevent a financial crisis. China's foreign exchange reserves, the world's largest, rose to $3.143 trillion in March, and the country holds around $1.17 trillion of Treasuries. Fan also warned of rising trade tensions with the US, which may lead to measures such as a trade war or blocking Chinese investment.

site_title: Yanlord joins consortium to buy 2 Tianjin land parcels
summary: Yanlord Land Group has acquired stakes in two property development firms securing development rights to two land parcels in Tianjin, China. Through its subsidiary Nanjing Renyuan Investment Co Ltd, Yanlord bought a 19.8% stake in Tianjin Hefa Property Development Co Ltd and a 16.5% stake in Tianjin Lianzhan Property Development Co Ltd. The land parcels are valued at 4.8 billion yuan and 2.95 billion yuan, respectively, and are slated for mixed development with access to schools, hospitals, and shopping malls.

site_title: Runaway train in India rolls for 12 km without engine
summary: A runaway train in India's Odisha state rolled for 12 km without an engine after 22 train coaches carrying 1,000 passengers detached from the engine. The incident occurred during a journey from Gujarat, and authorities believe brakes were incorrectly used or overlooked. Seven railway employees have been suspended, and an investigation is underway. Fortunately, none of the passengers were injured. The incident has raised concerns about safety and the possibility of "more heads rolling" within the railway ministry.

site_title: Ascott signs deals with China, Japan, Thailand developers
summary: Ascott Limited, the serviced residence unit of CapitaLand, has signed deals with developers in China, Japan, and Thailand to manage apartments and future projects. In China, Ascott will launch two serviced residences with 350 units, while in Japan, it is exploring opportunities with NTT Urban Development Corporation. In Thailand, Ascott partnered Ananda Development to manage properties in Bangkok. The partnerships aim to increase Ascott's global portfolio to 160,000 units by 2023 and create cross-marketing opportunities for its properties.

images.alt_text: Ascott Songshan Lake Dongguan and Citadines Songshan Lake Dongguan. These two properties mark Ascott's entry into Dongguan, China.

site_title: 'Heterogeneous' Bordeaux 2017 restores confidence
summary: The 2017 Bordeaux vintage is described as "heterogeneous" due to spring frosts and varying growing conditions. Despite initial pressure on demand, the market has seen a price rally over the past two years, with the Fine Wine 1000 Index climbing 11%. This has helped restore buyer confidence, particularly after the mediocre vintages of 2011-2013. The report from Liv-ex notes a decline in Bordeaux's market share and top estates holding back sales, potentially to maintain price levels.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Noble Group, a distressed commodities firm, announced that over 70% of its creditors have agreed to a restructuring support deal, with 10% more creditors showing broad support. Meanwhile, Alliance Mineral Assets completed a share placement ahead of a merger with Tawana Resources, while Advanced Systems Automation acquired several semiconductor companies for S$10 million. Keppel Corporation entered a cooperation agreement with KrisEnergy, and Mirach Energy plans to diversify into selling agricultural crops. These developments come amidst a broader market trend of companies seeking restructuring and diversification.

site_title: Sustainability reporting: listed firms report mixed experiences
summary: Singapore-listed companies have started filing sustainability reports under the new comply-or-explain guidelines, but many face challenges due to unfamiliarity and high costs involved. Companies like ComfortDelGro and Roxy-Pacific Holdings had to allocate significant resources and staff time to compile and report on various aspects of their operations, including environmental impact, staff welfare, and electricity use. While some companies, such as OCBC Bank, found it easier to comply, others, like small firms, expressed concerns over the high costs and need for clearer reporting frameworks. The guidelines aim to increase transparency and accountability, but more standardization is needed to make reporting easier for companies.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: SBF team in Chongqing for Chan Chun Sing's official visit
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) led a 35-person business delegation to Chongqing, China, from April 9-13, 2018, in conjunction with Minister Chan Chun Sing's official visit. The delegation focused on the Chongqing Connectivity Initiative (CCI), a government-to-government project aiming to drive growth in China's western region through improved transport and services links. The mission aimed to facilitate business networking, collaboration opportunities, and trade and investment promotion.

site_title: Sinanju orders first dual-fuel LNG-powered bunker tanker
summary: Singapore's Maritime and Port Authority (MPA) has supported the construction of the country's first dual-fuel LNG-powered bunker tanker, ordered by licensed marine fuel supplier Sinanju Tankers Holdings. The vessel, valued at over $10 million, is scheduled for delivery in the second half of 2020 and will be built in Singapore. The MPA has provided up to $2 million in co-funding for the project, as part of its efforts to boost the use of liquefied natural gas (LNG) as a marine fuel and reduce emissions.

site_title: Lego fund shopping for more London property
summary: The Kirkbi fund, managing the wealth of the Lego billionaires, is expanding its real estate portfolio despite uncertainty surrounding the UK's departure from the EU. The fund has bought a London office property in the King's Cross district, its third investment in the British capital, and plans to invest in other areas not linked to the financial sector. The fund's goal is to grow its real estate portfolio 14% this year, with a focus on developing properties and investing in areas such as technology, media, and telecom companies.

site_title: Singapore continues to support China's opening up: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed confidence that China will continue to uphold the multilateral trading system and contribute to regional and global development. During a meeting with Chinese Vice-President Wang Qishan, Lee emphasized the importance of cooperation between the two countries, citing successful government-to-government projects and potential for the Belt and Road Initiative. This comes as protectionist sentiment rises in the US, with the US threatening to impose tariffs on Chinese imports, sparking concerns of a trade war.

site_title: SIA named world's best airline by TripAdvisor reviewers
summary: Singapore Airlines has been named the world's best airline by TripAdvisor reviewers, based on reviews of service, quality, and value. The airline received awards for Best Airline in Asia, Best International First Class, Best Economy Class, Travellers' Choice Business Class, and Travellers' Choice Premium Economy Class. CEO Goh Choon Phong attributed the award to the hard work and dedication of the airline's staff worldwide. This recognition validates Singapore Airlines' commitment to remaining competitive globally.

site_title: Vietnam stocks may be in for some inclement weather
summary: Vietnam's stock market is poised for potential volatility, despite its strong performance in 2017, with a 52% return. The country's economy expanded by 7.4% in the first quarter, and the government aims for double-digit export growth. Foreigners have invested over $440 million in local shares, and the government plans to sell more shares this year. However, speculators are concerned about the high valuation of stocks, with the MSCI Vietnam Index trading at 30.5 times 12-month trailing earnings. The market's correlation with US stocks has also increased, raising concerns about potential risks.

site_title: Zuckerberg to face angry lawmakers as Facebook firestorm rages
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg will face lawmakers on Tuesday in a Senate panel and Wednesday in the House of Representatives amid a data privacy scandal. The firestorm pressures new regulations on social media platforms. Zuckerberg, 33, will address concerns over Facebook's handling of user data, following a report by Cambridge Analytica. Pressure mounts for new regulations as lawmakers scrutinize Facebook's practices and seek to protect users' information.

site_title: Goldman leads banks in setting up periodic auction service
summary: Goldman Sachs has launched a periodic auction service, allowing fund managers to buy and sell shares without revealing their trades to the market. This move comes as the bank seeks to win the business of investors in the era of MiFID II price transparency. The service, which began matching trades on March 21, enables investors to keep their trades hidden from the rest of the market, providing an advantage in price discovery. Goldman's move is seen as a defensive play to benefit from volatility in the market.

site_title: Mahathir to review China ventures if he wins election
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has vowed to review Chinese investments in the country if he wins the upcoming election, citing concerns over economic inequality and sovereignty. Mahathir criticized plans by Country Garden to invest US$100 billion in Johor state, stating that the investment brings in foreigners without benefiting locals. He referenced Sri Lanka's experience with China's debt relief and infrastructure investments, which led to the loss of land. Mahathir's comments reflect broader concerns about Chinese investment across Asia, with many countries wary of becoming too dependent on China.

site_title: UK watchdog to publish review of cryptocurrencies
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) plans to publish a review of cryptocurrencies in the third quarter of 2018, following its warning to the sector. Regulators have cautioned retail investors about the risks of investing in cryptocurrencies, which can result in significant losses. The FCA will work with the Bank of England and Treasury to develop policy thinking on cryptocurrencies, but resources will be stretched due to Brexit implications. The review aims to address concerns about the sector's potential for harm and will be published later this year.

site_title: MOM's Kok Ping Soon to be new GovTech CEO from May 1
summary: Kok Ping Soon, the deputy secretary of development at the Ministry of Manpower, will become the new CEO of GovTech on May 1. He will replace Jacqueline Poh, who has held the position since 2017. This change is part of a strategic shift in GovTech's leadership.

summary:

US stocks opened lower due to President Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Companies reported mixed earnings, with Creative Technology warning of potential revenue shortfall and CGSI downgrading Grab to 'hold'. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case, and Heathrow Airport planned to increase fees for its £10b upgrade. Singapore stocks continued a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Cost of French rail strike escalates as walkout enters second week
summary: France's state-owned SNCF railway operator is facing a second week of rail strikes, which may have already cost the company 100 million euros. The strikes, led by the CGT labor union, are over the government's planned bill to reform the national railway, including ending job security and special pensions for workers. The standoff is expected to continue, with labor groups planning two-day stoppages every five days until at least June, affecting about a quarter of cross-Channel trains and 80% of high-speed links.

site_title: Will the US be able to avert another cyclical crisis?
summary: The US has not learned from its past economic crises, with policymakers failing to adequately respond to the 2007-2008 financial crash. Unlike the Great Depression, the Great Recession's impact on output and employment was limited, but the long-term response was inadequate, with per capita national income still 5% below its peak in 2006. Historians will likely conclude that the US response was third-rate or worse, unlike the New Deal-era policies that laid the groundwork for the post-war boom. The current political environment suggests that policymakers may not have the monetary and fiscal space to address future crises, increasing the risk of another cyclical crisis.

site_title: Hong Kong's most painful short keeps on breaking record highs
summary: Hong Kong's Kingdee International Software Group Co shares surged 13% on Monday, reaching a record high, despite a four-year high in short interest. The stock's cloud strategy has drawn bullish bets, and further gains could lead to its inclusion in MSCI's benchmark indexes. Analysts predict a sharp, brief rise in the stock, citing its new cloud product launch and potential monetization in 2019.

site_title: Kim's visit ends Chinese isolation but questions remain
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un's visit to Beijing ended China's isolation on the Korean peninsula, but Beijing remains cautious in its relationship with Pyongyang. The visit has been welcomed by Washington and Seoul, but it raises concerns that China may relax UN sanctions against North Korea. China's primary economic partner, North Korea, may benefit from the rapprochement, while Beijing distances itself from Pyongyang's attempts to use Hong Kong to circumvent economic sanctions. The international community must navigate this delicate balance to address the North Korean nuclear problem.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Moya Holdings Asia's founding shareholder Moya Holding sold out its stake, indicating confidence in the company's growth prospects. The management is in talks to extend the concession for its Aquatico assets, which could benefit the company and lead to a re-rating of the stock. With over $100 million in cash, Moya may acquire and consolidate Indonesian private water treatment players, boosting earnings growth. Y Ventures Group expects a promising year with initiatives bearing fruit and a potential partnership with SingPost.

site_title: Tax harmonisation in Asean: S'pore should take the lead
summary: Singapore should take the lead in promoting tax harmonization among Asean member states to reduce tax compliance costs and complexities, as proposed in the AEC Blueprint 2025. Harmonization of withholding tax rates and implementation of common standards for tax administration could encourage foreign investment. However, a "middle-ground" approach is recommended, focusing on simplification of tax rules and elimination of unintended tax obstacles rather than a strong form of harmonization. Singapore's pro-business stance and experience in tax administration make it an ideal candidate to lead the effort, with other countries following suit.

site_title: New Deutsche Bank chief's mission looks like more Deutsche, less bank
summary: Deutsche Bank's new CEO, Christian Sewing, is a company lifer with a "safety-first" approach, indicating a reduction in the bank's global footprint. A smaller US presence is also likely, following Sewing's track record of deep job cuts. Sewing's background is in consumer banking, differing from previous attempts to lure investment-banking outsiders.

site_title: Indonesia to regulate non-subsidised fuel prices to control inflation
summary: Indonesia plans to regulate non-subsidized fuel prices to control inflation, following President Joko Widodo's previous efforts to cut government fuel spending and shift petroleum subsidies to state-owned Pertamina. The regulation aims to boost people's purchasing power and manage administered prices. Non-subsidized fuel prices, currently set by retailers, will be subject to government approval. The government hopes to boost private consumption and manage inflation, which remains below 5%, a concern for the president's re-election chances in 2019.

site_title: Two weekend property launches see keen take-up rates
summary: Strong buying momentum in Singapore's property market continues with robust take-up rates at weekend launches. Lendlease sold 149 units of Park Place Residences, while Oxley Holdings sold 129 units of The Verandah Residences, both at high average prices. This follows a strong take-up at City Developments' The Tapestry in Tampines. Analysts expect prices to rise further, with potential jumps of 7-15% in the property price index this year.

site_title: Europe: Stocks advance at open
summary: Europe's major stock markets advanced in opening deals on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.2% to 7,198.22 points, and the eurozone's DAX 30 index climbing 0.6% to 12,311.02 points. Asian markets also rose, driven by hopes of a trade war agreement between China and the US. Despite US President Trump's new threats, traders brushed off the uncertainty, with shares in mining and healthcare sectors propelling gains.

site_title: Kingboard Copper's stock jumps as controlling shareholder buys more shares
summary: Kingboard Copper Foil Holdings' controlling shareholder bought 40.3 million shares, increasing their stake by 5.58%, at a price range of S$0.40 to S$0.45 apiece. The move led to a 18.4% rise in the company's shares to a decade high, closing at S$0.45.

site_title: Japan ministry proposed story on land sale to justify discount: official
summary: Japan's Finance Ministry proposed a cover story to justify a discount in the price of public land sold to school operator Moritomo Gakuen, which has ties to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's wife. A finance bureau employee suggested that the school operator claim thousands of trucks were used to remove rubbish, but the proposal was rejected. The attempt to fabricate a story was deemed "highly embarrassing" by the official. The scandal has eroded Abe's public approval ratings, with a recent survey showing disapproval outnumbering support for his Cabinet for the first time in six months.

site_title: How to avert a Sino-American trade war before anyone gets hurt
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration threatened to impose $50 billion in tariffs on China, sparking fears of a costly trade war. National Economic Council director Larry Kudlow attempted to calm markets by stating that the tariffs were a bargaining position to bring China to the negotiating table. However, Trump escalated tensions by suggesting an additional $100 billion in tariffs, prompting China to reaffirm its willingness to negotiate. Despite the back-and-forth, Kudlow's efforts seemed to have a temporary effect, with the Dow Industrial rising 230 points on Wednesday.

site_title: United Mansion, Landmark Tower up for collective sale
summary: Two Singapore developments, United Mansion and Landmark Tower, have been put up for collective sale. United Mansion, a freehold walk-up project, has a reserve price of S$98 million, while Landmark Tower, a 99-year leasehold complex, has a reserve price of S$285 million. Both sites are in highly sought-after areas and are expected to attract developers looking to redevelop them into boutique residential projects. The tenders for both sites are set to close on May 9 and May 17, respectively.

images.alt_text: The United Mansion site can potentially yield 87 apartment units with an average size of 70 sq m gross floor area, subject to the relevant authorities' approval.

site_title: Hyflux's uphill task in selling down Tuaspring
summary: Hyflux, a Singaporean water and power company, is struggling to sell its loss-making Tuaspring plant, which was built at a cost of $1.05 billion. Despite being partially divested, the plant's value of $1.3 billion may be too high due to the severe overcapacity in the power generation market. The company aims to sell 70% of the plant, but potential buyers are hesitant to pay the asking price, citing low wholesale electricity prices. Hyflux's financial situation is precarious, with a cash balance of $314.2 million and a deteriorating balance sheet, making it uncertain whether the company will be able to return to profitability.

site_title: US dollar extends gains as trade war fears nag
summary: The US dollar extended its gains against its rivals, rising 0.2% against a basket of currencies, as investors unwound short dollar bets due to escalating trade tensions between the US and China. The dollar is up nearly 1.5% over a two-week period. Investors are trimming bearish bets against the greenback, citing a potential impact on Asian exports and equity markets. The Chinese yuan held near day's lows against the dollar, and the euro remained broadly stable despite weak eurozone data.

site_title: Dubai splashes billions on mega projects ahead of Expo
summary: Dubai is investing tens of billions of dollars in infrastructure and hospitality projects related to Expo 2020, a six-month international trade fair. The value of these projects reached $42.5 billion in March, with $17.4 billion spent on infrastructure, $13.2 billion on housing, and $11 billion on hotels and theme parks. The Expo is expected to attract 300,000 visitors per day, creating up to 300,000 jobs and boosting the real estate market and hospitality sector.

site_title: Uber agrees to buy electric bicycle rental company Jump Bikes
summary: Uber has agreed to purchase electric bicycle rental company Jump Bikes for over $100 million in cash and stock. The acquisition aims to expand Uber's presence in the bike-sharing industry, which is becoming increasingly prominent in cities like San Francisco. Jump will continue to operate independently, with its CEO reporting directly to Uber's CEO Dara Khosrowshahi. The deal is seen as a strategic move to provide more transportation options for urban consumers, with Uber planning to integrate independent bike companies into its app.

site_title: Rolls-Royce to sell diesel parts maker for 700m euros
summary: Rolls-Royce has agreed to sell its Germany-based diesel parts maker L'Orange to US-based engineering company Woodward Inc for 700 million euros as part of a plan to simplify its business. The sale is part of CEO Warren East's turnaround plan to counter declining demand for oil equipment. L'Orange will continue as a key supplier to Rolls-Royce's power systems business under a 15-year agreement. The sale is expected to enable the company to allocate capital to core technologies and businesses.

site_title: Saudi prince skips visit to mega tech incubator during French trip
summary: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman cancelled a visit to Station F, Europe's largest startup incubator in Paris, during his three-day trip to France. The visit was meant to highlight Franco-Saudi tech ties, but the decision was likely due to strained relations between the two countries over Iran's regional role. Prince Mohammed instead plans to work on defining entrepreneurial projects with President Emmanuel Macron before a potential high-level visit, and the two countries agreed on a massive tourism project and a national orchestra development.

site_title: UK watchdog to publish review of cryptocurrencies in third quarter
summary: Britain's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) will publish a review of cryptocurrencies in the third quarter, following its latest warning to the sector. The FCA warned retail investors about the risks of investing in cryptocurrencies, which can result in significant losses. The watchdog will study the implications of cryptocurrencies on the financial sector, particularly in light of Britain's withdrawal from the European Union next year. The review will focus on areas where the FCA sees the greatest potential for harm, with resources stretched due to Brexit preparations.

site_title: Homegrown firm Actxa blazes a trail to fitness
summary: Singapore-based fitness wearables firm Actxa has seen rapid growth since its founding in 2015, driven by its success in the National Steps Challenge campaign. The company, which was spun off from parent company Activate Interactive, has developed a range of trackers with increasing features, including heart rate monitoring and VO2 max tracking. Actxa aims to double its staff size and sell 100 million devices and products in the next seven years, with projected revenue of S$2.5 million to S$3 million for this year. The company is expanding its health and wellness offerings, including a stress and recovery assessment service, to provide a more holistic approach to fitness.

site_title: 'Ideas' conference to grapple with dark side of tech
summary: The Technology, Entertainment and Design (TED) conference in Vancouver is shifting its focus to the dark side of tech, exploring unintended consequences of innovations such as artificial intelligence and robotics. The conference theme, "Age of Amazement," highlights growing concerns about a loss of privacy in the digital world. Experts will discuss the risks of AI and robotics, including the potential for machines to lie, scheme, and threaten their creators. The gathering comes as the field of AI and digital innovation continues to advance rapidly, with numerous organizations investing heavily in AI research and development.

site_title: Catalist firms fret over high compliance costs
summary: Catalist-listed companies in Singapore are concerned about high compliance costs associated with sustainability reporting, according to the Association of Catalist Companies. The group's president, Philip Rickard, suggests tweaking the Singapore Exchange framework to make annual sustainability reporting mandatory only for companies with a market capitalization of S$150 million or more. Some companies may struggle to allocate resources for reporting, compromising on core businesses. The issue highlights the challenges smaller companies face in preparing sustainability reports, with data collection and strategy development being major hurdles.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: MindChamps, Temasek tie up in preschool franchisee fund
summary: MindChamps Preschool and Temasek Holdings' Pavilion Capital Holdings have co-invested in the MindChamps PreSchool Global Fund, a joint venture to manage international franchisees. MindChamps owns 70% of the fund, while Palace Investments, a Temasek unit, commits US$50 million. The fund will raise capital and invest in local education products. MindChamps expects to receive profits from the fund's operations and management fees. The deal was announced on April 9, 2018.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Iranian rial hits record low; dealers stop trading dollar, euro
summary: Iran's rial hit a record low of 57,000 against the US dollar, its second record low in two months, due to concerns about the country's economy. Foreign-exchange dealers suspended trading, citing "opportunistic speculation" and the fragility of the nuclear deal. The slide has led to business uncertainty, with some companies halting operations amid concerns over prices and imported materials. Authorities are investigating the cause of the fluctuations, with some attributing it to a wider political conspiracy against moderate President Hassan Rouhani.

site_title: UK's French Connection to sell Toast stake; may restart dividend
summary: French Connection Group Plc is selling its 75% stake in women's clothing brand Toast to Bestseller United A/S for £23.3 million.
