The sale, subject to shareholder approval, aims to help the company focus on its core business and return to profitability. French Connection also plans to consider restarting dividend payments if the deal is successful. The sale follows the company's efforts to turn around its struggling business, which has been competing with fast-fashion rivals.

site_title: Malaysia: shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 12.70 points to 1,849.71 on Monday, driven by gains. The index closed with 2.21 billion shares worth RM2.10 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 702 to 249, indicating a positive trading session.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with big gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose over 1% on Monday, driven by easing concerns over a potential China-US trade war. The Hang Seng Index increased 1.29% to close at 30,229.58, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.23%. This follows a similar trend in US stocks, which also reached fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: WHO says Australia exported listeria-tainted melons to nine countries
summary: The World Health Organization reported that melons contaminated with Listeria monocytogenes bacteria, exported from Australia, have been linked to seven deaths and one miscarriage in at least nine countries, including Hong Kong, Japan, and the United Arab Emirates. The contaminated melons were produced by an Australian firm and recalled on February 27. The cause of the outbreak was attributed to environmental conditions and weather contaminating the fruit, and the grower has returned to supply melons after testing cleared the property.

site_title: Malaysia election: Nomination and polling dates to be announced Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Election Commission will announce polling and nomination dates for the country's upcoming election on Tuesday, following Prime Minister Najib Razak's Parliament dissolution announcement last Friday. The election must be held within 60 days, and all state assemblies except Penang have dissolved. A press conference will be held at noon, with the announcement broadcast live on TV1 and TV3.

site_title: China should invest in assets other than Treasuries-PBOC adviser
summary: China's central bank adviser, Fan Gang, recommends the country invest its capital reserves in real assets instead of US Treasury bonds. China is a high wealth country with a low income, and Fan believes investing in real assets would be more beneficial. China's debt load is a concern, but Fan asserts that the majority of debt is domestic and the country has ample savings, reducing the risk of a financial crisis.

site_title: Nafta deal in principle may not be announced at Lima summit-sources
summary: US, Mexico, and Canada's talks on reworking the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) are not advanced enough for an "in principle" deal to be announced at the upcoming Lima Summit. Despite progress made by US, Mexican, and Canadian ministers, key issues remain unresolved, including new automotive sector rules. Officials are hopeful for substantive progress before the April 13-14 summit, but a deal may not be possible by the end of April or early May. The Trump administration is under pressure to reach a deal before the mid-term congressional elections in November.

site_title: Keppel O&M wins order from Sinanju for Singapore's first LNG-powered bunker tanker
summary: Keppel O&M has won a US$10 million order from Sinanju Tankers Holdings for Singapore's first LNG-powered dual-fuel bunker tanker. Scheduled for delivery in 2019, the 7,990-deadweight tonne tanker will be the first of its kind flagged and built in Singapore. The order is valued over US$10 million and is supported by a grant of up to S$2 million from the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore. This is Keppel O&M's seventh dual-fuel vessel built, with options for a second similar vessel to be exercised within six months.

site_title: Trendlines reveals its 'Most Valuable Portfolio company' to be Stimatix, valued at US$42.6m
summary: Trendlines, an Israel and Singapore-based incubator, has named its 'Most Valuable Portfolio Company' as Stimatix, valued at US$42.6 million. Stimatix, a medtech startup, developed low-profile solutions for colostomy management, was sold to B Braun Group in 2014 for an estimated return of 79.1 times and an internal rate of return of 80%. B Braun will market Stimatix's products internationally from mid-2018, with royalties to be distributed to shareholders, including Trendlines.

site_title: Why not a regulatory sandbox for SMEs?
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) face significant challenges in a rapidly changing world, where automation and digitalization are transforming industries. To survive, SMEs need to "reinvent" themselves, and governments are prioritizing their growth. However, the current regulatory architecture can be restrictive, hindering innovation and job creation. Creating a regulatory sandbox for SMEs, similar to the one for fintech startups, could help streamline regulations, reduce bureaucracy, and promote innovation. This could be a game-changer for Singapore's SME sector, which employs two-thirds of the workforce and contributes half of the country's GDP.

site_title: ECB weighs emergency cash injections to smooth bank rescues
summary: The European Central Bank is considering a new policy tool to inject cash into banks rescued from insolvency. The proposed Eurosystem Resolution Liquidity (ERL) framework would allow the ECB to fund viable parts of a lender, known as the "good bank," spun out of a failing financial institution. The measure aims to address a gap in rules for dealing with troubled lenders and improve confidence in the euro-area resolution framework. The proposal is seen as potentially controversial due to the ECB's ban on financing actions typically undertaken by public authorities.

site_title: Noble says more than 70% of creditors have given nod to restructuring scheme
summary: Noble Group, a distressed commodities firm, reported that over 70% of its creditors have approved a restructuring support agreement. The proposal aims to halve its $3.5 billion debt by asking creditors to take on equity and new debt instruments. The company will issue three new bonds totaling $1.655 billion, with annual coupons of 9.75% and 10%. Noble remains confident that more creditors will join the agreement, with advisors in contact with approximately 10% of creditors who have expressed broad support. The deadline for new subscriptions is April 11.

site_title: US: Wall St higher as US-China trade war worries ebb
summary: US stocks rose on Monday, rebounding from last week's trade tariff-driven selloff, as Trump administration officials expressed optimism over resolving the trade dispute with China through talks. The Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite indexes all opened higher, with the Dow up 0.58%, the S&P 500 up 0.53%, and the Nasdaq up 0.98%. The rebound was also driven by earnings season, with major US banks set to report first-quarter results, and investors expecting tax cuts to boost corporate profits.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.2% higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index gained 7.5 points, or 0.2%, to close at 3,449.96 on Monday, despite global market losses due to US-China trade tensions. The index saw increased turnover with 249 gainers and 165 losers. Investors remain cautious, awaiting the release of US Federal Open Market Committee meeting minutes and President Xi Jinping's remarks at the Boao forum. The US-China trade tensions persist, with investors bracing for potential retaliation.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: UK house prices rise more than expected in March
summary: UK house prices rose 2.7% in the first quarter of 2018, the strongest increase in nearly five years, according to Halifax. This surpasses economists' forecasts. Despite this, prices are still rising more slowly than before the Brexit vote, which saw a 10% annual increase in prices shortly before. A shortage of homes for sale is expected to continue supporting the market, with Halifax predicting 3% price growth in the coming months.

site_title: Yanlord buys stakes in two property development firms in Tianjin
summary: Yanlord Land Group has acquired stakes in two property development firms in Tianjin, China. Through its subsidiary, Nanjing Renyuan Investment Co Ltd, Yanlord acquired a 19.8% stake in Tianjin Hefa Property Development Co Ltd, securing rights to a land parcel worth 4.8 billion yuan. It also acquired a 16.5% stake in Tianjin Lianzhan Property Development Co Ltd, securing rights to a land parcel worth 2.95 billion yuan. The move is part of Yanlord's expansion in China's property market.

site_title: Russian aluminium giant Rusal share price nearly halves after US sanctions
summary: Russian aluminium giant Rusal's share price nearly halved to HK$2.38 after US sanctions on the company and its billionaire owner Oleg Deripaska were announced, prompting warnings of potential debt defaults and supply disruptions. US sanctions targeted 12 Russian companies, including Rusal, for actions in Crimea, Ukraine, and Syria. Aluminum prices surged 3.3% to US$2,110 a metric ton, as investors bet on supply disruptions, with Rusal accounting for about 17% of global supply outside of China. The company's annual report may be delayed due to the sanctions.

site_title: Landmark Tower up for collective sale with S$285m reserve price
summary: The Landmark Tower, a 38-storey apartment complex in Singapore, has been put up for collective sale with a reserve price of S$285 million. The site, zoned "Residential" with a GPR of 3.7, is expected to fetch in excess of S$300 million. The complex, built in the mid-1980s, is located near Orchard Road and two major MRT interchanges. The tender closes on May 17, with the potential for redevelopment into a high-rise apartment development.

site_title: UK watchdog to publish review of cryptocurrencies in third quarter
summary: Britain's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) will publish a review of cryptocurrencies in the third quarter, following its latest warning to the sector. The review will focus on the use of cryptocurrencies, not the cryptocurrencies themselves, which are outside the FCA's regulatory remit. Regulators worldwide have warned retail investors about the risks of investing in cryptocurrencies, and the FCA will work with the Bank of England and the Treasury to develop policy thinking on the matter.

site_title: Islamic scholars debate validity of cryptocurrencies
summary: Islamic scholars are debating the validity of cryptocurrencies, such as Bitcoin, in relation to Islamic finance principles. The issue revolves around whether cryptocurrencies, like commodities, are subject to the "ribawi" category, which requires equal exchange and immediate transfer of possession. This debate could influence the development of Sharia-compliant cryptocurrencies and determine whether Islamic financial firms can invest in them. The Accounting and Auditing Organisation for Islamic Financial Institutions (AAOIFI) is hosting a conference to discuss the matter.

site_title: China said to study yuan devaluation amid US trade spat
summary: China is studying the potential impact of a gradual yuan depreciation amid a trade spat with the US, according to senior officials. The analysis examines the effect of using the currency in trade negotiations and the potential for a devaluation to offset trade losses. While a weaker yuan could help China's export industries, it also poses risks, including increased volatility and the potential for US retaliation. China's central bank did not comment on the matter, and experts warn that a devaluation could destabilize markets and harm China more than the US.

site_title: Oil exploration firm Mirach mulls durian diversification
summary: Mirach Energy, an Indonesian oil and gas company, plans to diversify into selling durians and other agricultural crops, complementing its earlier plans to invest in property. The move is seen as a synergistic and logical business expansion. Mirach aims to buy 70% of RCL, a company specializing in timber and logging, cultivation, and agriculture. This diversification aims to broaden the company's revenue streams and expand its business presence in Indonesia.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks climb as domestic institutions buy; won firms
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 0.60% on Monday, driven by domestic institutions' heavy purchases. The won firmed 0.23% against the dollar, while bond yields rose. Biotechnology stocks like Celltrion and Samsung Biologics surged. The KOSPI is down 1.5% this year but up 0.63% in the past 30 days.

site_title: Americans world's biggest TV addicts watching four hours a day
summary: The average person worldwide spent nearly three hours a day watching TV in 2017, according to Eurodata TV Worldwide. Americans and Canadians watched the most, averaging four hours and three minutes daily. European viewers came next, watching three hours and 49 minutes a day. Despite growing online content, TV viewing remained stable, with a slight decline in North America and Asia. Millennials and young adults increasingly watched TV on mobile phones, often catching up on shows that way.

site_title: As Malaysia's Najib seeks reelection, Johor may no longer be the jewel in the crown
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak is facing a tough reelection bid as the opposition coalition, led by former mentor Mahathir Mohamad, focuses on exploiting Najib's weaknesses in the state of Johor. The state, traditionally a stronghold for UMNO, is now seen as a key battleground as voters express anger over corruption and the cost of living. If the opposition wins control of Johor, it could severely weaken Najib's power and credibility within UMNO, potentially denying the ruling coalition the two-thirds parliamentary majority it needs to pass constitutional amendments.

images.alt_text: A few days before he triggered the countdown to an election last week, Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak headed to the state of Johor with a pocketful of promises: a railway revamp, the widening of a jam-plagued expressway and a new sports stadium.

site_title: Oxley sells 76% of The Verandah Residences at S$1,815 psf average at launch
summary: OXLEY Holdings sold 129 units, or 76%, of its 170-unit The Verandah Residences condominium at an average price of S$1,815 per square foot (psf) during its launch. The project, near the South Buona Vista neighbourhood, was sold out to buyers, with 85% being Singaporeans, 10% permanent residents, and 5% foreigners. The site was purchased in 2017 for S$121 million, and the project is expected to be completed in 2023.

site_title: South Korea ex-president Lee indicted for corruption
summary: Former South Korean President Lee Myung-bak has been indicted for corruption, charged with bribery, power abuse, embezzlement, and tax evasion. He faces up to life in prison if convicted of all allegations. Lee's successor, Park Geun-hye, was recently jailed for 24 years for corruption. This marks the latest in a trend of South Korean ex-leaders facing criminal charges, with all four still alive now charged or convicted of criminal offenses.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Key developments include the collective sale of United Mansion in Siglap with a reserve price of S$98 million, MindChamps launching a preschool investment fund with Temasek, and Keppel O&M winning an order for Singapore's first LNG-powered bunker tanker.

images.alt_text: The site can potentially yield 87 apartment units with an average size of 70 sq m gross floor area, subject to the relevant authorities' approval, said Cushman & Wakefield.

site_title: Reinvigorated Belfast still bears scars of past conflict
summary: Belfast, the capital of Northern Ireland, has undergone significant transformation since the 1998 peace accord, with hundreds of millions of pounds in investment and a relatively low unemployment rate of 3.2%. However, stigmas from the past conflict persist, with "peace walls" separating Protestant and Catholic communities and a growth rate below the UK average. Lord Mayor Nuala McAllister emphasizes the need for integration and inclusive society, citing the importance of addressing the past to ensure a more prosperous future.

site_title: Xiaomi pushing for smartphone component suppliers to invest in India
summary: Xiaomi is urging its global smartphone component suppliers to invest in India, aiming to bring $2.5 billion in investment and create 50,000 jobs. This move could boost Prime Minister Narendra Modi's "Make in India" drive, increasing local assembly of smartphones and reducing import duties on key components. Xiaomi has already established six smartphone manufacturing plants in India, its largest market after China, and is hosting 50 suppliers for an investment summit in New Delhi.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks edge higher at close
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.51% at close on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index ending at 21,678.26, as investor sentiment improved following US President Donald Trump's comments on a potential trade deal with China. The yen eased against the dollar, contributing to the market's positive tone.

site_title: Australia shares gain as investors track higher US futures; NZ up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% on Monday, driven by gains in the healthcare sector and higher US stock futures. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 20 points to 5,808.7, with CSL Ltd and Fisher & Paykel Healthcare Corp Ltd leading the gain. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.7% on Monday, as investors took cues from the US market's recovery from a 2.2-2.3% drop on Friday.

site_title: Deutsche Bank's new CEO plans investment banking review
summary: Deutsche Bank's new CEO, Christian Sewing, plans to review the structure of its investment bank to avoid further setbacks and restore profitability. Sewing, a retail banking specialist, succeeds John Cryan, who stepped down amid a three-year loss streak. The review comes as the bank battles high expectations from clients, investors, regulators, politicians, and the media. Sewing's leadership signals a possible retreat from decades of investment banking expansion, a move aimed at restoring the bank's financial health.

site_title: Novartis to buy US gene therapy group AveXis for US$8.7b
summary: Swiss pharmaceutical giant Novartis has announced the acquisition of US gene therapy company AveXis for $8.7 billion. The all-cash deal was unanimously approved by both companies' boards. AveXis is involved in clinical studies for spinal muscular atrophy, a rare neurodegenerative disease. The acquisition is expected to expand Novartis' gene therapy capabilities and enhance its pipeline for SMA treatment.

site_title: Bordeaux 2017 vintage 'heterogeneous' as sales start: Liv-ex
summary: The 2017 Bordeaux vintage is described as "heterogeneous" due to spring frosts in some areas, despite a relatively good growing season. Demand for Bordeaux "en primeur" futures has been under pressure, but a price rally and positive returns from recent campaigns have helped restore buyer confidence. Bordeaux's market share has been declining, falling to 68% last year, while other regions like Burgundy and northern Italy have seen growing demand. The heterogeneous vintage is being presented to global merchants this week, amid a challenging market for Bordeaux.

site_title: Risotto from Sri Lanka is just as good
summary: A Sri Lankan immigrant, Ramesh Kumar Balakrishnan, has thrived in Italy, rising from a dishwasher to managing a restaurant in the small town of Agazzano. Despite facing anti-immigrant rhetoric, Balakrishnan's restaurant, "Palazzo dei Camini," serves traditional Italian dishes, including risotto, to a thriving local community. His wife, Gowry, also learned Italian and became the head chef, making even better risotto than a Milanese. The restaurant's success showcases Italy's adaptability and willingness to integrate immigrants.

site_title: MindChamps to set up preschool investment fund with Temasek unit
summary: MindChamps PreSchools has partnered with Temasek Holdings' unit, Palace Investments, to set up a preschool investment fund, the MindChamps PreSchool Global Fund, with a US$50 million commitment. MindChamps will own 70% of the fund's share capital, while Palace Investments will own 30%. The fund aims to invest in preschools globally, with returns exceeding a threshold to be shared between MindChamps and Palace Investments.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: World's top iron shipper says China's import boom will level off
summary: Australia's Department of Industry, Innovation and Science forecasts that iron ore prices will average US$61.80 per metric ton this year and US$51.10 in 2019, with prices expected to moderate as growing low-cost supply from Brazil and moderating demand in China. China's steel production is expected to drop each year through 2023, while iron ore shipments from Australia and Brazil rise before leveling off. This is attributed to slowing construction activity and increasing environmental regulations, leading to a decrease in iron ore imports from China, from 1.08 billion tons this year to 1.04 billion in 2023.

site_title: Rolls-Royce sells parts maker L'Orange to Woodward for 700 mln euros
summary: Rolls-Royce has agreed to sell its German-based diesel parts maker L'Orange to US-based engineering company Woodward Inc for 700 million euros, as part of a plan to simplify its business. The sale will allow Rolls-Royce to focus on other long-term opportunities and allocate capital to core technologies and businesses. L'Orange will continue as a key supplier to Rolls-Royce's power systems business under a 15-year agreement. This transaction is part of Rolls-Royce CEO Warren East's plan to streamline the company and counter declines in older aero-engine programmes.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes afternoon trading at 3,448.36, up 0.2% on the day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed afternoon trading at 3,448.36, up 0.2% on the day, with the Straits Times Index rising 5.86 points. About 1.1 billion shares worth S$555 million changed hands, with KrisEnergy being the most actively traded stock. The rally comes ahead of GDP data, as investors brush off new Trump threats to extend the stocks' rally.

site_title: Goldman leads banks with stock auctions as a MiFID II workaround
summary: Goldman Sachs has launched a periodic auction service to win fund manager business, allowing investors to buy and sell shares without revealing their trades. The service, which started on March 21, enables fair, multilateral, and transparent trading, a workaround for MiFID II's price transparency requirements. Several major banks, including UBS Group, are now offering similar services, and European exchanges like Cboe Global Markets are seeing increased volumes through periodic auctions. This trend is a response to the EU's caps on dark pools, which aim to reduce the efficiency of stock markets.

site_title: Cities running on car batteries? Just so crazy it might work
summary: A tinkerer in Ireland, Damien Maguire, uses his electric car's battery to power his home during frequent power outages, storing excess energy from solar panels. This "vehicle-to-grid" concept, where electric car batteries act as mini power plants, could revolutionize the public power grid. If successful, it could make renewable energy cheaper and more widely used, reducing reliance on fossil fuels. Utilities and automakers are exploring this idea, which could transform the way energy is generated, stored, and distributed.

site_title: Zuckerberg to face angry lawmakers as Facebook firestorm rages
summary: Mark Zuckerberg will appear before US lawmakers this week as a data privacy scandal rocks Facebook, with 87 million users' data being hijacked and shared with Cambridge Analytica. Facebook has suspended another data analysis firm, Cubeyou, and plans to require political ads to state who is paying for the message. Lawmakers are calling for new regulations on social media platforms and a privacy bill of rights, while Zuckerberg has announced plans to hire thousands of people to verify the identity of advertisers.

images.alt_text: Mark Zuckerberg will appear before US lawmakers this week as a firestorm rocks Facebook over its data privacy scandal, with pressure mounting for new regulations on social media platforms.

site_title: Trek 2000 FY2017 profit falls to US$5.2m after write-off in intangible assets
summary: Trek 2000 International reported a lower audited net profit of US$5.2 million for FY2017 due to a US$950,000 write-off of intangible assets deemed to have no further commercial value. The company initially reported US$6.2 million in profit, but revised research and development costs to US$2.11 million. This adjustment reduced the profit by US$3.1 million. The write-off and revised costs impacted the company's financial statements, leading to a lower profit for the year.

site_title: Rakuten's telecom plans are now real, but so are the costs
summary: Rakuten, a Japanese e-commerce group, has received approval to build its own telecom outfit after a panel reviewed its application. The company will have to develop its own network and technical capabilities, rather than relying on other firms. Rakuten plans to invest 200 billion yen (S$2.5 billion) in 2019 and 600 billion yen by 2025 to achieve 15 million subscribers. The move is seen as a significant step for the company, but its costs and technical capabilities remain to be seen.

images.alt_text: Japanese e-commerce group Rakuten Inc got the go-ahead to build its own telecom outfit late Friday.

site_title: Runaway train rolls for miles in India without engine
summary: A runaway train in Odisha, India, detached 22 coaches carrying 1,000 passengers from the engine and sped backwards for 12km before being stopped by railway staff. The incident occurred on Saturday night, with none of the passengers injured. The railway ministry described the incident as "ghastly" but praised the staff for preventing a more severe accident.

site_title: SIA named world's best airline by TripAdvisor
summary: Singapore Airlines has been named the world's best airline by TripAdvisor based on reviews from global travellers. The national carrier won awards for Best Airline in Asia, Best International First Class, Best Economy Class, Travellers' Choice Business Class, and Travellers' Choice Premium Economy Class in Asia. CEO Goh Choon Phong praised the award as a validation of his staff's hard work and dedication to ensuring Singapore Airlines remains competitive globally.

images.alt_text: The national carrier also landed awards for Best Airline in Asia, Best International First Class in the World and in Asia, Best Economy Class in the World and in Asia, Travellers' Choice Business Class in Asia and Travellers' Choice Premium Economy Class in Asia.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars tad higher but traders cautious
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars held within recent ranges on Monday, with the Australian dollar 0.2% firmer at US$0.7691 and the New Zealand dollar 0.2% higher at US$0.7290. Investors remain cautious due to the simmering US-China tariff spat, despite positive headlines suggesting a potential resolution through talks. Experts warn that a trade war could negatively impact the open economies of Australia and New Zealand, and their currencies.

site_title: China's yuan edges up, likely to ease in long run on trade dispute
summary: China's yuan edged up against the US dollar on Monday, reversing a decline seen late last week, as weaker-than-expected US jobs data and trade tensions weighed on the greenback. The yuan is expected to recover in the long run due to China's potential compromise on trade tensions. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.3114 per US dollar, 0.3% weaker than the previous fix. Analysts predict the yuan will fall 0.8% to 6.35 per US dollar in a year, but market expectations remain cautious.

site_title: Hot stock: Kingboard Copper share price rises 19.7% to hit decade high
summary: Kingboard Copper Foil Holdings' shares rose 19.74% to a decade high, trading at S$0.455, on a volume of 40.4 million shares. The company received a query from the Singapore Exchange Regulation regarding "unusual volume movements." Kingboard Copper was added to the FTSE ST Fledgling Index in March 2017, following a takeover-cum-privatisation offer that was rejected by shareholders.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Competition watchdog to conduct market studies on online travel booking, transfer of personal data
summary: Singapore's Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) launched its new consumer protection role, focusing on online travel booking and data portability. The CCCS will conduct market studies on the two topics, examining commercial arrangements and consumer protection issues. The studies aim to foster competition among service providers and ease the process for consumers to switch. The commission's new role is designed to safeguard fair trading and competition, ensuring consumers have access to a wider variety of products and services at competitive prices.

site_title: Gold steady as investors await fresh move in US-China trade spat
summary: Gold prices remained steady on Monday, unchanged at US$1,332.46 an ounce, as investors awaited fresh developments in the US-China trade spat. Despite US President Donald Trump's comments predicting China would take down its trade barriers, gold prices remained unimpressed. The easing of tensions between the US and North Korea also reduced the appeal of gold. Hedge funds and money managers reduced their long position in gold and boosted their short position in silver.

site_title: Ascott in strategic tie ups with developers in China, Japan and Thailand to manage properties
summary: ASCOTT Limited, the serviced residence unit of CapitaLand, has formed strategic partnerships with developers in China, Japan, and Thailand to manage properties. The agreements include partnerships with Riverside Group in China, NTT Urban Development Corporation in Japan, and Ananda Development in Thailand. The collaborations will see the launch of serviced residences with a total of 1,500 units in Bangkok and two projects in Japan. The partnerships aim to maximize returns for partners and drive growth, with Ascott targeting 80,000 units by the end of this year and 160,000 units by 2023.

site_title: Bank of China, ICBC join 7 other banks offering PayNow in Singapore
summary: Bank of China and Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) have joined seven other banks in offering PayNow, a peer-to-peer funds transfer service in Singapore. The service, which allows customers to send and receive Singapore dollars using their mobile number or identification card, has seen over 1.2 million registrations and $470 million in transfers as of March 31. Nine banks now participate in the service, including Bank of China, ICBC, and Citibank Singapore. The Association of Banks in Singapore will continue to promote PayNow as a convenient and secure means of transferring funds.

site_title: Dubai splashes billions on mega projects ahead of Expo
summary: Dubai is investing tens of billions of dollars in infrastructure and hospitality projects related to Expo 2020, with $42.5 billion worth of projects underway as of March. The investments include $17.4 billion in infrastructure and transport, $13.2 billion in housing, and $11 billion in hotels and theme parks. The expansion of Al Maktoum International Airport and a new metro line are among the projects, which are expected to boost the real estate market and hospitality sector, creating up to 300,000 new jobs and energizing the economy.

site_title: What the pho? Vietnam streetfood cocktails make a splash
summary: Vietnamese bartender Pham Tien Tiep has created a pho-inspired cocktail that combines aromatics like cinnamon, star anise, and cardamom with gin and triple sec. The unique drink has gained popularity in Hanoi, where it's being served at upscale bars, and has even inspired copycat versions across Vietnam. This departure from traditional Vietnamese beer culture reflects a growing trend of elevating street food to luxury cocktails, with Tiep aiming to promote Vietnamese cuisine globally.

site_title: From juice to jewellery, Southeast Asian social ventures lift poor out of poverty
summary: In the Philippines, social enterprises have emerged as a key driver in lifting poor families out of poverty. Enchanted Farm, a rural development project, has created six social enterprises that provide jobs and income for 48 families, who previously lived in slums. The ventures include peanut butter, plush toys, and skincare products, and have enabled the families to escape poverty and improve their lives. Experts say that such efforts could be boosted if the Senate approves the Poverty Reduction Through Social Entrepreneurship Bill, which aims to increase training and access to funding for social enterprises.

site_title: United Mansion in Siglap up for collective sale with S$98m reserve price
summary: The owners of United Mansion in Siglap have put the site up for collective sale with a reserve price of S$98 million, or S$1,485 per square foot per plot ratio. The freehold site has a land area of 5,135.2 square meters and can potentially yield 87 apartment units. The site is within walking distance of the Siglap neighbourhood and educational institutions, appealing to small and mid-size developers. The tender will close on May 9 at 3pm, offering a boutique residential redevelopment opportunity in the highly sought-after Siglap area.

site_title: Manpower Ministry's Kok Ping Soon will be GovTech's new CEO from May 1
summary: GovTech's new CEO, Kok Ping Soon, will take over from Jacqueline Poh on May 1. As Deputy Secretary of Development at the Ministry of Manpower, Mr. Kok oversees workplace safety, human capital development, and digitalization initiatives. Ms. Poh, who led GovTech since 2016, set the strategic direction for the agency and transformed it into an organization that delivers innovative solutions. GovTech chairman Ng Chee Khern welcomed Mr. Kok, who will build on the foundation laid by Ms. Poh, and credited her with setting the agency's strategic direction and delivering results.

site_title: Prince Harry's fiancee craves 'Diana 2.0' role: biography
summary: Meghan Markle, Prince Harry's fiancée, is reportedly aiming to emulate Princess Diana's philanthropic efforts, as detailed in a new biography. The 36-year-old actress is fiercely protective of her public image and has a calculating approach to her charitable endeavors. According to the book, she has a history of ditching friends and relationships to advance her career, including a past divorce that cost her a lifelong friend. The biography, "Meghan: A Hollywood Princess," is set to be released in Britain on Thursday, May 10, 2018.

images.alt_text: Meghan Markle has her heart set on becoming "Diana 2.0", according to a new biography of Prince Harry's fiancee that details her lifelong embrace of good causes but also points to a calculating streak.

site_title: Canada town honors hockey crash victims at sombre vigil
summary: In the Canadian town of Humboldt, a sombre vigil was held on April 8, 2018, to honor the 15 victims of a truck-bus crash that killed players, coaches, and team personnel of the Humboldt Broncos junior hockey team. Nearly 3,000 people attended the event, which included Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, public safety minister Ralph Goodale, and local officials. The crash, which occurred at a highway intersection, has sent shockwaves through the hockey world, with tributes pouring in from around the globe. A GoFundMe campaign has raised over $3.7 million for the families of the victims.

images.alt_text: Mourners in the tiny Canadian town of Humboldt, still struggling to make sense of a devastating tragedy, gathered at a prayer vigil Sunday to honour the victims of a truck-bus crash that killed 15 of their own and shook North American ice hockey.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks open slightly higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened slightly higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.31 points to 1837.68, a 0.07% gain. The market saw 38.8 million lots traded for RM15 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 120 to 70.

site_title: Kinder Morgan stops work on controversial Canada pipeline
summary: Kinder Morgan has suspended most work on the Trans Mountain Expansion Project, a Canadian oil pipeline, due to opposition from provincial authorities. The project, which would increase oil capacity from 300,000 to 800,000 barrels per day, is supported by the federal government and Alberta and Saskatchewan provinces. The decision comes after the company's legal challenges to local bylaws were rejected by the Federal Court of Appeal. A final decision on the project is expected by May 31. The pipeline's opponents cite risks of oil spills and greenhouse gas emissions.

site_title: Stocks to watch: LTC Corp, Keppel, Asti, Alliance Mineral, Perennial, Sinopipe
summary: LTC Corp's buyout bid has been declared unconditional after regulators approved a reduced acceptance threshold of 50% from 90%. Keppel Corporation has entered into a cooperation agreement with KrisEnergy to be its preferred contractor for upstream oil and gas projects. Asti-owned Advanced Systems Automation plans to acquire several semiconductor companies for S$10 million. Alliance Mineral Assets has completed a share placement and will issue 76.52 million shares to institutional investors. Perennial Real Estate Holdings has been awarded a contract to operate a 768-bed eldercare facility in Shanghai. Sinopipe Holdings Limited has applied for an extension of its annual general meeting and financial statement submission.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.87% at open on April 9, 2018, after US President Donald Trump stated an end to escalating trade tensions with China, while a below-forecast US jobs report tempered interest rate concerns. The Hang Seng Index increased to 30,104.32, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices declined 0.18% and 0.34%, respectively.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks opened higher Monday after Donald Trump said he saw an end to escalating trade tensions with China, while a below-forecast US jobs report last week tempered worries about a sharp rise in interest rates.

site_title: From juice to jewellery, Southeast Asian social ventures lift poor out of poverty
summary: In the Philippines, social enterprises are helping lift thousands of people out of poverty. The Enchanted Farm in Bulacan, for example, has created jobs and homes for 48 families who previously lived in shanties. The businesses, including peanut butter and plush toys, are run by the residents themselves, providing financial security and empowerment. Experts say the Poverty Reduction Through Social Entrepreneurship Bill could boost such efforts, and social enterprises have already shown promise in other Southeast Asian countries like Vietnam, Malaysia, and Thailand.

site_title: French brace for rail strike havoc as state vows to enact reform
summary: France is bracing for rail strike disruptions, with SNCF cancelling about a quarter of cross-Channel trains, 80% of high-speed links, and two-thirds of regional trains. The strike, called by unions opposing President Emmanuel Macron's planned reforms, is expected to last until Tuesday. The state won't consider taking over SNCF's debt until the changes are made, with Prime Minister Edouard Philippe vowing not to compromise on opening up the rail market to competition. The strike has sparked widespread support, with 44% of respondents believing it is justified and 72% welcoming competition on high-speed and regional lines.

site_title: North Korea ready to discuss denuclearisation with US: report
summary: North Korea has reportedly told US officials that Kim Jong Un is willing to discuss denuclearisation, paving the way for a planned meeting with President Donald Trump. This is the first time Pyongyang has made such an offer directly to Washington, following a South Korean envoy's previous invitation. The US wants "complete, verifiable, and irreversible" denuclearisation, a high bar, and the summit's success remains uncertain. The meeting is scheduled for the end of May, with a third country potentially hosting the talks.

site_title: Australia shares flat as miners, financials drag; NZ slips
summary: Australia's shares slipped 0.1% on Monday, with mining firms and financials dragging down the market. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to 5,784.6, as BHP and Rio Tinto lost 0.9% and 1.3%, respectively. The sector index was also weighed down by National Australia Bank and Australia and New Zealand Banking Group. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.1% to 8,387.44, hurt by weakness in consumer staples and utilities.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Monday; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.2% lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index down 5.65 points to 3,436.85. About 50 million shares worth S$100 million changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 82 to 50. This followed a flat start for Asian shares and a decline in Wall Street indices on Friday.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat amid lingering trade war fears
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Monday, April 9, 2018, amid lingering trade war fears, with the yen easing modestly against the US dollar. The Nikkei 225 index edged down 0.02%, while the Topix index declined 0.06%. Investor sentiment was hurt by falls on Wall Street, contributing to the flat market open.

site_title: Kinder Morgan halts most work on disputed Canada pipeline expansion
summary: Kinder Morgan Canada suspended most work on its contentious C$7.4 billion pipeline expansion, citing concerns over shareholder funds and the project's viability in a crowded market. The decision was a victory for environmental groups and the British Columbia government, which had opposed the project. The company plans to decide by May 31 whether to continue the project, which is crucial for Canada's oil industry but faces fierce opposition. The Canadian government, led by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, had approved the project, but its approval is now in jeopardy.

site_title: Trump says 'big price to pay' for Syria chemical attack
summary: US President Donald Trump warned of a "big price to pay" after aid groups reported dozens of people killed by poison gas in the Syrian rebel-held town of Douma, an attack attributed to Syrian government forces. Trump directly criticized Russian President Vladimir Putin, and the US denied any missile strike on a Syrian air base. The European Union and UN also confirmed evidence of chemical weapons use by Assad's forces, prompting a meeting at the UN Security Council. Trump has authorized a cruise missile strike on a Syrian air base previously and may consider another strike, but details remain unclear.

site_title: UK firms more optimistic after Brexit transition deal: Deloitte poll
summary: A survey by Deloitte found that 27% of UK finance chiefs are more optimistic about their businesses after the Brexit transition deal, up from 18% before the deal. The poll, conducted after the deal was struck in March, suggests a boost in confidence among leading companies.

site_title: Japan fires football coach months before World Cup: local media
summary: Japan has fired national football coach Vahid Halilhodzic just two months before the World Cup, citing disappointing performances. Japan Football Association president Kozo Tashima will announce the new coach at a press conference later Monday. This move comes after months of tension over Halilhodzic's performance, with the coach forced to rebut rumors of his dismissal last year.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks firm on local institutions' purchases; won rises
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index and won rose on Monday, with the Kospi up 9.78 points or 0.40% at 2,439.36. Local institutions and individual investors drove the recovery after the benchmark index fell earlier due to US-China trade war fears. The won rose 0.17% to 1,067.8 per US dollar, and the MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index rose 0.18%.

site_title: Trump's 'Art of the Deal' bombast faces ultimate test with China
summary: US President Donald Trump's aggressive trade tactics towards China face a test, with Chinese President Xi Jinping expected to respond to Trump's demands for a trade deal. Trump has imposed tariffs on steel imports and proposed duties on Chinese products, but his record suggests he may use these threats to gain leverage. China has proposed retaliatory duties on US$50 billion of American goods, and Xi Jinping's speech may shed light on his plans. Analysts believe China will take a cautious approach, expecting Trump to eventually back down, and that Xi Jinping is inclined to take Trump seriously.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump has shown a penchant for trying to bully America's trading partners into concessions at the negotiating table. In China, he faces a rising superpower with the economic might to hold its own.

site_title: For Indonesian billionaire, flashy car takes a back seat to 20-hour days
summary: Indonesian billionaire Donald Sihombing, 61, has shifted his focus from luxury properties to modest residential projects, prioritizing the prosperity of his 2,000 workers. His company, PT Totalindo Eka Persada, has seen a 1,200% surge in stock value since going public last June. Sihombing now aims to raise 30% of revenue from residential projects by this year and 50% by 2020, seeking a 50-50 balance between government and private projects to alleviate fluctuations in high-end properties linked to the global economy.

site_title: Horror thriller 'Quiet Place' makes a lot of noise in North American debut
summary: Horror thriller "A Quiet Place" made a significant debut in North American theaters, earning an estimated US$50 million over the three-day weekend, the second-highest domestic opening of the year. The film, directed by John Krasinski and starring Emily Blunt, tells the story of a family adapting to a world invaded by blind, sound-tracking creatures. With a 97% Rotten Tomatoes rating, it drew rave reviews and took the top spot, ahead of "Black Panther" and "Ready Player One".

site_title: ComfortDelGro expands into patient transport in Australia with A$30m acquisition
summary: ComfortDelGro Corp is acquiring Australian non-emergency patient transport provider National Patient Transport (NPT) for A$30 million. The deal, subject to regulatory approval, will expand ComfortDelGro's land transport services in Australia. NPT operates a fleet of 144 vehicles providing healthcare transport services, including walker, hoise, and stretcher transport. The acquisition is seen as an opportunity to leverage on ComfortDelGro's core capabilities and explore similar opportunities in other geographies, particularly with ageing populations.

images.alt_text: COMFORTDELGRO Corp is buying Australian non-emergency patient transport provider National Patient Transport (NPT) for A$30 million (S$30.2 million).

site_title: The billionaires behind Lego are shopping for London real estate
summary: Kirkbi A/S, the fund managing the wealth of the Lego billionaires, is expanding its real estate portfolio in London despite Brexit uncertainty. The US$16 billion fund has bought a property in King's Cross, its third UK investment, and plans to invest in other areas like technology and media. CEO Soren Thorup Sorensen believes these sectors will be less exposed to the UK's financial sector exodus. The fund aims to grow its real estate portfolio, which reached US$1.2 billion last year, and is considering investments in Germany, Switzerland, and other countries.

site_title: Syria 'chemical attack': what we know
summary: A chemical attack in Syria's rebel-held Douma has sparked international outrage, with Washington warning of possible military action against the Syrian regime. The White Helmets reported 500 cases of exposure to poisonous chlorine gas, resulting in over 100 deaths, mostly women and children. The Syrian government and Russia denied the claims, calling them "fabrications." The US, UN, and other countries condemned the alleged attack, with some warning of potential military action, while others called for an investigation. The attack is the latest in a seven-week regime assault on Eastern Ghouta, which has killed nearly 100 people.

site_title: Oil steadies after Friday's falls, but trade disputes still weigh
summary: Oil prices steadied on Monday after a 2% drop on Friday due to US-China trade tensions and increased US drilling activity. US WTI crude futures rose 0.2% to $62.17 a barrel, while Brent crude futures rose 0.2% to $67.23 a barrel. Despite concerns of a trade war, oil demand remains healthy and supply restraint led by Opec has supported prices. US exports have surged, offsetting the impact of Venezuela's supply disruption.

images.alt_text: Oil markets stabilised on Monday after slumping around 2 per cent last Friday on the back of concerns of an intensifying trade dispute between the United States and China, as well as increased US drilling activity.

site_title: Facebook's Zuckerberg to meet US lawmakers on Monday: sources
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg will meet with US lawmakers on Monday, ahead of his scheduled Congressional hearing on the use of customer data by a political consultancy. The meetings, scheduled for Monday afternoon, will include lawmakers from committees before whom Zuckerberg is set to testify. Facebook declined to comment on the meetings, which were not made public.

site_title: LTC Corp takeover offer declared unconditional after share threshold lowered
summary: The buyout bid for LTC Corporation has been declared unconditional after regulators approved a reduced acceptance threshold of 50% from 90%. As of April 6, 84.21% of shares had been tendered, satisfying the new condition. The closing date for the offer has been extended to April 25. The bid vehicle, controlled by the Cheng family, aims to delist the company and turn it into a wholly owned subsidiary. The offer price is S$0.925 per share, a 44.5% premium over the stock's previous close.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Forget the trade war. China wants to win the computing arms race
summary: China is focusing on winning the computing arms race, surpassing the US in developing quantum computers. Chinese universities and US tech companies like IBM and Microsoft are racing to create these powerful machines, which can process data beyond modern computers' capabilities. The technology has the potential to transform industries such as drug-making, agriculture, and automotive manufacturing. China's efforts in quantum computing could give it a significant economic advantage over the US in the coming years.

images.alt_text: As the US and China threaten to impose tariffs on goods from aluminum to wine, the two nations are waging a separate economic battle that could determine who owns the next wave of computing.

site_title: KrisEnergy inks agreement to appoint Keppel its preferred contractor
summary: Keppel Corporation has entered into a cooperation agreement with KrisEnergy, a controlling shareholder, to be appointed as the preferred contractor for the construction and refurbishment of various marine assets, including mobile offshore production units, drilling units, and floating storage units. The agreement allows KrisEnergy to access Keppel's experience and facilities at a competitive price, giving the group a competitive edge in specialized areas. The deal is expected to have no material impact on Keppel's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the financial year ending December 31, 2018.

site_title: Chinese AI startup SenseTime snags Alibaba, Temasek funding at record US$3b valuation
summary: Chinese AI startup SenseTime has secured US$600 million in funding from Alibaba Group and Temasek Holdings at a record valuation of over US$3 billion. The company, specializing in facial recognition and image analysis, plans to use the funds to invest in autonomous driving, augmented reality, and computing power. SenseTime aims to double its workforce to 2,000 and develop a service called "Viper" to parse data from thousands of live camera feeds, which will be used for mass surveillance. The company's valuation is expected to reach over US$4.5 billion, making it the world's most valuable AI startup.

images.alt_text: SenseTime Group Ltd has raised US$600 million from Alibaba Group Holding Ltd and other investors at a valuation of more than US$3 billion, becoming the world's most valuable artificial intelligence (AI) startup.

site_title: Asti-owned Catalist unit to buy a group of semiconductor companies for S$10m
summary: ASTI Holdings' unit, Advanced Systems Automation, plans to acquire a group of semiconductor companies for S$10 million. The acquisition includes Yumei Technologies, Yumei Reit, and Pioneer Venture. Pre-tax profits for the target companies are expected to be at least S$3 million for 2018 and 2019. The deal is expected to be earnings-accretive, according to the Catalist-listed unit.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: US dollar nurses losses as US-China trade tensions cloud outlook
summary: The US dollar experienced losses due to concerns over US-China trade tensions, with the dollar index falling to 90.180 after a one-month high. The US economy created the fewest jobs in six months in March, and China warned of a "fierce counter strike" if the US imposes tariffs on $100 billion of Chinese goods. Despite this, risk aversion appears to be decreasing, and investors are holding out hope for a compromise. The dollar held steady against the yen at 106.92 yen, and the euro was down 0.1% in early Asian trade.

images.alt_text: The US dollar nursed its losses on Monday, having retreated late last week due to concerns over US-China trade tensions and following data that showed the US economy created the fewest jobs in six months in March.

site_title: Deutsche Bank replaces CEO amid losses and lack of direction
summary: Deutsche Bank's supervisory board replaced CEO John Cryan amid three years of losses and a troubled investment bank. Christian Sewing, a 47-year-old insider, will take over as CEO, tasked with resolving the bank's ambivalence towards its investment banking unit and scaling back its workforce and assets. Sewing's appointment follows a period of turmoil and infighting, with investors punishing the bank's shares, which have lost over half their value since 2015. The shake-up aims to address long-standing issues, including a large inventory of risky assets and dysfunctional internal computer systems.

site_title: Three injured after quake hits Japan: agency
summary: A 6.1-magnitude quake struck western Japan, leaving three people with minor injuries and damaging buildings and roads. The quake, 96km north of Hiroshima, also caused 100 households to lose water supplies and 50 to lose electricity. No problems were reported at the nearby Shimane nuclear power station. Japan's location on the Pacific "Ring of Fire" makes it prone to earthquakes, but the country has since rebuilt after a devastating 9.0-magnitude quake and tsunami in 2011.

site_title: Six arrested on suspicion of Berlin half marathon plot
summary: Berlin authorities arrested six people on suspicion of plotting a violent crime at the city's half marathon, which drew 36,000 runners and spectators. The arrests came after a deadly van rampage in western Germany and amid heightened security concerns. Authorities confiscated data storage devices, mobile phones, and a small knife, but details of the planned attack remain unclear. The incident has raised concerns about the security situation in Germany, which has seen a rise in Islamist radicalism since 2015.

site_title: A millionaire mindset never made anyone rich
summary: A self-help industry promoting a "millionaire mindset" has been criticized for its lack of evidence and effectiveness in achieving wealth. The idea that believing in one's ability to become rich is enough to make it happen is debunked by experts, who argue that doing and creating value is key to achieving success. Millionaires, including Jamie Dimon, Warren Buffett, and Ray Dalio, do not rely on visualizations or placebos, but rather on hard work, learning, and responding to market forces. The author concludes that the self-help industry's focus on mindset over action is a form of "psychological warfare" that preys on people's desperation.

site_title: Trump sees trade deal with 'friend' Xi
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that he believes a trade deal with China is possible, despite escalating tensions and retaliatory tariffs. Trump called China's President Xi Jinping a "friend" and said taxes will become reciprocal, paving the way for a deal on intellectual property. The US imposed tariffs on $50 billion in Chinese goods in March, prompting China to retaliate with levies on $50 billion in US exports. Trump instructed trade officials to consider additional tariffs on $100 billion in imports, but senior economic advisers dismissed talk of a trade war, saying tariffs will be part of the negotiations.

site_title: Offshore oil industry suppliers fight to be fit for frugal future
summary: The offshore oil industry is shifting towards a more frugal future, with suppliers cutting costs and seeking alternative revenue streams in the Norwegian sector. Statoil is phasing out giant oil platforms and focusing on smaller, more efficient installations, while yards like Kvaerner are diversifying into decommissioning, recycling, and renewable energy projects. Global consultancy WoodMackenzie reports a trend towards "brownfield" expansions and smaller, less capital-intensive projects, with offshore suppliers such as Aker Solutions and Subsea 7 expanding into renewables.

site_title: Alliance Mineral completes book building for share placement; issue, allotment and trading in May
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets, a CATALIST-listed lithium miner, has completed a book building for a share placement, issuing 76.52 million shares to three institutional investors at S$0.33 apiece for A$25 million. The issue and allotment is set for May 2, with trading to begin on May 4. The placements aim to fund capital expenditure and working capital for its lithium and tantalum project in Western Australia. The company also plans to merge with Tawana Resources under a scheme of arrangement, with Alliance acquiring Tawana's issued shares at 1.1 Alliance shares per Tawana share.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Malaysia's AG term extended for another 3 years
summary: Malaysia has extended the term of its attorney-general, Mohamed Apandi Ali, for another three years until 2021. Apandi, 68, vowed to uphold the rule of law and work with stakeholders for the country's peace and harmony. The extension comes close to Malaysia's elections, where Prime Minister Najib Razak is under pressure to score a win amid rising costs and a scandal at a state fund. Apandi was appointed in 2015, replacing Abdul Gani Patail, and his term renewal has been criticized by Najib's contender, Mahathir Mohamad.

site_title: Mahathir pledges to review China investment after Malaysia vote
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has pledged to review Chinese investment in the country if he wins the upcoming election. Mahathir has expressed concerns that Chinese investment is not bringing in capital and technology to Malaysia, and is instead benefiting foreign companies. He has cited examples of countries such as Sri Lanka, which he claims "lost a lot of land" due to Chinese investments. Mahathir's opposition party, Pakatan Harapan, has vowed to review all foreign mega-projects to ensure there is no element of corruption.

site_title: Power generation sector crushed by massive overcapacity
summary: Singapore's power generation sector is facing a massive overcapacity, with all but one of the seven generation companies (gencos) operating at a loss. The sector's total capacity is 13,350 megawatts, but peak demand averages only 7,000 MW, resulting in a spare capacity of 48%. The overcapacity led to low wholesale electricity prices, averaging S$81 per megawatt hour in 2017, making it difficult for gencos to cover fixed costs. To alleviate the situation, the Energy Market Authority (EMA) is exploring temporary measures, but the industry's financial health remains a concern, with some gencos warning of potential bankruptcies.

site_title: Faced with global warming, aviation aims to turn green
summary: Aviation aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by adopting electric technology, with Norway leading the charge. The Nordic nation aims to electrify all short-haul flights by 2040, and several airlines, including Wideroe, are exploring electric-powered aircraft. Major manufacturers like Airbus and Boeing are also developing hybrid models, with the first flight planned for 2020. Electric planes could reduce emissions by 50% and operating costs by 60-70%, making them a viable option for the highly competitive airline industry.

site_title: Asia focus fuels growth for Credit Suisse
summary: Credit Suisse's private banking business in Asia-Pacific has seen significant growth, with assets under management rising 18% to a record 196.8 billion Swiss francs in 2017. The bank's Asia-Pacific division, dubbed "Wealth Management & Connected," has merged private banking and investment banking into a single unit, focusing on serving Asia's entrepreneurs. Revenues rose 22% to 2.32 billion Swiss francs, and pre-tax income surged 63% to 799 million Swiss francs. The bank's cost-to-income ratio improved, and recurring commissions and fees increased 19% to 381 million Swiss francs.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: US$1.4b hedge fund sees intact fundamentals for Facebook
summary: A US$1.4 billion hedge fund, Cadian Capital Management, believes Facebook's fundamentals remain intact despite a 14% stock drop amid a data breach scandal. The selloff has pushed the stock to 18 times next year's earnings, a 25% discount from its previous multiple. Despite this, Eric Bannasch, the hedge fund's founder, thinks Facebook's core business remains strong.

site_title: Soros planning to trade cryptocurrencies
summary: George Soros' US$26 billion family office plans to trade cryptocurrencies, despite previously calling them a bubble. Soros' comments in January were followed by a 41% drop in bitcoin's value. Other macro managers, such as John Burbank, have also turned to digital coins as profits dwindle. Billionaires Alan Howard and Soros have made personal wagers on cryptocurrencies, while regulators globally investigate the benefits and risks of digital assets, amid growing concerns of government intervention.

site_title: Singapore, China sign Belt and Road MOU on greater collaboration
summary: Singapore and China signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) in Beijing on April 8, 2018, to promote greater collaboration between the two countries' companies in third-party markets along the Belt and Road Initiative. The MOU aims to facilitate business matching activities, financing, and project structuring needs between Singaporean and Chinese companies. This move strengthens economic ties between Singapore and China, which already have strong trade and investment relations.

site_title: Perennial unit clinches deal for eldercare health facility in Fengxian
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings' unit, Shanghai RST Chinese Medicine Co, clinches a 5-year contract to operate the 768-bed Fengxian Second Welfare Home in Shanghai's Fengxian District, expected to open in Q3 2018. The facility will provide integrated eldercare, medical care, and rehabilitation services, and is the first government-built-privately-operated facility in the area. Renshoutang will leverage its expertise in healthcare services to enhance and operate the facility for five years.

site_title: Deutsche Bank seen replacing CEO Cryan with Sewing
summary: Deutsche Bank's supervisory board is set to replace CEO John Cryan with co-deputy CEO Christian Sewing, marking a strategic shift towards retail banking in Germany. Sewing, 47, will take over in May, following weeks of speculation and a rift with supervisory board chairman Paul Achleitner. The move comes as the bank tries to strengthen its brand and address losses, with investors losing faith in Cryan's ability to return the bank to profitability.

images.alt_text: The promotion of Mr Sewing comes as Deutsche Bank and its major shareholders debate the path forward for the investment banking unit where revenues have dried up and key staff defected.

site_title: Saudis hike May oil price for Asia; traders stumped
summary: Saudi Arabia has raised the official selling price (OSP) for its Arab Light crude sold to Asian refiners in May by 10 cents per barrel to a premium of $1.20 a barrel, exceeding market expectations of a cut of 50-60 cents. The move deviates from the usual pricing formula, leaving traders stumped. The price increase widens the gap between Arab Light and Arab Heavy crude by 30 US cents to $3.25 a barrel, the widest since July 2016. The decision may influence other Middle East producers' OSPs announced next week.

site_title: California proposes new rules for self-driving cars
summary: California's Public Utilities Commission proposes rules allowing self-driving car companies to transport passengers without a backup driver. The move is seen as a step forward for autonomous car developers, such as Waymo and General Motors, which could clear the way for companies to offer public rides without human drivers. The proposal is a response to heightened scrutiny over safety concerns in the industry.

site_title: Hardening of nine-year rule for IDs
summary: The Corporate Governance Council has recommended a hardening of the nine-year rule for independent directors, targeting board renewal, succession planning, and diversity. The rule, which requires a minimum of nine years of service for IDs, has two alternate implementation options. The council aims to improve corporate governance and oversight, but the exact implementation details have yet to be determined.

site_title: Tech sector sweats as US-China trade tensions simmer
summary: US-China trade tensions are escalating, with the tech sector worried about potential collateral damage to the $3 trillion industry. Industry leaders, including Amazon and Google, fear that the trade war could hit US tech firms operating in China, where concerns about censorship, labor, and human rights exist. Analysts say the Trump administration's tariffs may be counterproductive, as they could lead to higher costs for US consumers and businesses. The tech industry is bracing for a potential tit-for-tat escalation of trade frictions, with some predicting tariffs on electronics and components, including iPhones.

site_title: Focus on investment grade the key in bonds: DBS banker
summary: DBS Bank has maintained its lead in the Singapore bond market with a 41% market share in Q1, despite interest rate volatility and trade tensions. The bank issued S$6 billion worth of bonds, up 12% from the same period last year, and completed mega deals with the Land Transport Authority and HDB. However, investors are cautious, with most new issues trading at par or slightly under, and the market experiencing thin liquidity. DBS estimates that a 10 basis point premium may be needed to attract repeat issuers or investment grade names.

site_title: Schwarzenegger back home after heart surgery: spokesman
summary: Arnold Schwarzenegger, 70, has been released from the hospital after undergoing open heart surgery to replace a valve that had outlived its life expectancy. The procedure was done as an emergency measure following complications with a routine operation. Schwarzenegger, a former California governor and action hero, is recovering at home in Los Angeles in good spirits. He had previously undergone non-urgent heart surgery in 1997.

site_title: Making room for renewable energy
summary: Acromec, a Singapore-based clean room builder, is shifting its focus to renewable energy after a series of setbacks in its core business. The company, which had a compound annual growth rate of 14.5% in its net profits, plunged into the red after its IPO debut in 2016. However, led by executive chairman Lim Say Chin, Acromec is now betting on renewable energy as a third core operation to propel growth and boost its bottom line. The company plans to build, own, and operate an organic waste-to-energy plant in Singapore, with plans to replicate the model across Asia.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Pavilion Gas imports maiden LNG cargo for local use
summary: Pavilion Gas, a subsidiary of Temasek-owned Pavilion Energy, has received its first liquefied natural gas (LNG) cargo for use in Singapore. The cargo, supplied by Qatargas, was delivered to the Singapore LNG terminal on April 7. Pavilion Gas supplies a third of Singapore's industries with natural gas, and the company's chairman, Mohd Hassan Marican, called the inaugural cargo a "significant milestone." The cargo will be regasified and delivered to downstream customers. This marks Pavilion Gas' readiness to supply the domestic market and follows the company's recent expansion of LNG trading and operations activities.

site_title: Purpose over paycheque
summary: Employee engagement in Singapore is below-average compared to other countries. According to Ho Yat-Wai, Singapore Country Manager of American Express, boosting engagement involves providing feedback, sharing successes, and recognizing employees. The company's approach includes sharing feedback on products and services, showcasing employee achievements, and fostering a sense of community. Employers in Singapore can spark enthusiasm by implementing similar strategies, such as open communication, employee recognition, and opportunities for growth and development. By doing so, they can boost employee commitment and create a more engaged workforce.

site_title: Trump's tariffs raises concerns over potential impact on healthcare costs
summary: US President Donald Trump's proposal to impose 25% tariffs on dozens of Chinese-made medical devices and ingredients has raised concerns over potential impact on healthcare costs. The list includes products such as pacemakers, artificial joints, and birth control pills, which could lead to increased prices for patients. Analysts estimate that the tariffs could cost the medical device industry up to $1.5 billion annually, affecting baby boomers who rely on hip and knee replacements. The tariffs have unsettled the medical device and supply industries, with companies like Medtronic and Zimmer Biomet facing potential losses.

site_title: Softbank borrows US$8b using Alibaba shares as collateral: sources
summary: Softbank borrowed US$8 billion from a group of banks, using its Alibaba shares as collateral. Morgan Stanley, Citigroup, Goldman Sachs, Bank of America, and JPMorgan Chase were among the lenders. This is one of the largest margin loans, which are guaranteed only by Softbank's Alibaba holding.

site_title: Blackstone said to begin marketing 15 US hotels
summary: Blackstone Group LP is marketing 15 US select-service hotels, a move part of its ordinary course of managing a large portfolio. The properties, which include Residence Inn and Homewood Suites, are being sold after the company amassed over 100 in the US. The sale's value is unclear, but American Hotel Income Properties REIT LP paid $407.4 million for 18 similar hotels last year. The move is part of Blackstone's affinity for the select-service market, which demands lower capital expenditures and offers potential for higher returns. A Blackstone representative declined to comment on the plans.

site_title: After re-branding, FAS wants a bigger slice of sponsorship pie
summary: The Football Association of Singapore (FAS) plans to increase its sponsorship and streaming presence with a new initiative. At least 50% of Singapore Premier League (SPL) matches will be streamed "live" on FAS platforms, with the league owning the rights to all content. The goal is to make the SPL a commercially viable and entertaining league, with a focus on youth development and vibrant football culture. The FAS aims to attract wider audiences and improve the league's reputation, following a decline in interest after the S.League's rebranding in 2018.

site_title: Earnings could soothe investor worries
summary: US stocks may experience relief from investor worries as earnings season begins, led by JPMorgan Chase and other banks. Global markets have been volatile due to trade tensions between the US and China, with President Trump's bellicose rhetoric fueling uncertainty. Analysts warn that prolonged brinksmanship could lead to draconian trade policies, similar to those that contributed to the Great Depression. Strong earnings expectations, however, could soothe investor concerns and boost stocks, with Thomson Reuters projecting a 18.4% year-over-year earnings increase for the S&P 500.

site_title: Lufthansa Group going digital in a big way
summary: Lufthansa Group is investing €500 million over four years in a digitalization strategy to improve its operations, customer experience, and revenue. The airline aims to boost sales through digital services such as upgrade sales, streamline maintenance work, and enhance customer loyalty. Digital initiatives include predictive maintenance, robotic check-ins, and virtual reality for passenger experience. The group is also developing an innovation hub in Berlin and a new web platform to integrate travel options across its airlines. Digitalization is expected to increase revenue, reduce costs, and improve passenger loyalty.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Sinopipe seeks 2-month extension to hold AGM
summary: SinoPipe Holdings has applied to the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for a 2-month extension to hold its annual general meeting (AGM) for FY2017, from April 30 to June 30, 2018. The group is also seeking an extension to submit its consolidated financial statements for FY2017. This comes as the company faces financial distress.

site_title: India sets October target for gas trading exchange
summary: India plans to establish a natural gas trading exchange by October 1, aiming to standardize prices and reduce risks associated with the pricing differences between domestic and international markets. The exchange will help India meet its target of increasing the share of gas in its energy mix to 15% by 2030. With domestic gas output expected to rise to 140 million standard cubic meters per day in the next three to five years, the exchange will facilitate the smooth operation of gas supply.

site_title: Singapore offers LNG traders location, infrastructure and ecosystem: Koh Poh Koon
summary: Singapore offers liquefied natural gas (LNG) traders a strategic location, infrastructure, and ecosystem, Minister Koh Poh Koon said. The city-state is poised to capitalize on growing LNG usage in Southeast Asia, driven by environmental policies and regional demand. Singapore LNG is set to complete its fourth storage tank and modify its jetty to accommodate smaller vessels. The Energy Market Authority has also enabled spot pricing for LNG buyers, aiming to develop Singapore as a gas price discovery and trading hub.

site_title: Advancing CSR as a way of life
summary: Singapore-based company Advanced Holdings prioritizes corporate social responsibility (CSR) as a core aspect of its business, aiming to enrich communities and make a real difference. Founder and group CEO Dr. Wong Kar King emphasizes CSR as a journey, not a destination, with initiatives like charity events, home visits, and shoe donation drives. Despite challenges, the company remains committed to CSR, recognizing its benefits for both beneficiaries and staff volunteers, who experience a sense of purpose and meaning in their work.

site_title: UK universities face uncertainty as Brexit looms
summary: UK universities face uncertainty as Brexit looms, with potential impacts on research funding, talent acquisition, and student enrollment. European Union grants, which currently fund about 12% of British universities' research income, may dwindle, and faculty from other European nations may face new immigration rules. Many young scientists, like German-born Nicole Grobert, who have spent their careers in the UK, are considering leaving or are already being courted by universities abroad. The uncertainty has already led to a decline in international applications and a decrease in the number of European students enrolling in British universities.

site_title: STI remains comparatively resilient; 32 director acquisitions filed
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) maintained a 0.4% gain for the 2018 year, outperforming the MSCI Asia-Pacific Index, which declined 2.1%. In March, 26 stocks repurchased 86 million shares for S$222 million, with 32 director acquisitions filed, including UOB-Kay Hian Holdings chairman Wee Ee Chao's 156,200-share acquisition. Other notable director acquisitions include Centurion Corporation's David Loh Kim Kang and Han Seng Juan, and GSH Corporation's Sam Goi Seng Hui, who increased their stakes in their respective companies.

site_title: Pritam Singh elected unopposed as Workers' Party leader
summary: Pritam Singh was elected unopposed as the secretary-general of Singapore's Workers' Party, marking a smooth handover of power. Chairman Sylvia Lim was also re-elected unopposed. The election comes after outgoing party leader Low Thia Khiang stepped down, and Singh is seen as a relatively inexperienced candidate to maintain the party's electoral performance. The next general election is due by 2021, and Singh will face challenges including an ongoing lawsuit over the party's Aljunied-Hougang Town Council's accounts.

site_title: Speculators trim net US-dollar shorts for second week
summary: Speculators reduced their net US-dollar shorts for the second week in a row, with a value of $20.71 billion, down from $21.73 billion. The US dollar's positioning reflects its recent recovery, but the currency remains down over 2% for the year. The weak dollar outlook is attributed to the ongoing trade dispute with China and the Federal Reserve's tightening cycle. Analysts expect the Fed's cycle to end, potentially moving interest rate gaps against the dollar.

site_title: Domestic factors may take centrestage this week
summary: Domestic factors in Singapore may overshadow the US-China trade tiff this week. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is set to release the advance first quarter GDP figure and semi-annual monetary policy statement on Friday. Market strategist Pan Jingyi expects growth to accelerate to 4.4% year-on-year, surpassing the previous quarter. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks have rallied for five consecutive days ahead of the GDP data release, indicating investor confidence in the country's economic prospects.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
