site_title: Trump sees trade deal with 'friend' Xi
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed optimism about a potential trade deal with China, calling President Xi Jinping a "friend." Trump stated that China will remove trade barriers and that the two countries will make a deal on intellectual property. The US had previously imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, and China retaliated with tariffs on US$50 billion worth of goods. Trump has since instructed officials to consider additional tariffs on US$100 billion in imports, but Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said the administration remains willing to negotiate.

site_title: Navigating the trade talk proves dicey
summary: US stocks rallied after National Economic Council director Larry Kudlow calmed investors with "don't overreact" remarks amid concerns over US$50 billion import duties on China. The Dow Jones Industrial Average surged over 700 points from its low. The rapid turnabout in White House policy has led investors to adopt a wait-and-see attitude. Kudlow's comments followed a week in his new role, with investors initially reacting negatively to the administration's plan.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for last week's tanker and dry bulk market reveals significant declines in rates for various vessel types. The LR2 market lost 5/7.5 WS points, while the VLCC market dropped 1/1.5 points. Capesize rates tumbled on the West Australia/China run, coming close to dipping below $5.00. Panamax rates remained under pressure due to holidays and falling paper values. Supramax rates also fell, with a 57,000-dwt fixed for about five to seven months worldwide at $12,500. Despite the downturn, charterers continue to seek tonnage, albeit at lower levels.

site_title: Singapore offers LNG traders location, infrastructure and ecosystem: Koh Poh Koon
summary: Singapore offers liquefied natural gas (LNG) traders a strategic location, infrastructure, and ecosystem to unlock regional business, said Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry and National Development Koh Poh Koon. The city-state's LNG sector is poised to capitalize on growing LNG usage in Southeast Asia and environmentally driven policies. Singapore LNG will complete its fourth storage tank by mid-2018 and modify its jetty by 2019 to accommodate smaller vessels. The Energy Market Authority has also enabled spot pricing for LNG buyers, further augmenting Singapore's development as a gas price discovery and trading hub.

site_title: Singapore, China sign MOU on third-party markets along Belt and Road
summary: Singapore and China signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) in Beijing to promote collaboration between the two countries' companies in third-party markets along the Belt and Road Initiative. The MOU aims to facilitate business matching activities and forums to support financing and project structuring needs of ventures by companies from both sides. Singapore's Minister for National Development and Second Minister for Finance Lawrence Wong and China's National Development and Reform Commission Vice Chairman Zhang Yong signed the agreement, which is expected to strengthen economic ties between the two countries.

site_title: Wynn Resorts CEO said to weigh sale of Boston-area casino
summary: Wynn Resorts' CEO Matt Maddox is considering a sale of the company's Boston-area casino, Wynn Boston Harbor, amid the ongoing fallout from founder Steve Wynn's sexual harassment allegations. The casino, valued at $2.4 billion, is still under construction and was won by Wynn Resorts in a bid against rival operators. The company has incurred $1.13 billion in costs so far, and its Massachusetts gaming license is at risk due to the ongoing investigations. A sale could potentially mitigate the financial losses and reputational damage caused by Wynn's resignation and allegations.

site_title: Dropbox shows it's possible to defy tech giants
summary: Dropbox's successful initial public offering (IPO) has shown that startups can defy tech giants despite their advantages. The company's focused strategy, distinct services, ease of use, and customer loyalty contributed to its 40% value increase. This success comes amidst a backlash against tech giants, who have been acquiring smaller rivals and leveraging their user networks and infrastructure. Dropbox's IPO success demonstrates that smaller companies can thrive in the tech industry with the right approach.

images.alt_text: During its market debut last month, Dropbox's value leaped nearly 40 per cent. Its IPO success came despite facing big-name, multibillion-dollar competitors, such as Google, Microsoft, Amazon.com and Apple.

"They turn to us, and they're like, 'Hey, can someone build a cloud to sync my clouds?' " - Dropbox co-founder Drew Houston, on customers who show him their app-packed phones, equipped with a mash-up of work-related tools, such as word processors and spreadsheets, hosted by different software companies.

site_title: Kushners will buy rest of 666 Fifth Avenue from partner Vornado
summary: The Kushner family has reached a deal to buy out its partner, Vornado Realty Trust, in the troubled 666 Fifth Avenue skyscraper. The deal, announced in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, marks the end of Vornado's involvement in the building. The Kushner family's purchase price was not disclosed, and it is unclear whether they have found a new partner or secured financing for the deal. The sale of 666 Fifth Avenue is a significant development for the Kushners' real estate empire.

site_title: Sinopipe applies for extension of two months to hold AGM
summary: Sinopipe Holdings Limited has applied to the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for a two-month extension to hold its annual general meeting (AGM) for FY2017, citing financial distress and a credit crunch in China. The company faces serious financial issues, including withdrawal of banking facilities and closure of production plants, and has delayed the disposal of loss-making subsidiaries. Once the disposal is completed, the company will use proceeds to pay for AGM expenditure and audit fees. Trading of the company's shares has been suspended since April 2, 2012.

site_title: Merkel and Macron may find they can agree with Trump on China
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Emmanuel Macron are set to meet with US President Donald Trump in Washington, attempting to forge a "trade coalition of the willing" to counter China's alleged unfair trade practices. The EU is under pressure to stop the US from imposing tariffs on steel and aluminum, with the May 1 deadline looming. Merkel and Macron may find common ground with Trump, potentially alleviating trade tensions, but their domestic agendas and differing priorities remain uncertain.

site_title: Nasdaq 100 looks likely to rebound back to the uptrend
summary: The Nasdaq 100 index is expected to rebound back to the uptrend, despite a recent sharp selloff in the tech space. The index remains positive year-to-date, while other major indices are down marginally. A 12% selloff has occurred, which has historically led to a reversal, lifting prices back into the uptrend. The Nasdaq 100 index is currently holding a pivotal support area at 6,300, justifying a rebound. If this support holds, the long-term uptrend is expected to resume, targeting the 7,000 psychological round number.

site_title: Australians want Turnbull to stay as 30th Newspoll defeat looms
summary: Australians overwhelmingly support Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's leadership, with 62% wanting him to stay in the job despite a poor government rating. A recent survey showed Turnbull's lead over opposition leader Bill Shorten as preferred prime minister increased to 52%. The government faces its 30th consecutive Newspoll defeat on Monday, which Turnbull used to challenge Tony Abbott in 2015. Turnbull aims to cut company tax rates to boost jobs and wages, with support increasing to 49% among voters.

site_title: China trade dispute could slam US retailers
summary: The Trump administration is considering tariffs on $100 billion in Chinese goods, in addition to the $50 billion already proposed, in a trade dispute with Beijing. The tariffs, targeting industrial goods and electronic components, could lead to higher prices or a shortage of merchandise for US retailers, potentially harming sales. Some retailers, such as Levi, are anticipating revenue growth to offset the impact, while others, like Adidas, are exploring alternative product lines. The tariffs are seen as a negotiating tactic to force China to address intellectual property policies.

site_title: Boeing tops Airbus with US$12.3b American Airlines deal for 787s
summary: American Airlines has ordered 47 Boeing 787 Dreamliners worth $12.3 billion, surpassing Airbus's sales in the US market. The deal marks Boeing's second win over Airbus this year, following a similar switch by Hawaiian Airlines. American will simplify its fleet by reducing the number of wide-body aircraft types from five to three. The new 787s will replace aging Boeing and Airbus planes, and deliveries will begin in 2022 and 2023. This move further solidifies Boeing's dominance in the US aviation market.

site_title: US congressman pulls loaded gun at constituent meeting
summary: US Congressman Ralph Norman drew his loaded Smith & Wesson pistol during a constituent meeting, attempting to illustrate gun safety. Norman, a concealed carry permit holder, placed the gun on a table to convey that guns are only dangerous in the wrong hands. The incident occurred amidst ongoing debates about new gun safety laws following mass shootings, including a Florida high school massacre. Norman's actions sparked criticism, with some likening his reference to Gabby Giffords' injury to downplaying the severity of gun violence.

site_title: Facebook adding unsend message tool after CEO caught unsending
summary: Facebook is introducing a feature allowing users to retract messages after a report that CEO Mark Zuckerberg used an early version of the feature without telling anyone. The feature was developed after the 2014 Sony data hack, which exposed sensitive internal communications. Facebook initially tested it with executives but later decided to make it available to all users. The move comes amid the company's worst privacy crisis, following the Cambridge Analytica data scandal, with Zuckerberg set to testify before Congress on April 10-11.

site_title: Trump, UAE leader push for unity in Gulf as dispute drags on
summary: US President Donald Trump and UAE Crown Prince Sheikh Mohammed bin Zayed agreed to promote unity among Gulf nations amid a dispute between Qatar and other US allies. The UAE, along with Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, and Egypt, cut off ties with Qatar in June over terrorism allegations, which Doha denies. The Trump administration postponed a May summit with Gulf Arab leaders until September, citing lack of progress in negotiations. Trump is scheduled to meet with Qatari Emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad al Thani on April 10.

site_title: MMA star McGregor charged with New York assault
summary: Conor McGregor, a 29-year-old MMA star, was charged with assault and criminal mischief in New York after throwing a dolly through the side window of a bus carrying rival fighters, injuring two athletes, Michael Chiesa and Ray Borg. McGregor surrendered to police and was released on $50,000 bail. The UFC has canceled UFC 223 and will review McGregor's future in the organization. McGregor's actions were deemed "the most disgusting thing ever" by UFC president Dana White, who warned that McGregor would likely face legal action.

site_title: Harvard pushed by US to share admissions data in bias suit
summary: The US Justice Department is joining a lawsuit against Harvard University, seeking to unseal admissions data on hundreds of thousands of applicants in a bias suit. The data, which includes information on applicants from Asian-American groups, was previously shared with the plaintiffs, but Harvard is resisting its release, citing concerns about confidentiality and trade secrets. The government argues that the public has a right to know about the judicial process, and the Justice Department's interest overlaps with an ongoing US probe into similar complaints. A hearing is set for Tuesday.

images.alt_text: The US Justice Department is joining a legal attack on Harvard University's admissions policies, saying the government and the public have a right to see the admissions data of hundreds of thousands of applicants to the nation's oldest university.

site_title: Moscow wants British explanations over Skripal's niece visa refusal
summary: Moscow is seeking explanations from the UK over the refusal to issue a visa to Viktoria Skripal, the niece of former Russian spy Sergei Skripal, who was poisoned in March. The UK Home Office stated that Viktoria had been denied a visa due to her alleged involvement in espionage activities. Sergei and Yulia Skripal, his daughter, are recovering from their poisoning and are no longer in critical condition. The Russian Foreign Ministry is seeking answers from the UK regarding the visa denial, which has raised tensions between the two countries.

site_title: Aramco is said to plan US chemical complex project study
summary: Saudi Aramco is set to sign an agreement with British oilfield services firm TechnipFMC to explore building chemical facilities in Texas, US. The study aims to produce materials used in gasoline and industrial solvents, as well as ethylene for plastics. The project, part of Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's "Vision 2030" to diversify the Saudi economy, is expected to be a major investment. Aramco plans to use proceeds from its upcoming initial public offering to expand its refining and petrochemicals business, not oil exploration and production.

site_title: Fed's Powell points to rate hikes, uncertainty on trade tensions
summary: Fed Chairman Jerome Powell stated that the US economy may need further interest rate hikes to control inflation, which is expected to rise towards the Fed's 2% objective in the coming months. Powell also expressed uncertainty about the impact of rising trade tensions on the US economy, saying it's too soon to determine their effect.

site_title: Wells Fargo called out by teachers union over gun industry ties
summary: Wells Fargo may lose its recommended mortgage lender status with the American Federation of Teachers (AFT) due to its ties to the gun industry and the National Rifle Association (NRA). The AFT expressed alarm over Wells Fargo's financial involvement with gunmakers and the NRA, which assisted 1,600 AFT families with home financing last year. The bank's CEO, Tim Sloan, said the bank values its relationship with the union but believes the issue should be addressed through the legislative process, not corporate decisions.

images.alt_text: Wells Fargo & Co's ties to the gun industry may soon be costing it business.

site_title: Amid trade tensions, Asean seeks integration
summary: Singapore's Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for Asean members to integrate their economies amid trade tensions, while promoting financial technology (fintech) to foster financial inclusion. Asean's growth is expected to continue, with members holding meetings with China, Japan, and South Korea. Fintech innovations, such as mobile devices and digital payments, are seen as key solutions to enhance financial connectivity across the region. The Asean Financial Innovation Network (AFIN) will pilot its platform by the end of the year to match financial institutions with fintech firms.

site_title: Fashion company Nine West files for bankruptcy; to sell some brands
summary: US footwear and apparel company Nine West Holdings filed for bankruptcy and will sell its Nine West and Bandolino brands to Authentic Brands Group for US$300 million. The company received debtor-in-possession financing and entered a restructuring agreement, aiming to restructure its debt.

site_title: Rebuilt house in Bin Tong Park sold for S$48m
summary: A rebuilt house in Bin Tong Park, Singapore, has sold for S$48 million, translating to S$2,063 per square foot. The 23,269 sq ft freehold land area features a 15,600 sq ft built-up area spanning two levels and a basement, designed by Ong & Ong. The sale marks a significant price point for the Good Class Bungalow (GCB) Area.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Facebook to verify identities for political ads
summary: Facebook will require political ads to state who is paying for the message and verify the identity of the payer, aiming to curb outside election interference. The new policy, set to take effect this year, will label messages for candidates or public issues with the name of the person or entity paying for it. The move follows criticism of Facebook's role in the 2016 election and is intended to improve transparency and accountability. Facebook will hire thousands of people to enforce the policy ahead of the US mid-term elections in November.

site_title: What if we paid for Facebook - instead of letting it spy on us for free?
summary: A proposed subscription-based model for Facebook could liberate the social network from perverse financial incentives, allowing it to focus on user security and data protection. The idea, dubbed "Facebook Plus," would require users to pay a monthly fee, potentially ranging from $5 to $7, to remove targeted ads and enhance data security. This could restore user trust and potentially mitigate the risks associated with data collection and targeted advertising. However, the feasibility of such a model is uncertain, with many users expressing reluctance to pay for a service they currently access for free.

site_title: Spain mulls appealing Puigdemont extradition ruling to EU court
summary: Spain's public prosecutor's office may appeal a German court's decision to reject the extradition of Catalonia's ousted separatist leader Carles Puigdemont to the European Court of Justice. The German court ruled that rebellion was not punishable under German law, and the closest equivalent, high treason, did not apply because Puigdemont's actions were not accompanied by violence. Spain plans to study the possibility of exercising actions to protect the European legal order before the European Court of Justice.

site_title: Trump threatens more China tariffs, Beijing ready to hit back
summary: US President Donald Trump threatened additional tariffs on China, sparking a "fierce counter strike" from Beijing. China warned it's prepared to retaliate against US$100 billion of Chinese goods if tariffs are imposed. The US and China are in a tit-for-tat trade confrontation, with potentially damaging consequences for the world's two biggest economies. Financial markets have been roiled, and analysts predict a slowdown in real GDP growth if a trade war escalates. China's President Xi Jinping is expected to unveil reform measures to open up sectors to foreign investment.

site_title: Chinese sperm bank gets political with donors
summary: A Chinese sperm bank, Peking University Third Hospital, has set strict criteria for would-be donors, requiring them to be loyal to China's Communist Party, have good political mindset, and support the Party's leadership. Men aged 20-45 with "orthodox manners" and "good character" can register to donate sperm by May 23 and receive up to 5,500 yuan in cash. The move aims to address China's low birth rate, which is a concern for the government. This is part of the Communist Party's efforts to tighten its grip on society.

site_title: Nafta ministers meet again, no major breakthroughs made
summary: US, Mexican, and Canadian trade officials met in Washington to discuss updating the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta). Canadian Foreign Minister Chrystia Freeland stated that no major breakthroughs were made, and talks will continue to find a good deal. The US wants to increase North American content in vehicles to 85% from 62.5%, a contentious issue that needs to be resolved before an agreement in principle can be reached. The lack of clarity has impacted financial markets and currencies, with the Canadian dollar and Mexican peso experiencing fluctuations.

site_title: MGM Growth Properties to buy Hard Rock gaming resort for $1.06b
summary: MGM Growth Properties to acquire Hard Rock Rocksino Northfield Park in Ohio for $1.06 billion. The gaming facility has over 2,300 video lottery terminals and various entertainment venues. MGM Growth Properties plans to sell the licensed and operating assets to a third-party operator, with annual rent expected to be between $50 million and $60 million. The deal is expected to close in the second half of the year, funded by a mix of cash and debt.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends down 2% as US-China trade fears intensify
summary: US stocks dropped 2% on Friday, with the Dow falling over 570 points, amid growing concerns over a potential US-China trade war. US President Donald Trump's latest tariff threat on Chinese imports intensified fears, while Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell indicated the central bank may need to continue raising interest rates to control inflation. Despite the market volatility, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hyflux clinched a contract with Asia Water Development Engineering Company to design, manufacture, and supply a seawater reverse osmosis desalination package in Bandar Abbas, Iran, valued at approximately 68.7 million euros. The contract, expected to last two to three years, is expected to contribute to Hyflux's financials by the end of 2018. Meanwhile, Tat Hong Holdings received a takeover offer from its CEO and Standard Chartered's private equity arm, with ANZ recommending shareholders accept the offer due to fair and reasonable financial terms.

site_title: New Noble has 'zero chance of success': Iceberg
summary: Iceberg Research has stated that Noble Group's proposed restructuring plan has "zero chance of success" due to unsustainable high financing costs. The plan involves issuing three new bonds totaling $1.655 billion, but Iceberg claims that Noble cannot afford to pay the high coupon rates, which would lead to significant interest expenses. The research firm also questions the motivations behind the management's submission of the restructuring plan, suggesting it may be to secure a full release from liability.

site_title: Levi Strauss sues LVMH's Kenzo over jeans pocket tab
summary: Levi Strauss & Co has sued LVMH's Kenzo over trademark infringement for using tabs on its pants pockets, similar to those on Levi's jeans. The lawsuit claims Kenzo's actions threaten to cause Levi to lose sales and suffer "incalculable and irreparable damage" to its goodwill. Kenzo's new clothing line featuring Britney Spears is also cited as an example of the alleged infringement. The US-based company is seeking unspecified damages for trademark infringement in the US District Court in San Francisco.

site_title: Deactivation of Uber app pushed from April 8 to 15
summary: Uber's deactivation of its app in Singapore has been delayed to April 15, allowing the Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) to assess a suspected breach of the Competition Act. Uber and Grab have proposed alternative interim measures to preserve the status quo, and the CCCS will review these proposals before imposing its own measures. The delay aims to facilitate deliberation on the deal and prevent any integration of businesses that could affect competition and the viability of the businesses.

images.alt_text: Christopher Tan

site_title: Reits
summary: Real estate investment trusts (REITs) have been a high-yielding option for investors, with several trends emerging. The Q3 condo launch wave in Singapore will test demand for prime projects above $3,000 psf, while Manhattan rents have reached a record high. US mortgage rates have climbed after five weeks of declines. In the UK, homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high. Other news includes WeWork securing new tenants at 21 Collyer Quay and New World selling China property assets. These trends suggest a mixed real estate market with increasing demand and changing investor priorities.

site_title: Malaysia gears up for 'unpredictable' election with parliament's dissolution
summary: Malaysia's parliament has been dissolved, paving the way for a general election. Prime Minister Najib Razak, facing pressure over a multi-billion dollar scandal, is expected to retain power but will face a tough challenge from his old mentor and opposition leader Mahathir Mohamad. Analysts predict an unpredictable election, with some warning that Najib's opponents claim the election will be unfair due to changes in electoral boundaries and a fake news bill. Polling must be held within 60 days.

site_title: Midas directors to travel to China to meet firm's subsidiaries
summary: Midas Holdings, a Singapore-based railway-parts maker, will send its directors to China to meet with subsidiaries to address issues such as litigations and cash validation. The move comes after the company received limited cooperation from staff in its Chinese subsidiaries. The directors aim to gather information on undisclosed subsidiaries and other matters affecting the company's operations.

site_title: SMRT-backed firm makes pact with Mobike over transport app
summary: SMRT, backed by the Singapore government, has partnered with Chinese bike-share company Mobike to boost urban transport planning. The two companies will share data insights from their platforms to enable smarter transport planning and optimised operational efficiency. Mobike's bicycles will be loaded onto the mobilityX app, which aims to integrate public and private transport services. The deal comes amid a debate over dockless bike parking in Singapore, and follows Mobike's acquisition by Chinese e-commerce firm Meituan Dianping for $3.4 billion.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Enterprise Singapore teams up to launch human resource initiatives
summary: Enterprise Singapore has launched three human resource initiatives in collaboration with the Ministry of Manpower and other agencies. The initiatives aim to strengthen human resource operations in three key ways: enhancing the National Career Development Framework, introducing a new Professional Conversion Programmes, and introducing a new Workforce Development Fund. Second Minister for Manpower and Home Affairs Josephine Teo announced the measures at the Institute for Human Resource Professionals (IHRP) Conferment ceremony and office opening.

images.alt_text: Enterprise Singapore, in collaboration with the Ministry of Manpower and other agencies, has launched two new measures and enhanced another to strengthen human resource operations.

site_title: BlackRock to offer ETFs excluding investments in gun makers
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, plans to launch two exchange-traded funds (ETFs) that exclude investments in civilian firearm makers and large sellers, following the Florida high school shooting. The iShares MSCI USA Small-Cap ESG Optimized ETF and iShares ESG US Aggregate Bond ETF will track investment results of an index mostly made up of small-cap US companies and exclude producers and big retailers of civilian firearms. The move comes as gun control and background checks debate reignites, and other firms like Vanguard have excluded gun manufacturers from their funds.

site_title: Trump: 'We've already lost the trade war'
summary: US President Donald Trump stated in a radio interview that the US has already lost the trade war with China, despite imposing tariffs on Chinese goods. Trump said the US would experience "a little pain" but would ultimately be much stronger in the long run. He cited the 40-42% increase in the US market as evidence of the country's resilience. Trump's comments come as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: American companies in China prepare to be squeezed
summary: US companies in China, which have invested over $400 billion in the past 25 years, are at risk of being squeezed by escalating US-China trade tensions. President Trump has threatened to impose another $100 billion round of tariffs, potentially harming businesses with assets in China. The Chinese government has shown no qualms about punishing foreign businesses, as seen in the case of Lotte Group, which abandoned its mainland hypermarket chain due to regulatory harassment. If globalisation retreats, American companies' businesses could take harder hits to the bottom line.

site_title: Reap gains from dialogue and engagement for long-haul investing
summary: Long-term investors should focus on company fundamentals rather than market sentiment to make informed decisions. Engaging in dialogue with non-executive directors and listening to a company's business strategies can provide valuable insights. Ignoring short-term "noise" and focusing on data, circumspection, and long-term management can help investors avoid distractions and expensive mistakes. By prioritizing fundamentals, investors can better navigate the complexities of investing and increase their chances of long-term success.

site_title: Bull market's anchor at risk in shifting growth story
summary: The US, Japan, and other developed economies are experiencing synchronized growth, but a shift in this trend may lead to a more complex trading environment, according to market analysts. The Morgan Stanley developed market cycle indicator is nearing levels last seen before prior recessions, and a protectionist US trade stance threatens the industrial cycle and emerging-market boom. As a result, investors are bracing for increased market volatility and correlations between assets, which could lead to a more subdued appetite for risk taking and a less synchronized global economy.

site_title: How can one art photograph have four very different price tags?
summary: A 1907 photograph by Alfred Stieglitz, "The Steerage," is being sold at four auctions with vastly different price tags. The same image, printed by Stieglitz, can fetch between $12,000 and $80,000 depending on the auction house, the image's condition, and whether it was signed by Stieglitz. The price difference is largely due to connoisseurship and collectibility, rather than artistry. The market for historical photography is complex, requiring serious research or a leap of faith, and even experts acknowledge that trends can vary widely depending on the artist and market.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: AEM Holdings reported a 67% increase in sales orders for FY18 to S$192 million, up from S$115 million in February. ComfortDelGro's taxi business faces competition after Grab acquired Uber's South-east Asia operations. Perennial Real Estate Holdings entered a 40:60 joint venture to develop a freehold residential site. Analysts have varying views on these companies, with AEM's earnings guidance and test handler usage unclear, ComfortDelGro's acquisition prospects uncertain, and Perennial's joint venture offering significant exposure to the Singapore property market.

site_title: Singapore, Hong Kong bourses end higher, shrugging off trade war threats
summary: Asian stock markets rose on Friday, shrugging off US-China trade war threats. Despite US President Donald Trump's threat to impose tariffs on an additional $100 billion of Chinese imports, Hong Kong's Hang Seng index ended 1.1% higher. US stock index futures fell, but Singapore's benchmark rose 1.1% as investors became increasingly desensitized to trade tensions. Markets in mainland China, Taiwan, and Thailand were closed.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: EPL serves up a Saturday derby day feast
summary: The English Premier League (EPL) is hosting two high-stakes derbies on Saturday: the Merseyside derby between Everton and Liverpool, and the Manchester derby between Manchester City and Manchester United. Everton, currently in ninth spot, will face Liverpool, who are in third place, with Liverpool having a 2-point lead over Manchester United. The Manchester City derby could seal the EPL title for City, who have a 16-point advantage over United with just seven games left. Both derbies promise to be intense and action-packed, with Liverpool's Mohamed Salah and Manchester City's Gabriel Jesus expected to play key roles.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Global Dragon buying Katong Omega Apartments for S$46.3m in en bloc deal
summary: Global Dragon Limited, a CATALIST-listed company controlled by Singapore tycoon Koh Wee Meng, has bought Katong Omega Apartments in a collective sale for S$46.31 million. The 18-unit freehold development in District 15 has a potential GFA of about 39,063.4 sq ft, which could house 36 apartments. Each unit owner is slated to pocket between S$2.52 million and S$2.6 million, or more than 120 per cent of the current value. The deal brings the total collective sales value year-to-date to S$6.14 billion.

site_title: MAS reminds FIs to be on alert for fraudulent fund transfers
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued an advisory to financial institutions to remain vigilant for fraudulent fund transfers using the SWIFT platform. The advisory comes after recent cyber incidents overseas where attackers attempted to transfer funds. MAS' chief cyber security officer, Tan Yeow Seng, emphasized the importance of vigilance in the face of constant cyber threats. The advisory includes measures to beef up security, including the use of the SWIFT platform. This move aims to protect the financial sector from potential cyber attacks.

site_title: Amid trade tensions, Asean seeks integration
summary: Asean members aim to integrate their economies despite simmering trade tensions, with Singapore's Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat emphasizing the need for openness to globalization. The region's growth is expected to continue, with an estimated 5% growth last year, and Asean+3 meetings with China, Japan, and South Korea planned for May. Financial technology (fintech) is identified as a key area of cooperation, with Asean launching the Asean Financial Innovation Network to facilitate fintech development and financial inclusion.

site_title: Care for some prata and poulet, anyone?
summary: A family's dinner at a French bistro in New York was disrupted when the father, known for his love of Singaporean food, discovered a prata place next door and ordered local dishes despite being already eating. He claimed he would eat quietly in his corner, but the food arrived anyway, and the family finished their meal while he enjoyed his "outside food." The incident was met with amusement and acceptance by the French restaurant staff, and the family ultimately continued their meal with more local treats.

site_title: China vows to fight Trump tariffs 'to the end' as tension rises
summary: China has vowed to counter US President Donald Trump's proposed tariffs "to the end, and at any cost" following Trump's order to consider additional tariffs on $100 billion in Chinese goods. The US president cited "China's unfair retaliation" in response to his earlier list of proposed tariffs covering $50 billion in Chinese products. The statement from Beijing comes after US stock futures tumbled in response to the news, escalating tensions between the two countries.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip on new Trump tariff threat
summary: European shares fell 0.45% on Friday after US President Donald Trump warned of additional tariffs on China, raising concerns about a potential trade war. Despite the threat, losses were limited by gains in defensive stocks like utilities. Investors remain cautious, expecting a trade war to be unlikely, but will closely monitor developments.

site_title: YuuZoo raided by police in SFA probe
summary: Singaporean police raided YuuZoo Corporation's premises, seizing documents and computer equipment in a probe related to the Securities and Futures Act. The raid followed a notice from the Commercial Affairs Department and came after an independent review by Ernst & Young Advisory raised concerns about possible SFA breaches. Chairman and former CEO Thomas Zilliacus has surrendered his passport, and former management staff have been interviewed by the police. The company has agreed to cooperate fully with the investigation and will make further announcements as necessary.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Piloting the digital flight path
summary: Airlines are leveraging digitalization to boost revenue and improve customer experience, as the industry faces thin margins and competitive operating environments. With 17,000 next-gen aircraft set for delivery, airlines have access to vast amounts of data, which can be used to optimize flight paths, predict maintenance needs, and offer targeted services to passengers. Analysts estimate that airlines could save over $5 billion annually through data-driven initiatives, while generating an additional $100 billion in revenue through data monetization. Early adopters, such as Singapore Airlines and AirAsia, are investing in digital transformation, and airlines are exploring new revenue streams through partnerships, targeted advertising, and personalized services.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: ZBJ-SPH joint venture partners retail studies institute to launch Gig Economy Immersion Programme
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) and China's ZBJ Network have launched the Gig Economy Immersion Programme in partnership with Nanyang Polytechnic's Singapore Institute of Retail Studies (SIRS). The programme, costing around S$7,000, aims to educate participants on leveraging freelancers and temporary workers. It will consist of trips to China and offer local courses on entrepreneurship and cost-efficiency. The partnership aims to grow the gig economy in Singapore, with subsidies available for eligible participants.

site_title: Casualties of a US-China trade war
summary: The US-China trade war escalated as China retaliated with tariffs on US agricultural commodities after President Trump imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum. This has led to a downward spiral in global trade, potentially undermining the current global rules and the World Trade Organization. The US dollar has fallen below long-term support levels, indicating a strong downtrend, while the Shanghai Index has plunged to near 3,100. The trade war may accelerate the roll-out of the One Belt One Road, offering investment opportunities.

site_title: Berlin's lively tech scene helps its office boom beat Frankfurt's
summary: Berlin's thriving tech scene has driven a surge in commercial real estate investments, surpassing Frankfurt as the hottest market in Germany. Last year, investors spent over 8 billion euros on office space and other properties, with vacancy rates falling to 2% and rents increasing to an average of 19.20 euros per square meter. The city's vibrant startup scene, including major companies like Uber and SoundCloud, has attracted investors, with the purchase price for office space tripling to 5,200 euros per square meter in the last five years.

site_title: Here's to the oddballs at work
summary: Mavericks and misfits are not just tolerated, but needed in today's fast-changing work environment. Companies are realizing that these individuals with wild ideas and a passion for challenging the status quo are essential for innovation and growth. However, they are often unappreciated and may struggle with team dynamics. To tap into this talent, companies must create a safe environment where employees feel comfortable sharing their ideas, experiment, and learn from failure. Leaders must also recognize the importance of diversity in hiring and address potential bad behavior, such as bullying or corruption, to maintain a positive internal culture.

site_title: 103,000 jobs added in March; jobless rate stays at 4.1%
summary: The US economy added 103,000 jobs in March, the smallest increase since September, but the labor market remains tight, allowing the Federal Reserve to consider further interest rate hikes. Despite a moderation in job growth, wage gains picked up, indicating a labor market nearing full employment. The construction and retail sectors shed jobs, while employers struggle to find qualified workers.

images.alt_text: The US economy created the fewest jobs in six months in March as the boost from mild temperatures faded, but a pickup in wage gains pointed to a tightening labour market, which should allow the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates further this year.

site_title: The art of the flail
summary: US President Donald Trump's trade threats against China have led to stock market fluctuations, with investors fearing a potential trade war. However, the administration's incoherent approach, veering between threats and reassurances, has raised doubts about the likelihood of a trade war. China's trade surplus with the US, which Trump claims is $500 billion, is actually less than $340 billion, and trade policy has little to do with the US trade deficit. A trade war would devastate rural America and the global economy, and it's unclear why the US would demand China to stop assembling products for the US market. The situation is characterized as "the art of the flail," with Trump's tweets and statements creating market uncertainty.

site_title: SPH Reit maintains Q2 DPU at 1.4 cents
summary: SPH Reit has maintained its Q2 distribution per unit (DPU) at 1.40 Singapore cents, unchanged from last year. The Reit's net property income slipped 1.1% to S$42.3 million, mainly due to lower revenue from Paragon retail mall. Despite negative rental reversions, the Reit's portfolio remains full-occupied, and tenant sales have grown. The Reit manager expressed optimism for Paragon's potential benefits from the recent retail sales recovery and a forecasted GDP growth of 1.5-3.5%.

site_title: OCBC's CEO gets 15.6% pay increase
summary: OCBC Bank's CEO Samuel Tsien received a 15.6% pay increase in 2017 to S$9.69 million, including a salary of S$1.24 million and a bonus of S$5.03 million. This follows a 20% pay cut in 2016. The bank's chairman and CEO warned of the threat of protectionism and risks that could derail regional growth prospects, citing potential miscalculations and erosion of confidence due to geopolitical posturing.

site_title: George Soros prepares to trade cryptocurrencies as prices plunge
summary: George Soros' US$26 billion family office is planning to trade cryptocurrencies after calling them a bubble in January. Soros Fund Management, led by Adam Fisher, has obtained internal approval to trade virtual coins, but no wager has been made yet. Soros previously stated that digital coins cannot function as actual currencies due to their volatility, contradicting some forecasts of their hard tumble.

site_title: Qatar announces comeback deal
summary: Qatar is set to issue its first international bonds since a 2017 dispute with Gulf neighbors, meeting investors in the UK and US from April 9-11. The $5, $10, and $30-year US dollar notes are expected to be rated Aa3/AA-/AA- and are seen as having strong fundamentals. The move is seen as a positive sign for the country's economy, despite ongoing tensions with Saudi Arabia, the UAE, and Bahrain. Qatar's last bond issuance was in June 2016, raising $9 billion.

site_title: Asean remains open to trade, financial inclusion: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Singapore's Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat stated that ASEAN remains open to trade and financial inclusion, aiming to boost investments and send a strong signal against escalating trade tensions. ASEAN members want to integrate economies and benefit those negatively affected by globalization through free and open trade. Heng emphasized the importance of openness in trade, noting that it has lifted millions out of poverty, and the region will continue to work closely to open up more investment avenues.

site_title: China urges EU to 'act together' against US protectionism
summary: China urged the European Union to take a united stance against US protectionism, warning that a joint stand was crucial to preserving the multilateral trade order. China's commerce ministry has vowed to pay any cost in the trade spat with the US, while the EU has reacted cautiously, emphasizing the need for trade measures within the World Trade Organization framework. The EU is also facing its own trade drama with the US, under threat of crippling steel and aluminum tariffs. China's President Donald Trump warned of another $100 billion in tariffs on China's imports, fueling fears of a global trade war.

site_title: Everything you need to know about Fortnite and why it's so popular
summary: Fortnite, a battle royale game, has become an international obsession, captivating 150 million players worldwide. Its free-to-play model, social media presence, and high-quality gameplay have contributed to its success. The game's "battle royale" mode, released in September, has become the most-watched game on Twitch and YouTube Gaming, with a record-breaking 628,000 concurrent viewers. Analysts compare Fortnite's popularity to other big titles, such as World of Warcraft and Minecraft, and estimate its revenue to be around $126 million in February, with potential growth as the game moves to mobile.

site_title: MAS reminds financial institutions to stay vigilant against fraudulent fund transfers
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued an advisory to financial institutions to remain vigilant against fraudulent fund transfers, particularly those using the SWIFT system. MAS' chief cyber security officer, Tan Yeow Seng, emphasized the importance of strengthening security measures, including implementing a layered security approach and monitoring SWIFT messages. The central bank regularly assesses financial institutions' cyber resilience and requires them to develop remedial plans if vulnerabilities are identified. This advisory comes after recent cyber incidents overseas where attackers attempted fraudulent fund transfers.

site_title: Midas Holdings' board to travel to China for due diligence, to hold shareholders dialogue
summary: Midas Holdings, a beleaguered railway-parts maker, will send its board to China for due diligence on its Chinese subsidiaries. The board will meet with staff to obtain information on cash validation, litigations, and undisclosed subsidiaries, after receiving limited cooperation. The company is also planning a shareholders' dialogue to address concerns, following several litigations and unauthorised loans. Trading has been suspended since February, and the Singapore Exchange has demanded the resignation of top executives. The dialogue session aims to address shareholder questions on corporate developments.

site_title: Malaysia: shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Friday, down 0.88 points to 1,837.01, with losers outnumbering gainers 589 to 383. The FTSE index saw 3.03 billion shares traded worth RM2.4 billion.

site_title: Global Dragon acquires Katong Omega Apartments for S$46.31m
summary: Global Dragon Limited, a Singapore-listed company, acquired Katong Omega Apartments through a collective sale for S$46.31 million, the highest bid in a contest of seven bidders. The acquisition was made by wholly owned subsidiary GDL Land Pte Ltd. following the close of the public tender on April 5.

site_title: Poisoned Russian spy Skripal 'improving rapidly,' hospital says
summary: Sergei Skripal, the Russian double agent poisoned in England, is "improving rapidly" at a hospital, according to a statement by the medical director. Skripal was poisoned with Novichok, a Soviet-era nerve agent, on March 4. The UK has blamed Russia for the attack, leading to expulsions of over 150 Russian diplomats. Russia demands proof and involvement in any investigation.

site_title: Uber rival Didi makes Mexico launch official, recruits drivers
summary: Chinese ride-hailing company Didi Chuxing has officially launched in Mexico, marking its first launch outside Asia. The company has set up a website advertising its service to drivers and passengers, with operations expected to begin "very soon". Mexico's clogged streets and growing smartphone user base make it an ideal market for app-based ride services, potentially setting the stage for a showdown with rival Uber.

site_title: Hyflux awarded 68.7m euros deal for seawater desalination package in Iran
summary: Hyflux has been awarded a 68.7 million euro contract by Asia Water Development Engineering Company to design, manufacture, and supply a seawater reverse osmosis desalination package in Bandar Abbas, Iran. The project, valued at S$110 million, will produce 200,000 cubic meters of water per day and is part of a proposed 1 million cubic meter per day desalination plant. The contract is expected to contribute to Hyflux's financials by the end of 2018, addressing Iran's growing domestic water scarcity and serving industries in the southeast region.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as trade war fears escalate
summary: US stock indexes opened lower on Friday, down 0.96% due to escalating trade war fears between the US and China, despite lower-than-expected March jobs data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 234.05 points to 24,271.17, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite dropped 22.96 and 78.46 points, respectively. The declines outweighed concerns over aggressive interest rate hikes.

site_title: ZBJ-SPH joint venture ZomWork ties up with SIRS to launch Gig Economy Immersion Programme
summary: ZomWork, a joint venture between China's ZBJ Network and Singapore Press Holdings, has partnered with Singapore Institute of Retail Studies to launch the Gig Economy Immersion Programme. The programme, costing approximately S$7,000, aims to equip local professionals with skills to thrive in the gig economy, drawing from China's thriving model. Participants will embark on trips to China to learn from local companies and government officials. The revamped website, launched alongside the programme, features an escrow payment system and a transaction record space.

site_title: Flawless white diamonds, among largest ever offered, to go on sale
summary: Two flawless white diamonds, a 51.71 carat round brilliant-cut and a 50.39 carat oval, are set to be auctioned in May for over $15 million each. The diamonds, discovered in Botswana, are the second-largest of their kind ever to come to auction. The sale comes after a 102 carat white diamond sold for over $260,000 per carat in February, surpassing the previous record price for a colorless diamond. The diamonds will be auctioned alongside "The Farnese Blue," a 6 carat blue diamond passed down through four European royal families.

site_title: US job gains smallest in six months, wage growth picks up
summary: The US economy created the fewest jobs in six months in March, with nonfarm payrolls increasing by 103,000. This follows a 326,000 surge in February. Wage growth picked up, suggesting a tightening labor market. The labor market is moderating as temperatures returned to normal and job growth is also slowing down due to full employment. Employers in construction and manufacturing sectors are struggling to find qualified workers.

images.alt_text: The US economy created the fewest jobs in six months in March as the boost from mild temperatures faded, but a pickup in wage gains pointed to a tightening labor market, which should allow the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates further this year.

site_title: SGX daily turnover up 4% to S$1.3b in March
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 4% increase in daily turnover to S$1.32 billion in March, a 16.7% increase in the first quarter to S$1.45 billion. Total turnover for the month was 4.8% lower year-on-year due to fewer trading days. The number of traded shares declined 26.3%, while derivatives market volumes rose 18.5%. The SGX attributes the higher turnover to increased share prices, despite a decline in actual traded shares.

site_title: Singapore shares shrug off trade tension to end higher
summary: Singapore shares ended higher on Friday, shrugging off the latest US-China trade conflict as a mere battle of words. The Straits Times Index rose 1.08% to 3,442.5, driven by gains from HPH Trusts, Genting Singapore, and Wilmar International. Volume doubled to over two billion shares, with 197 gainers to 225 losers. The rally marks the fifth consecutive day of gains ahead of GDP data and amid US-EU trade talks.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks, China H-shares end higher but trade woes cap gains
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 1.1% on Friday, catching up to global market gains, but gains were capped by the threat of US tariffs against China. The Hang Seng index ended at 29,844.94, with China's H-shares index closing 0.9% higher. Investors shifted to sectors less exposed to the trade dispute, with energy and IT shares rising 1.8% and 1.58%, respectively. China warned it would fight back with fresh measures if the US imposes additional tariffs, but investors remain cautiously optimistic about a potential compromise.

site_title: Chinese online lender Weidai planning US$400m IPO
summary: Chinese peer-to-peer lender Weidai Hangzhou Financial Information Service Co plans to raise approximately US$400 million through an initial public offering (IPO) in the US. The company aims to list shares as soon as this year, following a revival in Chinese fintech IPOs. Weidai, which provides cash lending and car financing products, has processed over 160 billion yuan of transactions since its operations started in 2011. The IPO would be the first major listing of a Chinese financial technology company in the US or Hong Kong since 2016.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Noble Group faces high financing costs, potentially jeopardizing its restructuring efforts. Ezion Holdings plans to raise up to S$50 million through a share and options deal. Daily turnover on SGX increased 4% in March to S$1.3 billion, while daily volume fell 26%. ExxonMobil installed a new lubes reactor in its Singapore refinery expansion project. The STI ended higher, up 1.08% from its previous day's close. International news includes Malaysia seizing RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets, China's GDP growth set to slow, and the UK economy shrinking for the second month.

site_title: Former South Korea president Park Geun Hye jailed 24 years for corruption
summary: Former South Korean President Park Geun-hye was jailed for 24 years for corruption, following a trial that lasted over 10 months and found her guilty on multiple charges including bribery and abuse of power. Park, 66, had boycotted most of the trial, and her secret confidante Choi Soon-sil was sentenced to 20 years in prison. The scandal led to public fury and ridicule, and Park's legacy is now one of being the first democratically-elected leader to be forced from office.

site_title: Britain's sugar tax on soft drinks comes into effect
summary: Britain's sugar tax on soft drinks came into effect on April 6, 2018, aiming to reduce sugar intake and combat childhood obesity. The tax has already led to a 45 million kg reduction in sugar content per year, with over 50% of manufacturers reformulating their products to meet the levy's sugar threshold. The tax is expected to raise £240 million in its first year, less than half of its prior forecast, due to the reformulations. The move is seen as a ground-breaking policy to reduce sugar intake and fund sports programs for children.

site_title: SPH Reit maintains Q2 DPU at 1.40 Singapore cents
summary: SPH Reit has maintained its second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) at 1.40 Singapore cents, unchanged from last year. The Reit's net property income slipped 1.1% to S$42.3 million, mainly due to lower revenue from Paragon mall. Gross revenue dipped 0.8% year-over-year to S$53.59 million, with negative rental reversions in two shopping malls. Despite this, tenant sales have grown and the malls have maintained full occupancy. The Reit's CEO expressed confidence in the malls' performance, citing a recovery in retail sales since 2017.

site_title: ExxonMobil installs new lubes reactor in Singapore refinery expansion project
summary: ExxonMobil has successfully installed a new lubes reactor at its Singapore refinery as part of its expansion project. The 800-tonne reactor, measuring 46 meters long and four meters wide, was transported from India and took six hours to reach the refinery. The project is on track for completion in the second quarter of next year, with the expansion expected to strengthen the global supply of its EHC Group II product line, enabling customers to blend lubricants with improved performance and reduced emissions.

site_title: GM workers in South Korea trash CEO office after company holds back bonus
summary: GM Korea workers in South Korea violently protested the company's decision to withhold bonuses due to a cash crisis. Approximately a dozen union members stormed the CEO's office, destroying furniture and equipment, and urged the CEO to resign. The incident resulted in significant damage to company property. GM Korea described the event as a "violent incident." The company's decision to withhold bonuses sparked the protest, with the union calling for the CEO's resignation.

site_title: China bitcoin miner eyes IPO, prefers to list outside mainland
summary: Canaan Creative, a Chinese company that produces cryptocurrency mining equipment, is considering an initial public offering (IPO) outside mainland China, citing the country's tightening regulations on digital currencies. The company, which saw a surge in demand for its mining machines in 2017, is open to listing on any suitable venue but prefers to do so abroad. This move comes as China cracks down on the cryptocurrency market, with the price of bitcoin dropping over 50% in 2018 amid increased scrutiny and regulations.

site_title: Facebook faces Indonesian police investigation over data breach
summary: Facebook is facing an investigation by Indonesian police over a data breach, with over 1 million users' information potentially shared with Cambridge Analytica. The country's communications minister has threatened to shut down the social media platform and imposed penalties of up to 12 years in jail and $1 million for Facebook employees who breached Indonesian privacy rules. Facebook has taken steps to improve its privacy tools, but the incident has sparked concerns and advertisers have paused spending.

site_title: Uber-Grab deal: Uber app extended to April 15
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) has extended the shutdown date of the Uber app in Singapore from April 8 to April 15, allowing both Uber and Grab to propose alternative interim measures to preserve competition. The CCCS had previously suspected that Grab and Uber had infringed on the Competition Act, proposing interim measures that would keep the companies independent in pricing, product options, and business operations. The CCCS will now deliberate on the proposed measures before making a final decision.

site_title: South Korea's ex-president Park Geun Hye found guilty of bribery, abuse of power
summary: South Korea's former President Park Geun Hye was found guilty of bribery and abuse of power by a court, ruling she colluded with friend Choi Soon-sil to receive billions of won from conglomerates like Samsung and Lotte. Prosecutors are seeking a 30-year sentence and 118.5 billion won fine. Park, 66, denied wrongdoing and was not present in court.

site_title: Nissan eyes bigger East African market with Kenya car plant
summary: Nissan plans to assemble vehicles in Kenya, bolstering government efforts to develop a regional car-manufacturing hub in East Africa. The Japanese carmaker will initially produce pick-up trucks from semi-knocked-down kits, with a proposal to be submitted to the government after market studies and assessments. If approved, the facility could be operational by the end of 2019 and cut new-vehicle costs for customers in the region. Nissan prefers starting with half-finished vehicles to build market share and a skilled workforce, and considers partnering with existing plants in Kenya.

images.alt_text: Nissan Motor plans to start assembling vehicles in Kenya, bolstering government plans to develop a regional car-manufacturing hub in East Africa's biggest economy.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes afternoon trading at 3,426.81, up 0.6% on the day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading with a 0.6% gain, reaching 3,426.81 as of 1:01pm. The Straits Times Index rose 21.16 points, with 902.3 million shares worth S$644.2 million traded. Losers outnumbered gainers 196 to 148, driven by a decline in Cosco Shipping International (Singapore) Co. and a rise in Genting Singapore plc.

site_title: Australia shares steady as trade war fears intensify; NZ up
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Friday, awaiting China's response to US President Donald Trump's proposed $100 billion tariff plan on Chinese goods. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 10 basis points lower at 5,788.7, after a three-week run of losses. Gains in materials stocks countered losses in financials, with miner BHP and mall operator Westfield Corp rising. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.4 per cent, driven by gains in materials and consumer discretionary stocks. Investors expect China to soften its tone behind the scenes, but remain cautious amid escalating trade tensions.

site_title: Atlantic Navigation gets US$29.8m term loan facility
summary: Atlantic Navigation, a wholly owned subsidiary of Atlantic Navigation Holdings, has secured a US$29.8 million, seven-year term loan from a UAE banker to finance the acquisition of seven new vessels. The loan will support long-term charters worth US$236 million with a national oil company in the Middle East. The company has drawn down US$20.4 million of the loan to purchase the first five vessels, which are on their way to the Middle East to fulfill their charters.

site_title: The 9-Year Rule for Director Independence: To vote or not to vote?
summary: The "nine-year rule" for independent directors in corporate governance is a debated recommendation. The Corporate Governance Council provided two alternate implementation options. The rule aims to ensure that independent directors are not too closely tied to the company. However, the exact implementation timing remains unclear, sparking debate on whether to vote or not to vote. The outcome of the vote will determine the future of this key recommendation.

site_title: US job growth seen slowing in March, jobless rate likely fell
summary: US job growth likely slowed in March due to cooler temperatures, but still remained strong, with a predicted 193,000 jobs added. The unemployment rate is forecast to fall to 4% for the first time since December 2000. Wage growth remained moderate, with average hourly earnings expected to rise 0.2% for the month. Economists expect the slowdown in job growth to be temporary, with employment growth likely to pick up in the second half of the year.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end lower on renewed US-China trade war fears
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index closed down 0.33% on Friday due to heightened US-China trade war fears, despite Samsung Electronics reporting record March-quarter profit. The Korean won fell further, while bond yields decreased. LG Electronics' stock rose 5.7% after beating market expectations with a 20% increase in first-quarter operating profit. The benchmark index shed 0.7% for the week, while Samsung Electronics fell 0.7% after a 4% gain on Thursday.

site_title: Asean's growth can be 'dramatically' affected by headwinds: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Singapore's Minister of Finance Heng Swee Keat warned that ASEAN's growth can be "dramatically" affected by headwinds including trade tensions and technological disruptions. Despite growing 5.1% in 2017, ASEAN faces challenges such as rising protectionism, technological disruptions, and demographic trends. To address these challenges, ASEAN finance ministers are focusing on sustaining growth through infrastructure financing, boosting resilience through disaster financing and cyber resilience, and fostering innovation through new technology. Working together, ASEAN can rise to meet these challenges.

site_title: Mobike partners SMRT-backed company to enable 'smarter transport planning'
summary: Mobike, a Chinese bicycle-sharing company, has partnered with SMRT-backed mobilityX to share data analytics and enable smarter transport planning. The deal will allow Mobike to load its bike-share services onto mobilityX's "jalan2" app and will also provide insights from Mobike's smart bicycle locks and Internet of Things-enabled two-wheelers. The partnership aims to boost first and last-mile connectivity for urban journeys in Singapore, with SMRT Services deploying manpower to manage Mobike bicycle parking at MRT stations. The collaboration is expected to optimize operational efficiency and provide integrated mobility-as-a-service solutions to commuters.
