site_title: Facebook faces Indonesian police investigation over data breach
summary: Facebook is facing an investigation by Indonesian police over a data breach, with the country's communications minister threatening to shut down the social media platform. The breach may have affected over 1 million Indonesian Facebook users, who could face up to 12 years in jail and a fine of $1 million if found to have breached Indonesian privacy rules. Facebook has taken steps to improve its privacy tools and has coordinated with law enforcement to address the issue.

site_title: Scoot bomb scare: Passenger thought threat was a joke
summary: A Scoot flight from Singapore to Hat Yai, Thailand, was diverted back to Changi Airport on Thursday after a passenger allegedly made a bomb threat, claiming to have a device in his carry-on baggage. The plane, carrying 173 passengers and six crew members, was met with two Republic of Singapore Air Force F-15SG jets, which escorted the plane back to Singapore. Despite the intense security measures, passengers were not informed of the reason for the diversion until after the plane landed. The suspect, a 41-year-old Singaporean man, was detained and arrested for making a false claim of a terrorist act.

site_title: South Korea's political princess lands in prison
summary: South Korea's former President Park Geun-hye, known as the "political princess," has been sentenced to 24 years in prison for corruption. The 66-year-old politician, who was the first female president of South Korea, was convicted of abuse of power and bribery. She will spend the next two decades behind bars after her conviction. Park's rise to power was marked by her pampered upbringing as the eldest child of former President Park Chung-hee, who ruled the country from 1961 to 1979. Her spectacular fall from grace is a rare example of a South Korean president being held accountable for corruption.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks opened higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 1.06% higher, adding 316.61 points to 29,835.3, despite US threats to slap an additional $100 billion of tariffs on Beijing in a growing trade dispute. The Shanghai, Shenzhen, and Taipei financial markets were closed for a public holiday.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks down on late profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks fell on Friday, closing 0.36% lower at 21,567.52, as late profit-taking erased early gains in thin trading. The Nikkei 225 index lost 77.90 points, while the Topix index fell 5.31 points. Investors remain cautious ahead of US jobs data, with traders in a wait-and-see mode.

site_title: Daily turnover on SGX grew 4% in March to S$1.3b, but daily volume fell 26%
summary: Daily turnover on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) grew 4% in March to S$1.3 billion, with an average of S$1.32 billion of trades per session. However, daily volume fell 26% to 1.8 billion shares. Total turnover for the quarter increased 16.7% to S$1.45 billion, while derivatives daily average volume rose 18.5% to 822,594 contracts. The decline in volume was attributed to share prices rising over the year.

site_title: Singapore seen poised for first monetary policy tightening in six years: poll
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), is expected to tighten monetary policy for the first time in six years, according to a Reuters poll. Twelve of 19 analysts predict a slight increase in the appreciation rate of the Singapore dollar's policy band from zero per cent, while seven expect policy to remain unchanged. The decision is driven by solid economic growth and improving labor market conditions, outweighing risks from US-China trade tensions. The MAS is expected to adjust its stance to a more neutral one, allowing for modest and gradual appreciation of the Singapore dollar.

site_title: Malaysia's Parliament to be dissolved on April 7, paving way for all-out election battle
summary: Malaysia's Parliament will be dissolved on April 7, paving the way for a nationwide election. Prime Minister Najib Razak has declared this election a "do-or-die" battle, with the opposition, led by former premier Mahathir Mohamad, painting it as a crucial opportunity to unseat him. The election, expected to take place in early May, will determine the future of Malaysia's government and institutions, with analysts predicting a multi-cornered fight and a potential loss of Malay support for the ruling Barisan Nasional (BN) party.

site_title: Mahathir vows to fight 30-day party ban ahead of Malaysia vote
summary: Former Malaysian premier Mahathir Mohamad vowed to fight a 30-day ban on his party, Parti Pribumi Bersatu Malaysia, ahead of the country's election. The ban was issued by the Registry of Societies Malaysia after Mahathir's party failed to submit required information and documents by the deadline. Mahathir plans to appeal the ban and continue campaigning, promising to achieve a 6% growth rate and introduce new economic policies if his coalition wins the election.

site_title: Monex to buy hacked cryptocurrency exchange Coincheck for 3.6b yen
summary: Japanese online brokerage firm Monex Group Inc. will acquire hacked cryptocurrency exchange Coincheck Inc. for 3.6 billion yen (S$44.2 million). Monex will execute the deal on April 16, with Coincheck's CEO and COO resigning and becoming executive directors. Monex will gain access to Coincheck's trading platform and customer base, and Coincheck generated 471 million yen in net income for the year ended in March. This deal brings a mainstream financial services operator into the frontier cryptocurrency trading market in Japan.

site_title: IndiGo ends interest in buying Air India
summary: IndiGo, India's largest airline, has ended its interest in buying Air India, dealing a blow to the government's privatisation campaign. IndiGo expressed interest in acquiring Air India's international routes and low-cost arm Air India Express, but not its domestic operations. The airline cited a lack of capability to take on Air India's entire operations. The government aims to sell a 76% stake in the debt-laden carrier, with Air India needing more bailout funds to turn around. This decision may impact the government's privatisation plans for the national carrier.

site_title: Singapore seen poised for first monetary policy tightening in six years: poll
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), is expected to tighten its monetary policy for the first time in six years, according to a Reuters poll. Twelve analysts predict the MAS will slightly increase the appreciation rate of the Singapore dollar's policy band from zero per cent, which has been unchanged since April 2016. The move is seen as a response to solid economic growth and improved labor market conditions, outweighing risks from US-China trade tensions. The MAS review is set for April 13.

site_title: China has more to lose in a trade war, but Trump has a key weakness
summary: US President Donald Trump is facing a challenging trade war with China, with China having more to lose economically. China's exports to the US, worth $506 billion, are a significant portion of its economy, while the US only sold $130 billion to China. Trump's administration lacks clear and coherent demands, allowing China to play the victim and gain sympathy. China has more levers to retaliate, including stopping cooperation on North Korea, selling US debt, and making life harder for US companies in China. The Chinese strategy appears to be to anger farmers, business leaders, and Republicans in Congress to pressure Trump to back down.

site_title: Iceberg says new Noble has 'zero chance of success'; Goldilocks objects to newest directors
summary: Noble Group faces financial risk despite restructuring plans, according to Iceberg Research, which believes the company's future is at risk due to unsustainable financing costs. Goldilocks Investment Company, a substantial shareholder, also expressed concerns about the board's representation of shareholders' interests following the appointment of three UK-based directors. Iceberg stated that Noble's restructuring plan has "zero chance of success".

site_title: Enterprise Singapore teams up to launch three human resource initiatives
summary: Enterprise Singapore has launched three human resource initiatives in collaboration with the Ministry of Manpower and other agencies. The initiatives aim to improve access to self-help human resources, scale up human resource shared services, and promote the use of data and technology for better decision making. The new measures include an online self-help portal, an enhanced HR Shared Services Scheme, and an HR Tech pilot to improve job fit and individualized training programs.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks slip; Samsung Elec skids on profit-booking
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 0.29% to 2,430.40 on Friday, weighed down by Samsung Electronics' 1.4% decline after a surprise profit booking. The Korean won slumped 0.54% against the US dollar, while bond yields fell. The Kospi is down 1.2% this year and up 0.32% in the past 30 days, with foreigners selling 130 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: Chinese state media slams latest US tariff call as 'ridiculous' attempt at intimidation
summary: Chinese state media has condemned US President Donald Trump's threat of additional $100 billion tariffs on China, calling it a "ridiculous" attempt at intimidation. The move escalates a trade dispute between the two nations, with China already imposing its own tariffs on US imports. The US has proposed $50 billion in duties to force China to address intellectual property theft and forced technology transfer. China's foreign minister, Wang Yi, accused the US of picking the "wrong target" with its tariffs, and warned that the US should respect China as an equal.

site_title: Samsung profit tops estimates bolstered by memory-chip demand
summary: Samsung Electronics Co. reported higher-than-estimated profit in the first quarter, with operating income rising to 15.6 trillion won, exceeding analyst projections. Strong demand for memory chips, used in phones and servers, offset concerns about display supplies to Apple, the company's largest customer. This is expected to keep Samsung on track to post record profits for the year, with its semiconductor business driving the majority of its profit.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mixed on new trade move; yen rises
summary: Asian stocks were mixed on Friday after US President Donald Trump ordered his administration to consider tariffs on an additional $100 billion worth of Chinese imports, dashing investor optimism about easing trade tensions. Japanese shares rose, while South Korean equities fell, and US stock futures declined. The yen rose 0.3% to 107.12 against the US dollar, while crude oil prices dropped 0.6% and gold rose 0.3%.

site_title: Singapore to issue MAS policy statement, Q1 GDP data on April 13
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will release its semiannual monetary policy statement and first-quarter GDP data on April 13. The MAS is expected to tighten its exchange rate-based policy for the first time in six years, driven by solid economic growth and improving labour market conditions. The government's advance estimate of Q1 GDP is also set to be released at the same time.

site_title: No jobs, no vote: Indian town warns Modi ahead of 2019 polls
summary: In the Indian town of Kasba Bonli, residents are expressing dissatisfaction with Prime Minister Narendra Modi's failure to create jobs, despite his promise to do so. Rakesh Kumar, a 31-year-old post-graduate with no salaried job, blames the government for not delivering on its promise. The unemployment rate in India has hit its highest level in 16 months, with nearly two-thirds of the population under 35 years old seeking employment. Modi's popularity remains high, but the lack of jobs could be a major issue in the upcoming 2019 general election.

images.alt_text: Rakesh Kumar has a post-graduate degree but works as a house painter in the small town of Kasba Bonli in northwestern India.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars hold ground in the face of trade headwinds
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars held ground despite US President Donald Trump's announcement of additional US$100 billion in tariffs on China, which fueled global market volatility. The Aussie dollar initially fell 30 ticks to US$0.7658 but rebounded to US$0.765, finding solid support. The resilient currency performance is attributed to the fact that the Australian and New Zealand dollars have been stable for over a week.

site_title: China's HNA adds US$6.5b Hilton stake to global property selloff
summary: HNA Group Co, a debt-laden Chinese conglomerate, plans to sell its US$6.5 billion stake in Hilton Worldwide Holdings, part of a global asset purge. HNA owns 26% of Hilton's stock and has already sold stakes in two spinoffs. The sale is seen as a step to remove an "overhang" and alleviate pressure on the company. If successful, HNA stands to make a paper profit of nearly US$2.35 billion. This move follows HNA's recent disposals of properties and reduction of stakes in other companies.

site_title: Prince Charles backs 'blue economy' to save Barrier Reef
summary: Prince Charles has called for a "blue economy" to promote sustainable use of ocean resources and save Australia's Great Barrier Reef, which is suffering from coral bleaching due to climate change. He emphasized the need for wise management of coral reef ecosystems as natural capital assets. The prince's visit prompted A$10 million in donations for conservation efforts, with companies including Lendlease, BHP, and Qantas committing to support the cause. Charles stressed the importance of transitioning to a low-carbon economy and acting before it's too late to save the reef.

images.alt_text: Prince Charles has called for a "blue economy" to promote the sustainable use of ocean resources and save Australia's Great Barrier Reef, as he visits the World Heritage-listed ecosystem on Friday.

site_title: If there is a trade war, China may have some 'unconventional weapons'
summary: A potential trade war between the US and China could lead to unconventional tactics, as traditional rules of commerce may not apply. China may employ "unconventional weapons" in a trade war, including state-backed hacking, cyber attacks, and intellectual property theft. This could be a response to US tariffs and trade restrictions. The escalation of tensions could also lead to a slowdown in China's GDP growth, putting pressure on policymakers to address the economic implications.

site_title: Malaysia's Parliament to be dissolved on April 7, paving way for all-out election battle
summary: Malaysia's Parliament will be dissolved on April 7, paving the way for an all-out election battle. The government and opposition have described the election as a "do-or-die" battle, with Prime Minister Najib Razak warning that a poor performance could spell the end for his parties. The ruling Barisan Nasional has announced handouts to crucial votebanks, while opposition leader Mahathir Mohamad's entry into the opposition sees an alliance of once bitter foes. The election is expected to take place in early May, with the Muslim fasting month beginning in mid-May.

site_title: Japan's cryptocurrency exchanges face shortage of engineers
summary: Japan's cryptocurrency exchanges face a shortage of engineers, contributing to recent security breaches. Coincheck Inc. cited a lack of skilled workers as a factor in a $530 million hack. Despite efforts to expand through headhunters, the company struggled to fill gaps in security and system risk management. This shortage is attributed to Japan's limited supply of software engineers, hindering the industry's ability to improve security and prevent similar breaches.

site_title: Ezion to raise up to S$50m in share and options deal with Temasek's Pavilion
summary: Ezion Holdings, an offshore and marine group, plans to raise up to S$50 million through a share and options deal with Temasek-linked Pavilion Capital Fund Holdings. Pavilion will acquire a 4.43% stake in Ezion by buying 96.2 million shares and receiving options that could be converted into shares. Ezion intends to use the funds for business expansion, debt repayment, and working capital. The deal comes as Ezion has emerged from a debt refinancing exercise and marks Pavilion's second investment in the offshore and marine sector.

site_title: Malaysia's Najib attends cabinet meeting ahead of expected election announcement
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak is set to dissolve parliament and call for an election ahead of his term's end on June 24. The move comes amid pressure to address a multi-billion dollar scandal and rising living costs. Najib's cabinet meeting, attended by several ministers, was seen as a step towards securing a stronger mandate. The king's consent is expected to be sought later in the day, paving the way for a general election. Najib's five-year term officially ends on June 24, but he can dissolve parliament anytime before then.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.05 points, or 0.06%, to 1839.05. The market saw 221 losers compared to 123 gainers, with a total volume of 129 million lots worth RM50 million.

site_title: Chinese double amputee to climb Everest after ban revoked
summary: A Chinese double amputee, Xia Boyu, 69, has been granted a permit to climb Mount Everest after Nepal's top court overturned a ban on blind and double amputee climbers. The ban was introduced in December, but disability advocacy groups successfully overturned it, citing the UN convention on the rights of people with disabilities. Xia, who lost both legs to frostbite in 1975, has attempted to summit Everest five times and hopes to finally reach the summit this year.

site_title: Japan animation giant Takahata of 'Grave of the Fireflies' fame dies at 82
summary: Japanese animation director Isao Takahata, co-founder of Studio Ghibli and creator of "Grave of the Fireflies," has died at 82. Takahata passed away at a Tokyo hospital after a recent bout of illness, according to public broadcaster NHK. He was best known for his Oscar-nominated film "The Tale of the Princess Kaguya" and "Grave of the Fireflies," a moving tale of two orphans during World War II. Takahata co-founded Studio Ghibli with Hayao Miyazaki in 1985 and produced around 20 films throughout his career.

site_title: Trump renews attack on Amazon, vows 'very serious look' at business
summary: US President Donald Trump announced plans to examine Amazon.com Inc and what he claims is an "uneven playing field" for the retailer, criticizing its tax treatment and postal rates. Trump vowed to take a "very serious look" at Amazon, despite earlier assurances that no punitive measures would be taken. The comments came as Amazon shares rose for the third day in a row, shrugging off Trump's repeated attacks since last week.

site_title: Libor bites as Asia dollar bonds see worst start since 1997
summary: Asian dollar bonds saw their worst first-quarter returns in two decades, with dollar-denominated notes in Asia ex-Japan losing 1.3% in the three months through March 31. The decline was driven by rising short-term interest rates and investors unwinding leveraged positions due to higher borrowing costs. Asia dollar bond issuance declined 37% in March, and private banks have become less active in leveraged purchases. The weakening demand is expected to soften demand for dollar bonds issued by Chinese corporates, which dominate the Asian bond market.

site_title: Asean's growth can be 'dramatically' affected by headwinds: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Singapore's Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat warns that ASEAN's growth can be "dramatically" affected by headwinds including rising protectionism, trade tensions, technological disruptions, and demographic trends. Despite growing at 5.1% in 2017, ASEAN faces challenges that could impact its growth trajectory. To address these, ASEAN finance ministers are focusing on sustaining growth through infrastructure financing, boosting resilience through disaster and cyber financing, and fostering innovation through new technology. By working together, ASEAN can rise to meet these challenges.

site_title: USDA looking for ways to protect farmers in China trade dispute: official
summary: US Department of Agriculture official Bill Northey stated that the USDA is exploring ways to protect farmers from the trade conflict between the US and China. Following US President Donald Trump's decision to impose additional tariffs on China, China retaliated by targeting US agricultural exports, including soybeans. Northey emphasized the need to assess the market reaction and potential tariffs to find suitable protection measures for farmers, but no specific proposals have been proposed yet.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble, FJ Benjamin, Sinjia Land, KTL Global
summary: Noble Group faces opposition from Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX Regco) over a part of its restructuring proposal. FJ Benjamin Holdings' rights cum warrants issue was oversubscribed by 48.6%, raising S$7.8 million and S$27 million in net proceeds. Meanwhile, stocks to watch include Sinjia Land, KTL Global, and others. The STI rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investors' positivity despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: US willing to talk trade with China, no session set yet: official
summary: The US is willing to negotiate with China on trade, but only if talks are serious, according to a senior US official. The official stated that President Trump will insist on "verifiable, enforceable, and measurable deliverables" from China in any trade negotiations. No formal negotiating sessions have been set, but the US has considered imposing $100 billion in additional tariffs on China. The US has also targeted 25% tariffs on some 1,300 industrial products, prompting China to retaliate with duties on US imports, including soybeans and cars.

site_title: US dollar slips vs yen after Trump threatens more tariffs on China
summary: US President Donald Trump instructed US trade officials to consider $100 billion in additional tariffs on China, sparking concerns about global trade and economic growth. The US dollar fell 0.2% to 107.15 yen, while the yen rose against the euro. Market participants await more details on the tariffs, which could deepen the dollar's decline if Japanese and US equities come under pressure. The move follows China's "unfair retaliation" against earlier US trade actions, and may impact US jobs data and Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell's comments later on Friday.

site_title: Sinjia Land's negative working capital widens to S$3.03m after two adjustments
summary: Sinjia Land's negative working capital widened to S$3.03 million after adjusting for S$2.36 million in non-current receivables and providing for impairment of receivables and investment in subsidiaries. This resulted in a widening of accumulated losses to S$9.13 million from S$5.80 million.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Friday's open; STI down 0.43% to 3,390.91
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.43% to 3,390.91 at Friday's open, as US President Donald Trump ordered a further $100 billion in tariffs on Chinese imports. Losers outnumbered gainers 90 to 35, with Jiutian Chemical Group and Cosco Shipping International (Singapore) Co leading the decline. Active index stocks, including United Overseas Bank, DBS Group Holdings, and OCBC Bank, also dropped. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: How to save on wedding flowers
summary: Nathalie Guedes and her husband saved $2,000 on wedding flowers by using discarded marble and renting back their flowers to another couple through Bloomerent, a company that connects brides and grooms with local florists. The service allows the first bride to receive a 10% refund and the second bride to pay 40-60% of the original cost. Experts also suggest saving money by choosing flowers with more volume, selecting focal points in the reception space, and considering DIY alternatives, but caution against attempting to create flowers yourself, as it can be stressful and time-consuming.

site_title: Trump urges US$100b in new China tariffs, stoking tensions
summary: President Donald Trump ordered his administration to consider $100 billion in new tariffs on Chinese imports, stoking US-China trade tensions. This move threatened to unravel efforts to reach a trade agreement, causing US stock futures to drop 1.6% on Thursday. The decision raised concerns about a potential full-blown trade war between the world's two largest economies, potentially harming global markets and trade relations.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump said Thursday he is ordering the US Trade Representative to consider US$100 billion in additional tariffs on Chinese goods, ratcheting up tensions with Beijing after his administration signaled it would be willing negotiate.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open slightly higher after Wall Street gains
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.2% higher, driven by a lower yen and gains on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose to 21,689.36, while the Topix index increased to 1,727.36. This follows a strong rally on US stocks, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: OCBC chief Samuel Tsien gets 15.6% rise in salary in 2017
summary: OCBC Bank's CEO Samuel Tsien received a 15.63% salary increase to S$9.69 million in 2017, compared to S$8.38 million in 2016. This follows a 20% pay cut in 2016 due to the oil rout. DBS Group Holdings' CEO Piyush Gupta and United Overseas Bank's CEO Wee Ee Cheong also saw pay increases in 2017, with Gupta's rise being 23% to S$10.3 million and Wee's rise being 11% to S$9.4 million.

site_title: Japan household spending posts biggest drop in nearly a year
summary: Japan's household spending fell 0.9% in February, the largest annual decline in nearly a year, according to government data. This drop, following a 1.9% increase in January, was the biggest since April last year. The decline is attributed to slow wage growth, keeping consumers from increasing their spending, and has reinforced the view that the economy may be peaking. Core consumer inflation stood at 1% in February, below the Bank of Japan's 2% target, making it challenging for the central bank to achieve its inflation target.

images.alt_text: Japan's household spending suffered the biggest annual decline in nearly a year in February, data showed on Friday, reinforcing the view that slow wage growth is keeping consumers from loosening their purse strings.

site_title: 'You'll be sorry', Russia tells Britain at UN Security Council meet on nerve agent attack
summary: Russia told Britain at the UN Security Council that "you're playing with fire and you'll be sorry" over its accusations of Moscow's involvement in the nerve agent attack on former Russian spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter. This was the second UN Security Council meeting on the issue, following a March 14 meeting at Britain's request. Russia denies involvement, while the attack has led to mass expulsions of diplomats from both Russia and Western countries.

site_title: Saudi crown prince to visit France in whirlwind global tour
summary: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman is set to visit France on a two-day official trip, focusing on cultural ties, investments, and the Yemen crisis. The visit aims to project a new liberal image of the conservative kingdom, following a tumultuous period at home. French President Emmanuel Macron will host the king-in-waiting, treading a delicate line between business deals and diplomatic challenges, including Saudi Arabia's role in the Yemen crisis and the export of arms. The trip comes after a weeks-long tour of the US, Britain, and Egypt, and is part of Prince Mohammed's global tour to garner recognition and acceptance as the de facto leader of Saudi Arabia.

site_title: UN's top court to hear Malaysia v Singapore Pedra Branca case in June
summary: The International Court of Justice (ICJ) will hold public hearings in June on Malaysia's request to overturn a 2008 ruling granting Singapore sovereignty over Pedra Branca/Pulau Batu Puteh, a strategic island in the South China Sea. Malaysia claims the island, citing new documents discovered in British archives, while Singapore maintains its 2008 ruling. The ICJ will hold four days of hearings starting June 11, following Malaysia's lodging of the case in 2017.

site_title: Facebook's Sandberg says data-sharing tool complied with FTC
summary: Facebook's COO Sheryl Sandberg said the company's data-sharing tool complied with a 2011 FTC agreement, allowing a researcher to access 87 million users' data, which was later shared with Cambridge Analytica. The FTC is investigating whether Facebook violated the decree, misled users, or violated data shipment rules between Europe and the US. Sandberg expressed confidence in the tool's compliance.

site_title: Japan Feb real wages fall for third straight month
summary: Japanese workers' wages fell 0.5% in February for the third consecutive month, after adjusting for inflation, indicating consumer spending may slow. This data reinforces the Bank of Japan's inflation target of 2% and suggests the central bank's stimulus program will remain unchanged. Nominal cash earnings rose 1.3% year-over-year, while overtime pay and special payments also increased, but not enough to offset the decline in real wages. The decline in real wages comes as household sentiment worsened and inflation expectations weakened, making it difficult for the central bank to encourage consumer spending.

site_title: Trump breaks silence, claims no knowledge of porn star payment
summary: US President Donald Trump broke a two-month silence on allegations he slept with a porn star, Stormy Daniels, and claims no knowledge of the $130,000 hush money paid to her by his lawyer, Michael Cohen, shortly before the 2016 election. Trump denied knowing about the payment, stating "you'll have to ask Michael Cohen," while Daniels' lawyer Michael Avenatti questioned the president's lack of knowledge, calling it a "deceit under oath."

site_title: Venice Ship Returns
summary: Zai Kuning's 17-metre-long ghost ship, "Dapunta Hyang: Transmission of Knowledge," has returned to Singapore after showcasing at the 57th Venice Biennale. The artwork, made of rattan, string, and beeswax, explores the history and migration of Malays in South-east Asia. The homecoming show at TheatreWorks will feature guided tours, live performances, and talks by experts, and will run from April 12 to May 13, 2018, with free admission.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: US to update Saudi artillery for US$1.31b
summary: The US has approved a $1.31 billion contract to sell 180 self-propelled artillery systems to Saudi Arabia, as part of a larger arms deal. The deal is seen as part of Saudi Arabia's $110 billion plan to purchase US equipment, with Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman visiting the US to strengthen ties. The sale includes medium self-propelled howitzers and equipment to convert them into the M109A6 Paladin artillery system. The US State Department described Saudi Arabia as a "leading contributor of political stability and economic progress in the Middle East."

site_title: Gold prices drop as US-China trade tensions ease
summary: US-China trade tensions ease, signaling a willingness to negotiate, rather than impose tariffs. As a result, gold prices dropped 0.5% to $1,325.81, reaching a one-week low of $1,322.40. Investors shifted to equities, strengthening the dollar and making gold more expensive for other currencies. The easing of tensions is expected to moderate safe-haven demand for gold.

site_title: Oil climbs with equities, Saudi Arabia hikes crude prices
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday, driven by gains in US equities markets and Saudi Arabia's hike in crude prices. Brent crude futures gained 31 US cents to $68.33 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 17 US cents to $63.54 a barrel. The strength of the US dollar limited oil's gains, but analysts attributed the increase to improved market sentiment and Saudi Arabia's move to increase official selling prices. Oil inventories in the US rose, and production hit a new high, but the extent to which it will counterbalance OPEC's output cuts remains uncertain.

site_title: Easing of trade tensions boosts European stocks
summary: European stocks rose 2.4% to their highest level in over two weeks, driven by a decline in trade tensions and gains in financials and industrials stocks. Germany's DAX jumped 2.9%, with heavyweight financials and chipmakers leading the gains. Citi strategists said it's too early to call a bear market, estimating global equities to rise 8% by year-end. Despite concerns over slowing economic indicators, individual stock moves were driven by dealmaking and results, with Telecom Italia and Ubisoft making significant gains.

site_title: Foxconn to produce blockchain phone
summary: Foxconn, a subsidiary of the world's largest electronics manufacturer, has agreed to produce a blockchain phone from Sirin Labs, called the Finney. The device aims to securely store and use digital coins, such as Bitcoin, and related services, and is expected to ship in October. With over 25,000 preorders, Sirin plans to ship 100,000 to a few million units this year, with the goal of eventually selling the device through mobile carriers. The phone's architecture is secure, but experts have raised concerns about potential theft risks. Sirin hopes to license its technology to other phone manufacturers, potentially reducing the price from $1,000 to $200.

site_title: Researcher kills four staff at Turkish university
summary: A researcher at Osmangazi University in western Turkey killed four staff members, including the deputy dean and two lecturers, in a shooting on Thursday. The attacker, identified as Volkan B, a researcher at the education faculty, was detained by police after initially trying to flee. The motive behind the attack is unclear, but the university's rector described the individual as "problematic" and said he targeted the personnel due to psychological problems. The incident is being investigated, with no indication of a link to extremist activity.

images.alt_text: A researcher killed four fellow staff members in a shooting Thursday at a university in the western Turkish city of Eskisehir, in one of the deadliest incidents of its kind seen in Turkey.

site_title: 'Energy islands' among new solar energy projects launched
summary: Singapore has launched "energy islands" made of floating solar panels as part of a project by the Solar Energy Research Institute of Singapore. The project aims to supply electricity to nearby industrial zones or living areas. This initiative marks the 10th anniversary of Seris at the National University of Singapore.

site_title: BlackRock to exclude Walmart from some new funds over guns
summary: BlackRock plans to exclude Walmart, Dick's Sporting Goods, Kroger, American Outdoor Brands, Sturm Ruger & Company, and Vista Outdoor from some new funds due to their gun sales, citing client demand for socially responsible investments. The move comes after a February school shooting in Florida and is part of BlackRock's pledge to meet the needs of clients who do not want to invest in firearms. The funds, worth $2.2 billion, will screen for major gun retailers and manufacturers, offering clients more choice of products that exclude firearms.

site_title: US: Stocks gain for 3rd day as trade fears recede
summary: US stocks rose for the third consecutive day, driven by optimism over a potential trade war being averted and strong earnings expectations ahead. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 1% to 24,505.22, while the S&P 500 rose 0.7% to 2,662.84. Analysts, including Maris Ogg, believe the escalating tariff threats from President Trump and Chinese officials are unlikely to lead to concrete action, instead focusing on the upcoming earnings season. Key gainers included Facebook, Amazon, and Tesla Motors.

site_title: Grenfell survivors still displaced 10 months after blaze
summary: Ten months after the Grenfell Tower fire in London, many of the displaced families still live in hotels or temporary accommodations, with nearly 200 households and 100 families from nearby towers affected. The local council has spent around $280 million on new housing, but many complain that their needs are not being met, with some expressing frustration over the slow pace of the recovery process and the lack of consideration for their expressed preferences.

site_title: Russia is behaving like the 'Beast from the East'
summary: A cold snap from Russia, dubbed the "Beast from the East", has brought severe weather to the UK, causing widespread disruption. The phenomenon, fueled by a Polar Vortex, led to record-breaking snowfall and icy conditions. However, the real "Beast" is Russia's government, accused of orchestrating a nerve agent attack on a British ex-spy and his daughter in Salisbury, leading to international condemnation and expulsions of diplomats. This incident has sparked a re-evaluation of Russia's aggressive actions, including its involvement in the Syrian civil war and annexation of Crimea, prompting calls for increased sanctions and diplomatic pressure.

site_title: CapitaLand launches all-in-one e-payment service
summary: CapitaLand, Singapore's largest mall operator, has launched an all-in-one e-payment service called StarPay, partnering leading e-payment players to cover over 2,500 stores in 17 malls. This move makes CapitaLand the first mall operator in Singapore to offer such a service. The goal is to promote a cashless drive and enhance the shopping experience for customers.

site_title: Indonesia's new bank rules aim to spur credit growth
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, announced new bank rules to spur credit growth by giving banks more flexibility in managing excess liquidity. The goal is to reach double-digit credit growth, as annual bank credit grew 8.2% in February. The rules aim to encourage banks to lend more, following a 200 basis point policy rate cut in 2016 and 2017.

site_title: Cambridge Analytica scandal: 65k local Facebook users affected
summary: A data breach involving Cambridge Analytica has affected over 65,000 Facebook users in Singapore, according to the social media giant. The breach, which is part of a growing scandal, may have improperly shared the information of these users with the data analytics company. Cambridge Analytica, a political consultancy firm, applies data mining and analysis to elections. The incident is part of a larger data breach investigation, but no further details have been released.

site_title: DBS aims for 30% reduction in corporate cheque payments by 2020
summary: DBS Bank aims to reduce corporate cheque payments by 30% by 2020, helping clients adapt to the increasing popularity of digital payments. The bank has seen a five-fold increase in corporate clients requesting digital payment solutions, citing consumer behavior changing rapidly. Instead of issuing cheques, clients can use DBS's PayNow solution to instantly pay retail customers, improving operational efficiency and convenience.

site_title: Appreciating sangiovese for what it is
summary: A wine producer challenges the notion of "perfect ripeness" in Sangiovese grapes, highlighting that the concept is subjective and influenced by factors such as vintage conditions, site, and producer intent. A review of three Rosso di Montalcino wines, La Torre, Le Potazzine, and Lisini, reveals that each exhibited a different degree of ripeness, with the La Torre being picked early, the Lisini being riper, and the Le Potazzine striking a middle ground. The article emphasizes the importance of understanding the producer's intent and the unique characteristics of Sangiovese, rather than relying on marketing claims of "perfect ripeness."

site_title: For AI to succeed, women need to get involved
summary: A growing number of experts believe that women's involvement in AI is crucial for its success, as the technology has the potential to both benefit and harm the workforce. Despite AI's benefits, women are more at risk of job displacement and face limited opportunities in the field. To maximize AI's benefits, it's essential to eliminate human biases and increase access to career opportunities and skills. Women don't need a computer science PhD to get involved, and their diverse perspectives are vital for creating intelligent AI.

site_title: Government monitoring trade spat; Singapore, KL may gain from trade diversion
summary: Singapore's government is closely monitoring the escalating trade tensions between China and the US, which could impact the country's small, open economy. Singapore's Free Trade Agreement (FTA) networks are seen as a potential solution, offering stability to firms affected by the trade dispute. Meanwhile, Malaysia's May industrial production rose 0.3%, below forecast, and the country's central bank cut interest rates to shield the economy from tariff threats.

site_title: Street Cred
summary: Streetwear is gaining establishment status, driven by millennials and Gen Z spending habits. Virgil Abloh's appointment as Louis Vuitton's artistic director and Supreme's successful collaboration cement this trend. Luxury streetwear brands, such as Amiri, create limited quantities to convey a sense of luxury and scarcity, which drives demand. This formula, combined with the influence of punk and grunge subcultures, has made streetwear a bankable business. As a result, streetwear brands are becoming increasingly sought after, with high prices for their products, such as Amiri jeans retailing above S$800.

site_title: Eel Effect
summary: Unagi rice restaurant Ichinoji Miyagawa is set to open in Singapore on April 12, marking the first outlet outside Japan for the 125-year-old chain. The restaurant will serve freshwater eel in three ways: hitsumabushi, seiro mushi, and donburi. Hitsumabushi is a Nagoya-style ritual involving eating the eel in different combinations, while seiro mushi is grilled eel steamed in a bamboo steamer and covered in sauce. The classic donburi is a simple, shovel-and-enjoy option. The restaurant is a must-try for eel lovers, particularly those who frequent Man Man and Uya.

site_title: Jokowi turns to creative sectors to spur Indonesia's growth
summary: Indonesia aims to shift its economy away from natural resources by promoting creative sectors like films, fashion, and handicrafts. President Joko Widodo's agency for creative economy targets a 9% contribution to GDP by 2020, up from 7.4% in 2017. Foreign investments in the film industry have led to a surge in movie screens and viewership, with 21st Century Fox and Lotte Cinema among the investors. The government is also promoting Indonesian designer goods and supporting startups in the creative economy to boost foreign investment and job creation.

site_title: San Francisco's median house price hits new record of US$1.6m
summary: San Francisco's median house price reached a new record of $1.6 million in the first quarter, a 24% increase from last year. Despite stock-market volatility and tax-law changes, homebuyers appear unfazed, with feverish demand outstripping supply. The median condo price increased by 4.6% to $1.18 million. The surge in prices is attributed to consumer confidence and fear of possible interest rate increases, with quarter-to-quarter fluctuations deemed less meaningful.

site_title: Australia to probe Facebook over data breach
summary: Australia is investigating Facebook over alleged privacy breaches after the tech giant admitted that the personal data of 300,000 Australian users was improperly shared with Cambridge Analytica. The investigation will consider whether Facebook breached the Privacy Act, with the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner (OAIC) conferring with international regulatory authorities. Facebook's CEO Mark Zuckerberg is set to testify before the US Congress, amid multiple probes and investigations from the US and European Union. The Australian probe is the latest action taken by the country following the scandal.

site_title: 'Energy islands' among new solar energy projects launched
summary: Singapore launches "energy islands" of floating solar panels to supply electricity to nearby industrial zones or living areas, as part of its efforts to expand the world's largest floating photovoltaics testbed. The project, led by the Solar Energy Research Institute of Singapore, aims to develop more efficient solar cells and cheaper solar panels to overcome land constraints. Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean noted that solar energy is the best alternative energy option for Singapore, with costs reduced by 85% in the last decade, and the country is well-positioned to trial cleantech solutions.

images.alt_text: "Singapore, a sunny island set in the sea", as a song goes, may soon have "energy islands" made up of solar panels floating in the sea.

site_title: Lucky Strike
summary: Singapore-based artist Allison M. Low created 10 paintings as a response to feeling lost and displaced. The artworks, titled "The Luckier," feature delicate graphite strokes and pastel colors, representing visual metaphors for peace, happiness, and mortality. The exhibition, which ran until May 13, aimed to symbolize an ideal self that doesn't doubt opportunity or allow self-sabotage.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Merger of Alliance Mineral, Tawana proposed to create mid-tier lithium play
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets Limited and Tawana Resources NL have agreed to a merger of equals, creating a mid-tier lithium producer with a pro-forma market capitalization of A$446 million. The merger, expected to be completed by Q4 2018, will see Alliance acquire all of Tawana's issued share capital at 1.10 Alliance shares for each Tawana share. The merged entity will own 100% of the Bald Hill lithium project, expected to start producing lithium concentrate in April 2018. The deal is subject to shareholder and regulatory approvals.

site_title: ECB, BOE unlikely to deviate despite snow-induced slowdown in Europe
summary: The European economy experienced its weakest expansion since 2017 in Q1 due to heavy snow and a strong currency, with eurozone businesses ending the quarter with a 0.6% growth rate and British services contracting at the slowest rate since 2016. Despite this, the European Central Bank is unlikely to deviate from its policy, with a possible bond purchase cut expected this summer. The Bank of England is expected to raise interest rates next month for the second time since the global financial crisis.

images.alt_text: The ECB is looking to wind down its huge stimulus programme in coming months.

site_title: French giant Vinci buys majority stake in Singapore engineering firm for S$250m
summary: French engineering giant Vinci has acquired an 80% stake in Singapore-based mechanical and electrical engineering firm Wah Loon Engineering for approximately S$250 million. The deal allows Wah Loon to expand internationally, leveraging Vinci's strengths in Asia Pacific. Founder and managing director Alan Chong will remain in charge, stating that he is "diluting his shares" to bring the company to the next level. The acquisition is expected to boost Wah Loon's growth, with plans to enter the Indonesian market and expand staff.

site_title: Make Asean infrastructure financing an asset class: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat called for Asean countries to make infrastructure financing a mainstream asset class, citing the region's vast infrastructure needs and potential for private sector participation. Asean countries have been successful in tapping private capital, but more work is needed to increase visibility and bankability. The Asian Development Bank estimates Asean's infrastructure investment needs will total $2.8 trillion between 2016 and 2030. Heng also proposed improving documentation and risk-mitigating measures to attract investors and reduce project volatility.

site_title: EU's Eastern challenges highlighted by Hungary election
summary: Hungary is set to re-elect eurosceptic Prime Minister Victor Orban for a fourth term, amid growing concerns over the country's democratic backsliding and tensions with the EU. Orban's government has been accused of weakening press freedoms, clamping down on NGOs, and promoting a model seen as similar to Russia's or Turkey's, sparking fears of an "East-West rift" within the EU. The country's expected re-election is seen as significant, as Orban has led the Visegrad group in opposition to EU integration, and his government's stance is viewed as a challenge to Brussels' values on democracy and rule of law.

site_title: Register of unclaimed insurance proceeds now covers wider range of payouts: LIA
summary: The Life Insurance Association of Singapore (LIA) has expanded its register of unclaimed life insurance proceeds to include individual accident & health (A&H) policies and other types of payouts. The register now allows for searches of unclaimed proceeds due to policyholders or claimants, including those from A&H policies, which have remained unclaimed for over 12 months. Since its launch in 2016, LIA has paid out S$9.87 million to 690 policyholders or claimants, with the goal of ensuring insurance benefits reach claimants. The updated register is available online and updated quarterly.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Kingsford allowed to start work in some areas of condo project
summary: Kingsford Development, a Chinese developer, has been allowed to resume construction works at areas of its condominium project, Kingsford Waterbay, that do not require rectification. The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) granted this permission on March 19, despite an earlier order to stop building works due to safety concerns. The developer can continue selling units, with 1,032 sold as of February. Rectification works must be completed to the BCA's satisfaction before the order is lifted.

site_title: SGX Regco steps up its game, but it should also step with care
summary: SGX Regulation (Regco) has stepped up enforcement actions against four listed companies, issuing compliance notices and suspending one, in a bid to improve market oversight. The effort aims to reassure stakeholders that this is a step in the right direction, but SGX must balance enforcement with proportionality and due process to avoid disrupting the market. Early intervention carries risks, including unfairly marking entities or depriving them of due process, and requires transparency in decision-making. SGX Regco's strategy aims to improve regulatory efficiency and reduce compliance costs by intervening earlier, but must be cautious to avoid a chilling effect on the market.

site_title: Keppel Electric wins most market share in electricity retail market in 2017
summary: Keppel Electric gained 3.3 percentage points to become the second-largest electricity retailer in Singapore, with a 13.6% market share in 2017, behind Tuas Power's 13.9% and ahead of Seraya Energy's 12.1%. The firm attributed its growth to the liberalisation of the electricity retail market, which introduced more customers with different energy profiles and needs. The market share shift was part of a broader trend, with Senoko Energy Supply losing 1.3 percentage points and PacificLight Energy shedding 1.2 percentage points.

site_title: Feb trade deficit widens to a fresh nine-year high
summary: The US trade deficit widened to a fresh nine-year high in February, reaching $57.6 billion, exceeding the median estimate of $56.8 billion. This marked the sixth consecutive month with a widening deficit, the longest streak since 2000. Imports and exports both increased 1.7%. The growing trade deficit has raised concerns about a potential trade war ahead of the Trump administration's tariffs.

site_title: Movies draw record US$41b at box office in 2017
summary: The global box office reached a record US$40.6 billion in 2017, a 5% rise from 2016, according to the Motion Picture Association of America. The increase was driven by blockbuster films like Star Wars: The Last Jedi, Beauty and the Beast, and Wonder Woman. Despite a slight decline in North America, the Chinese market resumed growth, contributing to the overall record-breaking figure.

site_title: The 2 homes Augusta National can't buy
summary: Augusta National Golf Club, home to the US Masters, has failed to convince two neighboring homeowners to sell their properties, despite offering over $40 million. Herman and Elizabeth Thacker, who have lived in their home since 1959, have refused to sell, citing sentimental value and memories of their family. Their home, along with another nearby house, has become a free parking lot for Masters patrons, a situation that has been in place for years. The owners, Jimmy and his sister, also have no desire to sell their properties, which have been in their family for generations.

site_title: Jaguar E-Pace review: Claws and effect
summary: The Jaguar E-Pace is a crossover vehicle that combines the looks of a modern-day Jaguar with the practicality of a Range Rover Evoque. The E-Pace boasts a sparkling personality and a practical body, making it a desirable choice for buyers. The vehicle's design is the result of a fusion of Jaguar's sports car expertise and Land Rover's off-roading capabilities. With its cute looks and modern features, the E-Pace is poised to win over buyers in the market. The review highlights the vehicle's unique blend of style and substance.

site_title: Government monitoring trade spat; Singapore, KL may gain from trade diversion
summary: Singapore is closely monitoring the escalating US-China trade dispute, which has sparked concerns about its impact on global growth. The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) is urging companies to utilize the country's free trade agreement network for stability and predictability. Regional exporters, particularly in Singapore, Malaysia, and Thailand, may benefit from trade diversion if the US imposes tariffs on Chinese imports. However, some sectors will face disruptions in supply chains. The Singapore government is taking steps to support businesses affected by the trade tensions, including a new grant of up to S$100,000 for tariff-hit businesses.

site_title: Fake news can make - or break - stock prices
summary: Fake news can significantly impact stock prices, and corporations are vulnerable to such falsehoods. Recent incidents, such as a hacked AP tweet causing a $130 billion stock value loss and a fake Twitter account promoting a cryptocurrency to drive up its value, highlight the potential power of fake news in the stock market. To avoid being duped, investors should verify information through legitimate news websites, scrutinize articles for official confirmation, and consult with their relationship manager. In the absence of effective regulation, investors must rely on diligence and caution to navigate the risks of fake news.

site_title: Setting Sail
summary: The Singapore Yacht Show returns for its eighth edition, featuring a line-up of prestigious superyachts and boating brands, along with social events and high-end entertainment. Companies such as Azimut and Simpson Marine will unveil new yacht models, up to 30m long. The show will also include wellness workshops, craft beer and wine tastings, and a gala dinner at W Singapore.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Alessandro Bastagli
summary: Alessandro Bastagli, executive chairman of Shanghai Tang, spoke candidly about his fashion brand, revealing a flamboyant personality behind his dignified appearance. He led a consortium to buy Shanghai Tang from Richemont last July, marking a significant change for the luxury conglomerate. Bastagli's comments provide insight into his leadership style and vision for the brand, showcasing his confidence and willingness to engage with the media without pre-approval. His candid remarks offer a glimpse into the future of Shanghai Tang under his leadership.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Emily Blunt opens up about stuttering
summary: Actress Emily Blunt opens up about her childhood stutter, which she overcame through acting. The British actress, starring in the new film "The Quiet Place," reveals she was bullied for her stutter as a child and hid behind characters. Her stutter still flares up occasionally, particularly when she's tired or pregnant. Blunt joins a group of Hollywood actors, including James Earl Jones, Marilyn Monroe, and Bruce Willis, who also stuttered and overcame their conditions through acting and therapy. The actors highlight the challenges faced by those who stutter, including bullying and finding work.

site_title: FJ's rights cum warrants issue oversubscribed
summary: F J Benjamin Holdings' rights cum warrants issue has been oversubscribed by 48.6%, raising up to S$39 million for working capital and expansion. The issue, priced at 3.5 cents apiece, will raise S$7.8 million in net proceeds. The funds will support expansion plans and general corporate purposes. The warrants, priced at 4 cents each, will be allotted on Friday and listed from Tuesday. If all warrants are exercised, the company will raise an additional S$27 million gross. The rights shares are expected to be allotted on Thursday and listed on Monday.

site_title: Ssangyong Rexton review: Rex to riches
summary: Ssangyong's latest release, the Rexton, is a full-size seven-seat sport utility vehicle aiming to break into the mainstream market. The brand, known for its challenging aesthetics, seeks to emulate the success of Hyundai and Kia. The Rexton boasts old-school luxury ambitions, positioning itself as Ssangyong's flagship model. The review aims to assess the vehicle's performance, design, and overall value, marking a significant shift for the underdog Korean brand.

site_title: Republicans warn Trump: trade war risks backfire come November polls
summary: US President Donald Trump's proposed tariffs on Chinese imports are sparking concerns among Republicans that a trade war could hurt the party's chances in the November midterm elections. China has retaliated with $50 billion in tariffs on US products, primarily affecting rural areas that are crucial to the Republican base. Economists warn that a trade war could reduce US GDP by 3.5% and have a devastating impact on farm states. Republicans are urging Trump to reconsider his plans, with some warning that the economic blowback could cost the party control of Congress.

site_title: SGX RegCo calls on Noble creditors to reconsider proposal
summary: SGX RegCo urges Noble Group's senior creditors to reconsider its restructuring proposal, calling for parity in treatment of all shareholders. Noble has struck a restructuring support agreement with 55% of senior debt holders, requiring a 75% majority in value for approval. Shareholders who vote against the proposal will not receive shares in a new company, sparking concerns about fairness. The regulator disagrees with this clause and may register its concerns with the administrator if Noble is placed in administration.

site_title: SGX approves Fincantieri's renewed bid to delist Vard
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has given in-principle approval for Fincantieri's renewed bid to delist Vard Holdings, a yard group, provided shareholders approve the proposal. Fincantieri, majority shareholder of Vard, has acquired 736,000 shares at 25 Singapore cents, bringing its stake to 83.06%. The company plans to vote all its shares in favor of the delisting proposal at an extraordinary general meeting, expected to be passed unless minority shareholders vote against it. The delisting would allow Vard to avoid preparing and issuing an annual report and holding an annual general meeting.

site_title: Long Live The Library
summary: BT Weekend's "Long Live The Library" series invites local artists to create heritage-themed drawings, which subscribers can colour and keep. IT director Tay Thain Lin, who enjoys sketching, fondly remembers the Queenstown Public Library where he spent hours as a child. He now takes his daughters to the library, where they enjoy the children's collection. This nostalgic series aims to preserve Singapore's heritage through art.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Alpina B5 review: A BMW with brawn
summary: The Alpina B5 is a high-performance BMW sedan that offers supercar-like performance without compromising on everyday usability. With a 4.4-liter V8 engine producing 608 horsepower and 800 Newton-metres of torque, it accelerates from 0-100km/h in 3.5 seconds and reaches a top speed of approximately 330km/h. The car features an 8-speed automatic transmission, all-wheel drive, and a range of standard safety features. Alpina's unique approach to building high-performance cars has resulted in a unique blend of power and practicality, making the B5 an attractive option for those who want to drive fast but still need a car for everyday use.

site_title: How a crazy idea led this former journalist to US$3.4b buyout
summary: Mobike, a bike-sharing startup, has been acquired by food delivery giant Meituan Dianping in a deal valued at $3.4 billion. The founders and investors, including former journalist Hu Weiwei, will receive over $1 billion in cash, while Mobike's team will continue to run the business. The sale highlights China's tech industry, where startups can amass riches quickly, with Meituan and Mobike backed by giants Alibaba and Tencent, respectively. The acquisition marks a significant shift in the bike-sharing market, with Mobike and its rival Ofo accounting for 90% of the market.

site_title: Boeing seen dodging real pain from China's tariffs
summary: China's proposed aircraft tariffs target a generation of Boeing's 737 jetliners nearing the end of production, but most newer models would be exempt. The tariffs, which could reach 30%, are seen as a message to the US administration rather than a major impact on Boeing. Analysts predict a risk for both Boeing and Airbus from policy uncertainty and an escalating trade war, which could harm global economic growth. Boeing fell 1% after the announcement, while Airbus fell less than 1%.

site_title: Jokowi turns to creative sectors to spur Indonesia's growth
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo aims to shift the country's focus from natural resources to creative sectors, such as films, fashion, and handicrafts, to spur growth. The creative economy sector is expected to exceed the nation's GDP growth rate of 5% by 2020, with growth in these industries already exceeding the target. Foreign investments in the film industry have led to a surge in movie screens and viewership, while the government is promoting Indonesian designer goods and handicrafts at global exhibitions. The goal is to reduce reliance on natural resources and improve Indonesia's ease of doing business ranking.

images.alt_text: Models presenting creations by designer Gee Batik at a fashion show in Surabaya. Indonesia's agency for creative economy is pushing for exports of the country's designer goods by aggressive marketing.

site_title: Eight Hands Cook
summary: Chefs from Singapore, Manila, and Sydney will come together for an eight hands restaurant bar exchange, "A Tale of Three Cities," on April 10 and 12. The event, presented by Remy Martin Cognac Fine Champagne, will feature unique menus combining modern European cuisine, Asian, and Filipino flavors. Local teams from Tess Bar & Kitchen and Zui Hong Lou will join forces with visiting chefs from Australia and the Philippines to create four meal sessions. Cocktails will be priced at S$15++ and small plates at S$14++ to S$24++.

site_title: BHP quits World Coal Association over climate clash
summary: BHP Billiton Ltd has quit the World Coal Association due to a clash of views on combating climate change. The mining giant cited a "material difference" and lack of benefit from membership, while remaining part of the US Chamber of Commerce and Minerals Council of Australia. BHP aims for net zero emissions by the second-half of this century, following a 61% emissions cut in six years. The decision comes after rival Rio Tinto Group sold over $4 billion of Australian coal mines, also seeking to reduce its environmental footprint.

site_title: Irish Sensation
summary: The Script, an Irish three-piece band, will return to Singapore next week to support the release of their latest album Freedom Child. The band, consisting of Danny O'Donoghue, Mark Sheehan, and Glen Power, has sold over 29 million albums worldwide since forming in 2007. Their concert at the Singapore Indoor Stadium on April 12 will feature stadium anthems like "The Man Who Can't Be Moved" and "Rain" from their new album, which has had 44 million streams on Spotify. Tickets are available from S$98 to S$278.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Saudi Arabia to open its first cinema in decades on April 18
summary: Saudi Arabia will open its first cinema in over 35 years on April 18 in Riyadh, marking a significant shift in the country's entertainment landscape. Authorities have signed an agreement with AMC Entertainment Holdings to open up to 40 theatres over the next five years. Unlike many public places in Saudi Arabia, cinemas will not be segregated by gender, and the first screening will be Marvel's Black Panther. This move is seen as a step towards modernizing the country's entertainment industry.

site_title: New Highs For China's Art Scene
summary: China's art scene has reached new highs, overtaking the UK as the world's second-largest art market, with the US retaining the top spot. The Chinese art market grew by 21% in 2017, reaching an estimated $67 billion, with sales at the top end of the market driving the growth. International marquee names such as Sarah Morris, Paul McCarthy, and Liu Wei are showcasing their works in Beijing and Hong Kong, with the latter's art week seeing impressive sales and the opening of a new purpose-built art and lifestyle building. Meanwhile, many small- and medium-size galleries are shuttering due to high overheads and shrinking margins.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Greenback edges up as trade war fears fade
summary: The US dollar rose to a two-week high against major currencies on Thursday, driven by a rebound on Wall Street and signs of a potential resolution to the US-China trade dispute. The dollar gained 0.1% against a basket of six currencies, while the yen rose due to market turmoil. However, currency markets generally dislike trade intervention, and analysts warn of a possible exodus of capital, which could weaken the dollar.

site_title: Winners and losers in a US-China trade war
summary: The US-China trade war is escalating, with China imposing a 25% tariff on $50 billion of US imports, matching the proposed US tariffs. The impact is likely to be mixed, with US farmers, automakers, and tech companies facing significant losses. However, soybean exporters may benefit from increased competition from Brazil and Argentina. Asian export economies, particularly Singapore, Malaysia, and Thailand, could also gain from the displacement of demand for certain products, while some sectors may face supply chain disruptions.

site_title: Gender pay gap raises uneasy questions for progressive good
summary: A recent report from the UK reveals a significant gender pay gap, with the financial sector having the second-largest gap at 24%. The disparity is attributed to the underrepresentation of women in senior leadership roles, with only one in seven executive committee members being female. The issue is further complicated by the "motherhood wage penalty," where women are penalized for taking time off to care for children. Companies like Standard Chartered Bank Singapore are taking steps to address the issue, such as increasing paid maternity leave and flexible working arrangements.

site_title: Hot House
summary: Ann Siang House, a 20-suite boutique hotel and F&B destination, has reopened after renovation by Ashish Manchharam, managing director of 8M Real Estate. The venue features several pop-up spaces, including CULT, The Guild, and Perbacco, offering unique dining and drinking experiences. The Guild focuses on craft beer and natural wines, while Perbacco serves traditional Italian dishes. CULT, a popular micro-cafe, will remain at Ann Siang House. The venue aims to attract foodies and locals, providing a more elevated feel compared to the energetic Club Street area.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Qatar says too early to exit Opec oil cuts as investment still low
summary: Qatar's Energy Minister Mohammed al-Sada says it's too early to exit OPEC oil cuts due to low investment levels, supporting longer-term cooperation to balance global crude output. Despite a recent oil price recovery, investments remain low, and demand is expected to rise by 1.5 million barrels per day. Al-Sada urges OPEC to maintain supply curbs to ensure healthy price levels and encourage investment, warning that medium- to long-term demand may not be met without increased investment.

site_title: Door still open for talks to avert US-China trade war
summary: The US and China are still open to negotiations to avoid a trade war, despite the introduction of tariffs by both countries. The US published a list of 1,300 product categories subject to a proposed 25% tariff, while China retaliated with tariffs on around $50 billion worth of US imports. Analysts say the tariffs will have a marginal impact on both economies, but the situation could escalate further if no consensus is reached. China has laid out an ambitious "Made in China 2025" roadmap, and China could respond to US demands with measures such as increasing imports of natural gas or reducing its trade surplus.

site_title: Apple 'working on touchless control, curved iPhone screen'
summary: Apple is reportedly working on touchless gesture control and curved iPhone screens, aiming to differentiate its products in a crowded market. The gesture technology would allow users to perform tasks by moving their finger close to the screen without tapping it, and the curved display would be a significant departure from the flat screens used in previous models. The features are still in the early stages of development and may not be ready for consumers for at least two years.

site_title: Dairy Farm joins billion-dollar en bloc list with asking price of over S$1.68b
summary: The Dairy Farm, a 750,019 sq ft freehold development in Singapore, has joined the billion-dollar en bloc list with an asking price of over S$1.68 billion. Owners will vote on the collective sale agreement on Saturday, with the potential gross floor area of 1.58 million sq ft and 1,500 apartments. This could surpass the S$1.34 billion record held by Farrer Court, with other developments like Pine Grove and Mandarin Gardens also vying for the record.

site_title: A Blooming Story
summary: Sharon Tan, a graphic designer, transformed her apartment in Tampines into a personal sanctuary after realizing her previous space wasn't hers. She applied her design skills to create a unique space, combining her experience in print and product design. Tan's goal was to create a deeply personal space that reflected her personality, rather than a space designed by someone else.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Midas receives requests from noteholders seeking redemptions worth US$30m
summary: Midas Holdings, a Singapore-based railway parts maker, received requests from noteholders for US$30 million redemption and unpaid coupons. The company must pay the noteholders within seven days. Following a notice from the Singapore Exchange, Midas' top executives, including Chen Wei Ping and Ma Ming Zhang, are barred from holding executive positions for three years. The company has also uncovered possible suspicious transactions and will cooperate with authorities. Trading in Midas' stock has been suspended since early February.

site_title: Giselle Ma Belle
summary: The Singapore Dance Theatre is set to stage Giselle at the Esplanade Theatre from April 12-15, marking the classic ballet's first performance at the venue. Created in 1841, Giselle tells a tragic tale of a peasant girl who dies of a broken heart and is raised by spirits of angry dead virgins, ultimately rescuing her lover from a fatal fate. The production showcases the ballet's memorable sepulchral and supernatural scenes, culminating in a dramatic climax. Tickets are available through Sistic.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: All eyes on South Africa's new president
summary: South Africa's President Jacob Zuma resigned on Valentine's Day, ending his nine-year administration. Cyril Ramaphosa was sworn in as president on February 15, 2018, and markets reacted positively to the transition. Ramaphosa is expected to adopt business-friendly policies, boosting the rand. However, he faces significant challenges, including divisions within the African National Congress and its top leaders. Ramaphosa must address corruption and maladministration to restore optimism in the country, following Zuma's scandal-marred legacy.

site_title: Royal Retreat
summary: Hua Hin, a beachside town in Thailand, retains its royal charm since the 1920s when King Prajadhipok built his summer palaces there. The town's tranquility and elegance are reflected in its upscale resorts, such as Avani Hua Hin, and attractions like the Monsoon Valley Vineyards and Mrigadayavan Palace's Tea Room. Visitors can escape the noise of Bangkok and indulge in leisurely activities like strolling through landscaped gardens, watching monkeys, and savoring afternoon tea. The town's laid-back atmosphere and gentle pace make it an ideal getaway for those seeking a peaceful retreat.
