site_title: Statoil awards 11.4b Norwegian crown contracts to rig builders
summary: Statoil has awarded 11.4 billion Norwegian crowns (S$1.91 billion) in contracts to three companies for the second phase of its Johan Sverdrup oil field development. Aibel won the largest contract for the process platform's deck, while a joint venture between Aker Solutions and Kvaerner secured a 3.4 billion crown deal for modifications. The Johan Sverdrup field, with up to 3.1 billion barrels of recoverable oil, is expected to cost close to 133 billion crowns to develop and start producing in 2022 with peak production of 660,000 barrels per day.

site_title: Flying the digital route, in BT Weekend
summary: Airlines are leveraging data to boost revenue, as many struggle to maintain thin business margins. The industry must adapt to maximize available information, from flight bookings to passenger behavior. Meanwhile, companies are recognizing the value of "misfits" and "troublemakers" in times of change, and Singapore is seeing a rise in unique food ventures, such as mod-Indian cuisine and zero-waste initiatives. These trends are set to shape the future of the workforce, investing, and business, with a focus on innovation and adaptability.

site_title: Luxury In A Bottle
summary: Francois Demachy, a renowned perfumer, has launched a luxury perfume-only concept boutique in Singapore, exclusively featuring his 26 bespoke scents. As Dior's Perfumer-Creator, Demachy has reimagined classic fragrances and created new ones inspired by his imagination and finest ingredients. The boutique, located in ION Orchard, offers a luxurious atmosphere with handcrafted scents and exclusive products like silk scarves and candles. Demachy emphasizes the importance of creativity and curiosity in his work, with no deadline or technical constraints.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Fund managers face scrutiny over selective use of benchmarks
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) is proposing changes to require fund managers to disclose more information about their performance measurement and transaction costs. This would enable retail investors to compare funds more closely across the industry. The FCA also plans to amend its rules to calculate performance fees excluding other charges and make it easier for investors to switch to cheaper versions of the same fund. The regulator aims to help firms deliver value to investors, addressing the issue of weak price competition in the industry.

site_title: Gin Up
summary: Sipsmith, a London-based distillery, has revived handcrafted, small-batch gin production, thanks to the efforts of Sam Galsworthy and Fairfax Hall, childhood friends from Cornwall. Starting in 2009, they aimed to bring back London Dry Gin, a style the city first earned its name for. Influenced by the craft beer movement in the US, they brought a copper-pot based distillery to London, nearly 200 years after the last one. Their mission has contributed to the resurgence of gin production in London, with Sipsmith becoming a pioneering force in the city's spirit-making tradition.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Central bank officials called on by police to aid in PNB fraud probe
summary: Indian central bank officials are being questioned by police to aid in the probe into the $2 billion fraud at Punjab National Bank. The RBI officials, who have no suspicion of wrongdoing, are being asked to explain banking processes. The probe has led to the arrest of 20 people, including PNB executives, and has raised criticism about the RBI's failure to detect the long-running fraud. The RBI Governor has called for reforms to give the regulator more powers over state-run banks. The investigation is ongoing, with no further details on the officials' involvement.

site_title: Perry Madness
summary: Katy Perry's Witness tour, supporting her fifth studio album, will make a one-night stop in Singapore. The concert promises a visually stunning and energetic experience, featuring larger-than-life props and a musical journey through space and the ocean. Perry's previous tour, Prismatic, was described by Rolling Stone as "a show to damage retinas and blow minds," and this tour is expected to deliver a similar experience.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Alpha sells Shanghai property for about 2.35b yuan
summary: Alpha Asia Macro Trends Fund II sold Shanghai International Plaza, a 56,000 sq m office-and-retail property, to LaSalle Investment Management for approximately 2.35 billion yuan (around $8.755/sq m). The property was acquired by Alpha in 2014 for $133 million and repositioned to attract quality tenants. Alpha's internal rate of return (IRR) on the sale is close to 20%.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: MindChamps is partnering with China First Capital Group to launch a US$200 million fund for preschools in China, driven by strong demand in the Singapore market. Oxley Holdings has returned to the Singapore market, acquiring sites and an office building, and is expected to lower gearing. Wilmar's share price declined after China imposed a 25% tariff on US soybeans, but analysts maintain a buy call, citing short-term decline in soybean prices.

site_title: Yellen is speaker for hire in meetings with Wall St elite
summary: Janet Yellen, the former US Federal Reserve chair, visited Wall Street for a paid appearance two months after stepping down, discussing the economy and interest rates at a Jefferies event. Yellen stated that inflation is in check and rates will remain relatively low, aligning with her successor Jerome Powell's views. She earned an undisclosed fee for the appearance, following a pattern of former Fed chiefs cashing in on their expertise. Yellen's comments were seen as a potential market mover, with some experts predicting three or four interest rate hikes this year.

site_title: Indonesia's new bank rules aim to spur credit growth
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, has introduced new rules to spur credit growth, aiming for double-digit growth by giving banks more flexibility in managing excess liquidity. The rules, effective July 16, include relaxing reserve requirements, introducing a "macroprudential liquidity buffer," and revising loan-to-funding ratio requirements. The goal is to counter the economic cycle and encourage banks to lend more, despite the benchmark rate being fully supported. The central bank expects the new rules to encourage banks to put excess liquidity in financial market assets and reduce volatility in the overnight money market.

site_title: Japan panel approves casino entrance fee of 6,000 yen
summary: A working panel in Japan has agreed on a 6,000 yen (S$73.95) entrance fee for casinos, as part of the country's integrated resort plans. The fee, which was previously proposed at 2,000 yen or 8,000 yen, was settled at 6,000 yen after compromise between the Liberal Democratic Party and its coalition partner Komeito. The government aims to pass the draft legislation into law this month, with a maximum of three casinos and revenue sharing between national and local governments. The plan aims to address concerns about gambling addiction, with Japanese customers allowed three visits per week.

site_title: Gender pay gap highlights UK economy's latent potential
summary: The UK's gender pay gap highlights the country's economic potential being underutilized. The disparity, driven by more men in senior roles and women working part-time, could add £150 billion to annual GDP by 2025 if addressed. The UK's 70.9% female employment rate masks a complex picture, with women often sacrificing career prospects to care for families. To boost female participation, the government may focus on incentives, retraining, and better pay, potentially becoming more pressing with Brexit's impact on hiring EU workers.

site_title: India's finance minister being treated for kidney ailment, infections
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley is undergoing treatment for kidney-related problems and infections, cancelling his visit to London for annual economic talks. He is currently working from home and a medical report is due on Friday. If required, Prime Minister Narendra Modi may temporarily appoint a minister to replace Jaitley. This comes after Jaitley skipped a meeting of finance ministers from the Group of 20 countries in Argentina last month due to health concerns.

site_title: AEM snaps three-day skid amid orders growth, bullish brokers
summary: AEM Holdings' shares rose 9.53% after three negative sessions, closing at S$5.86 with 2.7 million shares traded. The rally came as bargain hunting took hold, despite the stock remaining 15.1% below its close of S$6.90 before the weekend.

site_title: Record labels cash in on Spotify's listing
summary: Major record label Sony sold 17% of its stake in Spotify for over $250 million on the company's first day of trading. The sale comes as the industry grapples with the impact of streaming on CD and download sales. Despite promising to share profits with artists, the labels have offered few details on the payment structure. This move raises questions about the timing of the sale and whether it prioritizes short-term gains over artist compensation.

site_title: Mahathir's party told by authorities to suspend activities
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's party, Parti Pribumi Bersatu Malaysia (PPBM), has been told by authorities to suspend its activities for 30 days after failing to submit required documents. The party must comply with the Registrar of Societies' demands or face permanent deregistration. The move comes as the opposition Pakatan Harapan (PH) pact plans to contest the upcoming polls using the logo of Parti Keadilan Rakyat (PKR).

site_title: Facebook shares rise as Zuckerberg soothes investors
summary: Facebook shares rose 4.2% on Thursday after CEO Mark Zuckerberg said the social network had not seen a meaningful impact on usage or ad sales following a data privacy scandal. The shares have declined 16% since March 16, wiping $80 billion from its market value. Data showed Facebook's social app downloads improved globally, with a 33.2% expansion in share. Analysts see the decline as a buying opportunity, with Zuckerberg set to testify to Congress next week, and the company taking steps to tighten its privacy controls.

site_title: Trustee calls on Swiber to pay up
summary: The Bank of New York Mellon has called on Swiber Holdings to immediately pay on its Series 001 Trust Certificates worth S$150 million, due 2018. Swiber, currently in judicial management, is unable to meet its payment obligations. The company plans to engage with the trustee within the judicial management framework.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Nominations for E50 Awards 2018 now open
summary: Nominations for the 2018 Enterprise 50 (E50) Awards in Singapore are now open, recognizing the 50 most enterprising, privately held local companies across all industries. Organized by KPMG in Singapore and The Business Times, the awards honor firms that contribute to the city-state's economic development. The launch was attended by corporate leaders from over 100 local enterprises, including past E50 winners.

site_title: US: Facebook, Amazon lead Wall St higher at open
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by gains in Amazon and Facebook, amid easing trade war fears. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.45%, the S&P 500 gained 0.536547%, and the Nasdaq Composite added 0.78%. Despite ongoing US-China trade tensions, stocks continued to rally, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: US trade gap widens for sixth month ahead of Trump tariffs
summary: The US trade deficit widened to a fresh nine-year high in February, increasing 1.6% to $57.6 billion, driven by broad-based demand for imports ahead of Trump administration tariffs. Imports and exports both rose 1.7%, with the trade gap with China narrowing to $34.7 billion. The widening deficit may hinder economic growth, and trade tensions with China and other countries pose a wild card for the outlook. The US typically runs a deficit in merchandise trade, but the services sector accounts for the remaining one-fourth.

site_title: Financials take Australia shares higher; NZ down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to 5,788.8, led by gains in bank stocks, following a positive turn in global sentiment as US-China trade tensions eased. The "Big Four" banks rose over 1%, while healthcare stock CSL Ltd added 0.9%. In contrast, iron ore and steel miners fell, and New Zealand's benchmark index dropped 0.4% due to a 3.2% decline in Fonterra Shareholders' Fund.

site_title: Alpha fund sells Shanghai International Plaza to LaSalle; price said to be 42,000 yuan psm
summary: Alpha Asia Macro Trends Fund II has sold Shanghai International Plaza to LaSalle Investment Management for approximately 42,000 yuan (S$8,755) per square meter of gross floor area, generating an internal rate of return (IRR) of close to 20% for the fund. The property was acquired by Alpha in 2014 for US$133 million and underwent renovations to attract high-quality tenants. The sale follows Alpha's successful sale of another mixed-use property in Shanghai in 2016, demonstrating the fund's approach to value-add investing in the Asia-Pacific market.

site_title: Mainstream Asean infrastructure financing as an asset class: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Singapore Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat called for a collective effort by Asean countries to mainstream infrastructure financing as an asset class. The region's infrastructure investment needs are estimated to total $2.8 trillion over 15 years, with opportunities for private sector participation. Heng emphasized the need to increase project visibility, improve bankability, and reduce risks through measures such as co-funding and government guarantees. Asean countries are also exploring partnerships with multilateral development banks and developing standardized documentation to attract investors.

site_title: STI rallies 2% after Wall St rebounds
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore rallied 2% to close at 3,405.65, driven by overnight gains on Wall Street. Despite ongoing US-China trade tensions, investors are cautiously optimistic, with analysts advising to hedge against risk. Key sectors, such as electronics and telecommunications, could be impacted by trade war tensions. Bank of Singapore's James Cheo recommends managing risk through put options and rotating out of companies exposed to US-China trade.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Top miner BHP quits world coal association over climate clash
summary: BHP Billiton has quit the World Coal Association due to a clash of views on combating climate change. The mining giant cited little benefit from remaining a member and will instead focus on other groups, such as the US Chamber of Commerce and the Minerals Council of Australia. BHP aims to achieve net zero emissions from its operations by the second half of the century, following a 61% reduction in emissions over the past six years. The move follows rival Rio Tinto's exit from coal last week.

site_title: CAD raids YuuZoo office, seizes chairman's passport
summary: CAD raids YuuZoo office, seizing chairman's passport and valuation reports, amid investigation into possible Securities and Futures Act breaches. YuuZoo's chairman, Thomas Zilliacus, and former head of franchise management Sebastian Zilliacus have been interviewed by the Commercial Affairs Department. The company's COO, Mohandas, made the announcement in a Singapore Exchange filing.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 20.19 points to 1,836.13 on Thursday, with a 660-344 gain-to-loss ratio. The market closed with 2.22 billion shares worth RM2.02 billion.

site_title: KTL Global unit terminates lease for Tuas Bay office; to pay S$5.87m to landlord
summary: KTL Global's unit, KTLOS, has terminated its lease at the Tuas Bay office, effective March 1, 2018. As part of the deed of surrender, KTLOS will pay a total of S$5.87 million to landlord SB (Pioneer) Investment, including S$1.5 million in rental arrears, by August 25, 2021. The company must make monthly instalments of S$5.3 million and has already made initial payments of S$126,190 and S$178,816.62. The lease termination reduces a long-term commitment, allowing KTL Global to focus on the global offshore oil and gas market.

Midas appoints a new non-executive chairman and re-designates directors. The STI ended 2% higher, shrugging off trade conflict concerns.

site_title: Mainstream Asean infrastructure financing as an asset class: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Asean finance ministers, led by Singapore's Heng Swee Keat, urged collective efforts to mainstream Asean infrastructure financing as an asset class. The region's infrastructure investment needs are estimated to be $2.8 trillion over 15 years, with opportunities in energy and transport sectors. To address investor concerns, ministers proposed improving project bankability, showcasing investment opportunities, and standardizing documentation. Multilateral development banks and public-private partnerships can also play a role in reducing risks and increasing private sector participation.

site_title: SGX Regco calls on Noble's creditors to reconsider restructuring proposal
summary: SGX Regco urges Noble Group's senior creditors to reconsider its restructuring proposal, citing concerns over unequal treatment of shareholders. The proposal, which requires 75% creditor approval, allows shareholders who voted in favor to receive a 10% stake in the restructured entity, but those who opposed will not. SGX Regco disagrees with this clause, stating it should not affect shareholders' entitlement to new shares. The regulator's statement has been backed by the Securities Investors Association (Singapore), which argues it would be unfair to deny shareholders who opposed the proposal any new shares.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rally at open
summary: Europe's major stock markets rallied on Thursday, driven by a bounce on Wall Street and Asia, as trade war fears eased. London's FTSE 100 jumped 1.4% to 7,134.47 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices rose 1.6% and 1.5% respectively. The rally was attributed to mining and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: James Bond's Swiss Ski Resort loses license to thrill
summary: Swiss ski resort Crans-Montana has closed its lifts due to a financial dispute with the town of Crans-Montana, which refused to fund an 800,000-Swiss-franc subsidy for unprofitable projects. The resort, made famous by James Bond, was saved by Czech billionaire developer Radovan Vitek, but the town's refusal to provide funding has left the lifts shut. The closure comes ahead of a key vote on whether to fund a local bid for the 2026 Winter Olympics.

site_title: Don & Tori's casual bites hit the spot
summary: Don & Tori, a casual Singaporean-centric eatery, has opened its doors in Tras Street. The restaurant, which blends Japanese and Western flavors, offers a wide variety of dishes, including sashimi, sushi, udon, pasta, and rice bowls. Despite its eclectic menu, the restaurant scores well with cooked food, showcasing better quality ingredients and straightforward execution. The generous seating space and friendly service also contribute to a welcoming atmosphere. Overall, Don & Tori is a crowd-pleaser that caters to those looking for hearty food in a casual setting.

site_title: Tan Chuan-Jin appointed chairman of Healthway Medical's new advisory board
summary: Healthway Medical Corporation, Singapore's largest private clinic chain, has formed a new medical advisory board led by Speaker of Parliament Tan Chuan-Jin. The board also includes MP Lily Neo and Professor Bernard Yeung, dean of NUS Business School. The advisory board will provide insights on market trends and offer guidance on industry best practices, helping the company adopt a patient-centric and technology-enabled approach to healthcare. The appointment is part of Healthway's strategy to address sustainable healthcare challenges in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Other roles currently held by Mr Tan include deputy chairman of Mandai Park Holdings and senior adviser to Temasek. He assumed both roles in November last year.
Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Information of over 65,000 S'pore Facebook users may have been improperly shared
summary: Over 65,000 Facebook users in Singapore may have had their information improperly shared with Cambridge Analytica, a data analytics company. The breach involves 87 million people worldwide, with the majority being North American users. Facebook confirmed that it was investigating if Singapore accounts were compromised and assured affected users will be informed. The incident has raised concerns about Facebook's data security and its handling of user data.

site_title: Scoot flight returns to Singapore safely after 'alleged bomb threat on board'
summary: A Scoot flight headed for Hat Yai, Thailand, returned to Changi Airport after an alleged bomb threat on board was reported. The flight, TR634, was escorted by two Republic of Singapore Air Force fighter jets and landed safely at 3:23pm. Authorities are conducting checks, and Scoot is cooperating with the investigation. No further details on the passenger or the threat have been released.

site_title: FJ Benjamin rights cum warrants issue oversubscribed
summary: FJ Benjamin Holdings' rights cum warrants issue has been oversubscribed by 48.6%, raising up to S$39 million for working capital and expansion. The issue, priced at 3.5 Singapore cents, will raise net proceeds of S$7.8 million. The funds will support expansion plans and general corporate purposes, with the potential to raise an additional S$27 million if all warrants are exercised. The rights shares and warrants will be listed on the Singapore Exchange on Monday and Tuesday, respectively.

site_title: US jobless claims rise; continuing claims lowest since 1973
summary: US initial jobless claims rose 24,000 to 242,000 for the week ended March 31, exceeding expectations. However, continuing claims, which reflect those on jobless rolls, fell to its lowest level since 1973 at 1.81 million. The tightening labor market suggests a near-full employment scenario, with the jobless rate at 4.1% and forecast to drop to 3.8% by the end of the year. Economists expect this to boost wage growth and consumer spending in the second half of the year.

site_title: Jeweller Soo Kee set to change its name
summary: Soo Kee Group, a jewellery retailer, is set to change its name to SK Jewellery Group Limited at an upcoming extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on April 30. The name change aims to better reflect the company's profile, business activities, and direction. The company had applied to reserve the new name in March 2018 and received approval from the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority of Singapore. The name change will be reserved until July 5, 2018, with no other amendments to the group's constitution. Existing shareholders will not need to take any further action.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Markets closed for holiday
summary: Hong Kong, Shanghai, Shenzhen, and Taipei financial markets were closed on Thursday, April 5, 2018, for a public holiday.

site_title: South-east Asia needs tax moves for infrastructure: Maybank
summary: Maybank suggests Indonesia, Thailand, and the Philippines consider tax incentives and measures to boost infrastructure funding. The countries need to spend over $1.7 trillion annually between 2016 and 2030. Maybank has been working with regulators to encourage private sector participation and longer-term debt issues in local currency. Malaysia has already taken steps to develop its ringgit debt markets. China is seen as a potential booster for infrastructure funding in the region, accounting for only 2.5% of Malaysia's foreign direct investment.

site_title: Singapore shares end higher as investors shrug off trade conflict
summary: Singapore shares ended higher on Thursday, closing at 3,405.65, up 2% or 65.95 points from the previous day. Investors shrugged off the US-China trade conflict, with more than 1 billion shares traded. Gainers included Genting Singapore, Venture Corp, and AEM Holdings, with AEM rising 9.53% after receiving S$192 million in sales orders. The rally follows a see-saw session on Wall Street, where equities rallied into the close.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Average capex on major upstream O&G projects fell to 10-year low in 2017: WoodMac
summary: The number of sanctioned upstream oil and gas projects doubled in 2017 compared to 2016, with 6 projects sanctioned in the first quarter of 2018. Average capital expenditure for each major project fell to a 10-year low of $2.7 billion, down from $5.5 billion in the previous decade. This trend indicates an upgrade in industry sentiment as oil prices rebounded, leading operators to favor lower-cost projects. However, analysts warn that relying on small projects is unsustainable, with large LNG projects emerging on the horizon, such as the Mozambique LNG and Canada LNG projects.

site_title: Singapore stocks resume afternoon trading at 3,411.01, up 2.14% on the day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed afternoon trading at 3,411.01, up 2.14% on the day, with the Straits Times Index reaching 71.31 points higher. Gainers outnumbered losers 281 to 90, driven by Cosco Shipping International (7.1% gain), Genting Singapore (2.9% gain), and DBS Group Holdings (2.9% gain). Active index stocks also saw significant gains, with OCBC Bank up 3.5% and United Overseas Bank up 2.7%.

site_title: Register of unclaimed insurance proceeds now covers wider range of payouts: LIA
summary: The Life Insurance Association of Singapore (LIA) has expanded its register of unclaimed insurance proceeds to include individual accident & health policies, allowing for wider range of payouts to be claimed. The register now covers unclaimed monies from life policies matured or due to death, as well as unclaimed proceeds from A&H policies. Since its launch in 2016, LIA has paid out S$9.87 million to 690 policyholders or claimants, with the updated register set to be updated every six months to reach more unclaimed policyholders and claimants.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Trump, Xi wait to see who blinks first as trade fight heats up
summary: US President Donald Trump has imposed tariffs on 1,333 Chinese products, sparking a trade war, while China retaliated with tariffs on key American imports, including soybeans and Boeing jets. The US move was seen as a response to China's plans to dominate strategic technologies. The two leaders are waiting to see who will back down first, with China urging dialogue and the US seeking to squeeze Beijing harder. The trade dispute has created uncertainty and could impact global markets, with the US and China still having time to back down before the tariffs take effect.

site_title: Statoil awards 11.4b Norwegian crown contracts to rig builders
summary: Statoil has awarded 11.4 billion Norwegian crowns (S$1.91 billion) in contracts to three companies for the construction of a platform and other work on the second phase of its Johan Sverdrup oil field development. Aibel won the largest award for the engineering, procurement, and building of an 8 billion crown deck for the field's process platform. The Johan Sverdrup field, with up to 3.1 billion barrels of recoverable oil, is expected to cost close to 133 billion crowns to develop, with production starting in 2022.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher as trade war fears recede
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Thursday as US-China trade war fears eased, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 1.53% to 21,645.42. The yen weakened against the dollar, contributing to the market's boost. The broader Topix index also increased 1.08% to 1,724.61. The easing of trade tensions led to a rally in Asian markets, with Singapore and European stocks also rising.

site_title: Airlines cut back flights as Philippine holiday hotspot prepares for closure
summary: The Philippine government has ordered a six-month closure of Boracay, a popular holiday hotspot, to address sewage and environmental issues. Airlines, including Cebu Pacific and Philippine Airlines, have cut back flights to the island, with Cebu Pacific cancelling 14 daily round-trip flights and Philippine Airlines scaling down services. The closure is expected to impact the tourism industry, with the Philippine tourism minister stating that businesses and visitors must make sacrifices. The government has estimated that the closure could shave 0.1% off the country's gross domestic product.

site_title: CapitaLand to launch all-in-one e-payment service at 17 malls
summary: CapitaLand is launching StarPay, an all-in-one e-payment service at 17 malls in Singapore, covering over 2,500 stores. The service integrates five e-payment modes, including GrabPay, NETSPay, and Alipay, allowing shoppers to pay using different methods, including debit and credit cards, QR codes, and local and international payment apps. The service will be rolled out starting with Raffles City Singapore and American Express on April 18, with smart terminals provided to retailers at no cost by the end of the year.

site_title: Bus depot foreman jailed a year for cheating SBS Transit out of more than S$200,000
summary: A bus depot foreman, Ong Sang Fei, was jailed for a year for cheating SBS Transit out of over S$200,000 in a scam involving technical work payments. Ong claimed the work was done by Azech Engineering, a company set up by his accomplice Koh Dawei, but in reality, Venda Engineering and Trading employees performed the work without their bosses' knowledge. Ong received an 83% cut of the payments, with Koh receiving the rest. The scam ran from 2013 to 2015 and involved over S$66,000 and S$145,000 in additional charges.

site_title: Broadcom keeps promise to move to US from Singapore, after blocked Qualcomm bid
summary: Broadcom Inc has completed its move back to the United States from Singapore, following President Donald Trump's blockage of its $117 billion hostile takeover bid of Qualcomm Inc due to national security concerns. The semiconductor maker's existing co-headquarters in San Jose, California will become its sole headquarters. The move, approved by shareholders and the Singapore High Court, marks a significant milestone in Broadcom's history. CEO Tan Hock Eng stated that the completion of the redomiciliation is an important step, solidifying Broadcom's status as an American company.

site_title: Australia begins privacy investigation into Facebook
summary: Australia has launched an investigation into Facebook's handling of user data, following the revelation that 87 million users' information may have been improperly shared with Cambridge Analytica. The investigation, led by the Australian privacy commissioner, will consider whether Facebook breached Australian privacy laws. Facebook's CEO Mark Zuckerberg has accepted blame for the data leak and has agreed to testify before US congressional hearings. The investigation follows similar actions by New Zealand's privacy commissioner, who has charged Facebook with breaking laws in that country.

site_title: South-east Asia needs tax moves for infrastructure: Maybank
summary: Maybank urges Indonesia, Thailand, and the Philippines to consider tax incentives to boost infrastructure funding in South-east Asia, which needs over $1.7 trillion annually between 2016 and 2030. The bank, in collaboration with regulators, aims to encourage private sector participation in toll roads, power plants, and other infrastructure projects. Maybank has been working to develop ringgit debt markets in Malaysia, and China has the capacity to boost infrastructure funding in the region, but faces slower GDP growth, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise over 1%; won holds steady
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 1.22% on Thursday, driven by bargain-hunting and Samsung Electronics' 3.9% gain. The won held steady at 1,059.7 per dollar, while bond yields rose. Samsung Electronics' earnings guidance for the March quarter is set to be released on Friday. The KOSPI index closed at 2,437.52, up 29.46 points.

site_title: How a crazy idea led this former journalist to US$3b buyout of Mobike
summary: Mobike, a bike-sharing company founded by Hu Weiwei in 2015, has agreed to sell to food delivery giant Meituan Dianping in a deal valued at $3.4 billion. The deal values Mobike's equity at $2.7 billion and Meituan will assume $700 million in debt. Mobike's success in China's bike-sharing market, where it competes with rival Ofo, has made it a lucrative target for investors, with Hu and her co-founders pocketing over $1 billion in cash. The sale highlights China's booming startup scene, where companies can achieve rapid growth and valuation, with Meituan's acquisition of Mobike part of a larger trend of tech giants backing Chinese startups.

site_title: DBS aims for 30% reduction in corporate cheque payments by 2020
summary: DBS Bank aims to reduce corporate cheque payments by 30% by 2020, in response to changing consumer behavior. The bank has seen a fivefold increase in corporate clients requesting digital payment solutions, with the majority using mobile phones to receive instant payments. To achieve this goal, DBS will allow corporate clients to plug into its PayNow solution through APIs, enabling instant peer-to-peer funds transfers. This move aims to help businesses stay relevant, save time, and serve customers better as cheque payments become less popular.

site_title: AEM added S$77m of orders over two months, now has S$192m for 2018 delivery
summary: AEM Holdings has received S$77 million in new sales orders, bringing its 2018 delivery total to S$192 million. The company's profit guidance remains unchanged, with S$255 million in sales and S$42 million in operating profit before tax. AEM's largest shareholder, James Toh, will become a non-executive director, while Keith Toh Hsiang-Wen resigns to join Novo Tellus Capital Partners. The company's stock price rose 12.15% to S$6.00 following the announcement.

site_title: Alliance Mineral, Tawana in 'merger of equals' to create mid-tier lithium player
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets Limited and Tawana Resources NL have agreed to a "merger of equals" to create a mid-tier lithium producer with a pro-forma market capitalisation of A$446 million. The merger, expected to be completed by the fourth quarter of 2018, will see Alliance acquire all of Tawana's issued share capital at a ratio of 1.10 Alliance shares for each Tawana share. The combined entity will own 100% of the Bald Hill lithium project in Western Australia, expected to start producing lithium concentrate in April 2018.

site_title: China's state media warns of pain for Trump in trade battle
summary: Chinese state media warned US President Donald Trump that a trade war with China would bring him "painful lessons" as the country retaliated with 25% tariffs on $50 billion of US imports. China's swift counterattack was seen as a strong response to the US move, with state media emphasizing that China was acting in self-defence. The Global Times and People's Daily published editorials praising China's quick reaction, saying the US had "suffered financial and political losses" and that Sino-US ties were now "two equally matched giants."

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday; STI up 1.6%
summary: Singapore shares opened 1.6% higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index up 55.09 points to 3,394.79, driven by global market reassessments of US-China trade relations. The Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite rose on Wall Street, while regional markets in Japan, Australia, and South Korea also saw gains. The rally follows a 0.4% increase on Wednesday.

site_title: Indonesia says domestic market to shelter economy from trade war
summary: Indonesia's finance minister, Sri Mulyani Indrawati, believes the country's large domestic market will shield its economy from the potential fallout of a US-China trade war. With consumption accounting for over half of its GDP, Indonesia is less reliant on exports compared to other South-east Asian economies. Indrawati urged the US and China to resolve their trade disputes through the World Trade Organization, warning that a prolonged trade war would be detrimental to the world economy.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's economy may be cushioned by its huge domestic market as a trade dispute between the US and China poses risks to the global economic recovery, according to finance minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 13.34 points, or 0.73%, to 1824.46 on Thursday, with 302 gains outweighing 87 losses. Volume was 154 million lots worth RM53.2 million.

site_title: Australia shares rise as US-China trade war fears ease; NZ lower
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% to 5,796.6, driven by Wall Street's 1% gain after the US expressed a willingness to negotiate with China over trade tensions. China proposed its own tariffs, but market participants believed they would not take effect for at least six months. Banks led gains, with ANZ up 1.7%, while consumer stocks like Treasury Wine Estates rose 2.4%. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.2% as healthcare stocks dragged.

site_title: HDB resale prices up 0.8% in March from February but down 1.9% y-o-y: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices rose 0.8% in March from February but dropped 1.9% from last year, according to SRX Property. Resale prices are down 0.6% from the previous three months and 12.8% from their peak in April 2013. Resale flats sold increased by 58.5% in March, while the volume of resale flats dipped 0.8% year-on-year. Median Transaction Over X-Value (TOX) was negative, with some estates posting high TOX values, indicating buyers may be overpaying.

site_title: Philippines CPI at more than 5-year high adds to rate hike calls
summary: The Philippines' consumer prices rose to a 5-year high in March, increasing 4.3% from February, exceeding the median estimate. This surge in inflation adds pressure on the central bank to raise interest rates, with economists predicting a rate hike in early May. The peso has also declined 4.2% this year, and the central bank has resisted calls to tighten monetary policy, forecasting annual inflation to return to the target range of 2-4% in 2019.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise after 3 days of falls, won slips
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.59% to 2,422.32 after three consecutive sessions of declines, driven by bargain-hunting from investors seeking value amid eased trade war worries. The won slipped 0.24% to 1,062.3 per US dollar, while bond yields rose. The Kospi is down 2.4% so far this year, and foreign investors were net sellers of 25,940 million won worth of shares.

site_title: Philippines to close Boracay resort to tourists for six months
summary: The Philippines has announced a six-month closure of the popular tourist island of Boracay, starting April 26, due to concerns over sewage dumping into the sea, turning it into a "cesspool". The closure will affect 500 tourism-related businesses and 17,000 employees, with airlines and ferries to suspend services and beaches to be made off-limits. The move aims to restore the island's environment, with officials warning of untreated sewage entering the turquoise waters.

site_title: Tan Chuan-Jin to head Healthway Medical's new advisory board
summary: Tan Chuan-Jin, Speaker of Parliament, has been appointed chairman of Healthway Medical Corporation's newly formed advisory board, alongside Member of Parliament Lily Neo and National University of Singapore dean Bernard Yeung. The board will provide guidance on key market trends and advise on developments in the medical field that may impact the company. This move comes after the Riady family's successful S$103 million takeover offer for HMC last year, with non-executive director Stephen Riady expressing confidence in the new board's ability to lead the company as a leading healthcare provider.

site_title: Broker's take: KGI initiates coverage on MindChamps with 'buy'
summary: KGI Securities has initiated coverage on MindChamps with a "buy" call, citing the preschool-education counter's entry into China as a strong growth driver for its revenues. MindChamps has partnered China First Capital Group to launch a US$200 million fund for opening and acquiring preschools in China, with the potential to capture market share in the burgeoning early childhood education market forecast to expand from 380 billion yuan in 2016 to 540 billion yuan by 2020. The brokerage notes upside risks, including the failure to raise enough capital, but expects MindChamps' strong branding and science-backed curriculum to drive growth.

site_title: As Spotify goes public, Sony cashes in more than US$250m
summary: Spotify went public on the New York Stock Exchange, with a market valuation of $26.5 billion. Major record company Sony sold 17% of its stake in the company for over $250 million, valuing its remaining stake at around $1.29 billion. This sale is seen as a response to the streaming service's hybrid business model and the decline of CD and download sales. The sale's timing has sparked debate on whether the labels should share the profits with their artists, with some calling for the major labels to share the money with independent labels.

site_title: Sorting through Trump's claims about Amazon
summary: US President Donald Trump claims Amazon is costing the US Postal Service (USPS) billions of dollars, citing a bad deal. However, evidence suggests Amazon has been a boon to the Postal Service, with package shipping growing to 5.7 billion packages last year. Without Amazon's business, the Postal Service's financial picture would likely be bleaker. Analysts argue that equating the USPS's struggles with Amazon's rise is unfair and that the Postal Service was already generating billions of dollars in operating losses before Amazon became a large customer.

images.alt_text: Five times in the last week, US President Donald Trump has pointed his Twitter arrows at Amazon over what he insists is a bad deal for the US Postal Service (USPS).

site_title: US teachers say they sacrifice for the job they love
summary: US teachers are taking part in job actions due to long-stagnant pay and school budgets. Thousands of teachers in Kentucky, West Virginia, and Oklahoma are protesting, with some leaving their home states to seek higher-paying jobs. Teachers are demanding more spending on schools, up-to-date classroom materials, and better benefits. The protests come as largely Republican-controlled legislatures have cut funding for public schools to cut or hold taxes. The National Education Association warns that low wages are scaring away future teachers, with some colleges reporting a drop in applicants.

site_title: Midas Holdings noteholders ask to redeem US$30 million; company seeking extension
summary: Midas Holdings, a Singapore-based railway-parts maker, is facing financial distress as noteholders have requested to redeem US$30 million. The company, which has unpaid coupons, must pay the noteholders within seven days. The Singapore Exchange has also issued a notice of compliance, demanding the resignation of two top executives. Trading in the company's stock has been suspended since early February, and the company is seeking an extension to address the noteholders' demands.

site_title: Asia: Shares bounce from 2-month lows as US-China trade war fears ease
summary: Asian shares rose on Thursday after the US expressed willingness to negotiate a resolution to the trade fight with China, easing concerns of a full-blown trade war. The proposed US tariffs on $50 billion in Chinese goods were met with a quick response from Beijing, but investors believe the impact will be less than the headlines. The US and Chinese economies are highly inter-dependent, and both countries have much to lose from escalating trade tensions, with investors hoping for a negotiated resolution.

site_title: Tearful reunion highlights plight of China's missing children
summary: A Chinese couple, Wang Mingqing and Liu Dengying, were reunited with their 24-year-old missing daughter after a DNA test confirmed her identity. The daughter, Kang Ying, was believed to have been kidnapped and trafficked by an underground adoption ring. The reunion highlights the issue of child trafficking and disappearances in China, where thousands of children go missing each year. The couple's story has sparked a wave of social media sharing, with dozens of parents sharing information about their search for missing children.

site_title: Zuckerberg Senate testimony on Facebook data set for April 10
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg will testify before the Senate Judiciary and Commerce Committees on April 10 about Facebook's data handling and user privacy issues, following the revelation that data on 87 million people may have been improperly shared with Cambridge Analytica. Zuckerberg has faced intense criticism from lawmakers and has agreed to testify before the House Energy and Commerce Committee on April 11. The hearings come after Facebook reported that data on most of its 2 billion users could have been accessed improperly.

site_title: US seizes 100 'pot-growing' houses linked to China
summary: Federal agents in California seized over 100 homes linked to Chinese-run marijuana operations, part of the largest residential drug bust in US history. The operation, which began in 2014, targeted homes purchased with foreign money to cultivate marijuana. Agents seized 60,000 marijuana plants, 200 kilograms of processed marijuana, and 15 firearms. The US Attorney General stated that international gangs are trying to impose a "false sovereignty" over certain neighborhoods, and the IRS said the operation was worth millions of dollars.

site_title: Philippines CPI at more than 5-year high adds to rate hike calls
summary: The Philippines' consumer prices rose to a 5-year high in March, increasing to 4.3% from 3.8% in February. This exceeds the median estimate and pressure is mounting on the central bank to raise interest rates. Economists predict a rate hike in early May, citing broader price rises and a tax law that raised levies on fuel and other goods. The peso has declined 4.2% this year, with the central bank signaling no rush to tighten policy, sparking debate over the rate outlook.

site_title: Vard gets SGX nod for proposed delisting
summary: Vard Holdings, a Singapore-listed yard group, has received approval from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to proceed with its proposed delisting. The group's majority shareholder, Fincantieri Oil & Gas, has acquired 83.06% of Vard shares and intends to vote in favor of the delisting proposal at an upcoming general meeting. The proposal is expected to pass unless 10% or more minority shareholders vote against it. Vard has secured SGX's support to extend the timeline for the delisting process.

site_title: Two Bill Clinton impeachment shows abandoned by US TV networks
summary: US TV networks have scrapped two planned series about former President Bill Clinton's affair with Monica Lewinsky and his 1998 impeachment. History Channel dropped a scripted drama series "The Breach: Inside the Impeachment of Bill Clinton" due to creative reasons. Producer Ryan Murphy also abandoned a planned FX series based on the book "A Vast Conspiracy" after deciding to let Monica Lewinsky produce it herself. Meanwhile, Showtime has adapted Bill Clinton's novel "The President is Missing" for a series, with no release date announced.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Vard, Datapulse, IPC Corp, Compact Metal
summary: Vard Holdings' majority shareholder Fincantieri Oil & Gas renewed its bid to privatize the yard group, with the Singapore Exchange approving the delisting if shareholders agree. Datapulse Technology must reappoint independent professionals to review its internal controls by April 11. IPC Corporation terminated a conditional offer for the Ngiam family's shares after mutual consent. Compact Metal received in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange to exit its watch list.

site_title: Julius Maada Bio sworn in as new Sierra Leone president
summary: Sierra Leone's opposition candidate Julius Maada Bio was sworn in as the country's new president, winning 51.81% of votes in the March 31 election. He replaces outgoing President Ernest Bai Koroma, who was term-limited. Bio, a former military junta leader, faces rebuilding the impoverished nation's economy after the Ebola epidemic and global commodity slump. In his first speech, Bio appealed for national unity, saying "this is the dawn of a new era" and "we are all one people."

site_title: PACC Offshore shares fall 8.6% on Wednesday
summary: PACC Offshore Services Holdings shares fell 8.6% on Wednesday after being downgraded to "hold" by DBS Group Research, citing a 12-month target price of S$0.32. The downgrade comes amid news that Malaysian Bulk Carriers Berhad, PACC's second-largest shareholder, plans to dispose of its 21% stake through a renounceable restricted offer for sale. The sale is expected to ease MBC's cashflow burden and may boost PACC's free float to 29.4% if accepted by the Kuok Group and minority shareholders.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on April 5, 2018, as fears of a US-China trade war receded. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.18% to 21,570.59, while the Topix index increased 0.87% to 1,720.90. The yen remained relatively lower against the US dollar. This uptick in Tokyo stocks followed a broader Asian market rally, with Singapore stocks notching a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: US dollar steady vs yen after stocks recover from trade scare, US jobs data awaited
summary: The US dollar remained steady against the yen at 106.845 yen, after recovering from a low set the previous day due to a sell-off triggered by a US-China trade spat. Stocks rebounded, calming trade war concerns after President Trump's economic adviser stated the US was in "negotiation" with China. The dollar was also steady against the Swiss franc, while the euro nudged up 0.05% to $1.2285. The Australian dollar reached a nine-day high of $0.7726. The focus now shifts to the US jobs report on Friday, which could impact the dollar's value.

site_title: US: Wall Street closes higher as China tariff fears ease
summary: US stocks closed around 1% higher on Wednesday, rebounding from earlier losses due to concerns over a potential trade war with China. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite rose as investors shifted focus to earnings and technical analysis, citing a lack of immediate action on proposed tariffs. Strategists expect equities to rise further as the first quarter earnings season begins in mid-April.

site_title: America remembers Martin Luther King Jr, 50 years on
summary: On the 50th anniversary of Martin Luther King Jr.'s assassination, Americans commemorated the civil rights leader's legacy, marking dramatic progress but also acknowledging the need for continued work on racial equality. Demonstrators rallied in Memphis, Tennessee, and Washington, D.C., with activist son Martin Luther King III stating that his father would be disappointed by the current discourse but excited by the activist movements today. The US President honored King, but his own comments on unity and justice have been criticized for being divisive.

site_title: Two Koreas meet to plan landmark summit
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and South Korean President Moon Jae In are set to meet on April 27 at the South's Peace House in Panmunjom for a landmark inter-Korean summit. The two sides will discuss logistics, security, and media coverage, with attention on Kim's transportation mode and whether to allow live broadcasting. This will be the third inter-Korean summit since the 1950-53 Korean War ended with an armistice, preceding a planned US-North Korea summit in May. The rapprochement began with the South's Winter Olympics, where North sent athletes and Kim's sister as an envoy.

images.alt_text: Officials from North and South Korea met Thursday to discuss the logistics of a rare summit later this month, which will see Kim Jong Un become the first North Korean leader to set foot in the South since the end of the Korean War.

site_title: Apple said to be working on touchless control, curved iPhone screen
summary: Apple is reportedly working on touchless gesture control and curved screens for future iPhones. The new technology would allow users to perform tasks by moving their finger close to the screen without tapping it. The control feature is expected to take into account the proximity of a finger to the screen and is unlikely to be ready for consumers for at least two years. This technology aims to differentiate Apple's iPhones in an increasingly crowded market, following its previous innovations such as 3D Touch.

images.alt_text: Apple is working on touchless gesture control and curved screens for future iPhones, projects that may help the company differentiate its most-important product in an increasingly crowded market, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

site_title: Boeing seen dodging real pain from China's warning shot on tariffs
summary: China has proposed a 25% tariff on Boeing's 737 aircraft, but the levy primarily targets older models nearing production end, exempting newer 737 Max models. Analysts believe the tariff is intended as a message to the US administration rather than a major impact on Boeing. This cautious approach suggests Boeing may avoid significant financial pain from the proposed tariff.

site_title: Qatar National Bank seeks growth in South-east Asia
summary: Qatar National Bank (QNB) aims to increase its profit by 5-8% and loans and investments by 10-12% in 2018, driven by expansion into South-east Asia markets. The bank, the largest in the Middle East and Africa, plans to become a leading player in the region by 2020. QNB's CEO, Ali Ahmed al-Kuwari, also mentioned plans to acquire markets with a 4-5% local market share and an internal rate of return of at least 15% within three years.

site_title: HSBC leaker Falciani detained in Spain at demand of Switzerland
summary: HSBC leaker Herve Falciani, 46, was detained in Spain on Wednesday at the request of Switzerland, where he faces extradition for leaking documents alleging HSBC helped clients evade millions of dollars in taxes. Falciani, a former computer analyst, leaked a cache of documents in 2015, sparking the "Swissleaks" scandal, but was convicted in Switzerland for data theft and industrial espionage. Falciani has been viewed as a whistleblower in some countries, but his arrest has sparked criticism, with the president of Spain's tax inspectors union calling it "very regrettable."

site_title: Europe: Shares fall further as China responds to US tariffs
summary: European shares fell for a second day due to China's retaliatory tariffs on US goods, sparking concerns of an escalating trade standoff. China imposed duties on US$50 billion in goods, including soybeans, planes, and cars, while the US had planned to impose tariffs on similar Chinese imports. Despite the concerns, some European companies like Airbus and Adidas may gain a competitive edge in Chinese markets due to the tariffs, with Airbus shares falling 0.8% and Adidas rising 1.3%.

site_title: Golf: Timeless Tom Watson wins Masters Par-3 crown at age 68
summary: Tom Watson, 68, won the Masters Par-3 Contest, breaking the age mark of 61 set by Sam Snead in 1974. Watson shot a 6-under par 21, his best finish since 1982. This victory, without the Masters tournament, marks the first time a Par-3 Contest winner has taken the Masters in the same year. Watson's triumph may signal an opportunity for older golfers, including Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson, to compete in the Masters.

site_title: George Yeo tapped for new Yangon development
summary: Former Singapore foreign minister George Yeo has been appointed to lead the development of a Yangon city extension in Myanmar, a massive industrialization effort expected to spur growth for the country. The project, driven by New Yangon Development Co, will cover an area over twice the size of Singapore and will be fully owned by the Yangon region government. Yeo, chairman of Hong Kong-headquartered Kerry Logistics, believes that better infrastructure is needed in Yangon to support its growth, and that government control is essential for the project's success.

site_title: US expects talks with China as trade fight escalates
summary: The US and China are expected to engage in talks amid an escalating trade fight. China retaliated with tariffs on $50 billion in US goods after the US proposed 25% tariffs on similar Chinese products. US officials signal possible wiggle room, with top economic adviser Larry Kudlow saying the tariffs may never go into effect as a negotiating tactic. China's ambassador to the US, Cui Tiankai, stated that negotiation is preferable but "takes two to tango." A full-scale trade war could destabilize US-Chinese commercial ties and harm the global economy.

site_title: Japan Sumo Association chief apologises after female medics asked to leave ring
summary: The Japan Sumo Association apologized after female medics were asked to leave a sumo ring where they were treating a local official who had collapsed. The medics were asked to leave due to a long-standing tradition that forbids women from entering the ring, considering their presence as "unclean" and polluting the sacred space.

images.alt_text: "It was an inappropriate response in the life-threatening situation. I deeply apologise," Mr Hakkaku said in a statement.

site_title: Gold backs from 1-week high, still up as US dollar dips on trade-war jitters
summary: Gold prices eased from a one-week high, but remained up on Wednesday as the US dollar dipped against the yen and share markets faltered after China retaliated against US tariffs. Spot gold rose 0.2% to $1,335.66 per ounce, while US gold futures settled 0.2% higher at $1,340.20. The US dollar's decline made US dollar-priced gold cheaper for non-US currency holders, making gold more appealing as a safe-haven asset. However, global economic growth and expected US nonfarm payrolls data may limit gold's upside.

site_title: Qatar National Bank seeks growth in South-east Asia
summary: Qatar National Bank (QNB) aims to increase its profit by 5-8% and loans and investments by 10-12% this year, driven by expansion into South-east Asia markets. The bank plans to become a leading player in the Middle East, Africa, and South-east Asia, with a focus on markets with faster growth rates than Qatar. QNB has also set a goal to control at least 4-5% of the local market in potential acquisitions.

site_title: Facebook says 87m may be affected by data breach
summary: Facebook announced that 87 million users' personal data was improperly shared with Cambridge Analytica, surpassing a previous estimate of 50 million. The social network unveiled clearer terms of service and CEO Mark Zuckerberg will testify before a congressional panel next week to address privacy issues. This new revelation adds to Facebook's ongoing privacy scandal, which has already raised concerns about data sharing and user protection.

site_title: 'Brilliant' Liverpool should have killed off City: Klopp
summary: Jurgen Klopp praised Liverpool's 3-0 win over Manchester City, calling it "brilliant." However, he admitted that his side should have sealed the Champions League quarter-final tie in the first leg. Liverpool dominated the match, scoring three goals in the opening 31 minutes, with Mohamed Salah, Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain, and Sadio Mane scoring. The Reds' strong performance set up a potential advantage heading into the second leg.

site_title: Video blogger who opened fire at YouTube was angry with company, police say
summary: A 39-year-old Iranian-born woman, Nasim Najafi Aghdam, opened fire at YouTube's California headquarters due to anger towards the site, which she believed was suppressing her videos. In online postings, she claimed she was being discriminated and filtered on YouTube. On Tuesday, Aghdam wounded three people and killed herself at the site's offices in San Bruno, California. The motive behind the attack was her frustration with YouTube's content moderation policies.

site_title: Dual class shares: there should be minimum market cap of S$500m at time of listing
summary: The Singapore Exchange has issued a consultation paper on listing framework for Dual Class Shares (DCS) structures, proposing conditions to protect investor interests. Key safeguards include majority independent directors and a one-share-one-vote structure for board committees, as well as a sunset provision to prevent DCS holders from benefiting in a sale situation. To further protect ordinary shareholders, a minimum market capitalisation requirement of at least $500 million is suggested, ensuring DCS holders have a substantial "skin in the game."

site_title: Trump's perversion of leadership
summary: US President Donald Trump's leadership is characterized by incoherence, self-pity, and a lack of responsibility. He shifts blame, contradicts himself, and repels top talent, instead attracting sycophants who cater to his interests. Trump's administration is marred by petty graft and conflicts of interest, with the president himself exploiting his privilege to be small and petty. Unlike previous presidents, Trump fails to inspire or lead with dignity, leaving a question about whether he will ever demonstrate flashes of valour or moments of inspiration.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Blumont Group and Mencast Holdings have faced material uncertainties that cast doubt on their ability to remain as going concerns. Blumont's board believes it can raise sufficient funds to fund operations for 12 months, while Mencast's board has appointed a financial adviser to review its financial position and implement a debt restructuring plan. Mencast's independent auditor noted that certain banks require more information before deciding on the plan, unable to form an opinion on the appropriateness of the going concern assumption. Both companies' boards consider the assumption appropriate despite the uncertainty.

site_title: YouTube shooting shows how fake news spirals on social media
summary: A shooting at YouTube offices in California sparked a rapid spread of conspiracy theories on social media, with some claiming it was a "false flag" attack to discredit the US gun lobby. Wildly exaggerated accounts of the death toll and false images of the attacker circulated on Facebook and Twitter, with some pictures of well-known YouTubers. The incident highlights how fake news can quickly spiral on social media, often fueled by speculation and misinformation.

images.alt_text: Within minutes of the shooting at YouTube offices in California, social media was awash with conspiracy theories and images of the supposed "shooter" wearing a Muslim headscarf.

site_title: ST Telemedia, Ticon to build and operate data centres in Thailand
summary: ST Telemedia Global Data Centres (STT GDC) has partnered with Ticon, a Thai developer, to build and operate data centers in Thailand. The 51:49 joint venture aims to complete the Bangkok facility by 2020. The partnership expands STT GDC's global network and bolsters its presence in the region, following established bases in Asia. The move is seen as a response to the growing demand for data centers in Thailand, expected to double in size over the next three years.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust's share price fell 7% over the last month, underperforming the Straits Times Index. Despite concerns about its sponsor's exchangeable bond issuance, analysts believe the impact will be minimal and maintain their top pick in the hospitality sector. Soilbuild Business Space Reit's unit price is attractive, and analysts upgrade it from hold to buy, citing a decrease in cost of equity and fair value. Ezion Holdings is in talks with potential strategic shareholders to strengthen its balance sheet and expand its liftboat fleet after securing a 6-year refinancing proposal.

site_title: Oil down slightly; US inventory draw offsets trade war fears
summary: Oil prices settled slightly lower on Wednesday, as a surprise draw in US crude stockpiles offset concerns about a potential trade war between the US and China. Brent crude futures fell 10 cents to $68.02 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures dropped 14 cents to $63.37 a barrel. A draw in US inventories and rising refinery utilization rates contributed to the price decrease, but were partially offset by a turnaround in the US stock market. Opec's oil output also fell to an 11-month low, supporting prices.

site_title: 'Minding the gaps' in Asean: Protecting the present and financing the future
summary: Asean countries face significant financial gaps, including a "protection gap" in life and health insurance, a disaster risk finance gap, and a retirement income gap due to aging populations. To address these gaps, Asean needs to promote the growth of insurance and pension industries through government policies and industry innovation. This can be achieved by introducing policy nudges, increasing financial literacy, and leveraging new technologies. By doing so, Asean countries can mobilize billions of dollars in domestic savings to finance infrastructure, reducing their reliance on foreign borrowing and boosting economic growth.

images.alt_text: Monies spent on insurance or pension do not drag the economy but rather boost economic growth in a country.

site_title: STI down on tit-for-tat trade threats
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) plummeted 2.12% on April 4, 2018, amid escalating fears of a US-China trade war. China retaliated against US President Donald Trump's plans to impose tariffs on $50 billion worth of Chinese products, imposing additional tariffs on $50 billion worth of US imports. Analysts caution against bargain hunting, citing the risk of a trade war, but doubt its materialization, citing the potential for talks and a "lose-lose" situation.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: New rules for customer engagement in the insurance space
summary: The life insurance industry is facing a crisis in customer engagement due to a lack of trust and meaningful interactions. A recent study found that 41% of consumers in the Asia-Pacific region are uncomfortable sharing personal health data, and only 4 out of 8 categories of health information are shared. To address this, insurers are exploring innovative approaches such as dynamic underwriting, which uses wearable data to assess biological age and price premiums accordingly. This approach aims to promote active lifestyles and introduce lifespan protection offerings, providing a human-first approach to customer engagement and driving towards a shared goal of better health.

site_title: Spotify soars in US$26b stock debut
summary: Spotify made its highly anticipated stock debut, surpassing the market capitalization of other recent market entrants, including Twitter, with a value of over $26 billion. The company listed existing shares directly on the New York Stock Exchange, allowing its founders to maintain control. Despite closing 10% lower on its first day, Spotify's value still exceeded expectations. The company has 159 million monthly users, including 71 million paying subscribers, and faces rising competition from Apple, Amazon, and other tech giants.

site_title: Ad giant WPP investigating its CEO for 'personal misconduct'
summary: WPP, the world's largest advertising company, is investigating its CEO Martin Sorrell for 'personal misconduct' involving possible misuse of company assets. The board has hired a law firm to look into the allegations, which Sorrell denies. The probe comes at a challenging time for WPP, which has lost a third of its market value over the past year due to declining ad spending and increased competition. Sorrell's succession planning has also been questioned by some, with investors expressing concern over the company's future.

site_title: Going corporate by putting pedal to the mettle
summary: The OCBC Cycle Corporate Chase, a 42km road race, is set to take place on May 5-6 in Singapore. The event, which replaces the previous Corporate Speedway format, pits 30 corporate teams of four against each other. The winning team will receive a plaque and S$400, while the second- and third-placed teams will receive S$300 and S$200 respectively. Participants, including Henry Lim of SMRT Corporation and Jason Chaw of Changi Airport Group, welcome the changes, citing a more competitive and exciting format that encourages training and teamwork.

site_title: March share buybacks hit 30-month high
summary: Singapore-listed counters saw a 30-month high in share buybacks in March, with 26 companies purchasing 86 million shares at S$222 million, 65% higher than February. CapitaLand topped the list with 26.3 million shares repurchased for S$95 million, driven by a 30.3% year-on-year increase in profit after tax and minority interests. This surpasses the previous high in September 2015, with the majority of transactions involving six STI constituents.

site_title: China's home prices expected to rise in 2018 on falling inventories
summary: China's home prices are expected to rise 1% nationwide in 2018, with prices in tier-1 and tier-2 cities remaining stable or even decreasing, according to a Reuters poll. This growth is attributed to government policies promoting smaller cities and curbing speculation. Despite this, price gains are expected to be relatively muted due to rising borrowing costs and pressure on developers to accelerate project launches. The housing market has experienced a two-year boom, prompting authorities to implement measures to stem speculation and protect first-time buyers and upgraders.

site_title: India needs to keep focus on economy during election season
summary: India's government must maintain focus on economic growth amidst the upcoming state and national elections. Despite a recent economic recovery, the economy remains fragile and requires careful management. The government needs to avoid populist measures that could harm economic growth, as it has struggled to deliver on its promise of job creation and economic growth. India's growth is forecast to reach 7% in the 2018-19 fiscal year, with further improvements expected in the following years, but challenges such as a manufacturing sector expansion at its weakest pace in five months remain.

site_title: China's quick response surprises markets, takes dispute closer to trade war
summary: China swiftly retaliated against the US with a list of 25% tariffs on $50 billion of US goods, including soybeans, planes, and whiskey, just hours after the US released its list of targeted goods. The move, seen as a surprise, led to a sharp decline in global stock markets and commodities. The US list targeted 1,300 Chinese goods, mainly industrial and transport items, in response to China's intellectual property theft and forced technology transfer allegations. Beijing's response was seen as a game-changer in the trade dispute, with many consumer electronics products exempted, but traditional industrial goods and pharmaceuticals potentially affected.

site_title: Swiss Re says SoftBank stake unlikely to exceed 10%, talks at early stage
summary: Swiss Re is in talks with SoftBank to buy a stake in the reinsurer, with discussions at an early stage and unlikely to exceed 10%. SoftBank aims to broaden its investments, including its US$93 billion Vision Fund, which focuses on technology projects. Swiss Re's CEO Christian Mumenthaler expressed enthusiasm for the prospect of a deal, citing SoftBank's ties to China and access to 800 million customers. The investment is preliminary, and Swiss Re is exploring strategic cooperation with SoftBank.

site_title: SGX rewards good governance with selective Fast Track approvals
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX Regco) has introduced the SGX Fast Track programme, rewarding listed companies with good corporate governance practices and compliance track records with faster approval times for corporate actions. Companies selected for the programme will enjoy a faster turnaround time for submissions such as circulars, waiver requests, and share placement applications. The programme aims to motivate companies to pursue higher corporate governance standards and quality submissions, with assessment based on internal and external criteria.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: KPMG: Charisma Energy faces material uncertainty as going concern
summary: Charisma Energy, a Singapore-listed company, faces material uncertainty as a going concern due to a full-year net loss of US$31.36 million and a significant shortfall between current liabilities and assets. The company's auditors, KPMG, have highlighted three matters of material uncertainty, including defaulting on loan obligations and a shareholder loan. Charisma Energy plans to divest assets and generate positive cash flows from its renewable energy business to restructure loans and continue as a going concern. The company's stock price fell 25% on the news.

site_title: Rate hike fears pushing home buyers to fixed-rate loans
summary: Home buyers in Singapore are increasingly opting for fixed-rate loans despite higher costs, as interest rates are expected to rise. Banks such as DBS and United Overseas Bank (UOB) report a 10% growth in fixed-rate loan applications, with two-year fixed rates ranging from 1.85% to 1.95%. This trend is driven by concerns over rising interest rates and the desire for certainty. Experts predict further interest rate hikes, including a possible 2-3 hikes by the US Federal Reserve this year, which may lead to increased demand for fixed-rate loans.

images.alt_text: Home buyers are catching on that interest rates are rising and more are taking up fixed rate loans, say banks.

site_title: Sentiment, more than fundamentals, behind rout in port counters
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings (HPH) Trust saw its shares plummet to a record low due to a sentiment-driven sell-off in port counters, attributed to concerns over the US-China trade spat and reduced tariffs in China. Analysts argue that the impact on HPH's fundamentals is overstated, with limited exposure to the affected US-China trade. The trust's key profit generator, Yantian International Container Terminals, still expects single-digit growth in cargo volume and tariff rates this year. A recovery in the sector is expected, but investors are selling off their holdings amid geopolitical tensions.

site_title: Micron breaks ground on new flash memory fabrication plant in Singapore
summary: Micron Technology broke ground on a new flash memory fabrication plant in Singapore, a "multi-billion dollar investment" that will add 1,000 new jobs. The facility will be equipped over the next five years or more to meet future manufacturing requirements for its 3D NAND flash memory products. The new cleanroom space is expected to support Micron's growth in the region and strengthen its position as a leading semiconductor giant.

site_title: Datapulse told to appoint another independent reviewer
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has ordered Datapulse Technology to reappoint independent reviewers by April 11 to conduct an independent review of its internal controls and corporate governance practices. The review was initially required by February, but an extension was granted due to the company's failure to disclose a potential conflict of interest. Datapulse shares closed flat at S$0.38, amid the SGX's "serious view" of the omission, which could result in fines of up to S$50,000.

site_title: Ngiam family also exiting IPC takeover deal
summary: The Ngiam family, owners of IPC Corp, and Catalist-listed Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments (APSI) have mutually agreed to terminate the deal for APSI to acquire 11.9 million shares, or 13.95% of IPC, valued at 13.95% stake held collectively by IPC CEO Patrick Ngiam and other executive directors.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Sanctions risk gives some investors pause in Myanmar
summary: Foreign investors in Myanmar are delaying final approval of projects due to the risk of broader Western sanctions over the Rohingya refugee crisis, according to a senior International Monetary Fund (IMF) official. The IMF's mission chief to Myanmar, Shanaka Jay Peiris, noted that initial data indicates foreign investment approvals are slowing down, with FDI project amounts approved by the government for the first 10 months of fiscal 2017/18 showing a marked slowdown since September 2017. Despite this, the IMF expects economic growth to pick up to an estimated 7-7.5% in the coming years.

site_title: Hyperloop race hots up as startup takes on Elon Musk
summary: A Toronto-based startup, TransPod, is competing in the hyperloop technology race with Elon Musk's version. TransPod aims to attract $50 million for its half-size prototype, designed to transport passengers at over 1,000 kph. The company claims its technology is "better" and cheaper, using magnetic propulsion and electrified tracks, and predicts it will disrupt the transport sector and outlast competitors. TransPod plans to build a full-size model by 2021, with a test track in central France.

site_title: Asia, Europe markets recoil as China ups tariff ante
summary: China announced 25% tariffs on 106 US products, in addition to 128 previously announced, sparking a global market downturn. Asia's Straits Times Index fell 2.12% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng dropped 2.19%, while Europe's key indices also declined. The Dow Jones futures tumbled, and commodities like WTI crude fell, while gold rose. Analysts warn of a trade war, but note China's planned targets are "quite reserved" and may leave room for negotiations.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Facebook takes down accounts tied to Russian 'troll factory'
summary: Facebook has removed over 270 accounts and pages linked to Russia's Internet Research Agency (IRA), also known as the "troll factory," due to the agency's past fraud. The accounts were mainly in Russian and targeted users in Russia and neighboring countries. Facebook took down the accounts without finding any violating content, as the IRA's past actions were deemed deceptive. The move comes after a months-long investigation by Facebook's security team, led by Alex Stamos, and coincides with recent indictments of 13 Russians associated with the IRA.

site_title: SGX hires Mark Leahy to head electronic bond trading platform
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has hired Mark Leahy as head of fixed income, tasked with reviving the underperforming SGX Bond Pro electronic bond trading platform. Leahy, a 27-year fixed income veteran, will oversee bond listings, institutional participation, and strategy, aiming to drive growth and exceed the record bond listings volume of 2017.
